HEADLINE: A New Concept in Decorating Outlets

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

DATELINE: LARCHMONT

 BODY:
As damaging as the recession has been to many businesses, at least one family-owned company, the Fabric Design Center here, has managed to go against the tide by expanding rather than contracting. Last week, in addition to its retail fabric store opened in 1990, the center opened a second outlet across the street: a showroom for both interior designers and retail customers.
Ernest A. Leckart, who started the company with his wife, Priscilla, says it is the two-tier system of pricing -- wholesale for the bona fide interior decorator and retail for the consumer -- that has helped him increase his customer base.
 
Seeking a Broad Customer Base
 "It's a new concept in marketing in the county, stores selling home furnishings at both wholesale and retail," Mr. Leckart said. "What I had in mind was to clone the Design and Decoration Building on Third Avenue at 58th Street in Manhattan, but open it to a broader customer base. While the showrooms in the D&D Building offer designer fabrics, wallpapers, furniture, rugs and accessories, they are restricted to the trade, or decorators, only. I thought a shop that offered one-stop wholesale and retail shopping for decorators and savvy customers would go over in Westchester." 
 Mr. Leckart, who has been in the drapery and fabric business for 32 years, formerly owned three drapery stores in the Bronx and manufactured draperies for interior designers. Most recently, he and his factory did all the custom work for three Calico Corners fabric stores in Westchester.
 
'The Timing Was Pretty Bad'
 "I sold Calico Corners on the idea of offering their customers more than fabric," Mr. Leckart said. "I also taught their sales staff how to advise customers on draperies and window treatments, and I worked with Calico Corners customers for 15 years doing all the custom work at our factory in Mount Vernon."
At the time Mr. Leckart decided to go into business for himself, the recession was full blown.
"The timing was pretty bad," he recalled. "Our sales were down, and so was disposable income. Stores were standing empty, yet nobody was dropping rents. It was also hard to open lines of credit for the fabric houses. Calico Corners put in restraints, but I was persistent and determined. And finally, after I gave my personal guarantee to several fabric companies, I was able to open the store with the kind of designer fabrics I wanted to carry."
By the end of the first year, Mr. Leckart said, the business was comfortably in the black.
"We had a couple of very positive things going for us: a built-in sales staff, eight experienced people I trained at Calico Corners came with me. We also had quality control, which is very important. We supplied the fabric for customers and had the labor done in our own factory. What's most important is that people in the area are very involved with their homes and that gave us a ready market. We ran a couple of free workshops and gradually, through word of mouth, we got customers."
 
Wallpaper Selection Expanding
 Yearly sales at the Fabric Design Center climbed to $1.3 million last year, he added. "Growth is steady, although it's slower because of the recession. But lately, the recession may be working in our favor because many families are staying put. Instead of moving, they're refurbishing their homes, which is good for us."
The shop displays 1,000 bolts of fabric for immediate purchase, and racks in a back room offer 12,000 samples for orders, including those from such fabric houses as Robert Allen, Ralph Lauren, Duralee, Waverly and Greeff. Draperies and pillows made in the Design Center's workrooms are on display to give customers an idea of how the fabrics will look when made up. Some wallpaper is also available for purchase.
"We're going to expand our wallpaper line with the higher-grade papers our customers want," Mr. Leckart said. "Our retail customers have sophisticated tastes and a sense of style. They like to do their own decorating, and those are the customers we are catering to, those who never had access to the D&D Building. Our retail prices are still 50 or 60 percent off suggested retail prices."
 
Bigger Discounts to Designers
 For the 500 or so interior designers who are registered with the shop, discounts are deeper.
"We give decorators the same wholesale price they get elsewhere," Mr. Leckart said, "but only those who qualify, which means they have to have a resale number and a bona fide business."
Mrs. Leckart is in charge of the production side of the business in the company's Mount Vernon factory.
"The factory is an essential part of the business," she said. "Customers want more than fabric; they want the finished product. And they want the work to be done properly."
Finding skilled people to do the work, however, is an ongoing problem, she added. "People don't want to work in factories today," she said. "But because we are located in a neighborhood with a large Hispanic population, we manage to get the employees we need."
 
In-Home Service Offered
 Another 15 employees work in Larchmont, including three in-house designers who, Mrs. Leckart said, will make house calls and for a small fee will measure walls and floors, make suggestions and help customers select home furnishings.
"In our new showroom, we carry an upholstered furniture line from Kravet, woven rugs, unusual art objects, customized lamps and accessories," Mrs. Leckart said. "This makes it possible for customers to redo an entire house without leaving Westchester."
 
A Savings of Time and Money
 The showroom makes it easier for decorators, too, Mr. Leckart said. "The recession has changed the industry," he explained. "Instead of getting commissions to do entire houses, decorators are getting smaller assignments -- one room, or maybe two rooms at a time. If they don't have to travel into New York City, it's so much better in savings of time and money."
The Leckarts, who met as accounting students at Baruch College in Manhattan, live in Harrison with their sons, Adam, 22, and Gregory, 27, who both work in the family business.
When asked what was difficult about being in business with spouse and children, the Leckarts hesitated before replying.
Mrs. Leckart said, "You take your work home with you." Mr. Leckart added, "But there's nothing we'd rather talk about."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ernest A. Leckart and his wife, Priscilla, owners of Fabric Design Center in Larchmont. (Alan Zale for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: April 15 Alert: More Taxpayers Owe the State

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
WHEN the first three state income tax returns arrived at the state Department of Revenue Services in January, A. J. Janschewitz got an inkling of what kind of year 1992 was for taxpayers: each return had a check attached.
"More people are going to have to pay this year than paid last year," said Mr. Janschewitz, the spokesman for the department. "I wouldn't be surprised if 80 to 90 percent of the returns we receive owe us money." Last year, more than half the people who filed returns were due refunds. 
 "We're going to have a lot of unhappy campers come April 15," Mr. Janschewitz said.
The problem is the changes made to the state's withholding tables in January 1992. Legislators, facing difficult re-election contests because of the newly passed state income tax, lobbied the Governor and the department to reduce withholding. While the withholding tables approved at that time allowed people to hold onto more of their paycheck, it will now mean an unpleasant surprise come April 15 for most of the 1.4 million people filing returns. "It's a question of 'pay us now or pay us later,' and the choice that was made was to pay later," Mr. Janschewitz said. "It's later."
Tax preparers said the underwithholding has resulted from a variety of factors, and has been particularly severe in some cases. For instance, where two people in a family work, the second income can be taxed at the top rate of 4.5 percent from the first dollar the person earns, since the state income tax is based on combined income.
"I've seen a lot of couples where they missed the boat on withholding by quite a bit because of that second income," said John Fiorito, a tax preparer in Stamford.
"I think it's going to take another year before people become aware of how much they should be withholding," Mr. Fiorito said. "People just have to get used to the system."
A tax preparer in New Haven, Joseph J. Riccio, said that single people were particularly hard hit. "I've had some divorced people coming in, they've had $37 or $38 a week taken out of their checks, and now I have to tell them they owe another $600, and they're stunned," he said.
Mr. Riccio said that, on the average, single people owed $600. "There's very few single people getting out of here without writing a check to the state," he said. In another case that illustrated a common scenario, Mr. Riccio said that a laborer came in, and he had had the correct amount withheld from his paycheck. But his wife had taken a part-time job during the year, at minimum wage. "She didn't realize that every dollar she made was like overtime on her husband's check," Mr. Riccio said. She filled out the withholding tables the way she thought she should, but she and her husband now owe $1,200 in tax.
Mr. Riccio said he had received two stacks of envelopes from the tax department, one for people who owe money with their return, another for people getting a refund. He said he now has most of the refund forms left, but it was getting harder to find the payment envelopes. "It's going to leave a bad taste in everybody's mouth," Mr. Riccio said. "Everybody's paying."
Mr. Janschewitz said that for a lot of people, this season would bring a double dose of bad news. More than 22,000 letters have recently gone out to people who filed a Federal income tax return last year, but did not file a Connecticut return. Those people are being assessed a $50 penalty -- even if they did not owe any money.
"An individual can apply for a waiver of that penalty, and generally speaking, the department will waive the penalty for someone who is not trying to sneak something by us," Mr. Janschewitz said. "If it was an honest mistake, generally speaking, we'll give people a break the first time."
Mr. Janschewitz said the timing of the letters warning people they have to file a 1991 return, so close to the time the 1992 tax returns are due, is coincidental.
 
All Must File
 "We got the computer tape from the I.R.S. and ran the program to find people who did not file Connecticut returns," said Mr. Janschewitz, who explained that all wage earners must file a return, even those who do not owe any money, to reconcile that the amount they had withheld was correct.
Mr. Janschewitz said the crackdown on 1991 scofflaws is taking up staff time, even though the letters were sent out by the department's audit division, while new returns are handled by the operations division.
"While it is -- no pun intended -- taxing our resources, there really is no time that's better than any other time during the year," Mr. Janschewitz said. To hold off, penalties would continue to accrue, he said, which is not fair to taxpayers.
Mr. Janschewitz said the department was also cracking down in other areas as well. For instance, one recent effort involved sending agents to shows, flea markets, fairs and other events to determine if vendors were collecting sales tax.
In addition, Mr. Janschewitz said, the department is planning a major crackdown on violations to the minimum cigarette-pricing law. State law prohibits retailers from selling cigarettes below their cost, as a come-on to customers.
"We expect, over the next six weeks to two months, to take fairly aggressive steps against retailers who are breaking that law, up to and including arrest," Mr. Janschewitz said.
As for personal taxes, the department is undertaking a cooperative effort with municipalities to identify Connecticut residents who register their cars out of state, thus robbing the state of the sales tax on the car, and their towns of the property tax.
"We're going out looking for the tax cheats who have the Florida or New Hampshire plates," Mr. Janschewitz said. "Those are the two biggies, because neither of those states tax motor vehicles as personal property."
 
6 Percent 'Use Tax' Ignored
 Another area of concern is the mail-order business. People who buy things through the mail are supposed to report those purchases to the state and pay a 6 percent "use tax," in lieu of the sales tax charged by stores. Various estimates put the amount of lost state revenue from mail-order purchases at between $15 million and $60 million a year, Mr. Janschewitz said.
"Whatever the number, it's clear we are losing a substantial amount of revenue to people who buy from out-of-state mail-order houses and believe those purchases are tax-free," Mr. Janschewitz said.
This year's income tax forms have a new spot for the use tax on out-of-state purchases, Mr. Janschewitz said, and the state is negotiating to share information with other states to gain access to information on mail-order retailers.
"Eventually, we're going to find the records, and there's no statute of limitations on failure to file a tax report," Mr. Janschewitz said. "Theoretically, we could look back to 1947, when the use tax was enacted."
This year, though, it seems as though everyone is paying a larger share, particularly when it comes to the state income tax. Mr. Janschewitz said the changes to the withholding tables eliminated the "cushion" that provided more than half the filers with a refund last year.
"Overwithholding is standard policy in most tax systems," Mr. Janschewitz said. "With that cushion gone, it means most people will owe taxes."
Without substantial interest income or a second job, chances are the amount owed will be small. "But the psychology of writing out a $5 check is not significantly different from writing out a $50 check," he noted. "They're paying, and they're going to be upset."
 
Running 10 Percent Behind
 Mr. Janschewitz said returns were running at least 10 percent behind last year, probably because so many people owed money, and people who owed typically waited until the April 15 deadline to pay.
Tax preparers agreed with Mr. Janschewitz's assessment of taxpayer psychology, and said that as a result the tax department would be advised to have extra mail handlers on duty for a couple of days after April 15.
"The only way people are getting a refund is if they didn't claim all their dependents," said Harold H. White, a tax preparer in Bridgeport. Most of his clients are paying anywhere from $50 to $800 in taxes, on top of what they withheld last year, he said.
"Whatever happens on the state income tax, people are unhappy with it," Mr. White said. "Even if they get $1,000 back, no one likes it. There's still a lot of anger over this tax. And the way things are this year it's going to be worse."
Diane Andrews, a tax preparer in Higganum, said at least 45 percent of her clients owed taxes, a much higher percentage than usual, despite her advice on how to set up their withholding schedules. Some of her clients, though, either did not follow her advice, or the companies they work for did not withhold properly.
"If people were doing the calculations themselves, they didn't withhold as much as they should," Ms. Andrews said. "They thought what they were doing was right. They read the forms carefully, and filled out their withholding forms properly, and they still owe money."
Not all of the problems, however, were with the tax department, the tax specialists say. Howard J. Nitkin of Waterbury said the problems with the state's withholding tables was further complicated by employers who withheld incorrect amounts.
"A lot of employers did not know how to load the state withholding tables into their computer programs, and that means they've been withholding the wrong amount all year long," Mr. Nitkin said.
 
Tax on Jobless Benefits
 Another problem is the confusing regulations governing who pays state income tax. The state does not withhold income tax on unemployment compensation payments, for instance, but it will tax those benefits at year's end.
That means a person receiving $4,000 in jobless benefits, and had another $4,000 in dividend and interest income, will owe $720 more in taxes than was withheld, or almost $1,000 in tax, penalties and interest by April 15, Mr. Nitkin said. Penalties and interest are automatically imposed when a taxpayer has withheld less than 90 percent of his or her total tax bill, or less than the tax they paid the previous year.
Few tax preparers were forgiving of the state's Department of Revenue Services and the companies that fouled up on withholding allowances. But there were exceptions.
"This is our first full year -- we're going to have to make adjustments," said Robert E. Stern, who operates a Milford tax preparation service. Last year, the first of the state income tax, residents were taxed for earining over only four months. Mr. Stern said he believed the changes to the withholding tables last year were appropriate.
"If you're going to get the credit at the end of the year you ought to have that money in your paycheck all year long," he maintained. "I think that's only fair.
"But that means you have to be very careful figuring our your total income for the year, and add to your withholding if necessary."

HEADLINE: Holding On and Letting Go

BYLINE: By Helen Epstein; Helen Epstein, the author of "Children of the Holocaust," is writing a biography of Joseph Papp.

 BODY:

ANNA
A Daughter's Life.
By William Loizeaux.
213 pp. New York: Arcade Publishing. $19.95. 
 MANY years ago, following the first death in my family, a friend came to see me. How could he prepare? he asked. There was no way, I said. But had William Loizeaux's powerful and minutely detailed journal been written then, I would have gone out and bought it for him.
Mr. Loizeaux wrote "Anna: A Daughter's Life" as a memorial to his daughter, who died in 1989 at the age of 5 1/2 months. Citing "Walden," he writes that Anna took him to the equivalent of Thoreau's woods, "to a place we would have done anything to avoid, a place where we never would have gone on our own, where we had to live deliberately, day to day, and face the more essential facts of our lives. Because of Anna, I have come to know better what is mean, what is random, devastating, and what, by force of friendship and love, is sublime."
Moving day by day, Mr. Loizeaux, who teaches writing at the Writers' Center in Bethesda, Md., tells two stories: the first, of Anna's conception, birth, brief life and death; the second, of the year of mourning that followed. Neither narrative, informed as it is by medical technology, feminism and multiculturalism, could have been written by anyone but a late-20th-century American father.
William and Beth Loizeaux began their parental lives with basal body thermometers, semen analyses and awkward moments: "At least once while we were camping with Beth's parents in the Adirondacks, right there in the very midst of what might have become Anna, I remember a cheery camper's call from outside our tent. It was Beth's mom, Betsy, and a whiff of bacon: 'Yoo-hoo. Time for breakfast!' "
Finally, Anna was conceived. There was a pregnancy monitored by sonograms, a Caesarean birth and then the news: Anna had been born with "a rare association of physical problems." "Though she looked perfect on the outside," her father writes, "things were scrambled within." Anna had an imperforate anus; her throat ended in a blind pouch; her esophagus led to her lungs; her bladder, vagina and rectum came together in a common chamber, and she had an association of heart defects. One hour after Anna's birth, as her mother kept asking, "Where is she?" her baby was undergoing the first of several surgeries in Washington's Georgetown Hospital.
Mr. Loizeaux conveys the events and feelings of the following months in a clear, elastic prose that accommodates his daughter's development, as well as the complexities of further medical procedures for a congenital heart condition and the emotional roller coaster of fury, hope, pain, confusion, helplessness and love that he and his wife rode. "Anna was 'doing very well,' " he writes, thinking back to a day one month before her death. "I know that in my exuberance I was less cautious and reasonable than Beth. I knew the danger, yet I thought that in the end Anna could do just about anything; that given what she had been through and how she had fought, survived and flourished -- I thought that nothing in the world could stop her. In fact, I actually had it in mind to take her up to a ball game in Baltimore." As he and his wife start a new year determined to conceive a second child, he writes: "There may be something fearful, too, in this passing from one year to another, from a year in which Anna was born, lived and died, into a year and decade in which she never will physically exist. . . . Never before have I felt the present so stretched between the past and the future, my mind looking forward and back, and the space between seeming to widen."
This is honest writing that chooses to risk pathos and embarrassment rather than rewrite reality, that allows for humor, and that tracks the process of becoming a parent and the process of bereavement -- particularly the struggle between holding on and letting go of the deceased -- with extraordinary precision.
If I have one caveat, it is that the author chose not to locate his personal story in the context of current bioethical debate. Anna was one of thousands of newborn babies who would probably have died at birth a decade ago, but whose care is now raising multiple questions for parents as well as physicians, politicians, lawyers, economists and ethicists. Did anyone raise these questions with William and Beth Loizeaux? How did they respond? Did they concur? Was religion a factor? Was the Roman Catholic hospital in which Anna was born committed to saving an infant's life, no matter what? Would they have had a different experience in another hospital? Was it life on any terms that Anna's parents wanted for their daughter, or only a certain kind of life? I would have liked to know.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

LENGTH: 2035 words

HEADLINE: The New Tatterdemalions

BYLINE: By JILL ROBINSON

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
It's late winter in Soho. On Wardour Street, a smart, young film producer wears six-inch platforms by Vivienne Westwood, a mink-cuffed dress unsnapped over shorts and leggings, a Jimi Hendrix T-shirt and a toque from the 1940's. She towers over her aristocratic companion in his stretched-out black turtleneck, Oxfam charity vest and gray tweed pleated pants patched inside the thighs with glen plaid. But somehow it all works: perhaps it's the old maroon cravat tied like a noose at his neck that does it.
He heads across town and picks up a bouquet of miniature black irises from the flower cart at Conran's, then meets his wife in Sloane Ranger territory, at Joe's Cafe, part of Joseph Ettedgui's shopping and eating empire. She's wearing a flowing rayon dress -- very Kansas afternoon -- and bobby socks, brown penny loafers and a Pendleton jacket, her blond hair sprigging out around one of those rumpled-fabric elastics designed to hold ponytails when they're not worn around the wrist. 
 Joseph (who is known only as Joseph and never as Mr. Ettedgui) smiles at them as he wanders through his cafe in a rumpled linen suit, looking like a character out of "Casablanca." He greets Angie Rawlinson, a pale, young short-story writer, in her turtleneck leotard and 40's patio skirt. She has tied an Amanda Wakeley organza blouse around her midriff -- not what the designer had in mind, but, as Miss Rawlinson explains, "The thing is to wear everything you really like and that way you're never alone."
The young English are handling decline and deprivation with a kind of grim romance: they're a road company of "Midsummer Night's Dream" wraiths tumbling down into city life from the heath. They're like the tattered fellows Ben Jonson called "tatterdemalions;" like those "figures with their enthusiast complexion" cited by Carlyle; or the "tatterdemalion scraps and fragments of political discontent" cited in The Spectator in 1893. Through the decades, they have never been as bad off as they seemed. More often than not these grown-up urchins are wearing old family clothes (even someone else's family's), though in every outfit there is something that costs the rent.
The more prosperous of the latter-day-tatterdemalion shop at Browns, the store that Joan Burstein runs with her infallible eye, like the Hollywood moguls ran the studios in the old days. She's selective and astute. If you're in Browns, you've arrived; it's like having your paintings hung in the Art Institute of Chicago. She carries John Galliano, Georgina Godley (who did stretch and hoops before anyone else) and Scott Crolla. Behind Liberty and off Carnaby Street, along Newburgh and Marshall streets, you'll see even more. The best designers are not necessarily brand-new or mass-market properties. Like writers, they have their own inimitable voices and are part of Britain's treasure.
"They're stimulating," Mrs. Burstein said, "too artistic to be harnessed. Of course, the important thing is not to take it too seriously. The best designers put the value of life first."
 
The Urchins' Faerie Queen
 "Once when I was doing a lecture at the Smithsonian I heard Evangeline Bruce talking about my mother, saying what a great influence she'd been," the designer Zandra Rhodes says. "You know she was a fitter for Worth in Paris, and then a lecturer at the Medway College of Art in London. My mother was one of those people who gave additional quality to life -- and she taught me to believe in myself."
Miss Rhodes, daughter of Beatrice Twigg, materializes into her round persimmon dining room in Notting Hill, her pomegranate red hair pulled up into a fiery fountain. Miss Rhodes represents the hippie elite; she's the urchins' faerie queen. She's wearing printed tights and turquoise knit leggings stuffed into orange sneakers with rainbow shoelaces, a belted black and silver sweater with a necklace of bronze leaves, an Andrew Logan emerald-eye ruby devil's mask on one shoulder, his mirrored rose on the other and, hanging between her breasts, his mirrored giraffe penholders.
Miss Rhodes's legendary chiffon gowns are being reprised around the world, turning heads at the season's dances with platform sandals -- doing Deep House, Funk hiphops, Mirage and Rave along with every bare midriff and sarong in town.
"I work best without pressure, trying this, moving along," she says. She cups each sentence with her hands, pausing as if she's catching it in the light. Underneath the costume, her presence is stable, imperative and compelling. "If you're a true original, you can't compromise. You have to stand alone until it's your turn again."
She sits at her round table for 10, circled by candles stuck into sand-filled ceramic sundae dishes, glowing under the chandelier with the mirrored Z's swinging from a silvery wreath. Everything is ruched in gold lame. And it looks wonderful because it never seems brand new -- that's her secret; that's England's secret. Picked up yesterday, by tomorrow it's seasoned as if it has been in the family forever, even if the family is divorced and long gone.
 
Another Mother's Influence
 Rifat Ozbek is wearing a Turkish protective prayer engraved on a dark silver amulet his mother gave him. She saw his last show before she died.
"My mother dressed in wonderful Chanel little black dresses," he says, "so I love clothes that are beautifully made." Mr. Ozbek has a neat 1949 good-boy haircut and wide, eager, dark Tyrone Power eyes. He says he feels free as an artist in London.
"The design instinct starts with the kids here," he says. Mr. Ozbek watches them at night in clubs like the Ministry of Sound, where, he says, "they've been wandering around in 70's gear for two years."
His 1992 British Designer of the Year Award, the bronze Mercury, acts as a doorstop to his office at Haunch of Venison Yard, Mayfair. On the wall hangs a painting with a giant eye done by a 16-year-old, Jerry Di Bastiano. On the window ledge circling the room, there are spools of silk threads, a tumbler jammed with white quills, an emerald globe, an orange plume with pink flowers, a glorious feathered helmet and, like a giant staring through a window, a poster-size blowup of a photo of the designer, with long hair, beads and silver earrings.
Mr. Ozbek's hands are as mobile as the clothes he creates. His fingers are as fluid as streams, not thin but like stretched-out child hands, restless, as if what he really wants is to be working. He laughs uneasily after each comment, shifting around in his chair, longing not to talk anymore. "Yes," he says, "I hate talking, although sometimes with four or five people I know well I can be an extrovert. Some of my best ideas come when friends are around."
Designers, like writers, become blocked, it turns out. Mr. Ozbek says he has learned not to be frightened by the blocks. "Sometimes they produce wonders -- or sometimes a mistake -- but that's acceptable; these are, after all, only characters in the repertory." To be a designer, he says, "all you should be expected to do is one perfect dress a year."
He strides out of his office to see a buyer in his showroom, his shirttails flying, his long legs in a busy 10-year-old's lope. He's wearing jeans, huge white cotton socks, snub-nosed black dress shoes -- "policeman's shoes," he says. Three sides of this room are lined with racks of angled sarong skirts, capri pants, tail coats edged in heavy black lace, swashbuckling coats, shorts with crossed daggers on the back pockets. The season's star is the asymmetrical double-breasted cream silk jacket spinning down around a long, pleated skirt.
"Everyone in London is wearing that skirt," the buyer announces. She is thrilled by jackets with bronze coins sloping like birch leaves over snowy shoulders, by the fetching black sheer sleeves (just the sleeves!) like chiffon lamb-chop muffs. "They'll summer everywhere," she says, "with jeans and a bra." And just as likely they'll be worn with a stretch sequin bodice and lilac boxer shorts under an old sheer negligee.
"Yes," she declares, "sheer is causing an absolute storm."
 
One Who Doesn't Show
 The nouvelle tatterdemalions sport the to-the-recession-born, abandoned country-house look. Here in England, after the press has torn your family to shreds, you're left in only your John Pearse battered tweeds dreaming of how wonderful it once was.
Mr. Pearse's mother was a milliner; he started as an apprentice in Savile Row. While Mr. Ozbek shows in Milan and Miss Rhodes in New York, Mr. Pearse doesn't show anywhere. He has been tailoring his robust three-piece suits for Jack Nicholson, Angelica Huston, Mick Jagger and Jerry Hall from his relaxed shop in Soho since the days of the 60's dandies.
On Jan. 1, 1990, Mr. Pearse greeted all his customers with a letter that said: "Of all the events that happened in the 80's, none was more poignant than when the Berlin wall was knocked down. Hence we are having a sale."
Now, he has a customer who's concerned because Mr. Pearse is about to go off on his holiday to Bali (he always returns with printed fabrics). "Could you fast-forward the cords?" the customer pleads. "You don't have to measure my waist; it's 32 inches."
Mr. Pearse, who in the motorcycle movie version of his life would be played by Dennis Hopper, promises the pants will be ready before he goes and says, "Your waist hasn't been 32 inches since you were in jail."
The customer turns away and regards himself balefully in a huge mirror. "I have a reservation about the cords anyway," he says. "I read an article recently that said I looked like an out-of-work bookie. But sod it," he shrugs, "they'll do for hanging around with the Notting Hill crowd."
He leaves, taking the long way round to Villandry, the new French deli on Marylebone High Street. Everyone you'd like to know eats Saturday lunch here, like the actor Steven Hartley, who is wearing Mr. Pearse's heavy, red plaid Shetland jacket (lined with a purple and red-flowered print like the ones he is getting more of in Bali) with old gardening shoes and a Gerry Mulligan T-shirt. Running in to join Mr. Hartley is his young actress wife, Sophie Heyman, who's picking up things from the deli for a Sunday brunch. Her blond hair tied in twine, she is wearing an ancient Martha Graham dance skirt, striped tights and lumpy brown Caterpillars, the boots called "Cats." Her own vintage Pearse jacket swings open over her pale pink camisole from Ghost, Tanya Sarne's company.
Miss Heyman says she loves the lissome medieval jerkins, tunics and gowns designed by Ms. Sarne in her chapel turned factory in Ladbroke Grove. There, you can sit on a pew off to one side eating one of the best lunches in town. And there you'll often find Ms. Sarne's buddy, Lynne Franks, London's superstar fashion and music promoter.
"There's an insider humor about fashion in London," Miss Franks says. "It's a mix of various tribal looks. Chic New Yorkers have an inherent sense of style, but chic Londoners have an inherent sense of originality. There's an inverted pride in looking messy, and manners give you freedom -- people won't stare at you here."
"Not at all," says Bella Freud, a young designer. "The English don't avoid staring because they're polite but because they're embarrassed. English people don't want to be seen trying. Right from the start you're discouraged from going beyond your place. You have to be oblivious to self-consciousness if you are going to get somewhere."
Miss Freud says she is inspired by Colette's Claudine, but her trim composed outfits are often sabotaged and wind up beyond Notting Hill at Whiteleys' movie emporium.
The other night there, a young woman was checking out the designer jelly beans in a pale and polished Bella Freud jacket worn with trailing bell-bottoms and an Apache scarf. Her buddy wore a purple suede coat worn out at both elbows, a detail like the one described in Blackwell's magazine, in 1887, as "a kind of defiant Tatterdemalionism that the Colonel liked to hug." His old opera hat pierced with quills to look like an Ozbek design, he is exactly the kind of tatterdemalion the English designers love to dress.

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
Democrat Days In Silicon Valley

BYLINE: By Michael S. Malone; Michael S. Malone writes frequently about Silicon Valley from Los Altos, Calif.

DATELINE: LOS ALTOS, Calif.

 BODY:
WHEN President Clinton sat down for dinner with Silicon Valley chief executives recently at the California Cafe in Los Gatos, sitting on one side of him was John Sculley, chairman of Apple Computer.
That wasn't surprising. But on the other side of the President sat Regis McKenna, head of a locally based marketing firm. Although Mr. McKenna is a well-known figure in tech circles, his placement next to the new President was notable. So was the seating of David J. Barram, Apple's vice president of worldwide affairs and public policies, next to Vice President Gore at a nearby table. 
 For these two executives, as well as for a handful of the two dozen others in this largely Republican crowd, this dinner was a vindication. For years, these men and women had faced resentment and disapproval for their Democratic views. Mr. McKenna recalled that he was once warned "by a well-known company that I should cool it on my politics because it would really hurt me in business."
Now, with a young President wooing the Brahmins of Silicon Valley, these loyal Democrats enjoyed having old political opponents calling to beg for an invitation to dinner.
"I'm sure Regis and Dave don't want to talk about it," said Gloria Rose Ott, an investment banker who over the years has brought Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen; Senator Bob Kerry, Democrat of Nebraska, and Mr. Gore, among others, to town for fund raisers. "But my business is mostly international, so I can," said Ms. Ott, a lifelong Democrat. "Yeah, sure, it felt a little weird having all those Johnny-come-latelies there. But it's better to have people come to the table late than not at all."
The genesis of the Clinton visit dates back more than 15 years to a campaign for city council in the Silicon Valley city of Sunnyvale. A local progressive ticket, the Orchards, included Mr. McKenna's wife, Dianne McKenna, and Mr. Barram, both 33 years old and close friends. Mrs. McKenna won and is now a county supervisor.
Mr. Barram lost and returned to the computer industry, moving from Hewlett-Packard to the presidency of Silicon Graphics and then to Apple. His interest in politics never waned. From local planning commissions to state educational panels, Mr. Barram pursued his passion, and, with each Democratic Presidential candidate beginning with Jimmie Carter, he mailed off suggested campaign policy statements on high technology. "I never got a reply," he said.
But slowly, especially after electronics became America's largest manufacturing employer, Washington began to take notice of Silicon Valley. In 1987, while working with Mr. Sculley at the National Center on Education and the Economy, Mr. Barram met Hillary Rodham Clinton and through her the future President. So when Governor Clinton announced his candidacy, Mr. Barram dusted off the position paper he'd written for Michael Dukakis and gave it to Mrs. Clinton.
This time a candidate listened. At a breakfast meeting in San Jose, Mr. Clinton asked Mr. Barram for help in contacting the Silicon Valley leadership. Mr. Barram arranged a Saturday morning gathering. He invited 100 chief executive officers and got 40.
"My argument was that we complain in this valley that we don't get to participate in government -- and that here was a chance to do just that," he said.
Many of the attendees at this and subsequent meetings were long-time Republicans who came because they knew Mr. Barram. Among them were James G. Treybig, president and chief executive of Tandem Computer; E.R. McCracken, president and chief executive of Silicon Graphics; John A. Young, a director of Hewlett Packard, and Mr. Sculley.
Chuck Comiso, president of Link Technologies, a computer terminal maker, was a registered Democrat who had last voted for his party's Presidential candidate in 1960. But he was impressed with Mr. Clinton. "The part that really impressed me was that he was really a different kind of politician," he said. "He was so alert, in touch and technologically literate. He listened to us."
In May 1992, Mr. Barram took a leave of absence from Apple to focus on the campaign. He organized a gathering of chief executives at a hotel a few blocks from Apple, and they helped draft the candidate's technology policy. This same group gave a critical lift to the Clinton campaign soon thereafter when they walked out on stage before television cameras and announced their support.
It was not surprising, then, that when President Clinton returned to Silicon Valley in late February, it was Mr. Barram who organized the dinner -- and got the ride in Air Force One. Nor that Mr. McKenna, Ms. Ott and the loyal Clinton/Republican chief executives got their invitations. The only ones missing were the most unabashedly conservative chief executives.
Mr. McKenna says he was not surprised by the Valley's strong approval of Mr. Clinton, a 125,000-vote margin. "This valley was never as G.O.P. as it was made out to be," he said. "Instead, it's always focused on issues. With Clinton, we finally saw a candidate that combined a social conscience with a business perspective," he continued, adding, "I am excited about seeing the potential for Silicon Valley to help create policy changes."
Ms. Ott agrees. "We need to keep the process going," she said, to influence the White House's agenda.
Mr. Barram said: "People around here are politically in the middle. They support Clinton, but if they see him slipping off into liberalism, they could move right back to the Republican Party."
But for now, those concerns are minor compared with the afterglow of the triumphant dinner at the California Cafe. For Silicon Valley Democrats, the years in the wilderness are over.

HEADLINE: The Twin Towers: The Suspect;
Bomb Suspect's Path to Piety and Elusive Dreams

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ZARQA, Jordan, March 7

 BODY:
In cramped, unheated rooms on the outskirts of Amman, the relatives of Mohammed A. Salameh, the man charged in the bombing of the World Trade Center, gathered today and pondered the magnitude of the crime and the infamy that has befallen their name.
"He went to the United States to get a job and make money," said Aysha Salameh, his mother, as she keened to and fro in a red vinyl chair and clutched a damp tissue. "He went to make something of himself, to speak English, to study, to have a future. And now they say that he did all this, that he did this bomb. No, no, no . . . " 
 The woman, besieged by neighbors and relatives who came to the home on a narrow dirt lane to express their support, stopped to gain her composure. As she pulled herself together all that was heard in the small room, crowded with men of the Salameh clan, was the ticking of a wall clock and the soft clink of the prayer beads that slowly circulated between the men's calloused fingers.
 
Refugee in Infancy
 "He was a gentle man," said a cousin, Ali Mohammed Salameh. "He would not commit such an act. He was not a person of violence."
Mohammed Salameh was arrested on Thursday and charged with helping in the attack that killed five people.
Mohammed Salameh's childhood, like those of many Palestinians of his generation, was rudely interrupted by war. Israeli troops occupied Biddiya, his village on the West Bank, three months before he was born. His father, Amin Salameh, a lieutenant in the Jordanian Army, packed his wife, five boys and six girls, and left with thousands of other Palestinians for Amman when the boy was two months old. The home and most of the possessions were left behind.
The infant did not know it, but he had become a refugee.
The family settled in the Palestinian slums here. Mr. Salameh grew up amid a mass of concrete hovels and dirt streets, where many Palestinians still live piled one on top of the other. To supplement the army pension, his father took a job for an import clearing house. But the family always lived just a few steps away from poverty.
The squalid streets of Zarqa seemed a long way from the idyllic world of Palestine, or at least that version of Palestine that was dished out to the brood of children. A color photograph of the Dome of the Rock, the Muslim holy site in Jerusalem, hangs prominently in the living room, as it does in many households here.
Zarqa offers what vices Jordan can serve up: cheap hashish, a few weapons and a trade in stolen goods. But Jordanian authorities say that neither Mr. Salameh nor his family had any record of being involved in the criminal activity that is endemic in the country's third-largest city, where those who have legitimate jobs work mining phosphate and potash.
The boy was not a good student and had trouble finishing school.
"He wanted to study law or engineering," his mother said, "but he was not accepted into these schools. He could only get into the Islamic law department at Jordan University, although he never finished his studies."
His mother handed over a picture of her son at school, dressed in a neat blue suit and bearded. "He became pious and prayed a lot," said his brother Ahmed. "He stayed only with friends who were religious. He gave up everything else for religion. He grew a beard."
 
'Not a Fanatic'
 But the family, which does not run a strict Islamic household, insists he steered clear of radical religious groups.
"He used to spend a lot of time in mosques, listening to the clerics," said a cousin. "We could see he was becoming very religious, but he was not a fanatic."
His religion, his family says, was only an example of his piety.
"I go to prayers," his father said, "but that does not make me a fundamentalist."
When Mr. Salameh was 19, he abandoned his studies and tried to find a job.
"He looked and looked," his mother said, "but there was nothing."
Against his parents' objections he announced he was leaving Jordan for the United States. His departure six years ago was the last time he saw any members of his immediate family.
 
Rough Times in New York
 Two years after he left Jordan, his father finished building a small house, with four bedrooms, where they now live.
"He had so many dreams then," his mother said, "of a job, of money. He told us how he was going to help us."
But the streets of New York apparently did not embrace the young Arab with much more enthusiasm than those he had left at home. He took a few menial jobs, but after four months was destitute, the family said. He turned, for the first and only time, to his one relative in New York, a doctor, and asked for a $400 loan. But his relative, who had emigrated to the United States 20 years before, turned him down.
The refusal to aid a member of the family, so foreign a concept in the culture he had left behind, seemed, according to his parents, to have steeled in him a hatred for the callousness of the society he had entered.
"It was unemployment and poverty that drove him to the United States," said his mother, "and it was unemployment and poverty he found when he got there. This was very bitter."
For a while he stocked shelves in a supermarket for below minimum wage -- his parents were unsure where.
"But one day he came to work and they had replaced him," his mother said. "I remember him telling us this story, and he was out on the street again."
The young man seemed to begin drifting into a world his parents did not know. Jobs and addresses became vague. They say they were often unsure about his work and his contacts. But nearly every month he called home, asked a few questions about his brothers and sisters and assured everyone he was well. Small money orders intermittently reached the house.
"He sent us about $4,000 during all the time he was in the United States," his mother said. "I guess that's not much, but he tried so hard. He never asked us for anything. He always wanted to help."
The last phone call came in January. It was, the family said, the usual brief exchange of pleasantries, all parties acutely conscious of the meter ticking away the charge on the international line. In the conversation he mentioned a woman and there seemed in the air to be the prospect of marriage.
The call was taken at the neighbor's house, as the family has no phone of their own.
The next time his parents heard of Mr. Salameh he was in the news. After hearing of the arrest, the family said, Mr. Salameh's father went to Jordanian security officials to ask whether they had any information, but they said they had none.
For these Palestinians -- each pushed unjustly, they believed, from their homes on the West Bank after the 1967 war, and some pushed again out of Kuwait after the Persian Gulf war -- there is only one group capable of bringing this latest disaster into their lives.
"The Jews," Mrs. Salameh uttered with a vehemence that shattered the calm that had descended on the room. "This is from the Jews, who have done this and blamed my son. You will see that he is innocent."
Heads nodded in support. Men, to ward off the cold of the night air, pulled their brown, wool cloaks closer over their legs. And the mother turned to the only American in the room.
"Will they let him pray in jail?" she asked, "Or in this great democracy is this forbidden? I hear they do not let him practice his religion, that conditions are very bad in jail."
"My son," said his mother, leaning forward until her pale gray eyes were inches away, "is being persecuted."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1245 words

HEADLINE: Suburban Superstores Come To New York City Shoppers

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
Some of the nation's largest discount retailers -- the cavernous department stores, warehouse clubs and super supermarkets that for decades have shaped the shopping landscape of America's suburbs and small towns -- are coming to New York City.
With the price of the city's real estate falling and the appetite for variety and value growing, these discounters are now discovering that New York, like other big cities, represents the last untapped frontier for their low-margin, high-volume wares: more than seven million consumers and such a dearth of these stores that many New Yorkers drive to the suburbs to find them. 
 A handful have already opened in the city -- from the Kmart in Queens to the Finast in Brooklyn to the Bed, Bath and Beyond in Manhattan. The Home Depot and Caldor's have bought sites. And almost a dozen more -- including Pathmark, Wal-mart, Waldbaum's, the Price Club and BJ's Wholesale Club -- are mounting increasingly aggressive searches for space, particularly in Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx.
"It's an awareness of the awesome potential that exists," said Charles E. Lotzar, an executive with the Kmart Corporation, which wants to open more stores in the city, including its subsidiary superstores, Pace, Sports Authority and Border Books. "There's really no other place like it."
Desperate to fill the employment void left by the decline of manufacturing and the closing of some of the city's traditional department stores, the city's economic officials have eagerly welcomed the discounters that for years stayed away because of high costs. Now, in an effort to attract more, the Department of City Planning has proposed changes in zoning policies that some retailers and officials say have helped keep them out.
The arrival of these stores -- familiar sights along the nation's highways and boulevards, with their huge signs and sprawling parking lots -- could profoundly change the city, its neighborhoods and the sometimes idiosyncratic way that New Yorkers shop.
While officials and the retailers themselves say the stores will create thousands of jobs and raise millions of dollars in taxes, others warn that an unchecked proliferation will do to New York what it has done to other cities and towns. They darkly predict that the stores, with their high volume and low margins, will undercut and destroy the local merchants that have given the city's many Main Streets their singular character.
"We have to tread very carefully," said Bernd Zimmermann, the director of planning for the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer. "It's time the city addresses the flight of buying power to the suburbs, but there is a hefty amount of fear among small retailers that the market will be drawn out from under them. That has to be addressed, too."
 
Glut of Retail Space
 There was a time, in the early 1960's, when New York City was the retail center of the metropolitan region, accounting for nearly 50 percent of all retail sales. But as the retailers followed the flight of the middle class from cities to the suburbs, creating shopping hubs designed for the car, the city has watched many of its department stores close: Alexander's, Gimbels, B. Altman, May's, Ohrbach's, E. J. Korvette.
The closings have now created a glut of vacant retail space -- seven million square feet in Manhattan alone -- driving down prices by as much as $10 to $20 a square foot in Manhattan, where prices can vary from $40 to $50 a square foot, according to Charles Aug of Garrick Aug Associates Store Leasing Inc., who is doing searches for several discounters he declined to identify.
Now brokers and city officials say the dual effects of the lower rents and the void left by the closings has finally made the city attractive to the discounters. And after decades in which retailers, shoppers and money flowed to the suburbs, the arriving stores might reverse the flow.
"My belief is that we are watching the gradual re-entry into the city of the businesses that went to the suburbs in the post-World War II market," said Barry F. Sullivan, the Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development. "That market is relatively saturated. Now they're looking for ways to begin to come back in."
One indication of the interest was the remarkable bidding war between two regional chains -- the Caldor Corporation and Bradlees Inc. -- to buy six of the department stores left vacant by the collapse of Alexander's last year. As Alexander's wallowed in bankruptcy, Bradlees offered $82 million to buy the six stores -- two in the Bronx, two in Queens and one each in Yonkers and Valley Stream, L.I.
 
Bidding War
 Caldor, one of the largest discounters in the Northeast, countered with its own offer, said to have been at least $5 million more. The bidding culminated last November, when the two companies clashed in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, raising their bids 23 times in a single day, usually in increments of $1 million, until Caldor won with a bid of $120 million.
Caldor, which opened its first store in the city in Queens in 1990 and another on Staten Island in 1991, expects to open five of the six stores soon, possibly by the end of the year, with some 250 jobs in each. The other, in Yonkers, it leased to Bradlees.
"We were disappointed at the way it worked out," said Coleman Nee, a spokesman for Bradlees, a chain of 127 stores based in Braintree, Mass. "It doesn't mean we're not going to keep trying."
In addition to the discounters that have opened or hope to move into the city for the first time, others want to expand, opening larger stores, including Toys 'R' Us and Kmart, which has two smaller stores on Staten Island.
The Home Depot, the behemoth home improvement chain based in Atlanta, has bought a swath of land at the Aqueduct Race Track near Kennedy International Airport and has agreed to buy the closed Taystee Bakery plant in Flushing, Queens.
 
In Pursuit of Customers
 The chain has many stores in the region, particularly on Long Island and in New Jersey. As they crept closer to the city, opening stores in Paramus, N.J., in late 1990 and in Elmont, L.I., the next year, the managers noticed that many of their customers came from the city.
The company is now searching for more, especially in Brooklyn, said Larry Mercer, the president of the Northeast division.
The city's appetite for such stores certainly appears enormous. While Nassau County has one retailer with more than 100 workers for every 8,500 people, for example, the city overall has one for every 20,000.
Obstacles remain for the large retailers, though. The price of land remains expensive compared with the rest of the region and nation and the large parcels (usually at least 10 acres) that the stores desire are hard to come by.
Clearing such obstacles is a primary goal of the city's proposal to ease the zoning restrictions in some light and medium manufacturing zones, including areas left vacant by the decline of manufacturing in the city.
The city's zoning policy allows large retailers, like Macy's, in some areas, like 34th Street, but it also includes restrictions that require a developer to obtain a variance to build a store larger than 10,000 square feet in many commercial and manufacturing areas -- a process that can take years.
The proposal, which is subject to approval by the City Council, would allow stores up to 100,000 feet to move into these zones without the variance.

HEADLINE: Looking for Alliance, Clinton Courts the Congress Nonstop

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
Senator James M. Jeffords, a Republican from Vermont, was sitting in a hotel room in Damascus, Syria, one evening last month when President Clinton called to thank him for voting for the family leave bill.
"It was unbelievable," Mr. Jeffords said. "No one would believe that the President would call me in Damascus. No matter how long we've been around the Hill, there's nothing more exciting than a call from the President." 
 That Mr. Clinton would call a Republican halfway around the world on a matter that had already been settled is but one example of Mr. Clinton's strategy of stroking Democratic and Republican lawmakers more intensely than any President in nearly three decades. His near daily meetings with Congress members and frequent excursions to Capitol Hill suggest almost a parliamentary-style Government, where the President works in tandem with legislators.
By his nature, Mr. Clinton relishes the give-and-take of debating the intricacies of policy with a wide range of people, and as Governor of Arkansas he was known for practically camping out at the State Legislature. "Legislators used to hide from him because they thought he was going to talk them into something they didn't want to do," recalled Senator Dale Bumpers, Democrat of Arkansas. "He's a very persuasive lobbyist."
 
Pushing for Economic Plan
 But Mr. Clinton is also pursuing an energetic strategy of winning over lawmakers through personal contacts, with the most immediate goal of gaining support for an economic program that confronts some lawmakers with their most difficult votes in years.
Mr. Jeffords, a moderate whom White House officials have identified as a possible ally on many issues, acknowledged that the call made him more inclined to support the economic program. "It doesn't hurt," he replied.
Courting Congress is nothing new for a President, of course. President Lyndon B. Johnson was a master at it, although he was partial to intimidation. Even President George Bush made overtures to the Democrats on Capitol Hill early in his term.
But for Mr. Clinton, the massaging of Congressional egos is virtually nonstop. He invites even Republicans to travel with him aboard Air Force One. During an unusual visit to Capitol Hill to meet just with Republicans this week, Mr. Clinton called many of them by their first names. He has asked Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the Democratic whip, to compile a list of members whom he could invite to go jogging with him.
Though he has proved to be a chummy suitor, Mr. Clinton has also sent a clear signal that he will strike back when spurned. The day after Mr. Clinton announced his budget package to a joint session of Congress, Vice President Al Gore sought to sell the plan by visiting lawmakers. But he was embarrassed at a meeting in Senator Richard C. Shelby's office when, as the cameras rolled, the Alabama Democrat publicly complained that the proposal was "high on taxes and low on cuts."
 
Rebuttal Is Swift
 The response from the White House was swift and unapologetic: officials said they would move from Alabama to Texas the management team for a space shuttle contract, a loss of 90 jobs for Mr. Shelby's state. "We tolerate dissension here," said one Administration official familiar with the episode. "But he embarrassed the Veep on national television instead of speaking to us privately."
The extraordinary contacts with lawmakers are the political equivalent of preventive maintenance: Mr. Clinton wants to lay the groundwork to win support in the future. But White House officials said the efforts seem to be paying off already. "How many Democrats attacked any portion of the President's plan in the first two weeks?" asked George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director. "Very, very few. Part of the reason they're happy to have one of their own in the White House is because he's working with them."
So close are the ties between the White House and Congress that at times it can be hard to figure out who is working for whom. Mr. Stephanopoulos and David Dreyer, one of his deputies, have begun what are expected to become weekly skull sessions to plot legislative strategy with Mr. Bonior and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader. It is almost as if Mr. Stephanopoulos and Mr. Dreyer never switched jobs; before the campaign they were top aides to Mr. Gephardt, and now they are back meeting in his office.
In another effort to reward or woo House members, next week Mr. Clinton is to take the first of a series of trips to specific Congressional districts.
Though they have yet to be tested through critical floor votes, Mr. Clinton's efforts are clearly scoring political points. Saying he did not want to be "too fawning," Representative Jay R. Inslee, a newly elected Democrat from Washington State, spoke of his three meetings with the President thus far, including a cross-country trip on Air Force One. "Pretty extraordinary access for a freshman from Selah, Washington," he said.
 
Johnson as Role Model
 Another newly elected Democrat, Representative Eric D. Fingerhut of Ohio, trumpeted a brief session he and other colleagues had with Mr. Clinton in a press release with the headline, "Fingerhut meets with President at the White House."
Howard Paster, Mr. Clinton's chief Congressional liaison, said that he had followed elements of the model of President Johnson, who staked his legislative strategy on cajoling, even browbeating, members. Though less heavy-handed, Mr. Clinton's approach is no less aggressive.
"There is an intimacy between the President and Congress that we have not seen in some time," said Mr. Paster, 48, who was head of Hill & Knowlton's Washington office and was once a lobbyist for the United Automobile Workers. "There is a mind-set that these are our friends and that we need to recognize that."
It is a far cry from the last Democrat in the White House, Jimmy Carter, who was viewed even by Democrats as contemptuous of Congress, and from Presidents Bush and Ronald Reagan, who made limited efforts to work with chambers dominated by Democrats.
"Between Johnson and Carter you could kind of see Clinton as a middle ground," said Richard F. Fenno Jr., a political scientist at the University of Rochester. "It's not as impatient and in your face as L.B.J., but it's not as arrogant as Carter," he said, adding, "He's going to need their help, and sometimes personal relationships are more important than ideology."
Another difference is that unlike Mr. Johnson, Mr. Clinton was never a leader in Congress who dispensed favors that he could later demand be returned. "It was Lyndon Johnson that would say, you know, 'Lyndon's done a few things for you; now you're going to do a few things for old Lyndon,' " recalled Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois. "And that's exactly the way he approached it, and twisted our arms and got a bill out."
Suggesting that winning support in Congress might not be as easy for Mr. Clinton, and specifically citing the President's plan for national health insurance, Mr. Rostenkowski added, "This is a challenge for this young man as President of the United States."
Mr. Clinton has sought to compensate for the fact that he never served in Congress by surrounding himself with veterans of Capitol Hill.
Mr. Clinton frequently dispatches Mr. Gore, a former Senator from Tennessee, to smooth over problems in Congress, and he has stocked his Cabinet with veterans who are deeply wired on Capitol Hill. Lloyd Bentsen, the Treasury Secretary, was chairman of the Senate Finance Committee; Leon E. Panetta, the Budget Director, was chairman of the House Budget Committee, and Les Aspin, the Defense Secretary, was chairman of the House Armed Services Committee.
 
Fortunes Tied to Congress
 Mr. Clinton's pitch is that Congress can rise or fall with him. It is a message that seems to be resonating with Democrats who say they feel pressure to help keep their party's hold on the White House and are only encouraged by Mr. Clinton's entreaties.
"He said, 'We're all in this together,' " Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, a Connecticut Democrat, quoted Mr. Clinton as telling Democratic Senators recently. "He acknowledged there have been and will be controversies, but he struck a nice balance between being personable and standing his ground."
For all the attention that the Clinton White House is lavishing on lawmakers, some have felt snubbed. In the first days he was in office, critics said he could have avoided some controversies -- over his plan to lift the ban on homosexuals in the military and the scuttled nomination of Zoe Baird for Attorney General -- if he had consulted crucial Senators.
More recently, Robert H. Michel, the House Republican leader, said Mr. Gore had apologized to members this week for that fact that "none of us on the Republican side in the leadership were given any kind of heads up" on the air drops in Bosnia.
Mr. Paster defends the Administration, saying, "The problem with Congressional relations is that with every good intention, at the end of the day you can't accommodate all the requests that you get."
Other Administration officials said they feared that the period of good will between the White House and the Congress will, by nature, be short lived. Some lawmakers are skeptical as well.
"This is the first effort out of the White House to reach out to Republicans," Senator Daniel R. Coats, an Indiana Republican, said after sharing Big Macs with the President on Capitol Hill this week. "And it may be pure P. R. Time will tell."

HEADLINE: Executive Brief: THE COMMERCE DEPARTMENT;
Reason to Smile Again: Clinton Industrial Policy

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
During the Bush years, Commerce Department officials liked to quip that they were working for an industrial-policy agency in an Administration that did not believe in industrial policy.
The Clinton Administration, which does believe in industrial policy, is beginning to flex the department's atrophied muscles. While plans to spend more on commercial research and promoting exports have alarmed opponents of government intervention in the marketplace, they have sent morale at the agency soaring. 
 The most spectacular of the proposed changes is a plan to expand the department's advanced technology program. The former Commerce Secretary, Robert A. Mosbacher, fought hard to establish the program. But in the end industrial-policy opponents in the Bush Administration made sure it got only a tiny budget.
The program is the source of grants of up to $2 million to companies for research and development. President Clinton has proposed increasing its $68 million budget to $758 million by 1997.
 
Washington Does MITI
 That kind of activism -- and aggressive spending -- might seem a comfortable fit with Democratic Party traditions. But parts of the Clinton Administration's industrial-policy plan also seem to be modeled on a popular whipping boy of the Democrats: Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry, the oft-bashed MITI.
Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown insisted at a press conference on Friday that his plans to develop a closer partnership between the Commerce Department and American business were home grown, but another Clinton Administration official admitted that studies of MITI had been influential.
Daniel J. Mitchell, an economist at the conservative Heritage Foundation and a critic of industrial policies, said Democrats had exaggerated MITI's wisdom and power. "It's not nearly what they made it out to be," he said, pointing out that the ministry once tried to discourage Honda from entering the auto industry.
 
Little Things Count
 Some budget battles are fought over large sums of money. Others are fought over who gets to spend money, sometimes even piddling sums.
Candidate Clinton's pledge of increased Government spending to promote technology made it relatively easy for Mr. Brown to win a lot more money in President Clinton's supplemental budget. By contrast, he found himself with a fight on his hands over a paltry $12 million.
Last year, Congress authorized the Agency for International Development to transfer "up to $12 million" to Commerce to set up 13 offices in Russia, Ukraine, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and Belarus. The offices were to provide secretaries, telephones, translators and marketing advice to American companies trying to do business in those countries.
But A.I.D., which is coordinating aid to the former Soviet republics, initially offered Commerce only half the money, contending that it needed the rest for other programs. Mr. Brown personally intervened with A.I.D. officials and insisted that all the money be transferred. On Friday, he announced that his department would be setting up the offices.
 
Happy Days Are There Again
 Morale among the Department's 30,000 civil servants, severely deflated by years of Republican criticisms of industrial policy, has improved remarkably in recent weeks.
"No matter what you may think of the Democrats, they listen to what you say," one career officer marveled. "They're nice. They take your advice."
But political philosophy and policy manifestoes are not the only things on which the department's morale has turned. For many years, for example, a Commerce Department guard made sure that only the Secretary, top political aides and the Secretary's visitors used the only elegant entrance to the hulking, utilitarian Commerce Building, which covers two city blocks across from the Washington Monument.
The entrance, which sports a bright red awning that runs to the street, was restricted even though it led to one of the department's main corridors and provided no special access to the Secretary's suite on the fifth floor.
Mr. Brown opened the entrance to general use immediately after taking office. In the spirit of President Clinton's budget-cutting efforts, the awning remains; it would cost money to remove, explained James P. Desler, a Commerce Department spokesman.

The Economy
Plunging interest rates are putting money into the pockets of millions of Americans and many corporations. And so far they have been using this new-found cash mostly to reduce their debts, behaving with much more wariness than in the past. [Page D1.]
President Clinton has chosen Joseph E. Stiglitz to be the third member of the Council of Economic Advisers, Administration officials say. Many economists view the highly regarded Stanford University professor as an odds-on favorite to win a Nobel Memorial Prize at some point in his career. [D1.] 

International
Japanese consumers have a test case of how committed the Government is to protecting their rights. The Japanese recently learned that they have not been receiving warnings about a potential link between video games and a form of epilepsy that Nintendo was including in games for the U.S. and Europe. News of the missing warning has given fresh impetus to efforts to revise consumer protection laws. [A1.]
The collapse of the industrial machine of what was East Germany seems certain to weigh on the entire German economy, and all of Europe, for much of this decade. HEADLINE: Florida Officials Scramble to Save Air Base Damaged by Hurricane

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
Once a driving force in South Florida, Homestead Air Force Base has been closed since Hurricane Andrew damaged or destroyed most of its buildings last August. Now it is on a list of military bases facing closings, and Florida lawmakers are making one last major effort to bring it back to life.
Senator Bob Graham met on Friday with Pentagon officials to discuss the plan to close the base and ways to include Florida's Congressional delegation and members of the public in the military's discussions, an aide to the Senator, Samuel R. Shorstein, said today. Mr. Shorstein said that Mr. Graham hoped that the base would be rebuilt. 
 The base, where 8,400 civilian and military personnel worked, pumped $450 million a year into the local economy.
 
Support From Cisneros
 Henry G. Cisneros, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, noted on Friday that the area served by the base had a large immigrant population from Haiti, Mexico and Central America as well as low-income white and black Americans dependent on blue-collar and agricultural industries. He said that the area could degenerate into "a vast tangle of poor communities, uncoordinated and haphazardly constructed" and that he had made some recommendations to President Clinton about the future of the base.
Mr. Cisneros subsequently confirmed a report in The Miami Herald that said he had recommended that if the base was not reopened for military use, it be used for the Customs Service, the Drug Enforcement Administration or reserve units.
Last Friday the Pentagon agreed to release $76 million for partial reconstruction to allow the Customs and drug agencies and Air Force reserve units to use the base.
The fate of the base became an issue in last fall's Presidential campaign. President George Bush promised to rebuild the base at a cost of $480 million. But the Senate Appropriations Committee rejected Mr. Bush's proposal.
And Bill Clinton strongly suggested that if elected, he would rebuild and reopen Homestead. But in a nationally televised town meeting last month, President Clinton made no promises about Homestead's fate, saying he would go along with the commission's decision. Still, Mr. Clinton called the base an "invaluable asset" and promised to find a nonmilitary use for the installation.
He is expected to make a policy speech this week addressing the South Florida relief effort.

HEADLINE: White House Completes Its Team of Economists

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
President Clinton has chosen Joseph E. Stiglitz, a highly regarded Stanford University economics professor, to be the third and final member of the Council of Economic Advisers, Administration officials said this weekend.
Several economists said it was quite a coup for Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the council's chairwoman, to land Mr. Stiglitz, who in the view of many experts is an odds-on favorite to win a Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics at some point in his career for his research into the effect of imperfect or incomplete information on the functioning of markets and economies.
 
'A Restless Researcher'
 "We call him Jumping Joe," said Rudiger Dornbusch, an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "He's a restless researcher and teacher. In terms of professional reputation, I think he's the most distinguished young economist out there." 
 Mr. Stiglitz, 50, is scheduled to begin work in Washington on Monday, officials said, although Senate confirmation hearings on his nomination are not expected for several more weeks.
The council provides the President with a broad range of economic advice, helping formulate economic policy and assessing hundreds of proposals in terms of their economic benefits and costs.
Administration officials said that while Ms. Tyson oversaw the council's activities, Mr. Stiglitz would concentrate on microeconomic areas, like banking and securities regulation and trade matters. The other member of the council, Alan Blinder, a Princeton University economist, will focus on macroeconomic matters, like taxes and economic forecasts.
During the last two decades, Mr. Stiglitz has developed a reputation as one of the nation's leading economic theoreticians, doing work on public finance, labor markets, credit and the economics of the developing world.
When President Clinton appointed Ms. Tyson to head the council in December, many economists wondered how influential the panel would be because she is not considered one of the nation's leading macroeconomists. By enlisting Mr. Stiglitz and Mr. Blinder, Ms. Tyson would seem to have defused such criticism.
Indeed, some economists say that few other councils have had as much intellectual firepower as the one Ms. Tyson will head. Comparisons are already being drawn between it and the council under President John F. Kennedy, headed by Walter Heller, which included James A. Tobin, who later won a Nobel Prize.
Mr. Stiglitz said he would not grant an interview until after he was confirmed. But he has told friends that he was attracted to the job because he wanted a change of pace from academia and also wanted to contribute to improving the nation's economy.
Mr. Stiglitz, a graduate of Amherst College, obtained his doctorate in 1967 from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he studied under Paul Samuelson and Robert Solow, both of whom are Nobel laureates in economics. Like Mr. Samuelson, Mr. Stiglitz comes from Gary, Ind.
The two other members of the current Council of Economic Advisers -- Ms. Tyson and Mr. Blinder -- also hold doctorates in economics from M.I.T.
Mr. Stiglitz began his teaching career at M.I.T. in 1966 while still a doctoral student and left the next year to teach at Yale, where he became a full professor at the age of 26. He went to Stanford in 1974 and then joined the faculty at Oxford Univeristy in 1976. In 1979, he took a teaching position at Princeton, and in 1988, he rejoined the Stanford faculty.
In 1979, he won the John Bates Clark Award, which is given every two years by the American Economic Association to honor the nation's best economist under the age of 40.
 
Effects of Incomplete Information
 He has theorized that because employers do not have complete information about the people they hire, they often offer above-average wages so they can attract a large pool of applicants from which to choose. He has argued that one reason for unemployment is that these wage levels cause employers to hire fewer people than they otherwise would.
His work has also indicated that because bankers have only imperfect or incomplete information about potential borrowers, they tend to restrict their loans more than market forces might dictate. He argues that as a result of incomplete information, bankers often restrict loan size and exclude certain groups from consideration for loans.
Mr. Stiglitz is also known for helping develop economic models to examine international trade and technological competition. He has also done work on the economic returns of education. He wrote his dissertation on relationships between economic growth and income distribution.
"Joe is one of the great economic theorists of the last 20 years," said Paul Krugman, an economics professor at M.I.T. "Aside from trying to save the world, he is going to Washington because he is looking for an interesting new experience."
