HEADLINE: Japan Debates Broader Power for Consumers

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 7

 BODY:
Japanese consumers now have a test case of just how committed the Government is to protecting their rights.
Amid recent reports that playing video games can cause seizures in children with a particular type of epilepsy, the Japanese learned that they have not been receiving the warnings that Nintendo, the Japanese video game giant, has been including in games it sells in the United States and Europe. 
 Nintendo explained that the warnings were necessary to protect itself from lawsuits in the United States and Europe, but that in Japan such lawsuits were extremely rare. Indeed, there have been only about 150 court decisions in product-liability cases here since the end of World War II.
 
Tilt Toward Producers
 News of the missing warning has given fresh impetus to efforts to revise consumer protection laws, particularly to make it easier for customers to sue manufacturers when they are injured by defective products. Japan's orientation toward producers, often at the expense of citizens, has contributed to the trade surplus of Japan and an image abroad that it is interested solely in business.
But business groups here are resisting attempts to strengthen the product-liability system, fearing it could become a drain on competitiveness like the American system is often said to be.
Businessmen recoil in horror at the thought of huge class-action lawsuits and substantial payments, like the $105 million that a jury recently ordered the General Motors Corporation to pay the family of a teen-ager who died in the fiery crash of a G.M. pickup truck. If anything, they say -- and many Americans agree -- it is the American system that needs an overhaul.
"I believe that Japan needs to adopt an American-style product-liability system about as much as the United States needs to adopt a Soviet-style food distribution system," Robert C. Weber, a Cleveland lawyer, wrote in the latest issue of the Journal of Japanese Trade and Industry.
Last year, an advisory committee to the Prime Minister discussed a new product-liability law, but then tabled the matter until this year after an agreement could not be reached. One concern was that innovation could be retarded if companies were held liable for problems that could not be predicted at the time a product was developed.
 
Few Termed Dissatisfied
 "At this moment, there is no consensus about whether to introduce product-liability regulation in Japan," said Hiroshi Ogawa, director of the division of consumer affairs at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, which has set up its own advisory panel to consider the issue. "Only a small percentage of people are dissatisfied" with the current system, he said.
Mr. Ogawa said more effective and less costly consumer protection might be achieved not by encouraging lawsuits, but by tightening safety regulations and setting up funds to provide compensation to consumers. Japan already has such funds for drugs and for household products. The trade ministry is considering forming a new system for settling product-liability grievances out of court.
Others have long noted that the Japanese, who generally seek to avoid confrontation, do not like to sue. In the crash of a Japan Airlines Boeing 747 in 1985, the relatives of all 13 non-Japanese victims sued. But there were only 21 lawsuits representing fewer than 100 of the more than 500 Japanese victims.
But critics say there are so few product-liability lawsuits because consumers are powerless. "We don't have any rights at all," said Yoko Tomiyama, chairwoman of the Consumers Union of Japan.
They also argue that the existing compensation mechanisms are inadequate. To win a product-liability lawsuit in Japan, a consumer must prove that the manufacturer was negligent in designing or manufacturing the product, which often requires knowledge of the manufacturer's intentions or procedures. In the United States, a consumer in many cases merely needs to show that the product was defective and that the defect caused the accident or sickness, a standard known as strict liability.
The European Community also uses strict liability, but imposes restrictions that make it more difficult to file lawsuits and obtain large damage awards than it is in the United States.
In one case cited by lawyers who favor changing Japanese law, an apartment resident died because of incomplete combustion of a gas boiler. The police found that if the boiler was used for two hours on a windy day, carbon monoxide levels in an apartment would build to a lethal level. Nevertheless, the court ruled against the plaintiff in 1988, saying that the exact cause of the incomplete combustion was not known and therefore it could not be determined whether the manufacturer had been negligent.
There are other obstacles to such lawsuits in Japan. For one thing, there are only about 15,000 lawyers, compared with more than 700,000 in the United States. Moreover, in contrast to their American counterparts, Japanese lawyers will not take a case without advance payment, in hopes of winning a percentage of damages.
Court filing fees, which vary with the amount of damages sought, are also high. Filing a lawsuit seeking damages of 100 million yen, or about $800,000, costs 400,000 yen, or $3,200.
Even if someone gets to court, it is difficult to win. Japan's court system does not allow discovery, the process by which one side can request documents from the other after a suit is filed. So plaintiffs have to gather their evidence before filing suit.
Also, trials here do not use juries, which in the United States are often moved to make big awards. In Japan there are no punitive damages, only awards to compensate consumers. In the recent General Motors case, $101 million of the $105 million award consisted of punitive damages.
 
Several Proposals
 Several product-liability laws have been proposed here by consumer groups, a committee of the Japan Federation of Bar Associations and two minority parties. Generally, the proposals would change Japan to a strict-liability standard, but would not make many changes in the court system. That should prevent the American system's excesses from occurring in Japan, proponents say.
"There are not enough lawyers in Japan for lawyers to become ambulance chasers," said Masato Nakamura, a product-liability lawyer and vice chairman of the Consumer Problems Committee of the Japan Federation of Bar Associations.
One example of a problem, Mr. Nakamura said, is the case of L-tryptophan, a diet supplement that caused 1,500 cases of a rare disorder, resulting in 38 deaths in the United States and prompting hundreds of lawsuits. Showa Denko, the Japanese manufacturer of the product, has paid out more than $600 million to American victims.
But in Japan, there have been no lawsuits. Showa Denko said that was because the product had not been popular here and that the health ministry had confirmed only two cases of the blood disorder caused by contaminated L-tryptophan.
But others doubt that assertion. "It's not like there aren't any victims in Japan," said Michiko Suga, a 54-year-old Tokyo resident who says she has suffered terrible pains from taking L-tryptophan for insomnia. The company, while not commenting on specific cases, apparently maintains that Mrs. Suga's problems are not connected to L-tryptophan.
While Mrs. Suga has thought about suing, "it's not really what I want to do," she said. "I want to get better."
 
Minolta Offer Rejected
 Some consumers do sue, however. Shoichi Iwasaki, a business consultant, said that on June 25, 1991, he left his house while his Minolta word processor was doing a lengthy printing job. When he returned, his daughter was outside screaming that there was a fire in the house.
"The first thing I saw from 15 feet away was the top of the word processor on fire," Mr. Iwasaki recalled, saying the fire was caused by a short circuit in the machine's electrical cord. The fire extensively damaged the first floor of his home and destroyed 200 floppy disks containing invaluable business data, he said.
Mr. Iwasaki said Minolta contended that such a thing could not happen. But it offered to pay 1 million yen, or about $8,000, and later increased its offer to 8 million yen, or $64,000. Last July, Mr. Iwasaki filed a lawsuit in Tokyo district court seeking 100 million yen, or $800,000.
A spokesman for Minolta said the company was confident that the word processor did not cause the fire. He said that 15,000 units had been sold by Minolta and Sanyo, which is the actual manufacturer, and that no other fires had been reported.
While most of the effort to change product-liability laws has been aimed at making lawsuits easier, the Nintendo situation has caused consumer groups to call for stricter warnings on products sold in Japan.
There is no health warning on alcoholic beverages sold here. And while cigarette packs in the United States include the Surgeon General's warnings that smoking causes lung cancer, heart disease, emphysema and may complicate pregnancy, cigarettes sold in Japan usually carry a more vaguely worded admonition along the lines of, "Because there is a danger of damaging your health, be careful not to smoke too much."

HEADLINE: Plunging Interest Rates Sow Hope and Caution

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Plunging interest rates are putting money into the pockets of millions of Americans and many corporations. And so far they have been using this new-found cash mostly to reduce their debts, behaving with much more wariness than in the past.
The interest rate phenomenon -- rates have fallen to their lowest levels in years -- is still too new to have changed economic patterns. But the beginnings are there. Not only are mortgage applications to buy homes rising, but the Federal Government's huge annual interest payment on the national debt is likely to be the same amount this year as last, the Congressional Budget Office says. Not since the 1960's has this outlay for debt service failed to rise. 
 "The total amount of the national debt is rising by roughly $300 billion a year," said Robert D. Reischauer, the Congressional Budget Office director, "and yet the interest payments on this debt are flattening out at $199 billion a year. That shows you the powerful effect the lower interest rates are having on a major Government outlay."
Many state and municipal governments have also taken advantage of the lower rates by refinancing their bonds. In January and February, such refinancings ran 53 percent above the level in the first two months of 1992, according to The Bond Buyer, a newspaper that reports on the credit markets. "These savings are helping states to finance public works spending," said Steven D. Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States.
Yet not everyone wins from lower rates. Elderly people who count on interest income to pay their expenses have experienced a sharp drop in the last year as rates have fallen. And people with credit-card debt are still paying the same high interest rates. The banks and other companies providing the cards have not reduced their rates although they are paying much less for the money they lend.
Nevertheless, a broad optimism came through in more than a dozen interviews late last week with economists, bankers, manufacturers, bond dealers, consumer representatives and housing experts. Most predicted that the lower rates would turn an uncertain economic recovery into a steady, solid one. But they were also wary.
"The decline in interest rates does not mean that corporations or consumers will spend a lot more," said Nancy R. Lazar, executive vice president of the ISI Group, a Wall Street investment firm. "That has not happened yet, although rates have been falling for two years. The reason is that debt levels are so high. But people do have a better feeling about their financial situation."
Because the Federal Government is such a big borrower -- the national debt is now roughly $4 trillion -- the Treasury securities that are sold to the public serve as guideposts for interest-rate levels in the private sector. Since consumer-loan rates have not dropped nearly as quickly, the biggest early winners from the lower rates have been big corporations, credit-card operations and banks.
 
Profitable Gap at Banks
 "The typical large bank that we follow has a net interest margin of 4.5 percent, an all-time high," said Raphael Soifer, a bank analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, referring to the gap between what a bank charges for loans and what it pays for money to its depositors.
Banks have two ways of making a profit: either charge high rates, or increase the dollar volume of loans outstanding, at lower rates. "They don't see the demand for enough new loans yet from creditworthy borrowers" to justify lowering rates, Mr. Soifer said.
Drawing on Federal Reserve data, Ms. Lazar said corporations had saved $25 billion in annual interest payments by paying off older loans and borrowing anew at lower rates. The similar saving for consumers is $11 billion, mostly from refinancing mortgages at the lowest rates in 20 years.
The mortgage savings come in this fashion: A 30-year, $100,000 mortgage at 8.9 percent, the typical rate last March, is refinanced today at 7.4 percent. The lower rate reduces the homeowner's monthly payment to $692 from $797, a savings of $105, the Mortgage Bankers Association calculates.
Much of the drop in mortgage interest rates has come since Election Day. "There's been a confluence of events," said David M. Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a Wall Street bond house. "The recovery has not generated many jobs, and that has kept inflation down. And investors have been pleasantly surprised by President Clinton's apparent determination to cut the deficit."
 
Home Sales Expected
 The result has been not only a surge in refinancing mortgages, but also a rise in applications for mortgages to buy homes -- applications that should show up as actual home sales in 30 to 60 days, said Lyle Gramley, chief economist of the Mortgage Bankers Association. "Our survey of 25 large mortgage bankers shows that applications for new mortgages have risen 80 percent above 1990 levels," Mr. Gramley said.
Some of the $11 billion that consumers have saved from lower interest payments has apparently been spent on appliances and furniture. Sales of these items have risen lately, helping to raise hopes among economists that home sales, new-home construction and the manufacture of all items purchased for a new home will lead the nation to a healthy recovery, as the housing sector has done in the past.
"There is no question that the latest fall in interest rates has energized the housing industry, although we have not yet seen this in new-home construction," Mr. Gramley said. "But we will."
The economy has been strengthened in other ways as a result of the fall in interest rates, starting in late 1990. Rates on short-term Treasury securities have declined steadily since then and in recent weeks rates on longer-term Treasury notes and bonds have plunged. The 30-year bond is down nearly a full percentage point since the November election, and many state and municipal governments have taken the opportunity to refinance bonds.
 
Some Rates Remain High
 But for all the benefits of lower interest rates, most Americans still pay more than 17 percent interest annually for credit card loans and most other consumer credit, the Consumer Federation of America says. Bankers justify the high rates by arguing that administering consumer credit is costly. They "are expensive operations," said Robert Hawkins, president of the Independent Bankers Association.
Banks have cut the rates that they pay to depositors to raise much of the money for consumer credit and other loans. Six-month certificates of deposit, for example, now pay their holders less than 3 percent a year, on average, compared with more than 8 percent in 1990. The result is that interest income, an important source of wealth, particularly for the elderly, fell by $55 billion in 1992, to $655 billion, the Commerce Department reports.
Scrambling for more income, Americans have moved savings, in huge amounts, from certificates of deposit and low-interest Treasury securities, to mutual stock and bond funds, and directly into such investments as five-year Treasury notes, now paying 5.10 percent, and 30-year bonds, at 6.73 percent.
And they have become more cautious shoppers, buying fewer cars, for example, and thus helping to inhibit the auto industry's sales, although car loan rates have fallen to an average of 9.65 percent from 13.16 percent two years ago. "Older people normally purchase about 15 percent of the cars and trucks that are sold in the United States," an official of the Chrysler Corporation said.
 
Companies Paying Debt
 Corporate America, although benefiting from lower rates, is also reluctant to borrow and spend big in anticipation of a strong recovery. Cooper Industries Inc., which is based in Houston and makes oil and gas equipment, auto parts and electrical products, is more concerned about refinancing existing debt, for example, than in borrowing more money for expansion.
"Low rates in a healthy economy are very positive, but low rates in an unhealthy one don't do much good," Robert Cizik, Cooper's chairman, said. "Most of our investments in the last several years have been to reduce our costs through the purchase of more efficient machinery. Very little has been spent to increase manufacturing capacity. There is no way that you can get a return on increased capacity, regardless of how low the cost of capital is, if there is not enough demand for the products."
Instead, Cooper is wondering what to do next with its $2 billion in debt. With short-term rates falling faster than long-term rates over the last two years, Cooper has shifted 75 percent of its debt to short-term loans with interest rates of 4 percent or less. Now with long-term rates having fallen, Cooper could lock in debt at 6.5 percent. Such a move would create a big additional expense, if the spread between short- and long-term rates remains.
"Two percentage points is a lot of money when you are borrowing $2 billion," said Mr. Cizik, who is also chairman of the National Association of Manufacturers. "And there is a question: Will the long-term rates go lower, or go up, or will short-term rates suddenly rise? We do not know."

HEADLINE: NEW ROCHELLE JOURNAL;
Hey Kids, What's Behind Door No. 3? Economics

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y.

 BODY:
IF Peter Bell and the New York State Council on Economic Education have their say, sixth graders like Imhotep Newsome and Cresentia Villarin will know that there is a lot more to economics than understanding math.
Along with other students at the Albert Leonard Middle School here, they will learn that while math has fixed and impersonal answers, economics calls for flexible thinking, a set of individual values and a new vocabulary for everyday experiences. 
 Dr. Bell, the executive director of the council, a private, nonprofit group based at the State University of New York at Purchase, would have students learn this as early as the second grade. But first, he says, teachers themselves must get the economic education they never got in school.
To that end, the council has begun offering workshops so teachers can spend a day thinking like sixth graders and learning how to use a course called "Choices and Changes" that was developed by the council's parent organization, the National Council on Economic Education.
In Jeffrey Engel's classroom at the Albert Leonard school one recent morning, students played a version of "Let's Make a Deal." Mr. Engel, who leads the teacher workshops at the university, had mounted photographs of consumer items on poster boards and hidden them behind three paper "doors." He then asked the student contestants to explain why they chose either to keep an item or take a chance on the next door.
The class, which reflects this city's ethnic diversity and wide range of family income, quickly got into the spirit of the game. Cresentia, who said she likes to study Asian civilization, passed up tomatoes, a chocolate bar and won a video telephone. She made good choices, the class agreed.
But Doug Forest, who collects baseball cards and said he likes geography, passed up diamonds and got exercise equipment. Not too bad, said the class, but Doug disagreed. "I feel like a fool," he said. "I would rather have had the diamonds."
Mr. Engel spoke up. "Choices aren't clear-cut," he said. "Economists also have to make choices that aren't clear-cut. President Clinton has to rely on his human capital to make the best possible choices, but it is not clear what the costs will be."
This led Imhotep to define "opportunity costs." It's what you miss out on when you choose something, he said. Kimberly Herzog pointed out that choices involve values: not everyone will like your decisions.
Now Mr. Engel made his main point. "The more you know about your choices, the better you can make an educated choice," he said.
In a classroom down the hall, Lester Hallerman's sixth graders evaluated the costs and values of three different kinds of chocolate chip cookies. The students divided into groups and sampled cookies from plastic bags marked A, B and C. Then on worksheets, they rated each cookie on such qualities as softness, taste, "chocolatiness" and chewiness.
"Looks stale," wrote James Hoch in the Brand C column.
"Looks whitish, like it's not cooked all the way," wrote Tracy Basso, assessing Brand C.
"Very tasty and sweet," wrote Kate Downs, judging Brand B.
"Great taste," wrote Ralph Dawson, evaluating Brand A.
When the assessments were tallied, Brand B -- Sunshine Mini Chocolate Chip Cookies -- got the most votes for flavor, looks and number of chips. Brand A -- Pathmark Bite Size Chocolate Chip Cookies -- was voted the most moist and chewy. Brand C -- Nabisco Mini Chips Ahoy! -- finished last in each category.
Surprisingly, Brand C was the most expensive cookie, Brand A the least expensive, while the price of Brand B -- the overall winner -- fell in the middle.
"Looking at a cost-benefit analysis, which would be the best choice?" Mr. Hallerman asked. Hands shot up for Brand B.
But then, he asked, "Let's say you're giving a party for 3-year-olds; which cookie would you choose?" For those consumers, Mr. Hallerman said, the right answer was "probably Brand A, because most of the kids would just throw them at each other."
While "Choices and Changes" has been developed for students at risk of dropping out of school, Dr. Bell said, economics should be made more accessible to everyone. "Teachers are scared" by the subject, he said, "and they're not seeing that the economy is about everyday things."

HEADLINE: Reviews Due On Benefits For Disability

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
About 300,000 residents of New York State will get notices from the Federal Government this week offering to re-examine claims for disability benefits that have been denied by the Social Security Administration since 1981.
The notices, giving people a fresh opportunity to show that they were entitled to benefits, are part of the settlement of a lawsuit. The plaintiffs contended that the Reagan Administration often flouted court rulings when it denied or terminated payments to disabled people. 
 Even as the Government sends those letters on Monday, the Social Security Administration is reporting record backlogs and delays in its disability program across the country. The delays result, in part, from reductions in the agency's staff, cuts in state welfare programs and a rise in the number of claims, which have increased because of the sluggish economy.
Nationally, the number of disability claims and appeals has increased 35 percent, to nearly 3.4 million this year, from 2.5 million in 1990.
 
Widely Criticized
 No other aspect of President Ronald Reagan's social policy was so widely criticized by Federal judges, governors and members of Congress as his effort to remove people from the disability rolls in defiance of court rulings. But there has been no nationwide remedy for those people. Payment of back benefits depends on the outcome of individual cases and class-action lawsuits in individual states.
In New York, for example, residents and former residents forced the Federal Government to offer such payments in settlement of a case known as Stieberger v. Sullivan. The lawsuit was filed in 1984 by the Legal Aid Society, Legal Services for the Elderly and a group called MFY Legal Services in Manhattan. The City of New York was also a plaintiff.
Under the settlement, approved in June 1992 by Federal Judge Leonard B. Sand of Manhattan, the Government must re-examine 40,000 cases a year in New York. So if 150,000 people respond to the notices, it may take four years to review the cases.
"Anyone who receives one of these notices should be sure to send in the reply form as soon as possible," said Matthew Diller, a lawyer with the Legal Aid Society in New York City. "Those who are found to be disabled may receive thousands of dollars that are desperately needed." Some people may get awards totaling more than $20,000, he said.
People needing further information can call local Social Security offices or Legal Services for New York City at (212) 431-7200.
 
An 11-Year Period
 Although the settlement covers an 11-year period, it stipulates that people who are found disabled cannot receive more than four and a half years' worth of back benefits.
Monthly payments now average $626 for a disabled worker and $224 for a spouse or a child. Benefits are increased each year to reflect changes in the cost of living.
The Clinton Administration cited the New York case as one reason for seeking $302 million extra for Social Security this year, in addition to $4.8 billion already appropriated for the agency's administrative costs.
Nationwide, the Social Security agency says, 724,768 disability cases were pending at the end of 1992. The number has risen each year since 1988, when there were 406,759. The agency expects to have more than 1 million cases pending at the end of this year. Nearly one-fourth of the pending cases are in California, with 106,105, and New York, with 68,224.
Because of the backlog, the Government last year examined only 73,145 of the 6 million cases of people already on the rolls to see if they were still disabled. Congressional investigators say they suspect that thousands of people continue to get disability payments after they regain the ability to work.
 
Time to Respond
 People who receive notices from the Social Security Administration will have 180 days to respond.
"After people return the form, it may still take a long time for Social Security to get to their cases because the agency does not have enough staff to deal with its backlog," said David S. Udell, a lawyer at Legal Services for the Elderly in New York City.
Representative William J. Hughes, acting chairman of the Select Committee on Aging, said he was "greatly concerned" about the backlog because it was delaying payments to eligible people and hampering the Government's ability to identify those who should be removed from the rolls. In the last three years, he said, the Government has lost "hundreds of millions of dollars" because it continued paying benefits to people who would have been found ineligible if they had been re-examined by doctors.
Mr. Hughes, a New Jersey Democrat, said in an interview that the backlog came to his attention because of complaints from constituents who had to wait six months or more for Social Security disability benefits.
"These people were dying before their cases were heard," Mr. Hughes said.
The pendulum seems to have swung toward a more lenient policy since the Reagan Administration, when officials were perceived as too eager to remove people from the rolls. Now some lawmakers say the Social Security agency does not conduct enough reviews. The 73,145 reviews done last year represented a sharp decline from 353,791 in 1988.
 
Limited Funds
 While acknowledging that the number of reviews had declined, Mr. Diller of Legal Aid said: "When Social Security reviews cases to see if people are still disabled, it finds that beneficiaries are entitled to assistance in the overwhelming majority of cases. Given its limited funds, the agency is right to deal first with new applications, rather than combing the rolls to root out the few people who may not be entitled to benefits."
Philip A. Gambino, a spokesman for the Social Security Administration, said 90 percent of the people re-examined by the agency were allowed to continue receiving benefits. After taking account of appeals, this figure rose to 94 percent, he said.
Judge Sand, like many other Federal judges, ruled that Social Security officials had acted unlawfully in refusing to follow appeals-court decisions. Until 1985, Social Security officials asserted that they were bound only by Supreme Court decisions and did not have to "acquiesce" in decisions of lower courts that contradicted their reading of the law.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Traders Say Rally Can Continue

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The surprisingly strong employment report released on Friday knocked out one of the four legs supporting a spectacular rally in the long end of the bond market: signs of continuing economic weakness. But it does not mean that the rally has to falter, traders and analysts say.
For the rally to continue, however, two of the other three legs will have to bear more weight. This means that news on inflation, the most important factor, will have to remain positive. And it means that President Clinton will have to continue making progress on his plan to reduce the Federal budget deficit.
 
Funds Pour into Bonds
 The market's third source of support has been the large flow of capital into bonds. This money has come from investment funds putting in new cash and from managers who missed the rally and are trying to catch up. 
 Holders of mortgage-backed securities, who have been hurt by the rush to refinance home mortgages, are also buying Treasury securities to help stabilize their returns. And state and local governments and other tax-exempt borrowers are gobbling up Treasuries for the escrow funds that are used to pay off the old higher-interest-rate bonds they are replacing with new, lower-rate issues.
So far, this flow has seemed oblivious to economic data, but that could change at any time. On Friday, this kind of buying accounted for much of the recovery in prices after the initial news of a 365,000 increase in nonfarm jobs shocked traders and speculators into rapid-fire selling across the spectrum of Treasury issues. After jumping to 6.84 percent, the yield on the 30-year bond recovered to end unchanged at 6.73 percent for the day.
"The market has not been responding to the data; it has been responding to the capital flows," said William Pike, a managing director at Chemical Securities. "And when the dust settles you can see that," he said, referring to Friday's market rebound.
 
'True Signs of Recovery'
 Friday's strong employment report took away the weak-economy leg. "We are getting true signs of recovery in the job market in this data," said Robert V. DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Brothers. As one example, he pointed to the decline since October of 628,000 permanent job losses. Until October, the number of people who had lost jobs had been rising despite the fact that the economy had already been recovering from the recession for more than a year.
The prospect of a weaker economy had supported Treasury bills and short-term Treasury notes, because some investors and traders thought economic growth would slow enough to force the Federal Reserve to cut short-term interest rates. Earlier last week, this view was heightened by some unexpectedly weak economic data, including a decline in factory orders, weak 10-day car sales and a jump in initial jobless claims. The new jobs data are likely to cap this rally.
This perception of weakness also helped support the 30-year bond and longer-term Treasury notes, like the 10-year, because a sluggish economy means there is no fear of a rise in the rate of inflation. In fact, the weak-economy view has led some forecasters to conclude that inflation will slip this year below last year's 3 percent rise in the Consumer Price Index.
A lack of weak economic news puts more stress on the other supports of the rally. And since belief in low inflation is a newly acquired tenet -- and deficit reduction is still only a proposal -- closer scrutiny could be troublesome.
 
Inflation Data Could Surprise
 For example, some argue that investors and traders have not been paying enough attention to actual inflation data, and that the February C.P.I. data, to be released on March 17, may provide a shock.
The January rise of five-tenths of a percent in the C.P.I. was shrugged off by traders and investors as an aberration. And there is not much talk about the surprising resurgence in the Commodity Research Bureau index, a closely watched monitor of inflation. Since Feb. 8, it has jumped to 207.09, from 198.46.
"I don't think there is inflation out there," said Peter McTeague, an analyst for Technical Data in Boston. "But the C.R.B. has made a pretty good move, and bonds have not paid attention. Either the market believes there is no inflation or the market is just in a frenzy and no one is paying attention to price or outside variables."
If Friday's employment data had been in line with expectations -- an increase of 126,000 -- or weaker, an increase in the Consumer Price Index of another three or four tenths of a percentage point might be less disturbing because slow growth would be a cushion. But that hedge is gone for now.
 
Priced for a Growing Economy
 "The market was priced for an economy growing at much less than 3 percent and an inflation rate of less than 3 percent," said Kathleen Stephansen, senior economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. But she said the jump of 365,000 in nonfarm payroll jobs, and other data in the February employment report, do not indicate that either growth or inflation will remain less than 3 percent.
A bad inflation report in a week and a half would make another leg wobble, and the weight of the rally would then have to rest on just two legs -- the still-unfinished deficit reduction and the continued flow of money into the market from funds trying to catch up and from state and local governments to do refinancings of old debt.
In the same way that inflation might get more scrutiny, Mr. Clinton's economic plan would then get a closer look. So far, investors and traders have decided that his plan will be successful. And there might be more good news for the bond market if a push by some Democrats for more spending cuts is successful. But given Washington's recent history, it is hard to rule out any complication, even just a temporary one.

HEADLINE: Murdoch to Sell New Notes

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, March 7

 BODY:
The News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch's global media group, has announced plans to tap United States markets for as much as $500 million in new funds.
The company, which in the last few months has floated a series of debt and equity issues that raised about $3 billion, said a subsidiary would issue stock known as liquid-yield option notes. "Proceeds will be used principally to repay bank debt," the company's secretary, Keith Brodie, said last week. 
 The issue would further dilute the stake in the News Corporation owned by Mr. Murdoch's family company, Cruden Investments. That is now estimated at 34 percent.
The option notes, with a maturity date of 2013, are to be exchangeable for ordinary News Corporation shares, at roughly 20 percent above market value on the date of issue.
The proceeds are expected to total $450 million to $500 million.
Stock analysts said the issue was a cheap and attractive way for the News Corporation to raise funds. The company, which was on the brink of collapse a little more than two years ago, last month reported a profit of $320 million for the six-month period that ended in December.
A spokeswoman for the Australia-based company, declining to give further details, said the issue had yet to be formalized in the United States.

HEADLINE: Violently, Drug Trafficking in Mexico Rebounds

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CULIACAN, Mexico

 BODY:
Without knowing of its reputation, without hearing it called "Little Medellin," it might be difficult to recognize this bustling provincial capital as the historic center of Mexico's drug trade.
The young men in dark glasses riding in chromed pickup trucks are harder to pick out these days in the traffic of businessmen's sedans and farmers in from the countryside. Where the city's three rivers intersect, construction has started on a $300 million project to reclaim the floodlands for a glitzy sprawl of shopping centers, residential developments and business parks. 
 The new Governor of Sinaloa state, Renato Vega Alvarado, would love to talk about how its vegetable farmers might take advantage of a North American Free Trade Agreement. He would rather not talk about drugs.
"It's just not fair the treatment that Sinaloa gets," he said. "This state has lots of potential."
 
80 Slain in 2 Months
 But in Sinaloa, as elsewhere in Mexico, the drug trade has been bursting violently back into view. On a single night in January, traffickers left 11 people dead on Culiacan's streets. In the two months since Mr. Vega took office, the local body count has passed 80, with most of the deaths believed to be drug-related.
The killings are just the most visible sign that four years after President Carlos Salinas de Gortari pledged to make life miserable for the nation's drug traffickers, the traffickers have adapted well. The more vigorous enforcement has helped to push the drug issue far down the agenda of Mexico's conflicts with United States. Yet officials estimate that as much as 70 percent of America's cocaine supply still flows through Mexico, leaving a trail of lawlessness and corruption that may yet complicate plans for a closer economic partnership between the two countries.
"The Mexican perception is, 'This is as much as we can do and it's more than what many countries do,' " said Peter H. Smith, a political scientist at the University of California at San Diego who studies drug-control policies in Latin America. "It is a strategy that can improve the tone of United States-Mexican relations. But I think many people recognize that it can't do a whole lot to change the objective realities of the drug trade."
Drug enforcement officials say cocaine traffickers, in particular, have shown their resilience by the steady evolution of the routes and methods they use to move the drug through Mexico.
Under pressure from the joint United States-Mexican air-interception program begun in 1990, the smugglers have stopped sending convoys of cocaine-laden planes from Colombia to northern Mexico. More than half of the cocaine shipped through Mexico now lands in the south, Mexican officials say.
 
Traffickers' New Technique
 In recent months, a new technique has become more evident: small planes hop from the lush Guatemalan highlands to southernmost Mexico, landing briefly on jungle airstrips or airdropping their bundles along the eastern coast of the Yucatan Peninsula or in the remote lagoons of Chiapas and Tabasco states.
Mexican helicopters are now scrambled in pursuit, but rarely in time.
Mexican and United States officials, who would discuss the trafficking operations only on condition of anonymity, emphasized that since Mr. Salinas took office, Mexico had seized nearly 200 tons of cocaine and increased its eradication of opium poppy and marijuana crops. But the officials also acknowledged that even the imprisonment of some of the country's most powerful traffickers had not necessarily curtailed their operations.
Until recently, an official said, Miguel Angel Felix Gallardo, considered the country's most important cocaine trafficker when he was captured in 1989, worked out of an office-cell in Southern Prison in Mexico City that was equipped with cellular telephones and a fax machine. Bodyguards performed clerical work, and bribes to prison officials insured that the operation was not disturbed.
Since his transfer to a more high-security prison in the state of Mexico, Mr. Felix Gallardo's communications have been limited to contacts with his lawyers, who are believed to carry coded messages about pending deals. But one Mexican official said the nature of the trafficker's business had expanded in his nearly four years in jail.
Rather than merely moving cocaine, the official said, Mr. Felix Gallardo, a former Sinaloa state policeman, has emerged as a diversified merchant of narcotics services. For less powerful traffickers, he trades on his connections to cocaine producers in Colombia, finances purchases, and helps launder profits.
"Felix Gallardo is really a sort of investment banker for the others," the official said.
 
The Focus Changes
 More recently, though, officials have focused on other leading cocaine traffickers from Sinaloa, Joaquin Guzman, 42, and Luis Hector Palma, 38, who are believed to act often as partners and are enemies of Mr. Felix Gallardo.
They have been identified as the authors of a wild shooting attack on Nov. 8 against the leading Tijuana-based cocaine trafficking ring, that of the brothers Ramon and Francisco Arellano Felix. The assault, in which gunmen with automatic rifles stormed a posh Puerto Vallarta discotheque where members of the Arellano ring were relaxing, left six people dead.
The attack blew another hole in the notion that drug-related corruption among the federal police was substantially reduced by sweeping personnel changes over the last 18 months. Among the 13 people charged in the shootout -- most of the Arellano Felix men got away -- were the local commander and five agents of the Federal Judicial Police, the investigatory and drug-enforcement arm of the Attorney General's office. All six were charged with selling the traffickers protection. Then they were released on bail.
The shootout among smaller-time traffickers that left 11 people dead in Culiacan on Jan. 19 would have been "almost irrelevant," one Mexican official said, had two traffic policemen and two young street vendors not been caught in the crossfire.
 
Killings in the Thousands
 In Culiacan, however, the effect of the shootings was gauged differently.
"The authorities are trying to pretend that the violence doesn't exist," said Alfonso Corona Sapien, a dental surgeon whose sister, Normal Corona, the area's leading human rights advocate, was murdered in 1990. "But it does exist and it has to be fought."
As Culiacan has boomed over the last few decades from a big market town into a metropolis of 700,000 people, the violence has grown. Over the last dozen years, 7,000 murders have been recorded in the state; the great majority are believed to have been drug related.
Some residents, including Dr. Corona, say the violence has changed. Last May, for example, two car bombs exploded downtown, killing a private guard and putting the sort of narcotics terrorism typical of Colombia on the Mexican map.
According to a leading Sinaloa economist, drug money is a great part of the explanation for the state's average economic growth of 5.35 percent over the last six years, a rate roughly double that for the country as a whole. And to businessmen like Hector Niebla, a 45-year-old box manufacturer, it seemed that the drug-related violence was a problem only for the traffickers.
 
Citizens' Movements Grow
 "Mostly you saw them killing each other," said Mr. Niebla, the head of a local manufacturers' group. "More than making you concerned, it made you happy: they were wiping each other out."
But since last year, citizens' movements calling on the authorities to end the violence have gained momentum. In the state election campaign last fall, the Governor acknowledged, drug-related violence was the dominant issue.
"People learned to live with it," said Rodrigo Esparza Cristerna, a lawyer who heads the Federal Attorney General's office in Sinaloa. "Maybe their cousin grew the stuff -- how were they going to turn in their cousin? The society tolerated it, and they are not going to tolerate it anymore. People thought it would not affect them. But it has."

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
A Lively and Long Friendship Is Over

 BODY:
Two weeks ago, Salsa Meets Jazz, the long-running series at the Village Gate that for more that 20 years brought together some of the biggest names in Latin music and jazz, shut its doors. The closing wasn't greeted with much public commentary or hordes of television cameras. Salsa Meets Jazz no longer had a fancy profile; after so many years, it had become low key. Pairing the finest salsa orchestras with the finest jazz musicians, it let them find common ground. The common ground often shook, and the shows worked, week after week. Like all things that are consistent, Salsa Meets Jazz had been taken for granted.
It shouldn't have been, and the program's death, from rising costs and a dwindling audience, makes the city just a little more musically impoverished. Under the guidance of Symphony Sid Torin, a disk jockey, and Jack Hooke, a music-business entrepreneur, the series began as a straight Latin music show and then evolved into something special. Over the years -- it took a decade off, between 1970 and 1980 -- it had provided an extraordinary meeting of cultures and some of the best music the city could offer. All the great Latin bands came through, from Oscar D'Leon, the James Brown of Latin music, to Eddie Palmieri, the music's crazy, brilliant uncle; Mario Bauza, Tito Puente, Celia Cruz, El Gran Combo and Mongo Santamaria all showed up. 
 Jazz players, eager for the chance to mix it up with the great salsa orchestras, would call Mr. Hooke and ask to be included in the concerts. Dexter Gordon, Dizzy Gillespie, Wynton and Branford Marsalis, McCoy Tyner, Clark Terry, Roy Hargrove and Kenny Barron all performed. The musicians and groups that straddled the idioms, whether the Gonzalez brothers' Fort Apache Band or the trumpeter Charlie Sepulveda, would be there as well, as would the Cuban expatriates, Paquito D'Rivera and Arturo Sandoval. Every show was exciting, and because there were no rehearsals, every show sparkled with the unexpected.
The audience was as fascinating as the music. In a city where cultural events are often segregated by age, sex, class, culture and race, Salsa Meets Jazz was cross-cultural before cross-cultural was hip. Bilingual second-, third- and fourth-generation Hispanic-Americans, male and female, turned up, as did their parents and grandparents. Tourists from all over the world came, as did people of all hues interested in the jazz soloists, or the salsa orchestra, or both.
Latin music and culture have been an integral part of New York's life since the 1930's, and the program signaled the presence of a complex, mixed society, part a product of heritage and memory and part the product of an indelible American present. Instead of the almost inevitable sense of division and mutual alienation brought on by diverging cultures, the shows illustrated that the two had more than a little in common.
And it was also a chance for the musicians to be taken seriously. Like most dance music, salsa places the audience in a more important position than the band, which is there for the dancers. It was no accident that the dance floor at the Village Gate was behind the rows of chairs and tables. People came to listen first, and then dance. The result was an audience that keenly appreciated the friendly cutting contests that inevitably arose between the hired-gun jazz musicians and the Latin players, who would gear up their improvisations under the challenge.
In the end, Salsa Meets Jazz may have been a victim of its own success. Latin music is by many accounts growing, expanding across its traditional cultural and linguistic boundaries. But when S.O.B.'s, one of the many clubs in the city offering Latin music, opened a Monday-night Latin-music series in direct competition with the Village Gate, the audience splintered. The small profit margin that an off night like Monday could provide vanished.
The recession had also been taking its toll, the promoters say. Advertising costs had risen dramatically. Ticket prices were forced upward, as band and transportation prices rose. The average salsa band has between 12 and 20 members, and they often had to be flown in from Colombia, Venezuela, the Dominican Republic or Puerto Rico.
At the last show, Ray Barretto's orchestra, from New York, played host to the tenor saxophonist Stanley Turrentine, and they quickly produced the sorts of miracles the series was known for. Mr. Turrentine came out and performed his "Sugar" and the tune "Footprints." For "Footprints," the band, improvising completely, produced a dense sound, boiling over with percussion and riding the tune's bassline. Mr. Turrentine stepped up to the microphone, and peals of notes poured forth in the form of guffaws, shrieks and complicated be-bop lines, all using his monumental sound. The audience, taken by the raw power of Mr. Barretto's band and the exuberance of the improvisations, loved it. But it was a minor victory in the face of a major loss for New York's music scene.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Elements of the Cure

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

 BODY:
Redesigning American health care, as Hillary Rodham Clinton and her colleagues are now trying to do, is a task daunting in its complexity. Those of us outside the debate find it hard even to grasp the terms: managed competition, global budgeting and the rest.
But there are some elements, easily understood, that I think must be part of any reform plan if it is to have a chance of success. I mean success in both the political sense of being enacted by Congress and the ultimate sense of working well. 
 A first essential is to end what The Economist of London has called "America's nonsensical link between a person's health care and his current job."
In this country, unlike the rest of the industrialized world, most of us get health insurance from our employers. The result is growing economic and human stress. Employers, beset by rising costs, seek to trim health plans. Employees feel betrayed. And they fear to move to better jobs or more attractive places because they may lose their health care.
A second point is closely related: Americans must be able to get health insurance regardless of their medical history.
Today health insurers keep a close watch on what they call "pre-existing conditions." They do not want to take on people who are statistically more likely than most to need medical attention.
This adds a cruel twist to the problem of job mobility. The person offered a great new job may not be able to take it because a prior condition will make it difficult to get health coverage.
Those two essential needs would be met by a reformed system that required the entities providing health care -- whatever they are -- to make it available to all individuals, regardless of prior conditions. Then each organization providing care would be funded in accordance with the actuarial profile of its members: their likely medical needs.
Under the approach that the President's task force is said to favor, the funder would be a regional cooperative. Employers or individuals would pay that cooperative, which in turn would approve different, competing plans for care, prepaid by a flat fee.
An approach of that kind would also meet a third essential of reform: to eliminate the vast burden of paperwork that now afflicts doctors, hospitals and patients alike.
Which of us insured, middle-class Americans has not had to struggle with successions of incomprehensible medical bills spewed out by computers? Administrative costs alone -- unnecessary in a rational system -- are estimated to be $70 billion a year.
It is even worse for doctors and hospitals. Both are subjected to layers of review by boards and committees, judging whether their costs and medical decisions were justified. Doctors have had to hire staffs to keep up with the paperwork: something unknown in other countries.
In a reformed system neither hospitals nor doctors inside a prepaid plan would bill anyone. They would work within annual budgets. For the consumer there would be no bills, and no need to claim reimbursements.
To state those necessary elements of reform is to realize, if one reflects, how difficult it is to frame a plan that attracts the needed support. For change has inherent tensions for all concerned.
Doctors, for example, long to get rid of the paperwork and bureaucracy. But those are the necessary concomitants of private, fee-for-service medicine, which most American doctors have traditionally preferred.
We the consumers want to stop the frightening rise in the cost of health care, and simplify its administration. But most Americans, when they are sick, tend to demand every test and procedure, regardless of how expensive it is or how remote its chance of success. That habit cannot be squared with a system that tries to hold down the nation's health costs.
The great danger is that President Clinton will be tempted merely to tinker with the existing system: put in some new cost ceilings here, some incentives for managed care there. That might look easier than grasping the nettle of real reform.
But tinkering would not work. Patients and doctors would think about how they might lose -- instead of seeing, and welcoming, the chance for logic and simplicity in our health care.

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Last New Nixon

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: PARK RIDGE, N.J.

 BODY:
"My partisan days are over."
Coming from Richard Nixon, who has raised more partisan ire than any American public figure in the past half-century, that's a stunning statement. 
 Back in 1966, the year of his first comeback, reporters listening to his longheaded world views would narrow their eyes and wonder about the "new" Nixon. I was present at the creation of his disarming and not defensive reply: "Of course there's a 'new' Nixon -- times change; there's a new America and a new world."
In 1993, at age 80, the American uniquely qualified to be foreign-policy elder statesman is renewing his role again. "There may be a need for a Vandenberg," he says, recalling the Republican Senator whose name is still associated with bipartisanship in foreign policy.
He has just returned from a grueling two-week private trip to Russia and other republics of the former Soviet Union. Today, he responds to an invitation from President Clinton to report his findings and help educate his youthful successor on global power-playing. A month from now, he's off to Japan and China.
Last Wednesday night at 9:40, the White House operator reached the former President in his New Jersey town house. The operator then could not find President Clinton, and apologized; Nixon said, "I'll wait; he's a helluva lot busier than I am." When Clinton came on, they talked for nearly 40 minutes.
I tried to find out what was said in that call (recommended to Clinton by Bob Dole and Bob Strauss) and received a mock-glower: one does not reveal confidences with Presidents. But Nixon returning from abroad always writes his thoughts and sticks to them; his long article on The Times's Op-Ed page, which was later looked kindly upon publicly by President Clinton, telegraphed his central points:
1. Boris Yeltsin is not hard to read -- charismatic, refreshingly straightforward -- and if he were replaced, we would not likely get a better hope for democracy in Russia, only a worse one.
2. The reformers need help from Western executives in developing an entrepreneurial class to attract private investment. In next month's summit in Vancouver, Clinton should have specific ways "to put some meat on the table," as statesmen say, and Nixon has a few thoughts about that.
3. Our stakes in Russia's reform could not be higher, because Clinton's budget package would be a dead letter if Russian nationalists took over and our defense budget had to be increased.
Nixon is candid about his liking for Russians. "I'm a Russophile, but not a Commiephile."
He takes a visitor on a world tour. On Bosnia: "I'm more hawkish than Bush was. You cannot work out a settlement unless there is a correlation of forces -- the arms embargo was a mistake. Your colleague Gelb is right about that."
On China: "They can never hope to attract Taiwan if they stomp on democracy in Hong Kong. I'll tell them that in Beijing." Trade pressure for human rights? "It would be a mistake for us to weaken the private Chinese economy -- that's the greatest pressure for political reform, and the next generation is more Chinese than Communist."
Japan: "It's really dumb for the Japanese to predicate help for Russia on four little islands."
America as world policeman: "Who the hell else do you want to lead the world -- China, Japan, Germany? The U.N.? Russia and all those republics could be lost to freedom if America abdicates leadership."
Clinton's call to arms? Looking out across a snowy landscape, Nixon gives an indirect reply: "By making freedom work here, we set a powerful example. We have to exercise leadership that makes the world respect us and build a society that makes the world admire us. You see misery in Moscow, but determination -- poor in goods, rich in spirit. That's the message to get across to kids these days. What a great chance for Clinton."
The 1996 campaign? Nixon, the old gleam in his eye, leans forward: "Republicans should forget about '96 and think about good candidates for '94 -- you can't win seven Senate seats with turkeys. In '66, two years after the Goldwater debacle, we --"
He catches himself.
"Nope. I don't want to reduce my effectiveness in foreign affairs. My partisan days are over."

HEADLINE: Japan Must Shoulder More of the World Burden

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Let Japan Choose Peace" (editorial, Feb. 21) describes the constitutional and military policy issues challenging Japan. Your figures about Japan's contributions of foreign aid and United Nations dues are correct, but leave a misleading impression. 
 Japan is limited to 1 percent of its gross domestic product for defense. It spends about 1/2 of 1 percent on foreign aid. The United States spends nearly 6 percent of gross domestic product for defense and about 1/4 of 1 percent on foreign aid. The United States economy is twice the size of the Japanese economy. So, we dwarf the Japanese (and all other countries) in defense spending. We also spend huge amounts not included in the official foreign assistance figures. The vast United States humanitarian efforts are only partly accounted for in foreign aid statistics.
Perhaps more significant, the United States provides global security for itself, Japan, the European Community and many other countries, as the world's only military superpower. For the common effort of world security, the United States percentage of G.D.P. devoted to this effort is about four times that of Japan's percentage-measured efforts. When translated into actual dollars and yen, this means that the United States effort is about eight times that of Japan.
Japan could do more. It could double its foreign aid every few years, adding more grants and untied concessional loans. Japan could help the United States provide security for the world principally by extending increasing amounts of concessional credit to poor countries to procure goods and services competitively.
Japan does not meet any concept of fair share in providing security for the world, if security is defined as both military and economic. What it cannot do militarily, it can seek to do economically. However, it tends to stress it is No. 1 in percentage contributions to foreign aid; that is pretty cheap when history has provided only a minimal military role for Japan.
And, of course, its assistance to the former Soviet republics is virtually nonexistent since Japan takes refuge in the Kurile Island question. Japan, unfortunately, looks for easy outs when it comes to meeting its foreign obligations.
 
HARRY L. FREEMAN
Chevy Chase, Md., Feb. 21, 1993

HEADLINE: Japan Must Shoulder More of the World Burden;
Noble Experiment

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Let Japan Choose Peace" (editorial, Feb. 21), does not go far enough. Not only the United States, but also the world has an interest in leaving Japan's "peace Constitution" intact. 
 The renunciation of war as a sovereign right of the nation and the prohibition of the maintenance of military forces are a noble experiment in world history. It has worked for 45 years, during which the country enjoyed peace and much economic growth. Let world public opinion support Japan to continue the experiment and urge the Japanese to live up to the peace Constitution by gradually disarming its huge and powerful Self-Defense Force.
The world has entered a new era. The Soviet Union is gone. Interdependence among nations has greatly increased. Instant, global communication is a reality. Globally coordinated efforts are called for. The world is ready for new ways to build peace. It's time to abandon the old ways of relying on weapons.
May Japan use its economic might skillfully to strengthen interdependence across nations, regions and continents, and to tackle global issues without threat of coercion. And may other nations adopt their own peace constitutions.
 
KOYA AZUMI
Mitaka, Japan, Feb. 24, 1993
The writer is a professor of sociology at International Christian University.

HEADLINE: Why Conservatives Will Keep Carping

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Mr. Clinton's Captious Critics" (editorial, Feb. 23) argues that Republicans should not waste their time taking "abstract potshots at government's legitimate role in American society." But it is the difference in how Republicans and Democrats -- or more precisely conservatives and liberals -- define the legitimate role of the Federal Government that explains much of the Republican Party's opposition to President Clinton's tax and fiscal policies. 
 The legitimate role of the Federal Government is expressly defined in the Constitution. Not that constitutional strictures limiting the role of the Federal Government seem to matter much anymore.
For more than 30 years, a Democratically controlled Congress, with the complicity of many Republicans, has routinely ignored these limiting provisions and expanded the role of the Federal Government beyond recognition. We have become less free as a result.
An uncomfortable fact of life, at least for conservatives, is that the state's ability to collect taxes rests ultimately on its power to coerce its citizenry. It is a power that should be used with discretion and explains why conservatives are loath to compel United States taxpayers into supporting programs that clearly exceed the Federal Government's constitutional mandate.
But more to the point: Do you really think that Americans reluctant to support extraconstitutional Federal programs or mandates (for example, high-speed rail, dairy supports, industrial policy, parental leave, training programs) should be given the choice of either paying up or going to Federal prison? It would appear the answer is yes.
However, I, for one, respectfully decline to be eviscerated to finance, as you put it in your best gray language, "a new level of government engagement," and I plan to continue carping and complaining. After all, to be captious in defense of liberty is no vice.
 
STEPHEN D. EULE
Washington, Feb. 23, 1993

LENGTH: 1709 words

HEADLINE: After 3 Decades Working in Senate, Kennedy Gets a Turn for His Agenda

SERIES: The Lawmakers: Portraits of the Powers On Capitol Hill -- Third article
of a series.

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
After three turbulent, sometimes triumphant and often troubled decades, Senator Edward M. Kennedy is entering a singularly calm, optimistic time in his life.
 For the first time since he accumulated real power in the Senate, he has a President as an ally. He has been a committee chairman during four Administrations, but he often fought Presidents Jimmy Carter, Ronald Reagan and George Bush over domestic policy. Today, his enthusiasm for President Clinton's vision seems unbounded. In a recent interview, he compared the new President to his own brother, John F. Kennedy. 
After an unhappy marriage, a divorce and years when supermarket tabloids paid more attention to his private life than political scientists did to his legislative skills, he has remarried. Now 61, he takes obvious pleasure in Victoria Reggie Kennedy's company and proudly interrupted a hearing a few weeks ago to explain he had to leave for her daughter's seventh birthday party.
 And even in the area in which he enjoyed continual success -- getting laws passed that he felt would help the sick and the poor and victims of discrimination -- 1993 looks particularly auspicious. For the idea he has preached from the political wilderness for two decades, universal health care, is suddenly at the center of the political stage.
 
Right Place, Right Time
 "In politics, as in life and love, a lot depends on being in the right place at the right time," he said recently. "That's certainly what's happened to me," said the Democrat who never fulfilled the destiny many saw for the last Kennedy, but is ranked by scholars and colleagues like Robert C. Byrd as among the most effective lawmakers in the history of Congress.
 As to Mr. Clinton, Senator Kennedy saw the President's opportunity as similar to Franklin D. Roosevelt's in the 1930's, and "30 years later, President Kennedy was beginning to move in the 60's." He said he thought Mr. Clinton understood "what the Presidency could mean in terms of domestic leadership as well as international leadership, and his own role in terms of history."
 This alliance might seem surprising. Last year's Presidential election was the first since the Lyndon Johnson era in which Mr. Kennedy did not consider running. And Mr. Clinton won last year by proclaiming himself a different sort of Democrat -- different from the old, big-spending Democrat, the Ted Kennedy Democrat.
 That stereotype, used for years by Republicans and some Democrats, had less validity in the 80's. With soaring deficits, the Senator tempered his views. Moreover, many of the areas where Mr. Clinton does want to spend money, those that fall under his general category of "human investment," have been Kennedy issues since before Mr. Clinton was a household word even in Arkansas.
 
Health Care Is No. 1
 He and Mr. Clinton may come to differ, though no cracks show yet. And if there is one domestic issue that the chairman of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee is counting on Mr. Clinton to advance, it is the issue of national health care. That is the issue for which Mr. Kennedy has been the Senate's foremost advocate since 1970.
 Health care is also the issue that first brought him and Mr. Clinton together. On Dec. 9, 1978, Mr. Kennedy made one of the most memorable speeches of his career, telling a party conference in Memphis that "national health insurance is the great unfinished business on the agenda of the Democratic Party."
 Plainly scorning the Carter Administration, he said: "There are some who say we cannot afford national health insurance. They say it has become an early casualty of the war against inflation."
 "Sometimes a party must sail against the wind," he said. "We cannot afford to drift or lie at anchor. We cannot heed the call of those who say it is time to furl the sail."
 Mr. Clinton, the newly elected Governor of Arkansas, was the moderator that day as the crowd roared approval with an enthusiasm that startled the Kennedy camp and encouraged the challenge he mounted against Mr. Carter for the 1980 Democratic nomination.
 
A Defining Issue
 Mr. Clinton, who had spent the morning boning up on health care, called it a "great speech." He told reporters he thought he had been chosen for the moderator's role because he was "neutral" on the issue.
 But that was 1978. Fifteen years later, health care is the ultimate measuring rod for his Administration, a staggering challenge.
 Mr. Clinton will need all the support he can get. In the Senate, jurisdiction on the issue is shared between Mr. Kennedy's committee and the Finance Committee, whose new chairman, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, shares his sense that something major has to be done.
 But in the Senate, anyhow, committee products are less determinative than they are in the House. This issue will surely be fought over and decided on the floor. The senior Republican on Mr. Kennedy's committee, Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum of Kansas, said of her chairman, "After all these years, he's not going to let it get away from him."
 This is the big issue whose solution has eluded him in 32 years in the Senate, as he played major roles on Vietnam, reapportionment, Watergate, campaign finance, tax reform, deregulation of transportation, education, medical research, and, above all, civil rights -- where he is now the Congress's unquestioned leader.
 
Dip in Reputation
 He established himself as the leading liberal of a conservative age, even though the event most recently set in the public's memory came on Good Friday of 1991, when he roused his nephew William K. Smith to go have a drink in Palm Beach. When Mr. Smith was arrested and charged with rape, Mr. Kennedy's reputation took another heavy blow.
 And before Mr. Smith was acquitted, the case effectively disabled the Senator from the role his followers expected in the Judiciary Committee's examination of the sexual harassment accusations Anita F. Hill made against Clarence Thomas.
 His reputation dipped even in Massachusetts, and polls suggested he would be vulnerable in the 1994 election. Continual appearances across the state, almost always accompanied by his new wife, whom he married last March, eased those concerns.
 The bumps that have upset his personal and political lives in the last few years have had remarkably little effect on his life as a lawmaker, or on the legislative tools he uses.
 One is staff. Year in and year out, Mr. Kennedy's aides are praised as among the smartest and hardest-working on Capitol Hill. Carey Parker, his legislative director, has worked for him since 1969. Most of his other aides stay several years.
 Senator Kassebaum's predecessor as ranking Republican on the Labor Committee, Senator Orrin G. Hatch, is the prime example of Mr. Kennedy's other major legislative weapon -- a knack for forming alliances with Republicans.
 For decades, Republicans have raised millions of dollars by using Mr. Kennedy as the pre-eminent symbol of liberal excess. The Kennedy specter has also been used, especially in the South, to help defeat Democrats.
 But many Republican Senators have been ready to work with him. In 1967, for example, he worked with Senator Howard H. Baker of Tennessee against Senator Baker's father-in-law, Senator Everett Dirksen of Illinois, over reapportionment. In 1991 the ally was Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri on civil rights.
 
Making Republican Allies
 Mr. Hatch came to the Senate from Utah in 1977 determined to fight Mr. Kennedy and the liberal ideas he stood for. Today a painting of the Kennedy family's Hyannis Port compound hangs in his reception room.
 When Republicans took over the Senate and Mr. Hatch became chairman of the labor committee in 1981, he found he could work with the Massachusetts Democrat far more than he expected. They worked together on a variety of health issues, including AIDS, and last year they pushed through the only urban aid bill Congress managed to enact after the Los Angeles riots, although it involved less money than either man sought.
 That ability to work with Republicans was especially critical in the Reagan and Bush years. The Labor Committee has an immense jurisdiction, ranging over all manner of labor and health and education issues. If laws were going to be enacted in those areas in the 80's, some Republican allies had to be found.
 This year, several other issues besides health care that are close to Mr. Clinton's heart will come before Mr. Kennedy's committee. They include the President's promises to improve job training programs; his hopes to tie college loans to national service programs; his commitment to improve health programs for children, and a range of other proposals.
 
Touchy Issues, Too
 And the Clinton Administration will have a major say in the committee's most time-consuming task of the year. Mr. Kennedy estimates that it will take six or seven months to rewrite the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, including an effort to adjust its formula for grants to take account of increasing numbers of poor children and the growing problems of big city systems with many children who do not speak English.
 And at odd moments it will be facing such hot issues as the Freedom of Choice Act, civil rights protections for homosexuals, replacement of striking workers, and the Occupational Safety and Health Act.
 But the biggest issue of all is universal health care. Over the years, Mr. Kennedy has supported one proposal and then another as he sought a majority. He tells a story to emphasize his attitude these days:
 Three geography teachers were competing for a job. The school board had a two-thirds-vote requirement to choose someone, and was bitterly split over whether the earth was round or flat. The first applicant was rejected because he taught the flat earth approach. The second was turned down because he was committed to a round earth. The third got the job, after telling the board, "I can teach it flat or teach it round."
 "I'm interested this time in practical solutions, in getting this done," Senator Kennedy said. "I'm ready to teach it round or teach it flat -- if it's universal, and cuts costs and provides quality."
