HEADLINE: Suburban Superstores Come To New York City Shoppers

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
Some of the nation's largest discount retailers -- the cavernous department stores, warehouse clubs and super supermarkets that for decades have shaped the shopping landscape of America's suburbs and small towns -- are coming to New York City.
With the price of the city's real estate falling and the appetite for variety and value growing, these discounters are now discovering that New York, like other big cities, represents the last untapped frontier for their low-margin, high-volume wares: more than seven million consumers and such a dearth of these stores that many New Yorkers drive to the suburbs to find them. 
 A handful have already opened in the city -- from the Kmart in Queens to the Finast in Brooklyn to the Bed, Bath and Beyond in Manhattan. The Home Depot and Caldor's have bought sites. And almost a dozen more -- including Pathmark, Wal-mart, Waldbaum's, the Price Club and BJ's Wholesale Club -- are mounting increasingly aggressive searches for space, particularly in Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx.
"It's an awareness of the awesome potential that exists," said Charles E. Lotzar, an executive with the Kmart Corporation, which wants to open more stores in the city, including its subsidiary superstores, Pace, Sports Authority and Border Books. "There's really no other place like it."
Desperate to fill the employment void left by the decline of manufacturing and the closing of some of the city's traditional department stores, the city's economic officials have eagerly welcomed the discounters that for years stayed away because of high costs. Now, in an effort to attract more, the Department of City Planning has proposed changes in zoning policies that some retailers and officials say have helped keep them out.
The arrival of these stores -- familiar sights along the nation's highways and boulevards, with their huge signs and sprawling parking lots -- could profoundly change the city, its neighborhoods and the sometimes idiosyncratic way that New Yorkers shop.
While officials and the retailers themselves say the stores will create thousands of jobs and raise millions of dollars in taxes, others warn that an unchecked proliferation will do to New York what it has done to other cities and towns. They darkly predict that the stores, with their high volume and low margins, will undercut and destroy the local merchants that have given the city's many Main Streets their singular character.
"We have to tread very carefully," said Bernd Zimmermann, the director of planning for the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer. "It's time the city addresses the flight of buying power to the suburbs, but there is a hefty amount of fear among small retailers that the market will be drawn out from under them. That has to be addressed, too."
 
Glut of Retail Space
 There was a time, in the early 1960's, when New York City was the retail center of the metropolitan region, accounting for nearly 50 percent of all retail sales. But as the retailers followed the flight of the middle class from cities to the suburbs, creating shopping hubs designed for the car, the city has watched many of its department stores close: Alexander's, Gimbels, B. Altman, May's, Ohrbach's, E. J. Korvette.
The closings have now created a glut of vacant retail space -- seven million square feet in Manhattan alone -- driving down prices by as much as $10 to $20 a square foot in Manhattan, where prices can vary from $40 to $50 a square foot, according to Charles Aug of Garrick Aug Associates Store Leasing Inc., who is doing searches for several discounters he declined to identify.
Now brokers and city officials say the dual effects of the lower rents and the void left by the closings has finally made the city attractive to the discounters. And after decades in which retailers, shoppers and money flowed to the suburbs, the arriving stores might reverse the flow.
"My belief is that we are watching the gradual re-entry into the city of the businesses that went to the suburbs in the post-World War II market," said Barry F. Sullivan, the Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development. "That market is relatively saturated. Now they're looking for ways to begin to come back in."
One indication of the interest was the remarkable bidding war between two regional chains -- the Caldor Corporation and Bradlees Inc. -- to buy six of the department stores left vacant by the collapse of Alexander's last year. As Alexander's wallowed in bankruptcy, Bradlees offered $82 million to buy the six stores -- two in the Bronx, two in Queens and one each in Yonkers and Valley Stream, L.I.
 
Bidding War
 Caldor, one of the largest discounters in the Northeast, countered with its own offer, said to have been at least $5 million more. The bidding culminated last November, when the two companies clashed in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, raising their bids 23 times in a single day, usually in increments of $1 million, until Caldor won with a bid of $120 million.
Caldor, which opened its first store in the city in Queens in 1990 and another on Staten Island in 1991, expects to open five of the six stores soon, possibly by the end of the year, with some 250 jobs in each. The other, in Yonkers, it leased to Bradlees.
"We were disappointed at the way it worked out," said Coleman Nee, a spokesman for Bradlees, a chain of 127 stores based in Braintree, Mass. "It doesn't mean we're not going to keep trying."
In addition to the discounters that have opened or hope to move into the city for the first time, others want to expand, opening larger stores, including Toys 'R' Us and Kmart, which has two smaller stores on Staten Island.
The Home Depot, the behemoth home improvement chain based in Atlanta, has bought a swath of land at the Aqueduct Race Track near Kennedy International Airport and has agreed to buy the closed Taystee Bakery plant in Flushing, Queens.
 
In Pursuit of Customers
 The chain has many stores in the region, particularly on Long Island and in New Jersey. As they crept closer to the city, opening stores in Paramus, N.J., in late 1990 and in Elmont, L.I., the next year, the managers noticed that many of their customers came from the city.
The company is now searching for more, especially in Brooklyn, said Larry Mercer, the president of the Northeast division.
The city's appetite for such stores certainly appears enormous. While Nassau County has one retailer with more than 100 workers for every 8,500 people, for example, the city overall has one for every 20,000.
Obstacles remain for the large retailers, though. The price of land remains expensive compared with the rest of the region and nation and the large parcels (usually at least 10 acres) that the stores desire are hard to come by.
Clearing such obstacles is a primary goal of the city's proposal to ease the zoning restrictions in some light and medium manufacturing zones, including areas left vacant by the decline of manufacturing in the city.
The city's zoning policy allows large retailers, like Macy's, in some areas, like 34th Street, but it also includes restrictions that require a developer to obtain a variance to build a store larger than 10,000 square feet in many commercial and manufacturing areas -- a process that can take years.
The proposal, which is subject to approval by the City Council, would allow stores up to 100,000 feet to move into these zones without the variance.

HEADLINE: Steisel's Standing Rises In Dinkins's Inner Circle;
First Deputy Mayor's Power Arena Widens

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Minute by minute, day to day, Norman Steisel, New York City's First Deputy Mayor, is at the helm in City Hall. He can often be spotted standing behind his secretaries' desks in front of his office at the far end of the main corridor. Phone planted firmly on his ear, Mr. Steisel barks out commands to commissioners and agency heads while his eyes survey the physical center of his domain, the long first-floor hallway through which most of the city government's movers and shakers pass each day.
It is not possible to reach Mayor David N. Dinkins's corner office without turning right at Mr. Steisel's hectic headquarters. These days, to reach Mr. Dinkins himself it is usually necessary to go first to Mr. Steisel. 
 Although he has been First Deputy Mayor since Mr. Dinkins entered office three years ago, only in the last six months has Mr. Steisel emerged as the pre-eminent figure in the Mayor's inner circle of advisers at City Hall.
 
Chief Coordinator
 And late last month, he demonstrated that standing on a very public stage. While the Mayor was in Japan on a trade mission, Mr. Steisel commanded the city's emergency effort after the World Trade Center bombing, coordinating the police commanders, fire officers, environmental officials and others.
Until Mr. Dinkins returned the day after the bombing, it was Mr. Steisel who presided as the city's chief spokesman at news briefings. Normally someone who functions almost exclusively in private and behind the scenes, Mr. Steisel found himself appearing on national television as well, including "Nightline" on ABC.
Mr. Steisel's rise in the administration is the result of the Mayor's growing trust in him, many senior mayoral advisers say, and of the departure of another Deputy Mayor, Bill Lynch, a longtime confidant of Mr. Dinkins's who left the administration last summer to work for the state Democratic Committee and is now the Mayor's campaign manager. Some say City Hall has missed Mr. Lynch's deft political touch, but others say Mr. Steisel's emergence has helped to streamline decision-making.
Mr. Steisel, who began in government 24 years ago as a budget analyst, has made his mark as a manager, someone whose intellect and passions are engaged by matters like closing budget deficits and increasing workers' productivity. He first came to public attention a decade ago, when as Sanitation Commissioner under Mayor Edward I. Koch, he won an arbitrator's order to reduce three-member garbage crews to two-member crews.
His admirers call him a superb technician, a problem solver with a deep understanding of government. Critics contend, though, that he does not exhibit a consistent strategic vision or a subtle political sensibility.
 
An Internal Referee
 Mr. Steisel insists that he is most interested in broad questions of policy and planning, but that the insistent demands of daily events often overwhelm his time and attention. "I probably spend most of my time firefighting problems, far too much of my time," he said. "Things sort of pop up on my desk."
As First Deputy Mayor, Mr. Steisel is responsible for planning broad policy on matters vital to the Mayor, including the budget, labor relations and health care. He also gets involved in planning for agencies overseen by the five other deputy mayors when significant issues arise, and he serves as a kind of internal referee when agencies disagree on a matter.
In a recent span of a few days, he presided at meetings or had long phone conversations on these issues, among many others: efforts to obtain more Federal aid or to get changes in Federal rules that might save the city money; creation of a new agency to run homeless shelters; relations with Jewish social-service agencies in Brooklyn; compliance with Federal clean-air standards; personnel management in the agency that oversees abused or neglected children; efforts by the administration and labor leaders to increase productivity in six agencies, and obtain City Council approval of legislation that would overhaul taxi regulations.
Through it all, he combines the erudition of a Harvard professor of management with the charm of a New York cabby, a combination his admirers say is precisely what is needed to move an institution as large and unwieldy as municipal government.
"Norman doesn't talk, he growls," said Betsy Gotbaum, the Parks Commissioner, who is an old friend.
"It's great fun working with Norman," Ms. Gotbaum said. "He's very smart. He's got a very good sense of humor. He'll go after me and I'll go after him. I respect his knowledge. I don't always agree with him. We have fights, but that's all right."
 
Feistiness and Feuding
 But what friends and some colleagues view as feistiness and sarcastic wit, other senior city officials sometimes see as impatience and arrogance. At a private meeting recently with senior officials on efforts to get more Federal aid for the city, Mr. Steisel needled a deputy budget director about whether a promised memo would include any new ideas. The aide bristled at his sarcasm.
"He can be very curt," said a senior adviser. "Norman can put people down, be very dismissive."
In one notable example that recently came to public attention, Mr. Steisel and Barbara J. Sabol, who heads the city's huge social services agency, feuded bitterly over how to improve the management of the city's services for the homeless and other poor people. Mrs. Sabol, in one memo, told Mr. Steisel that she had "come to expect demeaning and inappropriate responses from your office."
Mr. Steisel acknowledged that he can sometimes be brusque and impatient. "It's probably true," he said. "I don't tolerate fools kindly." But he also said he tried hard to listen to people and to take their thoughts into account.
When people re-argue an issue long past an appropriate point or fail to do what is in the Mayor's best interest, he said, "That's when I think I can be dismissive and perhaps even rude."
 
Earning Mayor's Trust
 Mr. Dinkins himself -- whose public manner is extremely courtly, though he too can be sharp with his staff in private -- dismissed the debate over Mr. Steisel's personal style. "Norman is terrific," he said. "He's a lot more patient than some people think."
"He's not supposed to be a diplomat," the Mayor said. "He's the guy who often has to deliver the bad news. He is perhaps not as diplomatic as some, but he's an awful lot more diplomatic than a lot of people I know."
Mr. Dinkins's trust in Mr. Steisel is now described by one senior adviser as "enormous." But when the Mayor took office in January 1990, Mr. Steisel was the only one of the four initial deputy mayors who had not also worked for Mr. Dinkins when he was Manhattan Borough President, and it took time for Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Steisel to forge their relationship.
Mr. Steisel's standing was also affected by the extremely strong bond between Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Lynch, who was deputy mayor for inter-governmental affairs and who had previously run Mr. Dinkins's mayoral campaign and served as his chief of staff when he was Borough President. Mr. Lynch's ties to the Mayor lent him the aura of a co-first Deputy Mayor, even if he lacked the title or the administrative authority of Mr. Steisel, who had had far more experience in city government.
But Mr. Lynch has been gone from City Hall since last summer and is putting together Mr. Dinkins's re-election operation. The Mayor and Mr. Steisel, along with other deputy mayors and many commissioners, said they talk on the phone constantly with Mr. Lynch, but his absence from City Hall has altered the internal dynamic of the Dinkins administration, many senior members said.
Mr. Steisel, who already oversaw a broad swath of the government, has taken on one of Mr. Lynch's major responsibilities, inter-governmental affairs, which includes relations with the City Council, Albany and Washington on everything from taxes to school aid to health care.
And with Mr. Lynch gone as a daily presence at City Hall -- as another center of power within the inner circle -- Mr. Steisel has consolidated his standing as the adviser on whom the Mayor leans most heavily and in whom he confides most often, many colleagues said.
 
Effect Measured Differently
 There is disagreement within the administration on whether his rise has affected city policies. Several officials said they felt the absence of Mr. Lynch's more gentle, consensual style, and his broad contacts in New York neighborhoods, when the Mayor was under attack last fall from Hasidic Jews in Crown Heights for his handling of racial violence in their area in 1991.
But other city officials said that decision-making seemed to be simplified in City Hall now that Mr. Steisel was firmly in charge. "It is such a sense of calm now -- everything is so much more relaxed," said a senior member of the administration. "There seems to be a lot less dissension, tension, being pulled in different directions."
Before, many officials said, any major matter would require the approval of both Mr. Steisel and Mr. Lynch. Though both tried to work cooperatively and often did, their different temperaments and backgrounds inevitably created tensions.
Mr. Steisel, a chemical engineer by training, has a short attention span. Mr. Lynch, a former community organizer and political operative, is extremely patient. "They could not be more different, except that they are both very strong-willed," said a senior mayoral adviser.
In any case, recent events have shown strong signs of Mr. Steisel's influence. He was quite proud, for example, of an agreement last month with sanitation workers to work longer garbage-collection routes and to be more productive in other ways.
City Hall has been rife with rumors that Mr. Steisel was looking for a new job, that he had grown tired of the 12-hour days, the 7-day weeks and the incessant crises that are the lot of a deputy mayor. He routinely declines to discuss the rumors, although he did say in a recent interview, "I've had from time to time offers of employment outside government."
Many of his colleagues said they assume Mr. Steisel will remain at least through the mayoral election. And despite his brusque manner, many senior mayoral advisers said they would miss him if he did move on. "I think he is genuinely a nice person," a colleague said. "Used to drive me crazy in the beginning, but I've really grown to like him."

GRAPHIC: Photo: First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel has emerged as the pre-eminent figure in the Dinkins administration, as demonstrated most recently by his command of the city's emergency effort after the World Trade Center bombing. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times) (pg. B1)

HEADLINE: Low Mexico Jobless Rate Is Deceptive

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
Mexicans are coming across the border by the millions, seeking work in the United States. And sidewalk vendors abound in every large Mexican city. Yet despite this evidence of people without jobs, the Government reports that the country's unemployment rate is only 2.9 percent. What's more, it is falling.
Not since 1953, when the Korean War brought boom times to the United States, have Americans had a rate so low. The Mexican economy is hardly enjoying similar prosperity. Rather than measuring national well-being, a 2.9 percent unemployment rate in a nation marked more by poverty than prosperity suggests to some Mexicans that the Western world's method of measuring unemployment is wildly unrealistic for developing countries. 
 That is certainly the view among several Mexican newspaper columnists, whose reactions to the Government's unemployment figure can be acid. "In more developed countries, the unemployment rate is 7 percent or more," Benito Solis Mendoza, a columnist for El Financiero, wrote recently, referring to the United States' 7.1 percent jobless rate in January. "One could conclude that in order for a country to advance, it has to raise its unemployment level!"
 
 
Scramble for Money
 That is partly true. Mexico, like the United States and most other Western nations, adheres to the definition of employment set forth by the International Labor Organization. In the organization's view, anyone who works one hour a week or more, and receives some income for this effort, is employed.
But in Mexico, where neither unemployment insurance, nor food stamps nor any other Government safety net exists for the unemployed, people have to scramble for money. And as they scramble, they end up listed as employed by the National Institute of Statistics, Geography and Information.
"In Mexico, where there is no unemployment insurance, it is a luxury that people cannot afford to stay without work," said Carlos M. Jarque, director of the Institute of Statistics. The unemployment rate, in fact, has fallen from 3.9 percent in 1987 to 2.9 percent today, perhaps an indication that times have gotten worse for Mexicans rather than better.
 
 
Street Vendors and Jugglers
 Many Mexicans without salaried jobs enter the vast off-the-books economy as street vendors or kiosk operators or even juggling three balls at street corners for drivers stopped at red lights, a not uncommon sight. If a driver gives a juggler a few pesos for the performance, that juggler becomes, for the Institute of Statistics, a person with work.
Half of the unemployed in the United States, in contrast, receive unemployment insurance, which means they are not under as much pressure as Mexicans to hustle for income, says Thomas J. Plewes, an associate commissioner of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics.
In the bureau's survey of 62,000 American households each month, the respondents are more likely than Mexicans to meet the labor organization's definition of a jobless person: actively looking for a job but without spending even one hour to earn income while job hunting.
A similar survey conducted by Mexico's Institute of Statistics covers 135,000 households a month in 34 cities and uncovers very few people not hustling to earn some money.
 
 
Half of Workers Salaried
 There are other yawning differences that help to explain why Mexicans are likely, in the view of Mr. Jarque and other Government officials, to continue to migrate to the United States in huge numbers long after a free trade agreement becomes a reality.
Only 13.5 million people, or 56 percent of the 24 million people in Mexico's labor force, draw salaries from legal companies or the Government. Only these people qualify for social security benefits in old age. By comparison, more than 80 percent of the 124 million people in the American labor force draw wages and salaries from corporate or government employers, and most Americans qualify for Social Security.
More important, the number of Mexican wage earners in the legal economy has stopped growing since 1991, despite the influx of foreign companies establishing manufacturing operations in Mexico. "Their hiring in recent years has been offset by cutbacks in government jobs and other layoffs," said Nestor de Buen Lozano, a labor lawyer.
 
 
Earnings Minimal for Many
 By measures other than the unemployment rate, hardship in Mexico is double, triple or quadruple what it is in the United States.
The percentage of Mexicans earning only the minimum wage of 14 pesos a day, or $4.70, is 18 percent of those listed as working, whatever their task. More significantly, roughly half of the work force -- in the legal or illegal economy -- earns what Mexican officials describe as two minimum wages or less. That is 28 pesos, or $9.40 cents a day.
"If you already own a house, a family of four people can live on a double minimum, but not well," said Gustavo Ponce Melendez, a Labor Department official. Many Mexicans say that even a small Mexican household, four people or fewer, requires at least 50 pesos a day in income, or nearly $17, to get by.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Yen Bonds To Be Offered By New York

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The Big Apple is going Japanese. New York City said yesterday that it had decided to include about $150 million worth of yen-denominated bonds in its spring bond sale.
The city's decision to sell what are known in the business as Samurai bonds is one borrowing innovation that municipalities are considering in efforts to reduce their costs. This will be the first bond sale by the city in any foreign currency. 
 By selling yen-denominated bonds in Japan, the city is following the example of corporations, which have already been selling their bonds in other countries and currencies. Denominating some New York City bonds in yen makes them easier to sell in Japan than bonds denominated in dollars.
Innovations like yen-denominated bonds are also beneficial for the investment bankers who work with the city, because doing new kinds of deals brings in more revenue. In fact, a lot of the new deals done by companies or municipalities start with the vision of investment bankers looking for ways to help their customers and to increase their own fees.
While the $150 million in New York City Samurai bonds is only a small part of the approximately $750 million of bonds scheduled to be sold this month, the sale uses high-finance techniques like currency swaps and interest-rate swaps, which protect the city from adverse fluctuations in the value of the dollar against the yen.
"This is the beginning of what we hope to be the expertise to take advantage of borrowing in other countries in the future," the New York City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, said yesterday in an interview. "It is very important for New York City to be as sophisticated as possible," she added, listing some other innovations, like floating-rate notes, she has tried in an effort to broaden the market for city bonds.
Ms. Holtzman said the city could save about $1 million in interest costs over the life of the bonds by doing the Japanese sale, although the final details have not been set.
 
 
Trips to Japan
 New York City has been considering such a sale for several months. Ms. Holtzman made a trip to Japan in January to present the city's case to large Japanese investment firms. Mayor David N. Dinkins was in Japan last month.
For the city, the real benefits of the sale may not come from this deal. The test will be whether it can develop this idea and begin to market itself abroad. The savings will then come from obtaining lower interest rates in other countries and from relying less on its regular domestic market.
Because of the complexity of the financings in this deal, the city had to watch several factors to determine if selling the Samurai bonds would produce any savings. Those factors include the strength of the dollar and the level of interest rates in the United States and Japan. The rates not only affect the cost of the currency swaps, but they determine how attractive New York City yields will be to Japanese investors.
 
 
Protection From Currency Shifts
 Under the proposal, a complicated transaction called a swap will protect the city against currency fluctuations and will turn the fixed interest rate the city is paying Japanese investors into a floating-rate obligation for the city. The floating rate will be based on the London interbank offered rate, which is a little over 3 percent now. The interest rate to be paid the Japanese will depend on the bond maturities chosen.
Darcy Bradbury, the Deputy Comptroller for Finance, said the floating-rate bonds that are swapped for the Samurai bonds are expected to have an interest rate, depending on the maturity, of between 100 to 125 basis points over the London interbank offered rate. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
"The economic conditions are getting very attractive," she said about the sale, but added one caveat: If the conditions suddenly shifted, the city would change its mind. "But we haven't seen anything that would indicate that this isn't something we should do," she said.
 
 
Treasury Market
 Treasury prices gyrated violently in light trading yesterday, as yields on the 30-year bond and on Treasury notes bounced around in wide ranges.
By the end of the day, the yield on the 30-year bond had slipped to 6.72 percent, down from 6.73 percent on Friday. As has been the case in recent weeks, the drop in yield reached a new low since the Treasury started regularly issuing 30-year bonds in 1977. The price was up 7/32 point.
But the yield had fallen as low as 6.65 percent as the bond made price gains in overseas trading. And as the rally faltered in the afternoon, the yield shot up to 6.74 percent.
Treasury notes followed the same volatile pattern. The yield on the 10-year note ended at 5.85 percent, down from 5.87 percent on Friday. But the yield traded in a range of 5.72 to 5.88 percent.
Traders said the market appeared to get a lift, both in overseas trading and in New York in the morning, from reports that Democrats in Congress had decided on a package of spending reductions to add to Mr. Clinton's deficit-reduction program.
But in the afternoon, there was some profit taking as prices moved higher. In the intermediate Treasuries, traders said that some selling may have followed another look at Friday's employment data and a decision that it might have been as strong as it looked. If that is the case, intermediate prices are high and yields are a little low.
Traders also said that the lightness of trading exaggerated the price and yield movements.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Marriott-Bondholder Accord Seen as Near

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
The Marriott Corporation said yesterday that it expects to reach an agreement with bondholders, perhaps as early as this week, that would allay their objections to Marriott's plan to split the company in two. But some bondholders said they would pursue their lawsuits against the hotel company, which they have accused of securities fraud.
Robert Souers, vice president of corporation information for Marriott, said any agreement "would be one that makes the bondholders more comfortable with our plan of action, but at the same time doesn't effectively change what we plan to do." 
 Marriott has proposed splitting its real estate operations from its hotel management business. It proposes that Host Marriott, the real estate operation, would inherit most of the Marriott Corporation's $2.9 billion debt, including almost $2 billion in bonds, leaving Marriott International virtually debt free.
 
$600 Million Backup Credit
 The corporation agreed to provide Host Marriott with a $600 million backup credit line through 1997, if needed. But the major institutional bondholders -- the California Public Employees Retirement System, Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association and Investors Diversified Services -- objected to the split, fearing that Host Marriott could not meet the annual $225 million interest payments.
Yesterday, the company refused to elaborate on recent reports in industry publications that the pending agreement with bondholders would shift some debt from Host Marriott to Marriott International.
An agreement to shift some debt to Marriott International would likely allay the fears of bondholders, but at the risk of depriving Marriott International of the flexibility and lack of indebtedness that was sought for it to pursue additional business. Under the original proposal, Marriott International would retain existing management contracts with some 750 hotels and motels and with 3,000 corporate and institutional cafeterias.
 
Real Estate Tax Revision
 Most of Marriott's debt accumulated from the company's ownership of hotels built before the 1986 tax revision law eliminated most real estate tax shelters. The recent recession further depressed property values, so that Marriott has been stuck with interest charges on some 140 hotels that it has been unable to sell. Host Marriott would inherit those hotels, along with their debt.
Whatever the terms of the new proposal, eight institutional bondholders plan to pursue their lawsuits, which are pending in United States District Court in Baltimore. The suits accuse Marriott and three top officers of securities fraud for selling bonds last spring without informing investors of their intention to split the company. Immediately after Marriott announced the split, the price of its 20-year bonds tumbled 30 percent.
"We intend to vigorously prosecute the action," said Lawrence Kill, the attorney for PPM America Inc., whose clients hold more than $120 million in Marriott bonds. "Our clients have been damaged substantially, and to the extent we understand the Marriott proposal, it is woefully inadequate."

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
Justices Say States May Make Union-Only Pacts in Public-Works Projects

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
The Supreme Court today validated a union-only master labor agreement for the $6 billion cleanup of Boston Harbor in a unanimous decision that cleared the way for states to use an increasingly popular tool for insuring labor peace on major public-works projects.
The decision in the closely watched case was a victory for organized labor. Justice Harry A. Blackmun's opinion for the Court overturned a decision by the Federal appeals court in Boston, which ruled in 1991 that the agreement violated Federal labor law. 
 The Massachusetts Water Resources Authority, the state agency in charge of the harbor cleanup, and an alliance of the construction trades unions both appealed the lower court's ruling. They were supported in the Supreme Court by the Bush Administration, despite an intense effort by the group of nonunionized contractors that had brought the initial court challenge to persuade the White House to switch sides before the case was argued in December.
The question for the Court was whether the National Labor Relations Act pre-empted the state's decision to enter into a collective bargaining agreement known as a project labor agreement, which includes a guarantee of union-only labor in exchange for a 10-year no-strike pledge.
 
State as Private Owner
 Under the agreement, first proposed to the state agency by the project manager, Kaiser Engineers Inc., all contractors and subcontractors have to agree to be bound by the terms and to use the hiring halls of the Boston-area Building and Construction Trades Council, a union group, as their source for workers. Any nonunion workers who are hired have to join the appropriate craft union within seven days.
Ordinarily, state and local governments are barred from interfering with labor-management relations in areas that are supposed to be left to the "free play of economic forces," as the Court put it in a 1976 ruling on labor law pre-emption. In a 1986 decision that the appeals court relied on to invalidate the Boston Harbor agreement, the Court ruled that the City of Los Angeles could not condition the renewal of a taxi company's operating license on the settlement of a labor dispute.
But in this case, the Justices accepted the argument of the state agency and the labor unions that Massachusetts was acting not in the prohibited role of a regulator but rather on its own behalf as the owner of the project. As such, the state argued, it should be entitled to the same flexibility that private participants in the labor market would have. A provision of the National Labor Relations Act that applies only to the construction industry permits employers to enter into union-only hiring agreements.
Justice Blackmun said today that "in the absence of any express or implied indication by Congress that a state may not manage its own property when it pursues its purely proprietary interests, and where analogous private conduct would be permitted, this Court will not infer such a restriction."
 
Late Reversal by Bush
 Massachusetts is under a Federal court order to stop polluting Boston Harbor. One of the biggest public-works programs in the country, the 10-year project includes the construction of primary and secondary sewage treatment plants, a five-mile-long tunnel to carry sewage for treatment and a 9.5-mile tunnel for the effluent. For the Massachusetts Water Resources Authority, the attraction of the project labor agreement was its promise of labor peace, making possible the uninterrupted work necessary to meet the terms of the Federal court order.
Project labor agreements are also being used in dozens of other public works projects, including the construction of a commuter rail system in California and the rehabilitation of the tunnel under the Baltimore harbor.
The Bush Administration was not initially involved in the Boston Harbor case, Building Trades Council v. Associated Builders, No. 91-261. Asked later by the Court for its views, the Administration told the Justices that the ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit was wrong and that the issue was an important one of states' rights within the framework of Federal labor law.
The Bush White House held to this position despite active lobbying by the Associated Builders and Contractors, a trade organization of nonunion contractors. To satisfy the group before the November election, President Bush signed an executive order on Oct. 23 declaring that Federal agencies would no longer award contracts for projects with union-only labor agreements. The executive order had no effect on the Boston Harbor project, and President Clinton repealed it on Feb. 1.
There were also these developments at the Court today:
 
Louisiana Abortion
 Without comment or noted dissent, the Court turned down Louisiana's appeal of a Federal appeals court ruling that declared its criminal abortion law unconstitutional.
The state law, enacted in 1991 over the veto of Gov. Buddy Roemer, outlawed abortion except to save a pregnant woman's life or, during the first three months of pregnancy, in cases or rape or incest that had previously been reported to the police. The law also had the effect of outlawing some kinds of birth control.
The Louisiana law never took effect because it was declared unconstitutional by a Federal District Court in Louisiana and by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans. Last September, the appeals court found the law "clearly unconstitutional" under the Supreme Court's ruling in a case from Pennsylvania last June that reaffirmed the constitutional right to abortion.
This was the second decision concerning a criminal abortion law that the High Court has refused to review since its ruling in the Pennsylvania case. In November, the Court let stand a ruling that Guam's law was unconstitutional. Gov. Edwin W. Edwards of Louisiana and Harry Connick, the New Orleans prosecutor, filed appeals in the Louisiana case soon after that. (Edwards v. Sojourner T., No. 92-1066).
 
Drug Supplies
 The Court agreed to hear a constitutional challenge to a Federal law, the Mail Order Drug Paraphernalia Control Act, that makes it a crime to sell drug paraphernalia. The law defines drug paraphernalia as equipment or products "primarily intended or designed for use" in manufacturing or ingesting controlled substances.
The case, Posters 'n' Things v. U.S., No. 92-903, was brought by the owner of an Iowa retail business that was found by a Federal jury to have violated the law by selling, among other things, chemicals commonly used in the manufacture of illegal drugs. The principal issue in the case is whether the law requires a specific finding that the retailer intended the products to be used illegally. In this case, the jury was instructed that the seller's intent was irrelevant.
 
Fugitive's Appeal
 The Court ruled, 5 to 4, that a person who flees after a criminal conviction and is then recaptured does not necessarily forfeit the right to appeal his conviction.
The decision, Ortega-Rodriguez v. U.S., No. 91-7749, overturned a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta. That court had dismissed an appeal of a drug conviction on the ground that the defendant should be punished for having fled before his original sentencing.
In the majority opinion today, Justice John Paul Stevens said that dismissal was appropriate only when the defendant's flight had actually interfered with the appellate process. Justices Blackmun, Antonin Scalia, Anthony M. Kennedy, and David H. Souter joined the majority opinion. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist dissented in an opinion joined by Justices Byron R. White, Sandra Day O'Connor, and Clarence Thomas.

Justice John Paul Stevens wrote the Court's opinion that dismissal of a convicted felon's right to appeal was appropriate when the defendant's flight had interfered with the appellate process. HEADLINE: CLINTON MAY SEEK LID ON DOCTOR FEES AND LIABILITY SUITS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
As part of their effort to control health costs, Clinton Administration officials are considering asking Congress to impose restrictions on medical malpractice lawsuits and limits on doctors' fees.
No decisions have been made. The proposals, under study by health policy experts at the White House, have not been endorsed by Mr. Clinton or reviewed for their political acceptability. 
 But confidential work papers from the President's Task Force on National Health Care Reform show that the Administration is seriously considering many proposals to limit lawsuits and payments for injuries caused by doctors' negligence.
 
Heated Debate a Certainty
 Doctors support many of the malpractice proposals, which grow out of the movement to curb liability lawsuits and are favored by conservative critics of the legal profession like former Vice President Dan Quayle. But doctors oppose fee limits' being an element of the plan that President Clinton is to send Congress by May 1.
The President has said he wants Congress to approve his proposals this year, but the legislation is sure to be complex and hotly debated.
A White House group studying medical malpractice says the current method of compensating injured patients and disciplining doctors "has produced only a litigation lottery."
 
Some Ideas Already Tried
 Among the ideas under consideration, some of which have been tried at the state level, are these:
*Limit damages for a patient's "pain and suffering."
*Reduce damages to take account of any money the patient gets from insurance or workers' compensation.
*Allow doctors to make payments periodically, over a number of years, rather than in a lump sum.
*Encourage patients to settle claims through arbitration rather than trials.
Supporters of such measures say they have produced benefits when tried in some states, particularly California.
In the context of major changes in the health-care system, the documents say, consumers "might accept some modification of their legally prescribed rights, some reduction in their potential financial recovery or some change in fact-finding procedures" in exchange for an assurance that they would be paid for injuries resulting from a doctor's treatment.
A White House official said Mr. Clinton was trying to balance concerns of doctors and trial lawyers.
In the 1992 campaign, President George Bush and Mr. Quayle charged that Democrats were under the influence of trial lawyers.
Ellen S. Miller, executive director of the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonpartisan research group, said members of the Association of Trial Lawyers of America gave $478,929 to Mr. Clinton in primary elections last year, compared with $75,015 in contributions to Mr. Bush.
In the campaign, Mr. Clinton said he would "reform medical malpractice laws" to take disputes out of the court system and to reduce the number of tests ordered by doctors.
 
Diverse Task Force
 The task force, headed by Hillary Rodham Clinton, has a staff of 300 to 400 people, divided into more than 30 committees. The panel studying malpractice is headed by Dr. Robert Berenson, a physician, and Kathleen Hastings, a lawyer and nurse. Dr. Berenson is a member of the Jackson Hole Group, an organization of health-care executives and policy analysts who are trying to mix free-market economics with Government regulation.
President Clinton has adopted many tenets of the Jackson Hole Group, named for its Wyoming meeting place. His plan would, for example, encourage people to get care from health-maintenance organizations and other networks of doctors and hospitals.
But work papers from the task force show that the Administration is considering a proposal that would give everybody access to at least one "free-choice plan." In such a plan, consumers could choose their doctors and pay a separate fee for each service they used.
Explaining the reason for this proposal, the staff of the task force says, in a confidential summary of its work, "Many members of the public want to select their own physician." In addition, it says, "physicians may feel more comfortable" if consumers are free to choose their doctors.
On the other hand, it says, "Free-choice plans are a major part of the problem that we wish to solve."
 
Cost of Malpractice
 Clinton Administration officials, like many health economists, assert that conventional fee-for-service arrangements give doctors an incentive to perform unneeded services, because the doctors are paid separately for each service. By contrast, a health-maintenance organization gets a flat monthly payment, or premium, for each person enrolled in its plan. Health-policy experts say H.M.O.'s have strong incentives to control costs, eliminate unnecessary services and provide preventive care.
The Federal Government says doctors spend $5 billion to $6 billion a year on malpractice insurance premiums, with hospitals spending half again as much. But malpractice premiums account for less than 1 percent of national health spending.
The American Medical Association says that "defensive medicine," which includes ordering extra tests and procedures, costs more than $15 billion a year. But the Congressional Budget Office says many of those tests and procedures "would probably be undertaken for other reasons." Moreover, it says, "the threat of malpractice suits may have improved the quality of medical practice."
Documents from the task force show that White House officials are considering stringent limits on doctors' fees.The panel is considering a national fee schedule like the one now used in Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly.
"Presumably," says one document, "the fee schedule would pertain to all payers: Medicare, Medicaid, private insurers and consumers paying out of pocket." The fee schedule could specify the amount that a doctor gets for each service, or it could set a ceiling. Private insurers typically pay 40 percent to 50 percent more than Medicare. Medicaid, the Federal-state program for low-income people, typically pays at least 30 percent less than Medicare.
The task force has not decided who should set doctors' fees. In one document, the staff of the task force said the Federal Government might set fees for the first few years. Then regional consumer groups, known as health insurance purchasing cooperatives, could set fees while bargaining with doctors and hospitals on behalf of consumers.
 
Campaign Is Recalled
 In the campaign, Mr. Clinton said he would set an annual limit on all health spending, public and private. The work papers show that the Administration is considering not only a rigid "cap on all expenditures," but also flexible goals for spending. If, for example, health spending exceeded the goal by 3 percent, "we could decrease hospital and physician payment rates by 3 percent," the work papers say.
The limits on health spending would not prevent affluent people from buying extra care.
Officers of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States met today with Ira C. Magaziner, a White House aide managing day-to-operations of the task force. Robert E. Patricelli, chairman of the chamber's committee on health and employee benefits, said the organization could support Federal legislation to require employers to provide health benefits to their workers, "provided there is a Government subsidy to help small businesses with a high proportion of low-wage workers."

HEADLINE: Zaire: Two Leaders, Many Problems, Few Hopes

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire, March 7

 BODY:
Two men now say they have the authority to rule this sprawling, impoverished nation, and their battle for control has paralyzed the Government and cast doubt about its future stability.
On one side, President Mobutu Sese Seko has denounced Prime Minister Etienne Tshisekedi as a bully and a megalomaniac, and suggested that Mr. Tshisekedi, 61, is mentally incompetent. The Prime Minister has countered by calling the President a "Zairian Caligula" who has kept his grip on this country for 28 years "without law, morals or principles." 
 Mr. Mobutu and his dwindling group of supporters control the national treasury, the huge state security apparatus and the armed forces. Mr. Tshisekedi ostensibly has the backing of the legislature, the High Council, which is dominated by the President's political opponents.
 
Unusually Odd Bedfellows
 So rather than keeping their distance, as feuding rivals might, Mr. Tshisekedi and Mr. Mobutu have been forced to run the Government together in an increasingly awkward power-sharing arrangement.
And the future of Zaire seems to hinge on whether their seemingly irreconcilable differences can be peacefully resolved. For the time being, the prospects look grim.
On Tuesday Mr. Mobutu and the High Council are to meet to try to unravel the contorted stalemate.
The two men met more than 30 years ago, and when Mr. Mobutu, who is a year or two older, siezed power in a coup in 1965, Mr. Tshisekedi was his Interior Minister. Mr. Tshisekedi helped draft the 1967 Constitution that established Zaire's one-party system.
In 1980 the alliance crumbled, and Mr. Tshisekedi was dismissed, exiled and imprisoned on several occasions over the next decade.
In 1991, while Mr. Tshisekedi was under house arrest, Mr. Mobutu included him in a new coalition Government. A month later, the President dismissed him. Last month, after Zaire's chief creditors -- France, Belgium and the United States -- insisted that Mr. Mobutu keep his promise to transfer power to a transitional government led by Mr. Tshisekedi, the President again tried to dismiss him.
President Mobutu also accused Mr. Tshisekedi of inciting mutinous soldiers to pillage the capital last month. Hundreds, including the French Ambassador, were killed.
 
5 Million, and Counting
 The issue was pay. In two waves of rioting, the armed troops protested being paid in new banknotes issued by the Central Bank, which is under the President's control.
In the second protest, the soldiers occupied the parliament building, trapping members inside and demanding that they approve the new banknotes, which were denominated 5 million zaires, or about $2. Following Mr. Tshisekedi's advice, merchants were refusing to accept the currency.
When Mr. Mobutu and the High Council meet on Tuesday, the Council will almost certainly insist that Mr. Tshisekedi remain as Prime Minister. And Mr. Mobutu will almost certainly insist Mr. Tshisekedi be dismissed.
Mr. Tshisekedi calls Mr. Mobutu's accusations of fomenting mutiny "insane, the ludicrous ravings of a dictator." Moreover, he insists that only the High Council can dismiss him.
"I am still Prime Minister, and I intend to remain so," he said during an interview in his cramped office in the rear of his modest home here.
 
Potential Is Rich
 The Prime Minister's ceremonial office in Gombe, a quiet neighborhood of opulent residences, is surrounded by armed members of the Presidential Guard, who have barred Mr. Tshisekedi and his staff.
The former Belgian colony's nightmarish economic and social problems have accumulated over 30 years of mismanagement and corruption.
Zaire is one of the world's major producers of copper and cobalt. It also has vast forests, plenty of rainfall and farming conditions suitable for cotton, rubber, coffee, palm oil and sugar, but these, along with its logging and hydroelectric potential, are largely undeveloped, and much of the modern industry was destroyed in the arson and looting that began in September 1991.
Thus the population has grown increasingly poor, while the President has profited on a grand scale since he took office.
 
Worst of Two Worlds
 A confidential State Department memorandum last month warned that Zaire was developing into "Somalia and Liberia rolled into one, with vast potential for immense refugee flows, regional destabilization and humanitarian disaster."
And never far below the surface are questions about whether a few generals are waiting to intervene if they decide this is all too disorderly.
In recent years, fears about military intervention have proved to be exaggerated. But anything could happen, especially if the soldiers are not paid on time. The decision in 1991 to allow Mr. Tshisekedi to assume a post in the coalition came after a week of looting and violence touched off by mutinous soldiers who were angry because they had not been paid.
Mr. Tshisekedi's return in September 1991, after seven weeks of political negotiating, hardly ended the violence, despite the fact that opponents to Mr. Mobutu got six of the 11 seats in what was to be a multiparty Cabinet.
 
Careers Intertwined
 Etienne Wa Malumba Tshisekedi (pronounced chee-SAY-kay-dee), a thickset man with a gravelly voice who comes close to being autocratic in style, presents himself as Zaire's long-suffering fighter for democracy.
Trained as a lawyer, Mr. Tshisekedi was Minister of Justice for the Congo, as the country was then called, when its charismatic Prime Minister, Patrice Lumumba, was killed in January 1961. It was also during this period that Mr. Tshisekedi first met Joseph Desire, a politically ambitious soldier who seized power in a bloodless coup in 1965 and who would later change his name to Mobutu Sese Seko.
Mr. Tshisekedi also served as Ambassador to Morocco and as national secretary of the ruling party and chairman of its political division.
 
Tracing the Break
 He has told various stories of how he broke with Mr. Mobutu. At one point he said the idea had risen spontaneously after soldiers killed nearly 50 students in Katekalay, a village in Kasai province, where they were prospecting for diamonds on land that the President considered his private domain.
At other times Mr. Tshisekedi has said he was a committed democrat all along, and quietly resisted efforts to turn Zaire into a dictatorship until he was outflanked by Mr. Mobutu.
In any event, in December 1980, Mr. Tshisekedi was one of 13 members of Parliament who signed a 51-page letter accusing Mr. Mobutu of an autocratic rule that had divided Zaire between "a few privileged people, scandalously rich" and the "mass of the people, wallowing in misery and counting only on international relief to survive as best they can."
For this, the 13 were stripped of their civil and political rights and exiled deep into Zaire's vast interior.
 
A Choice Means Treason
 In 1982 the group was convicted of treason for trying to form a second political party, the Union for Democracy and Social Progress and sentenced to 15 years in prison.
After his release in 1983 in a general amnesty, Mr. Tshisekedi suffered eight years of official harassment, during which he was arrested at least a dozen times and sent into internal exile twice. In one incident he was badly beaten by soldiers in front of a luxury hotel in Kinshasa only a few feet from a group of United States legislators on a human rights investigative mission.
But in the face of street disturbances and growing demands for greater democracy even from some of his staunchest supporters, in April 1990 Mr. Mobutu lifted the 20-year ban on opposition parties, opening Zaire to a multiparty government. Within months, dozens of opposition parties officially registered and, after forming a loose coalition, elected Mr. Tshisekedi as its leader. And Mr. Tshisekedi seemed the natural choice for Prime Minister when, in September 1991, Mr. Mobutu agreed to form a coalition government.
 
Parade of Prime Ministers
 At the time it was widely believed that Mr. Mobutu's fortunes had sunk so low that he would remain in power essentially as a figurehead presiding over a transitional government until elections were held. Since then, there has been a virtual standoff, marked by the appointment of five Prime Ministers in 18 months.
Mr. Tshisekedi spends most of his time at his private residence, surrounded by bodyguards and fawning staff members who invariably addresses him as Prime Minister.
It is a title, Mr. Tshisekedi insists, that is a "heavy burden to bear."

HEADLINE: Clinton Challenged on Share of U.S. Aid Going to Israel and Egypt

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration was forced by an influential Democrat in Congress today to confront the delicate subject of whether the United States can afford to pour billions of dollars into Israel and Egypt in light of a shrinking foreign aid budget and President Clinton's determination to resuscitate the American economy.
The Administration immediately said it was committed to continuing the aid, but the mere fact that Representative David Obey, the Wisconsin Democrat, was raising the issue meant that a sacrosanct item in next year's budget, which is just beginning to be debated by Congress, could be in for new scrutiny. 
 "There are also tremendous pressures on us, given the demands of our domestic economy," said Mr. Obey, who has long taken a very hard line on foreign aid spending, during a hearing of the foreign operations subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee. "There'll be tremendous pressures on the budget because of escalating needs with respect to assistance to the Soviet Union."
"I think that demonstrates that we cannot forever assume that we're going to be providing this high percentage of this bill to the Middle Eastern region. I think we have a right to expect over time to see that decline."
 
Pressure From Constituents
 Pressure is coming from the voters back home, added Mr. Obey, who heads the subcommittee, to change the practice. "People routinely call my office and say, well, with the budget squeeze, can we expect that Israel and Egypt are going to be taking a part of that cut?"
Of the $13.9 billion foreign aid budget for 1993, $5.1 billion -- or 36 percent -- will be sent to Israel and Egypt. By contrast, total aid to Russia for the last two years was a total of $650 million. Adding strain to next year's budget is the fact that Mr. Clinton has called for an additional $300 million in additional aid for Russia, but that money must be taken away from other countries.
Mr. Obey's remarks were reminiscent of an article on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times three years ago by Senator Bob Dole, the Kansas Republican, who said that the United States was going to have to spend a lot more money in eastern Europe and that at least some of the money would have to come from long-term aid recipients like Israel and Egypt, among others.
 
Dole Rebuked on Issue
 His remarks elicited a rebuke from Senate Republicans, who asserted that he created a false impression that American support for Israel was waning.
The new Administration has signaled its unflinching support both for Israel and for the Middle East peace negotiations, and even a debate on the issue of an aid reduction would be read in Jerusalem as an effort to undermine the Government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, which took office last year.
In the hearing today, Edward P. Djerejian, Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, was just as blunt as Mr. Obey in saying the new Administration had no intention of reducing aid to either country.
"Both President Clinton and Secretary Christopher have gone on record regarding the importance of continuing the aid to Israel and Egypt at the current levels," Mr. Djerejian said, referring to Secretary of State Warren Christopher. "We remain steadfast in our commitment to direct substantial foreign aid resources to the security of Israel, to support for Egypt's vital role in the stability and security of the region, and to promotion of comprehensive and lasting peace in the Middle East."
 
Arms Purchases Criticized
 Mr. Obey criticized the practice by which Egypt, and to a lesser extent Israel, buy vast amounts of military equipment from the United States under the assumption that there will be continuing American aid to pay for it over the years.
"It is, in fact, going to be virtually impossible for this committee to consider reductions in aid to that region over the next decade if those military contracts continue to be signed because of the principle of so-called cash flow financing," said Mr. Obey, who called on the new Administration to abandon the practice.
He also criticized both Egypt, and Israel to a lesser extent, for failing to institute the changes necessary to make their economies more healthy. "For a number of years, people have looked at the Egyptian program as being a black hole, and I think there is more than a little concern about the ability of the Israeli Government to get its own economic house in order."
 
'Moving Up the Pace'
 Mr. Djerejian gave a spirited defense of both countries' attempts at economic liberalization. But he acknowledged, "There's a serious question of moving up the pace of economic reforms in Israel, and we will be engaged on this very actively."
As for Egypt, Mr. Djerejian conceded, "The Egyptian economy remains dominated by large, inefficient public sector monopolies, the activities of private businessmen remain heavily restricted, and the regulatory environment remains extremely uncertain."
On another foreign aid issue, Mr. Djerejian said that the Clinton Administration hopes to give Jordan $50 million in security aid that has been withheld by Congress because of Jordanian support for President Saddam Hussein of Iraq after his 1990 invasion of Kuwait.
 
Sanctions Against Iraq
 Mr. Djerejian said that he will recommend shortly to Mr. Christopher that he release the funds, in part to support Jordan's helpful role in the Middle East peace negotiations. He also said that in recent months Jordan has tightened sanctions against Iraq.
During and after the Persian Gulf crisis, Jordanian officials, including King Hussein, repeatedly said the kingdom was doing all it could to enforce the sanctions. But American intelligence reports indicated that there were substantial violations of the sanctions and little policing of the border with Iraq, a situation that worsened relations between the two countries.
The decision to send the aid does not need to be approved by Congress, although there remains considerable resistance to it on Capitol Hill and it is unlikely the Administration will move on the matter without considerable consultation with Congress. Last September, the Bush Administration, after consultations with Congress, dispensed $55 million in security and economic aid to Jordan that had not gone forward in 1991.

HEADLINE: Like a New Drug, Social Programs Are Put to the Test

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
"WHAT is an ordinary member of the tribe to do when the witch doctors disagree?" Henry Aaron, an economist at the Brookings Institution, lamented in 1978.
Often not much, which is one reason Washington has seemed inclined to write off social science as special pleading. But a new breed of social scientists offers an answer more likely to satisfy the skeptics. Social policies, they assert, can be definitively tested in controlled experiments using randomly selected subjects, much the way drug companies test new treatments for asthma or arthritis or hypertension. 
 Such experiments are not always practical or, for that matter, ethical. Hardly anyone, for example, would wish to estimate the fraction of the unemployed who are malingering by randomly denying jobless benefits to every other applicant. But in other contexts, controlled social science experiments can be designed and have been used to measure policy changes ranging from higher copayments for health insurance to no-strings income supports for the poor.
More recent experiments designed and monitored by the Manpower Demonstration and Research Corporation, a nonprofit organization spun off from the Ford Foundation in 1974, have had enormous impact on the direction of welfare reform. And with admirers in high places, the experimenters are likely to influence everything from the design of public schools that work to so-called managed competition in health care, in which prepaid health plans such as H.M.O.'s would compete for the health insurance business of consumers.
Until the 1980's most social policy research was built around one of two related techniques. The cheapest method was, and still is, to infer causality from existing data. Economists, for example, have exploited the fact that states have different minimum wages to estimate the effect of changing the legal minimum on unemployment.
But such measurements require the analyst to isolate the influence of one factor -- in this case, the wage floor -- from all the others that might explain differing rates of unemployment. And that task is as much an art as a science.
Worse, suggests Orley Ashenfelter, an economist at Princeton University who was in charge of evaluating Labor Department programs in the early 1970's, it is an invitation to sophistry. Statistical modeling, he bluntly puts it, "leaves too many ways for the researcher to fake it."
Much of the social research commissioned by Washington has, in fact, relied on the collection of new data. If, for example, researchers wanted to measure the effect of paying dropouts to attend night school, they might compare the progress of program participants with a statistically similar group of dropouts culled from nonexperimental sources like United States Census surveys.
Unfortunately, there is a catch: choosing the comparison group requires assumptions that are no less difficult, or arbitrary, than the process of deciding which factors should be accounted for in the sort of statistical model used to measure the impact of the minimum wage.
It should not be surprising then that one analysis of women enrolled in programs under the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act showed average annual income gains of $800 to $1,300, while another estimated the average gain at just $13. Nor should it be surprising that the Labor Department's own technical advisers judged that the use of conventional methods to evaluate the Job Training and Partnership Act would be a waste of effort.
In light of the tangles created by nonexperimental methods, it is a puzzle why controlled experiments in social policy were so long the exception rather than the rule. One explanation is that the conclusions of the most important of the early experiments, a series of tests of what economists call the negative income tax that ran from the late 1960's to the mid-70's, were both unexpected and unwelcome to those who commissioned them. The evidence suggested that generous, no-strings financial support reduced the work effort of the poor and actually added to the instability of welfare-dependent families.
Another explanation, given by Judith Gueron, president of the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, is that early research was not intended to provide simple, transparent conclusions that busy policy makers could absorb from a few paragraphs or a few numbers.
The manpower research organization, with offices in New York and San Francisco, was not the first, nor is it the only player in the social experiment game. Mathematica Policy Research of Princeton, N.J., and Apt Associates of Cambridge, Mass., are both active in a number of projects. But by all accounts M.D.R.C.'s research has been the most influential.
One reason, says Peter Szanton, a consultant in Washington who was an associate director of the White House budget office in the Carter Administration, is that the nonprofit organization has worked overtime to establish the credibility of controlled experiments. It routinely provides briefings for Federal agencies, Congressional staff members and the press.
Ms. Gueron, whom Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a New York Democrat, has affectionately dubbed "Our Lady of Modest but Positive Results," is the first to point out that the low-cost welfare-to-work experiments in the 1980's generated only marginal improvements in income for the typical participant.
Most important, the research group frames its results as straightforward comparisons between randomly chosen subjects and members of control groups, the numerical equivalent of before-and-after photos that Mr. Szanton says "leaves little to argue about."
For example, in its evaluation of Arkansas' jobs search and work experience program called Work, the researchers estimated that the program cost $118 per subject, while raising average annual earnings by $242 compared with the control group during the three-year follow-up period. The study also found that welfare payments to participants fell by an average of $168 a year, thus generating small but significant gains for both participants and taxpayers.
Little to argue about, perhaps, but still enough to generate intellectual heat. James Heckman, a University of Chicago economist, challenges the conventional wisdom that controlled random experiments are less subject to bias than the alternatives.
 
Unplanned Change in Study
 He points out that the prospect of languishing in the control group may alter the initial pool of volunteers for the same reason that desperately ill cancer patients often refuse to participate in controlled studies of new drugs. And he notes that relegation to the control group may alter participants' incentives in ways that are hard to predict. Those who are denied job training, for example, may work harder to compensate for their second-class status, a phenomenon Mr. Heckman calls the "John Henry effect."
Irwin Garfinkel, a visiting scholar at Princeton University's Woodrow Wilson School, offers a very different criticism. An experiment may accurately measure the effect on participants, he argues, yet provide little insight into what would happen if the program were expanded to serve the entire target population or added to a broader mix of social services.
This tension between "micro" experiment and "macro" effect can cut either way. A job placement program may show promising results, but only because it displaces workers who were not in the experiment. On the other hand, a preschool enrichment program may not improve reading scores five years down the road unless most children in the neighborhood participate.
But for Gary Burtless, an economist at the Brookings Institution, these criticisms add up to no more than a reminder that controlled experiments demand cautious interpretation. Their only serious drawback compared with other evaluation methods, he says, is cost. And even that liability must be put in perspective.
While the bill for a big experiment typically runs into millions of dollars, Ms. Gueron notes that most of the money is spent to provide services and collect information about participants, costs that are not unique to controlled experiments. Thus the savings in opting for the conventional matched-group method rather than random controls are generally modest.
Mr. Ashenfelter has little patience for what he sees as a pennywise attitude toward experiments. In the 1960's and 1970's, he points out, Washington invested billions of dollars on job training without a clue about what worked and what did not.
 
Exposure of Myths
 That is an error unlikely to be repeated soon. The findings from 11 regional experiments in the 1980's, directed by M.D.R.C. and financed by both the Ford Foundation and state governments, are credited by Mr. Moynihan, who was then chairman of the Senate's subcommittee on family policy, with providing the grounds for a Congressional consensus on overhauling the welfare system.
Liberals were driven to face up to what Mr. Moynihan calls "the myth of social activism," in which dependence was viewed as primarily the fault of an ungenerous state. For their part, conservatives were forced to acknowledge that a brief period of training and help in searching for a job was no panacea for breaking the cycle of poverty.
The result, the Family Support Act of 1988, required states to set up far more ambitious welfare-to-work programs that include most welfare recipients. It also required Washington to evaluate these programs using randomized experiments. The manpower research group has a contract to manage the research.
Washington does not demand experiment-based monitoring of other social programs. But there is good reason to assume that the Clinton Administration will be eager to expand its uses.
For one thing, President Clinton approves. Last month he offered the National Governors Association a freer hand in experimenting with policy reforms. But "if you're going to be able to experiment in projects that use Federal dollars, let's measure the experiment," he pleaded. "Let's be honest about it."
For another, his Administration is chock full of believers: Alice Rivlin, the deputy director of the White House budget office, even wrote a book in 1972 urging controlled policy experiments.
Most important, perhaps, this Administration has a big appetite for changing the world and very little money to indulge that appetite. "President Clinton simply cannot afford to invest in programs that do not work," said Mr. Ashenfelter, "and I expect he knows it."
 
 
 
SOCIAL RESEARCH IN REAL LIFE
 As of May 1991, David Greenburg of the University of Maryland and Mark Shroder of the University of Wisconsin's Institute for Research on Poverty counted 63 controlled social experiments completed and 28 in progress. Here are some current projects:
Do families given the cash equivalent of their food stamp allotments buy less food?
Agency: The Department of Agriculture
Test sites: San Diego and Alabama
Evaluator: Mathematica Policy Research
Expected completion: 1993
 
What is the impact of providing social services and job training to the parents and siblings of children in Headstart?
Agency: The Department of Health and Human Resources
Test sites: Nationwide
Evaluator: Apt Associates
Expected completion: 1995
 
What is the effect of providing different levels of day care for children of poor families?
Agency: The Rockefeller Foundation, along with a number of Federal agencies and other private foundations.
Test Sites: Not yet chosen
Evaluator: Mathematica Policy Research
Expected Completion: Not known
 
Can generous wage subsidies help wean people off welfare?
Agency: The Canadian Government
Test sites: Four cities in New Brunswick and British Columbia.
Evaluator: Social Research and Demonstration Corporation a spinoff from the Manpower Demonstration Research Copration.
Expected Completion: 2000

Can home health care services reduce the rate of institutionalization of the elderly poor?
Agency: The Department of Health and Human Services
Test Sites: Selected counties in seven states
