HEADLINE: Jury Could Hear Rodney King Today

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 8

 BODY:
Still appearing frightened and reclusive, clearly burdened by his role as a symbol, Rodney G. King has had only a few stumbling words to say in public since he was beaten by the police two years ago. And in private, talking about the beating to investigators, he has sometimes contradicted himself.
Now, in the prosecution's biggest gamble, he is expected as early as Tuesday to testify for the first time against the four officers accused of violating his civil rights. 
 His testimony could change the course of the trial, but nobody knows just what he will say. Innocent victim or aggressive felon, the man the jurors see on the stand could influence the way they view the videotaped beating.
Mr. King's pain and bewilderment were evident in his emotional statement at the height of the riots last May 1. "People," he began, "I just want to say, can we all get along? Can we get along?" And he concluded: "We've just got to, just got to. We're all stuck here for a while. Let's try to work it out. Let's try to work it out."
 
No Stranger to Trouble
 But more frequently, the 27-year-old unemployed construction worker has been seen here in police custody, once accused of drunken driving, once accused of beating his wife and once for driving his car at an undercover officer after being surprised with a transvestite prostitute. No charges were filed in any of the cases.
In a state trial of the four officers last year, prosecutors chose to avoid the risks of bringing Mr. King to the witness stand and trusted instead in the power of the videotape that shows him being beaten and kicked for 81 seconds.
This gap in their presentation left the way open for defense lawyers to portray Mr. King as "an animal," a dangerous, almost superhumanly strong felon, sweating, grunting, violent and impervious to pain.
Sgt. Stacey C. Koon, Officers Laurence M. Powell and Theodore J. Briseno and former Officer Timothy E. Wind were acquitted of assualt charges last April 29, touching off days of rioting. They now face possible 10-year prison terms on civil rights charges that they used excessive force when they arrested Mr. King for speeding.
 
'Real Human Beings'
 "The jurors had the defendants as real human beings to identify with and sympathize with but no human being on the prosecution side of the case," said Erwin Chemerinsky, a law professor at the University of Southern California. "Rodney King could provide that."
But Mr. King does have a criminal record, for armed robbery, and his actions on March 3, 1991, did contribute to the events that followed, all elements that defense lawyers are likely to focus on. One of them said today he expects Mr. King to undergo cross-examination for at least a full day.
Aware of the risks, the prosecutors have gone out of their way to play down Mr. King's testimony, sandwiching his appearance between those of expert witnesses and acknowledging his problems to the jury from the start.
"He will tell you that he was on parole and that he broke the law on the night of the incident," said a prosecutor, Steven D. Clymer, in his opening statement Feb. 25. "He was drunk while driving, and he was speeding as he tried to get away from the police.When they tried to handcuff him, he resisted."
 
'A Very Poor Memory'
 Furthermore, said Mr. Clymer, an assistant United States attorney, "I expect Rodney King will tell you that because of the beating he has a very poor memory of the incident. He has made several statements that are inconsistent, with different versions of the events."
But he emphasized: "Rodney King is not on trial. The issue of whether he was guilty or innocent that night is not the issue in this trial."
These statements are part of a prosecution tactic, said Peter Arenella, a law professor at the University of California, Los Angeles.
"A basic message the prosecution wants to send to the jury is that they do not have to choose between King and the officers as to who is ultimately more sympathetic and appealing," he said. "They are going to do their best to educate the jury that even a criminal who is clearly resisting lawful authority retains the constitutional right to be free from excessive force."
Mr. King's few public statements since the beating, including his remarks during the rioting, portray a man struggling to understand his role in the events that have grown from the beating captured on amateur videotape.
 
Kept Out of Sight
 He has remained sequestered by his lawyer, Milton Grimes, living at an undisclosed location and rarely appearing in public. People who have talked with him describe him as nervous and sometimes confused.
Last December, Mr. Grimes announced that he was raising Mr. King's profile and would take him on speaking tours around the country. But this plan ended after one visit to a school classroom and one appearance on a call-in show at a local black radio station, KJLH-FM.
In that appearance, Mr. King gave brief, sometimes one-word answers to questions and seemed uncomfortable in a public setting. His one unforced moment came in a burst of spontaneous laughter over his discovery last year that the prostitute in his car was a transvestite.
When he is recognized in public, he said, he sometimes gets the feeling, especially from white people, that he is a problem to them, a cause of the city's turmoil. But he was unable to find words to express his reaction to finding his name linked to the devastating rioting.
 
'Like a Crushed Can'
 Mr. King's formal statements about the beating have been inconsistent regarding his drinking that night, about possible racial epithets used by the police and about other details, including when he was handcuffed.
In his grand jury testimony last July, he told one of the prosecutors, Barry F. Kowalski, that he could not remember the order in which events occurred. But he did not hesitate when Mr. Kowalski asked him how he felt at the end of the beating.
"I just felt horrible," Mr. King said, in a glimpse of the sort of testimony he may give in court. "I felt beat up and like a crushed can. That's what I felt like, like a crushed can all over, and my spirits were down, real low."
During the beating, he told the grand jury, the officers taunted him, saying repeatedly, "What's up? What's up, killer? How you feel now, killer?" In a separate earlier statement to investigators he said the officers also repeatedly used a racial epithet.
 
The Crucial Point
 This portrait of the police officers, if it is accepted by the jurors, would suggest that the officers were meting out summary punishment to a man who had angered them, as the prosecutors charge. This point is important because the prosecutors need to prove that the officers intentionally harmed Mr. King in violation of his civil rights.
As for his own actions, Mr. King said he never attacked the officers but was trying to protect himself from the relentless baton blows and jolts of electricity from a Taser stun gun.
In the earlier interview, with the District Attorney's office four months after the beating, Mr. King said: "What was I doing? Saying to myself, it's going to be over, it's going to be over, it's going to, just hang in there, just hang in there, it's going to be over soon."
When it finally was over, Mr. King said, he was left alone in a hospital bed thinking the thoughts of a beaten man.
"Damn, I felt so defenseless, useless," he said in the same interview. "Who am I, who am I to say I'm not -- who am I to say I didn't do this? That's what I was thinking about when I was lying in the bed sick. Who's going to believe you? Who's going to believe you?"

HEADLINE: Reviving the Education Department

 BODY:
President Clinton has wisely indicated that broad investment in education, like expansion of Head Start, retraining of workers and national service to help pay for college, is a vital part of his economic recovery program. But beyond these lofty proposals there are two key reforms his Administration needs to make: revitalize the moribund Department of Education, and revamp the Chapter 1 program, the main vehicle for Federal aid to improve the academic skills of poor children.
Mr. Clinton's choice of a trusted mentor, Richard Riley, as Secretary of Education was well received. Mr. Riley led a comprehensive effort to improve schools during two terms as Governor of South Carolina. His new deputy, former Gov. Madeleine Kunin of Vermont, also had a strong interest in education. 
 Created as a cabinet-level agency in 1980 at the end of the Carter Administration, the department has endured 12 years of neglect. Ronald Reagan wanted to abolish the agency, but was frustrated by his own Secretary of Education, Terrel Bell. George Bush said he would be the "education President," but his Administration used the department to tout choice among public, private and parochial schools, with Government vouchers to pay the bill. The Administration's preoccupation with this polarizing issue helped sour relations with Congress and stalled progress on issues like national standards and testing.
At his confirmation hearing, Mr. Riley outlined three laudable objectives: improving the quality of education for all students, assuring access and helping all students meet high standards. But the Administration needs to invigorate the school reform movement by pulling more communities, educators and parents into the effort. The Federal Government can encourage, through funding incentives, efforts to give schools more authority to design the mechanisms, from smaller classes to cooperative learning, to improve effectiveness.
One pressing challenge is to improve what many legislators consider a poorly managed department, with a $35 billion budget and 5,200 employees administering 220 programs. The department was recently cited by the General Accounting Office, Congress's investigative agency, for poor oversight of Federal student loan programs.
The chief candidate for improvement is Chapter 1, which provides remedial services to disadvantaged children. Three reports have criticized the $6 billion program for, among other things, pulling children out of regular classes for remedial instruction, with the result that they fall further behind.
Education is primarily a state and local responsibility. Now Mr. Clinton and Mr. Riley, who made education a priority as governors, can push it to the forefront at the Federal level as well.

HEADLINE: Needed: A Few Brave Republicans

 BODY:
The Senate minority leader, Bob Dole, must be proud of his legislative skills, if nothing else. Last week he rallied enough Republicans to block a vital political reform designed to make it easier for Americans to register to vote. The Senate majority leader, George Mitchell, is scheduled to try again today to break Mr. Dole's crippling filibuster.
The vote will be a particular test of principle for four Republican Senators: James Jeffords of Vermont, Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, Dave Durenberger of Minnesota and Bob Packwood of Oregon. Last year all four broke with their party to support reform. They can tip the balance if they do so again. 
 The reform is the "motor-voter" bill vetoed last year by President Bush and repassed by the House last month. It would require states to give people a chance to register when they obtain or renew a driver's license. States would also provide voter registration forms by mail and at welfare, unemployment and other government offices.
On a day when key senators were absent, Mr. Dole was able to deny Democrats the 60 votes needed to cut off debate on a motion to proceed -- a preliminary step to getting "motor voter" to the floor, where it seems a sure bet for passage on the merits. What a victory! And what a message to Americans still searching for constructive ideas from the loyal opposition.
Republicans say the bill would be costly to the states. They also warn of rampant voting fraud. But these are false arguments. Combining driver and voter registration could actually save money. And states that already register voters at motor vehicle departments report no rise in cheating.
The real basis of the G.O.P.'s opposition is its calculation that new registrants will vote Democratic. Mr. Dole's zealous opposition to such a simple, sensible reform makes that prospect all the more likely.

HEADLINE: Ford Motor Unit Prices Notes

 BODY:
The Associates Corporation of North America, a Dallas-based unit of the Ford Motor Company, yesterday priced $300 million of seven-year notes through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.
The notes, which are due in 2000, have a 6 percent coupon and are priced at 100 to yield about 54 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
 Noncallable before maturity, the securities are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by Standard & Poor's and Duff & Phelps Credit Rating.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IS PUSHING WEALTHIER NATIONS TO BOLSTER RUSSIA

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that he would support an emergency meeting of the major industrialized democracies to discuss how they can bolster the Russian democracy movement, adding that the group's next planned summit in July might be too long to wait.
"The important point I'd like to make," Mr. Clinton said, after talks with President Francois Mitterrand of France, "is I don't believe we can wait until July for the major countries of the world, who care about what happens in Russia and who would like very much to keep political and economic reform on track there, to move." 
 With each passing day Mr. Clinton has been speaking out more and more forcefully on the need to help the Russian reformers, and has promised to unveil shortly several "innovative" aid ideas. In doing so, he is raising substantial expectations for an American policy initiative toward Russia that would go far beyond the limited offers of help by the Bush Administration.
 
Meeting With Yeltsin
 It is not at all clear, though, that the Administration's foreign policy apparatus can produce concrete initiatives in the three and a half weeks before Mr. Clinton meets President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia in Vancouver, British Columbia, on April 3 and 4. It is also not clear how far Congress is ready to go in this season of budgetary restraint.
But the President's remarks today seemed to reflect a recent string of unusually strong warnings to the White House from the Central Intelligence Agency about the depth of Mr. Yeltsin's plight, Administration and Congressional officials said today.
"We do feel that Yeltsin is in greater trouble than at any time since the coup," a senior intelligence expert said in an interview today. The official stressed, though, that he believed "Yeltsin could still pull it out."
 
Needs Western Support
 But the analyst said that to help Mr. Yeltsin withstand his current challenge from political opponents within the Russian Parliament, it would be useful for the West to provide not only financial assistance, but also clear and repeated expressions of support for the Russian President.
Even with that support, however, Russian experts in Washington and Moscow agree that no one from the outside can save Mr. Yeltsin if his Government loses credibility at home. The most they can do is help him at the margins, the experts said. Ultimately, his fate and that of the democratic reform movement in Russia will depend on his political acumen in dealing with his parliamentary opponents and his ability to continue to reform the Russian economy.
Mr. Clinton, 46, tried to give a boost to both during his news conference with the 76-year-old French President, who endorsed the idea of an emergency summit meeting and criticized Japan for trying to block it.
Tokyo is the host for the scheduled July meeting of the Group of Seven and does not want to undermine the significance of that session by having an emergency meeting beforehand. The Japanese have also been reluctant to commit themselves to increasing aid to Russia until Moscow promises to return Japanese islands captured during World War II. Nevertheless, Mr. Clinton said that "it is entirely possible" that an emergency session of the group before July "might be useful" in helping Russian reform.
The Group of Seven consists of the United States, France, Britain, Japan, Germany, Canada and Italy. Its members pledged $24 billion in loans, cash, and technical assistance for Russia last year. But only part of that figure -- mostly $10.5 billion in short-term loans that Russia is already in default on -- has been delivered because of Moscow's inability to control its money supply and restructure its economy to a degree acceptable to the International Monetary Fund.
 
Urging From Nixon
 Former President Richard M. Nixon, in his meeting on Monday with President Clinton urged the United States to take the lead in calling for an emergency session of the group.
Echoes of that argument were present in Mr. Clinton's remarks today, when he said it is essential "for us to try to move aggressively to give the Russians the means to restore some economic growth and opportunity and preserve political liberty."
Mr. Mitterrand joined that view. "I'm in favor of an earlier G-7 meeting," he said. "I think it's absolutely necessary. There are problems, specifically in Eastern Europe and in Russia, that are urgent."
"I also know about the Japanese opposition to the idea," Mr. Mitterrand said. "And perhaps they, the Japanese, are not paying sufficient regard in this respect to the importance of events taking place mainly in Europe."
Jeffery Sachs, a Harvard University economist advising the Russian Government, has proposed that the Group of Seven treat economic reform in Russia as a step-by-step process. That means, he said, that the aid goes step by step as the reform goes step by step.
 
Trade Issue Discussed
 On a trade issue that also came up in today's talks, Mr. Clinton soft-pedaled his earlier criticism of European subsidies to the Airbus project, which has been blamed for taking away thousands of jobs from the Boeing Company and McDonnell Douglas Corp.
Today, Mr. Clinton said he has no plans to renounce the accord between Washington and the European Community, negotiated last year by the Bush Administration, which lays down how much both sides can subsidize their civlian aircraft industries.
"I support last year's agreement," he said. "The argument I was trying to make to the Boeing workers last week is that the adversity they have suffered in the market is through no fault of their own. That is, they have not failed by being unproductive or lazy or asking for too much. But that Europe was able to penetrate this market because of the Airbus policy. And the blame I placed was on our Government for not responding, not Europe's for trying to get in. That was their right."

HEADLINE: CHOICE FOR JUSTICE IS TREATED GENTLY

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
Janet Reno breezed through a balmy first day of confirmation hearings today before the Senate Judiciary Committee, where the gentle questions contrasted sharply with the turbulent selection process that led to her nomination to be Attorney General.
From the moment she loped up the aisle in the packed hearing room and took her seat behind the green felt-covered table, Ms. Reno seemed in command. Her testimony combined careful coaching, legal training and the political skills honed in five election campaigns as Dade County prosecutor. 
 Her folksy opening statement steered clear of the usual legal speech-making that is standard fare for nominees facing confirmation to head the Justice Department. Ms. Reno talked instead about her father, a Danish immigrant who was a reporter at The Miami Herald, and about her family home built by her mother outside of Miami.
 
A House as Symbol
 "She dug the foundation with her own hands, with a pick and shovel, she laid the brick, she put in the plumbing and my father would help her with heavy work at night," she said. "I have lived there ever since. And as I come down the driveway through the woods with a new problem to solve, that house stands as a symbol to me, that you can do anything you really want to, if it's the right thing to do and you put your mind to it."
Ms. Reno, who for 15 years has been the chief prosecutor in the county that encompasses Miami, seemed to embrace a philosophy tailored to liberals and conservatives alike. She frequently asserted the necessity to prosecute lawbreakers vigorously but said social programs were needed to divert drug users to treatment programs and to steer young people from crime.
Her emphasis on practical law-enforcement experience, more than her views on crime and justice, seemed to define the differences between Ms. Reno and former Attorneys General, like William P. Barr, her immediate predecessor. She offered few specifics of how her approach would differ from Bush Administration policies.
Reaching into her background to explain her views, she seemed to suggest that she would emphasize the Attorney General's role as the chief criminal-law enforcer, not the principal legal thinker. "I want to let people know that crime doesn't pay," she said.
 
Death Penalty Discussed
 She deflected criticism of her opposition to the death penalty, saying, "To find those people still in prison without that penalty carried out after 10 and 13 and 15 years makes a mockery of the justice system."
Democrats and Republicans on the Judiciary Committee expressed profound relief that Ms. Reno had arrived without any embarrassing issue on which they would be forced to pass judgment. Several recent confirmation battles left the impression that the committee could not relate to the anger of everyday citizens over issues like the hiring of illegal aliens by Zoe Baird, President Clinton's first nominee to head the Justice Department.
Mr. Clinton's second choice, Kimba M. Wood, a Federal judge in New York, fell out of contention after an internal dispute over whether she had answered fully when White House aides asked about her hiring of a household worker who was an illegal alien. At the time Judge Wood hired the worker it was not illegal to do so, a fact that prompted some critics to see a double standard and assert that she had been unfairly eliminated.
 
Biden's 'Sigh of Relief'
 Today, members of the panel seemed delighted that Ms. Reno allowed them to get the troublesome issue of who will lead the Justice Department behind them. During a break in the hearings, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Delaware Democrat who heads the committee, told reporters that Ms. Reno's hearings were going about as smoothly as anyone expected. "What your hearing is a collective sigh of relief," he said.
By day's end, several Democrats and Republicans on the panel were discussing the possibility of speeding up their deliberations after the hearings conclude on Wednesday. Some favored voting on her nomination on Thursday, instead of waiting the usual seven days. If the committee approved her, she could be confirmed by the end of the week.
Her deferential demeanor appeared to fray when two Republicans, Charles E. Grassley of Iowa and Hank Brown of Colorado, prodded her about whether Clinton Administration officials improperly intervened on behalf of Representative Harold E. Ford, a Tennessee Democrat who was an early Clinton supporter.
 
Tries to Deflect Question
 After black lawmakers complained to the White House and to the Justice Department, Stuart Gerson, the acting Attorney General who is a holdover from the Bush Administration, sought the dismissal of a nearly all-white jury selected to hear a fraud case against Mr. Ford, who is black.
Ms. Reno tried to deflect the question, suggesting that politics had played no role in the decision because it had been made by Mr. Gerson, a "high-level member of the past Administration." She said Mr. Gerson had said there was no effort "to influence anybody to do anything inappropriate."
She stiffened as Mr. Grassley pushed further, asking her whether she would continue to investigate how the decision was made and whether there were meetings between White House officials and Mr. Gerson.
She replied curtly, "I don't see any further action to be taken on it."
 
'Beyond a Red Herring'
 Senator Carol Moseley Braun, an Illinois Democrat who is a member of the Black Caucus, defended the black legislators' efforts to petition the Justice Department in Mr. Ford's case. She accused Republicans of "mudslinging," in raising the issue, saying it was a "beyond a red herring."
Mr. Grassley also queried Ms. Reno about another politically explosive case, the Federal grand jury investigation of Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. Administration officials are said to be fearful of the prospects for Mr. Clinton's economic proposals if Mr. Rostenkowski steps aside.
When Mr. Grassley asked whether she would provide the White House with a status report on the investigation, she answered with a sharp, "No," asserting, "I try to keep politics out of what I do."
Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, the ranking Republican on the panel, said at one point, "Having read every page of your F.B.I. report, I am impressed with your credentials and what you've done with your life."

HEADLINE: California Scrambles to Defends Its Bases From Pentagon Ax

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., March 9

 BODY:
Word that a new round of base closings would be concentrated in California has set off a week of clamorous activity by the state's elected leaders, who are reminding the Clinton Administration of its pledge to give special attention to the state's ailing economy, which threatens to stall the nation's recovery.
The full-court press by California's leadership, including the Republican Governor, the two new Democrat Senators, a host of powerful committee chairmen in Congress and dozens of state lawmakers, is the most intense effort to advance a statewide agenda since the earthquake in 1989, when officials set aside partisan and parochial interests to seek Federal aid. 
 "This is truly a California-first effort," said Don Perata, a member of the Board of Supervisors in Alameda County, which has 3 of the 10 bases in the state threatened with closure. "Everything has been put aside except the common concern that this will push us over the edge.
The Pentagon is preparing a list of about 180 military installations that it proposes to close, consolidate or reduce across the nation, and leaders from many states are lobbying to keep bases off the list before it is released on Friday. But state officials here argue that California, with an unemployment rate of 9.8 percent, nearly three points above the national average, is in a particularly difficult bind.
 
80,000 Jobs at Stake
 The California bases on a draft version of the list account for 80,000 jobs, a price leaders say the state cannot afford to pay after losing 17 bases and 68,000 jobs in two earlier rounds of military reductions.
Even where a closed base might some day provide opportunities to create new jobs in the private sector, the slow process of closing has put large numbers of people, particularly bllue-collar workers, out of their jobs in the short run, according to several defense conversion experts and officials in communities where bases are closing.
The here and now is what worries California's leaders, as each month brings new grim economic tidings. Senator Dianne Feinstein has led the chorus of desperation.
"I understand our country's military needs to reflect the realities of the post-cold-war world," she said today on the Senate floor, noting that 60 percent of the jobs lost in earlier rounds of military reductions were in California. "But closing 10 bases in a state where the economy is still fragile and 1.5 million people are unemployed just doesn't make sense."
Beyond trying to protect bases, state leaders are further arguing that the Administration must offer a thorough and well-financed defense conversion plan to train displaced workers and provide emergency benefits. They also seek financing to accelerate environmental cleanups in places like this one, which stands to lose the huge Alameda Naval Air Station, which is also a port for warships and employs 18,200 people, and the Oakland Naval Supply Center, with a military and civilian work force of 3,800.
A $1.7 billion fund for defense conversion, which was appropriated but not spent during the Bush Administration, could be released as early as Friday, when President Clinton is expected to discuss military matters aboard an aircraft carrier in Virginia. That would coincide with the official announcement of the list of bases proposed for closing by Defense Secretary Les Aspin.
Rep. Ronald V. Dellums, Mr. Aspin's successor as chairman of the House Armed Services Committee and an advocate of drastically reduced military spending, is seeking a further $7.5 billion for military conversion. Mr. Dellums's district, which includes Oakland and the island city of Alameda, stands to lose all of its bases.
"We have long been pushing the view that no matter how you feel about a local facility, the national Government has the obligation to provide meaningful transition," said H. Lee Halterman, general counsel to Mr. Dellums. "Base A, base B, the pain's the same. The Federal Government has to intervene quickly and aggressively."
Mr. Dellums, who has set aside fiery oratory in favor of inside maneuvering, met on Monday with Mr. Aspin and told him that the proposed closings, especially those suggested by the Navy, were strategically unsound. The cluster of bases in the Bay Area, Mr. Dellums said, can berth three nuclear carriers and provide housing and hospital beds that will be expensive to replace elsewhere.
Senator Feinstein made a plea to the White House chief of staff that the Administration should not close bases in states with unemployment rates above 9 percent. Ms. Feinstein will also introduce a Senate resolution that the cummulative economic impact of closing should be given more weight in the deliberations of the Base Closure and Realignment Commission, which will review Mr. Aspin's list before passing its recommendations to the President by July 1. The list then will go to Congress.
 
Delegation to Washington
 Gov. Pete Wilson issued an invitation to the commission chairman, James A. Courter, to visit California and "see the hardship firsthand." Such visits are a routine part of the commission's deliberations, but the Governor, a former Marine and onetime member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, hopes to use his years of friendship with Mr. Courter, a former New Jersey Representative who is a fellow Republican.
Sixty-three members of the California Assembly and Senate, and several important aides to Mr. Wilson, the largest contingent ever to visit Washington on the annual lobbying mission, stormed the Pentagon and Capitol Hill this week. While each lawmaker hoped to save his own installation, they gave collective voice to the distress of a state that has lost 800,000 jobs since mid-1990 and is now home to 17 percent of the nation's unemployed.
In addition to relief on the base closures, the state lawmakers hope to come home with nearly $1 billion in Federal funds to help pay the health and welfare costs associated with runaway immigration. That request to the Clinton Administration, in the works for many weeks, was the first indication of a new collegial spirit within the state delegation.
Leaders here view the base-closing situation as the first big test of the loyalty and sincerity of Mr. Clinton, whose economic plans and re-election prospects are tied to restored prosperity in the state.
The President, the first Democrat to win here since 1964, has pledged that $4 billion of a $31 billion package of new spending he intends to stimulate the economy will go to California. Mr. Perata heard a pledge to give this state special consideration from the President's mouth, via live satellite transmission, at a statewide economic summit conference last month, modeled on Mr. Clinton's highly praised gathering in Little Rock.
"I heard him say he would not abandon California," the county supervisor said. "I heard him say "As California goes, so goes the nation." He has a commitment to California and a political obligation to California. Now he can help us not make anybody else unemployed. I think he can do that and the rest of the country will understand."

(Stephen Crowley/The New York Times); His district stands to lose all of its military bases, including Alameda Naval Air Station, above, which employs 18,200 people. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Clinton Hails Congress on Budget Cut

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
As Congress began voting in committee on his economic program, President Clinton said today that he was pleased that the lawmakers were considering even deeper budget cuts than those he proposed last month. But the President warned that he might raise objections when Congress moved from dealing with general figures to specific ones.
At a news conference, Mr. Clinton praised Congress for trying "to get even more deficit reduction." But he added, "That doesn't mean we don't need more specifics, because we have to define how we're going to cut." 
 The House and Senate budget committees plan to vote Wednesday on general budget plans. The House measure would order $63 billion more in spending cuts over the next five years than the President included in his proposal. The Senate measure would include comparable spending cuts and an additional $30 billion in tax increases and fees for using Government services over the five years.
Mr. Clinton originally said his proposals would cut the deficit by $473 billion over five years, but the Congressional Budget Office examined the proposals and placed the figure at $406 billion.
 
Stimulus Package Backed
 On the spending side, the House Appropriations Committee today approved the first part of the President's economic-stimulus package, a $16 billion bill that would finance highway construction, summer jobs for students and other job-creation programs in the current fiscal year. Next week, the full House is scheduled to vote on this legislation, which will then be considered by the Senate.
The measures before the budget committees are called budget resolutions, the first Congressional step in the annual budget process. They establish the total amount of revenue that should be raised by taxes. They set total spending limits for all programs that require annual appropriations. And they also set total levels for programs like Social Security, Medicare and farm-price supports in which Government money is distributed according to formulas to everyone who meets eligibility requirements.
But despite all the talk in the budget committees about which programs should be cut where, the resolutions themselves are not binding in the details. After they are approved, Congress turns to the work of deciding, for instance, how much to spend for submarines and how much for welfare.
Leon E. Panetta, Mr. Clinton's budget director, told the House Ways and Means Committee this morning that he hoped the entire package would be enacted by August.
The measures before the budget panels follow Mr. Clinton's prescriptions closely.
"We in the Congress owe this President and this package a chance to succeed," said Jim Sasser of Tennessee, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee. That is the almost unanimous view now of Democrats in Congress, and since Democrats hold majorities on the budget committees, the package is almost certain to be approved in a form that meets with the President's approval.
Most Republicans will vote against it. Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the top Republican on the Senate budget panel, said the Clinton plan would not cut the deficit nearly so much as is being forecast because of its emphasis on tax increases.
The solid front now presented by the White House and Congress, as well as the unity among the Democrats in Congress, may weaken when it is time to get down to the actual details of which specific programs will be cut by how much and who will pay what new taxes.
The lawmakers are considering deeper cuts than Mr. Clinton sought largely because the new projections by the Congressional Budget Office showed that the President's actual proposals would fall somewhat short of the deficit-reduction goals he set in his speech to Congress last month. But another reason for the belt-tightening is that the senators and representatives have been under considerable pressure from their constituents to reduce Government spending.

HEADLINE: The Reluctance to Begin Rehiring

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LINDEN, N.J.,

 BODY:
While nobody here is yet calling it a boom, Fred D. Barre says business has improved significantly in recent months at his metal-fabricating company, just a wind shift from Exxon's giant Bayway refinery off the New Jersey Turnpike.
The Barre Company's backlog of unfilled orders now stands at $1.4 million, fully 25 percent above levels a year ago. And for the last couple of months, Barre workers have been putting in four to six hours a week of overtime. 
 Mr. Barre is no longer fighting for his company's survival, but neither does he have immediate plans to add to his work force of 62 unionized and management employees. In fact, his most recent personnel move, in December, was to dismiss five people, including his two tool makers.
"There's a lot of reluctance to add people," said Mr. Barre, whose name rhymes with "carry."
Despite statistics that show a strong growth rate for the nation's economy, this cautious approach to hiring, shared by legions of employers in both the manufacturing and service sectors, seems likely to continue because of powerful forces that have been reshaping corporate America for several years.
One factor is the realization during the recession that past staffing levels were not simply too high -- but counterproductive. Another influence is the rising cost of employee benefits like health care that make hiring increasingly expensive.
"The guy who earns $1,000 really costs $1,400," he continued, saying that the 40 percent markup for benefits compares with 36 to 37 percent a few years ago and less than 32 percent a decade ago.
 
Little Stimulus Is Seen
 Analysts say the Government's report of very sharp job gains in February is unsustainable, even considering that the bulk of those new jobs were part-time positions.
Nor does it seem likely that job-seekers, and employers like Barre, will be much aided soon by the Clinton Administration's economic program, one of whose goals is to generate an additional 500,000 jobs over the next year and 8 million by 1997.
"The countercyclical remedies offered by the Clinton Administration may not be sufficient to offset the powerful head winds of structural change," declared Stephen S. Roach, senior economist for Morgan Stanley & Company. "It's a real stretch to identify the emergence of any powerful new sources of job creation."
In fact, the Clinton program might retard job growth because of tax increases on the affluent and on corporations that could tend to drag down the overall economy.
 
Where the Trims Came
 The structural changes are evident at the Barre Company. Mr. Barre said cost-cutting undertaken during the recession pointed out just how flabby some operations had become.
"We had a plethora of supervisors," he said. By removing extra layers of paperwork, Mr. Barre says, the company now moves new orders to the shop floor in 3 days instead of 15. Barre, whose revenues run $4 million to $5 million a year, now has 17 salaried workers, down from 27 two years ago.
There was some belt-tightening at the top, too. Mr. Barre, who is 50, and who became the company's sole owner by buying out his two brothers in the 1980's, said he took a 35 percent pay cut last year.
Barre has also slashed its unionized blue-collar work force, which during the last year has contracted to 45 people from 61. Despite the recent pickup in business, Mr. Barre said he was still probably a month or two from reaching a "comfort level" with the economy that would prompt him to recall workers or hire new ones.
When overtime by his current work force no longer suffices, Mr. Barre said, eight laid-off workers will be rehired, followed by part-timers for the lower-skill jobs.
 
Impediments to Hiring
 But as he contemplates the need to put more people on the shop floor, Mr. Barre says he is increasingly inhibited by governmental and other burdens having little to do with stamping and punching sheet metal into precision chassis, panels and brackets for such customers as Hewlett-Packard and I.B.M.
In the end, he says, these burdens seem destined to discourage his kind of entrepreneurial company, for decades the source of much more job growth than the Fortune 500.
According to Mr. Barre, the problems include the rapid escalation of health-care costs; overregulation of banks to the point that lending is discouraged; thousand-dollar fines for violations of health and safety rules; New Jersey's nation-topping $5.05-an-hour minimum wage, and measures like the new Family and Medical Leave Act.
He also frets about the Administration's proposal to raise his $8,000 or more monthly energy bill by an as-yet undetermined amount through an energy tax and about talk of requiring employers to spend a certain percentage of payrolls on training.
 
Tax Breaks Not Applicable
 Mr. Barre dismisses a suggestion that Mr. Clinton's investment tax credit, at least, would help him. Accumulated losses have already reduced his tax liability to zero, leaving him nothing against which to apply such a credit. And even if he qualified, and the credit inspired him to buy new equipment, the machine would substitute for workers who might otherwise be hired.
Nor would the proposed 50 percent exclusion on capital gains help attract investors, he said, because it would apply only to investments in new companies.
Mr. Barre finds at least one favorable element in the Clinton program: the deficit reduction measures that Congress has been making progressively more credible.
"There are some real spending cuts, and if these do indeed get passed, that's going to keep interest rates down," Mr. Barre said. "That certainly is a plus."
 
Bemoaning Instability
 And he said that if the Administration followed through on welfare reform, like tying welfare payments to an obligation to work, as Mr. Clinton has recommended, this would tend to reduce unemployment and the drain on the employer-financed fund from which jobless benefits are paid.
But Mr. Barre holds little hope for relief on health care. He believes any dividends from cost containment will be used to finance coverage for the 35 million people who now lack it.
"One of the things a businessman looks for from government is stability and predictability," Mr. Barre said, lamenting its latest intrusions and the prospects for more. "But I negotiate a contract with my employees and the first thing the government does is come in and say I should give them something else, too."

HEADLINE: Drug Manufacturers to Ask for Antitrust Exemption

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
Under intense pressure from President Clinton to cut prices, the nation's drug companies said today that they would ask the Justice Department for an exemption from antitrust laws to discuss price restraints.
Bruce J. Brennan, senior vice president and general counsel of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, said that as a result of a decision by the trade group's executive committee, he would make the request to the department this week. 
Drug executives discussed their desire for an antitrust exemption with White House officials on Monday.
The drug companies' request could put the Clinton Administration in an awkward position. While an antitrust exemption might help achieve the White House goal of lower drug prices, Federal courts have been hostile to price-fixing agreements. Maximum prices tend to inhibit competition and become minimum prices, the courts have said.
In 1982, for example, the Supreme Court struck down a price list setting maximum fees that could be charged by certain doctors in Arizona.
Lynn Shapiro Snyder, a Washington lawyer who specializes in health care, chuckled when informed of the request by drug companies.
"They are holding the feet of the Clinton Administration to the fire," Ms. Snyder said. "It is not enough merely to say that the pharmaceutical industry should voluntarily agree to hold back price increases. To accomplish that across the board may require a bunch of competitors to coordinate their activities. That's a fine goal for the White House. But another arm of the Government could allege in court that such coordinated action violates Federal antitrust statutes."
 
Clinton on Antitrust
 The Clinton Administration is already considering sweeping changes in Federal antitrust law, which it believes may be needed to revamp the nation's health-care system. For decades, doctors and hospitals have fiercely competed for shares of local health-care markets. But now the Administration wants them to join in networks.
Confidential work papers from the President's Task Force on National Health Care Reform, headed by Hillary Rodham Clinton, suggest that antitrust laws may need to be modified "to permit collaborative arrangements" or to change the balance of power between buyers and sellers of health care.
During the campaign, Mr. Clinton said he would "stop drug-price gouging." On Feb. 12, he denounced vaccine manufacturers, saying they had pursued profits "at the expense of our children." On Wall Street, drug stocks have slumped, partly in response to his comments, partly in the expectation that he will ask Congress for price controls on prescription drugs.
The drug industry is asking the Justice Department for a business review letter: in effect, an advisory opinion to assure drug companies that the Government will not prosecute them for setting maximum prices.
 
Past Promises
 Gina M. Talamona, a Justice Department spokeswoman, said the agency normally tried to respond to such requests within 90 days.
A drug company is free to cut prices on its own. Ten companies accounting for 40 percent of the nation's prescription drug sales have voluntarily pledged to hold drug price increases to the general inflation rate, measured by the Consumer Price Index.
Data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics show that prescription drug prices rose 5.7 percent last year and 50 percent in five years, and that they more than doubled over a decade. By contrast, the Consumer Price Index for all items rose 2.9 percent last year, 23 percent in five years and 45 percent in the decade.
Several members of Congress said they were skeptical of the drug companies' motives. The latest request was called "sort of a joke" by Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, the Ohio Democrat who heads the Judiciary subcommittee on antitrust matters.
 
Skeptical About Industry
 "You have to wonder if the drug companies want to get together to restrain price increases, which I doubt, or to resist demands by large purchasers for deep discounts," Mr. Metzenbaum said. "This is a scheme to keep prices from falling and to undermine efforts by the Clinton Administration to reduce the cost of health care through competition."
Senator David H. Pryor, an Arkansas Democrat who is a frequent critic of drug companies, said he would be cautious in dealing with the industry's latest overtures. "Any voluntary agreements to restrain drug prices must have a credible auditing process and must lower prices for the average cash-paying buyer," he said.
Mr. Brennan insisted that the drug companies were not engaged in a publicity stunt. If companies got together to discuss the frequency or amount of price changes without the blessing of the Justice Department, "they would be in violation of the antitrust laws," he said.
Under the strategy of managed competition favored by Mr. Clinton, huge groups of consumers and small businesses would band together and use their market power to bargain with doctors and hospitals. The work papers from Mrs. Clinton's group say the Administration assumes that these groups "will be local monopolies."
 
More Competition Sought
 A main goal of the President's plan is to slow the rise in health prices by stimulating competition among health-care networks. But many providers want to seize the occasion to get exemptions from antitrust laws for certain types of behavior.
The American Hospital Association has prepared legal brief contending that "collaboration among hospitals can reduce costs." But the Federal Trade Commission continues to challenge some hospital mergers on the ground that they tend to increase prices.
The American Medical Association is also asking the trade commission to let local medical societies punish doctors for fee gouging. Under this proposal, patient complaints could go to the local society, which would have the power to review the doctors' fees and expel a doctor whose charges were deemed to be unconscionable.
The A.M.A. wants local medical societies to be able to mediate disputes between doctors and patients over fees. It says doctors should be required to cooperate with mediation. Now, doctors do not have to participate.

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeks Mexican Court Changes in Trade Pact

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, told the Senate Finance Committee today that the United States would seek some changes in Mexico's legal system affecting labor and environmental cases during the coming negotiations on side agreements to the North American Free Trade Agreement.
When President Clinton was a candidate, he said he would not sign legislation putting the provisions of the free trade pact into law until three such accords had first been negotiated. Mr. Clinton said these agreements would cover labor and environmental matters and surges in imports that might result as the pact gradually reduced tariff and non-tariff trade barriers.
 
Willing to Walk Away
 Mr. Kantor, in his first appearance at a Congressional hearing since he took office, said the Clinton Administration would be willing to walk away from negotiations on the side agreements if necessary rather than strike a quick deal to insure that the free trade pact could take effect as scheduled on Jan. 1. 
 But he also reaffirmed the Administration's desire to keep the pact on its original timetable. He only made the comment about walking awayfrom the talks after Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, sought reassurance that the United States would not make large, last-minute concessions to meet the deadline.
Mr. Kantor told the senators that "a very fine starting point" for talks on the labor and environmental accords would be a special set of judicial procedures created by the original free trade pact for cases involving patents and copyrights.
"Let me suggest, not too subtly, that I believe worker rights and environmental rights are similarly important," he said.
The procedural changes could include new rights for plaintiffs to appeal the results of administrative proceedings to Mexican courts, Mr. Kantor added.
Environmental, labor and business groups in the United States have long criticized the extensive powers of Mexican Government agencies to make sweeping decisions with little notice, public comment or opportunity for judicial appeals.
The side agreements would also set up environmental and labor commissions representing Mexico, Canada and the United States. Mr. Kantor said these commissions might have the power to request or even order investigations by national governments into violations of their laws.
But he played down suggestions by some trade experts, including Senator Max S. Baucus, Democrat of Montana, that nations might also have the authority to impose trade sanctions if the commissions could not settle matters.
Jaime Serra Puche, Mexico's Minister of Trade and Industry, declined to discuss the specifics of Mr. Kantor's testimony, saying he had not yet read a transcript.
But he said in a telephone interview today that Mexico had set three principles for the negotiations, which are to begin on March 17. The side agreements must not reopen issues settled by the original free trade pact, must not include protectionist measures disguised as labor and environmental rules, and must respect each nation's sovereignty, Mr. Serra said.
 
Ban of Subsidies Considered
 Mr. Kantor also said today that the United States might seek a formal exchange of letters with Mexico barring the use of government money to buy the other country's businesses and move them across the border. Two Democratic Senators, Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan and Mr. Moynihan, strongly criticized the Mexican Government's recent financial involvement in a fund with the sole goal of buying American companies and moving them to Mexico.
When told of Mr. Kantor's testimony, Robert F. Housman, a staff lawyer and trade specialist at the Center for International and Environmental Law, said that changes in some Mexican legal processes would be "a good starting point." He added that environmental groups would want the ability to bring cases in each country's courts.
The center is providing legal counsel to two dozen environmental groups that want extensive side agreements. Mr. Housman said he was disappointed that Mr. Kantor did not envision three-nation commissions with the ability to impose trade sanctions.

HEADLINE: Weeding Federal Panels, but Where?

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
When President Clinton vowed to eliminate some of the 700 Federal advisory committees that "have spread across this Government like kudzu," he cited one panel that actually went out of business last year.
The continued operation of the Commission on the Bicentenary of the Constitution -- four years after the bicentenary was celebrated -- was cited by the White House as a typical example of Government waste. As it happened, the panel died last June 30. 
 That the Administration was unaware of its demise may say something about the obstacles in the President's path as he prepares, in the name of efficiency, to attack the proliferating panels. Before he can weed them out, he has to find them. And like kudzu, the tenacious vine sometimes planted in the South for soil stabilization, many will not go away easily.
There are more than 2,000 Federal advisory committees, but most were set up at the direction of Congress, so the President cannot touch them; instead, he is attacking a third of the 700 non-statutory panels that have crept in unnoticed and cost the taxpayers about $150 million a year.
 
A Shadowy Existence
 Most of the panels keep a low profile in the nether reaches of the Government labyrinth. And many of the departments' public affairs offices had trouble coming up with a list of committees under their auspices, let alone describing what they do.
"Beats the heck out of me," said Rick O'Bourne, an Energy Department spokesman, when asked what the Health and Environmental Research Committee did. Mr. O'Bourne, however, was one of only a few people who could even name any of his department's committees immediately.
Under the Clinton proposal, Federal departments must specify a total of about 230 such panels that they deem unnecessary or duplicative, with the aim of saving the taxpayer around $100 million, the White House says.
Their exotic or enigmatic names often belie the panels' mundane missions. The Committee of Nine, for example, may evoke images of a powerful politburo dealing with weighty matters. In fact, the panel consists of the administrators of eight agricultural experiment stations and a home economics research office who advise the Secretary of Agriculture on cooperative research projects.
 
Some Thankless Tasks
 Just because the Government does not know what is going on in its own departments does not mean that the committees are a waste of taxpayers' money. After all, mostly non-Federal employees sit on the committees and, for a token per diem payment, set about such thankless tasks as setting safety and environmental standards, a job that Federal employees do not feel qualified to do without input from people in privately owned businesses.
The Scrapie Regulation Negotiation Advisory Committee is not as bureaucratic as it sounds. Scrapie is a neural disease found in sheep, and the committee has set up a flock registration program that monitors flocks of sheep for five years to certify that they are scrapie-free.
Some panels may be harder to justify. The Advisory Panel for the Dictionary of Occupational Titles was one of five committees singled out by the President last month as typical examples of Government waste. But a spokesman at the Labor Department said it was premature to conclude that this panel would be given the ax.
He said the panel served a very specific purpose: It advises those involved in drawing up the Dictionary of Occupational Titles, which lists all the job titles in the United States and the qualifications and education needed for these jobs. The dictionary is used by guidance counselors, researchers and employers and is available in most public libraries.
Whether it is necessary for a 15-member panel with an annual budget of $75,000 to meet and discuss the vital statistics of every job title in the United States is something for the new Secretary of Labor, Robert B. Reich, to decide.
 
Access to Aircraft Toilets
 The Committee on Aircraft Accessibility has "proven to be extremely valuable," said Bob Ashby, deputy assistant to the general counsel at the Department of Transportation. The panel, made up of representatives of airlines and people with disabilities, thrashes out the design requirements for access to toilets by the disabled on narrow-bodied aircraft.
The Defense Department has more than 66 advisory committees, costing taxpayers $15 million a year. "We feel they are quite necessary," a Pentagon spokesman said, "and we constantly review them and determine whether they should remain."
Among more than 300 committees in the orbit of the Department of Health and Human Services are ones with tongue-twister titles like the Advisory Committee on Special Studies Relating to the Possible Long-Term Health Effects of Phenoxy Herbicides and Contaminants.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Accounting for the lofty share price of Anchor Bancorp.

BYLINE: By Saul Hansell

 BODY:
THE stock of most healthy savings and loans sells for about 1.2 times the institution's book value. The very best commercial banks, when they are acquired, sell for 2.5 times book value. Why then is Anchor Bancorp, which just a few years ago was on the brink of failure, selling for $14.50 a share, nearly three times its tangible book value of $4.98? This has perplexed the savings bank's chief executive, James M. Large Jr., who has seen the stock run up from less than $1 two years ago.
The answer is that investors are looking at Anchor's earnings rather than book value. Anchor earned $1.85 a share in the last four quarters for a price-earnings multiple of 7.8, which is about average for healthy savings institutions. And investors have become confident that the bank, under Mr. Large, has put its problems behind it so that the earnings will continue to grow. 
 "Jim Large has taken Anchor from whistling past the cemetery to one of the surviving institutions," said Bruce Harting, an analyst with Salomon Brothers, who says his clients have become very interested in Anchor in recent weeks.
Indeed, Anchor's institutional ownership has increased from 10 percent to 20 percent within the last six months, Mr. Large said. And it is beginning to be followed by Wall Street analysts.
In the early and mid-1980's, Anchor bought a string of 13 sick savings and loan associations from the Government. And it expanded into other financial businesses including leasing, mortgage banking nationwide and construction lending.
When Mr. Large took over in 1989, he closed or sold most of these businesses except Anchor's branches and mortgage offices on the East Coast. He cut costs, slashing the work force from 3,400 to 1,500 jobs. He also required remaining employees to work longer weeks and trim vacation days.
Mr. Large also restructured the bank's portfolio, which consists largely of mortgages and mortgage-backed securities, to eliminate interest rate risk. Now the bank invests almost entirely in adjustable-rate mortgages, which means that about half its portfolio consists of loans in California, where such mortgages are popular. While the bank had some commercial real estate loans and some junk bonds, the problems with these investments did not prove crippling.
The bank's most difficult challenge has been to rebuild its capital in the face of ever-changing regulations. As it acquired the failed institutions, Anchor was granted more than $500 million in "supervisory good will," essentially the right to report additional capital on the banks' books. Much of this paper capital has been wiped out by subsequent regulations.
Indeed, as of Dec. 31, Anchor was in compliance with minimum capital regulations, but on Jan. 1 it fell out of compliance because some $20 million in supervisory good will was eliminated. Mr. Large said he expects his capital to meet the requirements again on March 31.
One source of confusion about Anchor's book value is $159 million in preferred stock owned by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation as a result of Anchor's acquisition of troubled institutions. The F.D.I.C. is owed more than $40 million in back dividends, and Anchor can't pay a dividend on its common shares until it pays that sum.
Some analysts suggest that if the preferred stock were treated more like common stock, Anchor's book value would be closer to $10 a share, and thus the price-to-book ratio would be closer to industry averages. Yet because of the strong valuation of Anchor's shares, the company may be able to sell new stock, which in turn could allow it to redeem the F.D.I.C.'s shares.

HEADLINE: Concern Mounts Over Closing of Bases

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
The New York region was largely spared in the last round of military base closings in 1991, but members of Congress from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut say the bullet may be harder to dodge this time. With the public and Congress clamoring for budget cuts, they say, the military will have much less room to maneuver, however well founded the objections.
"This time we're worried," said Representative Jim Saxton, a New Jersey Republican whose district includes McGuire Air Force Base in Wrightstown. 
 The base, which employs about 12,000 military and civilian workers, is expected to be on the preliminary list of bases around the country to be closed or reduced in size. Others in the region include the Navy's submarine base in Groton, Conn., the Navy home port on Staten Island, and Griffiss Air Force Base in upstate New York. The list is to be released later this week.
"There's an increased national attention on budget reductions on all levels," said Representative Susan Molinari, a Staten Island Republican. And there is little doubt, she said, that a major share of the budget cuts will come from defense.
"The Navy is facing this inordinate pressure to cut, cut cut," said Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut.
 
Some New Arguments
 But there are some new arguments to be made as well.
At a meeting today between Defense Secretary Les Aspin and members of Connecticut's delegation, for example, Senators Lieberman and Christopher J. Dodd, both Democrats, argued that closing the submarine base in Groton, which has 12,300 military and civilian employees, would devastate eastern Connecticut and cancel out any economic stimulus efforts that the Clinton Administration might pursue there. It is not a case that could have been made even six months ago.
"We ought to, at least, if nothing else, at least slow down on this until we've got a policy in place," Mr. Dodd said.
In other places around the region, the framework for opposing cutbacks is already built. That should guarantee at least a certain level of noise, if nothing else.
Representative Saxton, for example, began meeting last week with local groups formed in 1990 and 1991 in the fight to save Fort Dix, which is also in his district. On Friday the groups hired a consultant, who was an assistant counsel to the last base-closing commission, to help formulate New Jersey's case. And this week Mr. Saxton began issuing his own daily fax-sheet update, called the McGuire Watch.
 
Fact-Studded Reports
 In New York, money appropriated by the Legislature to help military-dependent areas plan their futures will be used to make the state's case for retaining the Staten Island home port and the Griffiss base. The effort has produced fact-studded reports and glossy brochures, including a 10-minute video about why Fort Drum in upstate New York, while not expected to be on this week's closure list, is too "modern, flexible and effective" to be shut.
New York City officials are also united behind the efforts on the home port, where six ships are based along with about 2,000 sailors and their families. Mayor David N. Dinkins, until he changed his mind last year, had argued that the danger of a nuclear accident at the port outweighed the economic advantages for the city.
New York City and the region may also have an argument as a sort of economic basket case that deserves special treatment. The region has been one of the areas hardest hit by the recession.
 
A Dire Warning
 Referring to the Groton area, Senator Lieberman said: "This is a part of our state that is in a recession now. If the sub base is closed, it will go into a depression."
But Ms. Molinari and other members of the region's Congressional delegations said that beyond the pressure to cut the military budget, fighting back will be harder this time around because the list is being prepared by the military branches themselves.
In the last round, bases to be considered for closing were proposed by members of Congress. That left lawmakers free to play the military against the base-closing commission in bolstering the local cause.
"It served us well to argue that the Navy believed it was rational" to retain the home port, Ms. Molinari said. "This does make it a little more difficult."
 
Vital to National Defense
 Yet the delegations will continue to try to convince Mr. Aspin that despite what his own military planners are suggesting, certain bases in the New York region are indispensable to the national defense.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, who also met with Mr. Aspin today, asserted that closing Griffiss Air Force Base would leave the Air Force with too few points on the East Coast from which the United States can respond to "many of the potential conflicts in Europe and Asia."
In Connecticut, Senator Dodd evoked the specter of terrorism. If the Groton base is closed, he said, and consolidated into a "mega-base," perhaps in Newport, R.I., he said, the submarine fleet would be more vulnerable by being more concentrated.
"Did anyone notice what happened at the World Trade Center?" he said.

Map shows locations of threatened military bases in the New York region.

HEADLINE: Stock Rise Continues as Dow Gains 2.70

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Stocks bobbed up a bit to new highs yesterday as individual investors followed through on Monday's mighty advance. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 2.70 points, to 3,472.12, a second straight record, as the American Stock Exchange index also reached a new high.
Even as the mass migration from bonds to stocks that propelled the Dow 64.84 points higher on Monday nearly ceased yesterday, strategists were impressed that the market was so steady. 
 "It's a sign that yesterday's rally was not just an aberration," said Richard McCabe, chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch. He added, however, that the market's progress is about due for a slight reversal before resuming in the spring.
Big Board gainers outnumbered decliners by about 11 to 8, with the Standard & Poor's 500 off slightly but the New York Stock Exchange composite index fractionally ahead to another record. Trading volume reached 290.7 million shares, moderately more than on Monday.
Much of yesterday's temperate buying came from individuals. "After the sharks finish eating, the smaller fish are still out there," said Tracy Herrick, chief investment strategist at Jefferies & Company.
With no quote machines on their desks, small investors often learn of the market's action from the evening news or morning papers. They sometimes sell the day after plunges and buy after rallies, with their decisions most evident in the smaller, Nasdaq and American Exchange stocks.
Yesterday, the Nasdaq Composite index gained 1.73 points, to 688.96, and the American Stock Exchange Composite index up 2.29, to 419.02, breaking a record set Feb. 8.
Cyclical and interest-sensitive stocks continued to lead the market, although their gains yesterday were far less uniform or dramatic than the day before.
The USX Steel Group rose 1 1/8, to 40 1/2, and Alcoa 1 3/8, to 73 3/8. Several major banking stocks hit new 365-day highs, among them Citicorp, up 7/8, to 27 7/8, and Wells Fargo, up 3 1/8, to 108 5/8. Low interest rates have let banks borrow at much lower rates than they lend.
Thomas McManus, a market analyst at Morgan Stanley, said that falling interest rates in Europe could revive demand for the products of America's global manufacturers, helping cyclical stocks continue their ride.
The largest percentage gainer among the S.& P. 500 was Primerica, up 4 3/4, or 11.9 percent, to 44 3/4. Primerica is seeking to buy the Shearson Lehman Brothers brokerage operations from American Express, which rose 1 1/4, to 28.
Payless Cashways, a building materials retailer in an initial public offering at 12 3/4 a share, jumped to 14 1/2 on heavy volume in its first day of trading. Intel warrants, giving holders the right to buy Intel stock at higher prices each year through 1998, came out at 30 but fell to 29, as Intel common stock dropped a point to 118.

HEADLINE: Solomon J. Buchsbaum, Physicist And Presidential Adviser, 63, Dies

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Dr. Solomon J. Buchsbaum, a physicist and top official at Bell Laboratories who served as a science adviser to United States Presidents for the last 22 years, died on Monday at a hospital in Morristown, N.J. He was 63 and lived in Westfield, N.J.
The cause was multiple myeloma, his family said. 
 Dr. Buchsbaum was the chairman of the White House Science Council under Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush and was chairman of the Energy Research Advisory Board under President Jimmy Carter. He was also on President Richard M. Nixon's Science Advisory Committee and President Gerald Ford's Committee on Science and Technology.
He also served as a consultant to nuclear power, science and military agencies. He was chairman of the Defense Science Board from 1972 to 1977 and an adviser on the Strategic Defense Initiative, known as the Star Wars system, and on the deployment of MX missiles.
In his 45 years at Bell, Dr. Buchsbaum rose to several high-ranking posts. Since 1979 he was the senior vice president in charge of technology systems.
He supervised projects dealing with fiber-optic communications, digital signal processing, advanced satellites, computers, software, military systems and high-definition television.
Dr. Buchsbaum began at Bell in 1958 as a researcher on gaseous and solid plasmas. He wrote 50 published articles on his specialty and was awarded eight patents. He was the associate editor of three physics journals and chairman of the plasma division of the American Physical Society.
He served on boards at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Stanford University, the Rand Corporation, Draper Laboratory and the Argonne and Sandia National Laboratories.
His honors included defense and energy agency medals, the National Medal of Science from President Reagan and awards from the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineering and the National Academy of Engineering.
Dr. Buchsbaum was born in Poland. His parents died in the Holocaust, but he and his sister avoided capture.
As a teen-ager he moved to Canada. Originally he planned to be an accountant, but his mastery of physics won him a scholarship in that field. He earned his bachelor's and master's degrees at McGill University and his doctorate at M.I.T.
Surviving are his wife of 37 years, the former Phyllis Isenman; a daughter, Rachel J., of Winchester, Mass.; two sons, David J., of Atlanta and Adam L., of Princeton, N.J.; a sister, Dorothy Steinbach of Glen Rock, N.J., and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: California Raising $118.4 Million

 BODY:
The State of California yesterday priced for sale to the public a $118.4 million bond issue through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. The proceeds will be used to refund in advance previous debt sold when interest rates were higher.
The offering, which was repriced to yield slightly less because of good investor demand, produced a maximum yield of about 5.385 percent for an electric refunding revenue bond due in 2013. The taxable equivalent of that yield is about 7.80 percent for investors in the 31 percent Federal tax bracket. 
 Yields on serial bonds with shorter maturities range from 2.10 percent in 1993 to 5.35 percent in 2010. For investors in the 31 percent bracket, the equivalent taxable yields would run from 3.04 percent to about 7.75 percent.
Underwriters said that the bond issue was rated AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation and that they expected Moody's Investors Service to rate it Aa.

HEADLINE: Clinton Plan Would Soften Banking Rules

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
Hoping to spur commercial lending, the Clinton Administration has developed a set of revised banking regulations meant to encourage a mellower mind-set among bank examiners without encouraging lenders to rebuild shaky loan portfolios.
The proposed new regulations, to be introduced by President Clinton on Wednesday at a White House gathering of business executives, are being presented as a form of economic stimulus that costs the Government nothing, requires no new legislation and benefits mainly small businesses, which the Administration says have the greatest potential to create new jobs and the hardest time getting credit. 
 At the heart of the plan are subtle changes in how real estate is appraised and how weak loans are treated, according to industry officials who have been briefed by Administration officials who fashioned the revision.
Among other things, the proposed rules would alter how banks are required to appraise real estate used as collateral and to document the ability of small borrowers to repay commercial loans.
These are among other proposed changes:
*Revising regulations on how examiners rate loans to businesses that are not in default but are deemed troubling because of things like incomplete documentation, declining markets and outdated financial reports. In effect, as long as a borrower continued to make payments, examiners would be discouraged from requiring a bank to set aside reserves or otherwise restrict so-called character loans.
*Setting new, more lenient standards for making appraisals of real estate when property is used as collateral for a commercial loan.
*Allowing banks to change how they treat loans that are partly written off once a borrower returns to financial health. Under current rules, banks must book the repayments into their reserves and cannot restore the full value of the loan to the portfolio of assets.
*Allowing banks to pool small-business loans together for purposes of examinations. That way, as long as the portfolio as a whole appeared healthy, problems with a single loan would not prevent the bank from continuing to make such loans.
*Relaxing bank examiners' rigid positions by subjecting their decisions to appeals by banks.
Roger Altman, Deputy Treasury Secretary and one of several Administration officials who has been drumming up support for the program, told a banking group in Washington on Monday that the changes "will modernize a series of outdated regulations and examiner attitudes, and make it easier for lenders to lend."
But Lawrence Lindsey, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, said in a speech today that "there is very little we can do simply by changing regulations. Most of what we do is dictated by the law of the land."
 
 
Limits of Change
 Fearing that the changes in the rules would invite a return to flawed banking practices, the Administration will limit many of the changes to small businesses and healthy banks.
The regulators are keenly aware that partly because of stricter regulations, banks have charged off billions of dollars in bad loans, added billions to their equity and reserves and attained the highest capital ratios in 25 years -- trends that no one wants to reverse.
Because key members of Congress are set against undoing the new laws that have tightened regulations in the past few years, the Administration has decided at least for the time being to make its changes around the regulatory margins. The new rules will take months to write.
