HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Prices for Natural Gas Jump On Cold and Supply Jitters

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Natural gas futures prices rose sharply yesterday on reports of relatively low supplies and the temporary shutdown of a Canadian pipeline as cold weather headed for the Midwest.
Other energy prices finished mixed on the New York Mercantile Exchange. 
 Natural gas for delivery in April surged 9.7 cents, to $1.921 for 1,000 cubic feet, on the New York Merc. Crude oil for April slipped 3 cents, to $20.68 a barrel; April heating oil rose 0.16 cent, to 58.25 cents a gallon, and April unleaded gasoline fell 0.14 cent, to $59.36 cents a gallon.
The forecast of colder weather and private estimates putting American natural gas inventories 7 percent below a year ago were "classic ingredients for higher prices," said Ed Ryan, a gas broker-analyst at Dean Witter in New York.
The rally accelerated after the Nova Corporation of Alberta, a Canadian pipeline operator, announced a 10-day shutdown of its system, which supplies up to 400 million cubic feet of gas daily to the Midwest and the West, about 1 percent of United States consumption.
"That took a market that wanted to go up anyway and gave it a reason to go up," said Fred Brill, an analyst at Pegasus Econometric.
The shutdown was initially reported as unscheduled, which would have forced domestic gas dealers to scramble for supplies. But Nova said in a statement that the move was for scheduled maintenance and that arrangements had been made to make up at least some of the shortfall.
Perceptions that economic growth will raise gas consumption also helped prices to firm and could provide support in the long term, said David Pruner, president of KCS Energy Risk Management.
"It looks like the economic recovery will continue to increase demand, month after month," he said.
On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, pork belly futures rose the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound for the fourth straight day. But livestock futures retreated. Live cattle for April delivery fell 0.15 cent, to 81.70 cents a pound; March feeder cattle fell 0.30 cent. to 85.70 cents a pound; April live hogs fell 0.38 cent, to 48.37 cents a pound, and March frozen pork bellies rose 2 cents, to 49.17 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Stronger Against Yen As Japan's Slump Continues

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The dollar strengthened against the yen yesterday as traders questioned whether the Japanese currency should be as strong as it is.
Gold prices declined. Gold for current delivery fell 50 cents, to $326.60 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The Republic National Bank said gold slipped 25 cents an ounce, to a late bid price of $326.75. 
 The dollar ended the day in New York at 117.75 yen, up from 116.81 yen late Monday.
"The yen doesn't deserve to be so strong right now," said Jim Maccario, vice president at the Bank of Boston. The yen is just off its post-World War II high of 115.85 yen to the dollar, set Feb. 22.
Mr. Maccario said that based on Japan's poor economic situation, the yen should be at 120 to the dollar or more.
 
Hit Highs Earlier
 The yen hit highs amid speculation that members of the Group of Seven industrialized nations would take steps to bolster the yen and curb Japanese exports when they met in London last month. The yen has remained strong even though the group remained tight-lipped on currency issues.
A stronger yen makes Japanese exports more expensive and gives Japanese consumers more buying power abroad.
Talk of lower interest rates in Japan also helped the dollar yesterday, said Carl Weinberg, chief economist at High Frequency Economics in New York.
The Bank of Japan last cut interest rates Feb. 3, when it lowered the discount rate to 2.5 percent from 3.25 percent in an effort to spur economic growth. More bad news about the Japanese economy has prompted talk of another cut, Mr. Weinberg said.
Lower rates abroad make yields on American investments more attractive, increasing demand for dollars.
Dollar gains against the mark were limited today by the Bundesbank selling dollars to replenish its supply of marks, said Albert Soria, foreign exchange manager at Kansallis Osake Pankki.
The Bundesbank and other central banks sold marks in September to ease tensions in the European Exchange Rate Mechanism, Mr. Soria said. Now the Bundesbank is selling dollars to get the marks back, he said.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.6665 German marks, from 1.6635 marks on Monday. The dollar hit a 1993 high of 1.6742 marks on March 5.
Among other currencies, the British pound weakened to $1.439, from $1.442 Monday. The dollar strengthened to 1.541 Swiss francs, from 1.5396, and rose to 5.654 French francs, from 5.637.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Data Can Move 45,000 Times Faster, for a Price

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The most debated set of letters in the telecommunications business these days is not A.T.& T. or MCI, but A.T.M. And it has nothing to do with getting cash from an automated teller machine.
A.T.M., short for asynchronous transfer mode, is a futuristic format for packaging and transmitting computerized data and images over telephone lines. It is blazingly quick, able to send digitized information at more than 45,000 times the speed available on typical telephone lines. But the technology is also fiendishly expensive, at least so far. 
 Besides its speed, the main appeal of A.T.M. is that it offers a single standardized way to transmit information -- whether electronic books, high-definition movies or three-dimensional medical images. A.T.M. can be used for sending such material to a co-worker down the hall or to a client across the country.
"The electronic superhighway that President Clinton wants to build, the one that does for information what the interstate highway does for cars and trucks, is going to use A.T.M.," said William J. Marshall, senior managing director of communications for Bear, Stearns & Company, the large Wall Street brokerage house.
Bear, Stearns is currently testing A.T.M. equipment. If the experiment proves satisfactory, Mr. Marshall said, the company may buy the equipment from the maker, who he said he was not free to identify. He also declined to estimate the costs, which might run into millions of dollars.
Indeed, cost is one of the big sticking points with A.T.M., said Paul D. Callahan, an analyst for Forrester Research Inc., in Cambridge, Mass. In a recent study on A.T.M., Mr. Callahan calculated that the cost of connecting each computer in a network to A.T.M. would be $4,000, compared with $900 a connection for simply upgrading an existing personal computer network to make it faster.
"People in the telecommunications industry are so pumped about A.T.M. as some kind of network nirvana," he said, "and they shouldn't be." There may not be enough big customers like Bear, Stearns to make it worthwhile.
Still, many potential customers are interested. Tomorrow, more than 100 large companies and government agencies -- including Boeing, the Treasury Department and the Walt Disney Company -- will meet in Washington with the Sprint Corporation and other potential A.T.M. suppliers to discuss their needs and expectations for the technology.
This and similar meetings elsewhere are expected to help determine the crucial technical requirements that will insure that all A.T.M. products can work with one another, regardless of the brand. Vendors see a billion-dollar market in the making.
The A.T.M. format has already been endorsed by many phone companies, the largest customers for such equipment, who must then provide services to corporate customers and, perhaps, residential customers. These phone companies include all the major long-distance carriers as well as many local carriers like the New York Telephone Company, whose tasks include providing high-capacity information circuits to Wall Street.
Unlike most current computer networking formats, A.T.M. has a signature way of parceling information into manageable bundles of computer bits that allow these parcels to pass smoothly from an office computer cable to a local telephone wire to long-distance fiber-optic lines. There is no need for the traditional "protocol conversion," or technical translation, of the information packets along the way. And unlike earlier formats, A.T.M. can work at different speeds, depending on how "wide" or "narrow" the circuit it is traveling through.
 
An Alternative Approach
 Moreover, A.T.M. deals with information in its entirety, rather than using the data compression process that will be deployed in the near future to allow cable television networks to carry 500 channels. Such compression methods actually remove part of the information, in roughly the same way orange juice is rendered down into juice concentrate.
A.T.M. is by no means the telecommunications industry's first attempt to promote a unified approach to computer networking. Since the 1980's, for instance, something known as the integrated services digital network, or I.S.D.N., has been touted as the magic carpet on which homes and businesses would ride into the Information Age. But demand has been only sporadic, seeming to back up the early critics who derided I.S.D.N. as standing for "innovations subscribers don't need."
Many business customers criticized I.S.D.N. as a solution in search of a problem, a creation of engineers who had failed to ask potential users what they really needed.
"We don't want to ride that horse again," said William G. Pfeiffer, senior vice president for technology at Sprint, who will be a speaker at tomorrow's A.T.M. industry pulse-taking meeting in Washington.
 
Scrambling the Sequence
 The "asynchronous" transfer in A.T.M. means that information is loaded onto telephone lines out of sequence, allowing numerous computer conversations to occur simultaneously. These packets of information are reassembled in their normal sequence at the receiving end.
This approach to transmitting computerized information, known generically as packet switching, has been around for years. One of the breakthroughs with A.T.M. is the uniform size of the packet, known in computer terms as a cell, which enables different computers made by different manufacturers to converse. The cell size, 53 groups of eight bits, became an industry standard last year.
Computers today are so fast that companies find it easy to build up huge computer files of as much as 10 million bits of computer code, the equivalent of a copy of "Moby Dick."
With today's transmission formats, the most widely used business telephone lines can handle only 56,000 bits a second, meaning it would take three minutes to transfer a 10-million-bit file. That may not seem like a long time, but practically speaking, three minutes can stretch into many minutes or even hours, as hundreds of other computer users vie to simultaneously use the network.
With A.T.M., data can lumber along at 56,000 bits a second if that is the top speed the phone line will accommodate. But if a high-speed fiber-optic line is used, A.T.M. can rev up to 2.5 billion bits a second. In other words, it could send nearly 45,000 copies of "Moby Dick" in the time it takes present methods to send just one. "Three minutes is an eternity for us," said E. W. (Bud) Huber, manager for strategic planning for the Hughes Aircraft Company in Los Angeles.
Hughes, which operates more than 53,000 personal computers tied together by more than 1,000 local area networks, is shopping for what is likely to be one of the biggest purchases of A.T.M. equipment this year.
As an alternative to personal trips or shipping by Federal Express, Mr. Huber envisions an A.T.M. network that allows Hughes engineers in California and Alabama, for example, to use desktop computers to hold videoconferences and swap three-dimensional computer images with NASA officials in Florida.
"It would mean we could move the work to the people," he said, "instead of moving people to the work."

HEADLINE: U.S. Panel Backs Testing All Babies To Uncover Hearing Losses Early

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BETHESDA, Md., March 9

 BODY:
One in every 1,000 babies born in the United States is deaf at birth or suffers a severe hearing disorder. Yet fewer than half of them are recognized as being hearing-impaired until their condition has already compromised speech and language development, a panel of experts assembled by the National Institutes of Health has concluded.
The 15-member panel, which met here for two days last week, recommended that all infants be screened for signs of hearing impairment, noting that the current practice of testing only those considered at high risk of hearing problems, like children exposed to severe infections early in life, allows many cases to go undiagnosed until it is too late to forestall lifelong problems. The panel recommended testing for all infants in the first three months of life, preferably at hospitals before they are discharged from newborn nurseries. 
 Hearing impairment can interfere with language development even before children move through the babbling stage. And for those with profound hearing loss, early detection can be essential for adjusting to life with both hearing and deaf people.
 
Testing in Hospitals
 Early testing in hospitals is superior to waiting for later visits to the pediatrician, the panel said, because a vast majority of the nation's annual four million live births occur there and the children are accessible. In addition, the equipment and personnel needed for the tests can be centrally located at hospitals.
"Our recommendation is to test all children shortly after birth," Dr. Gregory J. Matz, a professor of otolaryngology at Loyola University of Chicago Medical Center and chairman of the panel, said after the meeting. "It's the only way to get all children and not miss any." He noted that in addition to those with severe hearing loss, a further four or five of every 1,000 newborns also have some mild hearing loss.
The average age for identifying deaf or severely hearing-impaired children in this country is when they are almost 3 years old, child hearing experts said, and lesser degrees of hearing loss go undetected even longer. Since the first three years of life are the crucial period for developing speech and language skills, they said, reduced hearing acuity in this period can interfere with communication skills for the rest of a person's life.
In addition, the panel said, early hearing problems hinder the development of the auditory nervous system, and can be harmful to social, emotional and academic development, as well as to a person's vocational and economic potential.
"Delayed identification and management of severe to profound hearing impairment may impede the hearing-impaired child's ability to adapt to life in a hearing world or to prepare for life in the hearing-impaired or deaf community," the panel said in a draft report released at the conclusion of the meeting.
 
Praise for Recommendations
 Mary Pat Moeller, coordinator for the Center for Childhood Deafness at Boys Town National Research Hospital in Omaha, said the recommendations of such an influential panel were "vitally important" for getting more children and their families into therapy.
"When you have a hearing loss, it disrupts the entire family," Ms. Moeller said. "How parents react can either help or exacerbate the problem, such as when they become overprotective or overly controlling of the child. The earlier in life we start dealing with hearing loss, the better for all concerned."
If all newborns go through the two-stage screening process recommended by the panel, Dr. Matz estimated, it will cost the nation $150 million to $200 million a year. However, he said, early treatment could save the country billions of dollars in earning power that might otherwise be lost and in the cost of special education for those who would otherwise develop social or learning difficulties.
 
Cost to Society
 Studies indicate that a child whose hearing loss is not detected until the age of 3 or later earns on average $400,000 to $800,000 less over a lifetime because of a reduced ability to use language, Dr. Matz said. High school students with hearing loss detected late usually read at the fourth- to seventh-grade level, he noted.
The panel was made up of experts in hearing loss, including doctors, nurses, social workers, researchers and representatives of community health organizations.
Doctors have historically tested only children who fall into high-risk categories for possible hearing problems, but the panel said these criteria seem to be a factor in only half the children subsequently found to have impairment. Conditions that increase the risk of deafness and that should provoke concern from doctors and parents include significant head injury, viral encephalitis or bacterial meningitis infections, exposure to excessive noise, exposure to herpes virus or cytomegalovirus during birth, hereditary hearing problems and repeated, persistent middle-ear infections.
The panel cautioned that even with widespread newborn screening, some cases of hearing impairment might evade detection and that parents and doctors should not develop a false sense of security about hearing just because tests have found no early problems.
For universal screening of infants, the panel recommended a relatively new screening tool that measures otoacoustic emissions.
Dr. James F. Jerger of Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, one of the panel members, said the oto acoustic emissions test costs about $25 to perform; the necessary testing equipment costs $10,000 to $14,000. If the first test indicates a possible hearing problem, the panel recommended, a second, more common test should be performed to confirm the finding, called auditory brainstem response.
If past experience is an indication, Dr. Matz said, only about one in 10 infants receiving the first screening test would have to go on to the second test.
 
 
 
TESTING A BABY'S HEARING
 A Federal panel has newly recommended these hearing tests for screening all infants:
Test: Otoacoustic emissions
 Average cost: $25.
When test should be done: Before an infant leaves the hospital.
How the test works: Otoacoustic emissions are low-level, inaudible sounds produced spontaneously by the inner ear. A probe containing a tiny sound source can evoke the emissions in people with normal hearing. A microphone in the probe measures the emissions, which are thought to refelect inner ear function.
Advantages and disadvantages: Although the test is still experimental, it is quick, noninvasive and inexpensive.
Test: Auditory brainstem response audiometry.
Average cost: $75-$125.
When test should be done: When an infant fails otoacoustic emissions testing. It is also useful in infants and small childrent unable or unwilling to respond to behavioral testing methods.
 How the test works: Electrodes are attached to various locations on the child's head. Whe the child is sleeping or resting quietly, sounds are channeled through earphones. The electrodes record the electrical activity from the acoustic nerve and in other parts of the brain involved in hearing.
 The test is long proven and has been recommended for screening high-risk infants for 15 years. However, it is technically more difficult, costs more and takes more time.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
The Black Family's Role in Society

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

Climbing Jacob's Ladder
The Enduring Legacy of African-American Families
By Andrew Billingsley
444 pages. Simon & Schuster. $27.50.
In his classic study, "An American Dilemma," published 49 years ago, Gunnar Myrdal wrote that the problems confronting disadvantaged blacks in a dominant white society put a spoke through the wheels of democracy. Yet the Swedish economist recognized that despite slavery and adversity, blacks helped to hold the country's social fabric together. In his chapter on black family life in the rural South, he said that blacks had built up their own kind of close-knit family organizations that were conducive to social health.
Now in "Climbing Jacob's Ladder," Andrew Billingsley, a respected black sociologist, builds on Myrdal's work and offers his own surprisingly optimistic study about the inner strength and stability of black families. Professor Billingsley, chairman of the family studies department at the University of Maryland and visiting scholar in residence at Spelman College in Atlanta, finds that like white strivers on the lower rungs of society, blacks also want to gain entry into the American middle class. The new book, a sequel to his "Black Families in White America," published in 1968, continues his argument that black families are born survivors and contain the seeds of their own rejuvenation. 
 The central idea behind "Climbing Jacob's Ladder" is explained in a perceptive foreword by Paula Giddings, an author and a visiting professor in the black studies department at Princeton University. She notes that where a previous generation of scholars saw weakness in black families, the new generation of black sociologists sees resourcefulness and resilience. Historically, black families tried to remain intact through slavery; many slave couples had long marriages, and the majority maintained stable households. Ms. Giddings writes, "Indeed, much of African-American history has been shaped by the determination of black families to live their lives together."
Combining history and sociology, "Climbing Jacob's Ladder" (the title comes from the spiritual "We Are Climbing Jacob's Ladder") explores the entire black experience in this country. The book includes the evolution of families from their origins in Africa, through the slave trade, the period immediately after slavery, the migration to Northern cities and the present conditions of black Americans.
Professor Billingsley emphasizes that white families should not be the basis of comparison for black families to show similarities or differences. He says black-white comparisons distort the reality and complexity of black families and discourage government reform. And he deplores the pessimistic views in some of the writing of James Baldwin: that American society is too decadent and too racist to make an an equitable place for black citizens.
While the author admits that some readers will consider his views overly optimistic and reject his argument that black families are strong entities, he counters by citing these examples: "The resourceful black grandmother, the vital black church, the effective black school, the successful black business enterprise, the authentic black scholar, the hard-working, long-suffering black masses, the upwardly mobile sectors." He adds that "all hold important keys to the regeneration of our families, our communities and our society."
Professor Billingsley doesn't make a convincing case for the stability and adaptability of black families when he discusses such matters as single-parent families, runaway husbands and abandoned children. Whether the teen-age pregnancies and broken homes exist in black or white families, it isn't quite enough to rely mainly on the success stories of those who have overcome these problems.
The author is on more solid ground when he writes about the influence of the military in black achievement in uniform. Desegregation in the armed forces led to great benefits for many black families. Gen. Colin Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, is held up as the symbol of a black who went to the top of the profession of arms and gained national status. Blacks occupy more management positions in the military than they do in business, education, journalism, government or any other significant sector of American society.
Because military service has been a strong path to advancement, Professor Billingsley sounds like a Congressman with a military base or contract in his district when he advises that "the impending demobilization and down-sizing of the military services, budget and installations in the aftermath of the cold war and the gulf war be accomplished without an unfair share of the burden being placed on African-Americans." He suggests that comparable civilian services, such as the Job Corps, can produce comparable results for low-income men and women.
Because Professor Billingsley is independent minded and breaks ranks with traditionalists about the sorrowful black experience in the past, "Climbing Jacob's Ladder" is worth reading. His main conclusion is hard to dispute: economic viability and social status lead to stable patterns of family life.

HEADLINE: Review/Fashion;
In Milan, Comfort and Flourishes for Fall

BYLINE: By BERNADINE MORRIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MILAN, Italy, March 9

 BODY:
Dressing for a worldwide recession elicited two divergent responses from Italian designers as the fall fashion showings reached their midpoint. On the one hand, there was the escapism of revivals from the distant past, including the jackets of English dandies. On the other, there was the realism of classic dressing, emphasizing clothes that can last more than one season.
In the realism camp, there is a widespread revival of knitted clothes, long an Italian specialty. The knits include oversize bulky sweaters and long, skinny skirts. Both are youthful, durable and, when they are made in cashmere, luxurious. 
 Giorgio Armani managed to straddle both camps. The emphasis in his Emporio Armani collection is on reasonably classic, tailored pants suits. This collection, less expensive than his top line, usually focuses on more casual styles. This time, there is a plethora of herringbone patterns, checks and plaids, which add to the traditional formality.
Of course, there are fresh touches -- this is, after all, a designer collection. Some pants have buttons near the bottom to allow adjustment of the width; some have Zouave-like fullness. And a few jackets are as long as coats, stopping somewhere between the fingertips and the knees. The audience applauded the longer styles.
But as the collection moved along, touching on raincoats and patterned sweaters, a new, whimsical note developed. Armani began sending in the clowns. A red-silk clown suit, with billowing edges and ruffles around the neck, was a delicious novelty.
Why the clowns? Armani was perfectly willing to explain after his show. Clowns and circuses represent a universal childhood dream, and a woman can have fun at night dressing up in clothes that suggest that dream, he said. There was a more sober reason as well. On a visit to London, he said, he was impressed by the fact that people donned red clowns' noses to indicate their sympathy for people with AIDS. The red noses were akin to the red ribbons that were first worn in the United States and have since appeared in Europe. A serious undertone can be a positive association for fashion, he said.
A sideline of the collection was the appearance of skirts that fall in handkerchief points over trousers.
Mariuccia Mandelli, of Krizia, stayed with the reality course in fashion and showed one of her best collections since her first in Florence, almost 30 years ago. Knits have always been her strong point, especially sweaters, usually decorated with a single animal each season. This time, leopards, squirrels, monkeys and parakeets cavort in unlikely groupings on the front of her pullovers. But she showed more than sweaters. Sleeves flaring from elbow to wrist give a medieval cast to long, narrow, knitted dresses. A long torso dress with a full-tiered skirt is gently romantic.
Black velvet bands and borders give crispness to jackets worn with pants or transparent lace skirts. Flaring pants and combinations of leather and tweed give freshness to suits. There are seasonal allusions in the semi-transparent wool skirts worn with long jackets, the relaxed cut of leather pants gathered at the waistline, and the somber black-and-gray prison stripes on suits and dresses.
Few designers here would have had the confidence to send a model down the runway wearing a gray flannel overcoat, a matching double-breasted jacket, pants and sweater. No hoopla -- just elegant, subdued fabric and cut. An outfit like this needs no explanation -- it works.
Salvatore Ferragamo's ready-to-wear is constantly improving. Besides his ribbed cashmere coats, jackets and sweaters, he showed a neat collection of soft blouses with ripples of ruffles down the front that accent tights, pants and long, slim skirts. Some blouses are pleated, others have ties wide enough to toss over the shoulders.
Shearling coats with long-hair fur on the inside are a cozy cover-up for the cashmere sweaters. So are fringed blanket coats and sunny-colored suede jackets.
While Ferragamo's collection adopted popular themes of the season, it gave them a look of class.
Laura Biagiotti has long been known as Italy's queen of cashmere. She surpassed herself with her knitted clothes this season. Jumpsuits, dresses and vests augment her usual collection of sweaters. The cashmeres are knitted in fanciful patterns with a new complexity that enhances the three-dimensional effect. Sweaters tucked into the small waistline of flaring long skirts look especially attractive. So do dresses with panels inserted in deeper shades at the sides, to give a slimming effect. Cashmere camisoles with laced fronts suggesting corset tops are adorable.
When she ventured into more complex styles with, say, crushed ribbons appliqued on full taffeta skirts, the results were less impressive. Biagiotti is planning to open three shops in China, where much of her cashmere yarn comes from.
Grunge dressing has hit Milan. Take the first series of styles paraded down the Byblos runway. Black leather jackets topped flower-print dresses, which opened to show black leather shorts underneath. Knitted stocking caps were tied at the top of the head and flopped to the shoulders. Rubber-soled hiking boots gave feet a clunky look.
Long, wispy, partially braided hair kept the anti-establishment mood alive throughout. The dandy jackets paired with shorts, the ribbed cashmere sweaters and long skirts, and the glistening black-lace evening suits and dresses are all emerging as signs of the fall season.

HEADLINE: The Perfect Gift for Mr. Yeltsin

 BODY:
That long-running Russian cliffhanger, the Perils of Boris Yeltsin, resumes in Moscow today. Once again the anti-Communist hero, President Yeltsin, is fighting for political survival against a hostile, holdover Congress of People's Deputies, elected in the waning days of the old Soviet Union and packed with former Communist apparatchiks.
Despite the trappings of melodrama, extremely serious issues are at stake. President Yeltsin claims that his own political future and the future of reform are one and the same. Congressional leaders insist that they represent a more grass-roots version of reform and that Mr. Yeltsin's real aim is personal dictatorship. Mr. Yeltsin's authoritarian tendencies are undeniable. But his version of the present political stakes is far closer to the mark. 
 Washington would be foolish to get itself enmeshed in the fine details of Moscow political maneuvering. But that shouldn't preclude helping a friendly government build public support with a timely, targeted infusion of foreign aid.
The immediate quarrel between President Yeltsin and his congressional opponents is constitutional. Despite all the political upheavals in Russia since the failed hard-line coup of August 1991, the old, Soviet-era Constitution remains officially in force. The Constitution gives Congress, not the President, ultimate authority. Congress has used that power to purge reform ministers and to encourage the central bank to print excess rubles, fueling disastrous hyperinflation.
Mr. Yeltsin argues that a reallocation of authority is now imperative. But congressional leaders oppose his request to legislate a new power-sharing formula, leading Mr. Yeltsin to threaten unspecified "radical action" to resolve the crisis. That could include going ahead with a scheduled constitutional referendum, set to take place right after the Clinton-Yeltsin summit meeting on April 3 and 4 in Vancouver, British Columbia.
President Clinton responded with an appropriate sense of urgency yesterday when he and President Francois Mitterrand of France called for an emergency meeting of the Group of Seven industrialized democracies to speed aid to Russia. But that approach depends on convincing Japan and other reluctant participants. Meanwhile Washington can move on its own to put together a fast-flowing bilateral package of several hundred million dollars aimed at immediate political trouble spots.
For example, the U.S. could help fund an unemployment insurance program to soften the social impact of bankruptcies. It could help with job retraining for demobilized military personnel. Or it could fund a rural credit scheme to help small farmers adjust to market conditions.
With the overall future of reform still uncertain, some of this new aid might be offset by continued capital flight. That's why it still makes sense to link long-term multilateral aid packages to specific progress in economic reform. But the positive signals that Washington could send with a quick, politically targeted program are amply worth the financial risk.
Successful Russian reform would mean a major shift of resources from military to civilian use and would make it far less likely that Moscow would return to foreign policy adventurism. That could save U.S. taxpayers at least $100 billion a year in lower defense spending. Advancing one-half of 1 percent of that amount now to help keep reform afloat seems an eminently prudent bet.

HEADLINE: Hurricane Bill Threatens San Juan

BYLINE: By Rafael Hernandez Colon; Rafael Hernandez Colon was Governor of Puerto Rico from 1972 to 1976 and from 1985 to 1992.

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico

 BODY:
Puerto Ricans are distressed by a provision of President Clinton's generally fair economic reform plan. Though we occupy the bottom rung of the income ladder in the United States, one facet of the plan would amount to a requiem for Operation Bootstrap, which has elevated the island's standard of living.
Because of proposed changes in tax laws, the 3.5 million Puerto Ricans would be deprived of their principal legal instrument for economic development. The result would be stagnation, reduced productivity, lower wages, lower-quality jobs -- in short, a drastic reduction in our living standard, and dislocation. 
 Section 936 of the Internal Revenue Code authorizes a tax credit to promote corporate investment in underdeveloped U.S. commonwealths and territories. But President Clinton, attacking subsidies which reward companies that ship jobs overseas, wants to eliminate the credit, which exempts from taxes the income earned by U.S. corporations in Puerto Rico; he would replace it with a 65 percent exemption on wages paid to corporate employees.
Without Section 936's annual exemption, currently worth $3 billion, industrial development and the rise in Puerto Ricans' incomes would have been impossible. Textile and pharmaceutical companies are the main beneficiaries; together they account for more than a third of the in-plant jobs in the industrial sector. Currently, Section 936 companies provide up to $600 million in tax revenues to the commonwealth.
The jobs fostered by the tax benefit and the policies of the fiscally autonomous commonwealth government have steadily raised Puerto Ricans' per capita income to $6,360 from the $296 it was four decades ago. Yet it still lags far behind the $19,796 in the 50 states.
The Treasury has questioned the cost-effectiveness of Section 936, saying that in 1989 American taxpayers laid out $66,081 for every job pharmaceutical companies created in Puerto Rico. That sum is a mirage because it assumes that plants would remain on the island or elsewhere in the U.S. -- as if there were no other options.
Studies by KPMG Peat Marwick and Price Waterhouse show that repeal would put an immediate halt to new investment and produce a gradual exodus of companies that came to Puerto Rico because of Section 936.
We would lose, directly and indirectly, about 164,000 jobs -- about 17 percent of the island's jobs. Our unemployment rate (never less than twice the mainland's and at times four times as high) would shoot from today's 16 percent to at least 33 percent. We would lose 40 percent of our bank deposits.
Puerto Rico is no more overseas than Hawaii. The Section 936 jobs are occupied by U.S. citizens for whose well-being Washington carries economic responsibility. The alternative is increased spending for social programs, loss of work and harsh dislocations through further migration to the mainland.
Puerto Rico would not be able to compete in a North American Free Trade Agreement common market for investments or market share with Mexico, which sets its own economic policies.
Repeal would contradict the whole thrust of the President's economic policy. Surely he does not intend to inflict hardship on the island.

HEADLINE: U.S. Overstates Trade Deficit With China;
Single in Beijing

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your Feb. 17 article on the Westport Unitarian Singles Group, a Connecticut singles club with 2,000 members: "This group just couldn't exist in Idaho or many other places," you quote one club member as saying. He hasn't been to Beijing. 
 At the Beijing Weekend Club he would feel right at home with more than 300 women and men (26 to 75 years old), who have packed the club since April 1991.
On a recent trip to China researching gender and organizational change, I accompanied Dr. Wang Xingjuan, its founder, to the club one snowy November evening last fall. I danced, ate sunflower seeds, sang along in the kereoke (video) room and listened to tales of lost loves and romantic desires from widows, divorcees and the never-married.
The economic front is not the only area in which China is experiencing reform. The current era, which is known as "market economy with socialist tendencies," might better be known as a market economy with social tendencies. Maybe the Chinese-American balance of trade could be evened up if the two clubs exchange mailing lists!
 
VIRGINIA CORNUE
New Brunswick, N.J., Feb. 19, 1993
The writer, adjunct professor of women's studies at Montclair State College, is a graduate student in anthropology at Rutgers University.

HEADLINE: U.S. Overstates Trade Deficit With China

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Stirring Giant," your two-part series on China's awakening economy (front page, Feb. 14 and 15), emphasizes the growth of the United States trade deficit with China to $18.2 billion in 1992, the second largest United States import surplus after Japan. 
 The Clinton Administration should know that Western claims are the opposite of statistics from China. According to a recent Central Intelligence Agency publication, Chinese statistics show a small import surplus from the United States in 1991.
The difference is apparently caused in large part by the inclusion in United States statistics of Hong Kong export surpluses of transshipped mainland goods. Since Hong Kong will revert to China in 1997, United States statisticians are anticipating by about five years.
Another possible explanation of the discrepancy between United States and Chinese claims is the handling of Chinese gold imports, which have risen significantly. United States policy on gold has for decades been aimed at reducing the worldwide significance of gold, since it was a principal export of both the former Soviet Union and South Africa, neither of which was considered particularly friendly.
As a result, United States gold stocks in Fort Knox for the last two decades have been valued at approximately 42 dollars per ounce, about 10 percent of world market prices for gold. This is in contrast to France, where gold reserves are valued at world market prices.
Chinese trade policy, however, is still highly influenced by Maoist ideology, directed toward achieving "balanced equivalents" or lack of significant export or import surpluses with trading partners. This bias showed up in 1972, when Chou Enlai announced that the Chinese, in contrast to other Asian countries occupied by Japanese troops in the 1930's and 40's, would renounce any claims to Japanese reparations since this would presumably mean large Chinese import surpluses from Japan.
Reluctance to run import surpluses still shows up in the "subversiveness" of Chinese dissidents pressing for Japanese reparations. In 1989, according to the Voice of America, the leader of this grass-roots movement, which has collected 35,000 signatures, was placed under house arrest.
In lectures I gave in Beijing last September, I deplored the persistence of the balanced equivalents position and said that this was the golden moment to press Chinese claims. This position was received with enigmatic smiles from my audiences. I would also assume that Japanese businessmen, who are suffering from the worldwide recession, would be pleased should the Japanese Government recognize its moral responsibilities to pay reparations to China.
It is the dynamism of the greater China economy, including Taiwan and Hong Kong, in contrast to the worldwide recession affecting South Korea, Japan and all of Europe, including the former Soviet Union, that has stimulated interest in the Chinese locomotive.
 
LYNN TURGEON
Hempstead, L.I., Feb. 24, 1993
The writer retired as professor of economics at Hofstra University.

HEADLINE: New York Hit By Increases In Migration

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
About twice as many people moved out of New York as moved in from other states during the late 1980's, according to a new census analysis of a broad population shift over the decade, but New York appeared to have stanched the exodus, compared with the late 1970's.
In a study that gives more details about a trend described in earlier reports, the Census Bureau put New York near the top of the list of areas that lost more residents than they gained from other states. The list was led by California. But in both states, immigration from other countries was significant. 
 According to the bureau, twice as many New Yorkers who left moved to New Jersey as to California. And three times as many moved to Florida.
New York expatriates accounted for 1 in 6 of the 2 million people who moved to Florida from other states between 1985 and 1990 -- a diverse exodus that included job-seekers who found work in booming Orlando and former Gov. Hugh L. Carey, who found a tax haven in Boca Raton when the New York-based conglomerate for which he worked shifted its headquarters there.
 
An Influx of Foreigners
 An influx of foreigners may have spared both New York and California possible population losses. But the shift of 1.8 million Californians to other states signaled a turnabout in the state's reputation as a magnet for migration. Florida, Georgia, North Carolina, Virginia, Washington, Arizona and Nevada showed a larger net gain of people from other states during the second half of the decade than California did.
The report also said that more people had left New Jersey for other states than the number who moved in but that an infusion of foreigners also gave the state a net gain in migration. The pattern in Connecticut was similar. For demographers, population growth can be one measure of a region's economic vigor and of confidence in its future. Measured against trends in other states, the changes also determine the size of a state's Congressional delegation and the amount of money a state collects from Washington under a wide variety of Government programs based on population figures.
Changing regional demand for jobs is often cited by people and companies as a chief motivation for moving, and the uneven onset of the recession profoundly shaped migration patterns during the late 1980's. Other variables influence mobility, too, and as the population ages, they affect where people retire and how many of them return to rejoin their children or other relatives when they can no longer care for themselves or require more sophisticated medical treatment.
 
Oversaturated Neighbors
 Some of the biggest gainers, like Georgia and Nevada, were the beneficiaries of spillover from their seemingly oversaturated neighbors, Florida and California.
The migration figures released yesterday were not defined by income, race, ethnicity or age. But demographers say raw numbers -- the move of 28,000 New Yorkers to South Carolina or of 12,000 Illinois residents to Alabama -- hint at the reversal of one decadeslong trend: blacks who migrated north are returning to the South.
Kristin Hansen, the Census Bureau demographer who compiled the figures, said their significance generally lies in the details rather than in the broader new trends. Still, she said, the surge in Asian and Hispanic immigrants that took place in the decade, the sharp decline in the pace of California's growth and a shrinking of the total migration from New York were noteworthy.
 
Moving to Other States
 Between 1975 and 1980, about 1.7 million New Yorkers moved to another state, including 197,000 to New Jersey, 94,000 to Pennsylvania, 77,000 to Connecticut, 364,000 to Florida and 180,000 to California.
Between 1985 and 1990, the departures slowed slightly, with more than 1.5 million New Yorkers moving to another state. Over the same period, nearly as many people moved into New York from abroad as from another state, vastly reducing the losses in net migration.
In its own analysis, the New York City Planning Department found a marked reversal in migration between New York and Texas over a decade. During the late 1970's, Texas recorded a net gain of 65,000 New Yorkers. In the late 1980's, when the energy bust struck Texas, New York reported a net gain of nearly 3,000 Texans.
 
Shifting Patterns
 Joseph Salvo of the City Planning Department's population division said that New York State lost fewer people to California and Florida in the late 1980's but that the net loss to New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Maryland and Virginia increased.
During the second half of the decade, New York attracted 96,000 people from New Jersey, 64,000 people each from California and from Florida, 61,000 from Pennsylvania, 50,000 from Massachusetts, 42,000 from Texas, 42,000 from Puerto Rico and 40,000 from Connecticut.
At the same time, 361,000 New Yorkers moved to Florida, 219,000 to New Jersey, 125,000 to California, 102,000 to Pennsylvania, 77,000 to Connecticut, 68,000 to Virginia, 63,000 to North Carolina, 42,000 to Maryland, 40,000 to Georgia and 39,000 to Texas.
North Dakota was the destination for the smallest contingent of New Yorkers who left the state -- 621. Twice that number of North Dakotans moved to New York.
 
Questions on Census Form
 The statistics released yesterday are drawn from questions on the 1990 census form in which Americans were asked where they lived five years before and where they were born.
Their responses showed that among the 230 million Americans over the age of 4 in 1990, nearly half had lived in a different house only five years earlier. Among those who moved, though, only 1 in 5 left for another state.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 13, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a 1990 census report on the number of people who moved to other states referred incorrectly to the effect of a population shift on California. California lost more residents to other states than New York did over the last decade, but it still attracted more new residents than it lost.

HEADLINE: U.S. Overstates Trade Deficit With China

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Stirring Giant," your two-part series on China's awakening economy (front page, Feb. 14 and 15), emphasizes the growth of the United States trade deficit with China to $18.2 billion in 1992, the second largest United States import surplus after Japan.

The difference is apparently caused in large part by the inclusion in United States statistics of Hong Kong export surpluses of transshipped mainland goods. Since Hong Kong will revert to China in 1997, United States statisticians are anticipating by about five years.
Another possible explanation of the discrepancy between United States and Chinese claims is the handling of Chinese gold imports, which have risen significantly. United States policy on gold has for decades been aimed at reducing the worldwide significance of gold, since it was a principal export of both the former Soviet Union and South Africa, neither of which was considered particularly friendly.
As a result, United States gold stocks in Fort Knox for the last two decades have been valued at approximately 42 dollars per ounce, about 10 percent of world market prices for gold. This is in contrast to France, where gold reserves are valued at world market prices.
Chinese trade policy, however, is still highly influenced by Maoist ideology, directed toward achieving "balanced equivalents" or lack of significant export or import surpluses with trading partners. This bias showed up in 1972, when Chou Enlai announced that the Chinese, in contrast to other Asian countries occupied by Japanese troops in the 1930's and 40's, would renounce any claims to Japanese reparations since this would presumably mean large Chinese import surpluses from Japan.
Reluctance to run import surpluses still shows up in the "subversiveness" of Chinese dissidents pressing for Japanese reparations. In 1989, according to the Voice of America, the leader of this grass-roots movement, which has collected 35,000 signatures, was placed under house arrest.
In lectures I gave in Beijing last September, I deplored the persistence of the balanced equivalents position and said that this was the golden moment to press Chinese claims. This position was received with enigmatic smiles from my audiences. I would also assume that Japanese businessmen, who are suffering from the worldwide recession, would be pleased should the Japanese Government recognize its moral responsibilities to pay reparations to China.
It is the dynamism of the greater China economy, including Taiwan and Hong Kong, in contrast to the worldwide recession affecting South Korea, Japan and all of Europe, including the former Soviet Union, that has stimulated interest in the Chinese locomotive.
 
LYNN TURGEON
Hempstead, L.I., Feb. 24, 1993
The writer retired as professor of economics at Hofstra University.

HEADLINE: Aid to Russia: Should Yeltsin Be the Focus?

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 10

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's energetic new campaign to help Boris N. Yeltsin comes at a time when the Russian President's political future is again precarious and he is engaged once again in the trenches with a hostile Congress.
And once again, the instinct of the more democratic, prosperous West to protect the tender shoots of freedom in Russia has run up against difficult questions: Can Western aid really help Russia until it sorts out its political and economic mess? What sort of aid does Russia need? Is Mr. Yeltsin really on the ropes? Should the West be concentrating so hard on Mr. Yeltsin -- or on Russia? 
 President Clinton has made abundantly clear in recent days that he wants urgent and visible aid for Russia and for Mr. Yeltsin. He has scheduled a summit meeting with the Russian leader in Vancouver, British Columbia, on April 3 and 4, and he has declared that the major industrial democracies must get together soon to formulate a strategy of assistance.
 
Not a Clear-Cut Choice
 However well it might fit Mr. Clinton's plan, Russia's political crisis does not lend itself to a struggle between a "reformist" President and a "reactionary" Congress, in which victory by one or the other would necessarily bring either unhindered reform or renewed dictatorship -- or in which the United States or the West can swing the outcome through a quick infusion or aid or support.
However vicious and real it may be, the current Congress is likely to be only one of many convulsions of a system in the process of profound and bewildering transformation.
The process is as complex as Russia is vast. Even if the Congress was entirely behind Mr. Yeltsin, political and economic reform would still have to constantly struggle against inherent inertia, against local and regional ambitions, against corruption, organized crime and entrenched bureaucrats and, above all, against a mind-set alien to democracy and a free market.
That does not mean that Mr. Yeltsin is dispensable. As the one truly democratically elected official in Russia and as a stalwart champion of reform, he is both a powerful bulwark and a symbol of Russia's potential. At the current session of the Congress, proposals have already been made to reduce Mr. Yeltsin's powers and to transfer control over the Government to the Congress.
The conservative Parliament, under its ambitious chairman, Ruslan I. Khasbulatov, would then use its powers to slow or reverse economic reforms.
 
Yeltsin Welcomes Support
 Mr. Yeltsin, for his part, has welcomed the support. On his way to the Congress today, he told reporters: "All those who sympathize with us morally and materially unquestionably give support to our reforms, and the U.S. president is helping us now very seriously in political terms by backing the policy of reforms and the Russian President."
Indeed, nobody would deny that a public demonstration of support is politically beneficial -- even if the national referendum that was to be held on April 11, for which the summit meeting was evidently timed, is canceled, as it is now likely to be.
Though few politicians believe Mr. Yeltsin can be toppled anytime soon, he is in political danger, and the current session of Congress is generally viewed as the least predictable to date, especially since the only item on its agenda is division of state powers.
After so many confrontations and crises, Russians no longer whoop with joy when some Western leader declares support or promises aid. For one thing, not much of that aid has materialized. For another, there has not been widespread hunger, unemployment, or social upheaval yet in Russia, despite the constant doomsday forecasts. For another, long gone is the naive early notion that an International Monetary Fund austerity program, a few billion in aid and a round of elections can transform Russia.
It is noteworthy that the Clinton Administration's discussion of aid has not received much publicity in Moscow, certainly nothing in comparison with the political maneuvering around the Congress. Only Izvestia has given the developments in Washington regular coverage.
It is not that Russians have become hostile to America, even though hard-line Communists and nationalists relentlessly assail Mr. Yeltsin and his Government for "selling out" to the West.
Political analysts say the authority of America remains high. "The American voice has a strong impact," said Otto Latsis, a commentator in Izvestia. "Some years ago it was seen as the voice of a potential foe, but now it's taken as the voice of a partner."
But much as Russians may admire America, most seem convinced that they are different, that their history and traditions do not make them suitable for an American-style democracy or market.
That has led even some of the most pro-Western of Russian leaders to urge Americans not to expect Russia to fall automatically in lockstep with the United States, either in its internal organization or in its foreign policies.
 
Targets Unclear
 Another question that has stymied would-be Western donors is where to target aid. Western experts now agree that whatever hunger or poverty Russia has is the result of disorganization, not shortages.
There are estimates that more than a billion dollars each month leaves Russia for Western bank accounts and investments, far more than any incoming aid, the result of a totally muddled system of banking, export controls and monetary policy. These are not figures that garner political support for aid.
Even where aid has a specific target, problems are enormous. On Tuesday, a United States Senate committee was told that bickering among republics with nuclear weapons and lingering superpower ambitions among Russians have enabled American officials to disburse only $25 million of $800 million allocated to help former Soviet states dismantle nuclear weapons.
And while the Clinton Administration debates new forms of aid, shipments of grain to Russia have been stopped because Moscow has not paid its bills.
But if Americans sit back and wait for Mr. Yeltsin to get his house in order, his lieutenants argue, it will be too late. The question is not whether aid is effective or useful, they say, but whether the West is ready to commit the sort that would make a difference -- say a long-term rescheduling of Russia's $80 billion debt and a place for Russia in the West's lucrative arms market in underdeveloped countries.
That was what Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev proposed in an interview last Saturday: "The time is ripe for a much more developed and far-reaching strategy of cooperation, including the rescheduling of debt for the long term, a place at the markets -- and as a minimum equal terms for competition by economic sectors of our industries, including such sensitive areas as conventional weapons."
That is a long cry from the sort of visible and quick assistance that most Western governments have focused on. But then one thing on which both sides would probably agree now, after so many fits and starts, is that Russia's transformation will not come cheap or easy.

HEADLINE: Clinton Is Seeking to Soften The Impact of Base Closings

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
Seeking to cushion the political fallout from a round of forthcoming base closings, President Clinton will embark on a public relations offensive this week to demonstrate his commitment to help workers affected by cuts in military spending.
On Thursday, Mr. Clinton plans to visit a Baltimore company that is converting much of its business from military to civilian items. There, he plans to propose spending $15 billion to $20 billion over the next five years to help the communities and workers who would be hit hardest by military cuts and to encourage military contractors to pursue new technologies. 
 Then, seeking to show support for the military, he will visit an aircraft carrier off Norfolk, Va., on Friday to meet with troops headed for the Mediterranean.
 
Clinton to Preside
 The White House also announced today that Mr. Clinton would convene a one-day conference to grapple with another politically explosive issue: the dispute over logging and the spotted owl in the Pacific Northwest.
The April 2 conference in Portland, Ore., will be the Administration's first attempt to resolve a long-running battle between those who depend on forests for a livelihood and those who want to preserve them.
The President will preside over the conference, modeled after the economic conference in Little Rock, Ark., last December, with Vice President Al Gore, the Secretaries of Interior, Agriculture and Labor and the head of the Environmental Protection Agency. He will stop in Portland on his way to meet President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia in Vancouver, British Columbia.
"Planning and good long-term management can help us protect jobs and the unique, old-growth forests that are as much a part of our national heritage as the Grand Canyon or Yosemite," Mr. Clinton said. "It is time to break the gridlock that has blocked action and bring all sides together to craft a balanced approach to the economic and environmental challenges we face."
In last year's election, Mr. Clinton won support in many timber communities in the Northwest after promising to convene a forest conference. But as with the economic conference, White House officials said they did not expect the meeting to resolve the dispute.
George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, said the purpose of the session was for Mr. Clinton and others to "get a full understanding of the problem" and to "develop a comprehensive approach over the course of the next several months."
While environmental, labor and industry groups praised Mr. Clinton today for convening the conference, some also expressed concern about its possible outcome.
"Everybody's nervous about it because it's an unknown," said Brock Evans, a National Audubon Society vice president and one of many people briefed on the conference today by White House officials. "We're familiar with the Congressional arena, but no one knows how this is going to turn out."
White House officials have not worked out the details, such as whom to invite to testify at the public meeting or how it should be structured. Today, many in the White House were concentrating on a more pressing matter: a new round of proposed base closings.
Les Aspin, the Defense Secretary, is expected to announce his recommended closings on Friday.
Administration officials said they were packaging Mr. Clinton's relief effort to head off critics who might say he was not moving quickly enough to help those affected. Mr. Clinton has brought in Paul Begala, a principal consultant in the Presidential campaign, to help develop a political strategy to make the closings more palatable.
"The President has a deeply held belief that you have to have a way to bring along the people who otherwise would be out there in the wind, bearing the cost of change," said Bowman Cutter, a White House deputy for economic policy.
That is why, officials said, Mr. Clinton is using the Westinghouse Electronic Services in Baltimore as the backdrop for his announcement on Thursday. The plant manufactured navigation devices and sensors for the Air Force but is now developing that equipment for civilian purposes, such as detecting bursts of wind at airports that are dangerous to commercial airliners and for sensors that police departments can use to determine when an officer has fired a gun.
White House officials said they would ask Congress to spend $1.8 billion in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 on a package that would include aid for retraining workers and for communities most affected by the military cuts. Almost all of that money had been appropriated by Congress during the Bush Administration, but the Administration chose not to spend it.
Administration officials said about half the $15 billion to $20 billion in proposed spending in the next five years would go to help displaced workers, including supplementing their incomes and helping them find jobs, and to help communities establish retraining programs and to seek new industries.
The other half would be for development of new technology through financing of joint ventures among companies exploring new areas for military conversion, and grants to local governments and universities to develop such programs. About three-quarters of the money going to the development half of the program had already been proposed as part of Mr. Clinton's economic stimulus package.

HEADLINE: Senate Panel Summons 12 From the Fed

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
On the surface, they were called to talk about the economy, which they said was slowly improving. But there were other reasons why Congress, for the first time in decades, summoned the presidents of the Federal Reserve System's 12 regional banks to testify: several senators wanted to show them who was boss.
And on the same day, the Fed reported in its survey of economic conditions, the so-called beige book, that growth continued early this year, although New England and California remained weak. The report said that retail sales held up well after Christmas and that manufacturing continued to increase, with the strongest gains in household items and durable consumer goods. 
 But, the report said, banks were still making few commercial loans to allow small and medium-size businesses to expand. Today, the Clinton Administration introduced a package of technical measures to make credit more accessible to those businesses.
While the Federal Reserve's 12 starchy, dark-suited bankers squeezed uncomfortably together, the hearing before the Senate Banking Committee was cordial. Yet tensions were barely hidden.
 
Pointed Reminder Seen
 Fed-watchers said the central bankers had been called by the committee so they could be reminded that if they did not cooperate in pushing economic growth, Congress might move to reduce their power and the Federal Reserve's independence.
While several senators prodded them to do more to promote growth, the central bankers explained why they thought it was vital to keep inflation low. They also expressed optimism about the state of the economy, saying that growth should be moderately strong this year.
Senator Connie Mack, Republican of Florida, accused Democrats of orchestrating the hearing to intimidate the Federal Reserve presidents into following Congress's wishes. "This is a coup d'etat on monetary policy," Mr. Mack said. "Exerting more Congressional rule over monetary policy would be a horrible mistake."
Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, contended that he did not understand objections about inviting the Fed presidents to testify. He is sponsoring a proposal that would strip the regional-bank chiefs of their votes on the Federal Reserve's main policy-setting group, the Open Market Committee.
Mr. Sarbanes, a Fed critic, was, for the most part, disarmingly polite today. "The Fed does have a responsibility to publicly account for its policies," he said. "That's not inconsistent with its independence."
 
Accountable to Whom?
 Some Democrats in Congress say the regional bank presidents are not sufficiently accountable because, unlike the seven governors of the Federal Reserve Board, they are not appointed by the President but chosen by business executives in their areas.
Several of the bankers took pains to show that they had not forgotten the public's desire for economic growth.
One of them, Robert P. Forrestal, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, said, "I believe the Fed, like other policy institutions that act on behalf of society, must keep public preferences in mind when pursuing social goals.".
A few praised President Clinton's plan to cut the budget deficit and signaled that they would cooperate to promote growth. Robert D. McTeer Jr., head of the Dallas bank, said, "I am sure I speak for my colleagues as well as myself when I say that whatever the ultimate fiscal outcome, we will do our best to support it with a monetary policy that is in the broad national interest."
Translated, that means that if tax increases or other parts of the deficit-reduction plan retard growth, the Fed will try to keep rates low to offset the plan's negative effects.
The Fed's beige book said that in the New York region, discussions with 25 manufacturers showed that most expected moderate sales increases in the next six months, but felt that they could not significantly raise prices. More than half indicated that they planned to reduce investment this year.

HEADLINE: House Committee Clears Clinton Plan To Shrink the Deficit Over Five Years

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
President Clinton's plans to shrink the deficit cleared their first Congressional hurdle tonight when Democrats pushed his proposals through the House Budget Committee on a 26-to-17 party-line vote.
The Senate Budget Committee scheduled votes for Thursday on a similar measure calling for $502 billion in spending cuts and revenue increases over five years. 
 Under each plan the Federal deficit, which is now about $300 billion a year, would fall to below $200 billion annually by the end of Mr. Clinton's term. But exactly what the figure will be depends both on the state of the economy and the costs of whatever Congress and Mr. Clinton do about health care.
On a short-term budget matter, there were stirrings of Democratic discontent with the President's $16 billion spending package meant to stimulate the economy. Fifteen Democrats met with him at the White House on Tuesday night to urge him to scale it back. They reported he made no comment on their proposals.
In the House, fiscal conservatives like Representatives Charles W. Stenholm, Democrat of Texas, and Timothy J. Penny, Democrat of Minnesota, were seeking to reduce the package or find savings elsewhere to help pay for it. "I can't tell whether we'll be influential," Mr. Penny said.
 
Too Big or Too Small
 House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said at a news conference that Democrats were concerned about the package, both about whether it was too small or too big. But it was plain that they were more worried about the package's being too big. Democrats planned a caucus for Thursday to try to solidify support, since if Republicans remain solid in opposition, they cannot lose the votes of many more than 35 of their 255 members and pass the plan.
Before adopting its deficit plan, the House Budget Committee quickly rejected a Republican alternative that would have narrowed the deficit by a total of $429 billion over five years, without the tax increases the Democratic plan called for. The Republican plan would have cut Federal spending for Medicare, Medicaid and food and nutrition programs, among other items.
That proposal, offered by Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, was beaten, 27 to 15. Only Representative Rick A. Lazio, a freshman New York Republican, did not vote with his party. He joined 26 Democrats in voting no.
 
No Real Authority
 Much of the Senate debate and the House votes concerned spending details over which the Budget Committees have no real authority.
The committees were considering budget resolutions, the first Congressional step in the annual budget process. They establish the total amount of revenue that should be raised by taxes and set a limit on the total amount that can be spent for all programs that require annual appropriations. Similarly, they also set total levels for programs like Social Security, Medicare and farm price supports in which Government money is distributed according to formulas to everyone who meets eligibility requirements.
Despite all today's talk and votes about which programs should be cut where, the details of the resolutions are not binding. If the Congress decides later it would rather spend more on the space station and less on the staff of the Department of Veterans Affairs, it can.
Even so, the House votes presented an unaccustomed spectacle of Democratic resolve. Democrats who opposed projects like the space station or the superconducting supercollider in the past were sticking with Mr. Clinton today in supporting them.
 
Switching Positions
 When Republicans, defenders of the supercollider in the past, offered an amendment against it, Representative Mike Parker, Democrat of Mississippi, announced his vote on their amendment this way: "I hate it, but no."
As the Democrats stuck to their plan, Representative Alex McMillan, Republican of North Carolina, said, "I don't admire your vote, but I admire your discipline."
In both committees, Republicans ridiculed the Democratic proposals as vague and lacking in specifics. Senator Phil Gramm of Texas called it "the same old smoke-and-mirror phony document we've seen in the past."
In the House, Mr. Kasich quarreled with the lack of detail in the additional $63 billion of cuts committee Democrats came up with this week. "After weeks of saying, 'Show us the specifics,' you come in here and say you don't have to show us your specifics." he said "We show you ours and unfortunately you don't show us yours."
The Senate committee was debating a slightly different plan put forward by its chairman, Jim Sasser of Tennessee, to lower the budget deficit by a total of $502 billion over the next five years.
The Sasser plan closely follows the Clinton prescriptions for raising taxes and reducing spending. The plan would cut the deficit by $96 billion more than the Clinton package would over the five-year period, mainly by spending slightly less than Mr. Clinton wants in the next two years and by raising taxes slightly more over the next five years.
"There is absolutely no restructuring of the President's conceptual or philosophical approach," Mr. Sasser said.
In two days of meetings, the senators have taken no votes and have accomplished nothing except making political points. Senator Barbara Boxer, a freshman Democrat from California, watching the process firsthand for the first time wondered aloud, "What if there is someone watching this thing on TV?"
But with the senators eager to not to have their weekend getaway disrupted, they decided to stop debating and begin voting Thursday afternoon with a final committee vote scheduled for late Thursday.

Kasich. Speaking at right was Representative Jim Kolbe and at center was Representative Alex McMillan. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)
