HEADLINE: Giving Smaller Factories Big Ideas

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HUNTINGTON, W. Va.

 BODY:
When Paul Carman first saw the big Cincinnati Milacron T-10 at the Byrd Institute here, he gazed straight into his own future. The computer-controlled milling machine could spit out intricately shaped metal parts in 12 minutes -- 15 times faster than his own shop. And he could use the $350,000 T-10 for only $30 to $35 a hour.
Mr. Carman's first visit to West Virginia's "teaching factory" was an eye-opener. A hands-on center that gives small manufacturers low-cost access to some of the most advanced technology and management expertise around, it is equipped with the computerized tools and instruments that can ignite productivity and sales but that most small companies simply cannot afford to test. 
 Until now.
With public and private financing, Byrd and its counterparts in St. Louis and Toledo, Ohio, are models for the new Clinton Administration economic initiative aimed at shoring up the nation's manufacturing base. The National Center for Manufacturing Sciences, the not-for-profit industry research group that oversees the three centers, plans to open 15 more teaching factories this year. And that number could grow to hundreds in the next few years if President Clinton fulfills the pledge in last month's economic message to "give small business access to all the technologies of our time."
 
A Practical Opportunity
 Allowing small companies to use high-technology production machinery to turn out their products is not all the teaching factories do, though that is what distinguishes them from other industrial aid programs. "We want people to come in here and operate the equipment," said David M. Porreca, director of Byrd, which opened in 1989 and was the first of the three centers. "We think hands-on is a good way to transfer technology."
In a partnership with a local university, Byrd also offers classes in modern quality control, like statistical process control and computer-aided design, at its high-tech headquarters in an old bank building here. It also sends instructors into factories to teach first-line supervisors -- often newly promoted -- how to manage and motivate workers.
Each of the three teaching factories is tailored to its region. The one here aims to help the mostly small machine shops and mining equipment manufacturers prevalent in the area, while the one in St. Louis is geared to assist suppliers to the big aircraft and automobile manufacturers there. The Toledo center focuses on the tool and die industry.
For Mr. Carman, the Byrd center was a fine solution to a serious problem. He was eager to get experience using machines like the T-10, he said, because the manually operated lathes and mills in his eight-person shop in Ashland, Ky., are obsolete. He knows computer controls are the wave of the future. "We want to move in that direction," he said, "but we have to get our feet wet first."
 
 
Race for Greater Productivity
 The teaching factories are among several models being tested to improve the performance of small manufacturers, which have fallen behind larger American companies and rivals in Japan and Germany in the race for greater productivity. Other approaches include the technology extension services operated by about a dozen industrial states and seven National Institute of Standards and Technology demonstration centers.
Last month, President Clinton pledged to expand the technology development efforts of the institute vastly, by spending $1.3 billion over four years for industry-Government research initiatives. This year the outlay for the demonstration centers is $17 million.
 
Big Military Component
 Much of Byrd's annual $4 million in financing now comes from the Defense Department, which fears that erosion of the nation's manufacturing capabilities will damage the ability to produce military hardware. So it is not surprising to hear Byrd described in military terms.
"We consider that we are at war, and our small companies are fighting with rocks and sticks," said Steve Ricketts, a vice president of N.C.M.S. The $200 million research organization, based in Ann Arbor, Mich., is financed by manufacturers, the Federal Government and philanthropists.
Mr. Ricketts said the teaching factories could help small companies improve their weaponry by providing easy access to advanced production methods. The segment of the military budget devoted to civilian research is not currently scheduled for cutbacks, but the Administration seems bent on transferring control of such programs to the Commerce Department.
Like the teaching hospitals they are modeled after, the teaching factories have the equivalent of operating rooms. At Byrd, one contains a high-tech manufacturing unit in which automated machine tools are linked by an oval conveyor belt and robots take the place of machinists.
The unit is connected to desks equipped with personal computers at which manufacturing workers and college students can learn to operate in an automated environment. The institute is affiliated with Marshall University and its community college, which provide courses in computer-aided design and manufacturing that students can test at Byrd.
 
Lower Productivity
 There is no question that small manufacturers need help. Companies with fewer than 500 employees are 25 percent less productive than larger ones because they lack advanced equipment and production techniques, according to an analysis of Census statistics by the Industrial Technology Institute, a not-for-profit research and consulting group based in Ann Arbor.
Although they are seldom directly involved in world trade, these 360,000 small companies supply basic bits and pieces to the big manufacturers that compete with foreign companies. Some parts Mr. Carman machined on the T-10, for example, went into mining equipment exported to Australia. The analysis by the I.T.I. found that 45 percent of the value added to raw materials by manufacturing in America comes from small companies.
For example, Jack Klim's D & E Industries, based in Huntington, forges shifter forks used in large truck transmissions assembled and sold by the Rockwell International Corporation. Forging is like a first approximation of hell. Workers use long tongs to place red-hot bars of steel into a two-story machine. They hammer the bars into shape with floor-shaking thuds, as flames from lubricating fluids shoot out and smoke and grit hang in the air.
As low-tech as the forming process is, the forks must meet high-tech standards. Because a transmission's smoothness depends on how close to specification the parts are, Rockwell insists that Mr. Klim document the accuracy of the forks' dimensions on statistical control charts. Those charts must be included with the shipments. Instructors at Byrd taught Mr. Klim's workers how to prepare the charts, both at headquarters and during visits to the plant.
 
'Set Ourselves Apart'
 "Rockwell can buy all across the world," Mr. Klim said. "We had to do something to set ourselves apart." Since he can now meet world standards for pricing, quality and delivery, Mr. Klim got the fork business and recently negotiated a three-year extension of his contract.
Rockwell benefits, too, cutting costs because Mr. Klim's parts are pre-checked and shipped directly to the assembly line. Fewer incoming parts inspectors are required.
Senator Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico, who is backing legislation to provide more assistance to smaller manufacturers, said Japan and Germany do far more for their industries than the United States. Japan, he said, spends $500 million annually on a network of 170 manufacturing support centers. Germany has its noted apprentice training programs and government-backed centers to speed the transfer of technology from laboratories to producers.
For Paul Carman, whose Kilbourne Machine Company in nearby Kentucky was established in 1902, the ability to do actual production runs on Byrd equipment justified sending his shop foreman here for training. Small shops like his do not have the luxury of sending workers to class to keep up with changing technology.
"It takes time and money to learn technology," said Mr. Porreca, Byrd's director. He said the institute priced the use of its equipment low enough so small companies could afford to explore the unknown.
Not all new technology involves machines, of course. Managers are recognizing that the order-barking style of factory management does not generate high quality and productivity. So they are looking for ways to train first-line supervisors in up-to-date people-handling methods.
Part of the problem is the way foremen are chosen. In sports, there is no guarantee that a star running back will make a good football coach. Similarly, there is no reason to assume that the best factory worker will make an effective supervisor.
But that is who is promoted, observed Dick Kirby, vice president of manufacturing for the Service Machine Company, a local manufacturer of electrical distribution equipment used with mining machinery. "You have an individual who has been working here for 10 or 15 years, and he's the most highly skilled in his area," he said. "So he's made a supervisor and crosses the line into management. Now he's responsible for scheduling, planning, regulatory compliance and motivating people -- things he's never been exposed to before."
Mr. Kirby turned to Byrd to help his supervisors learn the communications and motivational skills to keep his 150-employee plant humming. The 27-hour course is being taught at the plant at night, so all the supervisors can learn as a group.
Properly motivated workers are important to Service Machine. Because its products are used in coal mines, where one spark can cause a lethal explosion, the equipment must conform to rigid standards.
 
Help With New Line
 Chuck Nease, who owns Mountaineer Archery, a local manufacturer of compound bows for hunters and target shooters, said Byrd's computerized machinery let him develop a new line quickly and inexpensively. In his older bows, the centerpiece is made of magnesium cast in a die. The new one has a centerpiece made of aluminum machined on automated equipment at the institute.
The change has cut the lead time for producing a new bow to eight weeks from six months, and the cost of producing a new model is down, too. "We are talking about a $400 program compared to a $70,000 die," Mr. Nease said.
Back at his shop in Ashland, Paul Carman keeps thinking about the big Cincinnati Milicron T-10 he learned to operate at Byrd.
"With the present size of this business, it is hard to justify a $350,000 machine," he said. "But if I could get a long-term contract with a respectable company, I'd have one in here next week."

HEADLINE: Accord Signed for a Casino in New York State

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VERONA, N.Y., March 10

 BODY:
Negotiators for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the Oneida Indians have reached agreement on a compact that would allow the opening of New York State's first high-stakes gambling casino in a tiny rural community near the center of the state.
The compact must now be signed by Mr. Cuomo and the United States Secretary of the Interior before the Oneidas can open a new $10 million casino that is near completion on rolling farmland owned by the Indians adjacent to the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway about 30 miles east of Syracuse. 
 Mr. Cuomo has said he wants the Legislature's response to the agreement before he signs it. Some legislators said that is an attempt to shift responsibility for a decision that could spark opposition on and off Indian lands. The state is also negotiating a gambling compact with the 3,400 St. Regis Mohawk Indians near the Canadian border.
Both opponents and supporters of casino gambling say the Oneida compact could be the first step toward legalizing casino gambling elsewhere in the state, including in the Catskills and at Niagara Falls. Debate over the compact is likely to reflect those broader concerns.
 
Federal Law Governs
 But to a large extent, Mr. Cuomo's hands are tied. Though Mr. Cuomo has said he opposes casino gambling in New York State, he was required to negotiate the compact under a 1988 Federal law that allows Indians to have profit-making gambling operations on their land. Under that law Indians can run the same games of chance the state allows charities to run. Las Vegas nights are commonly run throughout the state by charities.
At least 52 tribes in 17 states have opened 100 casinos and large-scale bingo halls since the Federal law was passed. In 1992, the 200-member Mashantucket Pequots in Connecticut opened a casino, a runaway success that has already earned the tribe tens of millions of dollars and become a model for other East Coast tribes.
The compact now before Mr. Cuomo would allow the 1,000-member Oneida Nation to operate blackjack, roulette and craps games 24 hours a day. It does not, however, allow slot machines, which are outlawed in New York State but are major moneymakers in Nevada and Atlantic City casinos.
The agreement gives New York State a major role in regulating the Oneida's casino. Inspectors from the state Racing and Wagering Board will be present in the casino at all times, and the state will run background checks on all casino employees and managers. Security at the casino will be provided jointly by the state police and a private police force hired by the Oneidas.
The state will not share in the take, but the Oneidas must pay for any regulatory costs incurred by the state.
Inspections have been a sticking point with the Mohawks, who consider state involvement an infringement on their sovereign rights.
"It's to our benefit to have the state involved," said Ray Halbritter, the Oneida Nation representative, an elected position in the tribe. "We're more concerned about integrity than anybody. That's just good business sense. And it's the Oneida way."
Mr. Halbritter said the casino would not serve alcohol, at least at first. "Alcohol has been such a problem with our people, we can't bring ourselves to serve it," he said.
 
Financing Many Activities
 Strolling through the Oneida's cavernous glass and metal casino, which will accommodate three restaurants, shops and 5,000 patrons when it is completed this spring, Mr. Halbritter said casino gambling could pump hundreds of millions of dollars each year into a largely impoverished community.
"We'd prefer other forms of economic development, but we don't have those resources," Mr. Halbritter said. "And we don't expect the Federal and state governments to take care of our people."
In recent years, unemployment among the Oneidas has risen as high as 80 percent, with many families earning less than $5,000 a year, Mr. Halbritter said. Many Oneidas live in trailer homes on their 32-acre reservation.
With revenues from the casino, which would employ 2,000 people, the tribe plans to build housing for senior citizens, expand the health clinic and start a college scholarship fund. Gambling profits could also finance Oneida ventures such as hotels, restaurants, a museum on Indian history and companies that produce and package Indian foods and herbal medicines.
In many tribes, gambling has sparked emotional debates pitting those who consider it a violation of sacred traditions and an impetus for crime against those who welcome it as a source of venture capital. In 1985, anti-gambling Oneidas burned a bingo hall, and in 1990, two Indians were killed during protests against illegal casinos on the Mohawk reservation.
 
Wider Implications Seen
 But opposition to the Oneida compact within the Legislature is likely to come from members who consider it the first step toward casino gambling throughout the state.
"It appears as though we're backing into gaming on Indian reservations and that opens the door to having it in other places," said Assemblyman John J. Faso, a Republican from Hudson. "What are the controls, what are the effects on the local economy, how do you keep organized crime out. These are all questions you have to ask."
But supporters of gambling, who view it as a way to revive tourism in places such as the Catskills, welcomed the Oneida compact for that very reason. "All this does is reinforce my belief that casino gambling should be allowed in New York State," said Senator Nicholas A. Spano, a Yonkers Republican. "It's apparent it's here to stay, and New York State should get some benefit from it."
There are also questions as to whether the Legislature has any power to veto the compact. The Oneidas contend only Mr. Cuomo's signature is needed. And if he withholds approval, the Oneidas can ask a Federal judge to approve the agreement.

HEADLINE: Loans Overdue Dropped in '92

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
The percentage of Americans behind on their loan payments dipped last year as the economy gradually improved, a banking group said today.
The American Bankers Association said consumer loans at least 30 days past due fell to a seasonally adjusted 2.43 percent at the end of the fourth quarter, from 2.58 percent a year earlier. The rate has declined for three straight quarters, from 2.75 percent during the first quarter of last year. 
 "Clearly, 1992 was a better year for the majority of households, " said James Chessen, the association's chief economist.
Areas of the Northeast, one of the areas hit hardest by the recession, had the highest delinquency rates at the end of the year. New York's rate was 5.26 percent; Rhode Island's, 4.80 percent; Connecticut's, 4.72 percent; New Hampshire's, 4.61 percent, and Massachusetts', 4.46 percent.
The rate is derived from a poll of 800 banks in the 50 states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico. It is a composite for seven types of closed-end consumer loans and excludes first mortgages and credit card loans.
The trade group said that delinquency rates for bank credit cards declined to a seasonally adjusted 2.93 percent in the fourth quarter, from 3.14 percent in the third quarter and 3.29 percent a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Rebels in Liberia Reported to Suffer Setbacks

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
After three years of tangled politics and intermittent warfare in Liberia, the rebel leader Charles Taylor's military position is deteriorating rapidly, according to reports from West Africa and State Department officials.
The officials say Mr. Taylor's rebel force, the National Patriotic Front of Liberia, is being pressed hard by a better armed West African peacekeeping force and their militia allies. 
 In addition, State Department experts say that Mr. Taylor is running out of fuel as a result of an embargo being enforced by the West Africans and that his troops' morale is plummeting.
Reuters reported that Mr. Taylor is about to abandon his headquarters, Gbarnga, and move his base of operations to Zwedru, near the border with the Ivory Coast, where his forces often get supplies.
 
Down But Not Out
 Still, American officials say it is too early to declare Mr. Taylor defeated.
"Certainly Charles Taylor has major problems," said a State Department official who spoke on condition of anonymity. "But keep in mind the fact that this guy still has troops in 70 percent of the country."
Aides to Mr. Taylor deny that his military position has been weakened and say the West African peacekeeping force has put out false reports of Mr. Taylor's problems. These aides called for the deployment of United Nations peacekeepers in the country and say they will not surrender any arms to the West Africans, who they say are taking sides in the civil war.
"What they are trying to do is put out a lot of false propaganda that doesn't contribute to the peace process," said Momolu Sirleaf, who describes himself as foreign minister for Mr. Taylor and who lives in suburban Maryland.
American officials are cheered by the reports of setbacks for Mr. Taylor, who they blame for an attack on Monrovia, the country's capital, that ruptured a 20-month cease-fire. His troops also killed five American nuns last October.
 
Concern Over Alliance
 But State Department officials and some experts on Liberia have also expressed concern that the Nigerian-dominated peacekeeping force organized by the Economic Community of West African States has taken sides in the civil war.
In particular, State Department officials have expressed concern that the West African force has been cooperating with the United Liberation Movement of Liberia for Democracy and remnants of the country's Army.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Official Faults Japan's Technology Industry

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 10

 BODY:
Signaling that Japan is preparing to respond to President Clinton's proposals to improve American competitiveness, a senior Government official contends that Japan's high-technology companies have grown lazy in recent years and that the country may be forced to begin Government-led research and development projects to restore its position in electronics and computing.
Noboru Hatakeyama, the Vice Minister of International Trade and Industry and the man responsible for overseeing the country's industrial strategies, harshly criticized Japanese technology companies. He said Tuesday that they had failed to master some critical technologies like microprocessors and computer work stations and that a concerted effort in coming years would be needed for Japan to catch up. "We cannot keep losing," he said. 
 "Up until now, we never thought that some industries have lost competitiveness," Mr. Hatakeyama said. "But now we have to face up to it."
 
Sees U.S.-Style Network
 Mr. Hatakeyama said no concrete plans had yet been made for research and development initiatives, and he suggested it would be several years before they came together.
But on a more urgent timetable, he added, his ministry hopes to begin an effort that closely mirrors one of the Clinton Administration's highest technology priorities: building a new, far more sophisticated telecommunications infrastructure. The idea, he said, would be "very similar" to the Clinton-Gore effort to build an information superhighway that would lead to a national high-speed computer network.
Mr. Hatakeyama's comments to a group of foreign correspondents were particularly striking because the critiques he offered about Japan -- and the solutions he proposed -- mirrored Japanese criticisms of the United States that had been issued here for years. Time and again, officials from Mr. Hatakeyama's ministry have lectured visitors that American industry needed to adopt a Japanese-style focus on the long term and a willingness for cooperation between business and government.
 
Bloated Powerhouses
 Mr. Hatakeyma, however, painted a very different picture, describing some of Japan's biggest industrial powerhouses as bloated and shortsighted. These days, he suggested, Japan is paying the price for a spending spree in which it added far too much factory capacity and gave too little thought to the technologies of the future.
"One of the reasons Japanese companies lost their competitiveness was their laziness during the bubble era," Mr. Hatakeyma said, referring to the period between 1985 and late 1990, when Japan's economy soared. "They just invested in too much capacity and thought they could survive without closing down older ones," he said. "That is why we are now facing a situation of having to close old plants."
Mr. Hatakeyama's criticisms notwithstanding, many economists have noted for several years that throughout the Japanese economic boom, companies spent heavily on research and development; so heavily, in fact, that the United States Congress held hearings on the "research gap" between the two countries.
 
Slow to Cut Costs
 Nonetheless, American executives working and visiting here have begun to argue in recent months that Japan is only now beginning a process of industrial restructuring that the United States started several years ago.
"For once, American industry has wrung itself out ahead of the rest of the world," Earle H. Harbison Jr., the president and chief operating officer of the Monsanto Company, said here this week.
At the same time, many economists and executives here say that pressure to restructure and cut costs plays to Japan's greatest strength. The virtual hysteria about plunges in industrial production and competitive lapses, these experts suggest, is part of the process of consensus building, creating an atmosphere that makes it easier for Japanese companies to justify breaking taboos about closing plants and forcing out workers.
Mr. Hatakeyama was quick to say that Japan's competitive troubles have their political advantages. American-made goods have become more attractive, alleviating Japan's surging trade surpluses. He noted, for example, that the Japanese market for computer work stations is dominated by two American companies. Though he did not name them, he was clearly referring to Sun Microsystems Inc. and the Hewlett-Packard Company.
But over the long term, he suggested, such dominance is not tolerable. "It is O.K. for the time being," he said. "We welcome those imports. But we cannot keep losing."

HEADLINE: Debt Grows by 5.3% in U.S.

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
Debt held by households, businesses and governments grew at a seasonally adjusted rate of 5.3 percent in the fourth quarter, the Federal Reserve Board said today.
The gain followed a 4.1 percent rate of increase in the previous quarter and reflected continuing rapid growth in Federal Government debt, the Fed said. 
 The debt report excludes banks and other financial institutions.
During the fourth quarter, Federal Government debt was mounting at a 10 percent annual rate. "In contrast, growth in debt of the non-Federal sectors was at a 3.5 percent rate," the Fed noted.
Household debt grew at a 5.7 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter after a 5.5 percent rate in the previous quarter.
Business debts rose at a 1.3 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, compared with a 0.3 percent rate in the third quarter.
The Fed said businesses are continuing to reduce their corporate debt as a percentage of equity. Corporations sold equities at an annual rate of $14 billion in the fourth quarter, the Fed said.
Debt growth among state and local governments declined in the fourth quarter to a 3.5 percent annual rate from 5.4 percent in the third quarter. The primary reason for the slowdown was a large volume of bond retirements by the state and local governments, the Fed said. Cheaper long-term interest rates have made it practical to pay off existing debt and refinance at lower rates.

HEADLINE: Trump Owes Back Taxes on Land for Tower

 BODY:
Donald J. Trump owes New York City $4.4 million in back property taxes for his land on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, where he plans to build a huge $3 billion apartment complex, city records show.
Mr. Trump said in an interview on Tuesday that he was thinking about withholding his tax payments, and would continue to do so until he gets new benefits from the city and state, including tax breaks and state-backed financing. 
 "I've always informed the city -- and I don't know if anyone was listening -- but I've always informed everyone that until such time that we get zoning and the economic development package together, to pay real-estate taxes would be foolish," Mr. Trump said on Tuesday.
Yesterday, though, after discussions with city officials who had said on Tuesday that they were unhappy with his stand, Mr. Trump telephoned The New York Times to say he had changed his mind.
 
Months in Developing
 "I've decided," he said late yesterday afternoon, 24 hours after insisting that he would not pay, "that I'm going to work out an agreement to pay the taxes."
This issue had been developing for months.
The city records show that last fall, as Mr. Trump was bargaining with city officials for extraordinary zoning changes and special permits that now allow him to build a his complex, called Riverside South, he owed the city more than $2 million in back property taxes for the site. The bill has now climbed to $4.4 million.
Virtually all of the city officials who negotiated with the developer last fall in the talks that led to final approval of the complex in December by the City Council said that they did not know that he owed taxes on the site, which is bounded by 59th Street, 72d Street, West End Avenue and the Hudson River. Mr. Trump plans to build 12 apartment towers, with a total of 5,700 apartments.
When they were told on Tuesday about the tax debt, several senior city officials said they were not inclined to discuss additional benefits with Mr. Trump while he was declining to pay taxes. Some also said they wished they had known last fall that he was falling behind on his tax payments.
Some city officials said that the zoning changes approved for Mr. Trump increased the value of his land, perhaps by hundreds of thousands of dollars, and that as a minimum he should have remained current in his tax payments. The officials could not be reached last night to comment on Mr. Trump's retraction of his threat to withhold further tax payments for the site.
There is no legal requirement that a developer be paid up on his property taxes to obtain zoning changes and other land-use benefits from the city, lawyers for the Council and other city officials said. Opponents of Riverside South argued last fall that Mr. Trump's financial status should be part of the debate on the proposal.
 
Breaks Not Part of Plan
 The Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, said on Tuesday, "There are taxes to be paid on this land and the owner ought to meet his obligations." Ms. Messinger supported the apartment complex proposal last fall when the developer and a coalition of civic groups pushed it through the city's prolonged land-use approval process.
Ms. Messinger, who has generally opposed special tax breaks for real-estate developers, said she was concerned about Mr. Trump's threat not to pay his taxes until his latest requests were approved.
 
Not Receptive
 Barbara J. Fife, deputy mayor for planning and development, said she had never been told by Mr. Trump that he would pay his property taxes only if he got approval for the zoning changes and tax breaks, and she indicated that she would not be particularly receptive to granting special tax abatements for the project.
Mr. Trump said he had talked yesterday with Mrs. Fife and Ms. Messinger, among others, about his tax bill and the additional city and state benefits that he is seeking for Riverside South. After those discussions, he said, he decided to drop his opposition and to pay the tax bill.
Officials from the city's Finance Department said that some major developers, feeling the financial pressure from the downturn in New York real estate, have let their tax payments slide. By law, if a large landowner does not pay property taxes for a year, the city can begin proceedings to take over the property. It takes at least one additional year before the city can take title to the land.
According to the Finance Department's records, Mr. Trump has not paid a property tax bill of $2,045,800 that was due last July and another bill of $2,045,992 that was due Jan. 1. With interest, at 18 percent, he owes a total of $4.4 million.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Saatchi & Saatchi's turnaround team plays back the highlights.

BYLINE: By Adam Bryant

 BODY:
THE agenda called for a discussion of Saatchi & Saatchi's 1992 finances with a small gathering of reporters in New York yesterday. But Charles Scott and Robert Louis-Dreyfus, respectively the incoming and outgoing Saatchi chief executives, were in a breeze-shooting mood, happier to talk about their past team efforts and independent futures than Saatchi's results.
But first, those sobering numbers. The company reported this week that it lost 595.1 million, or about $859 million, largely because of a write-down to conform to new British accounting rules. Those rules, addressing the way good will is carried, saddled Saatchi with a 600 million, or $866 million, write-down, reflecting Saatchi's generosity in making acquisitions during the 1980's. Still, operating profits were 18.9 million, or $27.3 million, better than many analysts' expectations. And revenue rose 1.1 percent, to 748 million, or $1.08 billion. 
 Contrary to more optimistic predictions, the two executives said that advertising spending would be flat in the United States and Europe this year.
"We're reading a lot about the pickup in the States," Mr. Louis-Dreyfus said. "But we don't see it on the client side." In Europe, he added, the reverse is true: many Saatchi clients there are saying the economy is not as bad as many believe.
Appearances can be deceiving, even at Saatchi. Consider the unlikely team of Mr. Scott and Mr. Louis-Dreyfus, who could not be more different in style. Mr. Scott looks very much at home in the standard-issue blue suit and blue dress shirt he wore yesterday, while Mr. Louis-Dreyfus looks uncomfortable in a tie. One executive of a Saatchi subsidiary said that when he first saw Mr. Louis-Dreyfus at the office wearing jeans and running shoes, he mistook him for a messenger.
Not surprisingly, Mr. Scott said his management style as chief executive would not be like his flashier predecessor's. "I don't have that sort of charisma," he said. "I'm a professional accountant and will run the company in a more orderly fashion."
To be sure, many inside the Saatchi empire say that Scott has long been Mr. Louis-Dreyfus's watchdog and financial conscience but that he has started running the company more overtly in recent months. "We've got to make the numbers work for Scott," has become an oft-repeated phrase at Saatchi agencies.
Despite speculation, Mr. Scott will not be joining Mr. Louis-Dreyfus at Adidas A.G., the troubled German athletic shoe maker, where Mr. Louis-Dreyfus will test his turnaround skills next month after a two-week skiing vacation. Before moving to Saatchi, the two men worked together at IMS International Inc., a large pharmaceuticial market-research and publishing company, and their shared history prompted many people in advertising to speculate they might work together at Adidas. "I don't think that doing something once necessitates a habit," Mr. Scott said.
Mr. Louis-Dreyfus said he was largely satisfied with his work at Saatchi, which was in terrible financial shape when he was recruited by the Saatchi brothers, Maurice and Charles, in 1989 to clean up after the company's acquisition binge of the late 1980's.
But what did he learn during the last three and a half years? "Never accept a job without being sure the bankers are behind you," he said. Shortly after Mr. Louis-Dreyfus took over, he found himself hamstrung by the unwillingness of Saatchi's bankers to support his rapid timetable for shedding operations.
He also said he regretted worrying that clients might follow employees who left or were dismissed. In hindsight, however, he described that notion with an expletive, apparently believing now that clients have more of an institutional, rather than personal, relationship with their advertising agency.
"People don't control clients the way I thought they did," he said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Off in Narrow Trading

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Treasury prices bounced around in a narrow range yesterday, ending lower as investors and traders tried to figure what the next move in interest rates would be. The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.75 percent.
Some of the downward pressure on prices came from the announcement of President Clinton's plan to encourage bank lending to small businesses. As earlier in the week, there was selling of intermediate Treasury securities because investors feared the proposal would make banks sell some of the billions of these securities they hold. 
 Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen appeared to undermine some support for the 30-year bond when he said he planned no radical change in the mix of Treasury borrowing. The prospect of a cut in the size of the 30-year bond auctions had made some speculators bet the bond's price would move higher.
 
Economic and Technical
 Since the February employment report released last Friday showed that the economy was stronger than many had thought, investors and traders have been focusing on the other reasons for interest rates to move lower. The economic reasons are low inflation and President Clinton's plan to cut the Federal budget deficit. The so-called technical reasons are the expected near-term decline in Treasury borrowing and the buying of Treasury securities by state and local governments for the escrow funds used to pay off old high-interest-rate debt.
"The technicals could resurface at any time and push interest rates lower again," said James S. Fralick, principal senior economist at Morgan Stanley. "But it is not clear whether these technicals are enough to offset some of these fears about inflation. So you will get into a trading range until these things clear up."
Some worries about inflation are arising for several reasons. One is that the economy is moving at a faster pace than expected, and another is that the Commodity Research Bureau index of prices has risen sharply recently.
Tomorrow and Wednesday, the Government will report February inflation numbers for the Producer Price Index and the Consumer Price Index. If these reports are higher than expected, bond prices could drop, pushing yields higher. "There is a lot of nervousness in the market," Mr. Fralick said.
But even if this happens, Mr. Fralick is not expecting a significant reversal in interest rates. "We could back up to 7 percent if we had a couple of bad inflation numbers," he said, referring to the yield on the 30-year bond. But to go back to 7.75 percent would be very unusual in the next six to nine months."
In trading in the secondary market, the yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.75 percent, from 6.73 percent on Tuesday, as the price fell 6/32 , to 10426/32 . The price of the five-year note, which is owned by many banks, was down 3/32 , and the yield rose to 5.22 percent, from 5.20 percent on Tuesday and 5.10 percent on Friday.
 
Bond Competition
 Do not doubt there is competition between the directors of two of the biggest borrowing operations in the country.
Yesterday, the Treasurer of California, Kathleen Brown, started a program to make state tax-exempt issues available to small investors. And she made clear that her proposal was outdoing that of the New York City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman.
The new California product, which works much like a savings bond, accommodates investors with as little as $250. New York City's mini-bond program requires a much higher investment, depending on interest rates and the maturity of the bond. An investor had to pay more than $2,500 for a 10-year mini-bond with a $5,000 face value last fall.
Ms. Brown, in an interview yesterday, said, "This is much more of an attractive investment than any of the other mini-bonds across the country."
The California program will sell zero-coupon bonds, which do not pay any interest until they mature. Because of this fact, the bond can be sold at a price far below its face value. This is the same kind of bond used in the New York program.
To get to the lower minimum investment level of $250, California has set up a unit trust, which allows investors to buy units of each bond.
In both the California and New York programs, the bonds are only for long-term investors because no interest is paid until maturity.
Andrea Bernstein, the information secretary for the New York City Comptroller, said in response to the California plan, "We will follow California closely, and if it seems to be a success, it would be an idea that we would consider."

HEADLINE: Farm County's 4-H Cuts: Head, Heart, Hand, Help!

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COBLESKILL, N.Y.

 BODY:
The boys and girls of the Dairy Dudes Club were out last month selling candy bars for $1 each. So were the members of the Sheep Thrills, the Hop-a-Lot and about 45 other 4-H Clubs here in rural Schoharie County.
The candy sales, along with chicken barbecues, bowlathons and other fund-raising, took in more than $56,000, enough to save the 4-H Clubs from extinction, at least for a while. 
 The money will also provide a reprieve for the clubs' parent organization, the Cooperative Extension Service, which had been scheduled to die on Feb. 28 as a result of broad budget cuts by the Board of Supervisors, the county's legislative body. The action by the supervisors, who are trying to keep the county tax rate down, automatically cut off matching funds from the state and Federal governments, in effect killing the Extension Service, which provides technical advice on agriculture, home economics and nutrition.
Even Donald Mackey, chairman of the supervisors' extension committee, voted against the appropriation for the Extension Service. "We had a choice," he said. "If we kept extension, we would have to lay off more workers."
 
Schoharie's Biggest Business
 Kenneth Olcott, president of the County Extension Service, said with emphasis that farming was still thriving here. "It is not a reflection of declining agriculture," he said. "It's an economic thing related to the county budget."
Indeed, agriculture is the county's biggest business, with 580 farms, mostly dairy and vegetable, making annual sales of about $30 million.
The farm community rallied to save the extension service and especially the 4-H Clubs, whose alumni include many farmers and other local residents. "Agriculture can come back, but if we lost 4-H, it could never come back," said John Stanton, a dairy farmer.
About 500 boys and girls between the ages of 8 and 18 belong to Schoharie County's 4-H, whose emblem is a four-leaf clover, with each leaf bearing the letter H, signifying health, heart, hand and head. They belong to clubs like the Dairy Dudes, which raises cows, the Sheep Thrills, which raises sheep, and the Hop-a-Lot, which raises rabbits.
 
'I Like Cows,' Says Trisha
 "It's a lot of fun," said Trisha Larkin, 11, who is a member of the Dairy Dudes. She cares for two cows and two calves herself, shows them at competitions and even on occasion judges cattle. "I like cows," she explained.
Joshua Radliff, 12, is a member of two clubs, the Dairy Dudes and the Hop-a-Lot.
"If they didn't have 4-H Clubs, a lot of people would feel really down and not as happy," he said. "The leaders they talk to you, they never yell. They're really great people."
The cliff-hanging rescue of the Extension Service and its 4-H Clubs put a spotlight on their pivotal role in education in upstate New York and their complicated financing.
 
Public-Private Cooperation
 Since 1912 the Cooperative Extension Service, based at Cornell University in Ithaca, has been advising both adults and youth. It gets its name because it is a cooperative venture between Federal, state and county governments and local residents, extending from Cornell.
Throughout the state last year it had a budget of $84 million, with 456 agents in offices in every county and in New York City. The money came 29 percent from county governments, 29 percent from the state, 19 percent from the Federal Government and the rest locally.
Because of the successful fund-raising drive here, which will allow the Extension Service to qualify for some matching money, it will continue to operate, although in a reduced form, for the rest of this year. Its budget last year was $480,000, with $200,000 coming from the county. This year it will make do with about $100,000.
Schoharie is the only county in the state that cut its extension budget completely this year. Sixteen counties cut budgets somewhat, 18 provided the same amount as last year and 22 increased their financing, according to Dr. Lucinda Noble, director of the extension service at Cornell.
"I don't see doom and gloom around the state about the future of Cooperative Extension," said Dr. Noble. "I see smaller programs, but sometimes smaller is better. We obviously will have to adjust."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In upstate Schoharie County, efforts to hold down the budget have threatened an institution that has kept interest in agriculture alive for generations of rural children, the 4-H Club. After a reprieve was found through private donations, Trisha and Lucas Larkin practiced presenting their calf as Kathy Krisowaty, the county's 4-H program manager, and, John Stanton, the farm's owner, looked on. (David Jennings for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New Jersey Air Base Stands to Lose Jobs

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
McGuire Air Force Base in New Jersey will apparently not be on the list of military bases to be shut down, but it could still lose 7,000 of its 12,000 jobs by 1996, according to preliminary plans presented to New Jersey's Congressional delegation by Pentagon officials today.
Under the plans, all active-duty military personnel now stationed at the base, which is home to the Air Force's 438th Airlift Wing, a supply unit, would be transferred to Plattsburgh Air Force Base in upstate New York. Three reserve squadrons, including two units of the New Jersey National Guard, would be left. 
 The plans were condemned by members of the Congressional delegation, who said the transfers would devastate the area economically. The base, adjacent to Fort Dix, employs about 12,000 people, and according to estimates from the office of Representative H. James Saxton, a Republican, 4,500 of those people are on active duty and would be subject to the transfers. Perhaps some 2,500 civilian support jobs would be moved, the Congressman's office said.
"This is a bad decision," said Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, a Democrat. "It's another economic blow to a region of the state that has already suffered." He said that he and Mr. Saxton would meet at the base on Friday to announce their strategy on how to get the plans changed.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends the Day Mixed; Gold Prices Mostly Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mixed on world currency markets yesterday and gold prices were mostly lower.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery fell 30 cents an ounce, settling at $326.30, its lowest price in about a year. The Republic National Bank said gold slipped 60 cents an ounce, to a late bid price of $326.15. 
 Analysts said there appeared to be a downward bias toward the dollar even though the currency posted spotty gains. Many traders were reluctant to commit to the dollar ahead of the Commerce Department's report tomorrow on retail sales for February, which is expected to be flat.
Interest rates continued to decline in Europe, with the Dutch and Belgian central banks announcing reductions. But Mr. Donney said they appeared to be catching up with the moves last week by the Bundesbank of Germany, which took steps to lower short-term rates.
 
Waiting for Statistics
 Meanwhile, the market appeared to be waiting for more statistics on the United States economy, Mr. Donney said. The 12 regional bank presidents of the Federal Reserve, who testified in Congress yesterday, offered no surprises about economy.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 117.90 yen, up 0.97 yen from Tuesday's close. The dollar was quoted at 117.95 in later London trading. In New York, the dollar settled at 118.05 yen, up from 117.75 on Tuesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.4325, from $1.4350 late Tuesday. In New York it cost $1.4330 to buy one pound, less expensive than Tuesday's $1.4405.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.6665 German marks, unchanged; 1.5355 Swiss francs, down from 1.5405; 5.6580 French francs, up from 5.6505; 1,606.50 Italian lire, down from 1,607.00, and 1.2448 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2457.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.6750 German marks, up from 1.6680; 1.5354 Swiss francs, down from 1.5425; 5.6525 French francs, down from 5.6570; 1.8713 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8740; 1,601.00 Italian lire, down from 1,610.00, and 1.2461 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2462.
Silver prices advanced. On the Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $3.561 an ounce, up from $3.557 on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: New Policy Forming on Asia Trade

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is drafting a trade policy toward Japan, China and Southeast Asia that would combine aid to American high-technology industries with negotiations to open Asian markets for these products, Administration officials said today.
The new policy of supporting specific exports is a sharp departure from the Bush Administration approach of seeking across-the-board trade liberalization, which sometimes benefited other countries as much as American companies. 
 The policy, the first and clearest outcome of President Clinton's call for making trade an integral part of the nation's economic and national security concerns, reflects a belief that the Bush Administration sometimes fought free trade battles that did little to create American jobs.
They point to the Bush Administration's long and successful struggle to persuade Tokyo to remove restrictions on large stores and allow Toys "R" Us Inc. to open outlets there. Many toys sold by the company come from Southeast Asia, not the United States.
 
Roles for 2 Agencies
 "You open up the distribution system and lo and behold, everything is manufactured in Thailand," said a senior Administration trade official who insisted on anonymity.
The Commerce Department, for example, would spend money to help the computer, semiconductor and aerospace industries stay technologically competitive, while the Office of the United States Trade Representative would oversee negotiations on opening Asian markets for them, the official said.
The new policy does not include any plans for the sort of severe trade restrictions that the auto and textile industries have been seeking. The Administration trade official said that because of the program's emphasis on supporting exports, there might be little immediate effect on the nation's swelling trade deficit with Japan, which reached $49.42 billion last year.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, told the Senate Finance Committee on Tuesday that American officials might seek specific shares of foreign markets for American companies, adding, "There is great interest in this Administration on that approach." He said an interagency review had begun of policy toward Japan, but he provided few details.
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, has played an extensive role in the development of the new policy. She has been in many hours of meetings with Mr. Kantor, who is overseeing the policy's development, and his top aides.
Ms. Tyson published a book last year, entitled "Who's Bashing Whom? Trade Conflict in High-Technology Industries," that outlined some of the specific policies now envisioned.
The new policy may also be tempered by the same diplomatic and military concerns that limited the Bush Administration's willingness to restrict imports from Japan.
Diplomatic and military concerns are also strongly affecting trade policy toward China but are being used within the Administration to justify a more restrictive trade policy instead of the less restrictive one for Japan. At a meeting last week with about two dozen chairmen of the nation's largest multinational corporations, President Clinton said he did not want a "showdown" on China's trade access to the United States but was concerned about Chinese exports of military technology.
 
Strong Position Urged
 Three people who attended the closed-door meeting in the Old Executive Office Building's elegant Indian Treaty Room said Mr. Clinton told the gathering that unless the United States took a strong position now, it might find itself a decade from now with a nuclear bomb under the World Trade Center and a need to evacuate all of Manhattan. White House officials declined to discuss the remark, saying the meeting had been confidential.
The Bush Administration persuaded Beijing last year to adopt a 12-page list of tariff reductions and other measures to open its markets. The agreement was partly intended to address a yawning trade imbalance, as the United States imported Chinese goods worth $25.73 billion and exported only $7.47 billion worth of goods to China.
Chinese bureaucrats appear to be obstructing some American exports covered by the agreement, notably auto parts. "We're coming up with all sorts of horror stories," the senior Administration official said.
The Clinton Administration is including Southeast Asia in the same policy review because it is one of the few regions in the world now showing strong economic growth. The United States holds the rotating chairmanship of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation this year, an organization with headquarters in Singapore that includes six Southeast Asian nations plus Australia, Canada, China, Japan, New Zealand, Taiwan, Hong Kong, South Korea and Taiwan.
 
The Semiconductor Example
 The new policy is heavily influenced by the perceived success of the Bush Administration's policies toward the semiconductor industry. These included a Government-sponsored industry research program, Sematech, as well as a 1991 trade agreement in which the Japanese Government "recognized" the American industry's expectation that it would win 20 percent of the Japanese semiconductor market by the end of 1992.
The new policy also owes an intellectual debt to Japanese Government-guided growth policies of the 1950's and 60's, which have fallen into disfavor with many academics during the current economic stagnation in Japan.

HEADLINE: Clinton Plan for Banks Gets Mixed Reception

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
In the words of a Treasury Department official outlining the Clinton Administration's new proposals today to spur lending to small businesses, the credit crunch is not a matter of clogged arteries but of constricted capillaries.
So what the economic doctors apparently prescribed today was a thorough massage of bank regulations, not open heart surgery. And the prescription, presented by President Clinton after weeks of promotion, was cheered quietly by advocates of less regulation but criticized mildly by others concerned with the safety of the banking system. 
 "No one could quarrel with the President's goal," said Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, a Texas Democrat who is chairman of the House Banking Committee. In an ambivalent statement, he said that "the true test" would come only when full details were provided, and that "the trick is to insure that lenders are not tempted again to become casinos."
 
Clinton Outlines Program
 Mr. Clinton, outlining the program to lenders and borrowers at the White House, called it "a step to speed the economic recovery that will increase jobs by increasing access to credit for the main engine of our economy, small- and medium-sized businesses."
Bankers were pleased but not ecstatic. "We are certainly supportive of what he is attempting to do, but we would like to see a lot more regulatory rollback," said James R. Lauffer, chairman and chief executive of the First National Bank of Hermanie in Pennsylvania. Mr. Lauffer was recently elected president of the International Bankers Association of America.
The broad outlines of the Administration's proposals, which make technical changes in the ways that borrowers' creditworthiness and collateral are assessed, had been revealed in the last few days.
For example, the plan changes the way problem loans would be rated by examiners when borrowers have not actually defaulted, and allows some real estate to be used as collateral without costly appraisals.
 
Regulators to Coordinate
 The bank regulators from four agencies -- the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the Federal Reserve Board and the Office of Thrift Supervision -- have agreed to coordinate their work better and avoid disruptive duplication in bank examinations. And each agency will establish processes by which bankers, and even potential borrowers who have been turned down, could appeal regulatory decisions.
Although the plan requires no legislation, members of Congress said they would hold hearings on the proposals anyway, as if to remind the Administration that the newly enacted banking laws that have led to stricter regulation must not be disregarded.
"Our best estimate of the number of banks that will fail as a result of this program is zero, zero, zero," said an Administration official who insisted on anonymity at a briefing for reporters because his nomination to a Treasury banking post had not been confirmed by the Senate. "The cost to the taxpayer as a result of this program is zero."
Administration officials said that the fine print that regulatory agencies would be disgorging as they put the changes into writing should have more than a psychological effect on lenders and bank examiners.
"What we're doing is not just making broad statements, but we are going to be issuing very specific, very detailed regulations," the Treasury official said. But crucial details were not disclosed today, because, officials said, they were still being worked out.
 
Cutting Down Paperwork
 For example, one proposal will allow strong banks to create baskets of loans for small businesses with minimal documentation. At his presentation, President Clinton held up a fat folder of paperwork for such loans under the current system, and a thin sheaf of forms under the new process.
But officials would not say how a strong bank would be defined, how big a small business could be and still qualify for fast-track loans, how big the loans could be, how many a bank would be allowed to include in its portfolio or exactly what documentation would be required under the new rules.
Some of the changes affecting how banks may treat real estate involved in foreclosures are likely to be much more difficult to work out. Two of the changes, one allowing banks to lend more money to buyers of foreclosed property and the other dictating how loans are valued on banks' books when borrowers have no hope of repaying them, must be negotiated with the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Financial Accounting Standards Board before they can be adopted.
M. Scott Reed, a partner at the accounting firm of Grant Thornton and head of its financial institutions practice, called those two changes "troubling."
"What it smells to me of is loosening accounting requirements to make a bank look better," he said. "I think the opportunity for abuse is significant in that area."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
U.S.-Made Steel Price Rises

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, March 10

 BODY:
The nation's big steelmakers, reacting to growing signs of an economic recovery, say they plan to raise some steel prices by as much as 5 percent, effective July 4.
The Chicago-based Inland Steel Industries, one of the largest steel producers in the United States, said Tuesday that it started the latest round of price increases March 1, as it began informing customers that it planned to raise prices of all of its sheet steel by $20 a ton, or 3 percent to 5 percent, depending on the product. 
The USX Corporation's U.S. Steel Group, the nation's largest steel producer, which is based here, and the Cleveland-based LTV Corporation's steel unit, the nation's third-largest, followed suit, notifying customers of similar price increases days after Inland's announcement.
A spokesman for the Bethlehem Steel Corporation of Bethlehem, Pa., the nation's second-largest steelmaker, said his company was studying the price increase.
The increase is the third planned by American steelmakers this year. The most recent was an increase announced in late January that will go into effect April 4.
Industry analysts said this winter's increases marked the industry's first success on pricing in years. They linked this success to the economy's slow climb out of recession, as well as recent successful trade cases, which have cut the amount of steel imported into this country.

HEADLINE: Lumber Prices Are Soaring On Shortages and Owl Feud

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, March 10

 BODY:
Lumber prices have jumped 82 percent since September and are likely to continue to soar with the arrival of spring, when building increases and the demand for lumber picks up.
Because the cost of lumber usually amounts to 10 to 15 percent of the cost of a new home, the shortage of lumber could eventually push up home prices. 
 "We haven't seen this kind of market since the late 1960's," said Robert Wulf, investor relations manager at Pope & Talbot, a 144-year-old timber company in Portland, Ore. "Panic buying started in the fourth quarter of 1992. If you're a builder and want to construct 10 houses, you want to make sure you have the lumber. Price is not as important as availability."
Behind the higher prices is a shortage of lumber, brought on in large part by the extent to which Federal forests have been closed to loggers for environmental reasons. Logging on eight million acres of timber owned by the Federal Government in the Pacific Northwest has been sharply reduced: from 1982 to 1992, sales of timber from land in Washington and Oregon owned by the United States Forest Service topped 4 billion board feet annually. Last year, they totaled a mere 385 million board feet.
William Pena, senior vice president for merchandising at Home Base, the nation's sixth-largest home improvement chain, with $1.5 billion in sales, said: "There's a code around our office that if you have the mill on the phone, don't hang up. An hour later, the price may have gone up $10 for a thousand board feet."
Reflecting the uncertainty, a sales flier from Henry Bacon Building Materials, which has five stores in Seattle, says: "Due to unanticipated market fluctuations, prices may be subject to change without notice."
In July composite framing lumber sold for $260 per thousand board feet; last Friday the cost had risen to $474.
The turmoil in the logging industry and the communities in which it is based -- 168 sawmills have closed and 20,000 people have lost jobs in the last decade -- has led President Clinton to schedule a meeting in Portland, Ore., on April 2, hoping all interested parties can help develop a plan to protect timber communities, save old-growth forests and create jobs.
The Federal forests in the Northwest remain a battleground between logging and environmental forces, the habitat of threatened species like the northern spotted owl.
And Mr. Wulf of Pope & Talbot said: "If it wasn't the owl, then it would be the marbled murrelet or salmon. They have a long list of species to keep people out of Federal forests."
John W. Creighton Jr., chief executive of Weyerhaeuser, in Federal Way, Wash., said: "I hope the President will reach an interim settlement to release Federal timber for sale. A new supply may mitigate some of the price increases. Otherwise, if housing starts surge, we might see a panic situation."
Still, not all lumber companies are suffering because of the shortages. Michael Shea, an analyst with the Charter Investment Group in Portland, said companies like Weyerhaeuser, Louisiana-Pacific, Pope & Talbot and Longview Fiber "will do very, very well in the next couple years."
The National Wildlife Federation said declines in supply could be offset by reducing the export of unprocessed logs. But Chris West, vice president of the Northwest Forestry Association, a timber industry group based in Portland, said exports were already coming down. He also noted that exports provided some other jobs even if they reduced some mill jobs.
Mr. Creighton of Weyerhaeuser said he was incredulous when he first heard of the spotted owl and its impact. The company said it had been forced to close large mills in Springfield and Klamath Falls, Ore., and a smaller mill in Snoqualmie, Wash. It also closed a pulp mill in Everett, Wash., where it had acquired its first sawmill in 1902. In all, 1,500 employees lost their jobs because the mills were dependent on timber from Federal lands.
 
'Families Split Apart'
 Jim Keller, the Klamath Falls city manager, said all of Klamath County had been hit hard, with 2,000 people out of work after six mills, including Weyerhaeuser's, were shut. "We've seen families split apart," he said. "The wife stays in the home because of the schoolchildren, and the husband relocates, looking for work."
Even so, environmentalists say automation has eliminated many of those jobs. But lumber industry executives dispute that, saying that automation may eliminate some jobs but add others, and has never been responsible for shutting a mill.
Weyerhaeuser is profitable now, but in 1991 the company recorded its first loss ever -- $162 million on sales of $8.7 billion. In addition to the recession and drop in housing starts, the company blamed falling pulp and paper prices and the spotted owl.
The situation has worsened because of extension of owl restrictions beyond Federal lands. State agencies in Washington and Oregon have declared that the restrictions apply to private lands as well, like the 2.5 million acres that Weyerhaeuser owns in the Northwest.
In November, Washington State's Department of Natural Resources told timber companies to set aside a 500-acre habitat circle nearly two miles in diameter around each owl sighting. In January the State Department of Wildlife sued the Natural Resources department, saying the circles should contain 2,600 to 3,900 acres, depending on the forest they are in.
So far, the Weyerhaeuser owl census has turned up 375. "We've got $2 billion in timber tied up that we can't ever harvest," Mr. Creighton said, speaking of the owl circles. "That's a sizable hit."
Weyerhaeuser says it spent $1 million searching for owl nests, and it recently wrote to contractors urging them to report any owl sighting. The letter said, "If your supervisor tells you to keep quiet, immediately report the incident to another member of management, bypassing the normal chain of command if necessary."
 
Soaring Prices and Profits
 Soaring prices that began in October in Weyerhaeuser's timber and wood products business helped turn finances around in 1992. The company earned $372 million on sales of $9.2 billion. In the fourth quarter the company had near-record quarterly earnings of $515 million, compared with a $67 million loss in the fourth quarter of 1991.
Peter T. Pope, chief executive of Pope & Talbot and the grandson of a company founder, said his company lost money for two years because of tough lumber, pulp, diaper and tissue markets. But strong fourth-quarter lumber sales helped trim overall losses for 1992 to $2.25 million, while sales rose 8 percent, to $544 million. "If markets continue as well as they are now, we'll make good money this year," he said.
Pope & Talbot used to depend on Federal timber, but Mr. Pope said he had closed an Oregon mill and bought three Canadian mills, where two-thirds of the company's lumber now comes from.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Planting the Clinton flag on what might have been Bush's recovery.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
TO stimulate or not to stimulate? Listening to Bill Clinton, one might guess that he is still eager to use fiscal policy to wrench the economy out of the doldrums. "We certainly cannot declare a victory now," the President told a radio audience last week. "For while employment is edging up, unemployment is still higher than it was at the depths of this recession."
In fact, Mr. Clinton has proposed only symbolic stimulus for the current fiscal year -- a mere $15 billion dollop for a $6 trillion economy that at very most would add two-tenths of a percentage point to the 1993 growth rate. And when the White House's new agreement with House Democrats to pare an extra $55 billion of spending between 1994 and 1998 is taken into account, the economic plan actually becomes mildly restrictive in the years thereafter. 
 Skeptics thus may wonder whether the President has anything more in mind than planting his flag on what might otherwise have been called the Bush recovery. The more charitable view is that President Clinton has already learned the lesson that eluded President Read-My-Lips: What you say about the economy is every bit as important as what you do.
The latest statistical revisions suggest the economy has been perking along nicely since the summer, with output growing at a healthy 4 percent clip in the last two quarters of the year. And while employment growth has lagged behind the pace of other postwar recoveries, a surge in hiring last month has persuaded many -- probably most -- professional tea-leaf readers that the economy is not about to stumble again. Morgan Guaranty Trust, generally a conservative forecaster, is now projecting 3 percent-plus growth through 1994 -- and that forecast was made before the February employment boom was announced.
All this suggests that George Bush's economists had it almost right. Their one apparent error, argues Robert Gordon, an economist at Northwestern University, was to underestimate the time it would take for the Federal Reserve's 1991 shift toward easy money to pay off. This lag was especially long, Mr. Gordon says, because businesses were initially more interested in paying off debt than taking chances on adding productive capacity.
Why, then, has Bill Clinton's gloom and doom rhetoric changed so little since the election campaign? One reason, presumably, is that the recovery is a comfort only to those who are part of it. And with 7 percent of the work force still unemployed, the President is not about to do a George Bush let-them-eat-pork-rinds number on millions of his less fortunate constituents.
Another, suggests one insider, is that "Clinton had to offer a sugar coating to convince Congress to swallow the bitter pill" of deficit reduction. The first year of the economic recovery program does offer a dash of sweetness for everyone from unemployed teen-agers to the corner hardware store owner looking for a tax break on a computerized cash register.
In hindsight, however, it is plain that the Clinton team had grown skeptical of the need for stimulus as early as December. The $50 billion shot in the arm proposed by a bevy of liberal economists during the campaign was shelved in favor of a $15 billion potpourri -- which could easily be whittled to $12 to $13 billion if spending on public works takes a predictably long time to begin.
But it is also clear that the President saw no need to abandon the symbolic commitment to jump-start the economy. "The Democrats have learned some lessons," concludes Paul Krugman, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "One is that people don't read balance sheets."
Actually the balancing act between the perception of action and the more cautious reality has worked better than Mr. Clinton could have possibly dreamed. On the one hand, his take-charge routine has given a lot of consumers and businesses the confidence to go out and shop, while the tough talk about deficit spending has apparently brought long-term interest rates down to levels that will help insure the recovery.
What could go wrong? Not everyone agrees that better times are sure to come without real stimulus. Lawrence Klein, the Nobel Prize-winning econometrician who has retired from the University of Pennsylvania, thinks the growth rate in 1992 was exaggerated by the big cleanup after the fall hurricanes. And he predicts that the economy will grow less than 2 percent in 1993 -- hardly enough to keep the current work force employed.
Perhaps the greater worry is that Mr. Clinton's nimble performance thus far will leave the public unprepared for a much tougher sell on the President's No. 1 priority: radical health-care reform. Here, Mr. Clinton will not be able to take credit for good things beyond his control. Indeed, the problem will be in convincing a skeptical majority that the alternative to less service at higher out-of-pocket costs is bound to be something worse.

HEADLINE: Increased Cigarette Tax Could Reduce Fires;
Phase Out the Growing

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Former President Jimmy Carter doesn't go far enough when he proposes that President Clinton raise the tobacco tax $2 a pack to improve health care and reduce Federal budget deficits (letter, Feb. 21). He argues that this would raise more than $20 billion a year in new revenue and reduce smoking rates, particularly among the young, enough to save two million lives. 
 Only since 1991 has the Federal Government reported that nearly half a million deaths in the United States each year can be attributed to smoking. This death rate from tobacco use roughly doubles the annual total of all deaths caused by AIDS, car accidents, suicide, homicide, fires, alcohol, crack-cocaine and heroin -- or the annual death rate from tobacco use exceeds all the casualties of the Civil War.
How can we call for a drug-free America and continue to ignore the causal relationship between tobacco smoking and cancer?
Tobacco farmers with whom I have spoken are seeking realistic economic alternatives for their cash crop. Why not offer farmers who grow tobacco in 20 states a five-year phase-out program, with technical assistance and low-interest loans for those who participate voluntarily to switch over to growing other commodities?
After all, precedent has been set, not the least of which were government incentives to cocaine growers in South America. The Agricultural Extension Service, a cooperative effort between the Department of Agriculture and the state land grant universities, could be the conduit for disseminating this technology and assistance to growers, as well as advice on marketing strategies and commercial outlets for alternative commodities.
In recent years, for example, the landscaping-nursery industry has exceeded tobacco in the amount of income generated in North Carolina, the country's primary tobacco-growing state. The tobacco industry has had such a hold on politicians, it's been difficult to get at the facts. Only last year, the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Foundation named 10 fellowships after North Carolina's Commissioner of Agriculture. The tobacco lobby has been among the top contributors to the party coffers of both Democrats and Republicans.
Even President Carter, right after his election, was the Georgia plantation-house guest of Smith Bagley, the Reynolds tobacco family heir.
President Clinton might fix a noble place in history by his leadership in creating a national transition program to phase out tobacco and by his appointment of Mr. Carter to head a commission to oversee that transition.
 
ROGER DEAN SHARPE
New York, Feb. 23, 1993

HEADLINE: Why Canadians Grew Cold to Mulroney

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Were you being tongue in cheek in "Mr. Mulroney Steps Down" (editorial, Feb. 25), praising Brian Mulroney, the Canadian Prime Minister? While you acknowledge that he is unpopular at home (he has the lowest popularity rating of any Canadian Prime Minister in this century), you state that he has been a "good friend" to the United States. 
 The (perhaps unintended) point you clearly make is that Mr. Mulroney's friendliness to the United States is exactly why Mr. Mulroney is so unpopular at home. He has spent most of his tenure dismantling Canada's "social accord," pushing the Reagan-Bush agenda of free trade, privatization and deregulation. United States and foreign corporations may love him for giving away Canada's wealth, but the cost to Canadians has been staggering: reduced social benefits, enormous loss of jobs, severe recession. It's not surprising he resigned -- he knew his party didn't stand a chance of winning another election with him at the helm.
One last thought: think of the company you have put Mr. Mulroney in, foreign leaders who were good friends to the United States, but massively unpopular at home. Some names that come to mind are Ferdinand E. Marcos, Fulgencio Batista, the Shah of Iran, Papa Doc Duvalier. I could go on, but I'm sure you get the point.
 
JAMES MANGAN
Exec. Director, Minnesota Working
Group on Economic Dislocation
Minneapolis, March 4, 1993
