HEADLINE: REPORTS WARNING OF H.U.D. PROBLEMS

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Mar. 10

 BODY:
Four years after corruption and mismanagement scandals mired the Department of Housing and Urban Development, a succession of reports has warned that the department's management systems remain out of control, and its Inspector General has warned that "another H.U.D. scandal is a distinct possibility."
The reports say problems in staffing, data systems and accounting controls are leading to the misuse of hundreds of millions of dollars, leaving the department with an uncertain grasp of more than $1 trillion in financial commitments. 
 A confidential report prepared by President Clinton's transition team said that mismanagement at the department was "clear and devastating" and that it "opens the door to the systematic plunder of many millions of taxpayer dollars." It also said the problems would take years to overcome and warned that they could hamper the Administration's plans for economic development.
The document, reported today in The Washington Post, offers few examples of projects gone awry, but in the past year Congressional investigators have produced graphic ones. They found department programs giving a low-interest loan to a Saudi sheik, spending $3 million to renovate housing built on a toxic-waste dump in Florida and paying more than $5 million in rent subsidies to the Philadelphia Housing Authority for buildings that had been destroyed as much as 15 years earlier.
 
Secretary Is Critical
 Speaking of the weak financial safeguards in a department that spends $25 billion a year and stands behind hundreds of billions of dollars in mortgage guarantees, Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros said in an interview today: "It's like a car without headlights. It doesn't mean it's going to go off the road, but it enhances your chances of not making the next curve."
In 1989 accusations of mismanagement, influence peddling and favoritism during the tenure of Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. in the Reagan Administration jolted the department. A special counsel later began an investigation, which has so far resulted in four convictions, with four cases pending. Jack F. Kemp, who succeeded Mr. Pierce, , was widely credited with improving the ethical environment in the department, and no one is suggesting that the department today is rife with corruption.
But the reports warn that the department still lacks the management systems to prevent and detect such abuses.
Mr. Cisneros praised Mr. Kemp's emphasis on ethics and said most of the problems began before the latter's watch. But he also said Mr. Kemp had been attracted to "ideologically attractive themes" like the sale of public housing, while "there was some inattention" to basic management.
 
Response to Secretary
 Mr. Kemp could not be reached today, but a spokesman, Bill Dal Col said Mr. Cisneros was criticizing his predecessor to protect himself in the event a scandal breaks out in his tenure.
The department's problems were graphically summarized in the transition report, written by Andrew M. Cuomo, who has since been nominated to be Assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development for Community Planning and Development. They were also detailed last year in analyses by the General Accounting Office and the outgoing Inspector General, Paul A. Adams.
"It's just a matter of time before something's going to slip," said John Connors, the department's Acting Inspector General.
In a report of his own, Mr. Connors listed six areas as especially troubled: public housing, the Community Development Block Grant program, the Section 8 rental assistance program, the management of repossessed single-family homes, the management of multifamily housing loans and the Ginnie Mae program, which has a staff of only 70 people to oversee Federal guarantees of $450 billion in mortgage securities.
 
A Troubled Program
 The criticisms of the block grant program could be especially troubling to the Administration, which has pledged to add $2.5 billion to the program's current budget.
The program offers about $4 billion a year in grants to cities and states, letting them use the money for a wide variety of activities like laying sidewalks, building schools, razing slums and creating jobs. At least 70 percent of the money is supposed to be spent on activities that benefit people with low or moderate incomes, but investigators have said the money is frequently used for ineligible purposes.
Mr. Cisneros said he had been warning mayors to be sure the money was spent appropriately.
The transition report was especially critical of the program for insuring loans for apartment buildings. It said understaffing and mismanagement were driving up the default rate since problem loans were not recognized until it was too late to do anything positive about them. The problems "could lead to hundreds of millions or even billions of dollars in losses," it said.
 
More Bad News
 In an interview last week, Mr. Connors said the department's problems stemmed from systemic weaknesses in data systems, personnel policies and "internal controls." For example, the size of the department's staff has fallen by almost a quarter in the past decade, to 13,000 from about 17,000, forcing the department to rely heavily on subcontractors.
Representative Collin C. Peterson, a Minnesota Democrat who heads the House oversight subcommittee, pledged to hold hearings on the reports' findings.
Mr. Cisneros insisted that the severity of the problems outlined in the transition report would not interfere with his ability to implement new programs.

HEADLINE: North Korea, Fighting Inspection, Renounces Nuclear Arms Treaty

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, March 12

 BODY:
North Korea, in a defiant move against international pressure to inspect its suspected nuclear weapons development program, announced this morning that it was withdrawing from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty to defend "its supreme interest."
The surprise announcement came just after the International Atomic Energy Agency gave North Korea a deadline of later this month to accept inspection of two buildings that the United States believes contain evidence of the extent of the bomb project. It marks a sharp reversal of course for the hard-line Communist government in Pyongyang, which had declared a new era of openness last year in an effort to save its desperate economy. 
 The abrupt decision, which took American officials in Asia by surprise, adds urgency to the Clinton Administration's biggest security challenge in the region. Several weeks ago the new chief of the Central Intelligence Agency, R. James Woolsey, said he believed that North Korea might be only months to a year or so away from producing its first atomic weapon.
Today's action appears to be the first time a nation has withdrawn from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, a 1968 international agreement that is the mainstay of efforts to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.
The Japanese Government, in a statement this afternoon, condemned the decision as "a challenge to the nuclear nonproliferation regime itself" and said it "will have grave repercussions."
 
Preventive Measures
 The series of inspections, which have also been supported by Russia, and less enthusiastically by China, were regarded as the chief means of preventing North Korea from building a bomb. The country also has significant missile technology and has become a major exporter of weapons to the Middle East.
"It is an act of sheer desperation," a Western diplomat in Seoul, who has been active in the effort to force North Korea to back down from its weapons project, said this morning. "It is a frantic, self-destructive, and ill-advised move."
A statement issued by North Korea's state-run news service, and monitored in Tokyo, said that its decision to renounce the treaty -- and with it its obligations to allow inspectors into the country -- "is a well-justified self-defensive measure against the nuclear war maneuvers of the United States and the unjust act of the the International Atomic Energy Agency."
It also accused the United States of making "nuclear threats against North Korea" by staging a series of annual military maneuvers with South Korea. The maneuvers, known as "Team Spirit," involve more than 100,000 troops and began earlier this week.
It said that "we will never be frightened in the least" by the agency, which has told North Korea that if it failed to open its nuclear sites, the issue would probably be referred to the United Nations for possible sanctions.
 
Weeks of Accusations
 For weeks the North has accused the atomic energy agency of acting as a pawn of the United States and of manipulating the agency's intelligence gathered from American spy satellites. That intelligence has been the agency's chief evidence that North Korea was still hiding some facilities that might reveal how much plutonium the country has produced.
No one from the atomic energy agency, which is based in Vienna, could be reached for comment. However one Asian official familiar with the agency's workings said that he believed that "North Korea cannot get off the hook just by renouncing the treaty" because past inspections have already raised fears that an active bomb project may be under way.
Jeff Eller, a White House spokesman, said, "We are monitoring the situation carefully and have no further comment." Richard Boucher, the State Department spokesman, declined to comment.
A Pentagon spokeswoman, Major Janet Reese, declined to comment on any possible effect the announcement might have on the "Team Spirit" exercises. Similar exercises were suspended last year "in recognition of the steps North Korea had taken to begin to resolve international concerns about its nuclear program," she said. But in October, after talks on inspections stalled, the United States and Korea announced that planning would begin for new exercises this spring.
In recent weeks, American officials have conceded they have little leverage over North Korea. The country is already deeply isolated, so economic sanctions would have little effect.
On Monday Kim Jong Il, the 51-year old head of the North Korean military and son of the nation's 80-year old leader, Kim Il Song, placed the country on what he termed a "semi-war footing," and announced that an attack from the United States and South Korea could come at any time during the military exercises.
The United States has said that the "Team Spirit" exercises, which began in 1976, are purely defensive. But this year it has also brought in for the first time the B-1B bomber and the F-117 fighter, in what many diplomats interpreted as a signal that the nuclear complex in the North could be reached in minutes.
North Korea's move was particularly surprising to American and Japanese officials, who believed that its government would drag along the inspection process rather than risk additional isolation by ending the process altogether. Pyongyang has repeatedly insisted that all of its nuclear activities are peaceful.
For a while, it seemed like tremendous progress was being made. Last year North Korea, which signed the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty in 1985, finally allowed inspectors in for the first time.
But things began to sour when the atomic energy agency declared that it had found what it termed "inconsistencies" in its examination of the North's declared nuclear materials.

HEADLINE: RUSSIAN LEGISLATURE VOTES TO REDUCE YELTSIN'S POWERS AND ASSUME DOMINANT ROLE

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 11

 BODY:
The People's Congress voted overwhelmingly today to sharply curb President Boris N. Yeltsin's powers and to cancel a planned referendum next month that he had hoped would give him a popular mandate to accelerate economic change.
A final vote is expected Friday. But already this evening it was evident that the thousand deputies, elected three years ago under the Communist system, intended to reject any proposals put forth by Mr. Yeltsin and to assume more authority for themselves and for their chairman, Ruslan I. Khasbulatov. 
 Almost certainly, unless Mr. Yeltsin takes some extraordinary steps like abolishing the Congress and imposing military rule, moves he has threatened in past weeks, the Congress will act next month to sweep away the economic changes already announced and further reduce Mr. Yeltsin's authority.
 
Two Key Votes
 The President, in addition to publicly threatening unilateral action to defeat his opponents, privately asked Chancellor Helmut Kohl last week if the NATO allies would support such a step, according to European diplomats in Washington.
But Mr. Yeltsin, who came to power in late 1991 after leading the successful opposition to the coup against the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, seems headed for a humiliating setback.
On the second day of a special session, the Congress of People's Deputies, which has increasingly challenged Mr. Yeltsin's economic program, voted 623 to 252 in a preliminary ballot to limit his power by scrapping a power-sharing accord reached in December.
The Congress also canceled a referendum planned for April 11 that might have strengthened his authority by allowing the people to vote for a new Constitution with increased presidential powers.
 
Lacks a Constituency
 It was in part to strengthen Mr. Yeltsin's hand in the referendum that President Clinton agreed to a summit meeting on April 3-4 in Vancouver, British Columbia. It is now unclear what can be accomplished at those talks.
Although Mr. Yeltsin has been a fairly popular politician, he has not been able to organize any real political strength. He lacks a power base in the Congress and has no political party of his own. The Congress, which has many Communists, and others who dislike the evolving system have been much more effective political forces.
The stakes go considerably beyond simply who will wield power.
A government beholden to the conservative Congress would almost certainly roll back the changes pushed through under Mr. Yeltsin. Beyond that, Russia's semi-autonomous regions have threatened to break further with Moscow if they sense that the center is growing either weaker or more aggressive.
And there is no telling how the public, however apathetic it has been to the power struggle so far, would respond if the unpopular Mr. Khasbulatov made an open grab for the Government.
Mr. Yeltsin began the day with a powerful 11th-hour appeal for a negotiated resolution of the conflict, but left the hall in mid-afternoon in apparent dismay after the attacks culminated in a demand for his impeachment.
 
His Earlier Warnings
 "At this point I am asking myself, do the deputies realize what they are doing?" he asked in his opening address. "Do they realize what kind of responsibility they are assuming?"
In recent weeks, Mr. Yeltsin has repeatedly warned of his readiness to take extreme measures if the Congress continues to erode his power. Today his spokesman drew reporters' attention to the fact that on entering the hall, Mr. Yeltsin first greeted the Ministers of Defense, Security and the Interior.
Most deputies, however, have taken such intimations as bluff.
But there was little question of the dismay and anger among Mr. Yeltsin's lieutenants and supporters. "If the Congress follows the path charted by Ruslan Khasbulatov, it will ruin itself," declared Lev Ponomarev, a staunch reformer.
Mr. Khasbulatov himself, the chairman and Mr. Yeltsin's chief rival, seemed to relish his dominance. Commentators have speculated that his goal is to reduce Mr. Yeltsin to a ceremonial role and to give the Congress and himself control over the Cabinet.
 
Scorn From a Rival
 Taking the floor after both Mr. Yeltsin and Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin had spoken, Mr. Khasbulatov declared that the "devil wrapped us round his finger" when the Congress approved the political truce last December.
Later, in an interview with the Interfax news agency, Mr. Khasbulatov gave even greater rein to his feelings, accusing Mr. Yeltsin of "pathological" urgings to destroy the legislative branch because of a "genetic link with Bolshevism."
Some of Mr. Yeltsin's supporters thought Mr. Khasbulatov was deliberately seeking to provoke the President into some rash act, which the Congress could then display as evidence that Mr. Yeltsin was seeking dictatorial powers.
But it was also evident that the Congress was resistant to any compromise. Whatever hope there had been that the new Constitutional Court and its chief justice, Valery D. Zorkin, might act as a referee faded today when Mr. Zorkin effectively threw his support to Mr. Khasbulatov.
 
Few Choices Left
 The feeling in the lobbies was that Mr. Yeltsin could either try to carry on and hope for some development to bolster his standing before the next session of the Congress, or fight back. In his address, he reiterated that he might still seek to put his case to the public.
Another option, indirectly but distinctly threatened by the President and his men in recent weeks, is to declare direct presidential rule with the backing of the security forces, though the risks are great and obvious.
There is also the possibility that the Congress would call new elections next year for both a President and a legislature. That has been pushed especially by Communists, who evidently believe that elections held when economic changes are causing the greatest pain would give them a chance.
Addressing the Congress at the start of today's session, Mr. Yeltsin maintained a conciliatory tone even as he noted that room for compromise was rapidly vanishing.
"There are fewer and fewer opportunities for reaching accord," he warned. He was in favor of strong presidential power, Mr. Yeltsin continued, not because he was President, "but because I am firmly convinced that without this, Russia will not be able to survive or revive its economy."
"Only a President chosen by the people can implement tough but necessary measures," he declared. "No reform can survive without these tough measures. Do deputies realize that neither the Congress nor the Parliament nor any other body are bold enough to implement these measures?"
Following Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Chernomyrdin rose to speak. A former Soviet Minister of Gas who was chosen as a compromise Prime Minister in December, he has been surprisingly supportive of Mr. Yeltsin.
After ranging through the familiar problems and challenges, he demanded that the Congress grant him and Mr. Yeltsin real power.
Then came Mr. Khasbulatov. With a tone that verged on insolence, he portrayed the legislators as the real victims in the conflict: "We keep working, toiling, but the members of the President's team, excuse my saying so, pose in front of microphones and make their charges against this and that. When will all this stop, I ask you, esteemed Boris Nikolayevich?"
The debate ranged on, and at the lunch break, Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Chernomyrdin and Mr. Khasbulatov were dispatched to join the drafting committee in trying to form an agreement.
The document that emerged still abandoned the December agreement and canceled the referendum.
However it plays out, this session already stands as the most severe episode in the power struggle that has plagued Russia's attempts to instill democracy and a free market.
 
What the Congress Is
 Elected in March 1990, when Russia was still a republic of the Soviet Union and the Communists were still in power, the 1,041 members of the Russian Congress were second-stringers to the main Soviet Congress.
Ironically, it was the Russian Congress that catapulted Mr. Yeltsin back into politics by electing him its first chairman. But once Mr. Yeltsin was elected President and Russia became independent, the Congress quickly became his greatest millstone.
Under Mr. Khasbulatov, an economics professor initially raised to prominence by Mr. Yeltsin as a member of the Chechen ethnic minority, the Congress became a bastion of old Soviet habits. Without any serious party discipline, without a sense of responsibility or any strong internal leadership, the deputies increasingly came to focus largely on expanding their powers and fighting Mr. Yeltsin.
They did so for many reasons: some were die-hard Communists or nationalists unyieldingly opposed to Mr. Yeltsin; some genuinely shared a popular dissatisfaction with painful economic changes; many had no idea of parliamentary procedure and simply grabbed for whatever power they could. Only about a fifth proved to be consistent supporters of change.
Mr. Khasbulatov quickly learned to exploit this, and already by last April the Congress was openly challenging Mr. Yeltsin's program. By December, the legislators had amassed enough confidence to force the ouster of Mr. Yeltsin's chief economic adviser, Yegor T. Gaidar.
Stung, Mr. Yeltsin retaliated by calling for a national referendum. Though out-gunned in the Congress, he was far more popular in the country.
It was then that Mr. Zorkin, the chief justice, stepped in to mediate a compromise: The referendum would be held in April on a new Constitution, and in the meantime neither side would take any measures that would change the balance of power.
But soon Mr. Khasbulatov and other politicians began to question the usefulness of a referendum. Mr. Yeltsin, too, declared himself in favor of canceling the poll if another means could be found to end the conflict. Among those he proposed was a "power-sharing agreement" that delineated the separation of powers until a new Constitution could be written.
The problem was that the existing Constitution, a Soviet-era document riddled with conflicting amendments, undermined provisions for different branches of Government by declaring that the Congress was the supreme authority. Thus it was only the Congress that could legally dissolve itself or approve a new Constitution, neither of which the deputies were ready to do.
In the debate today, each side bitterly accused the other of violating the Constitution. Justice Minister Nikolai V. Fyodorov lambasted Mr. Khasbulatov in particular for many edicts and appointments for which there were no provisions in the law, including large disbursements from a "Fund for the Social Support of the Population."
Hard-line deputies countered with accusations against Mr. Yeltsin, and it was in this debate that one of these deputies, Mikhail Chelnokov, prompted Mr. Yeltsin to walk out by proposing impeachment proceedings.
Justice Zorkin, in a brief address, once again called on the President and legislature to "come to terms." But he made no reference to the fact that he had declared himself the legal guarantor of the December agreement.

Invitation From Japan
 TOKYO, March 11 (Special to The New York Times) -- Under pressure from the United States and other industrialized democracies, Japan said today that it had invited Russia to join a meeting this weekend of representatives of the seven countries attending a summit meeting here in July. It said it would use the session to discuss immediate actions to bolster President Yeltsin's efforts at change.
The move seemed to suggest a retreat by Tokyo from its stand against an emergency meeting this spring to discuss additional aid to Russia.
A Japanese official said tonight that while he did not expect specific pledges to come out of this weekend's session, in Hong Kong, "I think there is a recognition now that we have to come up with something concrete."
The Japanese were somewhat stunned by criticism by President Francois Mitterrand of France during his visit to the White House Tuesday. Japan has fought the idea of an early support meeting for fear it would undercut the significance of the Tokyo summit meeting in July. Japan has also resisted pressure to provide more aid until the long-running dispute over the islands seized by the Soviet Union in the closing days of World War II is resolved.
At a news conference with President Clinton, Mr. Mitterrand said, "Perhaps they, the Japanese, are not paying sufficient regard in this respect to the importance of events taking place mainly in Europe." Mr. Clinton, while not directly critical of Japan, also made it clear that July might be too late to help Mr. Yeltsin.

HEADLINE: 2 CALIFORNIA BASES SPARED FROM LIST OF MILITARY CUTS

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
Throwing a bone to California, an economically depressed and politically crucial state, Defense Secretary Les Aspin has decided to spare two military installations there that had been on the armed services' list of those that should close, senior Pentagon officials said today.
But Mr. Aspin, ignoring pleas from dozens of lawmakers and communities nationwide, plans to recommend on Friday that about 30 other major installations be closed and as many as 150 other depots and smaller sites be consolidated or reduced. Acknowledging the importance of the base-closing issue, President Clinton visited a Maryland factory today and announced a plan to ease conversions from military to civilian manufacture. [Page A14.] 
 McClellan Air Force Base, a big installation near Sacramento, and the Monterey Presidio, a much smaller installation that is home to the military's Defense Language Institute, were spared from closing when Mr. Aspin decided that the "cumulative economic impact in an area already hard hit" would be too adverse to the community, a senior Defense Department official said.
 
Lobbying Is Fierce
 Since the armed services' recommendations for base closings became known last week, California's Congressional delegation has lobbied fiercely to persuade Mr. Clinton and Mr. Aspin to save military installations in a state where 17 installations employing 67,000 civilian and military workers are already being closed.
Despite Mr. Aspin's reprieve, at least eight other installations in California will be on the list the Defense Secretary will announce on Friday. Those include the Long Beach Naval Shipyard, El Toro Marine Air Station and March Air Force Base in Southern California, and five installations in the San Francisco Bay area, home of Representative Ronald V. Dellums of Oakland, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee.
The two installations spared have influential supporters. The Monterey Presidio is in the district formerly represented by Mr. Clinton's budget director, Leon E. Panetta. McClellan Air Force and Depot, which employs more than 30,000 civilian workers, is in the district of Representative Vic Fazio who, as chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, helps find financing for his colleagues' re-election campaigns.
 
White House Comments
 Senior Defense Department officials said the White House's concern for California's economic problems weighed heavily in Mr. Aspin's decision.
"This is the most blatant political twist I've ever seen," said a senior Pentagon official. "The White House is concerned about the vote in California, and they are wrestling hard with the political fallout."
But George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, said in an interview that while Mr. Clinton and Mr. Aspin had discussed the base-closing process in general, the President had not reviewed the Defense Secretary's final list.
Opponents of Mr. Aspin's recommendations will now focus their lobbying efforts on an eight-member Presidential commission headed by former Representative James A. Courter, Republican of New Jersey.
 
Next Deadline July 1
 The commission has until July 1 to accept the Pentagon's recommendations or alter the list of bases. Its decision will then go to President Clinton, who has until Sept. 1 to accept or reject them. If he approves them, the recommendations go to Congress.
During the last round of base closings in 1991, four communities mustered enough economic and intellectual evidence to save their bases: Fort McClellan in Alabama, the Navy's Orlando Training Center in Florida, Whidbey Island Naval Station in Washington and Moody Air Force Base in Georgia.
By resisting intense pressure the lawmakers and civic leaders have focused on the Pentagon this week, Mr. Aspin is showing a resolve to confront difficult political decisions at a time when the Administration is trying to sell its economic plan to Congress and the public.
Indeed, Mr. Aspin has warned that this round of base closings and consolidations would only bring the military's sprawling bases and ports in line with the last budget and troop cuts made by the Bush Administration. Troop reductions resulting from the new Administration's proposals to slash military spending will not show up in base closings until the next round, in 1995.
"Future changes will decrease force structure and will require more, not fewer, base closures than those I will recommend at this time," Mr. Aspin said in a memorandum to lawmakers on Wednesday.
Mr. Aspin pledged that his base-closing decisions would be "fair and objective" and will affect bases overseas harder than those at home.
"By downsizing in this way, we make resources available to allow us to do the right things in defense: maintain the quality of the people in uniform and maintain the technological edge of their weapons," Mr. Aspin's memo said.
Senior military officials said the armed services no longer needed the two installations in California that Mr. Aspin spared, but they are very important for political reasons.
McClellan Air Force Base, an aircraft repair facility near Sacramento employs about 31,000 civilian workers, or about 4 percent of the area's total civilian employment.
The Defense Language Institute on the Monterey Presidio teaches 3,000 students a year from the four military services in 20 foreign languages. The Army has proposed closing the institute and probably will contract with university language departments to fill the gap, a senior Army official said.
Pentagon officials said the language school was saved largely because adjacent Fort Ord was closed in the round of base closings two years ago. The closing of Fort Ord is expected to cost more than 14,000 military and 2,500 civilian jobs in the Monterey area, according to an analysis by Business Executives for National Security, a research organization in Washington.
The base-closing commission closed 34 bases and reduced or consolidated 48 other sites during its last round in 1991. The Pentagon operates 481 installations around the country. The military has closed scores of bases overseas in the past five years, but those do not need commission approval.

HEADLINE: $49 Million Deal Persuades CBS to Stay Tuned

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
After weighing offers to move elsewhere against $49.5 million in benefits from New York State and New York City, CBS Inc. has decided to keep its headquarters and studios in Manhattan for at least 15 years.
The announcement was made yesterday in the CBS Broadcast Center at 530 West 57th Street, which would be rebuilt to accommodate the new technology of high-definition television, taking advantage of sales-tax savings and lower-cost power. 
 Only a small part of the benefits, $2.5 million in real-estate tax savings, would be applied to the Ed Sullivan Theater on Broadway, at 53d Street, which CBS has bought and is renovating for David Letterman's use.
At a news conference in Studio 45, usually used for "The N.F.L. Today" broadcast, Mayor David N. Dinkins said: "We worked very hard with our partners in the state to keep CBS and its 4,600 jobs -- sorry, Mr. Letterman, 4,601 jobs -- in New York."
Before yesterday, there had been no hint, at least publicly, that CBS had any plans to depart. It seems almost inevitable that the new deal will raise the ante in economic benefit negotiations, as competing networks seek assistance to develop their own high-definition capability.
"The more we can do to encourage private industry to invest in new technology, the better," Mr. Dinkins said. Asked if this amounted to an invitation to ABC and NBC to come forward, he replied: "These are deal-by-deal circumstances. If it benefits the city, we'll talk. This doesn't mean we're saying, 'We have a bottomless pit. Come and get it.' "
Laurence A. Tisch, the chairman, president and chief executive of CBS, said the network had received "offers from various states" that "would have loved to use CBS or any network" as the nucleus of a broadcasting complex. But he would not name the states or disclose any particulars about such offers.
He added, "We never threatened the city that we were leaving."
Instead, Mr. Tisch said, he met 10 months ago with Barry F. Sullivan, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, and told him: "We want to stay here. Make us feel welcome here."
To do that, city and state officials offered $31 million in sales-tax waivers for new machinery and equipment, $12 million in energy savings through electricity furnished by the New York Power Authority and $6.5 million from real-estate tax savings.
In return, CBS is required to invest $300 million in building improvements, equipment and the development of high-definition television, known as HDTV. Over the life of the deal, officials expect to collect $1 billion in tax revenues from the continued presence of CBS.
 
Role as a Center for TV
 Gov. Mario M. Cuomo also emphasized the significance of maintaining New York City's role as a center for broadcast television and entertainment.
"To move something like CBS or a large part of its operations out of New York City is historically inappropriate," he said. "We need to keep our prominence in this field."
Mr. Tisch said network executives anticipated "more changes in the next 15 years than in the past 65 years" since the Columbia Broadcasting System was founded in New York City by William S. Paley.
"We're going to have to take this building and turn it into a facility for the 21st century," Mr. Tisch said about the broadcast center, a low red-brick building at 11th Avenue that was originally built as the Sheffield Farms Company pasteurizing plant.
 
'A Level Playing Field'
 Several hours after the CBS announcement, Julie Tarachow Hoover, the vice president of corporate projects at Capital Cities/ABC, said: "We would expect equitable treatment. We want a level playing field."
"We're all going to be gearing up for HDTV," she said. "That is an expense all of us will face. We have a much bigger presence in New York and we're facing identical, major expenses. We're talking tens of millions of dollars for one station and hundreds of millions of dollars for the network."
At NBC, Betty Hudson, senior vice president for corporate communications, said the network discussed its needs with state and city officials "on a continuing basis, with an eye on our own situation and the competitive environment." But she said it was too early to assess what issues might be raised by the CBS announcement.
 
A Threefold Goal
 Carl Weisbrod, the president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, said the goal of the deal was threefold: to keep CBS competitive, to help retain jobs and to encourage the production of television programs.
The deal "induces an investment in technology and live entertainment," Mr. Weisbrod said. "The benefits here are all geared to CBS production facilities, not Black Rock," he said, referring to the corporate headquarters tower on the Avenue of the Americas, between 52d and 53d streets.
Other recent economic benefit packages have included $106.2 million over 20 years for Prudential Securities, to keep its headquarters in Manhattan; $39.6 million over 10 years for the Morgan Stanley Group, to keep its headquarters in Manhattan and back offices in Brooklyn, and $29 million over 35 years to The New York Times, to build a printing plant in College Point, Queens.

THE END OF THE WILLOWBROOK ERA
For decades, Willowbrook State School on Staten Island was a barren warehouse for 6,000 mentally retarded people and came to symbolize everything that was wrong with the care of the mentally retarded, prompting sweeping reforms. The transformation to care in small group homes reached a final milestone: A U.S. District Judge has ended 18 years of federal court supervision over former Willowbrook residents. A1.

HEADLINE: U.S. Names Trade Violators to Pressure Belgrade

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
As part of a new effort to tighten the United Nations economic embargo on Yugoslavia, the Clinton Administration has begun to identify publicly foreign companies that are helping Belgrade to evade the trade restrictions.
Other parts of the effort include offering patrol boats to Romania and Bulgaria for use in enforcing the embargo on the Danube, a major artery for trade in Eastern Europe, and sending teams of Treasury and State Department officials to work with European allies on cracking down on Serbian financial transactions and imports. 
 Last week, President Clinton said that Washington would tighten economic sanctions against the Serbian-dominated Yugoslav federation, describing the effort as being in part a response to new attacks by Bosnian Serbs against Muslims.
Administration officials declined to provide details at that time, but since then they have discussed elements of the plan. Today, the Administration released the names of 25 shipping companies, including companies in Cyprus, Malta and Panama, that it says are secretly controlled by Yugoslavia. An official notice has been issued by the Treasury Department to notify American firms of the list.
Companies found to have violated the ban repeatedly will be barred from conducting business with the United States. The officials said that Washington will urge its allies to ban business dealings with these companies.
"Yugoslavia has continued to trade through its maritime fleet in flagrant violation of U.N. sanctions," said R. Richard Newcomb, the director of the Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control. "The United States will deny the Serbs and Montenegrins any benefit of international commerce."
Serbia and Montenegro are the two remaining Yugoslav republics.
 
Banks Included
 A senior Administration official said that the United States is also planning to name banks and other companies in Western Europe that are controlled by the Serbs and have been helping Belgrade violate the trade ban.
The Administration also plans to identify companies that are not controlled by the Serbs but that have committed multiple violations of the trade ban for profit. Greek shipping companies, among other concerns, have regularly violated the trade ban, American officials have said.
With the Clinton Administration discounting any talk of military intervention in the Bosnian conflict, the American push to tighten economic sanctions has become the main point of leverage on the Serbs. The White House spokesman, George Stephanopoulos, has said that stepping up the enforcement of the sanctions will cause "real pain." Proponents of the plan have also cited reports of hyperinflation and bank failures in Yugoslavia as indications that the sanctions are beginning to bite.
The Serbian economy was shaken this week when Jezdimir Vasiljevic, the owner of the private Jugoskandic Bank, which had been attracting savings by paying high interest rates on hard currency deposits, fled to Israel. Since fleeing, Mr. Vasiljevic has asserted that Yugoslav leaders are funneling millions of dollars in state funds to private bank accounts abroad. Specialists believe that Belgrade banks have financed arms sales and have been involved in money-laundering, arms purchases and smuggling.
Some Western officials doubt that economic sanctions will be sufficient to convince Belgrade to stop supporting the Serbian nationalist forces in Bosnia. Specialists say that some of the measures in the Clinton plan, like appealing to Cyprus to tighten control over suspected Serbian financial transactions, were also undertaken during the Bush Administration, with limited effect.
To tighten the sanctions, Mr. Clinton sent a team led by Treasury Department officials to Cyprus, Germany and Austria to crack down on banks and trading companies helping the Serbs.
Cyprus, which has long been a banking center for Yugoslavs, has been a special concern for the United States, which believes that banks and trading companies there have been helping Serbia evade the embargo. Following the visit of the Clinton Administration team, the Central Bank of Cyprus said that it would step up its monitoring of financial transactions by local banks.
A State Department team visited European capitals to discuss ways to tighten the embargo. One major avenue for evading the embargo has been the Danube.
To help enforce the sanctions on the river, the United States is planning to provide patrol boats to the Romanians and the Bulgarians, following through on an offer that officials said was made by the Bush Administration.
Clinton Administration officials said the offer of the patrol boats had been accepted in principle. Some analysts believe that Romania has enough river patrol craft to enforce the sanctions and that they are saying they do not simply to avoid tough actions on enforcement.
The State Department has said that the Danube is less of a problem than the diversion of supplies from trains running through Serbia, carrying goods headed for other countries. The Clinton Administration has proposed ways to step up efforts to check those shipments.
The Administration is also increasing the number of American officials assigned to watch some of the overland routes into Yugoslavia. But Greece has refused to allow monitors to be stationed along its border.
The United States has also urged nations to impound ships that violate the embargo.

HEADLINE: U.S. Backs Yeltsin but Fears He Might Oust Legislature

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
As it watches the unfolding political turmoil in Moscow, the Clinton Administration is caught between its desire to support President Boris N. Yeltsin and its concern that he might take authoritarian measures to stay in power.
In strong statements of support in recent days, President Clinton has portrayed Mr. Yeltsin as the best hope for economic and political reform in Russia and has promised to "do what we can" to help him succeed. 
 But American officials are increasingly uncertain about Mr. Yeltsin's future, and Mr. Yeltsin complicated their thinking last week by telling Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany during a brief stopover in Moscow last week that he might dissolve the Russian Parliament and assume emergency powers to defeat his political opponents.
Mr. Yeltsin had said the same thing publicly. But European officials here said that in private, he asked Mr. Kohl whether the United States and the other major industrialized nations would support him if he were forced to take extraconstitutional action. Mr. Kohl then wrote letters to Mr. Clinton and other heads of state from the Group of Seven industrialized democracies passing on Mr. Yeltsin's position, the officials said.
American officials said they did not take Mr. Yeltsin's comments as a direct threat to assume emergency powers, but viewed them as a bargaining move, perhaps intended to heighten concern for his future among his Western supporters. Still, that put the Western powers in an uncomfortable position.
The officials said Mr. Clinton has not responded to Mr. Kohl's letter, and a Western Ambassador said: "As far as I know, none of the G-7 have replied to the message. None of us dares to say anything. We all know that the Russian Congress is anti-democratic and unrepresentative, but you can't run around saying 'Let's dissolve Parliament.' "
In a whirlwind of activity in recent weeks to bolster Mr. Yeltsin's standing, Mr. Clinton has scheduled a summit meeting with the Russian leader, offered an increase in direct American aid and called for an early meeting of the Group of Seven to consider new financing for Russia.
But Mr. Yeltsin appears to have suffered a humiliating political defeat that would strip him of much of his authority before he and Mr. Clinton meet in Vancouver next month, putting Mr. Clinton in a situation that in some ways echoed the problem President Bush faced with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union.
During the campaign last April, Mr. Clinton criticized Mr. Bush for failing to distance himself from Mr. Gorbachev before his fall from power, and a senior Administration official said that Mr. Clinton does not want to embrace Mr. Yeltsin too tightly.
"Here is the dilemma we all have here," a senior Administration official said. "Obviously the previous Administration got into some trouble for overpersonalizing the relationship, and a lot of people have made invidious comparisons between Bush's support for Gorbachev and Clinton's support for Yeltsin."
But the official added, "There is no way you can divorce Yeltsin as a personality from the state and future of reform in Russia."
Mr. Clinton himself revealed the difficult choices he faces today when, during a photo session, he praised the Russian leader, then admitted that he could not predict the future.
Asked whether Mr. Yeltsin was going to survive, Mr. Clinton avoided giving a direct answer. He said: "I think that he is the duly elected President of Russia and a genuine democrat -- small 'd' -- and that he is leading a country that is trying bravely to do two things, one, escape from Communism into market economics, a world they never lived in before, and second, to preserve real democracy. That's a tough job. Pretty hard to do here.
 
'I'm Not a Seer'
 "I intend to do what I can to be supportive of that process, and to be supportive of him while he serves as President of Russia," he said. "You know, I don't know what else to tell you. I'm not a seer."
Senior Administration officials sought to play down the significance of the Kohl missive, saying that Mr. Yeltsin has already warned the Russian Parliament publicly that he may have to take emergency measures. They said that Mr. Kohl was not in a position to be an intermediary between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin, and that the main purpose of the letter was to discuss the urgency of quick action by the Group of Seven to move quickly to help Russia reschedule its debt.
"Yeltsin has notified the Parliament of that, the world of that," said one senior official, who dismissed the threat as "part of his psychological warfare." The official added that the American Embassy in Moscow was reporting today's developments "with some relief, suggesting that the confrontations may be easing a bit and that there may be a compromise in the works."
 
Discussion of Aid Program
 As a direct result of Mr. Kohl's letter, the seven G-7 nations -- the United States, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada -- plan to discuss an outline of an aid program for Russia at their regular meeting scheduled this weekend in Hong Kong, American and European officials said.
At the urging of the United States, the countries have invited the Russian Deputy Prime Minister, Boris Fyodorov, to attend in the hope that they can craft a strategy before the annual meeting of the group's heads of state in Tokyo in July.
The current political crisis in Moscow has aggravated a deep debate within the Central Intelligence Agency and among the other American intelligence agencies on whether Mr. Yeltsin and the entire reform movement can survive, according to senior intelligence officials. The most pessimistic view is articulated in recent classified reporting by the Defense Intelligence Agency that concludes that Mr. Yeltsin is a cornered man who has no control over his destiny.
"The thinking spans the spectrum," said one senior intelligence official. "The worst case scenario is that Yeltsin is getting weaker by the day and that there is going to be a right-wing coup that will throw Russia back to authoritarian rule, to the other end where people are saying, 'Oh, they're going to be able to work it out and democracy and economic reform is gaining and irreversible.' "
 
New Doubts in Washington
 The cracks that have existed for some time within the intelligence agencies are beginning to be reflected -- albeit not as visibly -- among policy makers as well. "I still think he is going to make it," said one senior Administration official, with less certainty than a few weeks ago. "What happens in Russia is that you go to extremes before you go back to stability."
Mr. Clinton so far does not face the political pressure to back away from Mr. Yeltsin that Mr. Bush endured.
But behind the official Administration support is a realization that the United States, either alone or with its Western partners, cannot change the course of Russia's history.
"We are not making any assumptions about what will happen," Secretary of State Warren Christopher told reporters after the Russian Congress voted to eliminate some of Mr. Yeltsin's power and canceled a national referendum he had sought to win public support. "It's a very dynamic situation. The end of the story has not been written."

HEADLINE: Clinton Offers Plan to Help Military Plants to Convert

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LINTHICUM, Md., March 11

 BODY:
Using a factory that is converting from military to civilian goods as a backdrop, President Clinton today announced a plan to help such plants retool and to retrain displaced workers.
Mr. Clinton's plan would combine new money with funds already available, and new ideas with approaches that have already been developed, on converting plants that supply the military to civilian uses. 
 The President's conversion plan would also include early retirement for military personnel with more than 15 years of service, make grants and loans for new businesses and speed environmental cleanup on closed installations.
"It has been said that while change is certain, progress is not," Mr. Clinton said at the Westinghouse Electronic Systems Group, which lost nearly a third of its work force as a result of canceled contracts and an industrywide downturn. "And that certainly is true when it comes to the challenge of meeting the national economic goals that we have in the face of cutbacks in military spending."
In the near term, the President said the Government would release $1.7 billion in money already appropriated by Congress for retraining and other programs. Some of that money is contained in the economic plan now being debated in Congress, which calls for spending $20 billion over the next five years for worker retraining, community development in hard-hit areas and the improvement of the nation's infrastructure, including roads, bridges, water treatment plants and high-speed trains.
White House officials said some of $1.7 billion is also counted as part of the technology initiative the President announced last month or is part of the existing Pentagon budget.
White House officials sought to present today's announcement as revolutionary. And the setting for the President's speech, a suburban white-collar factory, was seen by the White House as a perfect example of the Administration's intent -- even though Mr. Clinton had announced the $1.7 billion in defense conversion spending when he was in California last month to promote his economic plan.
 
Base Closings
 The President's helicopter trip to suburban Maryland was intended to bolster the Administration's weeklong effort to divert attention from the Pentagon's imminent announcement of a new round of military base closings.
Mr. Clinton's aides have said the President will have no direct involvement in deciding which bases to close until July 1, when an independent commission is scheduled to send its recommendations to the White House. But the public relations offensive has already begun.
On Saturday, Mr. Clinton plans a round of private interviews with reporters from Connecticut, Texas and California, the states that would be most affected by the proposed closings.
 
Help 'to Compete and to Win'
 As the President was shown electric cars, security systems and radar-equipped airplanes at the plant here, he was accompanied by Defense Secretary Les Aspin, several other members of his Cabinet and members of Congress.
"All the worker training in the world and all the community assistance in the world will do no good if there are no jobs for those workers and no businesses for those communities," the President said. "The private sector is the engine of lasting economic growth in our system, and therefore our plan must help our companies to make these transitions, to compete and to win."
Later in the day, Mr. Clinton sought to make the link between cutting military spending and using those savings to help cut the deficit as well as to finance some social programs.
In a speech delivered to the Children's Defense Fund in Washington, he asked people who normally demand more from the Government to support him in telling Congress that they must accept the spending cuts he has proposed as well as the increases aimed at stimulating the economy.
"The people that are attacking me act like anybody that wants any money from the Government just loves all that bureaucracy you have to put up with," he said. "I know better."

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Up Slightly As Jobless Claims Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
Fresh signs of slackened economic growth emerged today as the Government reported that retail sales rose a modest three-tenths of 1 percent in February and that new claims for jobless benefits climbed again in the week ended Feb. 27.
Sales were held back by a 2.2 percent drop in sales by automotive dealers, and there might have been no gain at all, analysts said, without price increases in building materials and some other items. The price of lumber soared 90 percent from early October to the end of February, reflecting increased demand brought on by the economic recovery and environmental battles that have sharply curtailed supplies from Federal lands.
 
Apparent Contradiction
 The 25,000 rise in jobless claims, to 376,000, was the third in a row and something of a surprise in light of last Friday's report of substantial job growth for February. That earlier report on employment conditions was conducted during the week ended Feb. 13. 
 Marilyn Schaja, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities, said today's reports seem "to fit with the hypothesis that the economy slowed in the second half of February."
It has been widely expected that the economy will throttle down this quarter from its strong 4.8 percent growth rate in the final three months of 1992. Job growth continues to lag, and consumers are restraining spending as they pay holiday bills and face smaller tax refunds this year after President George Bush ordered withholding reductions last year to spur the economy.
Analysts also say President Clinton, in disclosing his plans for the economy on Feb. 17, may have soured consumer attitudes with calls for sacrifice and higher taxes.
"Growth in consumption spending has slowed somewhat" following the fourth-quarter surge, said David L. Cohen, an economist at MMS International, a California company that provides information and analysis. Gains for four straight months in industrial production have relied heavily on automobile assemblies, he said, and this probably cannot be sustained unless sales, now weak, pick up soon.
Cars and trucks represent 21 percent of retail sales, which last month totaled $167.79 billion.
 
Impact of Lumber Sales
 Excluding the automotive group, the retail sales report showed a nine-tenths of 1 percent advance, better at first glance than had been anticipated. But closer inspection showed that the biggest gain was 3.3 percent for dealers selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes.
Much of this increase reflected higher prices resulting from extra demand for lumber in states battered by Hurricanes Andrew and Iniki as well as crimped lumber supplies.
The Commerce Department revised January sales to show no change instead of the initial three-tenths of 1 percent gain. The December jump, however, was revised upward to 1.1 percent from eight-tenths of 1 percent -- showing an even better Christmas season.
The February sales gain was the sixth in eight months. Tracy Mullin, president of the National Retail Federation, said, "A modest increase is better than no increase at all."
The February gain resulted from a seven-tenths of 1 percent jump in sales of nondurables that was not entirely offset by a five-tenths of 1 percent decline for cars and other durable goods, items designed to last at least three years.
Sales of furniture and home equipment declined by five-tenths of 1 percent from their January level.
 
Clothing Sales Down
 In nondurables, the only decline was among stores selling apparel and accessories. They suffered a 1.7 percent skid, after a smaller decline in January.
"We're still making progress," said Robert L. Marks, president of SOM Economics in New York. He noted that the February-to-February sales increase was 5.3 percent.
Today's Labor Department report on jobless claims showed them rising to their highest level since early November. The figures tend to be highly erratic, despite adjustments for normal seasonal variation.

HEADLINE: Military Industry Lobbies to Preserve Status Quo

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
While President Clinton unveiled his program today to retrain workers displaced by cuts in Pentagon spending, the nation's big military contractors were lobbying to keep their businesses intact.
The military industry welcomed President's Clinton's announcement that the Government would swiftly release $1.7 billion in money already appropriated by Congress to help retrain military workers and provide money to communities hurt by the closing of military bases. 
 Mr. Clinton wants to spend $20 billion over five years for retraining and other programs.
 
Conversion Seen as Hard
 But industry trade associations say it will be difficult for many companies to shift into consumer markets, and they argue that the country needs to preserve the industrial base for crucial military production.
To that end, they are pressing Congress and the Administration for export subsidies to increase foreign military sales, more favorable payments on remaining Pentagon contracts and greater freedom to use technology developed with Government money without paying royalties.
"It's difficult for our industry to convert," said Don Fuqua, president of the Aerospace Industries Association. "We can build a better commercial airplane, a more fuel-efficient airplane. But we can't make pies and cakes. That market is filled."
The big military contractors say the industry still hopes to find new lines of high-tech military work. They are pressing for a bigger slice of the $25 billion in work now conducted at Federal laboratories, as well as more of the $11 billion in maintenance and modernization done on ships and planes at military depots.
They are also asking the Pentagon to roll back some of its elaborate auditing practices and rigid technical specifications when buying equipment, and to buy more equipment designed for both commercial markets and military purposes.
The Electronics Industries Association is lobbying for legislation to create several billion dollars in new loan guarantees to support purchases of American weapons by foreign governments. Similarly, it and the Aerospace Industries Association support eliminating export restrictions on sales of jet aircraft and helicopters to countries like China.
"If we're in a situation where countries are going to buy arms anywhere and we're not going to be able to control that through multilateral dealings, then it's in our best interest to be competitive," said Dan C. Heinemeier, a vice-president at Electronics Industries Association.
The prospect of increased arms exports disturbs some military experts who warn that Government subsidies would worsen the global arms race. They also note that many seemingly burdensome contract requirements were adopted in response to scandals in the last decade.
"I think our weapons sales are already outrageously high," said Lawrence J. Korb, a military analyst at the Brookings Institution who served as Assistant Secretary of Defense under President Reagan. "I think we ought to be slowing down arms sales in the world."
He also noted that many of the rules were installed in response to scandals over high-priced hammers and toilet seats during the 1980's.
"I'd just love to relax controls on these guys, but they just seem to go from one scandal to another," he remarked.
The big military contractors also face a fight with the big Government-owned laboratories, which are also scrambling for work in an era of reduced spending on weapons. "Clearly, excess capacity exists in both the public and private sectors," noted a recent report by the Electronics Industries Association.
Converting military businesses to peacetime work is emerging as an important component of Mr. Clinton's technology policy.
The Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency is being given a broader mandate to invest in commercial technologies, while the big weapons laboratories operated by the Defense Department and Department of Energy are being ordered to work more closely on joint research projects with industry.
 
New Purchasing Rules Sought
 Both the White House and big military contractors also agree that the Pentagon purchasing rules should be changed to allow heavier reliance on dual-use technologies, like computers and radars that were developed for commercial customers but can fill military needs. Some leading Congressional Democrats also agree that it would be unwise to let the nation's military contractors simply atrophy.
"The defense budget can't be a jobs program, but we can certainly help these companies acquire the flexibility to survive in a post-cold war economy," said Senator Jeff Bingaman, the New Mexico Democrat who heads the Senate Subcommittee on Defense Industry and Technology and sponsor of legislation last year that supplies money for military conversion programs.
"I think that its in our best interest to keep these companies strong, and to keep the talent and the competence they have put together."

HEADLINE: Foes of Pornography and Bigotry Join Forces

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 11

 BODY:
Treading close to what critics consider the land of the thought police, some legal scholars are joining together to fight against images they believe should never be produced and words they believe should never be spoken.
They are feminist opponents of pornography and scholars of hate speech who, after years of pursuing their work alone and often with frustration, have joined forces in a search for a legal framework to strengthen both causes. 
 It is an alliance that follows a decade of near-victories and setbacks in court, and deep divisions among women as to what the feminist position should be in either fight.
 
Violence and Pornography
 The alliance is in its early stages and appears dominated by the anti-pornography wing of the feminist movement, a group that regards pornography as the cause and primary cultural symbol of violence against women.
The alliance is deeply at odds with some mainstream feminist groups that fear that attacking pornography is a fringe exercise that detracts from bigger battles like pay equity, child care and abortion rights, while potentially threatening women's own right to free sexual expression.
The two feminist schools are so polarized that they are barely on speaking terms and, in the words of Patricia Ireland, president of the National Organization for Women, "cannot even agree to disagree."
So the anti-pornography feminists have reached out to scholars of hate speech to broaden their constituency and perhaps more effectively test society's limits on protected speech and expression.
 
Harm vs. Free Speech
 They see it not as a First Amendment issue but as a question of harm and equal rights. At the core of their argument is the idea that both pornography and hate speech inflict harm not only on the individual taunted by the words or participating in the photo shoot but on all minorities or women in a kind of "collective defamation."
The goal of the new alliance is to fight hate speech and pornography through laws that would permit victims to seek damages against speakers of bigotry or producers of pornography by showing how the hateful speech or images have harmed them.
Neither side of the alliance has fared well in the courts. Anti-pornography laws drafted by Andrea Dworkin, a writer, and Catharine MacKinnon, a University of Michigan law professor, were considered or adopted in cities like Minneapolis, Indianapolis and Los Angeles, but they were either defeated by lawmakers or overturned by courts on the ground that they violated the First Amendment guarantee of free speech.
Last year, the United States Supreme Court ruled that a St. Paul hate-crime ordinance banning cross-burnings was unconstitutional. And hate-speech codes of the University of Michigan and the University of Wisconsin were overturned in lower courts.
The two groups sat down together for the first time at a conference at the University of Chicago Law School last weekend. It was a gathering of anti-pornography intellectuals, hate-speech theorists and constitutional scholars seeking sustenance and common ground.
"This was a historic moment that saw feminists and racial minorities come together," said Richard Delgado, a professor of law at the University of Colorado who is a specialist in hate speech. "Before it seemed as if gains for one could only be made at the expense of the other. This time they linked arms in a common venture against a hate directed at both of them."
 
Common Focus
 Ms. Dworkin described pornography and hate speech as very deeply related. "Harm is the central issue in both," she said. "Both require a showing of harm in order to do anything about them. In other words, how are people dehumanized by these expressions of hate?"
Though the two groups share this common focus on harm, there are significant legal differences between them. Those seeking to limit hate speech have supported criminal laws simply outlawing extreme expressions of racial or religious hatred. Those seeking to limit pornography, however, do not seek a criminal ban on pornography, but rather to allow women to seek damages and injunctions against the makers of pornography that causes harm.
Recently, the anti-pornography wing has won a few notable converts from the mainstream, including Ellie Smeal, president of the Fund for a Feminist Majority, who appeared on several panels at the conference.
In a telephone interview today, Ms. Smeal said: "I am not going to just sit here and ignore it any longer. The violence toward women is there, everywhere. It is bubbling up. It is the No. 1 question I am asked after a speech. Free speech is being used to protect the violence."
Mindful of the implications, she said, "I don't want a police state. I don't want censorship. But to do nothing, to not enter out of fear is wrong. We have to get beyond, 'We can't do anything,' and do something."
There were few dissenters at the conference, which at times had the atmosphere of a revivalist meeting, where group harm was the incantation.
Leanne Katz, executive director of the National Coalition Against Censorship, an umbrella group of First Amendment advocates, attended the conference as an outsider looking in, worried that the new alliance could ultimately threaten what she sees as free speech. "It seems a criminal diversion of energies," she said of the movement. "To say that pornography threatens women makes us think there is some kind of quick fix. It worries me greatly."
Civil libertarians see this as a reactionary movement closer to Jesse Helms than Susan B. Anthony. "Mac Kinnon gives this whole enterprise a superficial gloss of intellectual respectability," said Marjorie Heins, director of the Arts Censorship Project of the American Civil Liberties Union. "Their rhetoric is religious in its character and its highly charged incantatory."
 
A Litmus Test
 The debate has turned pornography into a litmus test for feminism. "This kind of issue has produced terrible polarization, the kind that says, 'How can you think this and say you support women?' " Ms. Ireland said.
Virtually all feminists agree that pornography is detrimental to women. "Where we come to verbal blows is over the solution," Ms. Ireland said, adding that there was an important distinction between pornography and erotica."
Ms. Ireland envisions a campaign to make the consumption of pornography seem philistine and unenlightened, as humiliating and socially unacceptable as smoking has become.
The anti-pornography forces say such broad strokes are not enough. They bristle at the comparisons to right-wing-religious-fundamentalists and argue that pornography is neither narrow nor peripheral but the basis of women's inequality.
"Women won't be able to get economic equity as long as we're seen as pieces of meat," Ms. Dworkin said. "Pornography determines our economic worthlessness. It is a really a form of colonialization of the woman's body. It is the equivalent of land. The people who own it are men."
Those who agree with Ms. Dworkin take great comfort in a decision last year by the Supreme Court of Canada that defined pornography as sexual depictions of violence that harm women by dehumanizing and degrading them.
Kathleen Mahoney, the law professor who argued the case, said the decision stopped looking at obscenity as a moral question and analyzed it instead in terms of the harm it does.
 
Goal of Persuasion
 Hate-speech experts agree with that analysis. "We have to persuade society and the courts that the harm of scathing speech and the well-being of women is sufficient to overcome the usual presumption that speech should be free," Mr. Delgado said.
Leaders of the anti-pornography movement are longing for an actual case to bring to court.
"We don't have a plaintiff who's actually suing to say, 'This is how pornography hurt me or how I was used by pornography,' " Ms. Dworkin said. "It would be much stronger movement if it broadened from the academy."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Profit Is Seen in Airline Junk Bonds

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Some traders and portfolio managers said yesterday that they saw considerable potential for profit in the bonds of the nation's three major airlines, even though Standard & Poor's had declared them junk bonds.
Prices on the bonds fell after S.& P. lowered the rating on the debt of the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines; the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, and Delta Air Lines Inc. to below investment grade -- the junk-bond level. 
 "We have done our homework and we believe this is an opportunity to buy," said Geoffrey Kurinsky, a vice president at Massachusetts Financial Services in Boston, who has confidence that the airlines have stabilized their problems.
An executive at a major underwriter, who spoke on condition of anonymity, added, "There is a large universe of accounts waiting to buy."
 
Companies 'Will Survive'
 Max Holmes, a senior bond analyst at Salomon Brothers, agreed that this was a buying opportunity because "I think all three companies will survive."
But he said that because Moody's Investor Services had not changed the ratings of the three, still carrying them as investment grade, much of the expected selling might not come until these ratings were lowered. That would be the better time to buy, he said.
Pension funds and insurance companies that are not allowed to own noninvestment grade bonds would be required to sell, he said, adding that with a split rating that now exists, many of these investors might be able to hold on for the time being.
Mr. Holmes also said that a downgrading by Moody's could be a blow to Delta because it had $441 million of employee stock ownership plan notes it could have to buy back from the holders if the two credit agencies lowered it to noninvestment grade.
Mr. Kurinsky said that yesterday's move had been expected in the market and that "nothing really has changed because the downgrading was priced into the bonds."
Given the new BB ratings and the current spreads between the yields on Treasury securities and the yields on airline bonds, Mr. Kurinsky said the yields on the airlines were quite attractive compared with other noninvestment-grade paper.
 
Cable vs. Airlines
 For example, he said that the yield on BB-rated cable television company bonds was around 9.5 percent, while the yield on Delta's bonds, which has the widest spread over Treasury yields of the three airline issues, would be around 10.25 percent. Mr. Holmes argued that this comparison was a little stretched because the airline industry and its bonds were so much more volatile than the cable industry so the yield on airlines should be higher.
Immediately after the afternoon announcement, the yields offered on all three airlines rose by about 20 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, as prices of their bonds fell. But there were no buyers right away.
Later, there were a few trades and the yields rose. By late in trading, it appeared that Delta had fared the best while AMR had fared the worst for the day. This is because there had been a possibility that AMR would not be downgraded while the debt of the two other airlines would. The possibility that AMR might avoid a downgrading is one reason why the spread between AMR 30-year bonds and Treasuries was much narrower than the spread for Delta.
According to Mr. Kurinsky, the spread on AMR widened by about 50 basis points after the announcement while the spread on UAL moved by about 30 basis points and the spread on Delta moved about 25 basis points.
In the corporate bond market, the performance of bonds is generally measured by the spread between the yields on comparable Treasury securities and the yields on the corporate bonds. As the spread narrows, the corporate bonds are doing well and gaining in value but as they widen they are not.
 
Marriott Bonds Jump
 In another closely watched bond story, the bonds of the Marriott Corporation jumped sharply in value after it was announced that the company had agreed to some changes in its plan to split into two companies -- a move that had angered bondholders. The yield on the 10 percent bonds due in 2012 dropped to 9.65 percent, from 10.25 percent Wednesday, a 6 percent move in one day.
The major deal in the corporate bond market yesterday was a sale of $900 million, $300 million each, in 5- , 10- and 30-year bonds by the Lockheed Corporation. The lead manager was the First Boston Corporation. The yield on the 5-year bond was 5.99 percent, or 80 basis points over the 5-year Treasury note; the yield on the 10-year bond was 6.87 percent or 92 basis point over the 10-year Treasury note and the yield on the 30-year bond was 7.91 percent, or 117 basis points over the 30-year Treasury bond.
 
Treasury Market
 Prices of Treasury securities bounced around again yesterday as traders and investors awaited the Labor Department's report on inflation today and possibly some indication of what direction the market should be moving in.
In a day of trading that was punctuated by economic reports on retail sales and jobless claims that showed that the economy might have been weaker than expected at the end of February, the price of the 30-year bond dropped 5/32 , to 10421/32 , and the yield rose to 6.76 percent, up from 6.75 percent Wednesday. The price of the 10-year and 5-year Treasury notes also declined, while the price of the 3-year note rose slightly.
The report on the Producer Price Index due out today and the Consumer Price index to be released on Wednesday could determine whether prices will move higher in the near future with yields resuming their decline.
Traders and investors are worried now that these two reports might show that inflation is a little higher than expected. If this is the case and the rate of inflation this year looks like it will be higher than 3 percent, the rally in the bond market that brought the yield on the 30-year bond to its lowest level since 1977 could be over for the time being.
