HEADLINE: Budget Panel Approves Clinton's Plan

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
On party-line votes, the Senate Budget Committee tonight rejected Republican efforts to change President Clinton's economic plan and approved, 12 to 9, the framework of a budget close to what the President had proposed.
In the House of Representatives today, the opposition of conservative Democrats to the President's short-term economic stimulus program seemed to have withered away. 
 Thirty-four different Republican amendments were offered, and each was defeated when no Democrat broke party ranks.
The Republicans, who hold 9 seats on the Senate Budget Committee against 12 for the Democrats, never stood a chance today. The Democrats were solidly behind the President's proposals and the measures sponsored by the committee chairman, Jim Sasser of Tennessee, to make small modifications in the Clinton program.
The House Budget Committee approved a budget framework on Wednesday. The Senate committee's plan, which has slightly deeper budget cuts from the House version, is supposed to shrink the deficit by $502 billion over five years.
In fiscal year 1997, the last of President Clinton's term, the deficit, which is now about $300 billion a year, would be reduced below $200 billion a year, according to the estimates of the Congressional Budget Office.
 
Votes Scheduled Next Week
 The committee measures, called budget resolutions, are scheduled for votes by the full House and Senate next week, when party-line votes are also likely to be the order of the day.
This is the first step in the annual budget process, setting overall requirements for taxes and spending but making no real judgments on which taxes to raise or lower or on what the money should be spent for. Party discipline may break down when the gritty details must be dealt with.
The Republicans' certain futility in trying to change the President's program now, without sufficient votes to win, did not prevent them from spending hours making their political points.
Beginning at 9:30 this morning and continuing well into the night, the Republicans zeroed in on the most politically touchy of the President's proposals: a higher tax on the Social Security benefits of the most affluent retirees, an energy tax, fees for using Government services like waterways, deep cuts in the military budget.
They offered amendments, one after another, that let them make their political arguments and forced Democrats to cast votes that might be used as Republican ammunition in the next campaign.
 
Talking for Television
 The top Republican on the committee, Pete V. Domenici, conceded that the effort was mostly for the consumption of the television audience that he hoped would eventually watch the taped proceedings on C-Span, the cable network that covers Congress.
For hours on end, the Republicans lined their side of the committee table and made points like these:
*Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi on Mr. Clinton's plan to require individual retirees with incomes above $25,000 and couples with incomes above $32,000 to pay higher taxes on their Social Security benefits: "They're raising taxes on retirees and using it for more Government spending."
*Senator Phil Gramm of Texas on the Clinton plan to charge a fee to state-chartered banks whose deposits are insured by the Federal Government: "This would make it hard for consumers who want to buy automobiles and refrigerators and washing machines."
While this was going on, the man running the television camera pointed at the Democratic side of the table had little to do, the Democratic seats being empty for most of the day.
Occasionally one Democrat or another would come in and offer a potshot, like this one from Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, who wore a U.S.S. Tennessee baseball cap to keep the TV lights out of his eyes: "You fellows act like you just walked out of Independence Hall and Government just got started."
Senator Sasser, for his part, sat quietly in the chairman's seat at the head of the table, knowing he had the votes locked up and looking ever so much like a poker player with complete confidence in his hole card.
Once in a while, he offered a defense of the Clinton plan. "The American people voted for a change," he said at one point, calling for more money for education, job-training, health care and law-enforcement. The new taxes, he said, "will be used to lower the deficit and advance the investment programs the American people have said they wanted."
In the House, Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington said Mr. Clinton's proposal for an immediate economic stimulus of $31 billion would be passed mostly intact. The package includes $15 billion in tax cuts for businesses and $16 billion in new spending for roads, summer jobs and other programs to create jobs.
 
Threat That Fades
 Some conservative Democrats had threatened to oppose the stimulus measures. But after a caucus of all Democrats this morning, they withdrew their challenge, apparently because they did not have enough votes to make a difference.
Asked whether the stimulus would be cut back, Mr. Foley responded: "No, I don't think so. You know, we'll make some minor adjustments in it as we always do, but I don't expect any major scaling back of it."
At the other end of the Democratic ideological spectrum, the members of the Black Caucus met with Mr. Foley this afternoon to complain that the budget now moving through Congress cut too deeply into spending programs important to their districts. They also seemed to have too few votes to make a difference.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Rise in Metals Prices Is Led By Platinum and Palladium

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Platinum and palladium led metals futures higher yesterday amid perceptions that political unrest in Russia could disrupt supplies. Grains fell on fears that the unrest could shut Russia out of the United States grain market, analysts said.
The Russian Congress moved yesterday to strip President Boris N. Yeltsin of most of his authority, threatening his economic reforms. 
 Although Russian production of platinum and palladium has been falling, Russia produces about half the world's supply of the metals, which are used widely in catalytic converters and electronics.
"It's looking very uncertain," said Bette Raptopoulos, a metals analyst with Prudential Securities in New York. "Russia is a major producer and the fear is that if things got chaotic, production could be disrupted and shipments could be curtailed."
Platinum for April delivery closed $3.70 higher at $349.30 an ounce on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Palladium for delivery in June closed $2.30 higher at $105 an ounce.
The gains spilled over into other metals futures, analysts said. At the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for April delivery bounced off its life-of-contract low set Wednesday and finished 70 cents higher at $327.60 an ounce. Silver for delivery in May closed 5.5 cents higher at $3.637 an ounce.
Traders at the Chicago Board of Trade pushed soybean and grain futures prices lower.
Russia accounted for about 11 percent of American grain exports until November, when it missed payments on Washington-backed loans to buy United States farm products. Russian officials have been trying to reschedule its debt for months so that it might be reinstated into American loan programs. The instability in Russia could further delay a resolution to its debt problems, analysts said.
Oil futures extended Wednesday's losses on the New York Merc as traders shifted their attention to oversupply.
Crude oil for April delivery closed 26 cents lower at $20.13 a barrel. Among products, heating oil for April delivery finished 0.73 cent lower at 57.32 cents a gallon, and unleaded gasoline for April delivery finished 1.08 cents lower at 57.33 cents a gallon.
May orange juice jumped in reaction to forecasts calling for freezing temperatures in Florida's citrus belt this weekend, analysts said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends the Day Mixed Amid Concern on Yeltsin

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed in trading against the major currencies yesterday amid rumors about whether Boris Yeltsin would survive as the president of Russia.
Gillie Augeri, chief dealer at the Connecticut National Bank in Hartford, said the market was confused by moves by opponents of President Yeltsin to strip him of power. She said the dollar started rising late Wednesday and continued in yesterday's trading. 
 The Communist-dominated Russian Congress voted yesterday to strip Mr. Yeltsin of more of his powers and canceled a national referendum he had sought to cement his authority.
European currencies usually weaken on news of instability in Russia, as traders often buy dollars because of the relative security of the currency, driving up its value. However, once word got out that President Yeltsin was not immediately ousted, the dollar drifted lower, Ms. Augeri said.
Yesterday's economic numbers that showed a modest rise in February retail sales were offset by an unexpected jump in jobless claims and thus had no effect on the market, she said.
 
Dollar at 118.09 Yen in Tokyo
 Late yesterday in New York, the dollar sold at 117.65 yen, down from 118.05 yen on Wednesday. Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 118.09 yen, up 0.19 yen from Wednesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at the lower rate of 117.50 yen.
In New York it cost $1.4305 to buy one British pound, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.4330. In London, the pound rose to $1.4362, from $1.4325 late Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.6615 German marks, down from 1.6665; 1.5235 Swiss francs, down from 1.5355; 5.6435 French francs, down from 5.6580; 1,607.00 Italian lire, up from 1,606.50, and 1.24725 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2448.
Other late dollar rates in Europe compared with late rates Wednesday, included: 1.6615 German marks, down from 1.6750; 1.5215 Swiss francs, down from 1.5354; 5.6345 French francs, down from 5.6525; 1.8658 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8713; 1,604.50 Italian lire, up from 1,601.00, and 1.2445 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2461.

HEADLINE: Judge Orders Better Care For Homeless With H.I.V.

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

 BODY:
A State Supreme Court judge has ruled that New York City must provide certain minimum standards in housing homeless people with H.I.V. who have symptoms of illness but do not yet have AIDS. Advocates for the homeless say the decision will force the city to remove this group from the city's shelters.
Ruling on a lawsuit brought by the Coalition for the Homeless against the city and the state nearly five years ago, Judge Edward H. Lehner found that current city efforts to shield this population from tuberculosis and other infectious diseases do not go far enough. He ordered the city to place this group in rooms with four or fewer people where beds are at least eight feet apart, and said the city must also provide them with quarters that have adequate ventilation and separate bathrooms and dining areas. 
 "Not a single facility in the city meets the standards," said Virginia G. Shubert, the plaintiffs' lawyer. "The only logical response for the city is to expand eligibility for private housing to anyone with H.I.V. disease."
But in his ruling, issued March 4, the judge rejected arguments that H.I.V.-infected homeless people who are ill are entitled to the same private housing given to those with AIDS, the end stage of H.I.V. infection.
 
Appeal Is Planned
 City lawyers said yesterday that they will appeal the decision, the latest in a series of court orders in the last year that has found the city's handling of the homeless inadequate. Ms. Shubert said the defendants are also considering an appeal in the hope of getting those people sick with H.I.V. the same treatment as those with AIDS.
Neither side had estimates of how many homeless people would be affected by the ruling, or how much it would cost the city to meet the judge's standards. But both agree their numbers were reduced considerably earlier this year when the city decided to follow an expanded Federal definition of AIDS to determine who is eligible for city AIDS-related benefits. There are currently about 7,000 single adult men and women and 5,600 families in the city's shelter system.
The lawsuit was filed on behalf of three homeless individuals in 1988. Judge Lehner issued his decision following a trial last year that featured conflicting medical opinions about the risks involved in placing H.I.V.-infected people in homeless shelters.
The plaintiffs argued that the city's barracks-style shelters endanger the health of people whose immune system has been weakened by the AIDS virus and who have less ability to fight diseases they can catch from others. They argued that the shelters are breeding grounds for tuberculosis, pointing at studies that showed an outbreak of 12 cases at a Manhattan shelter for men and a TB infection rate of 43 percent at another, on Wards Island.
 
Debate Over Care Needed
 City officials argued that private housing for this group was neither medically required nor economically feasible. The city offers private housing and other benefits to more than 2,600 people with conditions that meet the Federal definition of AIDS. Those not deemed to have the disease are eligible for rent subsidies or, if in a medically frail condition, for a "comprehensive care program" that places them in special units within existing shelters.
The program's units have no more than 12 people per room and offer expanded medical care and social services, along with specialized diets. Participants still share dining rooms and other areas with the general shelter population.
"If we felt they were at risk we wouldn't do this," said James Capoziello, the Executive Deputy Commissioner for Adult Services in the city's Human Resources Administration.
Judge Lehner rejected the comprehensive care program as lacking a "rational basis." He said medical screenings upon admission cannot reliably detect, for example, whether a person has drug-resistant TB.
But he said he found no grounds to order the city to treat those infected as if they had AIDS.
"Although such a program of individual housing would be the most desirable and create the least risk to H.I.V.-infected persons of coming in contact with others with infectious diseases, government cannot be required to provide an optimal solution," he wrote.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Semiconductor's Income Rose 85% in 3d Quarter

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, March 11

 BODY:
Continuing its recovery, the National Semiconductor Corporation reported today that earnings for its third quarter were up 85 percent from a year ago, at the high end of Wall Street estimates. The Santa Clara, Calif., chip maker also reported improvement in profit margins and a record level of new orders.
The news moved National's stock, which closed at $12.875, up $1.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. National shares were one of the most heavily traded issues, with 2.4 million changing hands. 
 "I am pleased with our third-quarter results, which demonstrate that we are continuing our profitability for the sixth consecutive quarter, with substantial improvement in income from operations," Gilbert F. Amelio, National's president and chief executive, said in a statement.
For the quarter ended Feb. 28, the company reported profits of $26.9 million, or 19 cents a share, up from $14.5 million, or 11 cents a share, for the corresponding period last year.
Sales for the quarter were $491.5 million, up 22 percent from $401.8 million for the quarter last year.
"Gross margins also improved during the quarter to 31.1 percent, compared with 28.7 percent for the comparable quarter a year ago, and 29.7 percent in the second quarter of fiscal 1993," Mr. Amelio said. "This improvement is derived in part from lower production costs achieved by our continuing restructuring program."
 
An Improved Profitability
 Another factor in National's improved profitability is a continuing shift from commodity chips to more specialized devices that command higher prices, said Daniel L. Klesken, an analyst with Robertson, Stephens & Company. The product mix "is still in transition," as shown by a gross margin of 31 percent, he said. "Probably in another year it will be in the mid-30's; they know where they want to go."
National said semiconductor industry business conditions in the third quarter continued to improve over the second quarter and were substantially stronger than last year. National's third-quarter worldwide orders set a record and were up 40 percent over last year.
"We entered the fourth quarter with an improved backlog," Mr. Amelio said. "By having shipped through the holidays we expect to temper the normal seasonal upswing of the fourth quarter. As part of our continuing focus on gross margin improvement, we expect fourth-quarter gross margin to improve over the current quarter."
Mr. Klesken said that another favorable sign is that "customers are now feeling good enough to commit beyond 90 days," rather than the 30- or 45-day order commitments more typical of the semiconductor industry. "That's a first," he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Marriott Alters Plan To Split Up

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
The Marriott Corporation, acting to placate bondholders angry over its plan to split into two companies, said yesterday that it had agreed to issue new bonds at higher interest rates and to shift some debt between the two new companies.
The original plan to split, announced in October, angered bondholders and brought lawsuits because virtually all of Marriott's nearly $3 billion in debt would have been left with the new real estate company, rather than the profitable management company. 
 The corporation still intends to divide into separate companies, but, under yesterday's agreement, about $450 million of debts and assets will be shifted from Host Marriott, the proposed real estate company, to Marriott International, the company that will manage hotels and restaurants. About $1.9 billion of the total debt is in bonds.
News of the planned reorganization in October had sent the price of Marriott's 20-year bonds plunging by 30 percent. Yesterday, the bonds were up slightly after the news of the revision. Marriott's stock, which rose 12 percent the day the proposed reorganization was announced, closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $26.50, up 75 cents.
 
Agreement in Principle Set
 Yesterday's agreement in principle was reached with the plaintiffs in eight class action lawsuits, and with representatives of institutions holding about $400 million of Marriott's bonds. Those institutions that had threatened to sue are IDS Financial Services, the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association, the California Public Employees' Retirement System and the Allstate Life Insurance Company.
The offer to exchange new bonds for old will be available to all bondholders, and all participants would be required to abandon litigation seeking to block the restructuring. But not all creditors have accepted the terms.
The most conspicuous holdout remains PPM America Inc., whose clients hold more than $120 million in bonds and which has sued Marriott for securities fraud. That suit is pending in United States District Court in Baltimore.
Lawrence Kill, PPM's lawyer, described yesterday's offer as "woefully inadequate" and accused the company of trying to "steamroller" bondholders into accepting its offer.
"Had PPM's plaintiffs known of the restructuring they wouldn't have bought the bonds," Mr. Kill said, "or their price would have been substantially less."
In December, Marriott said it planned to form the new company through a special dividend, after which shareholders would have an identical number of shares in each company. That dividend remains contingent upon ratification by shareholders and a ruling from the Internal Revenue Service that it will be tax-free. The transaction is scheduled for completion this summer, the company said, and closing is not contingent upon the outcome of the exchange offer.
Among the assets being shifted to Marriott International are leased land and two retirement communities. Marriott International will lease another 14 retirement communities from Host Marriott. Assuming 100 percent participation in the exchange offer, Host Marriott's total debt would be reduced by about $500 million.
Stephen F. Bollenbach, Marriott's chief financial officer, said the contemplated adjustments are expected to reduce Marriott International's projected earnings by about 7 cents a share this year, and less than five cents a share in 1994.
J. W. Marriott Jr., chairman and president of the Bethesda, Md. company, said Marriott International "will continue to have a strong capital base with ample investment capacity to pursue strategic growth."
The agreement calls for Host Marriott to pay $1 million in fees and expenses to attorneys of the class action plaintiffs. And it provides warrants to purchase up to 7.7 million shares of its common stock, for the benefit of former bondholders who disposed of their bonds after Oct. 5, 1992, and cannot participate in the exchange offer.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Dayton Hudson Corp. (N)

 BODY:
Thanks to healthy sales and tight expense controls, the Dayton Hudson Corporation's profits rose 30 percent in the fourth quarter.
Sales in stores open at least one year, which analysts consider a better barometer of a retail company's performance than total sales figures, were up 6 percent in the fourth quarter and 4 percent for the year. 
 Wayne Hood, a retail analyst at Prudential Securities, said the Target discount store division, which accounted for 58 percent of the company's revenues last year, should have even stronger sales next year because of a strategy to lower prices on about a thousand items.
Dayton Hudson hopes that Mervyn's, its problematic chain of moderately priced apparel stores, will benefit from a change in merchandising strategy. Mervyn's customers typically have shopped for individual items, but the company is now trying to get them to buy clothes in ensembles.
The department stores that Dayton Hudson operates -- Marshall Field's, Dayton's and Hudson's -- got a big lift last year from aggressive cost-cutting. Mr. Hood said the stores were now poised to benefit from improvements in the economy in their Midwestern markets.

HEADLINE: U.S. Discounters Invade Mexico

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
The discounters that revolutionized retailing in the United States are at it in Mexico now, underselling not only the department stores and specialty shops but sometimes even the street vendors, kiosk operators and other members of the big informal economy.
The invasion began a year ago, after the Mexican Government lifted import restrictions on most American consumer goods in anticipation of the North American Free Trade Agreement. That meant that a Wal-Mart could transplant its high-volume merchandising to Mexico, and it was not long before a Wal-Mart's Sam's Club set up shop in a former candy factory on one side of town, and the Price Club opened one of its warehouse-like stores on the other side. 
 "I would say that 20 percent of the Mexican population could be our clientele someday," said Jaime Gonzalez Solana, director general of Price Club of Mexico and a member of the family that owns Comercial Mexicana, a chain of supermarkets and restaurants that is the Price Company's Mexican partner.
Until two years ago, the sidewalk stands, street peddlers and makeshift storefronts, which are illegal but operate everywhere here, had been a huge source for foreign-made goods sold as contraband at deep discounts.
This informal economy is still a very active part of Mexican retailing, accounting for more than 15 percent of the nation's total economic activity. But with the lifting of import quotas, the vendors have been deprived of some of their contraband market appeal, and operations like Sam's Club and Price Club are beginning to challenge them. The two discounters are also beginning to act as wholesalers to the hundreds of small, family-owned stores that sell everything from apparel to small appliances.
"They offer the quality, spare parts, service and warranties that the street vendors can't provide," said Mauricio A. Gonzalez Gomez, a director of the Economists and Associates Group, a consulting firm. "Many Mexicans, of course, lack the income to go to a Wal-Mart or don't yet know about such places. But the numbers of potential customers are rising."
Mr. Gonzalez Gomez and Ignacio Perez Lizaur, his counterpart at Sam's Club, speak of plans to open a dozen more outlets in the next few years. Their aim is to attract all sorts of Mexicans, including the thousands who migrated to the United States, lived there for a while and became shoppers at warehouse clubs before returning to Mexico. "For these people, Sam's Club and Price Club give the sensation that they are shopping again in the United States," said Homero Aridjis, a historian and novelist.
The flood of foreign goods pouring into Mexico is not particularly healthy for the economy. It comes at a time when Mexico's exports are insufficient to pay for the new merchandise and Mexicans are borrowing abroad to cover a rising trade deficit. That, in turn, is running up Mexico's foreign debt and putting pressure on the Government for a devaluation of the peso. Such a devaluation would slow the flood of imports by making them more expensive.
"A steep devaluation would undo the warehouse club approach," Mr. Gonzalez Solana said. "It is out of the question for us, and we are not worried that it will happen."
The Price Club here and the Sam's Clubs in Mexico City and Monterrey, are byproducts of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's decision to lift most import restrictions and encourage Mexicans to shop here rather than load up in El Paso and Laredo, Tex., or San Diego. That is still common practice, even for Mexico City residents 15 hours away by car.
But some of the customers crowding into Sam's Club on a recent Saturday afternoon were not so impressed with the prices. They were mostly middle-class families buying a week's or a month's supply of paper towels and toilet paper, soft drinks, soap and other staples.
 
Buying in Bulk
 Maria Teresa Verde de Hernandez and her 26-year-old son, Dr. Gustavo Hernandez, who recently completed his medical training here, were pushing a cart along the aisles formed by merchandise, which in American warehouse fashion was piled on wooden shipping pallets rather than on shelves. Some items were made in Mexico: stepladders, food blenders, irons and frozen foods. But they were invariably of high quality, often manufactured by American companies with low-wage factories here to serve the American market.
"People come here to buy in bulk, which is harder to do in Mexican stores or on the street, where merchandise is more commonly sold in single units," Dr. Hernandez said. Periodically as they shopped, Dr. Hernandez added up on a pocket calculator how much he and his mother were spending. Soon their cart contained several six-packs of imported soap, at nearly 9 pesos, or $3, a six-pack; 20 American-made razor blades for 45 pesos, or $15, and a case of 27 imported one-pint containers of chocolate milk for 34 pesos, or $11.33.
The soap cost only slightly less than Mrs. Verde de Hernandez said she paid at her neighborhood store. Her son said that he had bought razor blades at street stalls for roughly the same price as the Sam's Club store charges. The milk, however, came to the peso equivalent of 42 cents a pint, compared with 67 cents in Mexican stores, where milk is sold one pint at a time. And the quality is more reliable, Dr. Hernandez said.
Still, he added, "the price advantages for many things are greater at Sam's Clubs in the United States than they are here."
Hugo Mendez agrees. He and his family are the sort of customer that Sam's Club and Price Club really seek. The Mendez family has a small store that sells clothing, televisions and various electronic products. There are tens of thousands of stores like theirs in Mexico, and Sam's Club and Price Club want to supply them with goods to sell.
"Our primary goal is not to sell to high-income consumers but to be wholesalers to small businesses, to mom-and-pop shops and street merchants who cart off their purchases in a van or a pickup truck," Mr. Perez said, outlining a strategy that mirrors a Sam's Club approach in America. High-volume buyers, then, take priority over high-income shoppers, even if in Mexico that means extending membership and credit to illegal kiosk operators and street vendors.
"They have to show us to become a member that they have a business tax identification number, but that does not mean that they pay taxes," Mr. Perez said.
He added that most of the more than 100,000 Sam's Club members were merchants. Whether they are operating legally or in the informal economy is not an important distinction nor much of a moral issue in a nation that relies heavily on the informal market to provide jobs and incomes for millions of Mexicans.
 
Stress Mexican Links
 Price Club operates similarly and says it has a similar membership. Both also try to emphasize their Mexican connection. Sam's Club, for example, promotes itself as Club Aurrera here, a well-known trade name of Wal-Mart's Mexican partner, a company called Cifra that owns supermarkets and merchandise stores.
For shoppers like Mr. Mendez, Club Aurrera offers a flatbed cart big enough to haul two washing machines to the checkout counter, or an air compressor for an auto shop, or a pile of imported sports shirts or a case or two of frozen filet mignon that Sam's Club promotes to restaurants.
Mr. Mendez, on a recent afternoon, had not bothered to take a flatbed cart. He had come to compare prices on goods that might be sold at his store, which he runs with his father and brother. He was particularly interested in 21-inch Japanese color televisions that he hoped could be bought at 1,200 pesos, or $400, apiece for resale at 1,800 pesos, or $600. But the lowest Club Aurrera price was 1,358 pesos, or $450.
As an alternative, "We can drive to the Sam's Club in Laredo and buy a 21-inch set for $300 -- 1,000 pesos -- and have a bigger selection to choose from," Mr. Mendez said. "My father and brother and I make the trip every two weeks. We leave in our van at 6 P.M., get there at 8 A.M., shop all day, and drive back that night. Usually we can get through Mexican customs without paying duties or bribes; it depends on our luck."
 
Volume at Wholesale
 While the Government has lifted some import restrictions, it still charges duties, which average 12 percent of the purchase price for most imported goods. With import quotas largely gone, Price Club and Sam's Club can buy merchandise in huge volumes at wholesale prices that even the most agile black marketeers have difficulty matching.
But the American discounters still have to pay import duties, and various domestic taxes, which the informal economy escapes. The warehouse clubs, in turn, avoid the bribes to Government officials and the "rentals" for sidewalk space that drive up costs for street vendors.
As a result, the comparison between the big warehouse stores and the informal vendors is nearly a wash. For example, the 21-inch Japanese television at Sam's for 1,358 pesos, or $453, sells for 1,300 pesos, or $433, at a sidewalk kiosk, but without a warranty. At a higher end are the neighborhood stores like that owned by the Mendez family, which would try to sell the same television, with a warranty, for 1,800 pesos, or $600.
The big losers are the department and specialty stores and some of the Mexican factories that supply them -- stores like Al Progreso, which sells party dresses and bolts of fine silk, without much competition from the informal economy or the American warehouse clubs. But Al Progreso also carries a large stock of men's wool sweaters, made in Mexico, for 109 pesos, or $36.
Sam's Club "offers the same sweater, imported, for 79 pesos, or $26," said Julio Cesar Hernandez, an Al Progreso manager. "They buy big quantities in Hong Kong, Uruguay and Argentina. There used to be 20 factories making sweaters like these, and now there are 3 or 4."

HEADLINE: Review/Photography;
Flinty Perspectives On Urban Architecture

BYLINE: By CHARLES HAGEN

 BODY:
The German artist Thomas Struth casts a cold eye on urban architecture in his steely black-and-white photographs. Like his teachers Bernhard and Hilla Becher, Mr. Struth, who lives in Dusseldorf, uses a stark and rigorous style that underscores the seeming objectivity of his pictures. In earlier works, Mr. Struth recorded buildings and public spaces in cities ranging from Tokyo to New York to Rome; in his current show, he depicts similar scenes in cities of what was once East Germany, including Leipzig, Gotha, Weimar and Wittenberg.
Mr. Struth's precise pictures have an almost archeological sense of detachment, allowing viewers to read the history and character of a building or street, and by extension of the people who live in it, from the details of its style and physical condition. The buildings Mr. Struth photographs are for the most part undistinguished, important not as examples of fine architecture but as cultural artifacts. 
 In any given situation Mr. Struth tends to photograph from the most obvious viewpoint, whether directly in front of a building or looking down the center of a street, avoiding expressive angles or lighting. Three of the photographs here are in color, but they are as drab and dreary as the black and whites. Devoid of people, his pictures turn the streets and buildings into ghostly replicas of themselves, like film sets exact in every detail.
Much of the history of modern Germany can be read in the crumbling faces of these buildings. Some prints, showing tile-roofed houses crowding narrow cobblestoned streets, seem at first like postcards of a cheery Germany before World War II. But closer examination shows the buildings to be grimy, decrepit, with sections of brick visible beneath decaying stucco, and rubble piled up on the sidewalks. Bullet holes in the facade of an ornate building in Berlin testify to war damage left unrepaired since 1945.
Even the few new buildings, like an ugly gray housing block in Leipzig, are depressing. Other reminders of the former Communist regime can be found in the boxy Trabants, the foul-smelling cars manufactured under the old regime, that line virtually every street. But clustered on the rooftops of even the most deteriorated buildings are the television antennas that indicate the arrival of the consumer society of the West.
Mr. Struth's dispassionate photographs revive a 19th-century notion of photography as a neutral record-making medium, and they have about them an equally old-fashioned sense of anonymous craftsmanship. The pictures recall the photographs that Charles Marville took in the 1860's to record Paris streets and back alleys about to be obliterated by Baron Georges Haussmann's urban renewal projects. They also suggest Eugene Atget's photographs of the empty streets and courtyards of Paris, taken in the early years of this century.
Other photographers, notably Walker Evans and Berenice Abbott in the 1930's, have treated vernacular architecture as a mirror of a society. In the 1970's, Lewis Baltz produced a powerful series of pictures of the blandly streamlined warehouses and office buildings of industrial parks in Southern California. (Mr. Baltz's current work, night shots of European cities, is on view at the Janet Borden Gallery, 560 Broadway, near Prince Street, in SoHo, through March 20.)
In turning his camera to the cities of eastern Germany, Mr. Struth gives his pictures a topical edge. His earlier photographs of Tokyo, New York, Paris or elsewhere seemed somewhat theoretical in their cool analysis of urban growth. At times his pictures of skyscrapers and office buildings, with their pristine, geometric facades, took on an eerie, almost Surrealistic quality.
Here, though, his photographs offer a much more pointed critique of the East German regime, and in doing so move closer to the traditional concerns and methods of documentary photography. Despite this, Mr. Struth provides no information about each scene other than a vague address.
This unwillingness to expand upon the suggestions of meaning provided by the photographs may reflect the fact that for both theoretical and practical reasons, many German art photographers want to distinguish their work from photojournalism. But the lack of information here is frustrating, and undercuts the value of the pictures as records.
Mr. Struth has tried to apply his stolid style to other themes. Examples of his portraits of families and shots of museum visitors clustered in front of artworks can be seen in "Photography in Contemporary German Art: 1960 to the Present," at the Guggenheim Museum in SoHo through May 9.
But his attempts to depict other subjects have none of the fascination of his architectural photographs. In them he revives a powerful function of photography, using it to frame seemingly unremarkable sections of the everyday world and allowing viewers to pore over them at length. Buildings and streets are made to speak, to tell tales of both the past and the present.
The photographs of Thomas Struth remain at the Marian Goodman Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, Manhattan, through March 20.

GRAPHIC: Photo:"Erich Ferl Strasse, Leipzig," by Thomas Struth, at Marian Goodman.(Marian Goodman Gallery)

HEADLINE: Restaurants;
In Morningside Heights, quality outrides many changes.

BYLINE: By Bryan Miller

 BODY:
The Terrace restaurant, high above 119th Street at Columbia University in Morningside Heights, seemed a likely victim for the harsh recent recession. It is a long cab ride from midtown Manhattan and is in a less than glamorous neighborhood, yet its prices are relatively steep. The Terrace survived, though, and much credit is due to Nada Bernic, the owner, and her team.
The Terrace has seen many changes in the last decade. Dusan Bernic, the chef and Mrs. Bernic's husband, died in 1984, leaving the restaurant's future in doubt. Since then, Mrs. Bernic has recruited a succession of able young chefs who have managed to maintain the restaurant's quality. 
 The latest is a Cairo native, Ossama Mickail, who trained in Switzerland and later worked for Alain Senderens, the owner of Lucas-Carton in Paris. Mr. Mickail combines a solid sense of classic French cuisine with a sunny touch of the Mediterranean. His inventive fusions do not always make sparks, but when they succeed a fine meal can be had.
The Terrace remains one of the most romantic settings in New York City. The window-wrapped dining room on the roof of Butler Hall at Columbia affords sweeping views of the city and beyond. The candlelit rooms, with a rose on each table and a harpist entertaining nightly, are comfortable and soothing. As might be expected, this is a popular spot for birthdays, anniversaries and graduation celebrations at Columbia. In nice weather, a rooftop terrace is open for drinks and appetizers.
One of the chef's more compelling starters is a warm potato napoleon with crab meat and mint. The pristine, sweet crab meat is a winner on its own, even better under a roof made with a homemade potato chip, all ringed with a white-wine sauce and fresh mint. A revisionist ravioli is delicate and fresh, too: a thin sheet of pasta draped over deliciously herbed sauteed shrimp, ringed with a coulis of red and yellow tomatoes. A mosaic of marinated salmon and yellowfin tuna is a nice idea, but it was marred by mixed greens that were saturated with raspberry vinegar. And a starter called sesame-scented pasta with caramelized pearl onions and arugula sounded appealing, but it was served at room temperature, which left it tasting like leftovers.
You can't go wrong with the luxurious and expensive ($18) sauteed foie gras of duck with wild mushrooms and a thyme-accented duck juice, or with the pleasing seared roulade of smoked salmon and goat cheese enlivened with herbed olive oil.
Captains and waiters at the Terrace are likable fellows, amiable and enthusiastic, but they will never win a gold medal in the 50-yard dash. I have bought an automobile in less time than it took to get a bottle of wine -- and the wrong bottle, to boot. And little things like getting the check can make the lines in a Department of Motor Vehicles office seem speedy. The Terrace has beefed up its wine list noticeably in recent years, with a large stock of Bordeaux, a respectable and eclectic California roster and smatterings from around the world (except Italy). Markups are average to high.
Best choices among main courses are lusty winter specialties like succulent veal medallions paired with buttery duck confit under crumpled phyllo dough, all in a woodsy morel sauce. Also satisfying is roast poussin, or baby chicken, moistened with herb butter and ringed by whole garlic cloves, potatoes and carrots. The menu silliness starts with combinations like gamy and tender venison combined with a potato basket holding dryish roast quail camouflaged by sprigs of fresh herbs. A cloying venison stock sauce sweetened with peach schnapps did not help.
Journalistic curiosity compelled me to order a dish called mille-feuille of lobster with butternut squash, truffle vinaigrette, mango and ginger oil. In fairness, it was not quite so scary as it sounded: the mango was mostly ornamental, and the ginger oil was subtle. But it still was not something to search out.
One would do much better with the perfectly cooked rack of lamb with shredded lamb confit on the side, or breast of Muscovy duck with a smoked duck wing on the side and a good red-wine sauce sweetened with figs. Mr. Mickail has toyed with the house signature dish, called red snapper Adriatic style. Under the previous chef, it was a garlicky fillet of red snapper garnished with deep-fried parsley and surrounded by Provencal-style vegetables. The new version, a change to be sure but not necessarily for the better, combines the sauteed fish with a puree of sweet peas and potatoes, with fried celery on the side.
A good selection of Cognacs and brandies is available with dessert. Among the best sweets are a light-crusted mixed fruit tart with raspberry sauce, a fluffy napoleon of puff pastry and berries with whipped cream, and tarte Tatin with hazelnut ice cream. Chocolate mocha rum cake is rich and moist but hardly intoxicating with rum.
The Terrace still offers considerable beguilements, not the least of which is the dining room's elevation. As for the food, it can still entice, but overall at a lower altitude than before.
The Terrace
*
400 West 119th Street, Morningside Heights, (212) 666-9490.
Atmosphere: Romantic candlelit room with sweeping views of the city and beyond.
Service: Staff is good-natured and eager but occasionally slow.
Recommended dishes: Potato napoleon with crab meat and mint, ravioli of shrimp with tomato coulis, seared roulade of smoked salmon with goat cheese, veal medallions with duck confit, roast baby chicken with herb butter and garlic, rack of lamb, Muscovy duck breast with red wine sauce and figs, fruit tart, napoleon of berries, tarte Tatin.
Wine: Large international list particularly strong in Bordeaux, average to high markups.
Price range: Lunch: prix fixe, $25; a la carte appetizers $6 to $9.50, main courses $10.50 to $15.50; dinner: appetizers $9 to $18, main courses $20 to $27.
Credit cards: All major cards.
Hours: Lunch: noon to 2:30 P.M. Tuesdays through Fridays; dinner: 6 to 9:30 P.M. Tuesdays through Fridays, until 10 P.M. Saturdays.
Wheelchair accessibility: Elevator to 16th floor; ramp for three steps at entrance is available if you call ahead. Restrooms are not wide enough for wheelchairs.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
SIEMENS WANTS TO EXPAND IN SOUTHEAST ASIA

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The German electronics and telecommunications group Siemens A.G. wants to expand in Southeast Asia, its chief executive, Heinrich von Pierer, said yesterday. 
 Mr. von Pierer said at the company's annual meeting that trade in the United States, Western Europe and Japan was "no longer sufficient," and most opportunities were likely to arise from increased infrastructure investment as the economies of Southeast Asia develop. Mr. von Pierer also told the stockholders that he expected the company's unprofitable computer unit, Siemens Nixdorf, to break even within three years.

HEADLINE: The Korean Peninsula Heats Up

 BODY:
North Korea has just announced that it is backing out of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. This follows its decision on Tuesday to put its army on alert in reaction to the Team Spirit exercises conducted by U.S. and South Korean forces. Pyongyang is understandably provoked by the resumption of the exercises after a year's hiatus, but withdrawing from the nonproliferation treaty is an exceedingly unwise act that will arouse the worse suspicions about Pyongyang's nuclear intentions.
The North Koreans had sought talks with the U.S. to resolve differences. The Clinton Administration could use such talks to urge Pyongyang to open up access to International Atomic Energy Agency inspectors. 
 North Korea has refused to allow I.A.E.A. inspectors into its nuclear waste sites. By examining the North's reactors and waste, they could clear up any discrepancy between what Pyongyang told the I.A.E.A. about the operation of its reactors and what the agency discovered in recent inspections. Such inspections would help the agency determine how much plutonium the North could have produced -- and whether it was enough for bomb-making.
The Team Spirit exercises are not needed to reassure Seoul of Washington's rock-solid commitment to its defense. Military hard-liners in the previous Government in the South, eager to maintain their power and position, had sought the exercises as part of their strategy of isolating the North. Washington, unwilling to cast doubt on its security ties to Seoul, went along.
But Seoul's new civilian Government shows signs of breaking with the past. Moreover, the U.S. could defer participation in future exercises and encourage North and South Korea to scale down any exercises they may hold -- a useful step in building mutual confidence.
But Pyongyang's pullout from the nonproliferation treaty raises the nuclear nightmare anew and will surely lead to its further political and economic isolation. Bilateral talks between Washington and Pyongyang could break the current impasse and cool off the hotheads in both Koreas.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: For New York City and State, the Arts Are Bread and Butter

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Museums, music, dance and theater are merely frills in New York City. Welfare, health care, education and other social needs are essential, and require vast sums of money. So appropriations for the New York State Council on the Arts must again be cut. Right?
Wrong! We can only amass the resources for social purposes through our tax base. To get those taxes we must have people living in, working in and visiting our city. 
 New Yorkers remain here because the city and state offer amenities that make life in a difficult city more bearable -- the best in music and dance, marvelous museums, wide-ranging new and classical theater. Diminish these assets and what have you got? Fewer and fewer residents, businesses and visitors to bear the social costs.
The arts are not just for the elite. Millions of adults and children of all ethnic groups and economic status participate and benefit. Serious cutbacks in arts education make it more essential than ever that arts organizations fill the void.
In New York City, art and culture alone constitute a megaindustry -- more than $8 billion annually, conservatively estimated. Arts and tourism combined constitute one of the largest generators of tax revenues, some $2.5 billion in direct city, state and Federal tax receipts.
Nevertheless, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposed budget for fiscal year 1993-94 recommends that the appropriation for the State Council on the Arts be subjected to an additional cut of 13 percent for local assistance for New York and other cities. The proposed allocation is only $20.4 million for local areas and state operations, compared with almost $55 million in the 1989-90 budget -- an aggregate cut of 62.7 percent in three years!
Cuts in the arts also mean increased unemployment and reduced job opportunities for the unskilled and semi-skilled workers in hotels, restaurants and retail facilities. It is a disturbing prospect coming when President Clinton is challenging all Americans to create new employment initiatives.
For decades, New York State was first in financing the arts. Today, we have dropped to 10th in per capita expenditures. This trend augurs the accelerated flight of creativity, skills and jobs to other sectors of the country. It must be reversed.
The New York Convention and Visitors Bureau has had modest increases in funds to protect tourism. But what will the tourists experience? Reduced hours for galleries and museums? Shuttered performing arts organizations? Darkened theaters? Fewer concerts? Less dance? Less music? A dearth of programs for our children?
Governor Cuomo and the Legislature can advance the state's economy -- now and for the future -- by appropriating funds to the Council on the Arts that approximate 1989 levels. The arts are bread and butter in New York.
 
MARTIN E. SEGAL
New York, March 3, 1993
The writer is chairman emeritus, Lincoln Center for Performing Arts.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
Rubbernecking: Analyzing a Commuter Psychosis

BYLINE: By John Tierney

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
IT has been three decades since Fred Feldman introduced the term "rubbernecking delay" to commuters, and he can see that a little progress has been made against this scourge. Engineers have analyzed it. The police have attacked it. Economists have begun to reveal its costs to society -- about the same order of magnitude as the property damage from the bomb at the World Trade Center.
But so much remains unknown and unconquered. At certain moments, such as when he is monitoring rush hour from the Transcom regional traffic headquarters here, Mr. Feldman wonders if the situation is really any better than it was during his days in the WCBS Radio traffic helicopter. He began in 1962 as the first traffic reporter in New York, and he did not like what he saw. 
 "I noticed it right away," he recalled. "It's so clear when you're airborne. It looks crazy. You're flying toward the West Side Highway, you see traffic backed up four miles, and your eyeballs start going to see where the accident is. Then you get closer and closer and you say, 'God, I don't believe it.' All the lanes are open, but right next to the highway in Riverside Park there's a guy and a gal lying on a blanket necking."
Mr. Feldman would try appealing to drivers. "I'd say, 'If you've never seen two people making out on a blanket, be sure to slow down and take a look. But if you have, try to keep moving, because you're slowing down a million people behind you.' It never did any good."
This was not, of course, an entirely new phenomenon. Hannibal probably got impatient when Alpine vistas distracted the elephants up ahead. The problem was specifically documented in pre-freeway America by the country singer Mel McDaniel, whose lament about a traffic jam on Main Street featured the refrain: "They turn their heads and they watch her till she's gone / Lord have mercy, baby's got her blue jeans on."
But it was not until the age of expressways that the phenomenon received serious analysis. It has acquired several names: "gaper block" in Philadelphia, "curiosity delay" in Boston, congestion from "Lookie Lous" in Los Angeles. The most popular word nationwide is rubbernecking, a bit of slang from the turn of the century that Mr. Feldman began using about 30 years ago.
Some of his fellow trafficologists -- as Mr. Feldman likes to call them -- credit him with first applying the word to traffic jams, but he is modestly cautious. "I can't remember how I came up with rubbernecking delays," he said. "Maybe I was the first, or maybe I borrowed it from somewhere. I guess you could say I was the first to start using it on the radio in New York."
In the technical literature, "gawker delay" is classified as a significant part of "incident congestion" -- an overall problem, according to the Federal Highway Administration, that annually causes 1.3 billion "vehicle-hours of lost time" on urban freeways at a cost of $10 billion. An incident can be a disabled car on the shoulder, an accident, or an eight-story balloon of King Kong atop the Empire State Building, which in 1983 created an interstate rubbernecking incident by slowing down traffic in New Jersey.
To reduce rubbernecking, traffic engineers have pleaded with police officers to turn off the flashing light when parked on the shoulder. They've forced construction crews to put up plywood walls around work areas, and they've gotten the police in Los Angeles to put up experimental plastic screens around the scenes of accidents.
Above all, engineers have called for "incident management," which involves clearing the scene as quickly as possible. Every minute counts: a study in Los Angeles showed that even when an accident is cleared in 10 minutes, it takes another 40 minutes of "bleed-off time" for traffic to resume normal speed, which accounts for all those mysterious tie-ups with no discernible causes.
Mr. Feldman, who gave up helicopter reporting in 1978, is now heavily into incident management. At age 59, he is the manager of special projects at Transcom, a consortium of 15 local public agencies that monitors traffic and coordinates police responses throughout the New York area.
He remains passionate in his hope for better traffic -- he loves to preach what he calls "The Golden Rules of Traffic" (e.g., "Learn your alternate routes!"). But he is not optimistic about rubbernecking.
"Look at this," he said, flicking a slide on the screen in the Transcom control room. "This is the Bruckner Expressway in the Bronx. You have all lanes open southbound. Bumper to bumper. They're all looking at this car fire on the other side. You go past the scene and look at that spacing -- 10, 20 car lengths. Nothing wrong. No lanes closed. Strictly rubbernecking."
He threw up his hands. "People are people. Even when a guy knows that rubbernecking made him sit for half an hour in traffic, when he gets up to the scene he'll be damned if he's not going to take a look himself. No matter what you say, a well-proportioned woman jogging next to the Cross Island Parkway in rush hour will back up traffic for a mile. What are you going to do about it? You tell me."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 13, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
The Our Towns column yesterday, about rubbernecking, referred incorrectly to Fred Feldman, a former traffic reporter. He worked for radio station WOR, not WCBS.

HEADLINE: How to Get Ready For Retirement: Save, Save, Save

BYLINE: By DEBORAH M. RANKIN

 BODY:
They took early retirement last year and now split their time between their comfortable home on the southwest Florida coast and cruising on their spacious boat. He is 60, she is 55. Did they do it through inherited wealth? A megabucks career in investment banking? A lottery ticket?
None of the above. The experience of this couple, who agreed to discuss their finances if their names were not published, is simply an object lesson in the rewards of a disciplined savings program. He had a second career after the military in state government and she had her own practice as a clinical social worker in the Washington area. 
 At the peak of their careers, their total income was about $110,000 (including his military pension) and they managed to save at least 30 percent a year of that. His three children were almost grown when they married 21 years ago. By restraining their spending and squirreling away every penny they could for the last seven years, the couple amassed an investment portfolio that now exceeds $800,000, including about $100,000 in proceeds from the sale of their former home.
It's not that they were phenomenal stock pickers who found a few lucky investments, but rather that they followed the time-honored rule of saving religiously and spreading their money among many different types of investments, said their financial planner, Norma M. Severns of Armstrong, Welch & MacIntyre in Washington.
"Their portfolio grew by a bit over 10 percent on average, which was good but not astounding," she said. "Even though the numbers in their portfolio look surprising, they are really not huge and reflect our clients' ability to stick with a conservative, middle-of-the-road asset allocation program."
The retirees are unusual in their ability -- contrary to that of most Americans -- to control their spending. "Our country's modest savings rate, which was about 4 1/2 percent of take-home pay in the fourth quarter of 1992, is a permanent fixture on the landscape," said Irwin Kellner, chief economist of the Chemical Bank. "We are a buy-now, pay-later society."
Although the nation's savings rate has bounced around over the last three decades, reaching a high of more than 10 percent in 1974 and then plummeting to about 2 1/4 percent in 1987, it is currently close to the historical norm. "While 4 1/2 percent is low compared to countries such as Germany, where thrift is a national virtue, and Japan, where tax policy encourages savings, it is not low in reference to our own history," Mr. Kellner said.
But for most individuals, it is almost certainly too low for the future. People who expect to retire in the next decade or beyond will probably have to rely much more on their own savings than did their parents, because of the likelihood that Social Security and other government benefit programs will not be as generous.
Indeed, Merrill Lynch recently released a study showing that the oldest baby boomers -- those born between 1946 and 1956 -- will need to triple their savings rate in order to maintain their standard of living after they turn 65. These aging boomers will need to save as much as 19 percent of their after-tax income in order to retire in style, according to the study.
Such thrift does seem daunting, but the Florida couple took advantage of every opportunity to salt away money for the future.
"We never really lived at as high a level as we could afford," the husband recalled. "Our last three cars each had more than 150,000 miles on them. We didn't get the most expensive house we could afford and didn't buy a lot of furniture. Our boat was the focus of our recreational activities, and it cost a fair amount to maintain, so we didn't go to the theater or out to eat a lot."
Though it may seem impossible for other families to save as much as these retirees, particularly families that are raising children, their story has some lessons for everyone.
One piece of advice is to have a dream and make it as specific as possible. "My husband wanted to stop working at age 55 and spend his retirement boating for as long as I can recall," the wife said. Regardless of whether your goal is to come up with a down payment for your first house, or college tuition for your first child, try to attach dates and dollar amounts to those targets so you know exactly what you're aiming at.
Another rule is to pay yourself first. Use whatever means possible to remove a set amount of money from your bank account each month before you have a chance to spend it.
Many companies have payroll deduction plans that withhold as little as $25 from your salary each month and invest it in Series EE savings bonds. Many mutual fund families sponsor programs that automatically transfer a set amount -- usually at least $25 a month -- from your bank account to one of their funds. The idea is to view personal savings obligations just like any other monthly bill.
Make use of employer-sponsored retirement savings programs like 401(k) plans. This involves deferring a portion of your pretax salary and contributing it to stock, bond or money market funds in the plan.
Not only do these contributions lower your current taxable income, but the earnings on those contributions accumulate tax-free until they are withdrawn, typically at retirement. Some companies will match contributions up to a certain level.
"Most people will discharge their obligations religiously," said Michael Stolper, president of a San Diego investment management firm that evaluates money managers for wealthy individuals. "The trick is to never, ever just have that money just sitting in the bank," where it's available for nonessential purposes.

HEADLINE: Mr. Yeltsin, Surrounded Again

 BODY:
Nineteen months ago, old-guard Communists tried to halt political and economic reform in what was then the Soviet Union by surrounding Boris Yeltsin with tanks. Now the old guard in Russia's Congress seeks to achieve the same objective by hemming in President Yeltsin with constitutional restraints that would leave him a figurehead.
Despite years of political upheaval, Russia's Soviet-era Constitution still survives. By insisting on strict enforcement of that now-obsolescent document, Congress declares itself, not the President, the ruling authority. 
 Mr. Yeltsin, the man who stood up to the tanks, isn't taking this constitutional power play lying down. He's preparing to take his case directly to the people with a referendum on whether the President or Congress should rule.
America's interest lies squarely with Mr. Yeltsin.
The Clinton Administration seems to grasp that interest well enough, declaring its full support for Mr. Yeltsin so long as he does not resort to military force.
But some critics now argue that Washington is too rashly betting the bank on one individual, just as it earlier seemed to stake all on Mikhail Gorbachev. Reducing foreign policy to personalities is indeed risky. But in today's Russia, there's no other sensible choice.
The Congress of People's Deputies was elected under the old regime and has a stake in preserving its power and privilege as long as possible. Mr. Yeltsin symbolizes resistance to the August 1991 coup. Crucially, he is the only figure with a clear democratic mandate from the whole of Russia. Despite the painful adjustments of economic reform, he remains a far more popular figure than his Congress opponents. Hence his willingness to go to the people in a referendum.
A succession of ad hoc agreements has allowed Mr. Yeltsin to proceed, more or less, with his reform agenda. Now the Congress insists on repudiating those power-sharing agreements and returning to the letter of the old Soviet law.
A referendum that defies Congress is fraught with dangers. There's talk in Moscow of Mr. Yeltsin declaring emergency rule, perhaps in league with army generals. And there's counter-talk of regional administrators teaming up with Congress to prevent the referendum.
All this would obviously disrupt the evolution of democratic institutions. But to insist on the Soviet-era Constitution would choke off that evolution -- and reform -- completely.
President Clinton scheduled the summit meeting on April 3 and 4 to give Mr. Yeltsin a boost before the referendum, which was originally to be April 11. Washington has also been trying to speed up new aid to meet Russia's immediate political needs -- like unemployment insurance, retraining ex-army officers and credit for small farmers. These need to be kept separate from longer-term efforts linked to progress in economic reform.
But events now seem to be moving more swiftly than the Clinton fast-track timetable envisioned. By offering tangible support immediately, he and other Western leaders can bolster President Yeltsin's position at a perilous pass in Russian history.

HEADLINE: India Must Put the Old Hates Aside to Survive

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "India's Days of Rage" (Op-Ed, Feb. 27), Vibhuti Patel touchingly expresses her sorrow at the latest and most vicious communal riots in India. The juxtaposition of her family's close brush with the ugly religious fanaticism (a better term than fundamentalism in this case) and her distance from it as a United States resident may not be typical. But many of us who have made our homes in this country are affected by the same sense of loss of our dream for a genuinely secular India. What is even more painful is that not all Indians there or abroad share our distress. 
 It may not be enough to trace the rise of anti-Muslim feelings solely to the machinations of the political parties, old and new, that have manipulated the masses to gain votes and power. A strong case can be made for the allure of religious fervor in a society undergoing rapid transformation. The consumerist culture that is the driving force of economic growth in India is at odds with its traditional values of communitarianism, catholicism and common decency. The collision of growth and values has created tensions among India's, people who are irrationally turning backward.
In conversations with other Indians, I hear over and over again of the long history of Hindu-Muslim relations, in which Hindus were often the victims. Recent cases of wanton attacks against tiny Hindu minorities in Pakistan and Bangladesh, which have not received much coverage in the Western newspapers, only exacerbate the tendency to make the past a divisive force for the future.
The division has a powerful hold not just over the masses, but the professional classes as well. Unless Hindus and Muslims resolve to create a secular democracy in India combining the traditional with the modern, the recent riots may be only the beginning. From the discord over religion throughout the world, it is hard to be optimistic.
 
SUMITRA SHAH
Rego Park, Queens, Feb. 28, 1993

HEADLINE: India Must Put the Old Hates Aside to Survive;
Fundamentalist Peril

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"India at the Edge" (editorial, Feb. 24) raises legitimate concerns about the impact of Hindu fundamentalism on the world's largest democracy. The Bharatiya Janata Party's attempt to turn India into a Hindu state, if it succeeded, would backfire. 
 Muslims, Sikhs, Buddhists and Christians (India has the world's second largest Presbyterian population) would demand their right to worship, which must be granted as the most basic democratic principle. If it were denied, there would be reciprocal resistance, which could result in violence as in the weeks that followed the destruction of the Ayodhya mosque last December.
Turmoil and upheaval could destroy the confidence of foreign investors who went to India after Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao began an ambitious reform program. This program has moved India's economy from statist dependency on the Soviet Union toward privatization and long-term growth. Despite problems, the results have been commendable.
The United States has remained India's largest trading partner and its largest single investment source. In the last year, Du Pont, Ford, General Electric, I.B.M., Kellogg's, Raytheon and others have invested hundreds of millions of dollars in response to Prime Minister Rao's reforms. India's middle-class market of 200 million people adds a lot of interest to the international business climate. If reform continues, long-term mutual benefit will be enormous.
However, ethnic and religious extremism could bring down hopes for a democratically stable and economically growing South Asia, two of the United States policy objectives in the region. As for India, a departure from a long and admirable tradition of democracy and secularism would be political suicide.
 
SICHAN SIV
Washington, Feb. 27, 1993
 
The writer served in the Bush Administration as Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for South Asian affairs.

HEADLINE: Shakespeare Festival Dismisses Papp's Heir

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER

 BODY:
JoAnne Akalaitis, Joseph Papp's hand-picked successor as head of the New York Shakespeare Festival, has been asked to resign by the executive committee of the Festival's board. The action effectively ends her troubled 20-month reign as artistic director of one of the nation's most important nonprofit cultural institutions and its flagship, the Public Theater.
The 11-member committee has offered Ms. Akalaitis's post, with a new title of producer, to George C. Wolfe, the director and playwright who is best known for writing and staging the Broadway musical "Jelly's Last Jam." Committee members said that the actor Kevin Kline would also join the management team, though his proposed role was not specified. 
 Mr. Wolfe, should the full board approve his selection, would have complete authority over artistic decisions and management, much in the manner of Papp, the Festival's founder and producer. Under Ms. Akalaitis, Jason Steven Cohen, as producing director, presided over the management and administration of the Festival. Mr. Cohen would remain in his post, reporting to Mr. Wolfe.
 
Decision Was Unanimous
 Larry E. Condon, chairman of the executive committee, said that the 11-member committee decided unanimously on Thursday to recommend removing Ms. Akalaitis, and that the full board would vote on the matter at a meeting on Monday. Among the executive committee's members is Gail Merrifield Papp, Joseph Papp's widow.
Another committee member, Joan K. Davidson, said a preliminary canvassing of board members indicated "enthusiastic support" for dismissing Ms. Akalaitis and hiring Mr. Wolfe, who is currently preparing to stage the much-anticipated Broadway premiere of Tony Kushner's "Angels in America."
In an interview yesterday, Ms. Akalaitis said, "The board is having the meeting to fire me," adding that she had learned of the executive committee's recommendation from Mr. Condon on Thursday when she arrived at his office for a regularly scheduled business meeting. The news, she said, was "out of the blue," and she made it clear that she was leaving involuntarily.
"I want to say that I'm not resigning," she said. "I have been fired, or some verb like that. I think that's the verb."
Ms. Akalaitis, 55, has been the artistic director at the Festival since August 1991, when Papp, just before his death, picked her to succeed him. Though a theater director of acknowledged gifts, Ms. Akalaitis was widely seen throughout her tenure as lacking in the personal forcefulness and charisma that Papp used, over the course of 37 years, to forge the reputation of the Shakespeare Festival.
A tireless advocate and fund raiser for the Festival, as well as an ardent impresario with a populist artistic vision, Papp did the jobs it later took two people -- Ms. Akalaitis and Mr. Cohen -- to carry out. The Public Theater was renamed last year for Papp, and Ms. Akalaitis never really escaped from his shadow.
"It was a near impossible spot to move into," said Bernard Gersten, the executive producer of Lincoln Center Theater and a supporter of Ms. Akalaitis. "The New York Shakespeare Festival was made in Joe's image. The festival was Joe; Joe was the Festival."
 
Inherited Problems
 A declining economy and an erosion of charitable support, which plagued the last years of Papp's reign, hampered Ms. Akalaitis as well. The Festival's annual budget has been cut by more than one-third over the last three years, from $15 million to under $10 million, and the staff cut in half, to from 120 to 60.
Still, she was criticized on many fronts, with complaints ranging from her aloof, occasionally abrasive manner to her disdain for the fund-raising function of her position. She was also taken to task for her predilection for grim, arcane projects that many felt alienated the audience built up by Papp, and for not generating enough work to keep the five theaters at the Public busy.
Though films, lectures, readings and a new coffee bar in the lobby often keep the place occupied, there have been only 10 subscription offerings this season. Of those, only one, "Woyzeck" -- Georg Buchner's dark 19th-century drama, directed by Ms. Akalaitis -- was a full-length multi-character play whose production originated at the Shakespeare Festival. "Woyzeck," like Ms. Akalaitis's production last season of John Ford's Elizabethan drama " 'Tis Pity She's a Whore," got many positive reviews, but the moderate critical success could not offset the other problems Ms. Akalaitis faced.
"It was a mixture of things," said Ms. Davidson, when asked why the executive committee was dissatisfied with Ms. Akalaitis. "We became increasingly concerned that things were not working, largely because of the bifurcated leadership we had. It was a mess, frankly. Tensions were developing throughout the organization." She added that it was felt not enough work was being produced and that the work itself was not varied enough.
"I like Joanne a lot and respect her as an artist," Ms. Davidson said. "But I think there's a difference between being a talented director and a producer. We want the place to be hopping with all kinds of energy and activity, the way it was in Joe's glory days. We have felt a withering in the commitment and devotion of some of our longtime supporters, a lot of people who have been mainstays. We expect them to come bouncing back enthusiastically now."
Ms. Davidson said it was her understanding that if Mr. Kline joined the Festival staff it would be in an advisory position concerning productions of classics, particularly Shakespeare. Mr. Kline, who played Hamlet in a Papp production, could not be reached for comment yesterday.
Ms. Akalaitis said yesterday that she had been under the impression that her relations with the board were good, and spoke sharply in her own defense. "The box office on every show this year has exceeded projections," she said. "We've come in splendidly on production budgets. I was concerned about contributed income, individual and corporate, but I thought the theater was a lively, artistic, social, stimulating place. I was quite proud, and am proud, of the work that was done."
In the 38-year-old Mr. Wolfe, the Festival would be getting an energetic, highly esteemed writer and director, a man who first came to attention in the theater world in 1986 with his play "The Colored Museum," which was performed at the Public Theater. Papp made him a resident director at the Public, where he worked on many projects, including Anna Deavere Smith's acclaimed one-woman show of a year ago, "Fires in the Mirror."
It was his move uptown to Broadway, however, with "Jelly's Last Jam," that propelled him onto producers' A-lists and garnered him the choicest of this season's assignments on Broadway, "Angels in America," the epic play about AIDS and politics, Part 1 of which opens next month.
News of his impending appointment at the Festival provoked a torrent of praise.
"Isn't that great news?" said Margo Lion, a producer of both "Jelly's Last Jam" and "Angels." "He's going to bring that theater into the 90's."
Rocco Landesman, president of Jujamcyn Theaters, said: "George is like Papp, and unlike JoAnne in that he has roots in both the uptown and downtown communities. He's straddled both camps."
 
'Emerging and Emerged'
 And Jason Steven Cohen, who would report to Mr. Wolfe, said: "Clearly in George Wolfe the board has made a choice of the most emerging and emerged writer-director the theatrical scene has to offer. It's so exciting to me that in the discussions I had with the board, I was prepared to step back a bit from my present position."
Reached during rehearsals of "Angels" yesterday, Mr. Wolfe confirmed he'd been spoken to by the executive comittee, and said he would take the job if it was offered by the board.
"The fundamental why is the chance to nurture other artists," he said.
Mr. Wolfe has no producing credits other than two series of performance pieces he has put on at the Public. "My credits are my credits," he said. "I haven't been running a theater company because I've been busy being an artist. If everything comes out to be right, as of Monday at 4 P.M. I'll begin that journey."
