HEADLINE: Defense Chief Lists 31 Big Bases For Closing, and Outcry Is Swift

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today issued its plan to shut scores of military posts, ports and airfields, and lawmakers with bases in their districts lost no time in expressing outrage.
Defense Secretary Les Aspin, contending that base closings have not kept pace with recent troop reductions, recommended shutting 31 big military installations and shrinking or consolidating 134 other depots and smaller operations. 
 With the end of the cold war and subsequent reductions in military budgets and forces, the Administration has begun slashing billions from the armed services' overhead to try to avoid reducing troop strength even more or stopping the modernization of America's arsenal.
Once the Pentagon spends $1.7 billion to close and clean up these installations, it expects to save $3.1 billion a year starting in 2000.
 
Devastation Foreseen
 But the plan has provoked an uproar on Capitol Hill, where lawmakers with bases in their district predicted economic devastation -- even while Congress is pressing President Clinton for deeper cuts in Pentagon spending.
"The mother of all base closure lists clobbers Charleston," said Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, who vowed to save the shipyard and naval station in Charleston and "develop a unified front to keep the Navy in South Carolina."
In the New York area, the plan will eliminate 12,790 military and civilian jobs and could cost the region more than $1 billion in lost wages, contracts and other benefits. [Page 8.]
For members of Congress, however, the outrage is partly political theater. While senators and representatives are likely to join civic groups in marshaling arguments against base closings in their districts, they do not face painful votes on the subject.
The decisions will be made by a Presidential commission set up to insulate Congress from angry constituents. Representatives and senators can curry favor with voters by inveighing against specific base closings while voting for the politically popular principle of military budget cuts that will ultimately force more bases to close.
The eight-member panel headed by former Representative James A. Courter, Republican of New Jersey, will have until July 1 to accept or alter the Administration's recommendations. Its decisions will then go to President Clinton, who will have until Sept. 1 to accept or reject them. If he approves the recommendations, only a negative vote by both houses of Congress can stop the process.
Lawmakers with no bases marked for closing in this round praised the plan and urged their less fortunate colleagues to sacrifice to eliminate obsolete installations and save taxpayers' money.
"While this process is never easy for members of Congress with bases in their districts, the long-term effect is overwhelmingly positive," said Representative Dick Armey, a Texas Republican whose district was spared this year but suffered two years ago when Carswell Air Force Base closed.
The Defense Department proposal includes winners as well as losers. Once some installations are shut or reduced in size, troops and civilian workers will be moved to other sites.
New Jersey would lose 6,500 troops and civilian employees, New York 4,000 and Connecticut 2,200. The Staten Island Home Port, the New London submarine base in Connecticut, and McGuire Air Force Base near Trenton would close or be severely reduced.
California would lose 32,000 military personnel and civilian workers, South Carolina 17,400, Florida 11,500 and Alabama 9,000. The bases listed for closing, including Homestead Air Force Base in Florida, Fort McClellan in Alabama and the Alameda Naval Station in California, are underused, too costly to maintain or no longer meet a long-term military requirement.
 
Some State May Gain
 On the other hand, Illinois would gain 9,000 military and civilian positions, largely by consolidating Navy training centers at San Diego and Orlando, Fla., into a third center near Chicago on Lake Michigan. Missouri would gain 5,800 military personnel or civilian workers, Washington State 5,500, North Carolina 5,300 and Georgia 5,000.
Mr. Clinton has tried to ease the pain of the base closings by offering $15 billion to $20 billion over five years to help hard-hit communities and workers. But that offered little solace to lawmakers.
As fax machines whirred around Washington and lawmakers held dueling news conferences across the country, California's Congressional delegation, already reeling from the effects of 17 bases that are being closed as a result of two previous cutbacks and a sagging military industry, issued a call to arms.
"We've just begun to fight," said Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California.
 
Lobbying to Little Effect
 So far the lobbying by lawmakers and civic leaders this week had little effect on Mr. Aspin's decisions. The Defense Secretary spared only two military installations, both in California, that had been on the armed services' list of those that should close: McClellan Air Force Base near Sacramento and the Monterey Presidio, home of the Defense Language Institute.
Republicans immediately accused the Administration of partisan politics in reprieving the two California sites.
The Presidio is in the district formerly represented by Mr. Clinton's budget director, Leon E. Panetta. McClellan air base and depot is in the district of Representative Vic Fazio, who, as chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, helps find financing for his colleagues' re-election campaigns.
"It's unconscionable to have politicized the process in this fashion," Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican on the Armed Services Committee, told the Associated Press.
 
Political Motives Denied
 Pentagon officials said politics had played no part in sparing the two installations. American intelligence agencies objected to closing the Defense Language Institute, and contracting for classes at universities, Pentagon officials said.
Closing McClellan, which employs more than 15,000 civilian workers, would hurt the local economy too much, Defense Department officials said.
While lawmakers will not have an opportunity to vote on individual base closings, they can try to alter the decisions by joining the civic groups that have begun lining up to lobby the Presidential commission that was set up to review the recommendations.
Mr. Aspin and Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, will testify in support of the Pentagon plan at the commission's first hearing on Monday.
Versatility helped some bases survive. The Air Force, for example, had more large bomber bases than it needed with a shrinking fleet of aircraft. Minot Air Force Base and Grand Forks Air Force Base in North Dakota have Minuteman-3 long-range nuclear missiles as well as bombers, and were thus ranked more important that bases that are listed for closing like K. I. Sawyer in Michigan, which has only B-52's.
In other cases, the military plans to close parts of some bases. The Army, for instance, aims to shut all of Fort McClellan in Alabama, except for an enclave for Army reservists and buildings to keep open the Army's only live-agent chemical training center.
Few surprises appeared on the list as the names of many targets became became known within the last week. In fact, the biggest surprises were bases identified in news reports for closing that turned out never to have been among the recommendations to Mr. Aspin.
Several Pentagon officials had suggested, for example, that the Long Beach Naval Shipyard in California was on the list, but it never was. Long Beach residents, girding for the worst today, were jubilant. Fort Totten and Fort Hamilton in New York, which were also identified to be reduced in some reports, were not on the original Army list.
In a letter accompanying his report, Mr. Aspin warned that this round would bring the military bases and ports only in line with the last budget and troop cuts made by the Bush Administration.
Mr. Clinton has pledged to reduce the military by 200,000 more troops than Mr. Bush by 1997, and Mr. Aspin said he was confident that the future "will require more, not fewer, base closures than those I will recommend at this time."

HEADLINE: Stocks Sink on Worries On Inflation and Russia

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Stock prices fell sharply yesterday for the second straight session as investors used signs of higher inflation and rising political instability in Russia as a reason to take profits after the market's recent surge.
The selling began early: computer-driven program trades were executed soon after the Labor Department reported that producer prices posted their biggest monthly increase in more than two years in February. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 50 points in the first half-hour of trading, setting off the New York Stock Exchange's uptick rule, which limits computer-driven sell orders.
 
 
Dow Breaks Its Fall

 Stocks stabilized somewhat after the opening, and the Dow rebounded from its lows in the final two hours of trading to close at 3,427.82, down 29.18. For the week, the Dow was up 23.24 points.
Broader market indexes fared somewhat better. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell by 3.89, to 449.83, while the Russell 2000 index slipped by 0.87, to 229.53, and the Nasdaq's composite index of over-the-counter stocks fell by 1.50, to 692.78.
On the Big Board, declining issues outnumbered gainers by about 5 to 2.
While the four-tenths of a point rise in wholesale prices reported yesterday was a surprise and served as a catalyst for the stock market's decline, analysts said the message that inflation might be coming back carried more meaning for the bond market than for stocks.
That message was heard loud and clear by bond traders, who drove prices of Government securities down by more than a point and pushed the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond to 6.86 percent, from 6.76 percent on Thursday.
 
 
'A Reality Check'
 "All sorts of wonderful assumptions have been made about the bond market," said Peter Canelo, chief market strategist at NatWest Securities, "from the thought that you can't lose buying bonds because either the deficit will be cut or Clinton's plan will kill off the economy, or that inflation is nothing to worry about. What happened today gave those notions a reality check."
Laszlo Birinyi, who runs his own stock research firm, said that at this juncture the performance of the bond market was not "critically important" to the stock market.
Rather, Mr. Birinyi interpreted yesterday's selloff in stocks as a classic response to a market that has run too far, too fast.
"Market technicians will tell you that if over a 10-day period the average number of advancing issues exceeds those declining in price by more than 2,000, the market is overbought," he said. "Earlier this week we were at plus 4,000. We had a very overbought situation which was begging for a correction."
 
 
Technology High-Fliers
 Mr. Birinyi and others said they were impressed with the resilience of recent high-fliers in the technology sector like Intel, which closed yesterday at 117 5/8, up 3/4, and Compaq Computer, which rose 1, to 51 5/8.
Novell, another personal computer manufacturer, was the most actively traded Nasdaq issue, rising 1 3/4, to 35 a share.
Interest-rate-sensitive stocks were hit hard by the sharp selloff in the bond market.
The Federal National Mortgage Association's stock fell 3/4, to 82. And the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation declined 1 1/2, to 47 3/4.
American Express, which announced it had sold the brokerage operations of Shearson Lehman Brothers to Primerica Inc. for about $1 billion in cash and securities, finished up 5/8, at 28, in heavy trading. Primerica rose 1 1/2, to 49 1/2.
Gambling stocks moved higher. Showboat Inc. was one of the day's biggest gainers on the Big Board, rising 3 1/8, to 20, after receiving news it could operate a riverboat casino in New Orleans. And Circus Circus Enterprises was up 2 3/4, to 49, after a Morgan Stanley analyst, Kurt Fuerman, upgraded his rating on the stock to buy from hold.
Overseas, Japanese stocks ended firmer yesterday. The Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 132.73 points, to 18,037.52.
But British stocks dropped sharply. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index fell 37.5 points yesterday, to 2,915.9.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Rise 0.4%; Biggest Increase in 2 Years

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Producer prices spurted four-tenths of 1 percent in February, the biggest jump in more than two years, the Labor Department reported yesterday.
The report took investors by surprise and rattled the bond and stock markets. Financial markets watch the Producer Price Index -- which covers only the prices of domestically made goods, and excludes services and imports -- for clues to broader inflation trends and likely moves by the Federal Reserve. 
 In the bond market, the remarkable rally that had pulled interest rates to historic lows appeared to have stalled yesterday, with rates rising sharply. [Page 44.] And the stock market fell steeply for the second straight day, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 29.18 points, to 3,427.82. [Page 36.]
The surge in the Labor Department's index was mainly a result of big price increases for motor vehicles, civilian aircraft and cigarettes -- along with a 1.7 percent surge in the price of home heating oil. These increases offset a drop in the prices of raw energy and some vegetables. Even excluding food and energy, producer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent last month.
Cautioning that a single month does not make a trend, many economists interpreted the report as a sign that the inflation rate for consumer prices -- which has been declining for two years -- was more likely to level out than to keep going down.
"It tends to cast doubt on the argument that inflationary pressures will decline further this year," said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. "There was a signficant body of opinion, even among the 12 Federal Reserve presidents, that inflation could move lower this year. These numbers challenge that view."
As it turns out, a survey of purchasing managers released two weeks ago had already signaled that prices for raw materials, parts and supplies were firming. "The markets ignored it," said Robert Bretz, director of corporate purchasing at Pitney Bowes. "I think they wanted to."
The fact that many farmers and manufacturers are able to make price increases stick is a classic sign of economic expansion. "The P.P.I. suggests that there's a little bit of commodity and industrial price pressure in the system," said Richard Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities. "It's a sign of an economy that's doing a little better."
For the first two months of 1993, producer prices rose at an annual rate of 3.4 percent, more than double the 1.6 percent increase last year.
Still, most economists and executives generally do not expect inflation to take off. Despite last month's spurt, prices of finished goods are just 1.8 percent higher than they were a year ago.
 
Temporary Increases
 Most economists expect the Consumer Price Index, which was rising at a 6 percent annual rate as recently as 1990, to rise 3 percent this year, the same as last year. The Government will report the Consumer Price Index for February on Wednesday.
Economists regard the jump in energy and food prices reported yesterday as temporary. World supplies of both are ample, Mr. Perna said.
More important, the biggest influence on inflation, the cost of labor, is rising at its slowest pace in nearly two decades. Pay and benefits rose at a 3.5 percent rate for the last year. In the same period, productivity, or output per hour worked, grew at nearly a 3 percent rate.
But that does not mean that the downward trend in labor costs is likely to continue. Employers are starting to end their pay freezes and grant the occasional raise. And productivity, which soared at a 4.8 percent rate in last year's final quarter, is extremely unlikely to keep rocketing.
"One of the mistakes the bond market made is to listen to a lot of talk about how inflation continues to decline early in the recovery," Mr. Perna said. "They forgot that we've been in the early stages of a recovery for almost two years."
In a separate report yesterday, the Commerce Department said business sales slipped two-tenths of 1 percent in January -- the first decline in five months -- to a seasonally adjusted $575.4 billion.
But at the same time, businesses were keeping inventories in check -- a good sign for the recovery. The level of goods held in storage was unchanged for the month, at a seasonally adjusted $840.4 billion. The inventory-to-sales ratio was also unchanged at 1.46, meaning it would take 1.46 months to exhaust the backlog at the current sales pace. It suggests that factories would not have to cut production to keep inventories in line with sales.

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeking U.N. Pressure to Compel North Korea to Honor Treaty

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
Expressing alarm at North Korean defiance, the United States sought allied agreement today on a plan to enlist the United Nations Security Council in compelling Pyongyang to honor its commitment to open nuclear installations to inspectors.
Within hours after North Korea said it was pulling out of an international treaty requiring those inspections, the State Department called on Pyongyang to withdraw that announcement immediately. But United States officials, who suspect North Korea of hiding evidence of its efforts to build nuclear weapons, expressed little optimism that it would back down voluntarily. 
 The officials warned that North Korea's abandonment of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty could reverse years of progress in seeking stability on the Korean peninsula. A senior Administration official tonight described the North Korean action as "a very serious step" and added, "It needs to be turned around."
 
Ultimatum Sought
 While its exact details remained to be worked out, the officials said the main plan of response being discussed with American allies would call upon the Security Council to issue an ultimatum threatening North Korea with economic sanctions.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher held out hope today that the North Koreans might "withdraw their withdrawal." He made clear, however, that Security Council action would be a leading option "if they continue on the path that they are on."
North Korea has cast its withdrawal from the accord as a protest against joint military exercises being conducted by the United States and South Korea. But senior United States officials said today that they regarded that assertion as an excuse.
They said that North Korea instead appeared determined to protect materials necessary for its nuclear weapons program, and that it had concluded that the program would be discovered if international inspectors gained access to two sites believed to be secret nuclear installations.
 
Weapon May Exist
 As the State Department issued a statement "deploring" the North Korean move, other United States officials said American concerns had been heightened by a Central Intelligence Agency warning that Pyongyang might already have produced enough material to build a nuclear weapon.
That assessment has been questioned in the past by other Government officials. But Lawrence Eagleburger, who left office in January as Secretary of State, told a Congressional committee this week that he believed North Korea had built such a weapon.
Mr. Christopher said today that the North Korean action "raises many suspicions in our minds."
After announcing its decision in Pyongyang, North Korea gave the Security Council formal notification today of its intent to withdraw from the nonproliferation treaty, which it signed in 1985. But the strong protests today by the United States, Japan and other countries appeared intended to persuade North Korea to reconsider.
 
Called for Inspections
 The State Department also made clear that even such a move would not end North Korea's obligations. It said it would expect Pyongyang to honor terms of the treaty requiring that a country's installations remain open for inspection for 90 days after its withdrawal.
For the United States, which only a few months ago remained optimistic that North Korea was ready to provide nuclear inspectors with full access to its nuclear facilities, the announced withdrawal from the accord represents a substantial setback. It followed North Korea's abrupt refusal this year to allow inspections of two secret sites.
The International Atomic Energy Agency, the United Nations body responsible for enforcing the accords, last month gave North Korea until March 25 to give inspectors access.
 
U.S. Called 'Unjust'
 North Korea insisted that the two installations "have no relevance at all to nuclear facilities" and said its withdrawal would stand until the agency abandoned its "unjust conduct" and the United States nuclear threat was removed.
The State Department insisted that the military exercises had nothing to do with planning for nuclear war.
Government officials with access to intelligence reports said today that North Korea appeared to have moved armored military vehicles to positions guarding the sites. But they said they believed the move was an attempt to add to the perception that the plants were military installations rather than any effort to prepare for attack.
United States officials said today that the atomic energy agency would probably be the first international body to review the new North Korean defiance. But the officials said the United States believed thst the matter should quickly be turned over to the Security Council for enforcement.
Another possible step would be for the United States to make permanent the moratorium it has already announced on withdrawals of the 37,400 United States troops still based in South Korea.

Amid a widening investigation into the search for more suspects and motives in the bombing of the World Trade Center, the New York City police have reopened their investigation of the assassination of Rabbi Meir Kahane, a top police official said. Page 1.

The new bidder for The Post has deep pockets and a higher profile. Page 25.
 
 
WINNER DECLARED IN COUNCIL RACE
 Andrew S. Eristoff, a Republican and a 30-year-old lawyer, was declared the winner of a special election to represent the East Side of Manhattan on the New York City Council. Page 25.
 
CONTRACT OFFER FOR FIREFIGHTERS
 New York City's firefighters would receive a 4.5 percent raise in exchange for working more hours each year and performing a wider variety of tasks, under a proposed contract. Page 25.
 
3 OFFICERS ARRESTED IN HEROIN SALE
 Two New York City police officers and a New York State police investigator have been arrested on charges that they sold almost $25,000 worth of heroin, Federal and local law-enforcement officials announced. Page 25.
 
TEACHERS CHARGED IN TWO INCIDENTS
 A teacher at a Brooklyn school has been charged with raping a 12-year-old student, and a teacher at a Bronx school was arrested on charges of assaulting a student. Page 26.

But the verdict remained a secret because the jury chose not to return a partial decision. It was widely suspected, however that the jury had agreed to convict the four defendants. Page 27.

HEADLINE: Cost of Military Cuts at Bases in New York Region Is Put at Over $1 Billion

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
The Pentagon's plan to close or shrink military bases will eliminate 12,790 military and civilian jobs in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut and could cost the region more than $1 billion in lost wages, contracts and other benefits, economists and government officials said yesterday.
In relation to the region's civilian work force of 12.7 million, the proposed cuts are small. But that is scant consolation for an area that has lost 995,000 civilian jobs in the last four years, and that still faces big job cuts at companies ranging from banks to weapons producers. 
 "This is just another substantial obstacle to contend with," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, a branch of the Department of Labor.
The only major military base in the region facing outright closure is the Navy's Home Port on Staten Island, which would lose its 1,773 military and 1,001 civilian jobs and six ships.
"It casts a pall over the Staten Island community," said Guy V. Molinari, the borough's president who, along with other New York officials, vowed to fight the proposal. Staten Island's unemployment rate is almost 10 percent.
 
McGuire Losses Listed
 McGuire Air Force Base near Wrightstown in Burlington County, N.J., whose main missions are air transport and refueling planes, stands to lose 3,289 of its military and 374 of its civilian jobs. It now employs 11,700 people: 2,200 civilians, 5,410 full-time military personnel and 4,090 part-time reservists and National Guardsmen.
Fort Monmouth, at Eatontown in Monmouth County, N.J., would lose the headquarters of the Army Communications Electronic Command, resulting in the loss of 425 military and 2,122 civilian jobs.
In central New York, Griffiss Air Force Base in Rome would lose 3,338 military and 1,191 civilian jobs out of a total of about 8,000. It would lose an engineering installation group, an air-refueling squadron and a bomber wing.
Smaller installations in New York State -- in Garden City, Jamestown, Poughkeepsie, Niagara Falls and Scotia -- would lose 117 military and 77 civilian employees. But two bases in New York would gain from the Pentagon proposal: employment at the Plattsburgh Air Force Base in Clinton County on Lake Champlain and the Air Force's Stewart Annex in Orange Country would increase by 3,102 and 396, respectively.
The Groton, Conn., submarine base would have a net loss of 2,227 of its 10,700 jobs. But the news was not as bad as many had feared. Although the base would lose its 19 submarines, its hospital would be retained and its training school enlarged.
"We thought we were going to get killed; instead, we just got wounded," said Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut.
Electric Boat, the submarine-building division of the General Dynamics Corporation, has cut employment at its Groton yard to 13,200 from 18,000 in the mid-1980's.
Across the Thames River in New London, a Navy laboratory, the Undersea Warfare Center, plans to slash employment to 500 in 1995 from 1,379 now. And in nearby Montville, UNC Inc.'s Naval Products division, which makes nuclear reactors for submarines and warships, is going out of business: It has cut employment to 25 from 1,073 three years ago.
As in Connecticut, officials in New York and New Jersey said that while their states as a whole might be able to absorb the blow, the same might not be true of the communities near the bases. "For the localities it is a big number," said Norman J. Glickman, director of Rutgers University's Center of Urban Policy Research.
Mr. Molinari's office expected the Home Port, which opened in 1990, to spend about $375 million on payroll, construction, contracts and services this year. And with ship repairs already generating $30 million a year, New York officials have been hoping that the expanding fleet might enable them to reopen the Brooklyn Naval Yard, creating thousands of jobs. The Home Port shutdown "would close the book on that concept completely," Mr. Molinari said.
The Federal Government estimates that Griffiss Air Force Base directly and indirectly contributed $753 million to its surrounding communities in the year ended last Sept. 30. "The loss in central New York would be horrendous," said Vincent Tese, New York State's director of economic development.
The unemployment rate in the Rome-Utica area was 7.7 percent in January, down from 10 percent a year earlier. There are only 121,300 non-agricultural jobs in the area, which has lost 5,300 manufacturing jobs in the last decade.
The cuts at the two New Jersey bases would also have a severe impact on their communities, where the unemployment rate is 7.4 percent, economists and government officials said.
 
'A 'Setback' for New Jersey
 "It's a setback, there's no question about that," said Barbara W. McConnell, New Jersey's Commissioner of Commerce and Economic Development, noting that state's overall unemployment rate has been falling.
Because of the economic ripple effect from the military cuts, her department estimates that the state would lose 7 jobs for every 10 jobs lost at the military bases. Using that ratio, the 6,564 proposed military-job cuts would eliminate nearly 4,600 other jobs.
In Monmouth County, the proposed cuts at Fort Monmouth "would have a devastating effect on retail trade and services," said Allen Green, an analyst at the State Department of Labor.
Many residents of Burlington County, where McGuire is situated, now work at the Philadelphia Naval Yard, which was marked for closure in a previous round of cuts. The county was also hit by 3,500 jobs cut by the Army in recent years at Fort Dix.
"The towns around McGuire will be hard-pressed to replace many of the jobs lost," Mr. Glickman said. The Federal Government estimates that McGuire contributes $1.1 billion annually to the regional economy.
From Rome, N.Y., to Washington, government officials vowed to try to get yesterday's recommendations overturned. Representative Sherwood L. Boehlert, a Republican from upstate New York, said closing Griffiss would be "one of the dumbest decisions ever to come out of the Pentagon."

HEADLINE: Building a Wall Street Empire, Again

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
They call it Primerica Inc., but Weill Enterprises would be more descriptive. With Wall Street's other corporations now run by a bunch of anonymous suits -- goodbye, John Gutfreund; so long, Jim Robinson -- Sandy Weill's portly profile has loomed up as the investment world's most prominent empire builder.
He has arrived there not by the route of 1980's excess, but by 1990's economizing, at least in matters corporate. His specialty has been taking the least glamorous financial businesses -- insurance, consumer finance, mass-market brokerage -- and running them like industrial plants, making all the necessary cutbacks and layoffs, and then some. 
 As such, Sanford I. Weill stood out on Wall Street even before his agreement to buy Shearson Lehman promised to make his brokerage operation the equal of Merrill Lynch's -- with even more money under management, he points out.
In a business where analysts and money managers get paid good money to size up the performance of executives everywhere else, effective leadership has often been lacking, with profits as erratic as the price of some hot new riverboat casino stock.
At Primerica, profits have flowed as steadily as the rivers under those boats, with the stock price rising from the upper teens to 49 1/2 since Mr. Weill took over in December 1988.
Not that Mr. Weill, a few days shy of 60, is known for saying "Pretty please with sugar on top" to get what he wants. "Don't screw up" is perhaps his most printable warning, and that's what he always said to the last person brave enough to be his boss, James D. Robinson 3d. Until recently, Mr. Robinson was the chief executive of American Express, where Mr. Weill was president until 1985.
"Nobody ever taught me how to behave," Mr. Weill said. "That's why I'm not there anymore."
 
Selling and Buying Shearson
 Yesterday, that thought brightened his open features as he reviewed his Shearson purchase at his penthouse office suite in Manhattan. He sold Shearson to American Express for about $930 million in 1981. American Express more than doubled its brokerage force, spending billions more, and now Mr. Weill is taking back what he sold and the other parts he most wants for about $1 billion.
Mr. Robinson himself is among the appreciative Primerica shareholders. How many shares? "Not enough," Mr. Robinson said. Mr. Weill's own stake in Primerica is worth more than $100 million.
Mr. Weill has had a fireplace installed near his Primerica office, but he sounds wistful for the one he had built in his Shearson and American Express days on the 106th floor of the World Trade Center -- listed in the record books, he said, as the highest fireplace in any building. Published cost estimates have run into the hundreds of thousands, but Mr. Weill said the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the landlord, threw it in free.
Mr. Weill's other office decorations run from the imperial to the purposefully humble. Instead of just a top honcho's usual grip-and-grin photographs with this or that President, he has an autographed picture of five Presidents together, framed with a letter from Gerald R. Ford, an honorary Primerica board member. But above his Chesterfield sofa hangs a picture of the yellow stucco three-family home in Bensonhurst where he grew up.
 
Dealing With Golub
 Now he's a godfather in more ways than one. He brought Harvey Golub, another blunt Brooklynite, into American Express to manage a major unit, then became godfather to one of Mr. Golub's children. As soon as Mr. Golub was chosen to succeed Mr. Robinson a few weeks ago, Mr. Weill called up to revive his failed 1990 bid for Shearson. Now, Mr. Weill said, he got a much better deal than he could have three years ago.
"He can certainly buy at the right price," said Howard Clark Sr., a former American Express chairman, noting how eager the company was to get rid of Shearson.
Again and again, Mr. Weill has snapped up businesses -- "the more hum-drum the better," he said -- that others want to dump, bringing in his own young disciples and scarred veterans of other corporate battles, many from Shearson and American Express. "He takes cast-off people and makes them winners and he takes cast-off companies and makes them winners," said John J. Byrne Jr., who succeeded Mr. Weill as chief of Fireman's Fund, an insurance company that American Express once owned.
"Sandy does go after costs," Mr. Byrne said. "To a man with a hammer, everything looks like a nail."
The nails that stick out the most, in Mr. Weill's view, are any people or divisions that fail to produce adequate sales or profits. At Fireman's Fund, he sliced away at the offices of public relations, legislative affairs and the general counsel, loudly asking why $500 million in computer spending had failed to improve efficiency.
 
The Early Days
 His first cost-cutting campaigns came when he and three friends put their names on the door and began selling stocks in 1960. With more than 15 acquisitions, he built what became Shearson Lehman Brothers, the nation's second-largest brokerage firm, keeping the big producers but dismissing managers and squeezing back offices as he went.
During the year or two after he left American Express and before he began buying the businesses that make up Primerica, he stayed in circulation as co-chairman of another salvage operation, a $60 million fundraising drive to fix up New York's most famed musical landmark. Another industry leader had long ago bestowed his name on Carnegie Hall, but Mr. Weill's $2.5 million donation put his own name on a part of the building, the Joan and Sanford I. Weill Recital Hall. His favorite composer is Mahler, whose noisy, angst-ridden symphonies might recall some of Mr. Weill's business meetings.
 
No More Cigars
 Some associates are now breathing easier, however, because they no longer feel compelled to demonstrate their loyalty by smoking cigars. Mr. Weill gave up his trademark stogies seven months ago in a deal with a 4-year-old grandson, pressuring his chief administrative officer to quit smoking cigarettes at the same time. Mr. Weill said that only if he stays clean until the end of the year will he give away his stash of rare pre-Castro Cuban cigars.
Mr. Weill and his wife, Joan, their two children grown and a fourth grandchild due momentarily, shuttle between a New York apartment, a Connecticut home and an Adirondacks retreat. The Weills both play tennis, but seldom together. "We prefer to keep the marriage going," his wife said. "The one thing I can tell you about Sandy is, he is very consistent in whatever he does."

HEADLINE: Religion Notes

BYLINE: By Ari L. Goldman

 BODY:

Stereotyping of Muslims
Protestant, Jewish, Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox groups warned in separate statements this week against stereotyping Muslims because of the arrest of three Muslims in connection with the bombing of the World Trade Center. 
 "We don't deny there are extremists," said the Rev. Joan B. Campbell, general secretary of the National Council of Churches, which represents more than 30 Protestant and Orthodox denominations. "There are extremists of many different faiths, including Christians. But we must be clear that the problem is the extremism, not the faith group."
Earlier this week, after Nidal A. Ayyad of Maplewood, N.J., became the third Muslim to be arrested in the bombing, Ms. Campbell warned of the danger that all Muslims "will become characterized as terrorists."
The Union of American Hebrew Congregations also warned against imputing collective guilt, saying that to do so would be unethical and un-American. "We deplore those who hold all members of the American Muslim community as co-conspirators in the attack," the statement said. "This notion of collective responsibility is the seedbed of prejudice and intolerance -- anathema to the ideals of American society."
The statement was issued by Rabbi Gary Bretton-Granatoor, director of interreligious affairs of the union, which represents 850 Reform synagogues in North America.
The National Conference of Catholic Bishops in Washington said that, for now, it was leaving the matter to local diocese for comment. Among the local reactions was one from the Diocese of Rockville Centre, L.I. The statement echoed the Protestant and Jewish warnings against collective guilt and added an attack on the news media.
"The press often portrays the conflict between religious groups as if religion itself were the cause and not the excuse for the fighting," the statement said. "We call upon our news media to distinguish between religious beliefs and the ways in which religion is used as a tool for seeking power."
Among those who signed the statement were Msgr. Donald M. Beckmann of the Rockville Centre diocese, the Rev. Edward Pehanich and the Rev. Michael Mihalick of the Orthodox Church, and Al-Haaj Ghazi Y. Khankan of the National Council on Islamic Affairs.
 
The Image of Islam
 Concern about Muslim stereotyping was also expressed yesterday at the Islamic Center of New York, the new mosque in Manhattan at 96th Street and Third Avenue. Noting the recent arrests in connection with the World Trade Center bombing, Imam Abdel-Rachman Osman said, "It is our duty to give people the good image of Islam." He urged the 1,000 people who came for the noon prayer to "preach Islam by our own behavior."
"The spotlight is on us, and we must prove we are a peaceful people," he said. "We must teach that Islam comes from the word 'salam,' which means 'peace.' We are a religion of peace."
Imam Osman, who came to New York from Egypt to lead the mosque, also decried what he described as a double standard in the news media. When bombs go off in London, he said, the accused are called "freedom fighters or the Irish Army," rather than Christian militants. "Only when it happens to Muslims is the whole community blamed," he said.
 
Dominican Priest Expelled
 The Rev. Matthew Fox, a Roman Catholic priest who has tweaked church traditionalists with his blending of historic Christianity with New Age philosophies, has been formally expelled by the Vatican from the religious order he joined 34 years ago.
The 52-year-old Dominican priest, who preaches what he calls "creation spirituality" from an institute he founded in Oakland, Calif., was told of the decision on Wednesday. It came from the Vatican through the Midwestern Province of the Dominican order in Chicago, which had sought the dismissal.
To the end, Father Fox insisted he was under attack because of his teachings, which have included Eastern spiritualities, feminism and environmentalism.
Dominican officials said the issue was simply a matter of discipline. "Our decision," said the Rev. Donald J. Goergen, who heads the Dominican's Midwest Province, "was never a judgment on his theology, spirituality or ministry." Rather, he said, it was over Father Fox's refusal to return to Chicago in his home province.
 
Protestant Journal to Close
 Christianity and Crisis, a journal of mainline liberal Protestant thought, is preparing its last issue after 52 years of publication.
Leon Howell, the editor, announced this week in a letter to its 13,000 subscribers that the biweekly journal, founded by the theologian Reinhold Niebuhr, would close because of financial problems. "It has as much to do with the economics of publishing and skyrocketing postage rates and insurance costs as it does with the disarray in the 'mainline,' " Mr. Howell said.
He said that "only a miracle" could save Christianity and Crisis at this point, but he did not discount the possibility that an angel could be found at the last minute.

HEADLINE: Abe Hirschfeld: A Winner In Land If Not in Politics

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON

 BODY:
Abraham Hirschfeld, who appears set to assume ownership of The New York Post, has no more experience running a newspaper than Steven Hoffenberg did when he stepped forward two months ago. But he does have deeper pockets and a higher profile.
Mr. Hirschfeld, who amassed a fortune by building garages and added to it with a successful health-club business, is best known in New York as a perennial candidate for public office. 
 He has run for United States Senator, Lieutenant Governor, City Council President and, most recently, for the Congressional seat that represents primarily the Upper East Side of Manhattan. In New York, he has lost every time, although he was elected a commissioner, or local legislator, in Miami Beach in 1990.
He has also served in New York as the Democratic Party's state treasurer and as a member of the Electoral College.
Born 73 years ago in Poland, Mr. Hirschfeld has been called eccentric, offensive and worse by political opponents in the heat of a campaign, and unlike other politicians, he does not always make an effort to patch things up afterward.
When he ran for Lieutenant Governor against Stan Lundine in 1986, he earned the lasting enmity of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who succeeded in getting Mr. Hirschfeld thrown off the ballot and who refused to speak to him long afterward.
 
Disputes With Press
 Mr. Hirschfeld has also had his share of disputes with the press. In 1990, he spat in the face of a reporter for The Miami Herald at a hotel he owns in Miami Beach, the Clarion Castle Hotel and Resort, because he was unhappy with the newspaper's coverage of the city's efforts to shut the hotel for violating building and fire codes. In New York, he once spat in the face of the former State Assembly Speaker, Stanley Steingut.
In 1987, Mr. Hirschfeld started a brief campaign to draft Donald Trump for President, saying the entrepreneur was the nation's best hope to solve economic problems. His efforts fizzled quickly.
The exact size of Mr. Hirschfeld's fortune has been obscured by the plummeting real-estate market in New York City, but he said yesterday that he is worth more than $10 million.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Advances on Fears Of Russian Political Turmoil

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar edged higher yesterday as the political tensions in Russia rattled the foreign exchange markets.
The dollar's gains against the German mark were, however, tempered by the mark's strength against other European currencies. 
 Gold for current delivery rose 90 cents, to $328, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The Republic National Bank quoted gold late in the day at $328, up 85 cents.
 The dollar continued to profit from its role as a safe haven currency as the battle between President Boris Yeltsin of Russia and hard-liners in the Parliament escalated. At one point there were reports, later discounted, that troops were approaching the Kremlin. Parliament is set to meet again today.
 Dealers said the dollar firmed because many felt safer holding dollars over the weekend in case the Russian situation worsened.
 Expectations that the German central bank might ease interest rates when its council meets on Thursday were also helping the dollar, dealers said.
 "The two things the market is looking at is the Russian situation over the weekend and the Bundesbank meeting next week," said Robert Ryan, vice president at Bank of New York.
 But one factor that dealers believe will encourage an easing of German interest rates, the precariousness of the European Monetary System, actually aided the German currency, as several European central banks bought their national currencies and sold marks.
 Dealers said Portugal, Sweden, Finland and possibly France intervened to shore up their currencies.
 The dollar ended at 1.6640 marks in New York trading, up from 1.6615 marks Thursday. Earlier in London, the dollar ended at 1.6655 marks, above Thursday's 1.6630 marks.
 In Tokyo, the dollar ended at 117.85 yen, down from Thursday's 118.09 yen. In London, it fell to 117.70 yen from Thursday's 117.65 yen. In New York, the dollar rose to 118.00 yen, from 117.65 Thursday.
In London, the pound rose to $1.4350, from $1.4343 Thursday. It softened in New York to $1.4337, unchanged from $1.4337 Thursday.
 Other late dollar rates, compared with Thursday's quotes in the United States, included: 1.5181 Swiss francs, down from 1.5230; 5.6550 French francs, up from 5.6440; 1,607 Italian lire, down from 1,608, and 1.2444 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2465.

HEADLINE: U.S. Turns Up the Heat on Trade

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
Raising the temperature in two trade disputes, the nation's top trade official today strongly criticized the Japanese Government's stance on a computer chips agreement and canceled trans-Atlantic talks aimed at heading off American trade sanctions.
The European Community and the Japanese Embassy here responded indignantly. The language used today by all three sides was remarkably brusque and irritable, testimony to a growing tension in trade relations provoked by President Clinton's new and more confrontational approach to international negotiations. 
 Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, canceled negotiations in Brussels, scheduled for Monday and Tuesday, because of what he described as European inflexibility. The European Community had shown no willingness to suspend or cancel a government purchasing regulation that the United States had deemed protectionist, Mr. Kantor said.
 
 
Federal Contracts
 With no further talks scheduled, Mr. Kantor said that an American ban on bids from European companies for certain Federal contracts, "will almost certainly go into effect" on March 22, as previously threatened. The ban would cover about $45 billion of contracts, mostly for local services like the operation of cafeterias in Government buildings. European companies typically win only $50 million a year of these contracts.
The community had offered to suspend one of the new regulation's provisions that offended the United States, but not the entire regulation, a European Community official said. "How could we be flexible if we're not even allowed to meet?" asked the official, who insisted on anonymity.
Mr. Kantor also accused Tokyo today of making excuses for Japan's likely failure to meet an officially agreed target for imports of computer chips.
He told reporters in a hastily scheduled telephone conference today that he was upset by a Japanese Government official's contention on Thursday that American semiconductor producers had canceled certain shipments to Japan.
A 1991 bilateral trade agreement called for non-Japanese semiconductor makers to hold 20 percent of the Japanese market by the end of 1992. Although final figures will not be released until the end of next week, industry officials expect that the actual market share was around 17.5 percent in the fourth quarter.
The Japanese electronics industry has been seeking to deflect blame by gathering figures on canceled American shipments to Japanese computer chip users. An official at Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry leaked on Thursday some figures suggesting that canceled shipments represented at least three-tenths of 1 percent of the Japanese market.
"The Japanese Government wants to use these charges which there is no substantiation for, and which our industry rejects out of hand," Mr. Kantor said. "We didn't want any excuses like this to be used."
Hiroshi Hirabayashi, Japan's Deputy Ambassador to the United States, said that ministry was always careful in its research. "Those are the facts, not an excuse," he said this afternoon.
 
 
'Talk on the Facts'
 Mr. Kantor's vehement position today "doesn't impress us at all, and we should talk on the facts," Mr. Hirabayashi added.
Daryl G. Hatano, the director of international trade and government affairs at the Semiconductor Industry Association, an American trade group based in San Jose, Calif., said, "We have called some of our largest companies to check and we are not aware of any" cancellations.
Mr. Hatano said that the purpose of the semiconductor pact was to eliminate nontariff trade barriers, like Japanese industry buying practices that discriminate against American companies. One effect of the Japanese charges about cancellations, he said, "is to try to create the perception that we're not reliable suppliers, which in effect raises another barrier."
Stanton D. Anderson, a Washington lawyer for the Electronics Industry Association of Japan, said that a study of shipment cancellations was under way but that it had not yet produced any conclusive results and would not be used as an excuse in any case.
Mr. Hirabayashi helped draft the original semiconductor agreement in 1991, when he was the top economics official at the Japanese Embassy. He said in an interview on Thursday that he and other Japanese officials now regretted ever agreeing to the 20 percent figure.
 
 
'Not a Good Agreement'
 "We think, including those who were engaged in negotiating that agreement, including myself, think it was not a good agreement," Mr. Hirabayashi said. "That figure started to walk along independent of its parents."
The 1991 pact expressed the market share target in very vague terms. "The Government of Japan recognizes that the U.S. semiconductor industry expects that the foreign market share will grow to more than 20 percent of the Japanese market by the end of 1992 and considers that this can be realized," the agreement said, later adding, "The two Governments agree that the above statements constitute neither a guarantee, a ceiling nor a floor on the foreign market share."
Mr. Kantor said that in future semiconductor negotiations with Japan, "We see the 20 percent as a floor, not a ceiling."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative. He strongly criticized Japan's stance on a computer chips agreement and said that an American ban on bids from European companies for some Federal contracts "will almost certainly go into effect" March 22. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Village Woos Train to Prosperity

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASSAIC, N.Y., March 10

 BODY:
Peggy Whalen anticipates using the proposed new rail service to this pastoral hamlet to ferry her Cub Scout pack to New York City on excursions to places like the Statue of Liberty.
Ralph Vinchiarello envisions a "golf train," something he likens to an old-fashioned ski train, which would transport golfers from Westchester County and beyond to Wassaic's new 18-hole course at the foot of the Berkshires. 
 And Ron Arno believes a commuter rail link would give this slumping Dutchess County community, about 80 miles north of Grand Central Terminal on the Connecticut border, an infusion of new residents, new homes and new businesses.
When Metro-North disclosed plans earlier this year to extend passenger train service 4.67 miles north on its Harlem line to Wassaic -- and to build one or two train stations here -- it did so with little fanfare. But to a community that has been battered by the impending closings of the two state institutions that employ most of its residents -- and depressed by the struggles of three I.B.M. factories nearby -- the plans are being viewed as nothing short of a lifeline.
 
'Lost Its Oomph'
 If the $12.8 million project, part of the $9.6 billion Metropolitan Transportation Agency capital plan, is approved by lawmakers in Albany, it would represent the first extension of service in the 10-year history of Metro-North and the first time that passenger trains have rumbled into Wassaic since the Penn Central abruptly closed its station here in 1972, railroad officials said.
"They tell me this used to be a bustling little town when the train came through," said Mr. Arno, the fiscal officer of the state's Wassaic Developmental Center for the mentally retarded, which is to close by the year 2000. "There's nothing here now. It's lost its oomph. The train is what kept it alive."
Metro-North officials believe they can help revive Wassaic, a community of about 300. They envision the hamlet's becoming a magnet for travelers who use Metro-North to get within striking distance of their weekend homes in nearby Litchfield County, Conn., the Berkshires in Massachusetts and even Vermont. The license plates of all three states are liberally sprinkled among several hundred cars parked from Monday to Friday at Dover Plains, the station now at the end of the Harlem Line.
 
700-Acre Campus
 The inability to expand the small parking lot at Dover Plains is a factor in the decision to extend service north to Wassaic.
There is also the potential to attract homeowners who might build here and commute about two hours to New York City two or three days a week, or who might bypass the city entirely and use Metro-North to reach jobs in other places, like White Plains.
Christine LaManna, a 25-year-old receptionist who works at a division of the Pawling Corporation here, said she would gladly use Metro-North to travel the 15 miles or so from her home in Pawling, N.Y., to Wassaic. "I'm an impatient driver," she said.
Metro-North is also betting that the 700-acre campus of the Wassaic Developmental Center -- 70 buildings, 7 wells, a power plant and a waste-water treatment plant, among other resources -- can be converted into a real-estate development that might house residents, shops, restaurants and small businesses, all within walking distance of a train station. Although the old Penn Central tracks, which still run through the campus, must be replaced, the new tracks would be laid in the same place as the old, Metro-North said.
 
Planning Process
 Some planners see the campus, set on gently rolling hills and dotted with evergreen trees, evolving into a veritable "town within a town."
Hollis W. Shaw, the director of the center, which is closing because of a statewide move toward smaller, community-based housing for the mentally retarded, said the state was eager to see the property go to good use. Several dozen acres might be deeded to the town for affordable housing while the remainder might be sold privately. The key, he said, was for residents to join the planning process.
"If the community wants to protect its economic base," he said, "here is a facility it can use as a foundation. We're offering the community a chance to determine its economic future."
The recent economic past has been anything but bright. The 100 or so small dairy farms that thrived in the countryside here as recently as 25 years ago have dwindled to five, priced out, in part, by the escalating costs of operation. Amenia, the town of about 5,000 that governs Wassaic, cannot even afford to hire its own police force, relying instead on the Dutchess County sheriff and the state police.
And many here fear the fallout from the closing of the developmental center and the Harlem Valley Psychiatric Center, another state institution down the road in Wingdale, which is to shut down next month. Some Amenia families can count three generations that have worked at the two centers.
"The mood is kind of depressed right now," said Peter Inserillo, 37, the head chef at the Segalla Country Club, the new course that opened last May.
For now, Wassaic must turn its eyes toward Albany, as lawmakers debate the fate of the capital plan for the M.T.A., of which Metro-North is a part. While expansion to Wassaic is a high priority, Donna Evans, a Metro-North spokeswoman, said the railroad would have to weigh the project against other priorities if the entire capital plan is not approved.
Mr. Vinchiarello, the Amenia Town Supervisor, said the town's future may hinge on that decision-making process, with the railroad extension providing the only real hope for reversing decades of increasingly hard times.
"This town hasn't changed in years," he said. "We're going to try to make it change."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The inability to expand the railroad's parking in Dover Plains, N.Y., is a factor in Metro-North's desire to expand its Harlem-line service 4.67 miles to Wassaic, a community of 300 at the foot of the Berkshires; Hollis W. Shaw, left, director of the Wassaic Development Center, and Ralph Vinchiarello, the Amenia Town Supervisor, recalled the time when the rail line brought Penn Central trains to the village. Now they see Metro-North plan an economic boon for the area. (Photographs by Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
N.Y.R.A. Shrinks the Winner's Shares

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HALLANDALE, Fla., March 12

 BODY:
In a move aimed at cutting costs and sending a message to state legislators, the New York Racing Association is swinging its budget ax for the second time in a month, cutting purses by 2 percent over all and eliminating the $500,000 N.Y.R.A. Mile from next fall's calendar.
"New York just cannot continue to exist under the present structure and rules," Jerry Lawrence, executive vice president of the association, said today from Aqueduct race track in New York. "Other states have gotten the benefit of a reduction in taxes. And nobody else competes for business within its own state with off-track betting the way we do. We hope the Legislature will see fit to make some changes between now and 1994 that will make us more competitive." 
 The cuts, announced on Thursday, will affect a number of major stakes, including the Nassau Handicap on June 5, whose purse was reduced from $500,000 to $400,000, and the Suburban Handicap on July 4, back from $500,000 to $300,000.
The daily purse reduction begins March 28. As far as the cancellation of the N.Y.R.A. Mile, which had been scheduled for Oct. 23, Lawrence conceded that the race had been diminished somewhat because it is run so close to the Breeders' Cup championships.
 
Win, Place and Snow
 Racing in New York this winter has been hurt by stormy weather, which has caused six dates to be canceled, including Saturday's card. It has also been hurt by the escalation of simulcast betting at the Meadowlands in New Jersey, which imports full programs from Gulfstream Park in Florida, Oaklawn in Arkansas and other tracks. But New York's tracks are limited by state law to 50 imported races a year.
Lawrence reported that the total betting handle in New York, on and off track, had declined by $45 million already this year, and he again projected losses of $9 million by the time 1993 draws to a close. Last month, in its first move to cut costs, the association announced a series of economies that postponed some track-maintenance work and closed the training complex at Saratoga in the off season. The Saratoga closing has since been modified.
By contrast, Gulfstream Park announced today that it was increasing purses for the fourth time this year. The increase will amount to 10 percent, for a total gain of 35 percent.
Douglas Donn, president of Gulfstream, said, "The additional funding stems from the great wagering response to Gulfstream racing at interstate and intertrack sites."
 
Win, Place and Sun
 Gulfstream Park figures to do even better in the next two weekends.
On Saturday, the prime 3-year-old filly Sky Beauty, the East Coast's rival to Eliza, will make her 1993 debut in the $200,000 Bonnie Miss Stakes. On Sunday, nine senior horses will run in the $500,000 Gulfstream Park Handicap. And next Saturday, the East's best 3-year-old colts will take major strides toward the Kentucky Derby in the $500,000 Florida Derby.
Sky Beauty has finished first in all five of her starts, although she was disqualified and placed third in the Spinaway Stakes at Saratoga last August. She ran second to Eliza in the voting for the Eclipse Award for juvenile fillies.
Two West Coast stars, Siberian Summer and Missionary Ridge, were installed as favorites in the Gulfstream Park Handicap, the second race in the American Championship Racing Series. The 4-year-old colt Pistols and Roses, winner of the first race in the series, the Donn Handicap at Gulfstream one month ago, was the fourth choice behind Irish Swap, who ran second in the Donn.

HEADLINE: Bond Rally Stalls on Inflation Gain

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
After pushing interest rates to historic lows, the remarkable Treasury bond market rally ran into the wall yesterday, stalling the move to even lower rates for now.
The higher-than-expected increase in inflation in the Producer Price Index in February helped set off waves of selling in Treasury securities. Producer prices jumped four-tenths of 1 percent. Inflation, which erodes the fixed returns from bonds, is the worst news for traders and investors. 
 But doubts about the continuation of the rally had been growing since the February employment report, released March 5, showed that the economy was stronger than expected. The expectation of low inflation, or even declining consumer prices, and slow economic growth have been two of the important reasons for the bond rally.
 
 
Profit Taking
 In addition, there had been more talk about whether the rally had just gone too far, too fast. These doubts apparently encouraged some profit taking yesterday that added to the selling.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond plunged more than 1 1/4 points and the yield leaped to 6.86 percent, up from 6.76 percent the day before and up from its 16-year low of 6.72 percent on Monday. The yield on the 10-year note jumped to 6.11 percent from 5.98 percent.
But the rally had already brought rates down so far that traders were not betting that the pause would mean a major upturn in interest rates. Analysts suggested that long-term rates would remain in a trading range of 6.65 percent to 7 percent or so for the 30-year bond.
If this analysis is right, then the stimulative benefits for the economy of lower long-term interest rates should continue as long at this trading range is not broken. But that will now depend more than it has recently on the success of President Clinton's deficit reduction plan.
 
 
'On the Path'
 "We are on the path to get back to 7 percent or a tad higher as the market processes the inflation information," said Elliott Platt, director of economic research at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. He said the February report for the Consumer Price Index, which is due out Wednesday, would also be disappointing. He expects a rise of four-tenths of 1 percent in the index, following a jump of five-tenths of 1 percent in January.
J. Gregory Erardi, the managing director at Salomon Brothers in charge of the government trading desk, said that the broad-based selling yesterday by portfolio managers and other institutional investors "means that the technical picture is much more cloudy then it was and this means that we will see some consolidation."
Yesterday's sellers were the same people who were doing the buying even while many traders on Wall Street argued in late February and early March that prices could not go higher or yields lower.
Mr. Erardi and some other traders contended that the recent rally was based mostly on a constant demand from portfolio managers and other investors, many of whom were just trying to catch up because they missed the beginning of the upward move in prices, which pushed yields lower. Economic fundamentals, like growth and inflation, had less impact, Mr. Erardi said.
John Costas, the managing director of the Government trading desk at the First Boston Corporation, said he thought that the inflation number was a tip-off to a lot of investors that it was time for a pause. He said he saw selling by people who had held the Treasury bonds or notes for several months, which caused him to conclude that some investors have decided that the rally had come to a halt, at least for now.
 
 
'Defined the Low'
 "I don't think it is ultimately over, but for the near term we have defined the low for the yield and could trade back to 7 percent," he said.
Edward Yardeni, the chief economist at C. J. Lawrence, took a contrary view, arguing that the increase in the Producer Price Index was temporary and that inflation as measured by that index and the Consumer Price Index should still slow.
Yet he still agreed that the yields on bonds and notes could move higher temporarily. But he said because there is no threat that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates soon, long-term rates should resume declining again.

HEADLINE: Base Closings Start the Shift

 BODY:
The Pentagon's official list of 165 base closings and reductions, released yesterday, will spark intense opposition from politicians and hard-hit communities. Indeed, senators railed against the list even before it was released.
Senator Alfonse D'Amato said not in his (Staten Island) backyard, but the Pentagon didn't listen. Senator Dianne Feinstein of California pleaded that her state's economy shouldn't be forced to absorb more blows. Defense Secretary Aspin did spare two California installations -- McClellan Air Force Base near Sacramento and the Monterey Presidio -- but the state will still be socked with the loss of about 30,000 jobs. 
 The military drawdown will be painful. Over the next several years, perhaps one million workers will lose their jobs. But the President won election on a pledge to expand the economy by shifting Federal and private spending away from the military toward civilian investment, and base closings are a part of that process.
Washington has a special responsibility for communities where it operates bases that are the nucleus of the local economy. That responsibility is best met by helping them plan for conversion, assisting laid-off workers in finding new jobs and spurring nationwide recovery so that jobs are easier to find. The $20 billion, five-year program announced this week by President Clinton is a worthy start.
Tying up tens of thousands of workers and billions of dollars in equipment at unnecessary military installations does the economy no good. By one Government estimate, cutting back the military could eventually add $50 billion to annual output as workers and capital are redeployed to more efficient and more rapidly growing enterprises.
But the process of finding new work can take years, and many workers face substantial salary cuts. Though most communities won't be affected very much -- military cutbacks over the next few years will be much smaller than those after World War II, the Korean War or Vietnam -- there are some places where defense spending accounts for 20 percent of local employment.
There, cutbacks could prove bloody. Even some large cities and metropolitan regions will suffer: The San Francisco Bay Area will lose several bases; San Diego will lose more than 5,500 jobs at a single training center.
The Pentagon already provides planning grants to help hard-hit communities convert military property into, say, an office complex or an airport. And the Commerce Department assists communities suffering factory shutdowns or base closings by subsidizing investment in infrastructure and other development projects. These Commerce efforts aren't targeted on base closings; nor should they be. Workers laid off from Boeing or General Motors deserve help too.
President Clinton's package would substantially increase assistance for the victims of military cutbacks, providing $1.7 billion this year alone to retrain workers, encourage technology transfer from military to civilian purposes and promote local economic development. Washington can quicken the healing process, even if it cannot prevent the pain inflicted by the closings on jobholders and their communities.
Perhaps the biggest help Washington can provide is to put Mr. Clinton's short-term stimulus and long-term economic plan into play. The proposals emphasize public investment in infrastructure, worker training and technology as well as subsidies for private investment in plant, equipment and research. That will create jobs -- and put the unemployed to more useful work than perpetuating unneeded bases.

HEADLINE: To Be Irish, Gay and on the Outside, Once Again

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES

 BODY:
The news from home in Ireland has been startling for Brendan Fay: Gay men and lesbians will be marching in at least four St. Patrick's Day parades there this year, inspired by their embattled and far less successful brothers and sisters in New York City.
"Even in Drogheda, my hometown," Mr. Fay said, savoring the idea of a homosexual contingent parading for the first time on the narrow streets that he emigrated from because of the community oppression he sensed in Ireland over his homosexuality. 
Now, the 34-year-old religion teacher, who lost his job at a Catholic high school in Queens after parading his gayness among the green on Fifth Avenue in 1991, is finding a turnabout he said he never expected: greater interest and tolerance back home because of the challenge he and other members of the Irish Lesbian and Gay Organization have raised in vain over the New York St. Patrick's Day parade.
 
From Cork, 'Hello New York!'
 "It's extraordinary," he said, noting that other gay and lesbian contingents are expected to participate, with no church, state or civic opposition thus far, in the parades in the Republic of Ireland in Dublin, Galway and Cork. Last year, his colleagues in Cork were the first ever to step off openly as a homosexual group in a St. Patrick's Day parade in Ireland, he said, and they bore the banner: "Hello New York!"
The news from home cheered Mr. Fay and some friends in the gay and lesbian group's leadership as they met the other night in a walkup apartment in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn to discuss the court defeat of their demand to parade and, now, to plan a protest march on Fifth Avenue.
Their sense of Celtic humor seemed intact as they wondered whether the day's unofficial slogan -- "Kiss me, I'm Irish" -- should now be altered, in the face of the parade sponsors' successful arguments in the name of Roman Catholic orthodoxy, to read: "Kiss me, I'm a heterosexual Irish Catholic."
 
Stance on the Church Varies
 Actually, members of the group vary on their sense of church fealty. Some range from indifferent to antagonistic while others tell of regularly attending Sunday Mass, some in a homosexually oriented congregation disapproved by church authorities.
"Coming out of the closet means coming out of the church," one member of the Irish Lesbian and Gay Organization insisted. But others recalled clergy back in Ireland who were quietly gay men, or having heterosexual affairs, who could be inspiring in their holiness and tolerance.
"This is not really about Catholicism," said John Voelcker, a 33-year-old magazine editor and Irish-American gay man who noted the parade's initial history as a rallying point for Irish immigrants of all sorts in the face of widespread civil-rights abuse. "I'm not asking to have much to do with the Catholic church, but I do want to be Irish and gay at the same time," he said, underlining group members' past frustration at having separate identities, one of them secret.
 
Wary of the Green at First
 A number told of being wary of the green as new immigrants, bridling at the myth and sentimentality they find that the parade day perpetuates about the real Ireland, with its economic depression and civil war. "I thought the idea of marching was nonsense," said Sheilah Quinn, a publishing worker who changed her mind when she saw the issue as a way to demonstrate tolerance and not just declare herself a lesbian. "What's going on with this parade is not representative of our people," she said.
Patricia Nora Brigid Ryan, a first generation Irish-American who grew up in Boston 20 years ago appalled at the racial-integration struggles in resistant, sometimes violent Irish neighborhoods, said the parade controversy "for the first time made be proud to be Irish-American." Ms. Ryan had the knack of relaxing her friends with biting humor. "This whole thing is just about the church's anger at the numbers of priests and nuns who got away," she said in joking tribute to the members of the Irish Lesbian and Gay Organization.
Parade officials stress that homosexuals are free to march as individuals with Irish county contingents. But this amounts to a back-in-the-closet message of "pelvic orthodoxy," as one member of the gay organization put it.
Mr. Fay, arguing that hypocrisy is at work, said that heterosexual Catholics, by taking care to be quiet in widely violating the church condemnation if birth control, have "somehow found an accommodation" with prelates. But homosexuals, he said, have stirred opposition because of their public insistence on being identified as both Irish and homosexual and worthy of integration in the parading Irish community.
 
A Painful Campaign
 Far from talk of having a bit of St. Paddy's mischief, group members discussed their campaign as too painful and hate-tinged to be enjoyed. They recalled a construction worker named Peter, a devout man who never missed Mass and hesitantly came out in the group's first march two years ago and felt so free that he "danced down the avenue." They regretted that he met "torment" back on the job after he was spotted on television and he finally returned to Ireland, keeping his faith and retreating from notoriety.
Above all, the group of eight lesbians and gay men spoke with some amazement at the international controversy a few people ignited with their impulse to join in the pride and fun of the parade. They told of street support from New Yorkers, but razzing and anger, too, especially in some Irish immigrant precincts.
"The most frightening, insidious thing is that people will walk by and just say, 'Anne Maguire,' a scary, inherent threat that they know me and what I am," said Ms. Maguire, a 30-year-old film producer who is the group's most widely recognized spokeswoman because of a willowy Irish beauty punctuated by a colleen-red mop of hair and a pugnacious lilt in her challenge to the Ancient Order of Hibernians, sponsors of the parade.
 
O'Connor Isn't the Enemy
 Animus was relatively slight among the group toward John Cardinal O'Connor, the leader of the Archdiocese of New York, who championed the free-speech right of the Hibernians to ban homosexuals' marching as a group on the grounds that homosexuality violates Catholic teachings. "We're not fighting the Cardinal," said Mr. Fay. "Our nemesis is bigotry and homophobia in whatever form it takes."
There was concern that mothers in Ireland not yet aware of their offsprings' homosexuality might discover it in the news Wednesday when the gay group plans its protest march down Fifth Avenue from 59th Street before the main parade.
"My mother has 14 children and a lot of headaches," said Ms. Quinn, fearing that her old mother might be informed inadvertently when her daughter marches in the protest next week and "comes out" fully.
"She faced many issues she probably never thought she'd have to face as an Irish-Catholic mother, including drugs, sex outside of marriage, stuff like that which she would never countenance," Ms. Quinn said. "So she really is a woman of the world and even my brother says she probably knows, but it's a question of bothering her with this in her old age."
 
What Will Neighbors Think?
 Members of the gathering agreed that concern for "what the neighbors think" was the great cry of family members back in Ireland or, for that matter, in the immigrant enclaves where some Irish-American families of members of the Irish Lesbian and Gay Organization live and follow the parade issue. The group claims up to 100 active members, about half immigrants and half Irish-Americans, 70 percent of them gay men.
"You can never tell how parents will react," said Marie Honan, a 31-year-old office worker at New York University. "I wrote and told my mother, who is a devout Catholic, that I was a lesbian. I thought she'd say the worst, to not come back home ever. But she called and said, 'You will always be my daughter, and I'm just sorry I didn't know before, because maybe we could have talked about it and maybe I could have been of some help.' "
Clearly, a mother's peace of mind had more weight with the group than the Cardinal's opprobrium.
 
'The Way God Made You'
 "I came out to my mother," said Ms. Maguire. "She goes to Mass every Sunday and the only way she could feel fine about it was to say, 'This is the way God made you.' "
There was laughter when someone said, with a big brogue: "They're bloody smart, these mothers."
Ms. Maguire was appreciative that it took her coming out to her mother to believe finally "it doesn't really matter what the church says."
"It doesn't matter now if my mother has to sit every Sunday to hear the priest say your daughter is a pervert and a weirdo," she said, her Irish eyes more determined than smiling as she looked forward to St. Patrick's Day.
