HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Allegheny Ludlum Planning A Swap to Acquire Athlone

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON

 BODY:
The Allegheny Ludlum Corporation, the nation's largest producer of stainless steel, said yesterday that it planned to acquire Athlone Industries, a smaller maker of specialty metals, in a stock swap valued at $107 million.
Steel industry analysts say the deal will broaden Allegheny's product line even as rivals, like Armco Inc., are also bolstering their roles in the more lucrative specialty markets with similar deals. 
 Industrywide, the two-year recession has caused the earnings of steelmakers to slide from their peak in 1989. Only in recent months have they been able to raise prices in the face of higher demand. And virtually all producers are just beginning to realize benefits from recent favorable International Trade Commission rulings over unfair import practices.
 
Used in Power Plants
 About 80 percent of Allegheny's production from the company's five scrap melting plants is high-grade, thin stainless-steel sheets, which are used in power plants and pollution-control systems. Last year, the Pittsburgh-based company had a loss of $78 million, because of an accounting charge, on sales of $1 billion.
Athlone, based in Parsippany, N.J., is one of only a few producers of thick stainless-steel plates, which are twice as wide as the industry-standard 48-inch sheets, like the ones made by Allegeheny. Thick, wide stainless plates are preferred by some customers because they require fewer welds.
Athlone had sales of $207 million in 1992. In the first three quarters last year its net was $4.6 million on sales of $155.7 million.
Charles Bradford, a steel analyst with UBS Securities, said Allegheny's proposed deal with Athlone might have been prompted by another steelmaker's move to enter the market for wide stainless-steel plates.
 
Lukens Plans Expansion
 In January, Lukens Inc., based in Coatesville, Pa., announced an $85 million expansion to create a high-speed rolling mill that can produce specialty-metal plates and sheets wider than 100 inches. Allegheny already relies on Lukens to roll its stainless slabs into sheets.
Lukens's plans "put Allegheny in a box," Mr. Bradford said. Instead of an ally, Lukens becomes a competitor, he said.
A Lukens executive, who asked not to be named, expects Allegheny to remain a customer, saying: "At the current time, Athlone is running full out. There isn't any excess capacity."
Allegheny officials were unavailable to respond.
Allegheny's proposed deal comes less than a year after two similar buyouts of stainless-steel makers. Armco, also based in Parsippany, the No. 2 specialty steelmaker after Allegheny, acquired Cyclops Industries last April. And in March, Lukens bought out Washington Steel, No. 3 behind Allegheny and Armco.

HEADLINE: The Last Days of Castro's Cuba

BYLINE: By Jo Thomas; Jo Thomas, who teaches journalism at the University of Illinois, was chief of The New York Times bureau in Miami from 1979 to 1981.

 BODY:
My flight to Cuba checks in at 5:30 A.M. at an obscure desk marked Haiti Transair at Miami International, downstairs and away from the other ticket counters. It's a three-hour wait for a 30-minute charter flight. Because the 44-pound weight limit on baggage doesn't include medicine, all about me are people holding clear plastic bags filled with antibiotics, aspirin, vitamins, milk of magnesia and first-aid supplies. I feel I'm about to go on a disaster-relief mission.
On the plane, the elderly couple sitting next to me come from Matanzas, a city 63 miles east of Havana. They have been visiting family in Tampa and have brought on board so many plastic bags that they have to struggle to close the overhead bin. They have been in Florida for two months and they want to go home. 
 In the Cuba I visited a dozen years ago, it seemed everyone wanted to leave. In the chaotic summer of 1980, some 125,000 people left in small boats from the port of Mariel. It was such high drama it was easy to forget that most Cubans did not join them. Nor did they put Castro on a plane with five revolvers and a couple of bags of gold, as they did with the dictator Gerardo Machado in 1933. The Cubans who stayed with Castro called the ones who left gusanos -- worms. Good riddance, they said.
Since 1980, the whole world has changed. The Soviet Union has fallen apart, and Washington keeps talking about the fall of Castro, whose Government lost 85 percent of its foreign trade and 40 percent of its economy in the blink of an eye. Anticipating that fall and urged on by the right-wing section of the Cuban exile community, Congress last October passed the Cuban Democracy Act, extending the 32-year-old United States trade embargo against Cuba to include all foreign subsidiaries of American companies and barring all ships stopping in Cuba from American ports for six months. Still, Castro remains. His Government calls these crisis years the Special Period, as if it had some foreseeable limit, even though no one knows when it will end.
I have asked to see Castro, knowing my chances aren't good. No one will promise anything. In the old days, it was the same. If I was lucky, I could see him give a speech, watch him at a distance of several hundred yards at a reception or interview someone close to him. You can spend a lot of time in Cuba waiting for a call from Fidel.
IT'S LATE AFTERNOON IN HAVANA. People trying to get home from work form enormous lines to wait for decrepit Hungarian buses that belch black smoke into the winter darkness. Bus passengers are packed so tightly that they hang out the doors or cling like spiders to the side, a foot in any crevice, even the opening for the gas tank. Men in mustard-yellow uniforms stand at bus stops, brandishing clipboards, stopping Government-owned vehicles, arguing with drivers and helping passengers in. Ambulances. Dump trucks. Utility trucks. Army vehicles. None seem exempt.
There is a severe shortage of oil and spare parts, so there aren't enough buses. There isn't even enough oil to keep the lights turned on. The entire country has regular blackouts every day but Sunday. Factories work by sunlight, opening at 7 A.M. and shutting at 3 P.M. Hospitals, child-care centers and schools remain open, but night classes have been canceled. Elevators don't work. Clocks don't tell the right time.
At the entrance to the Malecon, the broad boulevard that runs along the city's seafront, a young woman is trying to find a ride. I stop my car and offer to take her in my direction, but she is going farther, east to Alamar. I say I'll take her anyway.
Alamar is one of the newer suburbs, built to house people who have moved to Havana from the country. The apartments aren't bad, my passenger says, but in the Special Period, it's difficult to commute. She is studying accounting part time. Newly married, she is living with her in-laws.
It's dark, there's no moon and it's Thursday, when the blackout in Alamar runs from 5 P.M. to 8 P.M. When we get to Alamar, I can't see it. On a four-lane highway, I'm driving the only car. The roadway is full of bicycles, people riding alone or in couples, sometimes with a child pinned between them, sometimes with two children, weaving back and forth across the lanes in the dark.
We pull off at an exit.
"It's dark," I say, braking for another bike.
"It's a disgrace," she answers.
She directs me through a maze, finally telling me to stop on a street where only two cars are parked. One is on blocks. We get out. There are no street lights and I can barely see the building in front of me. My passenger asks if I would like to come in to meet her family. There are people in the hallway, but no lights, not even a candle. The mother-in-law is cooking dinner in the blue light of a two-ring gas burner on top of her electric stove. Dinner is a pot of potatoes and a pot of rice. We talk for a while in the kitchen, but there isn't room to sit down, so we move to the living room and sit in the dark.
The father-in-law is a doctor, a specialist in internal medicine at a major surgical clinic. In the darkness, I can't see his face, but he sounds tired. "I get up at 4:45," he says. "I have to get to work by 8." It's only a 20-minute drive and he has a car, one of the two parked outside. But he hasn't been able to get gas for more than a month. "I take three buses," he says, "but to wait for a bus, it can take hours."
The doctor is 49, an Afro-Cuban. Before the revolution, he says, someone like him couldn't get into a hospital as a patient, let alone become a doctor. He worked as a doctor in Ethiopia in 1977, during the war with Somalia. He remembers the poverty there, the disease. He's proud that Cubans don't see those diseases anymore.
After a few minutes, we are talking about the differences between health care in Cuba and the United States. The doctor knows a lot about this. He compares the low infant death rate in Cuba with the high rate in some American inner cities. He knows how many Americans have no health care, while Cubans have it free, almost from the time they are conceived. Cuba is also one of the few countries that has kept the AIDS epidemic under control, although the Government's policy of testing as many people as possible for HIV and quarantining people found to be infected has been strongly criticized abroad and recently modified, with some patients released for short or extended periods.
Suddenly, the lights come on, and I can see the faces in the room. Noises begin -- radios, televisions. I can see the buildings across the street, and I realize we are in the middle of a huge apartment complex. It's like a fairy tale in which a spell is broken and an invisible city suddenly appears.
THE WALL MURALS HAVE changed. The warlike images have been replaced by the slogan "Si Por Cuba" ("Yes for Cuba"). One of the authors of this campaign is Roberto Robaina, 36, the head of the Union of Young Communists. He is often mentioned by American Cuba-watchers as a possible successor to Castro, who calls him by the diminutive Robertico. I meet him on a Saturday morning in his office, a sunny room done in bright colors, overlooking the harbor. On the wall is a large color photograph of Fidel Castro and his brother Raul, Minister of the Revolutionary Armed Forces.
Robaina, the son of a bus driver, is from the city of Pinar del Rio, 100 miles southwest of Havana. A short, animated man, he talks quickly, punctuating his remarks with a sharp "Look!" for emphasis. He was 3 years old at the time of the Cuban revolution. In fact, more than half of the 10.4 million people in Cuba were born after the revolution. Robaina's work, at the moment, is to motivate this group, to make them feel involved in public life. "It's true that we lack oil," he says, "but the best raw material, the best resources, are the men and women who were born here, who are developing here."
The "Yes for Cuba" campaign, he says, is designed to promote "feelings of love, caring, of being Cuban, of respect. In another time you might have seen a slogan about dying for Cuba -- we certainly don't want to die. We want to succeed -- yes for Cuba. We are ready to die. But you don't have to remind yourself of this so much."
What about the Special Period? What will be the outcome?
"People in the world have been waiting for three or four years for Cuba to disappear. They say, 'It will fall in January. It will fall in July. It will fall in December.' Now, three Januarys, three Julys, three Decembers have passed, and Cuba is here, day by day raising itself up. I am absolutely convinced that if we haven't yet touched bottom, we are at the point of touching it, and as soon as we touch it, we'll take off."
Whether Robaina succeeds in motivating his target group remains to be seen. One morning, I'm standing in the lobby of my hotel when a young man walks over to ask if I'm from the United States. His girlfriend lives in New York, he says. When he finds out I'm a journalist, he says he's a boxer and invites me to meet some of his fellow boxers. I arrange to meet them at a beach on the east side of Havana.
It isn't until I see six of them working out on the sand on a hot day that I realize they are kick boxers, doing karate kicks in a ballet with the waves. Manuel Lopez, 32, says he is a former Cuban national champion in karate. From 1982 to 1988 he belonged to the national tae kwon do team. But after he refused to renounce a good friend who got married and went to Spain, he was denied permission to travel overseas and eventually left the team. All this has led him to join two dissident political groups -- the Democratic Socialists and the Civic Current.
Another boxer, Guillermo Fernandez, 34 years old, who has also joined the dissident groups, says he spent a mandatory two years in the army after receiving a degree in civil engineering. Since then, he has worked as a civil engineer on several projects, including the stadium for the 1991 Pan American Games.
"I am one of those who doesn't want to leave," he says. "I have a position that's both open and moral, and I will never go. I am a patriot. I'm against the Americans. I'm against the United States blockade against the Cubans." What he wants is a chance to ask questions and a chance to disagree with the Government. He also wants a better future.
"The Soviet Union helped us," he says. "So what happened? We didn't use the money to build a future. We became a country that created images -- in sports, in art, in conscience, in internationalism, in a series of things that are crazy in a country so underdeveloped. Now we don't even have toilet paper. And why don't we have it? Why? Whose fault is it? How is it possible that today we have nothing?"
BY WAY OF AN ANSWER, THE Government is pointing to its sugar harvest. Under the old arrangement with the Soviet Union, Cuba was able to barter sugar for all the oil it needed, on terms so favorable that the surplus sugar, along with nickel and other exports like rum and cigars, paid for a vast array of imports, from buses and wheat to cooking oil and paper. The Cubans have agreed to sell this year's sugar crop to the Russians, but the deal is at market prices and it will take almost the entire crop just to buy oil.
"Time is on our side," Castro tells a group of cane cutters in a national telecast just before the start of this winter's harvest. "We need time." Although sugar is the lifeblood of Cuba, there have been no fertilizers for two years, no herbicides, no fuel for irrigation. Now there is less fuel to help the workers bring the cane in. "Offer our nation the time it needs to go forward and be victorious," Castro urges.
Meanwhile, the critical issue is food. Nothing makes Government officials flare up more quickly than the suggestion that Cubans are hungry. "No one is hungry," they insist. The last time I was in Cuba, farmers could sell surplus food at free markets. But prices were high, and some of those involved got very rich. Others were suspected of diverting Government resources. So these markets have been shut down.
Now temporary workers are being deployed to grow food on hundreds of acres of formerly barren land. Doctors and university professors, themselves the children of peasants and laborers, are working in the fields. A neurosurgeon says he isn't worried about cutting his hands, and some of the women tell me they carefully paint their fingernails each night. Hundreds of city people have picked up rocks and sown fields of fast-growing plantains. Driving past Batabano, 30 miles south of Havana, on a searing day, I see fruit piled in the shade to wait for trucks that will take it all over the country. Plantain has four to five days before it rots.
A man sitting in a doorway in Central Havana late one afternoon says he has a job but can't buy enough to eat. With a ration card, his family can buy rice (5 pounds per person per month), beans (20 ounces), sugar (6 pounds), eggs (4 per person each week), a small portion of fish twice a month, and coffee (4 ounces). But these don't last the month. He and his wife go without food so they can feed their three children. It's almost evening, and he has eaten only one roll all day. "It makes you crazy," he says.
A woman across the street is filling a bucket from a pipe in the street. She tells me the plumbing in her building is broken, along with just about everything else. I ask to see her apartment and she takes me inside. "Look at this!" she says with a sweep of her arm. Electrical wires hang crazily down the walls. "This can't go on." Then she mutters, "Fidel will fall. Fidel will fall."
Last month, she says, her family ran out of food for a week. It has been four months since they have had meat. A widow, she works in a school cafeteria and has two teen-age daughters. The black market, she says, keeps them alive.
The woman came to Havana a year ago because things in the countryside were so bad. The country, her daughters tell me, was "like Africa -- no nothing." It was in the provinces, however, not in the city of Havana, that the Cubans built and repaired thousands of homes after the revolution. It was an effort to improve deplorable rural housing -- 74 percent of it bad. It was also a successful effort to keep peasants from crowding into the capital city, as they do in most countries that are rural and poor. But Havana, which had the best housing, deteriorated. In 1990, just as the Cubans were about to turn their attention to it, the Special Period began and the money ran out.
ONE SUNDAY afternoon, I take the central highway west from Havana, passing trucks, bicycles, ox carts, dozens of hitchhikers and hundreds of people waiting for buses. Although the adults are thinner than I remember, the children look good. I don't see the grinding poverty I have seen elsewhere in the Caribbean and Latin America: the filthy drinking water, the lack of sanitation, people living in the street. Even in the Cuban countryside, children wear shoes, and I see electrical lines running to the smallest houses.
I pick up three hitchhikers, all young women. One of them offers to take me to meet her relatives. She directs me off the highway and I drive for several miles until we reach a sandy lane running into a field of sugar cane. Her aunt lives here in a batey, a collection of small wooden houses in the fields.
For lack of fuel, the men have not been able to use a tractor for more than a year. An ox and a horse are doing the work. The women have been managing without soap or detergent for a long time. What really seems to upset them is cooking without lard. Although they are in the middle of the cane fields, there is no sugar to put on the table, no rum to drink. All the sugar, they tell me, is going for export. The older children, the ones over the age of 7, get a glass of sugared water at school, but they no longer get milk. This is the case all over Cuba: The island's Canadian dairy herds, imported for their prodigious yields and crossbred with native cattle, no longer have Canadian grain to eat, and the milk supply has plummeted. What is left goes to babies and small children.
What bothers the men most is that they can't get socks. They pull off their boots and show me their bare feet, which are bleeding from working in the fields. No one has a car. There is one bicycle, which originally cost 125 pesos. The current price is 10 times as much. Their monthly income is 300 pesos. (At the official rate of exchange, a peso is worth $1; on the black market, it's 40 pesos to the dollar.)
Since the people here live near the coast, several have tried to leave the country. Some succeeded. Others went to prison. Not long ago, the authorities came and took away the boat the men used for fishing, just in case anyone else decided to make a run for it.
What do they see for the future? What do they think Fidel will do?
"He has us in his fist," says one of the women. "We don't know what would be worse. If he dies or if he lives. We have nothing."
Knowing that some of their family members have tried to leave, I ask what they think about the anti-Castro Cubans in Miami, especially Jorge Mas Canosa (chairman of the Cuban American National Foundation, the most powerful of the Cuban exile groups). They frown and say they don't know who Mas Canosa is, but they are afraid of the Cubans in Miami and what they might do if they should gain power in Cuba. It is a refrain I come across again and again during my 19 days in Cuba. Even those who hate Castro don't want the Miami Cubans back, and only a handful can identify Mas Canosa. When they think about alternatives to Castro, they think of Cubans in Cuba.
"It might have been different with Ochoa," says one of the women. "You don't dare talk about this. We talk only with each other." Gen. Arnaldo Ochoa Sanchez, a popular and much-decorated officer, was put before a firing squad in 1989 on charges of organizing a scheme to smuggle cocaine.
ONE DAY, GETTING ON THE highway heading east, I come across a young woman trying to find a ride to the exit near her home, about 100 miles away, in Cienfuegos Province. When I offer her a lift and she realizes I'm from the United States, she invites me to visit her family. They live on the grounds of the Primero de Mayo sugar mill.
Ivetty Curbelo is a university student, studying English literature. Her favorite author is William Shakespeare. As the miles roll by, she says she also likes rock-and-roll, the Cuban singer Pablo Milanes, Mel Gibson and police dramas, especially "Lethal Weapon." She's an enthusiastic member of the Union of Young Communists, and her father, she says, is a policeman. "He's always working, day and night. He'll probably be at work now."
The smokestack of the giant sugar mill towers over the green cane fields. The Primero de Mayo enclave, which adjoins the mill, is at the end of a long avenue lined with fig trees. We pass an old wooden train station painted yellow, with a sign that says "Perseverance." In the old days, this would have been the Dead Time, when the new harvest had not begun and there was no work, when workers lived on credit or went hungry. The town is small, with streets of red dirt and houses of wood or concrete, some new, many built by their owners. There is a school, a medical clinic and a movie theater.
The Curbelos' one-story concrete house is set off from the road by a garden of vegetables and flowers. Ivetty's mother and sister come out to meet us, then bring coffee from a back kitchen, where they are cooking with charcoal and wood. We sit in a front room with flowered curtains and tile floors. Military medals that have been given to Ivetty's father are carefully framed on the wall. He fought in the revolution and at the Bay of Pigs and served with the Soviets in an antiaircraft unit during the Cuban missile crisis.
Given Ivetty's taste for violent American cop movies, I wonder if her father will turn out to be a middle-aged Cuban version of Arnold Schwarzenegger. But when Eusebio Curbelo appears in his olive uniform, he is jolly and small and sweating profusely.
"Mother of God, it's hot!" he says, giving me a broad smile. Most days, Curbelo drives the fire engine, but it's in for repairs, so he has been working at his other job as an auxiliary policeman. He's 55 and comes from Cartagena, in another part of Cienfuegos Province, where he was put to work as a child cutting wood for charcoal.
"We were a family of nine," he says. "I started to work when I was 9 years old. I never went to school and I fought in the rebel army."
Why did he join?
"Not even I can explain why I went. I knew nothing. My mother thought I was crazy. I was the only one in my family who went. The older children were girls, and they didn't understand."
He went to the Escambray mountains to fight, and "after the revolution, all of us who were illiterate started school. I had to work too, but, look, I learned to read."
What about life during the Special Period?
"Every day it's worse," he concedes. "But we have to work at it, planting rice and vegetables. In Cuba, no one's dying of hunger. What you have to do is work, work hard. Today there's more than before. In the days before the revolution, some had everything, and the rest of us looked at them and what they had. We couldn't read. We had no radio, not even a newspaper. It was a dark night. Now it's a clear day."
AGAIN AND AGAIN, Castro and other Cuban Government officials go on television to assure people that there are plans to get out of the Special Period. Again and again, they urge people to work hard and be patient. While I am in Cuba, Carlos Lage, who is coordinating the economic restructuring of the country, holds a three-hour news conference -- televised over a period of two days -- explaining the Government's economic strategy in minute detail. An important long-term goal is for Cuba to become a world leader in biotechnology, even though it is having a difficult time breaking into the international market for pharmaceuticals. The industry is dominated by multinational companies that can afford to spend millions of dollars to develop and market just one drug. Then there is the United States trade embargo.
I spend one morning in the eight-story ultramodern Center of Biotechnology and Genetic Engineering opened in 1986 on the outskirts of Havana. With the full financial backing of the Government, Cuban scientists have already made recombinant interferon, which is sold in Sweden, Finland, Mexico, Peru, Chile, Panama and Costa Rica. They are also producing a cream, based on a skin growth factor, that keeps burns from scarring, as well as a drug, PPG, that washes cholesterol out of the blood. A new vaccine for hepatitis-B is being used in Brazil.
But the quickest way for Cuba to earn its way out of its shortage of foreign exchange is tourism. Private investors from Spain, Germany, Jamaica and elsewhere have come in as joint hotel owners and as managers, and the tourist industry has changed almost completely from what it was a decade ago. The Soviet bloc tourists are gone. Last year, half a million tourists came from Canada, Spain, Italy and Latin America -- a number twice that of 1958, the height of tourism before the revolution.
At Varadero, about 90 miles east of Havana, the skyline next to the long, powder-white beach is dotted with cranes and new hotels. On a Sunday, I stop at the Tuxpan, built in the style of a Mexican pyramid and filled with flowers and tropical plants and lots of vacationing Canadians. Eamonn Donnelly, the Irish general manager for the German firm LTI, which has a management contract for the Tuxpan, is tanned and easygoing. He has worked in Germany, Spain, the Canary Islands and Brazil, and he says that running a new hotel in Cuba has been easier than he expected. "We finished our first year at an average occupancy rate of 68 percent and we're running now at more than 86 percent of room average occupancy, heading on for a gross operating profit of something like 48 percent."
Back in Havana, I meet Rafael Sed, president of the National Institute of Tourism, in a room off the glittering lobby of the Nacional Hotel, newly refurbished by the Cuban Government at a cost of $15 million. I ask him about the possible backlash from having hordes of affluent foreign tourists eating in restaurants that are largely closed to Cubans (who are not allowed to have American dollars) and going to stores where all the prices are in dollars.
"I think a good part of the population doesn't understand, and doesn't want to understand," he says, "that there are resources we can't put at their disposal." Foreign goods have to be paid for in dollars, he explains, and if they are put on sale for pesos, the supply will quickly be exhausted. The profits from tourism, he adds, are being put into essentials like food.
It sounds good in theory, but it's wrenching in practice. Boys on the street beg for soap. A theater director asks if I can get him a bottle of shampoo. Several women ask if I can buy them shoes.
I ask Carlos Garcia, vice president of Cubanacan, which has been setting up joint tourist ventures with European and Latin American investors, what would happen if, as the Cubans wish, the United States embargo were dropped, diplomatic relations were resumed with Washington and his hotels started filling up with tourists bringing both American dollars and American ideas.
"It would be a great challenge for us," he replies. "As a friend of mine says, we have been preparing for 30 years to meet the Marines but never to meet tourists. This is the problem. I don't know what would happen with an invasion of two or three million tourists. It would have a huge social and political impact, and it would be a great challenge. We would have to see if we were prepared. I think we are."
CUBAN TELEVISION IS already brimming with foreign ideas, and it's possible to see everything from the science fiction of Ray Bradbury to a concert featuring Ray Charles. The current favorite is a Brazilian soap opera, popularly known by the name of its leading character, Fatima, a young professional woman on her way up. The Cubans are outraged by Fatima's cruel treatment of her adoring and unsuspecting mother. Episode after episode, they wait to see Fatima get what she deserves, and week after week Fatima gets away with it. She has become a synonym for things that are bad. If someone has a cough and a sore throat, they call it a "Fatima of a cold." Even the hand-lettered sign advertising a neighborhood meeting to nominate candidates for the recent elections to the National Assembly noted that it would begin at "9:30 P.M., after Fatima."
The final balloting in these elections took place last month, as Cubans for the first time cast direct secret votes for the 589 delegates to the Assembly. But candidates were carefully screened by the Government. No candidate could run against the Government and everyone had to run as an individual (rather than as a member of a political party).
Municipal elections by direct secret ballot began in 1976. Among its administrative duties, each municipal council oversees health care, child care and education. Members of these councils -- there are about 169 in the country -- do not have to belong to the Communist Party. The National Assembly, on the other hand, meets twice a year and tends to ratify decisions taken by the Council of State, the Council of Ministers and the Politburo of the Communist Party, all headed by Fidel Castro.
Technically, even Castro had to run for office this time, winning, officials said, 99 percent of the vote in his district. At a news conference with foreign journalists on election day, the Cuban leader hinted he might step down. "Time passes," he said, "and marathon runners get tired. This has been a very long race, too long."
The recent elections are obviously an effort by the Government to get new blood and some kind of popular mandate, but it does not extend to people like Elizardo Sanchez, a former professor of philosophy who is now a leader of the Democratic Socialists. He is also president of the Cuban Commission for Human Rights and National Reconciliation.
When I try to visit him at his house, he is not there, and his relatives seem fearful. They give me directions to another address, and eventually I am taken to a third building. Sanchez is in a friend's apartment on a high floor.
Sanchez is 48 years old, with gray hair and a serious, gentle manner. "My house, where you were," he says, "has been attacked eight times by the political police. I think it has been the house most attacked by the political police in the whole country. And my family has been terrorized." However, he dismisses my worries that a visit from me could put him or others in danger, saying that I am only one of hundreds of journalists who have been to see him.
Plunging into the subject of the Government's human rights abuses, he says Cuba has too many police, too many prisons and too many political prisoners. No one but the Government knows exactly how many there are, perhaps 2,000, perhaps 5,000. These political prisoners, he says, are ordinary people -- "workers, peasants, above all humble people, and this explains why people have so much fear." Most people, he says, "have internalized this feeling. They know what they should and what they shouldn't say." Still, he says, people today are saying things on street corners that would have been unthinkable two or three years ago. Most of the time, the Government lets this go, but "when the protests have a wider character, and more people get involved, the police come quickly."
Sanchez calls the elections "cosmetic changes" and says the Government is trying to win time to win more time. "The Government doesn't have a real exit from the grave national crisis," he says. "So this is also a passive tactic -- to wait to see if a miracle occurs. And I say that they are losing time, because this is the best time for them to permit changes and to participate in those changes. The Government should renounce its hope for a miracle."
Sanchez is one of many Cuban dissidents who have argued that the United States embargo is counterproductive, only making things worse for those inside Cuba who push for democratic changes. An aggressive stance by Washington gives the Cuban Government an excuse to clamp down on its citizens, and the tightening of the embargo, he contends, makes things worse. He calls the Cuban Democracy Act "a good demonstration of the lack of imagination and intelligence" in Washington."
His political group -- the Democratic Socialists -- wants a dialogue with the Government and other sectors of Cuban society, including the Cubans in Miami. Sanchez doesn't think Castro is going to fall any time soon. "These totalitarian, neo-Stalinist models are relatively stable. They have great internal stability. This, united with an almost unlimited capacity for repression, can let this Government, even in this sliding situation of crisis, keep control for several years. The tragedy of the Cubans could be a slow agony, prolonged over time."
Sanchez has spent almost 9 of the last 10 years in prison on political charges. As I'm about to leave, he stops me and says: "I'm not a brave man. I'm not a hero. Every time I'm arrested, I'm afraid. But I think we're getting near the end."
Eleven days after I speak with him, on Dec. 10 -- the 44th anniversary of the United Nations Universal Declaration on Human Rights -- a mob shows up at the apartment building where Sanchez is staying. Two members of the state security police ask to come in but are refused admittance for lack of a search warrant. Five minutes later, a group of six men, karate experts, kick in the door of the apartment, beat Sanchez unconscious and drag him downstairs to the waiting mob, which also beats him.
Sanchez is taken to a military hospital, then to detention, before finally being released on bond on Dec. 30, after protests from government leaders and political parties in Europe and in Latin America, as well as from Amnesty International and Americas Watch. He is charged with violating the peace and defaming the President of the Council of State, Fidel Castro.
WHEN I FINALLY SEE Castro, he is meeting with a group of American church people -- Pastors for Peace -- who have arrived in Cuba to protest the United States embargo. They gather at the Ebenezer Baptist Church in Havana, and Castro speaks in front of a giant portrait of Martin Luther King Jr. The Americans have brought food, clothing, medicine and other goods through Mexico, crossing the border at Laredo, Tex., deliberately breaking the embargo on American goods to Cuba. I am told that at the border a Roman Catholic priest carrying a Bible was thrown to the ground by a Treasury Department agent trying to wrest it from him. The group gives Castro the Bible. Castro goes into the audience, to wild applause, to embrace the priest.
Castro, as usual, is in army uniform. He is 66, but has aged dramatically since I last saw him. It is more than just the grayness of his beard. He looks tired and preoccupied, and it isn't until he starts to speak that the fiery and charismatic Castro I remember emerges.
"The blockade seeks to block all sales and exports to Cuba," he tells the group, "to deprive Cuba of the resources it needs to purchase essential goods. The blockade is a national persecution, a constant persecution." Cuba cannot buy food or medicine, he says, cannot sell its nickel on the world market.
"We tightened our belts and deprived ourselves of many things," he says. "Then they invented the Torricelli Law," a reference to the Cuban Democracy Act, whose chief sponsor was Representative Robert G. Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat. "The merchant fleet of the socialist camp is gone. We have to rent these ships. It's hard to conceive a more cruel bill. They see it as the last hammer to intimidate our people."
At the end of his speech, Castro tells the crowd: "They haven't finished writing the Bible, and you are another page in that book. A thousand times, thanks."
In many ways, the United States embargo serves as a constant reminder of the enemy only 90 miles away, across the Straits of Florida. The possibility of a confrontation with the United States is never far from the minds of most Cubans, although the apprehension seems far less palpable now than it was in 1980 and 1981, the first years of the Reagan Administration.
For Americans, the Bay of Pigs invasion is an entry in history books, but it is still very alive to most Cubans. A block away from the beach where the Cuban exile forces landed stands the Bay of Pigs museum. Just outside is a giant propeller broken from one of the invading aircraft. Inside are captured weapons and a detailed description of the invasion. A glass case contains the photographs of the Cubans who died here. Beside them are personal effects: a sock, a broken comb, a pair of bullet-ridden blue jeans worn by a youth who wrote "Fidel" on a door with his own blood before he died.
Also on display are a little girl's white leather shoes, riddled with bullets. They belonged to Nemesia Rodriquez, a charcoal maker's daughter, whose mother was killed in the air attack. An old photograph of six children, all but one thin and barefoot, shows what life was like before the revolution in this huge swamp known as La Cienaga.
Nemesia Rodriquez, now middle-aged and the mother of two, lives not far away, in a small, neat village of wooden houses with thatched roofs, set back in the underbrush a few miles off the main road. She works at a nearby farm, and today I find her cleaning up at the lunchroom. She is small, dark-haired and shy.
"I was 13," she says, recalling that day in 1961 when her mother was killed. "They shot us as we came down the highway. We were in a truck, my father, five children and my mother. The plane had Cuban markings. My mother threw herself on top of us. She was machine-gunned in the body and the legs and died immediately. My brother, who was 11, was also hit. We were just children. We hid in the weeds until help came."
Why are there bullet holes in the shoes?
When her family was fleeing from the air attacks, the 13-year-old took the box containing the shoes with her. "I had always wanted white shoes," she says. "They were my most precious things." The shoes were in their box with her when the attacking plane strafed the truck. The bullets hit the shoes but not her.
In the city of Cienfuegos, about 50 miles away, I find a commission store, where Cubans leave personal items they want to sell and pay the Government a commission. A man's hat sells for 300 pesos. A hand lawn mower is 400 pesos. A woman's bathing suit, 500 pesos. A baby carriage, 700 pesos. And there is a pair of little girl's white patent leather shoes. The price: 1,000 pesos.
MORE THAN AT ANY time since the revolution, the Cuban Government appears to be looking for a rapprochement with the United States. Ricardo Alarcon, the Cuban Foreign Minister, is no stranger to difficult situations. A veteran diplomat who has represented Cuba at the United Nations, he helped negotiate the Cuban withdrawal from Angola.
Alarcon has offices in a Havana mansion restored to its prerevolutionary grandeur. He meets me in a salon filled with mahogany and antiques, and we talk about a recent vote in the United Nations General Assembly, with many allies of the United States backing Cuba in a nonbinding resolution condemning the Cuban Democracy Act.
The Achilles heel of this legislation, Alarcon says, is that it gives the force of law to the longstanding Washington practice of pressuring other countries not to deal with Havana. Just a year ago, some top State Department officials told me they thought the law was a mistake for the same reason.
Alarcon says he doesn't have a good sense of what the Clinton Administration's policy toward Cuba will be. "For Cuba," he says, "it would be perfectly satisfactory if they left us in peace, if they weren't as active as the Republican Administration, which has been persecuting Cuba all over the world." The current policy toward Cuba "is based on the certainty that the Cuban revolution has only a few months of life. If someone analyzes the situation with equanimity and objectivity, he will arrive at the conclusion there is no proof that shows this in any way.
"I think someday the situation will have to change. Only two things can happen. We disappear, or we don't. We survive, or we don't. If we don't disappear, if we survive, if a Cuban socialist society keeps existing here after the end of the cold war, after there is no Communist danger to the United States, there is no political justification" for the hostility of the United States. And the United States, only 90 miles away, will be "the only country in the world that doesn't do business with Cuba. The moment will come when more reasonable people in Washington will try to think of an alternative to this policy."

HEADLINE: DANCE;
Arthur Mitchell Does Go Home Again

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
This is a time of homecomings for Arthur Mitchell and the Dance Theater of Harlem. It was 29 years ago that Mr. Mitchell danced the dazzling, quicksilver Puck in George Balanchine's "Midsummer Night's Dream," performed by New York City Ballet as the opening event at the State Theater. Now Mr. Mitchell, one of the few black dancers to reach stardom in American ballet, is returning to the State Theater as the director of an internationally celebrated troupe, renowned for the freshness, integrity and exuberance of its classical dancing -- and for the fact that most of its 49 dancers are black.
Mr. Mitchell, whose company begins a two-week season at the State Theater on Tuesday, had gone home to Harlem to found a school and company in 1968 and, as committed as ever, is now expanding Dance Theater's headquarters on West 152d Street. In September, the 58-year-old company director and his dancers traveled to South Africa to perform and teach in Johannesburg and neighboring townships, a return of sorts to a spiritual home. There is, however, a special personal satisfaction for Mr. Mitchell in the troupe's engagement at the State Theater. "It's coming full circle, in a sense," Mr. Mitchell said recently. "This is the first time the company is dancing at the State Theater, and it's right before City Ballet's celebration of Balanchine. I'm coming back home." 
 A high-voltage dancer and implicitly, through the work of his company, a spokesman for his race, Mr. Mitchell has always been a salesman of somewhat driven optimism and pizazz, charming the rich and well connected into supporting his school and company and convincing audiences that swans, Giselles and neo-classical heroes could be black as well as white.
Exhaustion and a certain bitterness, both carefully veiled, set in along the way as it became increasingly difficult for his own and other American dance companies to survive in a tough economy. But this winter afternoon, Mr. Mitchell was uncharacteristically relaxed and contemplative, sitting in his small office in the Dalton School, Dance Theater's temporary headquarters until construction on the $6 million expansion is completed uptown. Distant, tinkling piano music floated through the air as, somewhere above, the dancers rehearsed the company's version of "Giselle," set in a 19th-century Creole plantation. It will be performed at the State Theater along with "Firebird," transplanted from old Russia to an exotic junglelike forest, and ballets by Alvin Ailey, Michael Smuin, Balanchine, Glen Tetley and others.
"I've been trying to find a key phrase," Mr. Mitchell said, talking of his own and Dance Theater's history and objectives. "We named the South African tour 'Dancing Through Barriers.' In a sense, that is the essence of what Dance Theater has been doing since its inception -- and what Balanchine did when he took me into City Ballet."
Lincoln Kirstein, a founder with Balanchine of City Ballet and its school, had played a hand in it all by offering the young dancer a scholarship, advising him, in a now-famous pronouncement, that to get into the company's corps de ballet Mr. Mitchell must dance like a soloist. When he was eventually invited to join the company, he asked that there be no publicity about a black breaking a barrier. "I wanted to get in on my own merit," he recalled.
Mr. Mitchell was not the only black dancer in the school. But he was placed front and center in a photograph in a school brochure in the 1950's, not a time when racial mixing was readily tolerated. "I heard that some people called to say they didn't want their daughters dancing with me, and that Lincoln and Mr. B. told them to take their daughters out of the school then."
Mr. Mitchell also felt support as a company member. "We had a couple of incidents on tour, but never with the company," he said. "Basically, I was totally accepted.
"I remember Balanchine did a 'Nutcracker' for television, with me ending up with the Sugar Plum Fairy. It was during school integration in Little Rock, and Mr. B. said, 'I hope Governor Faubus is watching.' He and Lincoln were -- and are -- incredible men."
At City Ballet, Mr. Mitchell absorbed not only his many roles but the everyday workings of a ballet company, from costume fittings to lighting sessions to orchestra rehearsals. The assassination of Martin Luther King Jr. in 1968 spurred Mr. Mitchell to give back what he had learned. "I never actually started out to have a company. I wanted to start a school to get the kids off the streets. But I couldn't tell the young people in the school to be the best they could when they had no place to go. As we began to get grants, we had to match those grants, so I had to have a group earning income. And I was making role models for the kids."
Mr. Mitchell stressed that sensitivity to color and black cultural history, evident in his insistence on tights and shoes dyed to match the dancers' individual skin tones and in his re-staging of classics, was neither a concession nor a political statement. "We are artists who happen to be black, not black artists," he said. "In the final analysis, we are in service to the art form. By doing that, we then make things better for the race."
OVER THE YEARS, HE AND HIS dancers have taken on the roles of cultural emissaries. And they have brought dance to schoolchildren throughout the United States and abroad in lecture-demonstrations and workshops on ballet, classical technique and the behind-the-scenes production of dance. For those reasons, Mr. Mitchell said, Dance Theater was a natural choice to become the first major performing-arts troupe to visit South Africa as a statement of that country's increasing racial openness.
He sought a total political consensus about the company's visit. "It was the first time in history that every political faction in that country agreed on one thing -- to bring Dance Theater," he said.
In addition to performances that reopened Johannesburg's renovated, previously whites-only Civic Theater, dancers and company personnel fanned out to surrounding areas to conduct master classes, demonstrations and seminars in theaters, schools and community halls. The classes, organized by Cassandra Phifer, a charter member of Dance Theater who has since left to teach and choreograph on her own, drew as many as 90 children, most of whom had no formal dance training. To be seen and heard, the dancers often had to teach with the children ringing them in concentric circles.
"I'd ask them to show me something they did," Ms. Phifer said. "I'd show them something I did. At the end, we had the beginning of a little dance. Something they could keep for themselves."
Mr. Mitchell, who is known for getting his way, had a hard time convincing Ms. Phifer to come along. How much, she wondered, could things have changed in South Africa? But he persisted. "And Sandy was wonderful," he said. In fact, it was a time of discovery for all of them. Mr. Mitchell talks enthusiastically of the black South African dances the company brought back and of working with drummers who were taken aback at the sight of the company's woman conductor, Tania Leon. Poignantly, he found himself answering some of the same kinds of questions he was asked by his first Harlem students. Why was technique necessary, one boy asked, if you could dance well already?
Ms. Phifer was surprised to discover that one part of Soweto looked just like Beverly Hills. But most of all, there were the children, who got to see their American teachers dance and even occasionally performed as extras at the Civic Theater. They taught their teachers social dances and games, as well as lessons about the human spirit.
"I saw in them a sense of purpose and dignity," Ms. Phifer said. "To have so little, and to still know who you are and project a positive image, even in extreme adversity. Because of apartheid, they haven't developed the analytic skills they need to get from where they are to where they want to be. But I think there are a lot of people here in the United States with the same problem."
The three-week visit produced a dizzying kaleidoscope of racial imagery. Some stereotypes were stood on their heads. A reporter polling audience members on opening night at the Civic Theater was startled to hear a Johannesburg dance teacher talk of American blacks having better physiques for ballet than African blacks, an observation often made in America about white versus black ballet dancers. Mr. Mitchell himself was fascinated by the country's complex racial composition. "In America we just deal with black and white. In South Africa there are blacks, coloreds, Indians and Caucasians."
He was suddenly struck by yet another incongruity. One of the ballets by Mr. Smuin to be performed during the State Theater season is "A Song for a Dead Warrior," a dance about American Indians. Blacks playing Indians? Another barrier broken? Mr. Mitchell roared with pleased laughter. "I love that," he exclaimed.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
An Enterprise Zone for the Imagination

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp

 BODY:
Some say that Eric Owen Moss comes out of Frank Gehry. Others insist that Mr. Moss's true architectural forebear is the Venetian modernist Carlo Scarpa. Actually, the work of this young California architect springs right out of modern life. And the most penetrating angle into his work comes from the Harvard economist (now Labor Secretary) Robert Reich and his concept of the "symbolic analyst."
As Mr. Reich describes them in his book "The Work of Nations," symbolic analysts are the elite of the nation's work force, the professionals best poised to profit from the information economy. "Symbolic analysts solve, identify and broker problems by manipulating symbols," Mr. Reich writes. "They simplify reality into abstract images that can be rearranged, juggled, experimented with, communicated to other specialists and then, eventually, transformed back into reality. The manipulations are done with analytic tools, sharpened by experience." 
 All architects belong to this privileged group of workers. In fact, buildings are the most physically imposing examples of the process Mr. Reich describes. Architects call the process design; with it, they transform material reality on a gigantic scale. But Eric Owen Moss is in a special category. He does not just design buildings. He builds the process of design. His work, the subject of a recent show at Harvard University's Graduate School of Design, offers an exhilarating display of rearrangement, juggling, and experimentation with architectural form.
Mr. Reich's ideas are particularly apt for Mr. Moss, because much of his work focuses on the workplace. Though Mr. Moss has designed a wide range of building types, his most impressive projects are the offices he has designed in Culver City, Calif., for Frederick Norton Smith, a private developer. With four office buildings already completed and another four in the works, Mr. Smith and Mr. Moss have turned Culver City into their own urban renewal project, an enterprise zone for the architectural imagination.
These office buildings are classic illustrations of a phenomenon Mr. Reich describes: the shift from manufacturing to service industries that is transforming the American economy. Culver City, an independent municipality on the edge of Los Angeles, contains large stretches of industrial wasteland, with scores of factories that have been abandoned as manufacturing jobs have been transferred to Mexico, the Philippines and other centers of cheap labor. In the past seven years, Mr. Moss and Mr. Smith have renovated four of these buildings: 8522 National Boulevard, the Gary Group, the Paramount Laundry and Lindblade Tower. Now, instead of blue-collar plants, they house such media-based industries as advertising, movie production and graphic design. Mr. Moss's buildings bear witness to the transformation. Within their industrial shells, Mr. Moss makes architecture with the graphic punch of the media age. He teaches old buildings new skills.
Mr. Moss attacks these projects in the spirit of Gordon Matta Clark, the artist known for his elaborate "cuttings" of abandoned buildings. He slices through walls, floors and ceilings, exposing trusses, sky, innards. Into the carved-out remains he inserts structural and spatial elements in a protean array of materials and forms. Bridges leap through space atop columns made of fat clay pipes. Walls wrap space into incongruent geometries that nonetheless merge. A skylit stairwell splices a cylinder together with a cube. A cone of plywood collides with walls of old brick. Where another designer might hang a painting, Mr. Moss cuts open a partition to frame a view of people working the phones.
Though these images are startling, they arise almost incidentally from Mr. Moss's way of working. Unlike many architects, he does not begin with one strong image of a building and then figure out how to make it stand up. He starts with an initial idea -- say, how to get into a building -- that then branches off to other ideas. His method is something like a writer's exploratory draft: thoughts pivot off other thoughts, propelling the mind in directions unforeseen when the first sentence was committed to paper. With Mr. Moss, the thoughts are ideas about access, circulation, enclosure, structure, lighting, materials: each aspect of the building opens up new avenues for exploration. Then he goes back and makes whatever adjustments are needed so that the ideas support one another.
Of course, all architects revise their ideas in the course of designing a building. What distinguishes Mr. Moss is the degree to which the completed building retains the improvised air of the initial draft. Like writers who write to find out what they think, Mr. Moss designs to see what kinds of information can be extracted in the making of a place. He lays particular stress on the hardware that joins his ideas together: trusses, beams, cables, plates. These details offer visual reassurance that the spaces we're walking through aren't just a random collection of passing spatial fancies. They're tied down, bolted, fitted together with painstaking mental craft. The precision of the joinery balances the informality it makes possible.
The joints are metaphors for work. Mr. Moss's spaces, forms and materials are all pieces of information. His joints link those pieces together to create areas where information is pooled. The result is an architectural analogy to the climate of mental exchange that nurtures businesses based on information. "When one's job is to think about and communicate abstract ideas," Robert Reich observes, " 'work' occurs wherever and whenever ideas are communicated." For Eric Moss, space is knowledge. It is neither sequestered away in private boardrooms nor dispersed evenly over totally open floor plans. It gathers in corners, seeps in through windows, rises to the ceiling in effervescent bubbles of speculation and gossip.
The show at Harvard, which examined in detail eight recent and current projects, simulated the analytic process behind the work itself. With models, sketches, construction drawings and photographs, the show traced the evolution of small, tentative ideas into large, sculptural masses. But there are few architects whose work is less amenable to the exhibition format. In a text that accompanied the exhibition, Mr. Moss writes that "the task of architecture is both to put things together and, simultaneously, to re-examine, to take things apart." Only in the buildings can one experience how taking things apart can be a spellbinding way of putting them together.
Yet even inside the buildings themselves the spell sometimes breaks. Then you may slip into that chilling state of mind, a familiar one in Los Angeles, when you feel pushed to the edge by media excess: the ceaseless art direction, the brilliant conjuring of images, the explosions of color that rise up before the eye, dazzle briefly and subside, like the images of a kaleidoscope that turns a blind eye to the world.
Robert Reich can leave you with the same dazzling but bleak impression: a picture of an America fast-forwarded into a hyperbolic world of symbolic abstractions, a nation of people sitting inside sealed office buildings, gazing raptly at computer screens, heedless of the world outside. Meanwhile, the material needs of these ethereal souls are taken care of by unseen, unskilled, underpaid laborers or "in-person service providers," as Mr. Reich calls them, proles with less social status than robots. When that dyspeptic picture takes over, a burned-out storefront may appear a more telling form of "symbolic analysis" than all of Eric Moss's ingenious joints. Perhaps it's only a delusion to think that, with proper training, all can share in the good life enjoyed by Mr. Reich's privileged caste.
Yet possibly the symbols circulating among those computer screens will disclose more effective ways to educate children, treat disease or turn an inner-city neighborhood around. A creative solution to a social crisis may emerge from minds at play. As optimistic in spirit as it is generous in form, Mr. Moss's architecture inspires faith in the city as a limitless source of ideas yet to be hooked up.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Establishing Guidelines;
The Redevelopment Of City-Owned Sites

 BODY:
In the hope of shaping future redevelopment in 24 areas where New York City owns large amounts of vacant land or condemned and foreclosed buildings, the City Planning Department is developing guidelines for the disposition of these properties.
The first eight plans cover Long Pond/Butler Manor and West Poillon Woods on Staten Island; south central Harlem; northern Bathgate, Highbridge and Crotona Park East-Crotona Park South in the Bronx; East New York/New Lots in Brooklyn and Edgemere, Queens. 
 "The strategies are tailored to the unique conditions, issues and opportunities in each neighborhood," said Richard L. Schaffer, director of the planning department.
For example, planners recommend sites for new schools in Highbridge, owner-occupied housing and a new supermarket for East New York, medium-density housing in Harlem and preservation of natural areas in the Staten Island neighborhoods.
The plans cost $3 each and are available at the department's bookstore, 22 Reade Street, east of Broadway.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Early Lease Renewals;
Making Deals That Work to Everyone's Advantage

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
WHITTLE Communications was perfectly happy with the 4,000 square feet of offices in the Seagram Building that it had rented five years ago.It was less happy with the above-market rent to which it was committed for five more years.
So when it needed 10,000 feet more, Whittle and Brian D. Gell, the Edward S. Gordon managing director who handles the building's leasing, worked out a deal. They tore up the lease and wrote a new one to cover 14,000 feet at a rental still about $10 above market but a good 30 percent below what Whittle had been paying. 
 Both sides feel good about the deal. Whittle did not have to sublease at a loss, incur moving costs or write off the undepreciated portion of the improvements it had made to its space. Mr. Gell will not have to market the space when the lease runs out.
"We could have gotten a lower rental if we moved, but on an overall cost basis this was a win situation for us," said Douglas Kennedy, Whittle's vice president for facilities.
Added Mr. Gell: "When a creditworthy tenant takes three times the space they had, this kind of transaction makes sense."
Early renewals make sense for lots of reasons these days. Landlords are often willing to forgo some immediate cash flow in exchange for a guaranteed income for the next 10 years.
Thus, they are agreeing to long-term rents that, while $10 or so above the going market, are still many dollars below the rents and escalations that tenants had agreed to in the boom days of the 1980's.
In fact, some landlords are so gung-ho on early renewals that they've begun paying brokers full commission for them, a practice that was anathema scarcely four years ago.
"Landlords finally realize they'd have to pay full commission and a lot of free rent to get a new tenant," said Bruce Mosler, vice chairman of Galbreath Riverbank, which represented Whittle in its advance renewal.
Other brokers note that their tenant clients are optimistic enough about the economy to go ahead with expansion plans, particularly if they can lock in tomorrow's space at today's rents.
"They're saying, 'If we're going to expand let's do it now,' " said Robert L. Freedman, vice chairman of Williams Real Estate.
Even tenants that are not growing are renewing early to lock in reasonable rents.
For example, Donovan Leisure Newton & Irvine, a law firm, recently signed a new 15-year lease for its 100,000 square feet at 30 Rockefeller Center, even though its old lease was at below-market rates. The company did not ask for a substantial rent reduction; it just wanted to avoid a substantial increase when its lease expired in late 1994.
The motivations behind early renewals aren't exclusively financial. Leasing agents report that many professional partnerships are committing to long leases now, even at relatively high rents, in exchange for a landlord's agreement that, should the firm ever default on the lease, the partners will not be held personally liable.
Other tenants are using early renewals as a way to get all of their leases to expire at the same time, thus simplifying accounting and making it easier to extricate the whole company from space if it does eventually move.
The Securities Industry Automation Corporation, for example, was juggling several leases for its 100,000 square feet at 55 Water Street. The company has extensive computer systems installed, so it wanted to be certain thatall its operations would stay put for a while and that if it did eventually move its leases would expire at the same time.
It got the landlord to tear up all the leases and draw one new one covering all the space for 13 years.
"WE got a lower rent, but the reason for the advanced renewal was functional, not economic," said Jonathan C. Rudes, the Wm. A White/Grubb & Ellis senior vice president who represented the company.
Even if the renewal negotiations do not start over money, tenants usually throw rent reductions into the negotiation pot.
AGIP Petroleum, the American arm of the Italian oil monopoly, was so unhappy with the air-conditioning in its 20,000 square feetat 666 Fifth Avenue, near 52d Street, that it was thinking of moving. But it liked the location, and with less than three years left on its lease it was impractical to try to sublet.
Eric Peniston, the Cushman & Wakefield senior director who represents AGIP, told Sumitomo Realty, the building's owner, that AGIP would sign a new 15-year lease if Sumitomo would refurbish the space, put in new air-conditioning and halve the rent to $25 a foot with stepups, from the $50 a foot to which it had escalated. Sumitomo agreed.
When a lot of space is at stake, landlords may offer rent reductions themselves.
Prudential Insurance, which owns 100 Park Avenue, near 40th Street, recently suggested an early renewal to a 40,000-square-foottenant who needed an additional 25,000 feet. The lease, which called for more than $40 a foot in a building where the going rent was about $28, expires in late 1994.
"We figured how long it would take to find a new tenant and what kind of rent we would get, and then we compared that scenario to the costs of taking a market deal for the premises today," said Joseph G. Costabile, a Cushman & Wakefield senior director who handles leasing for the building. They recast the lease so that all the space would go for $30 a foot, $2 above market rent.
Still, for now, most early renewals are done at the tenant's behest. Mr. Gell, for example, has made no renewal overtures to other tenants in the Seagram Building.
"Many of our tenants are paying very high rentals, and it doesn't pay for us to lower them unless they are expanding significantly," he said.
Indeed, not all landlords are enamored of early renewals, particularly at a time when rents seem ready to move north. Some have a psychological aversion to negotiating with one of their own tenants and are loath to offer the kind of deal they would have to give if the space were vacant.
"The majority of deals I do are still relocations, because existing landlords simply couldn't bring themselves to negotiate a satisfactory deal ahead of time," said Mitchell S. Steir, a senior managing director with Julien J. Studley Inc.
Sometimes, lenders will refuse to O.K. an early renewal at lower rents. Since leases are generally binding even if the building changes hands, lenders fear being locked into below-market rents if they have to foreclose on the building some years hence.
"The biggest hurdle is finding a landlord whose lender will let the owner do the early renewal," said Joseph G. Genovesi, managing director of DG Hart Associates.
Moreover, landlords who do agree to advance renewals often play hardball on the new rent. Many will not lower rents for tenants with more than two years left on their leases, on the assumption that it is too soon for those tenants to go into the rental market anyway.
"You make an educated guess on whether the tenant will renew," said one leasing agent who insisted on anonymity. "If you think they'll stay, you don't reduce their rent."
INCREASINGLY, landlords are insisting that tenants factor their own cost of moving into the rental equation.
Philip R. Sprayregen, a senior vice president at CB Commercial, had one client, a huge financial services firm, that was considering moving from its 325,000 square feet in downtown Manhattan to Brooklyn or New Jersey. Then it realized that moving would cost $100 a foot.
Even if the new landlord reimbursed it for much of that cost, it would have to lay it out, incurring substantial interest expense. If it sublet its space, it would suffer huge losses, and if it didn't, maintaining the rent on that space would cost more than the considerable months of free rent the new landlord would probably agree to.
"We could have found them space at $15 less than what they were paying, but the savings just evaporated in moving expenses," Mr. Sprayregen said.
The firm, which had four years to go on its lease, renewed at a rent within $1 of market and extended the lease for 16 years.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Brian D. Gell, who handles leasing at Seagram Building, in space recently leased to Whittle Communications. (Stacey P. Morgan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Bond Traders Love Clinton, And Vice Versa

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
IT'S a wonderful time to be a bond trader. It's not just that the value of bonds in inventory has risen so far, producing profits and big bonuses. It's also the new respect from Washington.
Almost on an hourly basis, it seems, some Clinton Administration official cites the bond market as evidence of economic health and Wall Street approval. 
 For bond-market veterans, such attention must be heady. The real old-timers can recall a time when the bond desk was the place to which not-so-sharp nephews were sent when in need of work. They couldn't do too much harm there, it was thought.
But now, Washington hails the bond market as a barometer of the nation's health. On the Monday morning after the bombing of the World Trade Center, we learn from a Wall Street Journal reporter who was following the President around, Mr. Clinton asked if the bond market would be affected. He is not reported to have asked about stocks or commodities, although it was the New York commodity exchanges that were most directly affected.
That focus reflects the great Washington hope. Lower interest rates, it is believed, can both stimulate the economy and record a vote of confidence from the financial markets. For sure, such lower rates can save money for a debtor that issues $2 trillion in new securities every year, but Washington's reverence for the bond market seems to go deeper than that. "It's a kind of market mysticism," says James Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer. "I've never seen anything like it in any Administration."
Perhaps it should be viewed as a sentiment indicator. Bullishness on bonds is so ingrained that it is taken for granted that no one who points to low rates will be embarrassed by a serious market reversal. Stock prices are also high, but there is less confidence that they will keep rising, and they are seldom mentioned by politicians.
Mr. Grant recalled the very different attitude toward the bond market shown by Donald T. Regan when he was President Reagan's Treasury Secretary. Mr. Regan, who had run Merrill Lynch and was familiar with many a bond trader, was generally dismissive of their wisdom. Another Reagan aide, the economist Murray Weidenbaum, compared bond traders to "slow students."
As it turned out, he had a point. Bearishness was widespread then, and wrong. "Could it be," asked Mr. Grant, "that the bond market is no more perceptive now, at 6.75 percent, than it was then, at 15 percent?"
Interest rates could, of course, go lower. In 1955, long-term Treasuries yielded less than 3 percent. But it is quite possible that Robert Barbera, the chief economist at Lehman Brothers, is right when he says, "There is more risk than reward in the bond market now."
That is not necessarily bad news for the economy. The lowest interest rates in this century came during the Depression, and there would be few tears, except among bond bulls, if higher rates in 1993 reflected a surge of economic activity.
