HEADLINE: The Unorthodox Behemoth of Law Firms

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
WHEN the managing partners of most of the nation's top law firms gathered recently, the conversation turned to overseas expansion and the hot competition for multinational clients. "Someone said, 'You know, Baker & McKenzie did it right,' " recalled the lawyers' host, Steven Brill, editor of The American Lawyer. "And no one disagreed."
For many at the meeting, it was a case of bowing to the weight of the evidence, even if it was against their instincts. Skeptics have long derided Baker & McKenzie's unusual strategy of knitting lawyers in many countries into a confederation of offices, each of which keeps most of what it earns rather than sending it on to headquarters. Likening Baker to a legendary fast-food franchisor, some call the firm McLaw or McFirm. 
 But for all its critics, Baker has grown into the world's largest law firm by number of attorneys, with 1,640 lawyers in 32 countries. Profits per partner rose 21 percent in fiscal 1991, the fastest among the top 100 firms listed in The American Lawyer's annual survey. While foreign offices have been prestigious money losers for many big-name law firms, Baker's have thrived. And the firm had $505 million in gross revenues in its most recent fiscal year, which would be enough to overtake Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom of New York for the No. 1 ranking by revenues in the survey to be published this June if, as rumored, Skadden's revenues were flat in 1992.
Baker differs strikingly from the typical American law firm that does work overseas. In fact, it describes itself as an international law firm rather than an American one with offices abroad. Its attorneys represent 45 nationalities and speak 60 languages, and the majority live outside the United States. By contrast, the typical American firm deals with international markets through a handful of overseas offices tightly controlled from the United States. Most are heavily populated by Americans who plan to return to the United States within a few years.
 
'Eat What You Kill'
 Baker's compensation scheme is also unusual. For established offices, no more than 25 percent of payments from a client go to the main office here, where they are used for firm expenses like business development, communications systems, support for new offices or practices, and a fund that provides extra compensation to worldwide partners based on seniority. But most of the money stays right where the actual work is done and is divided as the local partners see fit. The policy has been dubbed "Eat What You Kill."
By contrast, partners at most other firms contribute a far larger percentage of their billings to their firm's coffers and share more equally in the payout. And the main office controls the allocation of compensation in the local offices.
Baker is also unusual in that each month it distributes a 120-page booklet to every office showing every partner's billings and expenses for the month and the year to date. At other firms, few partners regularly receive detailed financial reports.
"Baker is so distinctive that we left it out of many of the charts in our book," said Marc Galanter, a visiting law professor at Stanford whose "Tournament of Lawyers," co-authored with Thomas Palay, is a recent study of the partnership structure of 50 large firms.
Baker's strategy reflects a belief that understanding local cultures and practice is at least as important as understanding local laws in helping clients meet their overseas goals. Consultants say the approach is similar to the tack taken even more successfully by international accounting firms like Arthur Andersen. But they also note that other strategies, like forming alliances with local law firms, can achieve many of the same goals.
Baker's critics imply that in its rush to open offices and willingness to embrace native lawyers, the firm is offering a huge menu but less than four-star fare.
Such accusations have always irked the firm. "Franchise is the F-word at Baker," said Bradford Hildebrandt, a leading consultant to law firms based in Somerville, N.J. But Baker does concede that its strategy and structure have led to uneven levels of quality and that with competition heating up, addressing those defects has to be its top priority.
"We won't stop expanding entirely, but enhancing the network in place is the dominant theme for the next few years," said John V. McGuigan (pronounced mic-WIG-gin), the 44-year-old Australian accountant-turned-lawyer who was elected chairman of the executive committee last year.
 
Chicago Origins
 Founded as a two-man insurance litigation firm here in 1949 by Russell Baker (who died in 1979) and John McKenzie (who died in 1962), Baker & McKenzie has grown to the point where "they are probably doing something somewhere for every major corporation in the world," said Bobbie McMorrow, head of McMorrow Associates, a leading legal recruiting firm based in Los Angeles.
Or even something everywhere. One recent client wanted to know the legal status and tax treatment of stock options in 15 European countries where a company it was acquiring had operations. Another received an evaluation of sex discrimination laws in 17 European countries within 24 hours of bringing the assignment to Baker's London office.
"Half of our time in Eastern Europe is spent on the phone with ministries trying to find out how they will handle things with no precedent," said James T. Hitch 3d, a New York-based partner who once practiced in Yugoslavia and has helped set up Baker operations in Warsaw, Budapest and Prague.
Baker represented Sony of Japan in its acquisition of CBS and Minoru Isutani, the secretive Japanese developer, in his high-profile purchase of the Pebble Beach Company in California. But for a firm its size, Baker actually does remarkably little major acquisitions work or other high-risk corporate finance for its largest clients. In the international sector, this highly lucrative "bet the company" segment of legal practice has been dominated by New York firms like Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton and Coudert Brothers, and old-line British firms.
Profits per partner in Baker's New York office run around $500,000, well above the $375,000 estimated by The American Lawyer for all Baker partners in 1991. But that scarcely breaks into the top 20 for New York. Five firms in the nation's deal-making capital had profits of $1 million or more per partner in 1991, led by Cravath, Swaine & Moore at $1.46 million. Baker is now working to beef up its practice in New York, Los Angeles and other corporate law centers where big deals are usually hatched.
But the larger problem now confronting Baker is whether the structure that has powered its growth could undermine it as the competition for overseas business heats up. Not only are multinational clients developing the in-house skills to handle some jobs they used to farm out to Baker, they also have more choices than ever if Baker fails to keep them happy. And other law firms are competing with Baker to hire foreign-born lawyers who also have extensive experience with American law, or to establish cooperative relationships.
"People have become much more aggressive about going overseas," said Isaac Shapiro, senior partner in charge of overseas business for Skadden Arps. Skadden, for instance, has opened 12 overseas offices with 60 lawyers since recruiting Mr. Shapiro in 1986 to head the effort.
 
Tougher Competition
 One sign of the intensity of the competition was how long it took Baker to get established in Prague, where it finally opened last month. Local attorneys whom Baker had courted were afraid that joining the firm would cost them too much lucrative referral business from London firms, and a number of American lawyers of Czech background had already been snapped up by other firms. A key piece finally fell into place when Baker lured Martin Radvan, a Czech, from Skadden.
In such an environment, there is less leeway for poorly written documents, slow response times, failure to anticipate client concerns, confusing billing or other quality lapses. Nor can Baker ignore the feathers ruffled when a local office pursuing its own profits offends a big company that is a major client for numerous other Baker offices, perhaps by representing a local company against it.
Baker attorneys say such conflicts are not a major problem. But senior partners like Robert Cox, Mr. McGuigan's predecessor as chairman, say they are devoting more time to coordinating relations with major clients.
An enterprise as democratically organized and diverse as Baker will never find it easy to develop and enforce firm-wide standards. But clients and other lawyers who might refer business to Baker are blunt in saying something must be done.
"I can think of some places where I'd use them as co-counsel and some where I wouldn't," said Michael Silverman, who oversees offices in Eastern Europe for Squire Sanders & Dempsey.
Some recruiters, including Ms. McMorrow, say these quality shortfalls make it almost impossible to recruit "rainmakers," attorneys who have the most lucrative clientele or are seen as the experts in their field.
"One client with a really big international practice told me just this past weekend, 'They have the offices I need but they are just not strong enough consistently,' " Ms. McMorrow said recently.
 
A Drive for Quality
 Baker attorneys say that the quality problems are exaggerated, but that any perception that they exist is a serious concern. Roger W. Rosendahl, who recently moved his international practice to Baker's Los Angeles office from Donovan Leisure Newton & Irvine, conceded, "I'm still measuring whether my clients see my being here as an advantage."
Since last summer, Mr. McGuigan has been Baker's point man in the drive to face up to the quality challenge. His predecessor, Mr. Cox, is an engaging, energetic master of the personal touch. Mr. McGuigan, an extremely competitive sports enthusiast whose concession to aging has been to switch from rugby to tennis, is relying on more than diplomacy to improve performance levels.
Baker recently named Frank Wheeler, a former senior vice president at the Great Lakes Chemical Corporation, one of the region's most successful industrial companies, to become chief operating officer of the firm. His mandate: to study how communications systems and other support functions can be improved.
Baker has also retained consultants to poll its members on their views of each other's strengths and weaknesses, and Mr. McGuigan made the quality campaign a major focus of discussions at the recent executive committee meeting in Taipei and regional partners meeting in Manila.
Spending on training associates has doubled to $700,000 in the past three years and the budget for other professional development has shot to $1.2 million from $350,000.
 
Creating a Family
 Mr. McGuigan and other senior partners are counting on a reservoir of family feeling in the firm to help the quality drive. Russell Baker, the firm's founder, was famous for putting up young lawyers at his home. Spouses are routinely included in regional meetings. Mr. Cox happily recalls the time several years ago when the firm put together an international cookbook, and says he spent a great deal of his tenure worrying about how to preserve warmth as Baker grew.
One technique has been to subdivide the firm into regions and practice specialties (there are now more than 40), and to encourage relationships within these groups. The firm has been supporting a growing number of meetings like its annual briefing here on environmental law developments around the world.
"I got answers right there instead of having to leave my questions," said Lloyd A. Stewart, an environmental executive for Tenneco Inc. who attended the most recent such briefing here last June.
Baker also brings associates from around the world to meet socially. And at any given time, it has 40 or 50 of them posted to offices far from the one that hired them to strengthen their understanding of its network.
The ultimate decisions are made by the annual worldwide partners meeting, which resembles nothing so much as a meeting of the United Nations General Assembly, according to former guests. The chances of any centralized clique forcing change are further reduced by the firm's practice of not allowing executive committee members to serve more than four years.
"The process can slow us down and raise costs," said Mr. McGuigan, who said Baker is considering assigning some annual meeting decisions to the 60-member policy meeting.
But that process is also what has made Baker a much more cohesive and powerful enterprise than detractors thought possible. Said Mr. Rosendahl, the new partner in the Los Angeles office: "It's more of a centralized vision than people realize."
 
 
 
HE'LL 'CARRY THE MESSAGE'
 BAKER & MCKENZIE underscored its international outlook by choosing John V. McGuigan, an Australian in charge of its Hong Kong office, to succeed Robert Cox as chairman of its executive committee. Trained as an economist at Sidney University, Mr. McGuigan, now 44, picked up his law degree by attending night school there while working as an accountant for Price Waterhouse. He joined Baker in 1973.
Mr. McGuigan started out providing tax and general corporate law advice to mining and oil companies, a practice that spilled over into mergers and acquisitions involving Japanese and American companies that invested heavily in Australia in the early 1980's. He moved to Hong Kong in 1985, where he oversaw a quintupling of Baker's revenues over the next six years and the opening of offices in Shanghai and Guangzhou.
Mr. McGuigan emerged as chairman from a year-long process that involved interviewing 158 partners viewed as possible candidates. "He's very sharp financially, he has zeal and passion, and he's willing to go anywhere to carry the message," Mr. Cox said.
No American city could have been better suited to Mr. McGuigan's temperament than sports-crazy Chicago. But his wife, Rondel, and their four children have a better shot at putting down roots, because Baker business keeps Mr. McGuigan on the road about 60 percent of the time.

 
 
MEANWHILE, THERE'S TROUBLE BACK AT HOME
 While no overseas country seems too foreign for Baker & McKenzie to take root in, the firm has not always fared so well in this country.
An office set up in Minneapolis in the late 1970's generated so little business that it became the only one Baker has ever permanently closed. More recently and more painfully, Baker's attempt to establish a beachhead in Los Angeles by absorbing Macdonald, Halsted and Layborne, a 70-lawyer Los Angeles firm, has been an expensive fiasco. Baker added lawyers to the office but the expansion coincided with the collapse of the local economy. That left local partners in debt to the firm. Baker has invested nearly $1 million trying to steady the rocking ship, which several key Macdonald veterans have abandoned.
"Ten years from now, there won't be any sign of these problems," said Robert Cox, Baker's former managing partner. "But you have to deal openly with your mistakes."
Baker has also in recent years been confronted by a complaint to the New York Division of Human Rights that it fired a lawyer because he had AIDS and by a lawsuit in Chicago from an attorney who accused the firm of age and sex discrimination. The administrative law judge in the New York case last summer concluded that Baker should pay $1 million in damages plus lost pay to the estate of the lawyer, who died in 1987. Baker contested the findings and the case is now before Margarita Rosa, the State Commissioner of Human Rights. The Chicago case has not gone to trial.
Perhaps the most humiliating incident occurred in December 1988, when a Baker partner on a recruiting trip to the University of Chicago asked a black student how she would handle being called "black bitch" by another lawyer. Chicago, Stanford, the University of California at Berkeley and Georgetown University temporarily banned Baker from recruiting at their law schools and Harvard University put the firm on probation. Baker forced the partner to retire, stepped up efforts to recruit minority-group members and gave money to law schools for minority scholarships.
Baker's lack of pro bono work, as charitable law practice is known, has left it with scant good will on which to fall back when bad publicity surfaces. Although one of its founders, Russell Baker, was known in Chicago's Mexican neighborhoods during the Depression as one of the few Spanish-speaking members of the local bar willing to defend the poor, pro bono is, in the words of John McGuigan, the current managing partner, "not part of the firm's corporate culture." Until Mr. Cox's recent efforts to establish an International Press Center here, Baker has been almost invisible in Chicago civic affairs.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Turning Up Roses in Tokyo

BYLINE: By Andrew Pollack

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
IF one looked only at the Tokyo stock market, it almost seemed as if Japan's bubble economy had returned.
The market broke out of its doldrums and climbed for six consecutive days, including a stunning 5 percent rise on Monday. The Nikkei average of 225 selected stocks closed on Friday at 18,037.52, or 7.6 percent above the close on March 4; it was the index's first finish above 18,000 since September. On two days during the rise, trading volume reached 800 million shares, several times the recent average. 
 But looking outside the stock market, Japan seems in the same old rut. Almost daily, another company announces a loss for the year or a workforce reduction. Business confidence is at its lowest point in two decades. And on Friday, the Government announced that Japan's gross national product grew at an anemic annualized rate of only 0.5 percent in the fourth quarter. The gross domestic product actually fell for the third consecutive quarter.
Is this a contradiction? Yes, say some analysts, who think the stock market is heading for another fall. No, optimists say, contending that the market has finally bottomed out and has nowhere to go now but up.
One reason for optimism is that the Government has been directing public pension funds into the stock market to prop up prices and has been urging companies not to sell their holdings.
Moreover, some analysts say, Japan's economy has been hit by so much bad news that investors have become numb. The market barely reacted, for instance, to the strengthening of the yen in the last month, which threatens to hurt Japan's important automobile and electronics exports.
"It's been through three years of pneumonia," said Kathy Matsui, strategist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities. "Another bout of sneezes is not going to throw the market out of whack."
But analysts also say that what is now occurring is investment in advance of an economic recovery. That recovery is not expected until the end of 1993 or even later, but by the time it becomes evident, it might be too late to invest in stocks while they are still cheap.
"We can't really say we've turned the corner, but we have seen an improvement in sentiment," Ms. Matsui said.
Foreign investors, who had long neglected the Tokyo stock market, seemed to be taking bigger positions, she said. And Japanese institutional investors, while not plunging in, are at least getting nervous about sitting on the sidelines.
There are some valid reasons for this optimism. Japan's Government has been making stronger statements recently that it will enact another big economic stimulus package this year. And if the United States continues its economic recovery, exporters like automobile and electronics companies might benefit from increased demand.
Companies are also starting to become more aggressive in restructuring, although their measures -- reduced hiring and voluntary retirements -- are far less severe than those used in the United States. Even if Japanese companies do not return to their former robust strength, any increase in profits could lead to a gain in stock price.
Yuichi Matsushita, strategist at Nikko Securities, said the market sentiment regarding corporate cutbacks had changed. Last year, he said, when a company announced a loss or a work force reduction, investors took it as a sign of economic trouble, and the market declined. "But these days, whenever a company announces a restructuring, the market reacts positively," interpreting it as a step toward recovery, he said.
No stock has benefited more from changing sentiment than giant Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, the market's largest issue and long the villain. The precipitous fall of NTT stock in the last couple of years seemed to epitomize the Tokyo market's problems.
But in the last two weeks, telephone company shares have shot up more than 30 percent, closing Friday at 810,000 yen, up 15,000 yen for the day. Investors were reacting favorably to an announcement by the company that it would shed 30,000 jobs in the next few years and to the prospect that rates would be raised for local phone calls. In addition, Government officials are talking about building a modern telecommunications system to stimulate the economy.
The problem with investing in anticipation of a recovery is that the market could go back down if the recovery does not materialize. Noboru Kawai, chief economist for Morgan Stanley Japan, said the market's rise last week was caused by peculiar factors, "none of which is really sustainable."
One factor causing the rise, he said, was the mistaken notion that "the economy and corporate earnings situation is getting so bad it must be close to the bottom."
Mr. Kawai expects the economy to remain in a slump through 1993 and into 1994 and predicts that earnings in the coming fiscal year will be even worse than in this year. Corporate investment will not increase, and consumer spending, which is extremely weak, will continue to be depressed, as more people lose their jobs, he said.
Mr. Kawai said that while he thinks the current level can be maintained for a while, the market will trade in the range of 16,000 to 18,500 in coming months, meaning that stocks are now about as high as they will go. Investors who have wanted to sell stock will take advantage of the recent rise to do so, putting more pressure on prices.

HEADLINE: At Work;
More Than Labor Amity at A.T.& T.

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble

 BODY:
WHEN A.T.& T. and its unions settled their differences and signed a contract last year, the talk afterward was of mutual interests, shared goals and cooperation in service of defeating a common enemy, global competition. Conspicuously absent was the rowdy take-it-easy-but-take-it language associated in the public's imagination with collective bargaining. There was amity, but of a sort that tends to fade.
Except this year, it didn't. Last week, 1,000 members of the A.T.& T. work force, roughly divided between management and two A.T.& T. unions, the Communications Workers of America and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, gathered at a conference center in the New Jersey wilderness. The object: to prepare for the "Workplace of the Future," a company-union initiative instigated by a clause in the 1992 contract calling for labor participation in business strategy decisions. 
 The spectacle of labor coming to the table with management, to praise mutually, not to bury, was, in the words of one longtime A.T.& T. executive, "something not seen before in my time." Cheered on in a keynote address by Labor Secretary Robert Reich, the two ancient rivals spent the day plotting A.T.& T.'s future.
Worker participation is not entirely new at A.T.& T. Almost 10 years ago, the union tried to improve its members' lot with a "quality of life" proposal. The company has experimented with labor-management projects. Some of the programs continue, but some failed, victims of labor upheavals, personnel departures or restructurings.
But the new contract calls for an unusual degree of labor-management cooperation that can be achieved only by a huge change in culture. It is the type of change Mr. Reich and other members of Bill Clinton's policy wonkocracy consider critical to restoring civility to employee-employer relations and, with it, oomph to the American economy.
A.T.& T. could try hauling into the next century on its current management paradigms and generally impregnable behemothness. But the suburban New Jersey-based telecommunications giant does not want to become a pregnable behemoth, like its neighbor to the northeast, I.B.M. "It's a bread-and-butter issue," said Burke Stinson, an A.T.& T. spokesman.
Telecommunications has not been an especially cheerful industry since 1984, when its monopoly protection went the way of the Nehru jacket. Labor strife increased. Yippy little counter-behemoths like MCI and Sprint began circling A.T.& T.'s ankles. Hence the company's interest in strategies that might smooth its return to a clear and peaceful domination of its world markets.
What's in it for the unions? Why give up the pleasure of the barricades for -- gag -- collaboration? In the years before 1992, "the union was in a reactive mode," said Morton Bahr, C.W.A. president. "We had no role in the decision-making process. Everything that was negotiated took place essentially after decisions were made. This contract guarantees us, in writing, to be involved in the information-sharing process that's so necessary before decisions are made."
THE appropriate buzz phrase for what Mr. Bahr is talking about is "worker empowerment," which stands in for the cornier and unwieldy "giving workers dignity by giving them some control over their lives." Theoretically, at least, the contract could lead to the quality-of-worklife improvements the C.W.A. has sought before. Theoretically it could also institutionalize something unions have been trying to tell management, at different volumes, for years: A happy worker is a more productive worker.
In return for flexibility, the unions get a voice and a company commitment to, among other things, employment security, education and training or retraining.
A.T.& T. seems genuinely intent on reconfiguring its corporate culture, a task likened by one conference participant to "turning an aircraft carrier around." There is agreement between the parties that the workplace of the future will have four components: "workplace models," strategies for promoting change; business unit/division planning councils to improve customer satisfaction; the constructive relationship council, a remnant of the 1989 contract agreement that will review contract-related issues, and a human resources board whose scope will include external issues like health care that have an impact on A.T.& T. employees.
Resistance to the impending change tends to come from lower- and middle-management, which probably has the most to lose by the convergence of blue-collar and white-collar interests. "There is a lot of resistance to the sharing of power," said William Ketchum, the A.T.& T. executive responsible for the initiative. Similarly, union resistance tends to come not from the rank and file but from the local-president level, which worries about being usurped by the new model. Resistance -- table-pounding as Mr. Bahr put it -- may be satisfying but futile. Both the unions and A.T.& T. seem convinced that they've seen the future, and it works.
 
 
 
THE REICH VISION FOR THE WORKPLACE
 WHEN Bill Clinton appointed Robert Reich as Labor Secretary, it looked as if the prolific, professorial ur-F.O.B. was settling for a lesser post than he had expected. After all, Labor Secretaries of the Reagan-Bush years, three of whom were female, tended to behave in the manner of First Ladies, picking worthy, high-profile causes while allowing the more traditional functions of the department to wither.
Mr. Reich says he got the post he asked for. He has informally renamed Labor the Department of the American Work Force and clearly means to move it toward a position of influence in economic policy making. His appearance at A.T.& T.'s "Workplace of the Future" conference indicated the Clinton Administration's support for initiatives that may increase productivity and competitiveness.
Will the Secretary use his muscle to impose his vision of the workplace of the future? "The Clinton Administration is about shared responsibility," Mr. Reich told a news conference at A.T.& T. "We will do everything we possibly can to create a climate in which American managers and American workers are encouraged to generate better products and highly productive workplaces, but in the end, it's up to workers and managers to do it. In this respect, I'm a cheerleader."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Counting Down to April 15

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
WHY are so many tax-free bond fund investors receiving year-end statements reporting taxable gains and income in 1992? Answers to this and other reader questions about taxes and fund investing may help as April 15 approaches.
Question: I bought shares in a tax-free bond fund last year and I just received a Form 1099-DIV that shows I earned taxable capital gains and income. How can that be? 
 Answer: Because interest rates fell during 1992, pushing up bond prices, many tax-free bond fund managers earned trading gains on which investors do owe income taxes; only the dividends paid by these funds are tax-free. Profits earned on issues held more than one year would be long-term gains, taxed at a top rate of 28 percent; profits from short-term trades would be passed along as ordinary income, taxable up to 31 percent.
Q: I'd like to move my existing individual retirement account money from one mutual fund to another, but I'm confused about how the new withholding rules apply.
A: You're referring to the law that took effect Jan. 1 requiring companies to withhold 20 percent for income taxes from some distributions from company-sponsored retirement plans. These rules do not apply to distributions from I.R.A.'s, said Robert M. Fields, an attorney with Reid & Priest, in New York.
If you move your I.R.A. yourself, you can avoid all taxes and penalties by reinvesting it in another I.R.A. within 60 days, which you can do once a year. But you can also move it as often as you like without penalty or taxes by directing a "trustee-to-trustee" transfer directly between I.R.A. custodians; this requires completing a "Change of Trustee" form that authorizes the mutual fund group to take the money from your old I.R.A.
Similarly, money from a pension or profit-sharing plan that is directly transferred to an I.R.A. avoids the new withholding rules. But the same money when withdrawn by the employee and then reinvested in a rollover I.R.A. is generally subject to withholding and the investor only receives 80 percent of the distribution. If the investor, however, is able to add back the 20 percent to reinvest the full amount in the I.R.A., then taxes are avoided and the amount withheld may be refundable.
Q: Like many people seeking higher yields, I bought shares in a short-term bond fund last year. My 1992 Form 1099-DIV from the Scudder Short-Term Bond Fund reports nontaxable distributions and instructs me to reduce my shares' basis by that amount when I sell. Please advise.
A: The fund's dividends are figured using generally accepted accounting principles, which can differ from the methods required to figure taxable income, and can therefore result in different income amounts being reported to the Internal Revenue Service and on the fund's statements to the investor.
In the Scudder case, two losses in 1992 -- currency losses on foreign issues and losses on premium Ginnie Mae securities -- were reported differently, forcing the fund to pay a bigger dividend than it actually earned for tax purposes. So the fund returned a portion of its distribution to investors in the form of capital, said Daniel B. Gross, a principal with Scudder, Stevens & Clark, in Boston.
Because return-of-capital dividends represent your own investment in the fund, not the fund's earnings, you owe no income taxes. The amounts do, however, reduce your "basis," that is, what you paid for the shares plus any adjustments, like this, since the purchase. When you sell any shares, your taxable gain equals the difference between the basis and the sale proceeds, so reducing the basis increases the capital gains owed when you sell the shares.
Q: I own shares in the Oppenheimer Equity-Income Fund in a tax-sheltered annuity, but think the $200 annuity fee is too high. Can I take out the money without penalty?
A: You must have purchased shares through an outside annuity provider because Oppenheimer charges $10 a year for annuities, said Bob Zack, senior vice president of the Oppenheimer Management Corporation. Fees range from $25 to $50 a year, he said.
There is a penalty for taking money out of a tax-sheltered annuity: 10 percent of the amount withdrawn plus income tax figured at your regular rates. One way to avoid the penalty is by moving the money into another annuity in a trustee-to-trustee transfer.
Q: I want to use the money I invested in mutual funds for my Keogh plan contributions. Can I just transfer the shares?
A: The law is unclear and the Supreme Court has agreed to decide the issue. One Federal appeals court has ruled that you must sell your shares in the fund and then contribute the proceeds to the Keogh. That means you would owe income taxes on any profits from the sale, even if you bought shares in the same fund for the Keogh.
Another court said that pension plan contributions may be made "in kind," for example, in the form of the mutual fund shares themselves, rather than in cash. In that case, taxes are still due on any unrealized gain in the shares (the full market value of the shares when they are contributed minus your basis in the shares), but you will not have had to pay any transaction costs, assuming you are dealing with a "load" fund, or, if a "no-load" fund, you will at least avoid the transaction hassle, Mr. Fields said.

HEADLINE: Russia May Be A Spectacle Beyond Reach

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
CAN Bill Clinton save Boris Yeltsin?
The American President can embrace his Russian counterpart, send him food and money, promise to help reschedule his debts, invite him to a summit in Canada, ask him to help solve crises in the Balkans and the Middle East and maybe even look the other way if Mr. Yeltsin does some undemocratic things in the name of democracy.
But he cannot resolve Russia's constitutional crisis, make Mr. Yeltsin less a bully and more a statesman, pass a Russian code for private property, stabilize the ruble, dismantle Russia's nuclear arms, wipe out a bureaucratic mindset or settle Russia's disputes with Ukraine. 
 On Friday, after a hostile Russian Congress voted to slash Mr. Yeltsin's authority, the Russian President stalked out of the Grand Kremlin Palace, pledging to call a referendum on his own to decide who should rule his country. In the past week the Clinton Administration issued enthusiastic statements and announced initiatives to puff up Mr. Yeltsin in his showdown with his conservative foes, including a call for an early summit of the world's industrialized giants to devise an aid strategy and a donation of $102 million of American grain. But strip away the frenzy, and there was little that Mr. Clinton could do but sit on the sidelines and watch the drama play out.
For better or worse, Mr. Clinton has foreign policy elders like former President Richard Nixon looking over his shoulder and whispering in his ear that the only place he can prove his diplomatic manhood is in Moscow. "He can secure his place in history as a great President," Mr. Nixon wrote in an article on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times last week, if he shows the same "boldness and political courage" in addressing the Russia problem as he is showing with his domestic economic program. Mr. Nixon's similar -- and relentless -- campaign with President Bush last spring ultimately humiliated Mr. Clinton's predecessor into taking more aggressive steps to help Mr. Yeltsin, and Mr. Nixon obviously hopes it will work again.
Mr. Clinton has enough of a political ego that he wants neither to go down in history as the President who lost Russia nor to admit that there are limits to what American power can do in the post-Cold War world. But he has repeatedly vowed not to get engulfed in things foreign, and he knows that even if the United States and the West had endless funds to pour down the Russian rathole, it would not guarantee the triumph of Western-style capitalism and economic reform.
"Nobody on the outside can save a huge and complex country like Russia," said Dimitri Simes of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, who, paradoxically, is Mr. Nixon's adviser on Russia. "If these people want to continue with gridlock, if they want to be at each other's throats all the time, if they want to completely undermine confidence in the central Government and risk that the
provinces and the regions go their own way, no foreign influence can change the situation."
Mr. Clinton knows that it costs Germany more than $100 billion a year to rebuild its eastern half, and that South Korea estimates it will take just short of a trillion dollars to bring North Korea into the 21st century should there be reunification. He has not decided just how much political and financial capital to spend on Russia, but he is unlikely to follow Mr. Nixon's advice slavishly and mount the same campaign for Russia that he is doing for the domestic economy. That would require not only massive new aid, but also a full-scale scare campaign to persuade Americans that the alternative is a return to totalitarian rule in Moscow and to bomb shelters at home.
And at a time when the Pentagon has announced the closing of scores of military installations, even that argument might not convince Americans that they should pay for housing for demobilized Russian soldiers and re-employing Russian nuclear scientists. Some American lawmakers have even called for a revolution of a different sort to help Mr. Yeltsin, suggesting that the Administration might take some money from foreign aid's most sacred cow: the $5.1 billion that goes to Israel and Egypt every year.
American presidents have often had difficulty abandoning friendly foreign leaders who are in trouble. During the campaign last year, Mr. Clinton castigated Mr. Bush for clinging to Mikhail S. Gorbachev after it appeared that he was no longer democratic enough. "Time and again, this Administration has sided with stability over democratic change," Mr. Clinton said.
But now that he is President, Mr. Clinton is dealing with a Russian leader who appears to represent both stability and democratic change. Clearly, the Clinton Administration is frustrated that despite its desire for Mr. Yeltsin to prevail, it is unable to shape or even predict the course of the unfolding revolutionary process in Moscow. When asked last week about Mr. Yeltsin's chances for survival, Mr. Clinton said he would support Mr. Yeltsin as long as he remains Russia's President, before admitting: "You know, I don't know what else to tell you. I'm not a seer."
 
High-Stakes Chicken
 One of Mr. Clinton's top aides on Russia has suggested that the Administration would not oppose a move by Mr. Yeltsin to make good on his threats to consolidate power by suspending what is considered an undemocratic Parliament or abolishing the Soviet-era Constitution. For now, the Administration is convinced that Mr. Yeltsin's threats are just one element in a high-stakes game of chicken among politicians unused to democracy. But Administration officials said they would draw the line if Mr. Yeltsin tried the "Fujimori solution" -- a reference to the use of Peru's military by President Alberto Fujimori last year to dissolve Congress and arrest opposition leaders.
And Secretary of State Warren Christopher told Russia's foreign minister Andrei V. Kozyrev in a telephone conversation on Friday that he hoped any action Mr. Yeltsin might take be consistent with the principles of democracy and human rights.
Mr. Yeltsin's battle with his Congress fuels the pessimists who have already declared Russia's reform movement dead. "We looked at this situation and saw democracy, markets, happy days are here again and what we forgot is that this stage is likely to be a very small blip on the course of Russian history, which has never gone through any prolonged enlightened process," said Marshall I. Goldman, a Russia expert.
Such a view is anathema to the Clinton Administration, which argues that Russia moves in fits and starts, that the players may shout and threaten and storm out of meetings as a way to maximize their positions, but in the end they tend to call a truce and share power. Still, it is hard to see how the man who is scheduled to sit down with Mr. Clinton in Vancouver early next month will be anything but severely weakened.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
'Lead . . . or Leave' Asks: Who's Spending Our Inheritance?

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

 BODY:
The words travel slowly across the computer screens in the downtown Washington office: "Lead . . . or Leave." This political signature of angry young fiscal Puritans doubles as a screen-saver program, somehow fitting for the rallying cry of the first generation to grow up with computers.
Less than nine months since the words were first typed onto a screen, the group Lead . . . or Leave is commanding the attention of senators, college students and Ross Perot. Its founders, clustered in donated office space in downtown Washington, the heartland of the special-interest lobbyists they deplore, have a grandiose vision: that the impact of their ideas may rival that of the antiwar crusade of the 1960's. 
 Except that one was about death. This one is about taxes or, more properly, about Uncle Sam's bills and who is going to pay them.
"The deficit," said a co-founder, Rob Nelson, "is our Vietnam." The first-person plural refers to the men, women and children born during and after that war. "There was a 14-year-old kid at our rally in Montgomery, Ala., last month," Mr. Nelson said. "Someone shoved a microphone in his face and asked if he knew what it was about. He said, 'Somebody borrowed a bunch of money, I'm getting the bill, I'm going to have to pay it, and I don't get anything for it.' Believe me, these kids get it."
Generational politics is a verity older than the nation-state, but one that has become permanently enshrined in American culture during this century with everything from the Silent Generation to the Vietnam Generation.
Mr. Nelson, 29, and his colleague Jon Cowan, 27, say even if generational struggles are traditional, Lead . . . or Leave is different. Like soldiers who arrived at the ammunition depot just as the ammunition ran out, they are fighting for the right to fight, for the right to inherit a government that will have something more than spare change to spend on them and their visions. They feel the Clinton budget could improve their lot, but not as much as they would like.
"The nation went on a vast spending spree that didn't produce anything but bills," said Mr. Cowan, who was an aide to former Democratic Representative Mel Levine of California. "Now we not only have a financial deficit, but a social deficit, an environmental deficit, an infrastructure deficit. We're selling out the American dream. Whether you're a liberal and you want a new War on Poverty or you're a conservative and want a capital gains tax cut, you can't do any of it."
 
Mighty MitesA Message
 Measured in standard terms, Lead . . . or Leave is a tiny ground-dweller in the political jungle, with neither membership (1,000 and growing) nor money nor much but a message. A year ago, its issue -- the deficit -- was talked about but seemed dry as dust. But by casting its members as children cheated by their irresponsible parents, the group is riding high on the new concept of generational accounting.
Generational accounting itself is a 90's creation, the brainchild of three economists: Laurence J. Kotlikoff of Boston University, Alan Auerbach of the University of Pennsylvania and Jagadeesh Gokhale of the Cleveland Federal Reserve Bank. Adding to the political-economic dictionary, they created a new economic yardstick, lifetime tax rates. By these measurements, Mr. Kotlikoff predicts, the lifetime tax rate for Americans born in 1900 was 21.5 percent. For Americans born in 1990, the lifetime tax rate will be 33.5 percent.
In these calculations, which define taxes as total tax payments minus total income transfers like Social Security, the trajectory is relentless: the later people are born, the more they will work for everyone else and the less for themselves. "This," Mr. Kotlikoff said, "is the natural outgrowth of four decades of Government pursuing a variety of different policies -- most of which don't show up on the Government's books -- to expropriate the young and future generations for the benefit of older generations."
However, advocates of the current Social Security structure, including the American Association of Retired Persons, argue that Social Security is a self-contained system that actually helps offset Government debt. A.A.R.P. is one of the principal targets on Lead. . .or Leave's most-wanted list of special interests. It was on that lobby's doorstep that these angry young men and women held a rally last month to protest the debts they said were being bequeathed to them.
Mr. Nelson and Mr. Cowan also reject the idea that they are simply the generational mirror-image of A.A.R.P. "What we want to do will help everyone," said Mr. Nelson, who did graduate study in international relations before deciding that he cared more about the situation at home. However, he does not favor cuts in student loans, which he sees as investment in the future.
Martha Farnsworth Riche, who heads the Population Reference Bureau in Washington, agrees with the world view of Lead . . . or Leave. "This is the first time in the country's history the population pyramid has changed shape," Ms. Riche said. The pyramid is a demographers' representation of successive generations, younger underneath the older. But since the 1970's, the pyramid has begun to look like a pillar with the baby-boom section giving it the appearance of middle-aged spread.
"Right now the number of older people, 55-plus, is proportionately larger than we've ever seen before -- but nothing like what we'll see in 20 years," Ms. Riche said. She believes the nation has a momentary political opportunity -- while the boomers are still paying into the system and before they have an interest in reaping their own entitlement benefits -- to change entitlements to lessen the burden on the future's young workers.
Robert Avery, a Cornell University economist, is nervous about neat generational schematics. While he agrees that the problems posed by the deficit are enormous, he said there are other issues, including health care, raising the retirement age and the potential impact of a disease like AIDS on the wage-earning population. He reminds worried young workers that some of those Government transfer payments will be coming back to them as inheritances.
"The real issue here is uncertainty," Mr. Avery said. "It's very hard to write long-term contracts between the generations when we don't know what's going to happen."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rob Nelson, left, and Jon Cowan, founders of "Lead . . . or Leave," contend that the Federal deficit leaves the young with no options. (Lisa Berg for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Nonproliferation Treaty Bares Its Toothlessness

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
ONLY a few months ago North Korea seemed like a pathbreaking example of how the world's great powers can set aside other differences to make sure that fanatical leaders and nuclear bombs are kept apart. Faced with overwhelming evidence that the hard-line Communist regime of Kim Il Sung was building a bomb, the United States harnessed the West, and then Russia and China, to stop the project from turning into a nightmare. For most of last year, it looked like the strategy was working.
Beneath his usual cloud of defiant oratory, the 80-year old Mr. Kim finally agreed to live up to his obligations under the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. He allowed international inspectors to visit the mysterious nuclear site called Yongbyon. His motives seemed clear. He sought the trade and investment he desperately needs, especially now that there are reports of food riots and troops stand on rail-side coal piles to keep the residents from stealing enough to heat their homes. 
 On Friday, though, it was Washington's seeming success that turned to coal -- and along with it, much of the world's confidence in the workability of the treaty that 153 nations have signed. In an unnerving and perhaps self-destructive act of defiance, North Korea became the first nation ever to renounce the treaty, barring the door completely to international inspectors who were on the scent of a secret cache of plutonium. Vice Foreign Minister Kang Sok Ju declared that the North had signed the accord in 1985 to reduce what he termed a nuclear threat from South Korea and the United States, and said "We are now withdrawing from it because it is being abused to destroy our republic."
Surprised and more than a little scared, Japan and South Korea denounced the action as destabilizing and dangerous. At the same time, though, there were second thoughts about whether the safeguards designed 25 years ago, in an age of superpower patrons for countries like North Korea, still have any teeth.
 
Something Fishy
 What use is a treaty that allowed a country to develop nuclear weapons for seven years while it barred inspectors -- and that is renounced as soon as the first inspectors in the door smell something fishy? Is the International Atomic Energy Agency, a United Nations affiliate with no enforcement powers, the right institution to keep countries like North Korea in line? And even if the issue goes to the Security Council, what can you take away from a country that has nothing?
"The treaty is no longer quite so sacrosanct today," said Leonard Spector, head of a project on nuclear proliferation on the Korean Peninsula at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. "Now that one country has pulled out, others obviously can begin to think about it."
In many ways the North Korean experience is significantly different from the challenges the West has faced in dealing with nonsignatories -- including India, Pakistan, Israel and Algeria -- and even with countries that have signed and dodged, like Iraq. First, by all accounts, Saddam Hussein seems much farther from realizing his dreams than Kim Il Sung is. Estimates vary widely, but more and more analysts in the United States Government seem to agree that North Korea already has the raw material for at least one bomb, and a few think some crude, still-untested devices may have already been built. Second, North Korea has turned weaponry into its only successful export business; it ships home-grown missiles to the Middle East, and presumably would have few qualms about shipping nuclear weapons.
But perhaps most important, rather than play an Iraq-style game of hide-and-seek with the inspectors, the North has used the access to its nuclear facilities guaranteed by the treaty itself as a bargaining chip. In its statement Friday it said it would only return to the regime if "the United States stops its nuclear threats against the North" -- which was interpreted as a reference to the annual "Team Spirit" military exercises now under way between South Korea and the United States -- and if the atomic energy agency "returns to its principle of independence and impartiality."
In short, Mr. Kim turned a situation in which it held no cards -- he was trying to hold off a "special inspection" of two sites that American spy satellites have identified as waste dumps that would probably show how much plutonium he has produced -- into a situation in which he now holds at least one: re-entry into the treaty. In fact, once a three-month waiting period to exit the treaty expires, his bomb-development work will become legal.
"From the start it was always assumed that if a country did withdraw from the treaty, it would be a signal that they had decided to make a bomb," Gary Milhollin, the head of the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control, said recently. "If not, why take the political heat?"
What got everyone to this point is a 25-year-old system that acknowledges the right of every nation to use nuclear materials for peaceful purposes, even if those same materials, especially plutonium, are relatively simple to rework into weapons. It is the "safeguards" system of inspection that is supposed to assure that materials intended for civilian plants stay in civilian use.
The biggest advocates of that system are countries like Japan, which is already extracting plutonium from nuclear waste, much as North Korea is trying to do, as part of its aggressive civilian nuclear power program. These days the Japanese find themselves in the diplomatically embarrassing position of arguing that they have every right to do so because the world recognizes them as a solid international citizen, while at the same time arguing that their North Korean neighbors must be denied the right because they have an attitude problem.
 
Plutonium Politics
 The North Koreans, naturally, say that their intentions are benign and that the I.A.E.A. is "tacitly approving" moves by Japan and South Korea to secretly arm themselves.
"We are seeing the breakdown of a regime that believed that plutonium and bomb-grade material are O.K. as long as they are under safeguard," said Paul L. Leventhal, president of the Nuclear Control Institute and a harsh critic of the precedent set by Japan's plutonium effort.
Officials in Japan and South Korea, naturally, say they have no interest in nuclear arms. The Japanese have long renounced them, and South Korea stopped developing them after the United States got wind of its project in the late 1970's. But preventing such an arms race has always depended on Seoul and Tokyo remaining unshakably confident that the United States' support, and its nuclear umbrella, extends over them.
Though few will say it publicly, that is what the Team Spirit exercise, which was suspended last year when the North looked like it was beginning to cooperate, is all about. This year the United States brought the B-1B bomber and other nuclear-capable equipment to South Korea for the exercises, presumably to make a point. And it was exactly that which sent the North into a frenzy, declaring early last week that they were going on a "semi-war footing" because invasion was imminent.
Now Washington is in the position of having few attractive options. Some officials, including many in Japan and a few members of the two-week old South Korean Government, argue that going ahead with the 125,000-troop Team Spirit exercise this year is an unnecessary provocation. But it is too late to back down. Though the American military has endless scenarios for eradicating Yongbyon, everyone acknowledges they are of little use: If the North retaliated on Seoul, only 35 miles from the border, or on South Korean civilian nuclear plants, it would be disastrous.
Economic sanctions are likely to have little effect on a country that is already isolated from virtually all of its neighbors except China. Getting the Chinese to seal off that border, and with it food and fuel, is unlikely.
"It may not be over yet," said Mr. Spector. "We are about to see an intense diplomatic effort to get this turned around." But it may be, he said, that the world has little cause to be optimistic: Perhaps the North Koreans knew that they were about to get caught, he said, and the only solution was to jettison the one treaty that could betray them.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
How Serbia's Czar Holds Fast to Power

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia

 BODY:
ISOLATION, lawlessness and brain drain plague Serbia today, along with inflation, unemployment and a United Nations economic embargo. It would be enough to topple political leaders practically anywhere.
But not here. President Slobodan Milosevic, a Communist who metamorphosed into a nationalist, shows no signs of losing his grip on power. 
 That is crucial to the calculations of any diplomat trying to end the agony of the Balkans, because Serbia's leader, having inspired and backed nationalist Serbs in the republics next door, is still regarded as the man who could make them want to stop fighting; Lord Owen, co-chairman with Cyrus Vance of the international mediating effort, has even said he is counting on Mr. Milosevic to restrain Serbia's far right.
In some ways, this might seem outrageous. The United States has included Mr. Milosevic's name on a list of potential war-crimes suspects, and much of the outside world has expressed revulsion at Serb tactics in Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. Besides, Mr. Milosevic has a dismal record for seeking compromise and for keeping his word. But the overriding fact remains that he is firmly in charge and the man who must be dealt with. Indeed, last week he met in Paris with Mr. Owen, Mr. Vance and France's President, Francois Mitterrand, on the peace plan. To remain Serbia's czar, Mr. Milosevic has used a variety of tools, talents and techniques:
Nationalism. Today, nationalism is the only issue that really matters to a great many Serbians. Mr. Milosevic, in the 1980's, was among the first to recognize that this could become the case -- if then-latent nationalist feelings were properly cultivated. He did just that, and as a result is still the master of this issue.
He rose to power pledging to defend Serbs who felt endangered in the Kosovo region, where the overwhelmingly Albanian population wanted more autonomy. Later, facing opposition based on a stagnant economy and his own Communist past, Mr. Milosevic silenced critics by turning attention to wars he promoted in Croatia and Bosnia after those republics seceded from Yugoslavia. The rationale, again, was a claim that Serbian minorities needed protection.
Mr. Milosevic and his proteges have convinced most Serbs that these wars are not a brutal land grab, as much of the world sees them, but a struggle for Serbia's survival against a conspiracy of Islamic fundamentalists, neo-fascist Germans and Croats, Stalinists, the Vatican, the United States and the European Community. Each time pressure on Serbia has mounted, the purported conspiracy has grown more baroque. This adds to an authoritarian frame of mind, and to the notion that speaking out against Mr. Milosevic is akin to treason.
Television. In a land where much of the population is bound to the soil and functionally illiterate, and where newspapers are too expensive for many people, Mr. Milosevic holds full control of the only news outlet that matters: Television Serbia. Its 7:30 evening news broadcast, which surveys show is the only source of current-affairs information for about 65 percent of the population, has functioned since 1988 to instill fear and a siege mentality. In addition, Mr. Milosevic has interwoven what international election observers called ballot-box fraud with his control of television to win two elections in the last two years.
Economic leverage. As Serbia's economy tumbles, Mr. Milosevic's power has, in a seeming paradox, increased. Besides controlling the issuance of the funds that keep bankrupt enterprises, the bureaucracy and the military afloat, he pulls the strings of an old-boy network that operates the republic's large publicly owned enterprises. In exchange for political obedience, economists say, Mr. Milosevic allows enterprise directors free rein. Many have used it to enrich themselves by plundering their companies.
State statistics say about 96 percent of the work force is employed, but in fact a great many workers are idle or under-utilized. Protest about this has not gone beyond grumbling, however; most workers remain loyal to the regime because they fear losing their jobs altogether. Housing is a critical problem, and losing a job often means losing an apartment as well. And pensioners fear that if they speak out, the state could interfere with their monthly payments.
Police power. Mr. Milosevic, who has complete control of the police, has clearly used it to infiltrate opposition parties and news organizations, tap telephones and make house calls on opponents. It is taken as fact here that the police also selectively look the other way at the activities of crime bosses loyal to the President.
Since the official economy is not functioning, even normally law-abiding people are being sucked into the illegal economy. This enhances Mr. Milosevic's power by compromising them, making them susceptible to arrest at any time.
Infighting. Mr. Milosevic is a quintessential apparatchik, demanding total loyalty from those who serve him. His "anti-bureaucracy" campaign in the late 1980's solidified his hold on the bureaucracy by raising fears among government workers that they might lose their jobs.
Mr. Milosevic has stifled potential rivals by shuffling proteges from one position to another, then showing them the door. He has evaded a personal political cost for the devastation left by his policies by using disposable proxies.
Last year he created the office of Yugoslavia's Prime Minister and arranged to have it filled with a Serbian-American millionaire, Milan Panic, in an unsuccessful bid to lull the international community into lifting economic sanctions. Mr. Panic later challenged Mr. Milosevic in an election for Serbia's presidency, the real seat of power; Mr. Milosevic's grip on television, the ballot-counting machinery, and nationalist sentiment proved who was the real boss.
Maneuverability. Mr. Milosevic has unflinchingly broken faith and made tactical retreats to maintain his position. When he was rising to power in Communist Yugoslavia, his best friend was a colleague, Ivan Stambolic, and he professed faith in both socialism and the federalism of Yugoslavia. He abandoned Mr. Stambolic in 1987, and later walked away from Communism and the very idea of Yugoslavia.
His next crusade was to bring all Serbs into one state -- a Greater Serbia. He set in motion Serb militias in Croatia and Bosnia, backed by Yugoslav army resources. But last year, he seemed willing to slow even this scheme when he accepted a U.N. peacekeeping plan in Croatia. "Milosevic has a fantastic ability to adjust and to hide his real intentions," said a now-estranged friend who spoke on condition of anonymity.
"This is not a person who keeps his word, but an opportunist who doesn't know the meaning of the word compromise," the former friend said. "This person only understands force. His whole life has been based on yes and no, all or nothing. In politics, for such people, it always comes to nothing."

HEADLINE: Clinton Defends Backing Yeltsin As Elected Chief

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
President Clinton today rejected criticism that his policy toward Russia was too dependent on the survival of Boris N. Yeltsin, but he declined to say how he would react if the Russian President moved to suspend Parliament or resorted to military force.
In his most detailed comments on the beleaguered Russian leader, Mr. Clinton also asserted that the Group of Seven major industrialized nations should play a more aggressive role in helping Mr. Yeltsin. He said countries with a stake in the future of Russia had given him "an inadequate response to date." 
 The President seemed to be sending a message to senior G-7 officials, who are meeting this weekend in Hong Kong to discuss Russia and prepare for their July meeting in Tokyo, which Mr. Clinton is to attend.
 
'People Voted for Him'
 "In terms of whether we're putting too much reliance on Yeltsin personally," Mr. Clinton said, "my answer to that is we will work with what we have to work with, whatever happens. But I think we should support him because he has been elected, after all. There was an election. People voted for him."
In Moscow today, the power struggle between Mr. Yeltsin and the Congress of People's Deputies deepened as the Congress rejected Mr. Yeltsin's final bid for a national referendum on who should govern Russia. [Page 12.]
When asked if he would continue to support Mr. Yeltsin even if he suspended Parliament or sought to abolish the Soviet-era Constitution to regain power, Mr. Clinton answered, "I don't think it would serve any useful purposes for me to try to interpret the Russian Constitution right now, what it does or doesn't mean or what we would or wouldn't respond to."
The President was also asked how he would react if Mr. Yeltsin resorted to military force but declined to address the question.
Mr. Clinton's comments came during an unusual series of interviews at the White House today with local reporters from three states, in which the President sought to promote his military conversion plan in areas that would be affected by the closing of military bases. The President has not held such sessions with regular White House reporters since taking office, but a reporter from The New York Times was permitted to attend the meeting with reporters from Connecticut, where Mr. Clinton was questioned about his relations with Mr. Yeltsin.
In his session with reporters from Florida, Mr. Clinton demanded that the Haitian Government immediately release a military deserter who had been granted political refugee status by the United States, and he pledged to take a more active role in trying to restore democracy in Haiti.
"I'm very upset about what happened in Haiti," he said.
 
Counting on Group of Seven
 Mr. Clinton said he was counting on the Group of Seven nations to act more boldly to support Mr. Yeltsin's economic and democratic reforms.
"I think that if the major countries, the G-7 countries, that are in a position to support those movements would show a more coordinated and aggressive approach to the problems," he said, "it might be possible to build a consensus in Russia for how they would work with all of us. You know, every elected official has his or her political opponents. That's part of the way the system works."
Noting that he is scheduled to meet with Mr. Yeltsin in Vancouver on April 3 and 4, Mr. Clinton said, "I'll do my best I can to be ready on April 4, which is just a few days from now, with my meeting with President Yeltsin."
Though the President did not address the issue directly, his comments appeared to support those of a senior Administration official who said on Friday that Washington would not oppose a move by Mr. Yeltsin to suspend Parliament. But the official said the United States would react strongly if Mr. Yeltsin resorted to military force.
As Mr. Yeltsin's power has eroded -- Russia's Congress has voted to give itself the power to suspend his decrees and has made it easier to remove him from office for unconstitutional behavior -- Mr. Clinton has not wavered in his defense of the Russian leader.
That has prompted the sort of criticism that President Bush received in refusing to drop his support for Mikhail S. Gorbachev as the former Soviet leader was losing his power. But in detailed comments today, Mr. Clinton explained why he thought that it was necessary for the United States and other countries to do more to support Mr. Yeltsin.
 
'In America's Interests'
 "I'm trying to do what I can to muster the support to do more," President Clinton said, "because I think it's very much in America's interests. And he's the person that I think I should work with. He is the elected President of Russia. That is a fact. And I hope he will continue to be the elected President of Russia.
"But the United States has an interest in a Russia that is not hostile to us, that is not a military enemy, and that frankly has a whole lot more economic growth that the Russia that we know does now. And I'm just trying to respond to that."
Mr. Clinton went on to say: "No one knows what's going to happen. But the man is an honest democrat, small 'd.' And he's passionately committed to reform. And I'm going to keep working with him."
While saying that "I don't think you could have ever predicted an easy ride for democracy and for a market economy in a country which had never had a market economy," the President sounded optimistic. Russia, he said, "can still have a bright future as part of a peaceful coalition of nations in the world."

HEADLINE: Citing Caution, South Korea Puts Troops on Alert

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York TimesSpecial to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 13

 BODY:
 In what it termed a cautionary step, South Korea placed its troops on alert today, but officials said they saw no sign of troop movements or unusual activity in North Korea a day after that country's Government said it would pull out of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.
The alert came as South Korea's military exercises with the United States continued well south of the heavily armed demilitarized zone. North Korea has called the exercises a rehearsal for staging an invasion, and cited them a reason that it became the first nation ever to renounce the treaty. The United States says the annual exercises, which began in 1976, are purely defensive. 
 Leaders of the South Korean Government of President Kim Young Sam, who took office two weeks ago, spent most of the day in meetings deciding how to respond to North Korea's surprise action. But so far Seoul has said little, other than to say that the action "heightens the suspicion" that North Korea is developing nuclear arms. Along with the United States and Japan, South Korea has called on North Korea to retract its decision before it becomes effective in 90 days.
"There are a lot of discussions about what to do next, but the border is very quiet," Ryu Myung Hwan, the spokesman for the South Korean Foreign Ministry, said this afternoon.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher said on Friday that he believed North Korea's withdrawal from the treaty and its refusal to allow inspection of two suspected nuclear sites would likely be taken up by the United Nations Security Council unless the hard-line Communist Government of President Kim Il Sung reversed its course. Today in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, officials repeated their warnings to the United States and other nations not to press for economic sanctions or other pressure in response to North Korea's decision, according to reports on the official state news service monitored in Tokyo.
 
'Semi-War Footing' in North
 "We are fully prepared to take appropriate countermeasures," Kang Sok Jue, North Korea's Vice Minister for Foreign Affairs, was quoted as saying in Pyongyang. He said that the military could "face any offensive and pressure by the enemies."
So far, North Korea has said nothing to suggest that it is preparing any kind of offensive military movement. But earlier in the week, in response to the beginning of the American-South Korean exercises, the Pyongyang Government said it was going on a "semi-war footing" to guard against any attack launched during the exercises.
There are also indications that North Korea, which allows virtually no news from the outside world to enter the country, is being particularly careful that its own people hear only a Government-approved version of the reasons it pulled out of the Nonproliferation Treaty. Japan's official broadcaster, NHK, said today that its Korean-language radio broadcasts into North Korea were being scrambled for the first time in recent memory.
Military alerts for South Korea's 650,000 troops are relatively common. A low-level alert is routine during the exercises, which are an annual source of contention between North and South Korea. Higher-level alerts, like the one issued today, have been declared after border incidents and during special events, like the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul.
But the South Korean press seems less concerned about any imminent conflict than it does about the start of a nuclear arms race on the Korean peninsula. South Korea has said it has no nuclear arms of its own -- the United States stopped a project to develop them in the late 1970's -- and American nuclear weapons were withdrawn from South Korea in late 1991. But there is widespread speculation that if North Korea announces it possesses a nuclear bomb, Seoul will feel compelled to match the capability.
"We are afraid that the North's game will start a chain reaction of nuclear armament," the Hankook Ilbo, a major daily, said in an editorial today. "We warn that this will only bring about an early fall of the North's political system."

HEADLINE: Moscow Official to Ask Aid at Economic Talks

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONG KONG, March 13

 BODY:
A Russian Deputy Prime Minister arrived here today to ask officials of leading industrial nations for economic help for his country and political support for President Boris N. Yeltsin.
The Russian official, Boris G. Fyodorov, was invited to confer with top officials from the Group of Seven who are planning the summit meeting of those nations' leaders to be held in Tokyo in July. The officials from the United States, Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy and Japan are expected to issue a statement showing support for Russia's transition to democracy and a market economy. 
 They may also announce an agreement to hold a minister-level meeting on aid to Russia before the July conference. President Clinton suggested during talks this week with President Francois Mitterrand of France that the Group of Seven consider an emergency meeting prior to the Tokyo summit to discuss the growing crisis in Russia.

HEADLINE: Pledging Florida More Help, Clinton Offers Hope on Base

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
Seeking to head off an outcry from South Florida over proposed closings of military bases, President Clinton said today that he would intensify efforts to aid communities that were devastated by Hurricane Andrew, including keeping the Homestead Air Force Base operating on a reduced scale.
But he was less hopeful for Connecticut, saying for the first time that it was an "open question" whether he could ultimately support construction of another Seawolf attack submarine. He had promised to support the program in last year's campaign. 
 Now, Mr. Clinton said, the future of the Seawolf would be decided in the Administration's budget negotiations with Congress. "I haven't changed my position on it," he said. "But I cannot tell you it's a lock-cinch deal because of what's happened -- because this is sort of a wild card for us. And because I'm obviously involved with the Congress now in trying to work through this."
The President, who has met infrequently with reporters since taking office, today summoned groups of journalists from South Florida, California and Connecticut to the White House. Those states face the loss of thousands of jobs from the proposed base closings announced by the Pentagon on Friday.
 
Plea for Support
 The meetings were part of an intense public relations effort by Mr. Clinton for his plan to convert military installations to civilian uses while reassuring the public that he would create jobs to cushion the losses. That was also the message today in the President's weekly radio address, when he called on Americans to support the spending cuts in his economic package.
"In the days ahead," Mr. Clinton said, "you will hear a great debate in Congress about this plan. Some will say, 'Don't cut anything.' Some will say, 'Don't invest in anything.' But what many of them are really saying is, 'Don't change anything,' because failing to invest and failing to reduce the deficit means failing to change the status quo."
Mr. Clinton told the reporters from South Florida that he would release up to $2 billion in Federal money for the long-term rebuilding of the Dade County area, which was hit hard by the hurricane last August.
"Essential services were wiped out," the President said, "and although six months later, basic services have been restored, the progress toward redevelopment has been minimal."
 
New Uses for Homestead
 Included in Mr. Clinton's plan is money to repair the runway and control tower at the Homestead base, even though it is one of the bases scheduled to close. Mr. Clinton had made a campaign promise to rebuild the base, and said it could be used by reserve forces, the Drug Enforcement Administration and the Coast Guard and perhaps other uses.
As for Connecticut, Mr. Clinton had pledged during the campaign to continue the Seawolf, which is built in Groton, Conn., after President George Bush had canceled contracts for the attack submarine. Mr. Clinton's pledge was criticized by his opponent, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, who said that the ship had outlived its usefulness because of the diminished threat from Russia. He had accused Mr. Clinton of backing the Seawolf to gain support in Connecticut.
But Mr. Clinton today denied having political motives. "It didn't have much to do with the Connecticut primary," he said. "I didn't even know if I would be politically alive in November and December when were were trying to evaluate these decisions."
Mr. Clinton also denied to the California reporters that politics played any role in the Pentagon's decision to keep two California military installations off the list of proposed closings.
Mr. Clinton also denied to the California reporters that politics played any role in the Pentagon's decision to keep two California military installations off the list of proposed closings.
Mr. Clinton said that the Defense Secretary, Les Aspin, deleted McClellan Air Force Base, near Sacramento, and the Monterey Presidio, from the original list not to please Democratic lawmakers from the districts but "because he thought the aggregate economic impact was still too great -- the Bay area still takes a great hit."
Mr. Clinton repeatedly emphasized that final decisions about which bases to close had not been made. "I'm open to any arguments anybody wants to make," Mr. Clinton said. "And I think the base commission will be, too."
