HEADLINE: As 1968 Joins the Centuries, McCarthy Goes On

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
A quarter of a century has slipped by since Eugene J. McCarthy turned the Vietnam issue on President Lyndon B. Johnson in the 1968 New Hampshire primary, forcing him from the race.
But 25 years and a day later, the impact of that upset in the New England snow lingers in the Democratic Party and in the American political system generally. 
 And Clean Gene lingers too, writing, making speeches and every four years returning to New Hampshire for another quirky run for the Presidency.
"Twenty-fifth anniversary," mused the former Minnesota Senator, who turns 77 on March 29 and is, though now a little whiter in the mane, unmistakably the same man striding across the old campaign poster that proclaims, "He stood up alone, and something happened."
 
Lot to Complain About
 "Somebody said something about holding an anniversary celebration, but I told them I'd rather hold a rally," he said by telephone on Friday from California, where he was on a speaking tour.
Hold a rally? On what issue?
"Oh, there's no shortage of things to complain about," he replied. "We could start with the deficit or the trade balance or finding jobs for people. We didn't get it all done in 1968, not by a long shot."
But he accomplished plenty back then.
He pulled together the antiwar movement within the Democratic Party, and when primary day, March 12, 1968, was over, he had five times as many New Hampshire delegates as the President. He eventually lost the nomination to Hubert H. Humphrey, his fellow Minnesotan, who was then beaten by Richard M. Nixon, but the antiwar faction hung together fairly well in future elections, though it switched its attention to issues like the environment. And today, some former McCarthyites are showing up in the Clinton Administration.
 
A Lasting Effect
 Among them is Eli Segal. He was Gov. Bill Clinton's top aide and is now the head of the Clinton Administration's new Office of National Service. Shortly after last fall's Presidential election, Mr. Segal held a dinner party in Little Rock, Ark., for a dozen or so old McCarthy campaign workers who had worked to elect Mr. Clinton, people like James Johnson, the chairman of the Federal National Mortgage Association, and Susan Thomases, a New York lawyer, and Taylor Branch, the author.
But perhaps the most important effect of the 1968 McCarthy insurgency was the reform movement the campaign sparked in the Democratic Party, a movement that cracked open the party's Presidential nominating process and permitted a broader spectrum of people to have a genuine say.
"Gene McCarthy's greatest accomplishment was to energize a whole new generation of people, particularly young people, and get them involved in politics," said Anne Wexler, a Washington consultant who has long been active in Democratic Party affairs, including the 1968 McCarthy campaign.
As for Mr. McCarthy, he now makes his home in Virginia -- "Mother of Presidents," he notes -- and spends much of his time writing poetry, a carry-over from his days as a college professor before he went into politics. He cranks out books for children and for politicians, the latest a work on economics titled "Colony of the World." He travels the country making speeches. He continues to run for President, with five tries so far. But his first run is still his best. And he continues to be one of the wriest voices on the American political scene.
"Didn't do so well in New Hampshire in '92 -- just 211 votes," he said. "But down in the deep backwaters of Louisiana they apparently thought I was old Joe (Get the Commies) McCarthy, and I did pretty good there. Actually, I wanted to spend the campaign talking about the deficit and the trade balance and the job situation. We've really got to do something, get our priorities reordered. But most of the folks I'd run into just wanted to talk about 1968."
Well, what about 1968, looking back at it over a quarter of a century?
 
As Always, the Unexpected
 "Oh, I don't know," he replied. "I'd rather not talk about 'What did you do in the war, daddy?' I write poetry now. You can be a former Presidential candidate. You can't be a former poet."
Pressed for the assessment, he delivered, as he has always delivered, the totally unexpected.
"O.K.," he said, "what I really think is that the war might have ended sooner if I hadn't done so well in New Hampshire. If I'd just stung Lyndon real good, the party might have figured: 'Well, we really do have a serious problem with this war, so we'd better cut our losses, compromise and get out of it as fast as we can.' But because I beat him, beat him bad, they decided to fight me head on. And I'm afraid that caused things to drag out."
How's the new President doing?
"Too early to say," he replied. "But sometimes I worry that he's just more of the same old stuff that we've been seeing for so long. To be a successful President, you have to break free of the past."
Does he still have the Presidential bug?
There was a pause at the other end of the line. Then came a transcontinental chuckle.
"We McCarthys tend to live a long time," he said. "My grandfather made it to 98. That being the case, I've still got time for -- let's see -- for five more tries."

HEADLINE: Spared 2 Base Closings, Californians Lobby On

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., March 13

 BODY:
California's elected leaders claimed a partial victory this weekend in their effort to save military bases in the state and began a fierce second-round lobbying battle to spare at least one other base here from closing.
Two California bases were granted a reprieve on Friday by Defense Secretary Les Aspin, at least for the time being: the huge McClellan Air Force Base in Sacramento and the Presidio of Monterey, home to the Army's esteemed language school. Mr. Aspin has also recommended trimming, but not closing, March Air Force Base in Riverside County. 
 Still, many other installations in the economically hard-hit state are on Mr. Aspin's list for closing. Four are major bases in the San Francisco Bay area: the Alameda Naval Air Station, the Oakland Naval Supply Center, the Treasure Island Naval Station and the Mare Island Naval Shipyard. The bases employ about 40,000 people altogether.
 
Fazio a Big Winner
 With that scorecard in hand, the biggest winner among California's politicians seemed to be Representative Vic Fazio of the Sacramento area, the powerful chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. McClellan Air Force Base employs 16,183 people, more than 12,000 of them civilians. The Sacramento Bee celebrated the base's reprieve with a six-column headline, "McCLELLAN'S OFF!"
Mr. Fazio was obviously delighted that McClellan had "a new lease on life." He said he was sure that the base had been spared because of the "cumulative economic effect" of earlier base closings in the state's capital, which had already lost an Air Force base and an Army depot in two earlier rounds of military cutbacks. Unemployment in the Sacramento area is 8.3 percent, higher than either the Oakland or San Francisco areas.
But economic factors alone may not have spared McClellan: Mr. Fazio's district, especially after reapportionment, is not a sure thing for Democrats. And losses there, either in Congressional midterm elections or in 1996, would be costly to the party.
 
Biggest Loser
 The biggest loser was Representative Ronald V. Dellums of Oakland, the new chairman of the House Armed Services Committee and a longtime advocate of drastically reduced military spending. All four bases in Mr. Dellums district are designated to be closed, primary among them the Alameda Naval Air Station, which has 16,845 workers and will be the focus of renewed lobbying by the state delegation in Washington.
One local leader, Don Perata, a member of the Alameda County Board of Supervisors, said Defense Department officials had underestimated how hard Mr. Dellums would fight to preserve bases in his district because despite his long record of trying to cut military spending. "Why would you disrespect the chair?" Mr. Perata asked. "I can only guess they thought he'd allow the ball to pass without swinging at it."
But the Democratic Representative swung quick and hard. Clearly stunned by the list announced by Mr. Aspin, his predecessor as committee chairman, Mr. Dellums called the Defense Department's process of choosing bases "late-night horse trading" and said he was being "punished for his political views."
Such statements were reminiscent of his days as a firebrand outsider on Capitol Hill. But later Mr. Dellums struck a more statesmanlike pose, declining further interviews and resorting to formal statements.
 
He's Still the Chairman
 "I assume that the commission will thoroughly review and consider their recommendations in the light of the established criteria for closure and realignment," Mr. Dellums said, referring to the next step in the base-closing process. A Presidential panel has until July 1 to review the list proposed by Mr. Aspin. Its decisions will then go to President Clinton and Congress.
Mr. Dellums has argued that eliminating the Alameda Naval Air Station and the three other bases in his district was strategically unsound because no other installations on the West Coast have berthing for three nuclear carriers or adequate housing and hospitals.
Now, said Mr. Dellums's general counsel, H. Lee Halterman, the Representative may use his position as Armed Services chairman to deny the Navy authorization to upgrade its bases in San Diego or Washington State, the alternatives to Alameda.
California's senior Senator, Dianne Feinstein, noted that Mr. Dellums's power to authorize such spending means that he could be "very effective" in lobbying the Presidential commission. "He has a real trump card to play if he chooses to do so," Ms. Feinstein said.
 
Call for More Federal Help
 Senator Feinstein also said she would introduce legislation to set aside a portion of the $20 billion President Clinton plans to spend on military conversion for California.
Mr. Dellums also called for additional Federal help in making the transition from military to civilian use of the bases here. "The President's $20 billion plan for economic conversion needs to be enhanced more fully," he said.
Until Friday, the California delegation had shown uncommon unity in opposing further base closings in this hard-pressed state, where unemployment is now 9.8 percent, nearly three points higher than the national average. They pointed to two earlier rounds of military cutbacks, when the state lost 17 bases and an estimated 67,000 civilian and military jobs.
But once the list was issued, the ideological differences within the delegation became more apparent.
Senator Feinstein, for instance, was asked about Mr. Dellums's assertion that he had been singled out because of past political positions. She noted that Mr. Dellums' opposition to a plan, long since abandoned, to base the battleship Missouri in San Francisco Harbor certainly "didn't help" his cause.
Then, she boasted that she had been a cheerleader for the Missouri during her tenure as Mayor of San Francisco. "You can be sure this Senator isn't anti-military," she said. "I'm a big military booster. Always have been."

HEADLINE: Babbitt to Map Ecosystems Under New Policy to Save Them

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt has taken the first steps in a major policy shift intended to head off conflict over the Endangered Species Act by focusing on the preventive, long-term care of entire ecosystems.
Two of the nation's best-known conservation biologists, Dr. Thomas E. Lovejoy of the Smithsonian Institution and Dr. Peter H. Raven of the Missouri Botanical Garden in St. Louis, have been recruited to help set up a national biological survey to map the country's ecosystems and biological diversity, much as the United States Geological Survey maps its geology and geography. 
 The mapping will be undertaken as part of a reorganization of the Interior Department's biological research, which is now divided among several agencies. Mr. Babbitt is asking Clinton Administration budget officials and Congress to approve the transfer of $12 million from elsewhere in the Interior budget to bolster the consolidation effort in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. Interior officials said they expected the request to be approved.
A biological survey is critical to any effort to practice preventive medicine on ecosystems, Mr. Babbitt said in an interview Thursday. With an accurate map of the country's biological diversity, he said, "we can spot the problems coming while there's still flexibility and time to deal with them," before they result in a collision of economic and environmental interests.
Without such information, the Secretary said, "you don't have a chance."
 
'A Historical Moment'
 Dr. Lovejoy is to be detached from the Smithsonian for four months beginning about April 1 to advise in planning the survey, Mr. Babbitt said.
Constance Newman, Under Secretary of the Smithsonian, said that "we're very excited" about the institution's role in the survey and that the Smithsonian had "every intention of continuing" its involvement after Dr. Lovejoy's tenure.
Dr. Raven will head a National Academy of Sciences committee that will offer advice on organizing the survey, Mr. Babbitt said. Its report is to be issued in September.
"This is truly a historical moment," Dr. Raven said. "It's similar to when the U.S. Geological Survey was initiated over a century ago."
The geological survey, now one of the nation's major research organizations with a far-flung network of nearly 9,000 employees, grew out of a similar collaboration among the Interior Department, the Smithsonian and the National Academy of Sciences in 1879. Mr. Babbitt cited this "echoing of history" with enthusiasm, but at its start the biological survey will be much more modest than the present-day geological survey. Like the geological survey, the biological survey will be a continuing one.
 
Evolving Picture of U.S.
 Mr. Babbitt said that the nucleus of the biological survey would be the existing research establishment of the Fish and Wildlife Service, an Interior Department agency, and that other department research efforts on biological diversity would be consolidated with it. The survey will also seek the cooperation of state agencies and Federal ones outside the Interior Department, like the Forest Service.
The survey's goal, Mr. Babbitt said, is to produce a constantly evolving, computerized picture of the nation's biological diversity that "adjusts to changes in land use, to ecological changes, and which must with the passage of time become more sophisticated" and more detailed as knowledge of species and ecosystems grows.
He said compiling that picture was the only way to know where the ecosystems of maximum biological diversity were, which were the most fragile and which had the best regenerative powers. In this way, Mr. Babbitt said, it may be possible to diagnose problems earlier and take action well before any plant or animal species becomes endangered.
Once a species is declared endangered under the Endangered Species Act, its habitat is designated as critical, and after that, the Secretary said, "you can't destroy one square inch of it without an endless, protracted sort of legal process."
State and local governments and private conservation groups across the country are already devising ecosystem protection plans to avoid that kind of conflict.
 
First Step in California
 Mr. Babbitt said he believed that the most interesting plan was one in Southern California in which state and local governments and private landowners joined to protect more than 200,000 acres of mostly dry shrub that biologists call the coastal sage scrub ecosystem. Through land acquisition, zoning and local land-use planning, the governments intend to protect a variety of fragile species that are not yet endangered.
Because the California plan offers assurance that the overall ecosystem will be protected, it is less important to protect every little piece of property. As a result, Mr. Babbitt said, the Fish and Wildlife Service was recently able to issue an opinion allowing developers to construct a freeway, thereby avoiding "what would have been a big crisis."
The existence of the ecosystem plan, the Secretary said, means "we can kind of pull back and watch how the process unfolds and not be as heavy-handed about intervention." And that, he added, is why landowners like it.
In addition, if all the known plant and animal species are included in an ecosystem management plan or recovery plan, Mr. Babbitt said, landowners who cooperate in the plan are spared the possibility of having to confront one future endangered species crisis after another.
Such crises are "always fought out on a case-by-case basis in a highly legalistic way," Dr. Raven said, "and the result is that we're not necessarily making the best decisions."
One reason for that, he said, is that the United States has never had a comprehensive delineation of its plants, animals, fungi and microorganisms. With such a survey and the ecosystem approach it makes possible, "we can make decisions that will really serve our interests not only now but in the future," Dr. Raven said.
"Otherwise," he said, "we run the risk of picking ecosystems apart piece by piece, never getting the results we want."

HEADLINE: Pedigreed Pawnshop Deals Discreetly With a Big Burglary

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
The Provident Loan Society is where Jim Thorpe pawned his Olympic medals in 1912 and where the newspaper heiress Evalyn Walsh McLean gave the Star of the East diamond as security for $50,000 in fast cash 20 years later. A down-and-out Theodore Dreiser once pawned a watch there for $25, an amount he used to turn his life around before writing "An American Tragedy."
The institution has existed for more than 99 years, making many loans for under a dollar and others for tens of thousands. Inside its mahogany-paneled headquarters, clerks still fill out tickets with wooden pencils. 
 But in recent weeks the doors have been closed and the managers have been sifting through debris and soot, debating the wisdom of sending out letters to notify more than 4,700 pledgors that they cannot redeem their loans because their valuables are missing. To the Provident, the collateral the valuables represented is insured, except for a $50,000 deductible.
 
A Team of Professionals
 In the wee hours of Saturday, Feb. 6, the society's principal office at 346 Park Avenue South was burglarized by a team of what police officials are convinced were highly organized professionals. This was the second spectacular looting of the venerable society. On Feb. 17, 1969, two men entered the Provident's Jamaica, Queens, branch and held up the manager and two other office employees at gunpoint. More than 3,000 pieces of diamond and other precious jewelry, whose retail value was estimated between $4 million and $6 million, were taken. Approximately 90 percent was later recovered.
In the latest theft, the burglars found collateral for $1.9 million in loans inside a vault.
Hundreds, even thousands of wedding rings were surely lost. Perhaps a diamond brooch "borrowed" from a grandmother's jewelry box to buy a child's birthday present can now never be surreptitiously returned. Possibilities are as endless as human need.
"Some of our customers are very understanding," said James P. Keville, executive vice president of the nonprofit institution. "However, there are some who aren't so understanding."
 
Pawned Ring After Divorce
 A divorced woman, who had pawned her engagement ring there, said she cared little about losing it. Indeed, she said, she first pawned the ring right after her divorce, using the proceeds for a celebration party.
But she was happy that the society didn't lose everything. "If they'd have gotten the silver I hocked at the same time I'd be madder than hell," she said.
The appeal of the society, she said, is partly its august appearance. "It's very civilized," she said. "You see the most respectable sort of people coming in."
But lower interest rates than commercial pawnshops and almost instantaneous loan approval are the strongest attractions. "How can I put this?" she said. "I'm an improvident person in the upper middle class who every so often finds herself impoverished."
 
Founded by Old Families
 The Provident was founded and nurtured by the great old New York families, the Schiffs, Rockefellers and Vanderbilts, among others. Its purpose was delicately called "remedial lending," the mission being to aid those termed "the worthy poor." Worthiness has been variously defined, though the average loan amount is $400.
Mr. Keville greeted a visitor in the society's boardroom, where portraits of the distinguished trustees preside. There was no fire in the marble fireplace. The plush carpet was deep green.
A month after the break-in, the air still carried an acrid odor caused, the police say, by tools the burglars used to penetrate walls containing steel more than two inches thick. These "hot rods" reach temperatures of 10,000 degrees, roughly the temperature of the sun's surface, and require elaborate oxygen tanks to operate.
 
Melting Down the Gold
 Detective Joe Keenan said the burglars, who he thinks numbered between three and five, were not selling the jewelry piece by piece but had probably pried out the diamonds and melted down the gold to sell it in bulk.
Mr. Keville said the delay in notifying customers was a result first of having to seal the building because of asbestos released when the burglars dug through walls. Then too, there was the thorny problem of notifying those whom the Provident calls pledgors. The society strives to avoid correspondence, but finally decided there was no choice.
The society's beginnings go back to March 1892, when Alfred Bishop Mason wrote an article in "Charities Review" advocating that a group of men to which he belonged unite to "lend money at low rates on good security."
 
Modeled on European Shops
 The result was that Mr. Mason and other members of the Charity Organization Society each threw in $35,000 to start the Provident. They modeled the new insitution on the municipal pawnshops in Europe, some of which were more than 500 years old.
On April 13, 1894, the Governor signed a law approving a charter for the new organization, overcoming heated opposition from private pawnshops resentful of the society's tax-exempt status.
Immediately, demand exceeded expectations. Customers borrowed $6,761.50 in the first week of business, though only $5,000 was supposed to be lent in any one week.
The Provident offers a better rate than commercial pawnshops, an annualized rate of 26 percent compared with 36 percent.
Precious few of today's pledgors have wealth remotely near that of Mrs. McLean, who owned The Washington Star in 1932 when she was approached by a man claiming to be the kidnapper of Charles Lindbergh's son.
Mrs. McLean was asked to come up with $50,000 to save the child. She immediately dispatched an employee to the Provident with what she considered adequate collateral for a $50,000 loan. He carried the Hope Diamond in his pocket.
The society rejected the world's most famous gem. "The people here thought that if it ever had to go to sale, it would be hard for a single bidder to come up with what it is worth," Mr. Keville said.
Mrs. McLean's representative then reached into his other pocket, and pulled out a diamond named Star of the East, which was more than three times larger. The Provident accepted that on the grounds it could be cut up and sold if necessary.
The heiress lost the $50,000 to a swindler who turned out to have no connection with the kidnappers. But she scraped together enough cash to redeem her 140-carat diamond.
Indeed, just 7 percent of the society's collateral goes up for sale, a figure that indicates its worth even to people stretching to make ends meet.
"There are a lot of people whose lives are tied up in their jewelry," Mr. Keville observed.

HEADLINE: Try Convincing Counties the Recession Has Ended

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW YORK, NY

 BODY:
Even as states and cities are breaking free of the recession, buoyed by rising revenues from sales and income taxes, officials in the nation's counties say they are facing one of the worst years since the recession began.
County governments -- which provide everything from roads and health care to police and fire protection -- are suffering because they rely on property taxes for 75 percent of their own revenues. Cities, by contrast, rely on property taxes for 40 percent of their revenue. Real estate taxes, which are based on real estate values, fell sharply in the recession and will recover slowly because of legal and practical constraints. 
 Most counties are raising tax rates to try to offset the decline, but most are also sharply reducing services to balance their budgets. Counties in the worst fiscal shape are those with legal restraints on tax increases.
Last year was the worst of the recession for county budgets, and this year looks just as bad.
"Things are going to get worse before they get better," said Ralph Tabor, legislative director of the National Association of Counties. "No matter how strongly the economy comes back, counties will still be hurting for several years because residential construction in the suburbs has pretty much stopped and commercial vacancy rates are high everywhere."
 
Cuts in Services
 The group has just completed a survey of the nation's 66 largest counties, where one-third of Americans live. It found that more than 70 percent of the counties had reduced services and raised property taxes last year, and just as many said they planned to take these same measures again this year.
Counties vary in function from state to state, but as their fiscal problems deepen, the 98 percent of Americans who receive county services are likely to feel the pinch as counties reduce financing to schools, libraries, hospitals, highways, courts, prosecutors, public defenders and police and fire departments. Only Connecticut and Rhode Island do not have county governments; counties in these states are little more than lines on a map.
Many large, urban counties include municipalities in their jurisdiction, and some, like San Francisco and New York, have consolidated city-county governments.
 
Revenues Falling
 New York, as a combination of city and county governments, is second only to Los Angeles County in population and second to none in spending. New York City has enormous problems with its property tax revenues, but its problems are indicative of those faced in most urban counties.
Since 1990 the city's property values have declined 16 percent, to $303 billion from $352 billion, according to city finance officials. Last year alone there was a $21 billion decline in the market value of real estate, and property owners, primarily owners of office buildings, have already received $2 billion in reduced assessments. That reduction translates into a $350 million decline in real estate revenue for the fiscal year 1994, which begins July 1. Property tax revenues are projected to be about $8 billion, or half of the city's locally generated income.
 
Squeeze in Colorado
 In Colorado, 23 of the state's 63 counties faced declines in their overall property assessments, but they cannot raise property tax rates to make up for the shortfall, at least for now. A new state law, approved by voters last year, requires a popular vote on any proposed tax increase by any level of government. "I don't know how they are going to keep their schools going," said Karen K. Reinertson, the state budget director.
California's counties are also hard hit by declining property values and legal restrictions on increasing property taxes. Property values in the state have fallen by tens of billions of dollars during the recession, and property owners have received billions of dollars in property tax relief, state officials say. Precise numbers are unavailable. But no matter how quickly the real estate market rebounds, state law generally limits increases in assessments to 2 percent a year. The law, which voters enacted as Proposition 13 on the 1978 state ballot, permits greater increases in assessments under some conditions, including the sale of a property.
 
Supporting a Population Boom
 Counties with the most problems are often ones that grew rapidly in the 1980's and now lack money to provide services for their growing populations.
San Diego County, Calif., which saw its population increase to 2.5 million from 1.6 million during the decade, has depended on its annual 12 percent increase in real estate tax assessments to keep expanding services. But the growth in those assessments, and the tax revenue along with it, shrank to 8.2 percent in 1991 and 4.6 percent last year.
"The boom ended in 1990, and it was just like hitting a brick wall," said Manuel A. Lopez, director of financial management for the county.
The county has coped with its fiscal crisis by reducing health and social services and by not opening a new jail for 1,200 prisoners that was completed in 1990.
 
A Time of 'Ugly Decisions'
 In Fairfax County, Va., facing a $200 million deficit in last year's $1.3 billion general fund budget, officials raised property taxes by about 5 percent and hoped to raise taxes on restaurant meals. But voters rejected the meal tax in a ballot measure.
"So we had to cut the heck out of education and human services," said Tom Davis, chairman of the County Board of Supervisors. "We made the ugly decisions last year, so we're in better shape this coming fiscal year."
Prince Georges County, Md., reduced services across the board, eliminated 1,200 of 5,500 jobs and stripped costly provisions for things like wage increases, holiday pay and cost of living adjustments for police officers, firefighters and other employees.
"These are unusual times," said Marita B. Brown, director of the county's Office of Management and Budget. "And taxpayers are starting to understand that they will pay more and get less."

HEADLINE: THE TWIN TOWERS;
For Construction Workers, Opportunities From Tragedy

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
After hours of hauling rubble out of the damaged basement of the World Trade Center, Charles Janus collapsed into a chair and lit a cigarette. His face was black with soot and when he lifted his cup of coffee, pain spread through his 50-year-old body.
But Mr. Janus was happy, for the disaster at the Trade Center has turned his life around. "You have to be out of work for months to appreciate going back," he said. A phone call from the Turner Construction Company, which is handling some of the repairs at the complex, brought his first job since last summer. 
 The explosion that killed five people and injured more than 1,000 caused hundreds of millions of dollars in damage and business losses. But for Mr. Janus and others, it is creating opportunities and hope: for at least the next month or so, construction and maintenance companies will employ thousands of people for the repairs and cleanup.
 
Calling In Workers
 Turner's New York office has already taken on more than 30 new workers, calling in men like Mr. Janus who had spent much of the last few months fighting the frustration that seems as much a part of the depressed construction industry these days as hard hats and power drills.
Like Turner, other construction companies are hiring hundreds of extra people to rebuild the garage under the World Trade Center and the foundation under the New York Vista Hotel. Many of the jobs pay about $20-25 an hour.
And the three major maintenance companies at the complex say they are taking on more than 2,300 new workers, who will earn $13-14 an hour cleaning soot off floors, draperies and walls with special dry sponges.
"There is an enormous amount of economic activity associated with a project of this magnitude," said Anthony E. Shorris, deputy executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the Trade Center.
 
Work for Several Weeks
 "It's an irony of a disaster like this," he said. "Something terrible happens, but it has a silver lining. This is the sole good news out of this tragedy."
The jobs that have sprung from the disaster will probably not last more than three or four weeks. Most pay well because they are union spots, but few of those hired will get benefits like health insurance because their jobs will not last more than a month.
The other day, executives from maintenance businesses crowded around tables in the concourse level of the Trade Center, instructing cleaning crews and poring over lists to insure that they had enough workers. Richard R. Heade, a manager at Ogden Allied Services, said his company normally employs 400 people at the complex, but would soon add another 1,600.
 
Swamped With Applications
 Ogden and other companies said they had been swamped with job applications. Claribel Aguilar, a manager for Nelson Maintenance Services, said more than 50 people had walked up to her in the concourse in recent days and asked for work.
Some of them might have been former employees of the Windows on the World restaurant, on the 107th floor of 1 World Trade Center, or the Vista, which together have temporarily laid off about 900 workers because of the explosion. The Port Authority says it is using a referral service to help them find other jobs.
Some of the construction workers now at the Trade Center said they felt a little uneasy that they were finally off the unemployment rolls because of an event in which so many people had suffered. "It's unfortunate that you get work through a disaster like this, but you got to do what you got to do," said Robert Lamantia, 24, of Staten Island.
 
'Times Are Tough'
 Mr. Lamantia, who specializes in demolition and asbestos removal, said he was watching television at home on March 4 -- his birthday -- when Turner Construction called him. "It was a good birthday present," he said. "Times are tough out there. I went through the classifieds, I called my union. But there's no work anywhere."
Mr. Janus, a laborer who lives in Vernon, N.J., said he was starting his second week on extended unemployment benefits when he went back to work. The call from Turner, he said, came just in time.
"For the last couple of months, you eat and you sleep, so you're well rested, but you argue a lot," he said. "You're worried that you can't pay the rent, that you can't pay your kid's tuition, that you can't pay your taxes. Now you know you're getting a salary."

HEADLINE: Suit Attacks Swap Plan On Pollution

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the New York State Legislature are moving to block a Federal law that allows one utility to sell its right to pollute to another. If they succeed, environmentalists around the country could follow suit and a system that economists have hailed as a cheap way to clean the environment could be stopped before it gets started.
The Cuomo administration filed suit on Friday to stop the Long Island Lighting Company from selling a Midwestern company the right to emit pollutants that might be blown into upstate New York. The Assembly may act as early as tomorrow on a law that would do the same. 
 The question of selling pollution allowances divides environmentalists and also appears to pit the interests of electricity customers on Long Island against the health of lakes and forests in the Adirondack Mountains. It also sets the stage for an argument between Albany and Washington over which will rule on national environmental issues.
 
Trying to Reduce Acid Rain
 The basis for the conflict is a provision of the Clean Air Act of 1990, which orders utilities nationwide to reduce their emissions of sulfur dioxide, a byproduct of fuel burning that forms acid rain. Trying to reduce the cost of complying with the law, the electric companies and some environmentalists persuaded Congress to adopt an "emissions trading" provision. It is supposed to work like this:
Two utilities each have to reduce their emissions by 100,000 tons. One finds a cheap source of low-sulfur coal to substitute for its current high-sulfur coal and finds it can cut emissions at a cost of $200 a ton, but the other decides it must install a scrubber, at a cost of $400 a ton.
Instead, the first company cuts out 200,000 tons, twice what it has to, and sells allowances to emit 100,000 to the second company for $300 a ton. The first company makes a profit of $100 a ton, the second saves $100 a ton, and the cost to the national economy is reduced.
Lilco finds itself in the position of the first company. Because of rules adopted by New York State in 1984, it already exceeds the new Federal standards and is generating allowances of 40,000 to 50,000 tons a year. Deals announced so far have put the price between $250 and $400 a ton, so the allowances are worth $10 million to $20 million annually. The company says it would use the money to cut electric rates, which are the highest in the mainland United States.
Earlier this year, Lilco announced it had sold a Midwestern company an option to buy allowances. It has not yet said who the buyer was, or disclose the volume or price of the deal. But environmentalists fear the buyer is in the Ohio Valley, upwind of the Adirondacks.
So on Friday, Attorney General Robert Abrams and Environmental Conservation Commissioner Thomas C. Jorling filed suit against the Environmental Protection Administration in the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.
Joan Leary Matthews, the assistant attorney general in charge of the suit, said, "The Clean Air Act is an environmental statute, recognizing the problem of acid rain and the devastation it has wrought in sensitive receptor areas. What's the purpose of having this environmental statute if the problem isn't going to be abated?"
 
Rules Unintended by Congress
 She added that the Bush Administration had drafted rules that added a provision not intended by Congress, allowing utilities to generate allowances by cleaning up before the new requirements took effect.
The Environmental Defense Fund has filed a similar suit.
A spokeswoman for Lilco, Suzanne Halpin, said that even with the trading provision, the Clean Air Act would sharply cut overall sulfur dioxide emissions. "It's a new approach to cost-effective energy regulation and it should be given a chance to work," she said. She would not comment directly on the suit.
In another attack on the deal, Assemblyman Richard Brodsky, a Democrat from Westchester County who is the chairman of the committee on environmental conservation, has introduced a bill that could be voted on Monday that would require utilities in Lilco's position to file an environmental impact statement. If the statement shows damage, the trade could be blocked by the Public Service Commission.
"That there is a national scheme is terrific," he said. "That New York should pay the price is terrible."
But the Environmental Defense Fund, a national group based in Manhattan, does not like the New York State bill. If a market can develop in emissions trading, the group reasons, it will encourage Midwestern utilities, the nation's most polluting, to clean up in excess of the Federal standards.

HEADLINE: Despite Plant's Closing, a Town Remains Hopeful

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CORTLAND, N.Y., March 8

 BODY:
When Pamela Mott started working at Smith Corona's factory here 15 years ago, she was continuing a family tradition. Her parents, grandparents, uncles, aunts and cousins made their livings building typewriters for a company whose roots in upstate New York go back nearly 100 years.
The tradition will end with her. Recently, the plant began layoffs in preparation for moving its assembly line to Mexico. But Ms. Mott is adapting to the change and so, it appears, is Cortland, a town 30 miles south of Syracuse that is no stranger to the loss of factory jobs. 
 Besides the steady decline of Smith Corona, factory shutdowns in the mid-1970's claimed a number of tool-and-die shops, a sheet metal plant and a truck company. The message to local development officials was clear: diversify.
Since then, the arrival of new businesses and the expansion of some existing ones seem to have offset the recent jobs losses in this county of 48,000 people. Figures from the New York State Labor Department show that the number of nonagricultural jobs in Cortland County actually increased slightly from 1978 to 1992.
"We're not talking miracles here," said Richard Elliot, executive director of the Cortland County Economic Development Committee. "We're not doubling the number of jobs, but considering the gloom-and-doom comments that were made in the past when factories were leaving, I think we're holding our own."
The Mayor, Ronald Walsh, said: "What we're in the midst of is a transition. It's a transition from having the main employers be businesses that are here by accident because their founders in the 1800's happened to be from Cortland to companies that are here because it makes sense for them to be here. Smith Corona is just one more chapter of that transition."
In Cortland, diversification means businesses like the Marietta Corporation, which packages soap and other amenities for hotels; the J. M. Murray Center Inc., a provider of services for the disabled; NCC Industries, a producer of lingerie, and Buckbee-Mears, which builds television components. All these companies arrived here or expanded in the last 15 years and each employs about 500 people.
At Smith Corona, 18 assembly-line employees worked their last day at the plant last Friday. About 70 more will lose their jobs by the end of this month. The cuts will continue -- about 100 people a month -- until the plant closes this fall.
For 875 Smith Corona workers, there is help in finding new careers at a transition center financed by the state and the company.
Pamela Mott, who supports herself and her 10-year-old son, is back in school. Her tuition and books are paid for by the Federal Government while another grant supplements her unemployment benefits. After years on the assembly line, Ms. Mott, 33, plans to become a medical technician and eventually a veterinarian.
"It just sounds like a springboard to me to get somewhere," she said. "I have a bad feeling I would have sat right there for the rest of my life."
Suzie Fitzgerald, 35, has worked as a quality-control inspector for 17 years. With the help of retraining grants, she is studying to become a nurse. Her two oldest daughters, Tori, 7, and Shannon, 6, are amused.
"They think it's funny that I'm going back to school," she said. "They laugh when I have to do homework along with them. And it's a career that I couldn't have started otherwise, not with them to support."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Other New York Owner: Quiet and Supportive

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 13

 BODY:
The Mets are 2-6 and the owner is in the dugout. All, however, is quiet. Fred Wilpon, the president and co-owner of the Mets, is not George Steinbrenner.
Those who inhabit Shea Stadium, from management executives to players to fans, have enjoyed that indisputable, arguably luxurious reality for more than a decade. There has been no bombast from the owner's box, no front-office revolving doors, no tours of duty in exile. 
 "George has a style and strategy that works for him," Wilpon said here today. "All that occurs with him doesn't occur because he doesn't think it's good for his enterprise."
 
Public's the Judge
 What, then, of Wilpon's style and its effect on his enterprise, the Mets? What is the track record established by ownership that has chosen public circumspection over screaming headlines, stability over shakeups and respect within the game's inner circles of power above personal ego gratification?
"That's open to question," said Wilpon, the 56-year-old who was born in Brooklyn and who has owned a piece of the Mets since 1980. "That's up to the public."
Wilpon's links to the public are not well-established or often used. He rarely offers remarks for the record, and even more infrequently grants extended interviews. But with the Mets coming off consecutive fifth-place finishes and with Shea attendance having declined by more than a million over the last two seasons, Wilpon did not dismiss the notion that perhaps some direct communication with the public was appropriate, perhaps even obligatory.
 
Supports His Team
 And so Wilpon -- with a spring training game canceled because of the storm blowing across Florida, and up the East Coast -- spoke at length this morning about himself, and the Mets and baseball in general. Among the points he covered were the following:
*Wilpon, refusing to criticize a single management decision leading up to the disastrous 1992 season, gave every indication that General Manager Al Harazin's job security is not in jeopardy.
*The owner was unable to account for the recurrent rumor that the Mets were or could be for sale, but he categorically rejected the possibility, calling the Mets "a long-term asset" that he will help continue to run with Nelson Doubleday "for ourselves and our families." Wilpon said that even the unappealing economic prospect of revenue-sharing by the major league clubs would not compel him to contemplate selling his interest in the Mets.
*The Mets, while "basically a stable business operation," have "absolutely taken a financial hit" in recent seasons as attendance has plummeted.
*The club's program for improving minority-group representation in its front office has not to date produced acceptable results. When pressed, though, Wilpon could not cite any reasons for the failure other than "circumstances," insisting that "it's not for lack of trying." Wilpon said major league baseball would announce a minority hiring program within 10 days that would contain specific strategies, as well as real goals and timetables.
*The recent proposal to divide the leagues into three divisions with inter-league play and playoff wildcard clubs remains only "a concept at the moment," but is one "with great possibilities."
*The Mets, on paper, are a better club in 1993 than they were in 1992.
"We're all on the line, including Nelson and myself," said Wilpon. "We're on the line with the public."
Wilpon's recent encounters with the public at Shea have been painfully intimate. The place has been largely abandoned late in both of the last two seasons, the Mets having lost relevance in the National League East and New York having lost interest in the Mets.
"To tell you it has been easy would be an untruth," said Wilpon. "It's been very uncomfortable."
Wilpon, though, shrugged off the suggestion that the club was at any profound crossroads in its fight for New York's heart or its future financial viability. He said he was aware of the possibility that the Mets had left many New Yorkers disaffected by what he termed "a lack of hard-nosed effort," but he said he was satisfied with the organizational parts that were in place and remained convinced that another authentically competitive season would restore the club's stature in the city.
"My support of our people is unequivocal," said Wilpon. "I don't think there was anything we did to prepare for the 1992 season that I would say, in retrospect, we should have done differently."
That includes a lot: Harazin's succession of Frank Cashen as general manager, the hiring of Jeff Torborg as manager, the signing of Bobby Bonilla for $29 million, the trade for Bret Saberhagen.
"No criticism," Wilpon said abruptly.
Wilpon said he similarly has no regrets about his purchase of the Mets, and has found himself more challenged than worn down by his increasingly expansive and powerful role within baseball.
"The purchase of the Mets has been a good investment," said Wilpon. "It's a long-term investment and will coninue to be. Obviously, if you don't win, you don't maximize revenue. But the Mets are profitable, and the budget management has put before Nelson and myself has been approved. There is a plan."
"As for my involvement in the conduct of the game and its future, I don't look at it as having worn me down," said Wilpon, who was personally hurt by the ouster of Fay Vincent as commissioner. "Clearly, there have been things that have occurred that have pained me, that are not right. And that's why it's very mportant for us to get it right as we go forward. We are in an industry that means more to the American public than many of the country's largest businesses. It is our national pastime, and it can be more than that for the world."
 
Knows Discrimination
 Should it be more than it is for members of America's minority groups? Wilpon said yes.
"Look, years ago, I was a Jew going into business," said Wilpon. "There were places I couldn't go, things that were closed to me. I hated it. It stinks. Baseball will get better."
Any chance Fred Wilpon will get louder? He said no.
"It's not my style," he said. "My style allows me freedom. Being recognized has no meaning for me. I won't be in any headlnes."
The Mets, of course, will make headlines. They always do. They just haven't made them with their accomplishments of late.
"I think we are going to surprise people this year," said Wilpon.

SECTION: Section 8; Page 1; Column 2; Sports Desk

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
For Pateks, the Safety Net Fails

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BLUE SPRINGS, Mo.

 BODY:
A summer breeze rippled the curtain of the open window in the dark master bedroom on Evergreen Lane in this Kansas City suburb. The breeze carried with it the scent of a recent rain that still lay in scattered patches on the silent streets. At 3:35 on that morning last July 21, the telephone rang in that bedroom, waking the couple there.
"Is this the Patek residence?" asked the caller. 
 "Yes," said the wife, who had reached over to interrupt the ringing.
"You have a daughter, Kimberlie Patek?"
"Yes."
Jerri Patek does not remember who the caller was; nor does her husband, Fred Patek, the former shortstop for the Kansas City Royals and a three-time All-Star. But neither will ever forget what he said next.
"I'm from the Heartland East Hospital in St. Joe. Your daughter's been in a car accident."
"Is she hurt bad?" Jerri asked, her voice stricken.
"You need to come right away," replied the caller. He said nothing more.
With the click of the receiver, the Pateks were plunged into an odyssey of pain and personal loss that has left their daughter a quadriplegic and the family facing medical bills that already total more than a million dollars because she was not covered by her father's insurance policy.
But that night, in the hour's drive to the hospital in St. Joseph, Mo., the Pateks saw none of that. In their mind's eye they remembered the last time they had seen Kim, who had turned 20 years old two months earlier, a pretty, athletic young woman with shoulder-length blond hair and "always going and moving," as her mother said. It was two days before the phone call, on a Sunday afternoon at Royals Stadium.
Patek, who had been the shortest player in the major leagues at 5 feet 5 inches, was being inducted into the Royals' Hall of Fame. His family -- his wife and daughters, Kim and Heather, 10 months older than Kim -- were at home plate. Kim, who was 5-2 ("short like my father," she had said), wore a blue summer dress and red high heels and a winsome smile. She had recently moved out of her parents' home to a small apartment in Kansas City, gotten her own car, a white Ford Probe, and taken a job managing a loan office.
While much of what happened right after they got the phone call that night is a fog, Patek does remember that the roads to the hospital "were torn up" with construction, and on a bridge that had become one lane a truck had spilled furniture, blocking traffic. Fred, who is normally mild-mannered, shouted at a policeman that he had to get through because of an emergency, then threatened to throw the furniture into the river if he wasn't allowed to pass before speeding around the roadblock without police pursuit.
At the hospital, the Pateks were told that Kim was in a coma and had suffered injury to her spinal cord. They were taken to a room where she was hooked up to a life-support system. Clergy was there. A doctor told them that Kim was not expected to live through the night. Although she survived, their next news was that Kim would be a quadriplegic for the rest of her life and would never have feeling below her jaw.
"There are no words to describe how our hearts felt," Patek recalled.
Two or three days later, he called his insurance company to check on the policy that he still had through the Major League Baseball Players Association. Patek had annually paid $7,000 for what he checked off as "full family coverage." More bad news: he was told the policy states that when the holder's children turn 20, and unless they are full-time students -- Kim had shortly before left college -- they are no longer covered. Kim had not been covered yet by her new employer, either.
The family's understanding is that, had the group policy still been in effect, it would have covered Kim's medical costs to $1 million.
"The insurance company is under no obligation to tell the insured about this and that we could have taken out what they call a Cobra policy to cover the kids," said Patek. "It was my fault. I know I should have read the policy more carefully. I know I'm not much different in this than a lot of people, but that doesn't excuse it.
"I thought, 'I'm ruined.' No doubt in my mind. But my daughter's life was all that was important. I didn't think money. I thought survival. Will she live? But I was scared. I had this horrible feeling in my stomach. What was going to happen?"
 
A Blizzard of Zeros Accompany the Bills
 The Pateks had saved a modest amount of money. Patek, now 49, played in the major leagues from 1968 to 1981.
He began with the Pittsburgh Pirates at $7,000 a year. In the last three years of his career, with the Royals and Angels, his salary reached $100,000. After he retired, he lost money in real estate, got involved in restaurants that weren't particularly successful and had been a salesman for a computer-paper firm before he was "axed," he said, in a reorganization last spring. Jerri had a job selling real estate.
Last spring, he returned to baseball and became the roving minor league infield and base-running coach for the Milwaukee Brewers, at around $30,000 a year. He did not take additional insurance from the Brewers because he already had his policy through the players association. He would travel for a couple of weeks and then come home for a week. The week of the accident, he happened to be home.
After the accident, Kim remained in intensive care. The first week in the hospital cost $9,000; the total for the six weeks she was there was $45,000. She would be taken to the Texas Institute for Research and Rehabilitation in Houston, and there the cost was about $2,500 a day. She was there for six weeks. In the nine months since the accident, the costs have been about a million dollars.
The Pateks have raised close to $400,000 through various means: charity basketball games played by celebrities like Darrell Porter, a former teammate of Patek's, the former Royals pitcher Dennis Leonard and local athletes such as Lynn Dickey, the former pro quarterback. George Brett has signed hundreds of balls that were sold to raise money. Nolan Ryan and Mickey Mantle have offered to do whatever they could.
The Baseball Assistance Team -- B.A.T., an organization for needy former players -- has also sent "a substantial sum," said Patek. "And we've received money from some really wonderful people in Kansas City. I used to be involved in a lot of charities when I was a player. I guess I'm reaping some of the rewards of that now."
The Pateks are hoping that Kim will be able to get a nerve implant that would allow her to be off her respirator during the day -- though she would have to go back on it at night. The implant may cost $200,000. Patek estimates that other bills for Kim's care may total more than $1 million in the next year.
After two months and three hospitals, Kim had developed her third case of pneumonia. She was being fed through tubes but was losing weight. She had dropped from 105 pounds to about 60. "Daddy," she said, "I'm not afraid to die. But I want to die at home. Please take me home."
But doctors convinced the family to keep Kim in the hospital, and it was only three weeks ago that she finally did come home, with a banner around the house reading, "Welcome Home Kim, We All Love You."
She is now able to eat normally, and her weight has risen to about 100 pounds. She lies in a bed in the family room of the four-bedroom, three-level wood-frame house. She is hooked up to a Puritan Bennett model 2801 respirator, with a green light indicating it is on, and breathing through a tube inserted into her trachea. The Pateks, either Fred or Jerri or Heather, who works in a bank, have never left her side in nine months.
At night, Jerri Patek sleeps in a bed beside Kim's. She wakes every four hours to turn Kim on her side to pound her lungs to remove the congestion. Other times she must be there to ease the spasms. Kim must speak around the "trache," as the tube in her neck is called. It is hard for her to say more than one or two words before having to catch her breath, and sometimes, when the respirator tube accidentally disconnects, she has to signal to her parents by clicking her teeth. In the night, Jerri or Fred have been awakened with the cry, "Mom! Dad! Spasms! I -- feel them -- coming!" Kim's body vibrates as Jerri or Fred hold down her legs and pat them. Kim's eyes cloud with pain and grow teary.
Kim gets out of the house occasionally. She had gone to two of the benefit basketball games for her and has visited a dentist and gone shopping. She is taken in a wheelchair and placed in a van that the Pateks have rented. "To load her up takes about a half hour," said Patek.
When they get outside now, on these gray Missouri days, a blue sign planted in the brown lawn may be seen in front of their house. The house is for sale, and has been since the accident, for two reasons. One is, the Pateks could use the money. The other is that, as Fred says, "We need a house for Kim with no steps."
"So far no takers," said Patek. "And it's a little hard because of the economy right now, but also because of all the medical equipment around. It's not what you might call a model house."
 
Along With Tears, Hope for Tomorrow
 Kim, lying now in pink pajamas and a white bow in her hair, had recently had the fingernails of her immobile hands painted red by her mother. Her head was propped up by a pillow and a towel. Her neck needs constant stabilization. The family is looking for some kind of apparatus to do this but hasn't found the right one.
"Kim doesn't want to wear something that looks like a football helmet," said Fred.
"Still vain, huh?" said a visitor, Kim's high school gymnastics, diving and track coach, Lori Young.
"Yep," she said, smiling.
Young kidded Kim about how she and the other girls would primp and straighten their hair before Kim ran the anchor on the 800-relay team, and her father said of her athleticism, "She was a natural."
Kim says she still has all her clothes in a closet. "I want to keep everything," she said. "I'm afraid to lose it. I've lost enough."
She had a boyfriend for five years, but he hasn't called since the accident. "That hurts," said Kim.
Some of the hurt comes in little things like when her older sister, Heather, prepares to go out for a night. "That's so hard for Kim because she loved running here and there all the time," said Fred. "There's a lot of tears."
And there are tears with Fred and Jerri. "Sometimes," he said, "we're at our rope's end. But then we think, 'Tomorrow will be better.' "
Kim says she has fought the way her father did because he had to combat the odds himself. When Patek was called up to Class AAA in Columbus, the manager, Larry Shepard, said, "You're not the damn guy they sent me to play shortstop, are you?" He was. And Kim smiled.
"I can see the change in Fred," said Dennis Leonard, the former teammate and still a neighbor of the Pateks. "He's a little grayer, his face is a little more drawn. But he's been amazing, him and Jerri, the way they've held up."
"Nothing can prepare you for this," said Patek, who continues to be paid by the Brewers. "And all the winning and the trying to get to the top is like it never happened. Baseball seems in a different lifetime. And I read in the papers about the complaints of some of the athletes, about whatever it is that they're unhappy about, and I think, 'Bless their hearts. They have no idea.' "
Patek might be remembered best as a player in the last game of the 1977 five-game championship series between the Yankees and Royals. In the bottom of the ninth inning, he hit a smash to Graig Nettles at third that Nettles turned into a double play, giving the Yankees their second straight playoff victory over the Royals. The cameras captured Patek sitting alone in the dugout, his head in his heads in despair.
"All that seems like it never existed now," said Patek.
 
Exhortations To 'Keep Pushing'
 Sometimes, alone, the family thinks about the accident, which Kim does not remember at all. She had been driving home late at night, possibly had fallen asleep at the wheel, or tried to dodge a deer, or maybe the road was wet. But she hit the median divider on Interstate 29 and the car tumbled end over end six times. She was thrown out the window, even though she had been wearing a seat belt. A truck driver administered mouth-to-mouth resuscitation and called an ambulance.
Yes, Patek said now, there is sometimes talk by Kim about not wanting to live anymore. But there is also talk about trying to live better. They had met a 36-year-old woman, Kathleen DeSilva, an attorney for the Texas rehabilitation hospital. She too is a quadriplegic, and broke her spine when she was 16 and a gymnast. She is married to a paraplegic. "She said, 'Keep pushing,' " Kim said, adding that DeSilva had gone through everything she had. "She understood. She was -- an -- inspiration."
The family is religious, members of the Hickman Mills Church of Christ, and they pray a great deal. Kim said she has asked God, "Why?" But she said he has always been there. "He's helped me through all this," she said.
That night, the family loaded Kim into a van and took her to a basketball game at the Chrisman High School in nearby Independence that was played for her and another young woman who is also a quadriplegic. The "celebrity" team wore white T-shirts that read, "Kim's All-Stars." The other team, members of the faculty of the high school, wore red T-shirts with the same inscription and a drawing of Kim's face.
In yellow blouse and yellow jeans, Kim was rolled onto the court by her father. A crowd of 700 cheered Kim and the other woman, Linda Miller, 23, who shared center court in a wheelchair. The spectators paid $5 a ticket for the game. Patek would give all the receipts to the other girl's family. "Her father's insurance ran out, and he needs the money as much as I do," Patek said. "But he doesn't have the opportunities for the charities that I do because I was a ballplayer. It's terrible about this insurance thing and the incredibly high costs of medicines, hospitals, equipment and nursing help when you're confronted with a catastrophe in your family. Why should an individual in America have to go through this, being nearly wiped out physically, emotionally, financially?"
At halftime the Pateks, with Kim growing tired, left to return home. Covering her with a white blanket, Patek wheeled her to the van where, with Jerri holding her neck, she was lifted up by hydraulic lift.
In a few moments, the van drove out of the high school parking lot. A little yellow light went on in the back, where Jerri was holding Kim, perhaps to straighten her head or her blanket, or to ease a spasm. Patek turned onto Noland Road and the light in the back of the van switched off, as the vehicle merged with the night traffic.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
How To Help Russia

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB; Anna Quindlen is on vacation.

 BODY:
President Clinton has fashioned a no-lose policy to go the extra mile in aid and showmanship to "save" President Yeltsin and democracy in Russia. If it succeeds, he becomes Saint Bill. If it fails, somebody else has to take the blame -- Congress or the allies for not coughing up enough aid, or George Bush for doing practically nothing or the big bad Russians themselves.
No President could resist such a policy. Politically, it's foolproof. No one will ever be able to tar him with losing Russia. Strategically, it's probably his best shot. He knows that Western efforts can help only at the margins. But sometimes great historical scales are tipped by a single act of courage or one vote or a seemingly futile outstretched hand. 
 It won't be easy to sell Congress and the allies on more aid. And facing hard sells, Washington officialdom generally resorts to wrapping its efforts in standard foreign policy baloney. Someone else's burden becomes our burden. Friends are turned into gods and adversaries into devils. More money becomes a substitute for better policy, a strategy, a plan.
If President Clinton follows this well-traveled low road, he'll have an easier time collecting donations and a harder time promoting democracy in Russia. My advice for him is to break all rules and precedents -- and sell the truth.
First, Mr. Clinton should not try to pitch his policy as a way for the West to save Russia. It has to be sold as a means to help the Russians save themselves.
The Russians have already mastered one of the cardinal principles of democracy: it's easier to wait for miracles than to make tough decisions. Accordingly, they are waiting for the West to rescue them, while learning the fine art of threatening revolutions to extract more money. Over and again, Mr. Clinton has to remind everyone that the fate of democracy and free enterprise in Russia depends on the Russians themselves.
Second, Mr. Clinton is right to promote Boris Yeltsin, but wrong to join him in a war against the Russian Parliament. This body has not been a reformer's delight, but it's not dominated by a bunch of right-wing crazies.
Mr. Yeltsin looks to be the best bet around for reforming Russia and tending to Western interests. So, Mr. Clinton is right to back him. The great Russian democrat, however, has made a lot of mistakes and may not be around much longer. More likely, he'll still be President, but shorn of much of his power.
The Russian Parliament will become stronger, and while that's not good, it's not terrible either. About one-fifth of the deputies in the full Parliament are hard-line nationalists. A roughly equal number are Yeltsin loyalists. The diverse center group stretches from conservatives to industrial managers to former Yeltsin backers.
A solid majority of this Parliament would pursue reforms more slowly than Mr. Yeltsin, but would not dream of reverting to Communism. It would also be far less friendly to the U.S., but not anti-American.
The White House should not be burning bridges with this power-to-be. But that's exactly what it did in saying it would not oppose Mr. Yeltsin if he moved to suspend Parliament.
Third, Mr. Clinton should not focus his new effort on getting more money for Russia, at least not right now. He should emphasize better ways to spend aid and help the Russians reform themselves.
Throwing money at a trillion-dollar economy that's sinking in political anarchy, waste and corruption is not a brilliant idea. Russian bureaucrats can't even get themselves organized to spend most of the billions the West has already promised them.
Of the $800 million earmarked by the U.S. to help the Russians and others dismantle nuclear weapons, only $25 million has been disbursed. Why? The Russians don't want to denuke so quickly. This kind of problem has become typical.
Before the Russians need more money from the West, they need a sensible plan that gives them incentives to fix themselves up. As of now, the West and Russia haven't begun to develop such a plan.
So, Mr. Clinton, embrace Mr. Yeltsin in Vancouver for what it's worth. But spare us another worldwide begging session to save democracy in Russia until you have an overall strategy that makes sense -- especially to the Russians.

HEADLINE: MARCH 7-13: Japan and Mexico;
It's Our Ruling Party, And We'll Cry if We Want to

 BODY:
Japan and Mexico, two of the world's most economically dynamic countries and each long dominated by a single party, last week suffered embarrassments born of the riches that make their political systems work for the well-connected.
In Japan, Shin Kanemaru, until recently the kingmaker of the ruling Liberal Democrats, suffered disgrace on top of tax evasion charges when the authorities went through his home and offices and found hundreds of pounds of gold bars and $50 million in cash and securities. The stash is widely assumed to have been ill-gotten, and meant as grease for Mr. Kanemaru to apply to the wheels of Japanese politics. Even jaded Japanese were amazed at just how much political lubrication is evidently required nowadays. 
 In Mexico, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari tried to quell a furor created by reports that he had asked nearly 30 executives to contribute $25 million each to the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party. This after Mr. Salinas had promised repeatedly to make political competition in Mexico more fair.
The developments stirred new calls for reform in both countries, which are trying to enhance their international profiles.
Dogged by scandal at home, Japan's politicians are hard-pressed to exert leadership abroad commensurate with its economic clout. And Mexico is having a hard time convincing skeptics that it is democratically progressive enough to be intertwined with the United States and Canada in the still-unratified North American Free Trade Agreement.
It's all enough to set tongues clucking in Washington among elected officials dependent on year-round fund-raising and political action committees.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
The Future of Tall Towers Shaken By Circumstances at Street Level

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB

 BODY:
AS investigators and construction workers inched their way last week to Ground Zero, an old question about the World Trade Center, once the audacious symbol of a city that never doubted its ability to reinvent itself, was also being exhumed: Should it ever have been built?
The crippling bombing exposed the vulnerabilities of a complex made for the very idea of an intense concentration of commerce. That the concentration came under the sponsorship of a public agency only aggravated to the question.In the bombing's aftermath, for example, was the spectacle of financially pressed landlords scrambling to win tenants dislocated from a mega-competitor owned not by a private company, but by a public agency that pays the city relatively modest fees in lieu of real estate taxes. 
 More broadly, the viability of the Twin Towers and sister projects that dot cities across America has come under question for reasons that have nothing to do with the disruptive events of last month. Among them: a battered economy that has left 400 million square feet of office space vacant around the country, communications advances which make it far less necessary for companies to cluster their activities under one roof, and an evolved sense of what is special and most satisfying about cities.
This, in the sensibility of many, is less the stand-alone giantism of projects like the Trade Center and Renaissance Center in Detroit than the motley, serendipitous mix that colors the most interesting urban streets -- the very mix, in fact, that marked the bustling, ramshackle blocks of electronics stores and discount shops that gave way to the Twin Towers.
"I just don't know anywhere in the United States where anyone is thinking of that kind of heroic development embodied by the World Trade Center," said Richard H. Bradley, president of the International Downtown Association, made up of 400 organizations focused on the renewal of central cities.
 
New Projects Haunted
 The issues that confronted the Trade Center, however, still dominate development proposals in cities across the country. In New York City alone, the ghosts of the Trade Center debate waft through largeplans like the now dormant multi-billion dollar Times Square project, and smaller ones, such as the city's effort to move off the Avenue of the Americas the decades-old wholesale flower market, an incongruous patch of green in an area that might otherwise be ripe for high- rise development.
The formidable statistics generated by the Center would seem to provide ammunition for those pressing for large scale plans. The Center houses more than 350 companies with between 40,000 and 50,000 employees in 12 million square feet of office space, the bulk of which is in the twin 110-story towers which have become worldwide symbols of New York City. Through the deep local recession, it has managed to rent 89 percent of its space. And millions of tourists and commuters flood through it every year.
Furthermore, argues Stanley Brezenoff, executive director of the Center's owner, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the Towers opened 20 years ago when the downtown business district was reeling from pressure from Midtown. "The Trade Center accomplished the goal of supporting, reinventing and anchoring Downtown," he said.
But there were hidden costs and unmet goals. Destroyed to make way for the center was one of the most active hodge podges of economic activity in the city, an Electronics District, that merchants estimated employed 30,000 people. Three-hundred-twenty-five stores and 1,000 businesses operating above street level were pushed off the site and never reappeared as a distinct district.And in retrospect, the selection of this site seems to have been less than well thought out.The Twin Towers themselves seemed less the product of a developed planning ideal than what was referred to at the time as New York Gov. Nelson Rockefeller's "edifice complex," which critics said left a legacy of overly large and torpid buildings around the state.
And when they first opened in the early '70's, recalled Elliot Sclar, professor of urban planning at Columbia University, "those buildings almost single-handedly destroyed the commercial real estate market downtown." In fact the Trade Center had such a hard time finding tenants that it packed floor after floor with state offices who paid substantially lower rents.
 
Private Blue-Chip Tenants
 The original goal of bolstering the Port of New York seems to have vanished with the years. Early renderings show the Center against a backdrop of ships docked at Manhattan piers. Pronouncements by David Rockefeller and others emphasized that the Center was necessary to keep America's Number One port ahead of its competion.
Today no freighters dock at Manhattan piers and the port ranks second behind Los Angeles-Long Beach. Most tenants at the Center, too, seem to have only a remote relationship to the international movement of goods. Many of its largest tenants -- Dean Witter, Deloitte & Touche, and banks like Fiduciary Trust and Daichi Kangyo -- may deal in international securities and financial trading, but they could make up the roster of any privately developed blue chip building.
"It was not necessary for government to build a high rise office center basically for private sector customers," said Alan Altshuler, a professor of planning and public policy at Harvard University. "I don't think there's any question that the private sector could have accommodated the need."
The private buildings, though, would have been smaller and more diffuse, and because of their size less vulnerable to the current epic economic disruption at the Center.
If planned well, said Fred Kent, executive director of the not-for-profit planning group, Project for Public Spaces, they could have included buildings of ten to 20 stories filled with street-level stores and fitted around public squares.
As for the goal of building the world's tallest building, which the Twin Towers jointly were for a few years, "There's no city in the United States that's interested in that," said Mr. Altshuler. "I think we're beyond it."
