HEADLINE: When All (Busy) Roads Lead to the Casino

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER

 BODY:
The ground under David Candler's house shakes when the buses whiz by on Route 2A on their way to Foxwoods High Stakes Bingo and Casino in Ledyard. The house, built in 1740, is only 25 feet from the road. And the basement, with its dirt floor, acts as an echo chamber, spreading the rumbling to every corner of the house.
"This place was never designed to have buses going by at 45 to 50 miles an hour," said Mr. Candler, who lives in Preston, just north of Ledyard. 
 "The road was designed for buggies."
Between 12,000 and 20,000 people a day visit Foxwoods, traveling Route 2A and other country roads, said the casino's president and chief officer, G. Michael Brown, along with the 3,840 employees who work there. The casino, which marked its first anniversary on Feb. 15, has brought jobs and new business to a southeastern Connecticut economy fighting to recover from recession and bracing for possible cutbacks at the Navy's submarine base in Groton.
But at the same time, the breathtaking pace of the casino's growth has taken people in Ledyard and neighboring towns by surprise. Residents are suddenly confronted with steadily increasing traffic, pressure from developers eager to build, and concerns about adequate police patrols on the highways.
People on the staff of the Southeastern Connecticut Regional Planning Agency predicted three years ago that the casino, owned by the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe, would stimulate an influx of business. But there was no similar enterprise in New England to look to for a hint of exactly how big the market would be, said the assistant director of the agency, Gerhard J. Amt. A 1991 study by the agency estimated that 7,400 employees and patrons would fill the bingo hall, casino and related operations during peak hours.
As Foxwoods prepared to open, plans were made to keep the gaming operation open 16 hours a day, with employees working in two separate shifts, Mr. Brown said.
 
Working Overtime
 "We were so overwhelmed with patrons from the minute we cut the ribbon that we never closed," he said. "The staff worked double shifts until we could train more employees."
When the next phase of construction is finished in October, Foxwoods will be the nation's largest casino, with 126,225 square feet of gaming space. The next largest operations are the Excalibur Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, with 123,944 square feet and the Trump Taj Mahal Casino Resort in Atlantic City, which has 120,000 square feet of gaming space, according to the Nevada Gaming Control Board and the New Jersey Casino Control Commission.
The additions to Foxwoods will include a second casino, a five-story underground parking garage, a promenade with shops and three restaurants, a health club, two hotels, movie theater and a theater for live shows.
Although traffic on all roads leading to Foxwoods has grown steadily since the casino opened, the greatest increase has been on Route 2, which passes through North Stonington, Ledyard and Preston. Before the casino opened, 7,000 vehicles a day were using Route 2 east of Route 164 near Preston. By April 1992, the number had jumped to nearly 12,000 on weekdays and as high as 19,600 on summer weekends, Mr. Amt said. Traffic has increased even more since slot machines were installed at the casino in January.
Summer will be even worse for Stonington, which is on the coast southeast of Ledyard. Not only will there be the casino traffic on Route 2 and other nearby roads but there will also be motorists using Route 2 to reach the Rhode Island beaches, said Stonington First Selectman Peter N. Dibble.
 
More New Officers Needed
 Ledyard Mayor Joseph Lozier said he would need to increase the town's police force by two officers over the next two years to curb speeding on roads leading to the casino. "But," he said, "the town can't afford to do it."
The State Department of Transportation is studying changes to Route 2 to accommodate the traffic, and members of the Mashantucket Pequot tribe are involved in the planning.
"What we're going to do here is look 10 years into the future," said the department's transportation planning administrator, Richard Martinez. "The committee wants to know what other development will occur so we can get a full picture. Once we do that, we can take a look and see whether or not the roadways can accommodate it."
The Mashantucket Pequot tribe plans to reconstruct several intersections identified by the town and the state as needing improvement, and to widen a three-mile section of Route 2 between Routes 214 and 164 that runs past the casino. The tribe has agreed to pay for these projects, according to its lawyer, Jackson King. There is another reason the casino represents a venture without precedent in Connecticut. The Mashantucket Pequot tribe is officially recognized by Congress as a sovereign nation, and though its development projects must meet Federal standards, certain land owned by the tribe, like the casino site, is not subject to local zoning regulations and property taxes.
While residents are pleased about the new job opportunities Foxwoods has brought to the area, some worry that they have no town agency, like a zoning board, where they can discuss issues involving the casino, said State Senator Catherine Welles Cook, a Republican from Groton, whose district includes Stonington, North Stonington and Preston.
 
'Independent Folks'
 "These are communities that decide things in town meetings," she said. "They're independent folks. There is no place for them to go to say, 'Wait a minute. I can't turn left out of my driveway to go to church in the morning,' or, 'What are they doing about wetlands?' The casino could be the best thing since ice cream. But they aren't sure of that, because they haven't participated in it."
But First Selectman Nicholas H. Mullane 2d of North Stonington, which adjoins Ledyard, has a different outlook. Residents can turn to their local legislators, he said, adding that the Mashantucket Pequots have been good neighbors. Fire and emergency vehicles owned by the tribe respond to accidents on roads in the area and the tribe has kept nearby towns informed about its development plans.
Furthermore, the lines of traffic on Route 2 did not originate with the casino, Mr. Mullane maintained. Instead, the traffic was building for years, and even though a plan for improving the road was drawn up in the 1970's, only minor changes have been made, Mr. Mullane said: "This just put the last nail in the coffin."
The Route 2 corridor is an area of wooded hills, wetlands, farmlands, scattered homes and occasional businesses. While many residents would welcome motels, shops and restaurants seeking to capitalize on the growing number of casino visitors, there are just as many people who oppose further development, Mrs. Cook said. The answer involves the need to build a tax base and at the same time preserve the rural environment.
 
Farmland to Condos?
 "How do we protect our farmland from being made into condos?" she asked. "We need to have funds to commit to planning, and we need a tax base to preserve that land so that everyone's needs will be protected." 
Ledyard, North Stonington and Preston are considering new zoning regulations to protect their towns from unchecked growth. In Ledyard, for instance, acreage along Routes 2 and 214 in the northeast corner of town was rezoned to a resort-commercial cluster district, according to Mr. Amt, to prevent haphazard growth. And North Stonington residents are considering new regulations that will permit motels and hotels on Route 2 if the construction is compatible with existing development..
The chief executives of the three towns said that a plan proposed by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. for distributing a portion of the casino's slot machine revenue to local governments failed to take into account the casino's effect on their towns. And since a casino is above local and state taxation, the towns would be left to pay for added costs from its development.
The three town officials met with the Governor to discuss the problem and are now working with Mrs. Cook and other southeastern Connecticut legislators on a plan that would give their towns greater shares of the revenue.
 
$30 Million From Slots in 1992
 Under the agreement between the Governor and the Mashantucket Pequot tribe, $30 million in revenue from the slot machines in 1992 and about $100 million in the following years will be distributed to the 169 cities and towns in the state. Governor Weicker chose to allocate the money through the state's PILOT (Payment in Lieu of Taxes) program, which compensates communities that have large amounts of tax-exempt property.
But Mr. Lozier said Ledyard would receive only $37,000 under this plan. "Nothing has bothered people as much as the way that money was divided up," he said. "People in this town are furious about that."
By contrast, Preston, which has 90 percent of the state-owned Norwich Hospital property within its boundaries, would receive $529,000 in slot machine revenue, according to First Selectman Parke C. Spicer.
The towns in southeastern Connecticut have yet to feel the effects of the casino in full swing, said Mr. Dibble, the Stonington First Selectman. "The only thing that hasn't made the situation uncontrollable is the fact that we are in a recession. The recession has kept people away from vacations. It may be several years after the economy turns around before we deal with what could be a most difficult situation."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
The Clinton Fuel Tax Finds a Few Unexpected Allies

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
ORDINARILY, big companies are not eager for their customers to pay higher taxes any more than the customers themselves like it. But President Clinton's proposed energy tax is demonstrating that, among big auto-makers, refiners and utilities, politics is thicker than oil.
If enacted as proposed, the tax would raise gasoline prices by at least 8 cents a gallon, and a typical homeowner's electric bill by $1.50. However, General Motors, Ford and Chrysler have decided they support the higher fuel tax, and, broadly speaking, so do the chairmen of Arco, the refining company, and Southern California Edison, the utility. Other companies the tax would hurt have hinted that they are not entirely against it. 
 It is help the Administration badly needs. The vast majority of oil and electric companies are on record opposing the tax, but "the fact that you have a few symbolic major players that come out and support a position like this makes an enormous difference," said Alfred A. Marcus, a professor of management at Carleton College in Northfield, Minn. Offering an example, he pointed to airline deregulation during the Carter Administration. Most carriers fought it bitterly, but when United Airlines broke ranks, the White House carried the day, largely because it could say that some in the industry liked its idea.
Why do some players defect? It sounds backwards -- General Motors concluding that what is good for the country is good for G.M. But all of the backers of the tax say that the most important goal is to revive the economy and cut the deficit. Each also has its own reasons -- some of them subject to cynical interpretation.
The domestic car-makers have one overriding legislative goal: to avoid stricter fuel economy requirements. Today their car fleets must get an average of 27.5 miles per gallon, but many in Congress would like to raise that to 40 miles per gallon.
For a few years, the car-makers have been saying they would prefer a higher gasoline tax as a way to discourage gasoline use. Cynics said they did so only because they were sure Congress would never pass one. But the companies offer other explanations.
 
Now Detroit Builds Econo-Boxes
 "If the government is serious about regulating energy, then they ought to do it through market-based approaches, such as a gasoline tax or broad-based energy tax, rather than the command and control approach," said William H. Noack, a General Motors spokesman. Expensive gasoline, the company argues, would make car shoppers conscious of mileage but leave them choices. A 40-mile-per-gallon standard would leave them almost no choice, because car makers would have to sell small cars almost exclusively.
A third possibility is that Detroit smells competitive advantage. The old image of the thrifty Japanese econo-box is out of whack; lately the Japanese have shipped more and more hot cars with thirsty engines. If gas prices go up, then the American models, slightly more efficient and slightly duller, would start looking more attractive
Arco is more surprising. Its chief executive, Lodwrick M. Cook, a co-chairman of the Bush-Quayle campaign, said Mr. Clinton "has taken a gutsy step and deserves our support." "In a very positive and persuasive way," Mr. Cook said, "he has sent a signal to the world that America is serious about putting its economic house in order."
Arco, along with Conoco and Phillips, had previously endorsed gasoline taxes. Of the three, Arco especially has made a career of being a maverick. It espoused pollution-cutting changes in gasoline formulas, for example, and was ready to meet them before its competitors could because it has an unusually adaptable refinery.
Arco, said a company spokesman, keeps its prices low and "can compete effectively in any market out there," including one shrunk by taxes.
An independent oil expert pointed out that taking a counter-intuitive stand is always good for publicity, and maybe for access to the White House too.
Also, the expert said, it is not yet clear whether the energy tax will apply to the oil used in the refinery process itself -- about 5 percent of the total. If that oil is taxed, refining abroad will become much cheaper. If domestic refiners relentlessly oppose the tax, they may lose their leverage over important details like that.
 
Selling Its Skills
 Gaining competitive advantage plays a role among the utilities, too. Southern California Edison is a leader in energy conservation and in producing electricity from renewable sources like wind and sunlight, which would not be taxed. The company could sell its technology and skills around the country. Its chairman, John Bryson, has endorsed an energy tax, if some of it goes toward energy-efficient technologies.
Under a tax, different utilities would face different challenges. Those that buy coal could probably pass the costs directly to customers through fuel-adjustment clauses. Those that own hydroelectric dams or nuclear reactors will have the harder task of applying for rate increases, said Mary Kenkel, a spokeswoman for the Edison Electric Institute, which represents investor-owned utilities.
And some utilities are meeting with the White House to discuss details like whether the tax could be added to the bottom of the customer's bill, as some telephone taxes are, rather than quietly incorporated into the bottom line in a way that makes the utility a tax-collector in disguise. Ms. Kenkel said, "I don't know if they're going to support it, or they just want it fixed."
Whatever position the companies take, the tax will probably cut consumption only marginally. John Lichtblau, chairman of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, noted that the estimated reduction in oil consumption is about 350,000 barrels a day in the year 2000 -- that's from an assumed base of 18 million barrels a day, about a million barrels a day more than is used today. "Imports," he said, "will be significantly higher."

HEADLINE: THEATER;
In Westport, 'Merchant of Venice'

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
Following a no-frills revue earlier this season, aptly called "No Frills," the Fairfield County Stage Company in Westport is giving in to no-frills Shakespeare. It is inaptly called "The Merchant of Venice."
One understands that Christopher Cull, the director but not the master of the conceit, was looking to make Shakespeare "getable," especially to students in the Fairfield County middle and high schools that are participating in the theater company's educational outreach program. 
 He was also looking to make it affordable, given the economic disadvantage of running a small nonprofit theater. Mr. Cull, who is also the company's associate director, even explains his intentions -- "an approach, not an adaptation" -- from the obligatory nod to the play being the thing, right down to an apologia, in his program notes, about line cuts.
Counterproductively, the play, so approached, is not the thing. Nor is the production, though it is filled with arbitrary effects adaptable to, or approachable by, a play by any other name in the canon. Footlights, sometimes red, shine at stage rear. Flashlights are turned on to denote darkness. Iridescent tubes are twirled. There are steps and there is a stool. And Jessica does a balcony scene on the theater's real balcony.
How then does this "Merchant" according to Mr. Cull begin? For it is the beginning that sets the unwavering style for the next two-and-a-half hours.
Actors, five of them dressed unchangingly in white shirts and black trousers, introduce themselves: "Dramatis personae" at first; then, specifically by name, preceded by stage direction. Thus: "Act I, Scene 2; Belmont, a room in Portia's house; enter Portia and Nerissa." Then the scene. Follow?
A one-man band, Stephen Nunns, fills in as the voice of the people, of servants, attendants, messengers and the ominous sci-fi invisible mouthpiece of the Duke, replete with echoes, at Shylock's trial.
For students, themes will emerge -- love, friendship, tolerance, greed and benevolence -- especially with classroom preparation and follow-through, but this is at the expense of characterization, flow and the play's own impulse and internal logic.
To one for whom the quality of the "Merchant" remains unduly strained, a bare-boned approach ought to work. That it does not, further diminishes the play and nullifies Mr. Cull's intentions. Except for the actors; that is, four of them. Ken Triwush is a clownish Launcelot, a melancholy Antonio, a bold Gratiano and Tubal, too, as ordered. Leah Maddrie (Nerissa, Salerio, Old Gobbo) is versatile. Jerry Gomis is agile as Bassanio and two princes. All speak and move well.
Though the differences between Gwendolyn Lewis as Jessica and Gwendolyn Lewis as Portia are barely discernible -- Ms. Lewis also plays Solanio -- but the fact is that she is a gifted actress, possessed of distinct diction, of fair countenance, of commanding presence, and it is pleasing to hear her speak the speeches and simply say the lines with grace and style.
If it has not yet been made clear to the reader that 5 actors are thrust into 14 roles, be assured that it gets no clearer for the audience, in spite of repeated announcements. For example, "Act IV: Enter Lorenzo and Jessica," and so on.
Especially when it falls to William Shust, not one of the four acting exceptions, to appear as the dreamy Lorenzo, who is Jessica's husband, and the shyster Shylock, who is Jessica's father. Both parts are similarly intoned, neither believably.
In his magnificent plan, Shakespeare created Shylock as a master of irrationality and duality. All the oxymoronica are there: he is oppressor and oppressed, persecutor and persecuted, a wronged villain, a dignified, gentle usurper, the object and the holder of contempt, a small man of stature, a manipulative victim, a maniacal gentleman. It is up to the actor to humanize the character, but there are no revelations here. Those who approach Shylock with hostility, with compassion, with uncertainty, won't change their minds.
Shylock can be played with bitter, angry objectivity, but there is no need to go on with the inexhaustible interpretive possibilities when Mr. Shust, who expectorates with ennui but is more energetically spat at, cowering and stooping, is a Shylock of quiet ineffectuality, more disgruntled than disgraced.
It helps no one to inflict upon Mr. Shust double duty, for the uneasy transition from Shylock to Lorenzo, particularly in the same scene, seems more demanding for the audience than of the actor.
In the end, such streamlined Shakespeare turns into an uninvolving, abstract exercise in acting scenes, doing tricks and displaying half-baked ideas. Does Antonio have a homosexual attraction for Bassanio or does he not? Call it confusion for the sake of clarity.
"The Merchant of Venice," the Westport Playhouse, 25 Powers Court; 227-1072. Performances through next Sunday.

GRAPHIC: Photo: William Shust in "The Merchant of Venice" in Westport. (Jayson Byrd)

HEADLINE: Yarns Spun, Souls Blessed By Old Salt on City Turf

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
SAILOR JOE O'DONNELL swaggered into his compact room on Park Street in New Haven the other day, clutching his cane and a plastic bag stuffed with treasures he'd collected from the neighborhood's Dumpsters: a pair of designer sneakers, soap dishes, croissants, poppy seed muffins and a half a loaf of French bread. He plugged in his coffee pot and turned on the light.
"This is all going for my girls," said the sailor, who is 78 years old. He was referring to the prostitutes and other street dwellers who stroll the sidewalks below his window or make their homes in the nearby back alleys in abandoned buildings. 
 "Let's see," he said, "there's Susan, she's on the street with no place to go. Big fat Pat, she's been living in empty buildings for 25 years. Roseann, she's in her 50's and always getting kicked around by all those animals. Denise, she's on the needle real bad."
He paused and rubbed his yellow beard. "And oh Jesus Lord Christ, then there's Margo. She's the worst one. She'll steal you blind."
The sailor, formerly with the merchant marine, is a fixture within the street world of the city's downtown district. Stocky and tattooed, he survives on a modest Social Security check and whatever he can sell or hustle through the well-routed underground economy.
 
Making the Rounds
 Almost every day he makes his rounds with a pushcart collecting from trash containers a bounty of discards that he often gives away to those down on their luck. He gets European bread and pastries from the bistros that line Chapel Street, fruit and vegetables from a Korean grocery and meat from street vendors. "My toilet paper comes from Yale University," he added.
At the end of a semester, as Yale students move out of their dormitories, he waits by the nearby trash containers where he's garnered mattresses, portable refrigerators and wall hangings. To protect his stash, he fastens a makeshift blackjack to the inside of his pant leg. "You've always got to watch your back," he said.
Mr. O'Donnell said he survived the streets and the high seas because of his penchant for blarney and adeptness for living outside the law. As a lifelong renegade he said he has robbed banks, jewelry stores and package stores as well as broken into safes, picked pockets and forged checks. "I was also a drunk," he said.
 
Multi-National Convict
 His machinations brought about dozens of jail stints including ones in South Africa, Japan and Thailand, he said. He served his last prison term at Somers Correctional Institution in the early 1980's after he was convicted on several charges of forgery and theft. He was paroled to a home-release program through the Y.M.C.A. on Howe Street, where he lived for six years before moving in 1990 to the rooming house on Park Street two blocks away.
All the 12 men who live there survive on welfare assistance or Social Security checks. They cook on hot plates and share a hallway bathroom. The sailor's room is by far the homiest and most evocative.
"Take off your coat," he said to a recent visitor. "Don't worry, I won't dig through your pockets."
 
By the Heat of a Popcorn Popper
 Rosaries dangled from window shelves, and collages of nude women as well as ceramic dolls, stuffed animals and hangings of schooners decorated other surfaces. Walls were covered with Christmas wrapping paper that he had hung with staples. Five stereo speakers, six radios and two television sets were scattered about. Whenever it got too cold he would plug in a popcorn popper to take the chill out of the room. "If you're a bum, you've got to be innovative," said the sailor.
A white plastic bucket filled with soapy water sat on one side of the room. He said he used it to wash the clothes of the women who visited him. He was not in love with any of them, he said, they were more like fair-weather friends.
Across the hall, Manuel Borrero, a soft-spoken man who recently underwent double-bypass surgery, was cooking a vegetable stew. Down the hall, Herman Martinez sat and watched two televisions at once while he boiled a slab of pork on a hot plate. In the room below the sailor lived a young man who was a drug addict with AIDS. At night, Mr. O'Donnell said, he could hear the man's screams. The only time the man left the building was to get a shot of heroin, the sailor said.
 
The Mean Streets
 While the sailor told a story about the time he got shot "five times by a hit man for the Mafia" for robbing one of its restaurants, a woman named Susan staggered through his door. "Word out on the street is that Margo's dead," she said, then fell into a chair.
The sailor hardly blinked. "I knew she was headed for deep trouble," he said.
Susan, who has been drinking, had heard that Margo, who lived on the streets, had bought a $20 bag of heroin for $10 and "never cleared her account." Margo was known on the streets for stealing, the young woman said, and when the drug dealers caught up to her they "beat her all the way down Chapel Street, then ran over her with a car." Stories of beatings and murder over drugs often circulated through the streets, said the sailor, and it always took time for the truth to surface.
Susan, who is 26 years old, said she had been living on the streets for six years. She was an alcoholic and heroin addict, she said, and was trying to get into a methadone program. She made her living by panhandling and by borrowing money from friends.
 
Without Him, 'I'd Be Dead'
 Susan had known the sailor for three years, ever since he moved to Park Street from the Y.M.C.A. He washed her clothes and gave her money when she needed it. "He's an old salt," the young woman said, throwing her arm around his shoulders. "Without the sailor, I'd be dead."
But there was a dark side to his character, she added, and when it surfaced he could be moody and irascible. "I wish I had a bag of dope for every time he's thrown me out of here," she said.
She stood up and announced that she's going out to panhandle to buy some more wine. "I won't hear it," the sailor snapped, and handed her $2. The young woman staggered out the door.
 
One of 18 Children
 The sailor said he was raised in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., one of 18 children. His mother died while she was carrying her 19th child, he said, after being struck by a bus. His father worked in the coal mines and to make ends meet ran a speakeasy in the basement of their home. Mr. O'Donnell said he and his brothers began stealing as children to help support the family. "We'd steal coal, food, anything we could get our hands on then," he said. "You had to. Times were hard."
At 16 he was sent to a reformatory school for stealing. For months, he said, he was assigned to work in the field with two plow horses until one day he led them to a trough, wrote a note to his guardian that read, "see you later," and ran away to Philadelphia. It was 1939.
He joined the merchant marine and for the next 30 years sailed around the world dozens of times, usually during eight-month shifts. He towed every cargo imaginable, he said, and during World War II worked on patrol boats and carried munitions, food and supplies to operations in the Atlantic and Pacific. He also sailed on the Liberty ships, which were considered the workhorses of the seas. "There's nothing more wicked than sailing the North Atlantic," he said. "For weeks afterwards you'd be walking sideways."
While he was landbound he stayed in seamen's homes until he was called out to sea. He moved to New Haven in the mid-1960's.
 
Rob Them and Leave Them
 He had a daughter and a son from his first marriage, both of whom are now in their late 30's. His daughter, he said, drove a municipal bus in New Haven. Over the years, other women showed an interest in him, but he rarely reciprocated the feelings. "I'd promise them, rob them, then leave them," he said.
The true love of his life was his second wife, Betty, with whom he spent 15 years before she died of jaundice in 1978. He still carries her picture inside a heart-shaped locket. She was a hard drinker, he said, and spent much of her time on the New Haven green with other alcoholics. Many times he'd have to go to her rescue before the police would arrive and "cart all the drunks away in a fire truck with brass railings."
But despite her problem with alcohol, the sailor said, "She was a nice drunk and a good dancer, too." She often brought destitute people up to their apartment on Howe Street, in order to feed and clothe them. She was buried on Valentine's Day, he said, and every year on that day, "I get drunker than a pig."
He often longed for those days, he said, adding that the streets are much meaner now and devoid of trust. He said there was a respect among alcoholics in those days that you don't find now among drug addicts. He had good friends then too, he said, people you could count on. "But all the oldtimers are dead now," he said. "Nature Boy, Joe Ryan, the Coogans, all of them are gone."
 
Accomplice Named Friskie
 The next day, the sailor was sitting on his bed weaving nautical knots from a piece of twine. He was worried, he said, because his friend Susan had just stopped by after spending the night in jail. She'd gotten into a fight with a man named Canine. "She left here crying a while ago," he said. The temperature outside was falling and there was no telling what might happen to her. He said he still didn't know for sure if Margo was dead.
It didn't take long befor the sailor broke out other stories from his past, like the one about how he used to be a bootlegger on Howe Street by buying up cheap wine and selling it on Sundays. He'd reel the bottles down in a plastic crate with a rope while customers stood in the alleyway. Then he told the one about his dog named Friskie; he had trained her to bury the wallets from people he had pickpocketed.
"After the cops would frisk me, come up empty-handed and leave," he said, "I'd give a whistle and say, 'fetch me the bone, Friskie,' and she'd return with the cash."
That afternoon he was preparing to go on his Dumpster rounds, then come home to watch television. He said he liked Sally Jessy Raphael's talk show best because of the offbeat people that appeared on her program.
The sailor broke into a toothless grin and held out his hand. "You come see me anytime," he said to his visitor. "And make sure you tell everybody that I'm a good Catholic."

HEADLINE: New in the 2d Grade: Business Education

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
FOR 74 years, Junior Achievement has taught teen-agers about business, but last year its volunteer adult executives appeared in second-grade classrooms. They came with programs intended to give students as young as kindergarteners hands-on lessons in the basic skills they will need to become part of the future work force.
Too young, one might think, to understand things like decision-making or an assembly production line. Not so, said Leigh J. Abrams, the chairman of the Westchester County division of Junior Achievement of the Hudson Valley, which celebrated its 20th anniversary last month. The programs, he said, give young children incentives to learn. 
 "Studies show that potential dropouts can be identified as early as the second grade," Mr. Abrams said. "In response, the kindergarten-through-sixth-grade program was developed after years of research to reach young, at-risk students early and teach them the benefits of staying in school."
The Westchester division, he said, was one of the first in the country selected for the pilot program last year.
"It received such rave reviews from teachers and business people that we expanded it from 2,500 to 5,000 students this year," Mr. Abrams said. "By the 1995-96 school year, we hope to reach 10,000 students in our area, especially those in urban school districts, so students there who are most at risk of dropping out will have Junior Achievement programs available every year from kindergarten through the 12th grade."
 
The Skills They'll Need
 Angela D. Giustino, president of Junior Achievement of the Hudson Valley, said the program's objective is to introduce elementary students to the economic concept of choice and interdependence and to help make them aware of the wide range of jobs open to them and the skills they will need to fill those jobs.
John Pagliaroli, a New York Telephone customer service manager in Yonkers, spends an hour a week with the second-grade class at the Midland School in Yonkers.
"I begin by telling the kids what I do for a living, and that leads us into a discussion of the different kinds of jobs," said Mr. Pagliaroli, who was also a volunteer in the pilot program.
"I start the program by showing them how a community operates so they will be aware of how people live and work together," he said. "I use a map with pictures of public buildings, stores and other buildings, and we identify the variety of occupations held by people in the community and we talk about what skills are needed for the different jobs."
Hands-on activities are a big part of the program, Mr. Pagliaroli said. "In the Sweet-O-Factory, a simulation of a commercial doughnut factory, kids are introduced to the economic concepts of production, and they learn to work cooperatively," he said. "They start by coloring doughnuts individually and then they form an assembly line where each child colors only one part of the doughnut, using crayons that stand for yellow, brown and red flavors.
"Over the course of the program, you see the kids begin to understand the value and importance of work and the kinds of work people do, plus the skills they need to do different jobs."
 
An Award-Winning Recruiter
 Barbara A. Squires, office systems administration manager at I.B.M.'s corporate headquarters in Armonk, has been a Junior Achievement volunteer at the Somers Middle School for five years.
"I enjoy the work with children so much that I have won an award this year for recruiting the largest number of my peers as volunteers, eight from I.B.M. this year," Mrs. Squires said. "I work with eighth graders, 13-year-olds, and invariably the first question they ask me when we begin evaluating careers is, 'How much can I make and how fast can I make it?' "
The eight-week program deals with the relationship of school subjects to careers, she said.
"They make the connection between the skills acquired in school and those needed to succeed in the outside world," she said. "We use hands-on learning experience to demonstrate such things as how to handle money, the importance of responsibility and dependability.
 
The Hard Part of Selling
 "In one activity, for example, I set up a mock Disney World, and everyone has to apply for a job. Everyone gets a job, and they individually learn to deal with the situations that might arise on the job."
Junior Achievement's programs have also been adapted to the economics course now required of seniors in the state's high schools.
Every Friday, Michael Maloney, a banker at the Hudson Valley Bank in Yonkers, and Charles Gutekunst, a computer information-systems manager at the Yonkers Contracting Company, teach seniors in Jeffrey Roberts's economics class at Gorton High School in Yonkers about business.
"We study textbook economics four days a week, and the fifth day it's hands-on experience in economics," Mr. Roberts said. "With help and advice from the volunteers, the students sell stock to create a company, elect company officers and choose a product. One of our classes picked boxer shorts to sell, the other crystal pendants. Eventually, the company is closed down, and the profits are divided among the students."
The students, Mr. Roberts said, were surprised to find out how difficult it is to sell.
"At first they were very confident that selling would be a snap, the easiest part of the operation," he said. "However, although the crystal pendants were a popular item, the boxer shorts were difficult to sell. But the students persevered, and eventually both companies made a profit, and all of them got dividend checks. For some, it was the first time they had seen a check."
 
Volunteers Benefit, Too
 Such firsthand experience in business, Mr. Roberts said, can significantly reduce the dropout rate for students in urban areas by supplying them with activities that have tangible results and lessons that relate to the real world.
Mr. Abrams, who owns Drew Industries, a building-products manufacturing company in White Plains, is also an executive volunteer at the Woodlands High School in Greenburgh.
"I believe the volunteers get as much out of the experience as the students," Mr. Abrams said. "I've been doing it for years now. It's rewarding to me to see how kids with little prior contact with the business world quickly and enthusiastically learn the ropes."
Other lessons are also learned. The students on one project -- designing and selling T-shirts with a "Peace Throughout the World" logo -- had to make an ethical decision when the supplier sent them more T-shirts than they had ordered, he said.
"The class debated whether or not to call it to his attention," he said. "They had ordered 150 T-shirts and he sent them 165, but 11 were damaged. They did tell the supplier, and he told them that because it was his error, they could keep the extra shirts without charge. They eventually made a 300 percent profit on the business."
Junior Achievement programs cost the schools nothing, Ms. Giustino said, adding: "We have no government funding. We are entirely supported by corporate contributions, foundations, special fund-raising events, individual gifts and the work of our executive volunteers."

HEADLINE: Russia's Crisis

BYLINE: By Richard Pipes; Richard Pipes, professor of history at Harvard, is author of "The Russian Revolution."

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
Russia faces three options: it can continue to progress, however haltingly, toward democracy and a free market, relapse into some form of dictatorship, or dissolve in anarchy.
Contrary to conventional wisdom, the economy has not caused the present crisis: While it is far from satisfactory, nobody is starving and private initiative is beginning to fill the vacuum created by the breakdown of state ownership. There is food in stores, public transport is running, telephones are operating. Life goes on. 
 Russia's problems have always been first and foremost political, and today's predicament is no different. We are witnessing an attempt by the old Communist nomenklatura, or ruling class, to recapture power and the privileges that went with it, while using the parlous state of the economy as a pretext.
Led by an ambitious adventurer, Ruslan Khasbulatov, the chairman of the unrepresentative body called the Congress of People's Deputies, it is trying to gain by parliamentary maneuvering what it failed to acquire by military power in August 1991. It is a clever ploy because it conceals a bid for dictatorial authority behind claims of the defense of parliamentary democracy. The stratagem has sown confusion among Western leaders, taught by historical experience to side with parliament against individuals aspiring to personal power.
In this case, the conflict does not pit a duly elected legislative against a power-greedy chief executive. It is the President who has been democratically elected while the Congress is a largely self-appointed body dating to the Soviet Union. It is Boris Yeltsin who represents the nation. The proof is that the Congress has reneged on its pledge to hold a referendum next month in which, among other things, voters would be asked to decide whether they preferred presidential or parliamentary government. If Mr. Yeltsin's opponents thought they could win, they would have insisted on such a referendum.
In recent months, Russia has had, as in 1917, a dual Government in which authority has been exercised independently by the executive and legislature. This situation obviously cannot endure, and that is why the conflict has come to a head.
In the best of all worlds for the conservatives, who are mostly diehard Communists, they would remove Mr. Yeltsin and vest executive power in a parliamentary cabinet. If pushed, they might acquiesce to a ceremonial head of state. Presidential rule, they maintain, is alien to Russia (which is true) whose traditional form of government is the democratic collective (which is ludicrous).
They are emulating the tactic used by Lenin and Trotsky in October 1917, who accused Kerensky of dictatorial ambitions and demanded that he yield power to the Congress of Soviets, which they had packed with their own followers. A true dictatorship followed.
Should they succeed, Mr. Yeltsin's conservative opponents are unlikely to restore full-fledged Communism: The system has disintegrated too far for this to be a realistic alternative. They are more likely to follow the Romanian pattern, which retains the substance of Communism under different labels. This would entail restricting political and press freedom and introducing the so-called regulated market. They would probably make use of Russian troops deployed in the independent republics and in the guise of protecting the Russian minorities and maintaining regional "stability" attempt to re-establish the empire. And they would resume the arms race to regain Russia's superpower status.
Could they succeed? No, for two reasons. Most Russians, judging by opinion polls, even though disappointed by democracy have no desire for a dictatorship. A counter-revolution would unleash social and ethnic turmoil with which the putschists, even if initially successful, could not cope.
Moreover, Mr. Yeltsin is no vacillating Kerensky but a formidable politician, unwilling to be reduced to a figurehead let alone be displaced from power. Ill-suited to routine administration, impulsive and feisty, he is at his best when fighting for his political life. He has tried to assuage his opponents by numerous concessions, but they have interpreted each concession as a sign of weakness and an excuse to demand more until there is nothing left to concede.
To build his political base, Mr. Yeltsin has negotiated with moderately conservative groups and made some inroads into their camp. He has made contact with the military, which holds the key to any decisive power struggle. He makes no secret that he has been laying the groundwork for the imposition of emergency rule, which would enable him to continue political and economic reforms. His repeated warnings to this effect are no bluff.
If he takes this road, Mr. Yeltsin is much less likely to establish a personal dictatorship, which would make him very vulnerable, than to create a strong executive based on a popular mandate. This he will probably seek through a referendum held in defiance of the Congress in which voters will be asked to approve the presidential form of government, with its strong executive, and then convene a constituent assembly to give the country a democratic constitutional charter.
He should have taken such measures a year ago, when the memory of the failed August putsch was fresh and the conservative apparatus, paralyzed with fear, lay low.
The West's leverage is not formidable. Economic aid, on which some advocates of intervention rely, is not very relevant -- no more than it would have been in 1917, because at issue now, as then, is political power, not the economy. Even large-scale transfers of capital and food will not save the nascent democracy if the Russian people are not prepared to stand up and fight for it.
The most helpful thing the West can do is to throw the full weight of its support behind Mr. Yeltsin, for even reactionary Communists are sensitive to the prospect of international isolation and its economic implications. It is a welcome sign that after initial hesitation, Washington seems to have realized that the success of democracy in Russia may require resort to methods that in the West would be unacceptable. It should persist in this course and not allow itself to be misled by the putschists' professions that they are fighting for the cause of representative government against a would-be dictator.
Exactly like the Bolsheviks in 1917, they are exploiting populist slogans to camouflage a bid for authoritarian rule. Their success would be fraught with the gravest dangers to their own people and the rest of the world.

HEADLINE: Muslims' Fury Falls on Egypt's Christians

SERIES: Cornered By Fervor -- A Special Report

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, March 14

 BODY:
In a striking example of the power of Muslim fundamentalists, nearly 10 million Coptic Christians in Egypt, the largest religious minority in the Middle East and one of its most ancient, are under siege.
Copts from all walks of life are being attacked, robbed and killed by roving bands of fundamentalists. Churches are regularly vandalized and sometimes burned, prompting the Government to place virtually all them under police guard. 
 As Islamic fundamentalism has become a rallying cry for opposition groups throughout the Arab world, Christian Arabs have come under pressure that in the last few years has vastly diminished their political, social and economic status in Egypt, Lebanon, Jordan, Iraq and Syria and among Palestinians in the territories occupied by Israel. As a result, hundreds of thousands have emigrated to the United States, Canada, Western Europe and Australia.
 
Fundamentalists' Targets
 The sharpening hostility toward Christian Arabs is a byproduct of a wider Muslim fundamentalist challenge that began in the late 1970's. Militants have made secularist Arab governments their targets, including those of Syria, Egypt, Tunisia, Algeria and Jordan, as well as pro-Western fundamentalist nations like Saudi Arabia and others in the Persian Gulf.
The movement, which encompasses many groups, has gradually widened its targets to include Western interests regarded as a natural extension of secular modernization. Hostages were taken in Beirut by Muslim fundamentalists with close ties to Iran, where an Islamic Government came to power in 1979. Bombs planted by fundamentalist immigrants recruited from abroad shook France. Western airliners were hijacked and destroyed.
Now the United States may have become a target, too, as investigators pursue leads suggesting that Muslim fundamentalists were connected to the bombing of the World Trade Center in New York last month.
In Egypt, the Arab world's largest country, it is the little-known Christian minority that has become the main victim of Muslim violence.
Copts are reckoned to be a link to Egypt's Pharaonic past, direct descendants of the original inhabitants of the country. The word "Copt" has its origins in a Greek word meaning Egyptian. Christianity came to Egypt in the year 41, and the Coptic church was among the so-called Oriental churches that split with Rome in 451 in a theological dispute. After the Islamic Arab invasion of the seventh century, many Copts eventually converted to Islam.
The assaults against Copts, which have claimed 150 to 200 lives, are part of a strategy to bring down the Government of President Hosni Mubarak in favor of an Islamic republic like that in Iran. Militants hope to destabilize the country with the violence, which has also claimed victims among Muslim Government officials and security forces. In October, foreign tourists were added to the list of targets in an effort to devastate the tourism industry, which is crucial to the Egyptian economy.
Among the Muslim leaders who have called for attacks on Christians and others is Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, the exiled Egyptian cleric who lives in New York. Sheik Rahman, who was tried and acquitted in the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat by fundamentalists in 1981, and who calls for the overthrow of the Egyptian Government, has preached at mosques in Jersey City and Brooklyn to which suspects in the World Trade Center bombing have been linked.
Most Egyptians, including Copts, believe the Egyptian Government can contain fundamentalist violence here. But a majority of Christians and the Coptic Church leadership argue that the Government fosters a climate of religious intolerance that encourages violence against them. Benign neglect and pointed discrimination against Copts have been practiced by successive Egyptian Governments, including that of Mr. Mubarak, many Copts assert.
 
High Posts Denied Them
 In the last two decades, Christian Egyptians have been systematically eliminated from positions as Cabinet ministers, army officers, police officials, governors, bankers, parliamentary representatives and university professors.
In what many Copts see as one of most blatant examples of sanctioned discrimination, archaic laws from the Ottoman Empire have been used to ban the construction of new churches and the repair of ancient ones for nearly 30 years, severely constraining the practice of Christianity in Egypt and placing a rich heritage of centuries-old monasteries, churches and icons at risk.
A climate of fear and rejection has become pervasive enough that many Coptic women, abandoning a practice followed since Christianity came to Egypt nearly 2,000 years ago, refrain from displaying crosses. In Cairo, Christian schools have raised the walls surrounding them by several feet for added protection. At public schools, Christian children complain they learn nothing of their religion and are often insulted, ostracized or humiliated by militant Muslim teachers.
"We are living through moments of terror," said Sabri Khalil Ghabrial, a 37-year-old surgeon in El Minya, a city in southern Egypt. "There are days when you go into the streets not knowing what may happen to you."
Dr. Ghabrial narrowly escaped being taken hostage by fundamentalist students when he was studying medicine a few years ago at Asyut University, 100 miles south of El Minya. His uncle was shot and wounded in his pharmacy in December in Dairut, a small town in the region.
 
The Violence
Attacks in City And Countryside
 The attacks on Christians began in southern Egypt, a fiercely conservative, emotionally combustible region whose people have strong ties to the land going back centuries. In the 1980's and 90's the attacks moved to large urban centers up the Valley of the Nile, including the capital, Cairo.
Amid almost weekly reports of violence against Christians, a massacre in Dairut stood out as a particularly shocking example. On May 4, 1991, a group of Muslims mowed down 13 Christian peasants with machine-gun fire as they tilled their lands outside the village. Three other Copts were killed in town, one a doctor who was tending to a patient in his clinic.
Last October in the village of Tema, about 90 miles south of El Minya, 4 Christians were killed with axes in their homes by Muslims. The fundamentalists returned in greater numbers the next day and burned 64 houses and dozens of stores owned by Christians as well as a church before the police and firemen showed up.
Attacks claiming scores of victims have also taken place in Cairo, Alexandria, Faiyum and other large cities.
"In the face of these assaults the Government's reaction was always coming in too late after the people are killed, after the houses have burned down and the churches sacked," said Antoun Sidhom, editor and publisher of Watani, a weekly Coptic newspaper. "They never offered to pay compensation or provided credible comfort to their Christian citizens."
In many ways, some Copts say, the ultimate shock came in October, after a British tourist was killed in an attack. The Government, mindful that tourism was its single largest source of foreign revenue last year, bringing in $3.5 billion to $4 billion, began a huge security sweep that is still under way, resulting in the arrests of thousands of suspected militants.
Many Christians took this response as a chilling message.
"It is as if the Government is telling everyone, 'It's O.K. if you munch on little Copts, but don't touch the tourists,' " said Mr. Sidhom, one of a growing number of wealthy, eminent Copts who are publicly addressing discrimination.
In another crackdown last week, 21 people were killed and two dozen were wounded in raids by security forces in Cairo and Aswan. A mosque in Aswan was raided as the police searched for the gunmen who had killed one soldier and wounded another as they were guarding a church.
 
The Fundamentalists
Pluralism Rejected As a Western Idea

The wave of fundamentalist militancy began early in the 1970's, after the Government of Mr. Sadat, seeking a counterweight to a challenge from left-wing Arab nationalists, released hundreds of militant Muslims who had been jailed for much of the previous two decades. Among the Muslim groups that surged into action in that period was the Muslim Brotherhood, which was founded in 1928 and which advocates the taking of power by legitimate political means.
But a much bigger variety of militants, estimated in the tens of thousands and organized under disparate groups with names like Islamic Holy War, also mushroomed. Made up of tiny cells of fundamentalist extremists, they were united in the conviction that the use of force to push Egyptian society toward Islamic rule was a religious duty. Pluralism, they insist, is a decadent Western notion.
Copts were called infidels, natural allies of the hated Western enemies of Islam. Some fundamentalist preachers went so far as to issue religious edicts justifying the shedding of Christian blood as "halal." The Koranic expression roughly translates as "fair game." A result was a growing climate of religious intolerance.
The condition of Christians in Egypt today is a far cry from a golden Coptic era before World War I, when Boutros Ghali Pasha, a Copt and great-grandfather of Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali of the United Nations, was named Prime Minister. Even through the 1940's and 50's, the proportion of Copts in official posts exceeded their proportion of the population. Copts were among Egypt's large landowners, and many were leading members of the Wafd, Egypt's most popular political party before a military coup in 1952 ended the monarchy. Copts have also figured prominently in the evolution of Egyptian and Arab arts, theater and scholarship.
Yet today, even though Christians represent about 17 percent of Egypt's population of 58 million, not one of the 26 provincial governors is Christian. No senior army, police or Government official of any consequence is a Copt. In Parliament, representation of Copts, which peaked at 10 percent in the 1940's, is down to less than 1 percent, a handful of token appointments made by the President.
 
The Church
Some Copts Fault Leaders' Stand
 Part of their trouble, some Copts say, is that their church has turned inward under its present leadership, encouraging the faithful to embrace a posture of patience and prayer instead of social and political activism.
"Today's Coptic Church is suffering from sclerosis," said Amin Faheem, president of the Christian Association of Upper Egypt for Schools Promotion, a charity that runs 38 schools. "It is under dogmatic influence pushing away the more secularists among Christian dignitaries to replace them with theocrats of its own."
Magdi Mehani, a manager for the association in El Minya, said: "What we need here is to find a way to resume the dialogue with Muslims, a peaceful offensive if you will, to break this violent atmosphere. We must save Egypt from extremism. As Copts we must break the isolation being imposed on us."
Many Copts, perhaps half a million in the last 10 years, have simply left. They include a large number of university professors, professionals and wealthy businessmen. From their diaspora in places like the United States and Canada, some are trying to call the world's attention to the Coptic plight while pressing the Coptic Church to be more active.
"They don't call it the church of martyrdom for nothing," said Selim Naguib, a 58-year-old Coptic high court judge in Montreal whose doctoral thesis on Copts represented their situation as a "grave case of human right violations being systematically perpetrated by the Government." Mr. Neguib's Canadian Coptic Association is trying to bring the matter before the United Nations.
"At meetings in church, people often ask me until when are we going to watch silently as they burn our churches and kill our people," said Bishop Arsanious, the 63-year-old religious leader of the Christian communities of Minya Province, whose population of two million is about 20 percent Christian.
The Coptic Church leadership rejects a confrontational approach, arguing that while these are indeed hard times for Christian Arabs they are not the hardest.
"You are looking at the past year or 10 years -- I am looking at 1,900 years of Coptic history," said Father Aghaton, secretary to the supreme religious leader of Egypt's Copts, Pope Shenuda III. "We have gone though horrendous periods of oppression but here we are, strong, well educated and present. The facts are that all the Copts can do is hunker down in bad times and wait until the oppression lifts."
 
The Government
New Mosques, But Not Churches
 While the Administration of President Mubarak is largely secularist and liberal, it has shown increasing deference to Islamic fundamentalists since its beginnings in October 1981, granting many hard-liners space in the official press and yielding to fundamentalist edicts and practices in schools, public administration and business.
Coptic critics say the Government has at the same time gone out of its way to limit various aspects of Christian culture and practices.
According to Government figures, for example, about 125,000 unauthorized mosques and Muslim places of prayer have been built in the last 10 years by Muslims, including militants who control many of these gathering places. In that period, using laws dating from the Ottoman Empire, the Government has consistently denied permission for the construction of more than a handful of churches or the repair of most.
Government officials, who reject talk of an official policy of discrimination against Christians, say that these developments reflect the fierce winds of fundamentalism blowing throughout the region and fanned by militant Muslim nations like Iran and the Sudan in the last two years.
"Secularism has become a dirty word in the Muslim world," said Mamdouh El Beltagui, director of media and information for the Egyptian Government and head of the governing National Party for the Cairo region. "This is what we are up against."
But Mr. Beltagui and other senior Government officials also assert that change is on the way.
"For the first time the large silent centrist majority is feeling that Islamic fundamentalist currents are a threat to its interests, its income and its life style," Mr. Beltagui said. "There is a quantitative shift to the way Egyptian society feels on this issue now; people are no longer spectators."
But for Christians in Egypt, life under siege goes on.
Merim, a maid in a Cairo household with a tattooed green cross on her wrist and chin, as is customary with many Christians from Egypt's deep south, received her "slap of the day," as she put it, on the bus ride home on a recent evening. A man who got up from his seat barred her from taking it.
"It is reserved for Muslims," he told her.

HEADLINE: New Jobs Lack the Old Security In a Time of 'Disposable Workers'

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOLEDO, Ohio, March 12

 BODY:
Employment agencies call them contingent workers, flexible workers or assignment workers. Some labor economists, by contrast, call them disposable and throwaway workers.
Whatever they are called, their numbers are climbing. Federal figures are sketchy, but about half of the jobs people have been getting in the last year are part-time or temporary or involve other unconventional arrangements. That is up from less than a quarter of the new jobs a decade ago. 
 Most of these new jobs pay less than regular jobs, and few come with good benefits. The standard American job, with a 40-hour workweek, medical benefits and a pension at age 65, is on the wane.
"The entire system has fragmented," Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said in an interview earlier this month.
 
'A Market in Motion'
 Audrey Freedman, an economist for Manpower, the big temporary-help company, said: "The labor market today, if you look at it closely, provides almost no long-term secure jobs. It's a market in motion."
As the Clinton Administration ponders changes in the nation's health and welfare systems, the shift in the job market takes on added importance, as it will have long-term implications for Government regulators and taxpayers.
Labor market specialists say the shift accelerated in the recession as companies tried to hold down costs. But they say that much of the shift seems here to stay.
 
Core of Favored Workers
 Many companies have adopted a form of work-force management to compete in the world market. They keep a core of managers and valued workers whom they favor with good benefits and permanent jobs. They take on and shed other workers as business spurts and slumps.
Toledo is home to glass and automobile companies which, while shrinking, are unionized and make little use of contingent workers. It is home, too, to expanding nonunion retail stores, service businesses and small manufacturers that do employ such workers.
State officials report a smattering of offers of very good jobs, requiring high skills and years of experience and paying $12 to $20 an hour, and a surge of offers for low-skill, low-paying jobs.
The area's biggest new employer is the Maijer (pronounced MY-er) discount food and department store chain of Grand Rapids, Mich. It is hiring nearly 3,000 workers for four giant stores it is building here. Nearly all the jobs are part-time and the pay is $4.30 to $4.40 an hour -- 5 cents to 15 cents more than the Federal minimum wage.
The second-biggest new employer is an air-cargo company, Burlington Air Express. Burlington will soon have more than 1,200 sorters working three-hour shifts five days a week. The pay is $8 an hour to start, or $120 a week. Burlington's job advertisements say applicants must "be able to lift 70 pounds consistently."
State officials say that companies have little choice but to pay wages as low as their competitors.
 
Quality Put in Jeopardy
 But industries that strive for quality production run a risk in managing workers this way. The employees have little incentive to give their all when the employer gives little.
"The people never stop looking for full-time employment," said Lin Avendano, an official of the Ohio Bureau of Employment Services. "And when they find it, they leave in an instant."
James J. O'Shea, the 50-year-old manager of a Toledo branch of the Ohio Bureau of Employment Services, put the problem in a personal perspective: "Opportunity -- that's the thing that was here in abundance when I was 18.
"The whole middle of the job market is gone, the $8-an-hour to $13-an-hour jobs. Those middle, family-supportive jobs we've lost."
In Toledo, about 25 temporary-help agencies have displaced most of the permanent-placement agencies. One is Claus Temporaries Inc., whose owner, Pete Claus, finds welders, assemblers, electricians and other workers for small factories as well as clerical workers for offices. Mr. Claus arranges with client companies to pay employees' wages, unemployment insurance and their workers' compensation. But the workers receive no health or pension benefits because, he said, the market would not bear the cost.
 
'New American Sweatshop'
 Mr. Claus said some companies in Toledo were using services like his to provide their entire work force. "I call it the new American sweatshop," he said. "It's four people who are owners or managers in a shop that has 200 people. They might have 12 permanent employees who are making $6.50 an hour. All the others are paid $4.75. And they're all temporaries."
Robert E. Soncrant, who recruits businesses to do their hiring through Mr. O'Shea's state job service office, cited another development. "You find unscrupulous employers who bring people in for 29 days and then let them go," he said. "Why 29 days? Because the employer has an agreement with the union that says that at 30 days the people have to join the union."
Just how many Americans are landing contingent jobs is impossible to pin down. Mr. Reich said he thought about 30 percent of the work force was composed of contingent workers while current statistics suggest that far more of the new jobs are.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics's employment report for February, showing a decline in unemployment to 7 percent of the nation's labor force from 7.1 percent in January, said part-time jobs accounted for 90 percent of the 380,000 new jobs in February. So large a figure is almost certainly a fluke, but it confirmed a less-pronounced, longer-term decline of conventional jobs.
Twenty-four percent of the 1.6 million new jobs since February 1992 were part-time. The University of Toledo reports that 30 percent of its graduates have to take contingent jobs, an uncommonly high proportion for college graduates. Three years ago, 10 percent of the graduates took contingent jobs.
Other numbers reflecting the growth of contingent workers are still murkier. The Bureau of Labor Statistics says another 24 percent of the 1.6 million new jobs represented growth in self-employment. An indeterminate part of the growth in self-employment includes consulting and independent contracting. The Internal Revenue Service offers one hint of what part of those might actually be contingent workers: Employers illegally classified 90,000 workers last year as self-employed contractors. For legitimate independent contractors, employers are not required to pay Social Security and unemployment and workers' compensation.
No one is keeping track of the temporary workers employed directly by companies, without intermediaries.
The bureau says its latest figures show that 1,456,000 people were working through temporary-help agencies in January, 206,000 more than in January 1992. The increase, said Thomas Nardone, a bureau economist, amounted to 30 percent of the jobs that employers reported filling during the year. "It's quite huge," he said.
No one knows how firm this trend is. As the economy improves and the pool of workers shrinks, employers might have to sweeten their terms. Nor is it clear how Government should deal with the trend. Some workers, especially high-paid consultants, welcome the independence. The jobs can be a boon to retirees, students and people with children at home.
 
The Toll on Job-Seekers
 Here in Toledo, though, the loss of old-fashioned jobs and the growth of contingent work is taking a cruel toll on many job seekers. Gordon Mills, 44, had a 40-hour-a-week, $6-an-hour job as the night auditor for a motel. But his back, injured in an earlier job, began bothering him and he took a two-month leave for therapy.
"I knew they had hired this girl to do the job," he said, "but I thought she was temporary. When I came back, they cut my hours to 16 and she was getting 24." He walked out and is now living on $343 a week in workers' compensation pay for his back injury. Mr. Mills has gone back to school to study accounting.
Toledo's new job market can even be rough on those who seem qualified for the better jobs. Nannette Keating, 40, separated and the mother of two children, 3 and 6, has a bachelor's degree in public administration from the University of Toledo. She worked many years in government jobs before she went to work for a private adoption agency. But as the economy declined, the agency lost its money, and she was laid off last April.
Eventually, Ms. Keating wants a good job, but for now she said she would settle for any kind of job. "I've applied at retail stores, food stores, outlet stores," she said. Despite the high turnover among such employers, she said they told her they knew she would quit for a better job, so they turned her away.
Norman J. Drzewiecki is 24, single, a graduate of Rogers High School here and living with his parents. Four years ago, with industrial jobs here fading, Mr. Drzewiecki joined the Air Force, where he was a laborer, delivery driver and shipping and receiving clerk.
Mr. Drzewiecki had planned to enroll in Air Force training to become a loadmaster handling air cargo. But with the Air Force shrinking, he was discharged in September.
He looked for work at Ohio Bell, where his father has worked for 39 years as a repairman. But he was turned away. He is collecting $195 a week in unemployment that Congress just voted to extend until October, so he says he can afford to keep looking for a career job.
 
Worry Over Temporary Offer
 The few jobs he found were temporary or part-time or both. One work offer was for 60 days to 150 days. "After that you don't know," Mr.Drzewiecki said. "I'd hate to get into a job, give it my best effort and after 150 days, they say: 'Thanks a lot. Here's your last paycheck.' "
The President's economic plan offers new spending for education and continuous job training to enable people to move from one good job to another. But with industry relying on contingent workers, who might provide those better jobs is uncertain.
The job trend also lends some urgency to the Administration's promises to overhaul the nation's pension and health-care systems. By denying contingent workers health and pension benefits, employers are shifting more of the burden of supporting the lowest-paid workers to the welfare system.
Richard S. Belous, vice president of the National Planning Association in Washington and author of a study of the phenomenon, said: "We've made our labor market more flexible. But we've done zilch about making the social welfare system flexible."
