HEADLINE: Claims and Counterclaims on Vaccine Costs Generate Heat but Little Light

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
The price of a dose of the vaccine for whooping cough leaped from 19 cents in 1977 to $10.04 in 1992, and a dose of polio vaccine rose from $1 to $9.91. The cost of giving a child all the recommended immunizations rose more than 1,000 percent in the same period.
President Clinton has seized on these skyrocketing prices as he attempts to build political support for revamping the nation's health-care system, setting off a bitter fight with drug companies over what the figures mean: price gouging of citizens willing to pay anything for the health of their children, or an honest effort to insure a profit. 
 The President has condemned a "shocking" rise in the price of vaccines for children, suggesting it is in part due to the pharmaceutical industry's huge promotional budget.
 
Manufacturers Point to Tax
 Drug manufacturers counter that four-fifths of that increase actually resulted from the development of two new vaccines for children and a Federal excise tax imposed in 1988, which supports a fund for children who suffer from the rare but sometimes serious side effects of the shots. They say the President is misusing statistics.
Vaccine experts in ringside seats say that both sides are using numbers selectively to cast their positions in the most favorable light. Nonetheless, most agree that vaccine prices do seem inexplicably high.
"One wonders why prices have risen so much, particularly for vaccines that have been around for years," said Dr. Alan R. Hinman, director of prevention services at the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. "It's difficult to know how much a vaccine should cost, but I think that most of us think that prices have risen more than they ought to have."
 
Increases Before Tax
 The costs of production, research and development, and liability do not seem to justify the current prices, the experts say, and they point out that vaccines are generally cheaper overseas.
They add that in attributing rising prices to excise taxes and new vaccines, the manufacturers have performed some statistical wizardry of their own. The huge price increases in vaccines came before the tax went into effect, and many health economists consider the two new vaccines introduced since 1987, hepatitis B at $30.21 and a vaccine for meningitis at $60.52, to be overpriced.
Also, the excise tax supports a Federal program that relieves drug companies of liability for the side effect of vaccines, saving the companies tremendous expense.
"We had hoped to see a reduction in prices since parents are now paying their liability costs," said Jackie Noyes of the American Academy of Pediatrics. "In most cases all we've seen is some stabilization."
 
'We've Been Knocked'
 Vaccine manufacturers defend their charges. "We think we've been knocked very unfairly on promotion and clearly on price, for some political purpose," said Dr. R. Gordon Douglas, president of the Vaccine Division of Merck & Company. "Vaccines are very different from other pharmaceuticals. We do not have a lot of promotional expense and the public health benefits of vaccines are enormous."
While manufacturers acknowledge that vaccine prices rose sharply in the early 1980's they say they have leveled off in the last four years. Even at current prices, vaccines are a bargain compared with other medicines, they say, noting that two doses of the measles, mumps and rubella vaccine will protect against three serious diseases for a lifetime at a cost of just over $50.
 
Big and Quick Increases
 From 1977 to 1987 the companies raised prices rapidly, in part to improve profits that were considered too low and in part to cover the potential costs of lawsuits stemming from side effects. The measles, mumps and rubella vaccine jumped to $17.88 a dose in 1987, from $6.01 in 1977; the vaccine that protects against whooping cough, diphtheria and tetanus cost $8.92 in 1987, up from 19 cents in 1980.
Once the Government assumed the bulk of the liability for side effects in 1988, some vaccine manufacturers dropped their retail prices slightly, while others merely tacked the new excise tax onto their standard price.
An official of the Department of Health and Human Services who spoke on the condition of anonymity said that although outsiders do not have access to drug manufacturers' books, he and his colleagues suspect that "most of what they used to charge in liability has now been turned into profit." The only vaccine that decreased in price after the compensation program took effect was the shot for whooping cough, diphtheria and tetanus, and even there, the manufacturer's price is almost 10 times what it was in 1982.
 
Manufacturers Are Few
 While the excise tax accounts for almost half the price of the $10 whooping cough vaccine, it explains only 29 cents of a $9.91 polio shot; there is no excise tax on the new vaccines. The tax on each vaccine is determined by the predicted rates of serious side effects.
One source of frustration for public health officials is that each vaccine is made by only a small number of companies in this country. For example, two vaccines are made by only one company. That allows the companies to dominate the market and set prices as they wish.
When there is only one manufacturer "we have very little bargaining power," said Dr. Hinman of the disease centers. The agency buys about half the nation's vaccines and negotiates reduced rates that are generally about half those in the private sector.
But they are still often more expensive than similar vaccines in other countries, leading some pediatricians to suspect that the companies are reaping hefty profits.
"The pharmaceutical companies have not been willing to open their books to reveal the information that would allow us to make a judgment about their costs versus their prices, but we can compare prices here to international prices," said Dr. Ed Marcuse, of the Children's Hospital Medical Center in Seattle. "When you buy U.S. vaccine in the U.S. you get delivery and you get the ability to return outdated vials. On the other hand you're looking at a price difference of $26 for a vaccine here to $1 in much of the world, and I'm not sure it's worth it."
Oral polio vaccine, which retails to doctors for more than $9 a dose in this country before the excise tax is added, costs only about $1 in France. Merck sells measles vaccine for $25.29 to private doctors, who add a markup when they bill patients. The vaccine costs the disease centers $15.30, but the Ministry of Health in Ontario, Canada, where prices are negotiated by the Government, pays only about $7.
 
Unicef Pays Much Less
 Unicef spends only pennies for many of these inoculations, paying about 7 cents for a dose of polio or whooping cough vaccine, but it does not generally buy them from American manufacturers. The quality of these vaccines is considered high since all meet strict World Health Organization standards, and critics of manufacturers in the United States say that these low prices show how cheap vaccines are to make.
But drug manufacturers counter that in some countries certain vaccines actually cost more than the price charged to the Federal health agency, although they rarely cost more than private doctors pay. While the Canadian Government pays $3.79 a dose for Lederle's oral polio vaccine to cover all its citizens, the United States Government pays only $2.10 a dose; private doctors pay $9.91.
Dr. Douglas said Merck's measles vaccine was sold in Europe, Australia and New Zealand for about the same price as in the United States. He added that many inexpensive vaccines used by organizations like Unicef were sold below the true cost of producing them at the behest of European governments committed to producing cheap vaccines for the developing world.
Some experts blame complicated licensing and production regulations from the Food and Drug Administration in part for the high prices in this country as well as the small number of companies making vaccines here.
 
Role of Development
 "The bottom line is that you have to price vaccines so that you recover your capital or else you're out of business," Dr. Douglas of Merck said.
Skeptics say that vaccine manufacturers have in some cases exaggerated their research, production and liability costs.
In a statement before the National Vaccine Advisory Committee last month, Dr. Ronald J. Saldarini, president of Lederle-Praxis, a division of the American Cyanamid Company, emphasized "the pivotal role that U.S. industry has played in the development of new vaccine products in the past." But neither of the two new vaccines that the company has released in the last few years was developed in its own labs.
Praxis developed the vaccine for meningitis, and the company was then bought by Lederle; the pharmaceutical company's new whooping cough vaccine was developed in Japan and licensed to Lederle for sale in the United States. Lederle does have a number of other vaccines under development.
But officials at Lederle defended their research costs, pointing out that the company still had to do clinical trials to market the Japanese vaccine.
While liability costs for vaccine makers have clearly decreased since the Vaccine Injury Compensation Act took effect in 1988, manufacturers say that they are still pondering the full effect of the law and they emphasize that their liability will never be zero.
Apparently, liability has been sufficiently reduced that vaccine research in this country is once again an active field, with a number of companies working on vaccines for illnesses like respiratory viruses and chicken pox. And foreign manufacturers that left in the early 1980's because of liability concerns are beginning to return.
Public health organizations and medical groups like the American Academy of Pediatrics hope that renewed competition will bring prices down. Many also support Government purchase of vaccines, a plan the President has suggested, but that industry rejects, saying it might drive them out of business.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
As Economists Snipe, An Adviser Presses On

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
Backbiting is a time-honored practice in the nation's capital, but the nastiness that greeted Laura D'Andrea Tyson's appointment to head the President's Council of Economic Advisers surprised even veteran Washingtonians.
Respected academics telephoned each other -- and their journalist friends -- to snipe at her, whispering that she was an ill-advised choice because she was not a free-trader, was outside the economics mainstream and was not one of the brightest stars in her field. 
 Some members of the Cambridge intelligentsia protested because after 12 years of Republican rule they felt a sense of entitlement that this coveted post should go to one of their city's young liberal superstars, like Lawrence Summers of Harvard University or Paul Krugman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
And a few economists muttered about a reverse sexism in which President Clinton passed over a dozen male heavyweights to pick Ms. Tyson as the first woman to head the three-member council, which was set up under President Harry S. Truman.
 
'Professional Jealousy'
 Ms. Tyson, an easy-going, 45-year-old professor from the University of California at Berkeley, was stunned and hurt by all the viciousness.
"It seems clear that to some extent it must be professional jealousy," she said in her first one-on-one interview since taking office. "A lot of these people I know pretty well, and I feel personal loyalty to them. I would have hoped they felt some of the same loyalty toward me."
The tumble of recent events has helped her get over the uncomfortable episode. For the past few weeks, she has worked 13-hour days, sitting through marathon meetings on the President's economic plan, testifying before Congress and appearing on television news programs to defend the plan.
Her role in the economic plan, she said, included making sure that the amount of deficit reduction was not so large that it undermined the fragile recovery and not so small that it would be scoffed at by financial markets and the public. She also did much of the heavy intellectual lifting on the $31 billion stimulus program intended to speed job creation.
 
Knowledge of Trade
 When President Clinton set up the National Economic Council to coordinate the Administration's economic policy making, some prominent economists voiced fears that this would push the often-marginalized Council of Economic Advisers further into the background.
But Ms. Tyson says she is too busy to feel marginalized. Her job involves interpreting economic data for the President, preparing the Administration's economic forecasts, helping formulate policies and assessing the costs and benefits of a raft of proposals.
Because of her expertise on trade, she has helped tutor Mickey Kantor, the United States Trade Representative, on the ABC's of a subject in which he had little experience. She has also been instrumental in drafting a strategic trade policy that will pressure Japan and other Asian nations to open their markets more while providing more generous Federal support for high-tech industries.
Many economists have seen Ms. Tyson's unmistakable hand in some of the President's speeches. The clearest example was Mr. Clinton's Feb. 22 speech to Boeing workers in which he vowed to take a tougher approach toward Airbus, the European aircraft consortium.
Ms. Tyson explored in detail how Airbus had hurt American aircraft manufacturers in her most recent book, "Who's Bashing Whom? Trade Conflict in High-Technology Industries" (Institute for International Economics). She suggested that Washington subsidize the industry to offset the subsidies Airbus receives.
Displaying modesty that is rare in a city fueled by big egos, she denied that her thinking had heavily influenced the President. "One of the reasons he chose me was he thinks about many problems the way I do," she said.
 
Worries About Family
 Ms. Tyson's husband, Erik Tarloff, a Hollywood screenwriter who specializes in comedy, says his wife hesitated two and a half minutes before accepting the post. She felt that when the President beckoned she could not say no, although she was worried by her 9-year-old son's fears that he would hardly ever see his mother.
In an Op-Ed article in The New York Times, Mr. Tarloff wrote that their son's reaction was, "I'm going to become a Republican." But Mr. Tarloff added, "I've persuaded him that the cure he proposes is worse than the disease."
Sitting on a white sofa in an office that has a half-moved-into air, with a glossy picture of Mr. Clinton and four small Monet reproductions on the wall, Ms. Tyson exudes an I'm-just-glad-to-be-here attitude. A thin woman fond of bright scarves and suits, she said she was "honored" to be the first chairwoman of the council.
She said she was surprised that Mr. Clinton had chosen her because she had never met him before last August. She was invited to a meeting of economic advisers in Little Rock, Ark., where she was expected to be eclipsed by luminaries like Mr. Summers, Mr. Krugman and James A. Tobin, a Yale professor and Nobel laureate.
But it turned out to be her opportunity to shine. When Mr. Clinton said he wanted to do something about the loss of manufacturing jobs, several economists suggested that his worries were misplaced, explaining that in industrial nations the number of manufacturing jobs typically shrinks as the economy shifts toward service jobs. In a campaign where lost jobs was a major issue, that ivory-tower answer was the last thing Mr. Clinton wanted to hear.
But Ms. Tyson's response was pragmatic music to his ears. She outlined how Washington could help American manufacturers by taking a tougher stance against foreign trade barriers and by providing seed money for promising new technologies.
"She was able to give answers that were to the point and addressed what he wanted," Mr. Krugman said. "There was an immediate personal rapport between them. She's a smart, very sophisticated economist."
 
Outside Mainstream
 Ms. Tyson is outside the mainstream in that she specializes in trade, international competitiveness and high technology. In contrast, mainstream economists focus on theoretical models and elaborate mathematical equations to analyze how economies work. Another difference is that she discusses her profession in conversational English rather than the hypertechnical jargon favored by many of her colleagues.
"There's no artifice with Laura," said Michael Borrus, a Berkeley professor and colleague. "She's really an honest evaluator of ideas."
Her advocacy of government activism has brought criticism from conservatives, who see her suggestion for Boeing subsidies as evidence that she is an interventionist who favors government-run industrial policy.
Washington has long helped specific industries, Ms. Tyson argues, pointing to Pentagon contracts and farm subsidies. She says that when Europe and Japan are providing seed money to help promising industries it might be foolish for Washington to shun the idea. It is not a matter of picking which industries are going to live and which are going to die, she said, but of having the Government join business in financing research in new technologies, like superconductors, that might help many industries.
Ms. Tyson's book has also brought catcalls for shunning free-trade thinking. She defended the Bush Administration for persuading Japan to set aside 20 percent of its semiconductor market for American and other foreign suppliers. Her book, though condemning import quotas, also approved Washington's threats to erect trade barriers to put pressure on other nations to remove barriers to American goods.
To her critics, she is a pamphleteer who supports managed trade and protectionism. "She is increasingly unique among economists in being very sympathetic to protection," said Daniel Mitchell, a senior fellow at the Heritage Foundation, a research organization in Washington. "She has come to policy conclusions that I think are at odds with reality."
Ms. Tyson can hardly hide her exasperation with such criticism. "Many charges come from people who haven't actually read anything I have written, or if they read it, they haven't read it carefully," she said.
"The dichotomy between free trade on the one hand and protection on the other is usually not the choice that exists in reality. There is always some shade of gray in between."
 
'Some Shade of Gray'
 What is Washington to do when American semiconductor makers face a Japanese market all but closed to imports? she asks. Free-trade shibboleths provide no answers, she says, and nor does heavy-handed protection. Instead she says that "aggressive unilateralism," like threatening retaliation, may be warranted until unfair trade barriers are removed and better multilateral trade rules are negotiated.
But Gene Grossman, a Princeton University economist, said, "She doesn't, in my view, recognize that the fact that markets don't work perfectly isn't necessarily a rationale for government intervention unless you think you can put in place a political system that isn't subject to being co-opted by special interests."
Michael J. Boskin, who led the council under President George Bush, said the carping about Ms. Tyson's academic credentials was foolish, but he asserted that it was legitimate to worry about "her unorthodox views" on industrial policy and trade, because the council is often the sole voice in the Administration speaking up for the market.
Defending herself, Ms. Tyson says she is not a knee-jerk advocate of government intervention.
"The market does many things very well, but there is a rationale for the Government doing things that the market doesn't do very well," she said. "The role of the Council of Economic Advisers is to help evaluate when there is a defensible role for a government policy and whether government policy in pursuit of that objective is efficient."
 
 
 
LAURA D'ANDREA TYSON

 
Born: June 28, 1947; Bayonne, N.J.
 
Hometown, Berkeley, Cal.
 
Education: Holy Trinity High School, Westfield, N.J., 1965; B.A., Smith College, Ph.D., 1969; Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 1974

Publications: The Yugoslav Economic System and Its Performance in the 1970's (University of California at Berkeley 1980); Economic Adjustment in Eastern Europe (Rand Corporation 1984); Who's Bashing Whom?: Trade Conflicts in High-Technology Industries (Institute for International Economics 1992)
 
Family: Married to Erik Tarloff; one son, Elliot, 9
 
Hobbies: Reading fiction; exercise, taking her son to museums, music lessons, parks

HEADLINE: Lehman Without Shearson Can Still Be a Wall St. Force

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Lehman Brothers securities firm, which will remain at American Express after its Shearson brokerage affiliate is sold to Primerica later this year, will be less imposing than before, but its competitors and industry analysts say it will remain large enough to succeed.
The Primerica Corporation hopes that merging Shearson with its smaller Smith Barney, Harris Upham unit will be an opportunity to cut costs and raise profits. "One plus one makes three," said Sanford I. Weill, Primerica's chairman. 
 The American Express Company, which agreed to the $1 billion deal last week, wants more profit from Lehman, too, but it is using a different arithmetic -- subtraction. American Express hopes to strengthen Lehman's finances by taking away the distraction caused by Shearson.
To keep Lehman among Wall Street's leaders and collect a higher price from its possible sale, Harvey Golub, chairman of American Express, wants Lehman executives to avoid the strife between traders and corporate financiers that led to the breakup of the Lehman partnership in 1984 and its planned sale of Shearson. Since last month, Lehman has been run by co-presidents, J. Tomilson Hill, a former mergers and acquisitions specialist, and Richard S. Fuld, a former bond trader.
But maintaining Lehman's stature on Wall Street and raising profits may not be easy, particularly when interest rates turn up and the number of new issues decline.
In the competition for large companies that issue new securities, Lehman may no longer be able to claim that it is best qualified. The Shearson network of nearly 9,000 brokers and almost 400 offices gave Lehman insight into investor demands and the ability to sell securities quickly. Merrill Lynch & Company is the only other firm that can still make that claim. In the past, rival securities firms would often include Shearson or Merrill in their deals just to gain access to a large broker network.
Without the broker network, Lehman will lose a big advantage, some securities executives say, and will not be much different from First Boston; Goldman, Sachs; Morgan Stanley, or Salomon Brothers -- firms that limit their selling to institutions.
As a harbinger of the sniping that is almost certain to come from competitors, John L. Steffans, executive vice president at Merrill Lynch, said on Friday that the break-up of Shearson Lehman Brothers would give Merrill "somewhat of an edge in deals that require broad-based distribution."
He said that while Lehman would be distracted by arrangements that call for sharing research and back-office processing, Merrill's workers would be free to concentrate on selling.
But others do not see the loss of Shearson's distribution network as a big setback. Lehman Brothers will still have 750 brokers who sell to wealthy individuals and small institutions. In addition, the agreement with Primerica calls for Lehman Brothers to continue giving its regular share of new issues to Shearson brokers.
That agreement is unique but will last only one to two years, depending on the type of security.
James Hanbury, an analyst at Wertheim & Company, said Lehman executives claimed that their group of 750 brokers had sold about 45 percent of the securities allocated to Shearson Lehman Brothers as part of financings handled by Lehman.
The sale of Shearson may not be the end of the turmoil at Lehman. Mr. Golub of American Express said on Friday that costs at Lehman must be cut, and he still expects to sell the company when it is financially stronger. He said American Express might find a company to buy Lehman or sell part of the firm in a public stock offering. Lehman executives probably could not arrange to buy the firm, Mr. Golub added.
Lehman does not disclose its profits, but based on recent results at Shearson Lehman, including last year's $116 million loss, analysts estimated that Lehman's earnings have been below industry standards.

HEADLINE: Executive Brief -- HOUSING AND URBAN DEVELOPMENT;
Remaking H.U.D. for Those It Serves

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
Henry G. Cisneros has been walking the halls, and he does not like what he sees.
Mr. Cisneros, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, earned his Ph.D. in public administration from George Washington University. He says he knows "internalization of subgoals" when he sees it. 
 What Mr. Cisneros means is that many H.U.D. workers are so busy attending meetings, checking forms and enforcing obscure regulations that they have lost track of their real goal: housing for those who need it.
"At the end of the day, you're exhausted," he said, of the civil servants at the department's sprawling concrete headquarters. "But it has nothing to do with what you need to accomplish in the real world."
Mr. Cisneros has been making floor-by-floor inspection tours. He said he was astonished to find a woman who spent her day making sure that grant applicants had correctly copied information from Form A to Form B, and sending the forms back when discrepancies arose.
"This is an Alice in Wonderland world," he said. "No human being could ever consciously create something this gridlocked and mazed."
Mr. Cisneros has tempered such criticism with praise for some individual civil servants. In fact, he even took one of them, Michael Janis, who oversees the nation's public-housing programs, to meet the President.
But just as President Clinton has talked about "reinventing Government," Mr. Cisneros says he plans to "reinvent H.U.D." He has asked his planning staff to help him write a new statement of purpose for the department, and he is insisting that it include measurable goals.
As part of that process, he began a two-day retreat at the headquarters on Friday for about 70 employees, from top aides to secretaries.
 
Not Quite the C.I.A. When It Comes to Security

While he is at it, Mr. Cisneros might consider reinventing the building's security staff, which also has an Alice in Wonderland quality.
Lobby guards insist that visitors sign their names, write the reason for their visit and produce a photo identification card. But they virtually never check to see whether the photo matches the face, or whether the signature matches that on the card.
And under "reason for visit," a visitor could probably write "spray the hallways with gunfire," as long as the gunman flashed a laminated photo I.D. on the way in.
 
Andrew Cuomo's Office Is H.U.D.'s New 'Hot Shop'
 After a campaign in which homelessness seemed about the only thing Mr. Clinton did not have a plan to solve, there has been a surprising development.
The President's economic package proposes nearly to triple spending for "supportive housing," the Government's main program for the homeless. The President wants to increase its allocation to $423 million from $150 million last year.
One set of winners would be the not-for-profit groups that can use the money to build housing or to provide social services. Another winner would be Andrew M. Cuomo, the son of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
Mr. Cuomo, who used to run such a not-for-profit group in New York, has been chosen as the Assistant Secretary for Community Planning and Development, the division that administers the money.
Mr. Cuomo's office won another victory in the budget wars: a Presidential commitment to add $2.5 billion to its Community Development Block Grant program.
These are among the factors making Mr. Cuomo's office a "hot shop," which is insider talk for an exciting place to work.
 
The Ghost of Mr. Kemp And the Party of Lincoln
 Jack F. Kemp, Mr. Cisneros's predecessor, may be gone from the building, but his favorite President is not.
Mr. Kemp spent his four years trying to attract more minorities to the Republican Party, which he ceaselessly referred to as "the party of Lincoln." Accordingly, he decorated many of the halls with huge photographs of the Lincoln Memorial. Mr. Kemp even gave Mr. Cisneros an autographed copy of one of the photographs as a welcoming gift.
Mr. Cisneros has left the Lincolns in place -- so far, at least -- but he has been less kind to Mr. Kemp's favorite program, voicing doubts at his confirmation hearing about the plan to sell public housing to their tenants.
And he further annoyed the Kemp camp last week when he said his predecessor's interest in "ideologically attractive themes" may have led to "some inattention" to basic management.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Unpopular Projects Unite Minorities

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
WHEN Robert F. Wagner was Mayor, he once recalled, some of the loudest opposition to a proposed low-income housing project came from black residents of a nearby Queens neighborhood. Most had graduated from the slums only to find that city government was, by design, creating what market forces and racial prejudice had periodically fashioned on their own: a new ghetto.
Decades later, a Federal judge is weighing a similar challenge. Three Brooklyn women have filed a suit contending that the Fort Greene site for a proposed residence for homeless people with mental disabilities and drug or alcohol addictions was chosen because it is in a predominantly black and Hispanic neighborhood. 
 If Queens residents historically believed they got short shrift in snow removal and Staten Islanders have argued that they get too much garbage, diverse New Yorkers seem united in anger that their neighborhood is unfairly targeted for undesirable public projects. They find common ground with those in Manhattan neighborhoods, some of which have been forced to warehouse the homeless in mammoth welfare hotels.
When New York City voters revised the City Charter four years ago, one goal was to mollify people who feared that they were bearing a disproportionate share of change. Officials were required to calculate the ratio of onerous public projects in each neighborhood. If a community was considered oversaturated, a project could proceed only in an emergency, on a temporary basis or if there was no practical alternative.
Previously, said Richard L. Schaffer, director of the City Planning Department, those decisions had been made largely on the basis of two factors other than fairness: "political expediency and the availability of inexpensive city-owned land." The Planning Department drew maps to demonstrate how projects had been apportioned and it compiled a "statement of needs" from city agencies that suggested what new projects were anticipated and what alternatives might be offered.
"City agencies generally have failed to carry out the process of meaningful community consultation," says a report by Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, in part because they fear that identifying a proposed site too soon will only make it a rallying point for community opposition more quickly. (Ms. Messinger's own sights also have shifted beyond Manhattan: in appeals for support in 1993, she says she is running for mayor in 1997. What if Mayor David N. Dinkins seeks a third term? "I'm assuming that he's not going to," Ms. Messinger said.)
"As a result," her report says, "the goals of community involvement in the siting process and the actual siting of the facility seem to be at odds with one another."
Those goals have sometimes been circumvented, partly because guidelines vaguely define what constitutes "office space," which is largely exempt from the siting criteria as are verbal agreements with hoteliers to rent individual rooms to homeless people and nonprofit agencies -- the very formula that the Dinkins administration has embraced to provide transitional housing.
"Fair share is a wonderful ideal that will never be realized because it's never been defined," said Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President.
Previous studies have suggested that poorer neighborhoods shoulder a disproportionate share of programs for the homeless, the mentally disabled and drug addicts. Some of those programs mostly serve people from those neighborhoods. Some were placed there because sites in poor neighborhoods generally are less expensive to buy or rent.
"But when you're talking about disproportionate impact," said Rosaria Sinisi, a lawyer for three Brooklyn plaintiffs in the suit against the proposed Emerson Family Development Center, "does the fact that it's cheaper make it right?"
If predominantly minority census tracts are defined as those in which more than 5 in 10 residents are black or Hispanic, Ms. Sinisi found that, citywide about 8 in 10 of the city's housing sites for the homeless and the mentally disabled and nearly as large a share of drug-abuse programs had been placed in minority neighborhoods. In some boroughs, the proportion was even higher.
Rebutting the plaintiffs, the State Attorney General argues loftily: "Plaintiffs' complaint is not that minority residents of a publicly funded facility are being placed in a minority neighborhood, but that mentally ill residents are being placed in a minority neighborhood. Any claim that there is a stigma attacked to having these individuals living in plaintiffs' neighborhood must be rejected as against public policy. The segregation of minorities can be said to imply some inferiority or unacceptability of the minority groups. The same is not true of placing a residence for the mentally ill in a community."
Winning communities over can be costly, particularly when they are fed up with crime and anti-social behavior. By providing better security and social services and by spending more time consulting with prospective neighbors, though, government can come closer to meeting the Charter's goals: equity, vision, consensus, accountability and neighborhood preservation or even improvement.
The price of paying only lip service to those principles is cynicism and alienation. For the public, the proposed solutions may become paramount while the underlying problems may be out of mind. Meanwhile, the city may be out of sites.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
F.C.C. Tilts Toward Lower Cable TV Rates

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
Taking a tough new stance toward cable television prices, the Federal Communications Commission is preparing new pricing rules that are likely to jolt the industry but make consumers happier.
In recent months, the agency has collected pricing information from hundreds of cable operators and found that cable systems with competitors charge about 48 cents a channel each month, while those that have a monopoly charge 65 cents. Systems with fewer than 1,000 subscribers generally charge even more. 
 Commission officials say their decision will almost certainly end up somewhere between what consumers desire and what the industry would like, but they leave little doubt that they are tilting toward tighter regulation.
"There won't be a perfect answer," said James H. Quello, acting chairman of the F.C.C. But signaling a new attitude on the commission toward regulation, he added, "there's no doubt the intent of Congress was clearly lower rates and better service for customers."
After a bruising battle over cable prices in Congress last year, a coalition of Democrats and moderate Republicans managed to override a veto by President George Bush and pushed through a bill that reimposes rate regulation for the first time since 1986.
 
Just What Is 'Reasonable'?
 The law requires the commission to draft guidelines under which local governments would be allowed to set "reasonable prices" for the basic package of service. With anything beyond that, customers and local authorities could ask the F.C.C. to roll back "unreasonable prices."
But the law offers wide room for interpretation, and the cable industry has been feverishly trying to limit its losses. At the same time, consumer groups and local-government officials have fought back, lobbying for stronger rules.
Now it appears, three weeks before the April 3 deadline imposed by Congress, that the cable industry will wind up unhappy. Commission officials say that while they have still not decided precisely how to regulate the different tiers of cable service, the outcome will probably be closer to the proposals of consumer groups than to those of the industry.
 
Negative Response Expected
 "We're working toward something that the cable industry will probably squawk about," said a commission official, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified.
Commission officials say they have accumulated new cable price data that could help them set tough benchmarks for "reasonable prices."
Rising cable rates proved to be an explosive issue in Congress last fall, and they represent a big pocketbook issue for the 58 million Americans who subscribe to these systems. Prices for the most popular tiers of programming have climbed more than twice as fast as the rate of inflation in recent years, in part because most cable systems have enjoyed both exclusive franchises and freedom from regulation.
The National Cable Television Association has argued that Congress intended to impose tight regulation on only a bare-bones package of services consisting of little more than local over-the-air television channels. Under the industry's proposal, the cable packages offering most of the other channels -- from CNN and Nickelodeon to sports channels like ESPN -- would be left almost completely unregulated.
Furthermore, the F.C.C. would assume that the prices charged by at least 95 percent of all systems for these expanded packages were reasonable. Only the 5 percent of systems that are most expensive would be considered unreasonable, and the companies offering these systems would be given a chance to justify their rates.
James P. Mooney, president of the trade association, saw the matter in stark terms. "The lifeblood of our industry is at stake," he said. "At some point, this has to go beyond political pot-shotting to the grownup regulatory stage, and that is happening now. The Government has to get down to serious analysis."
 
Search for 'Rough Justice'
 Consumer groups and local governments, including New York City's, have argued that the F.C.C. should essentially roll back prices for most services by about 30 percent. They argue that the rollbacks would bring prices into line with what they would be if the cable operators faced direct competition.
"Our approach from the beginning has been to look for a model of rough justice," said William F. Squadron, New York City's Commissioner of Telecommunications. Mr. Squadron noted that prices charged by Time Warner in the city have jumped about 25 percent in three years and by 3 percent since the new cable law was passed in the fall.
"There have been a number of analyses that have found essentially you've got a 30 to 40 percent monopoly rent markup," he said. "To achieve a rough-justice benchmark, a middle-ground number would give sufficient protection to customers and not be unfair to industry."
 
Competition Is the Point
 The law broadly defines "reasonable" as prices charged by the handful of cable systems that face "effective competition." But there has been much fighting in setting the benchmark that embraces this idea.
The new data suggest that "reasonable" rates would be higher than those proposed by the Consumer Federation of America and city governments, which have suggested a per-channel rate of 34 cents.
The F.C.C. has become far more amenable to regulation since President Clinton took office. Alfred C. Sikes, who served as chairman under President Bush and was hostile to regulation, has stepped down.
Mr. Quello, a Democrat who has served as a commissioner for more than two decades, has been far more receptive to regulation than Mr. Sikes was. Less than two weeks ago, the commission announced its intention to impose stricter regulation of children's television. And, acting on a separate part of the cable legislation last week, the commission pushed through rules requiring cable systems to answer customer calls within 30 seconds and start responding to problems within a day.
The composition of the five-member commission is still shifting. Mr. Clinton has not named a successor to Mr. Sikes. One of the two remaining Republicans, Sherrie P. Marshall, is not taking part in the cable discussions because she is preparing to join a law firm that represents media companies. That leaves one Democrat, Ervin S. Duggan, and one Republican, Andrew C. Barrett, neither of whom fit neatly into political categories.

HEADLINE: Patents

BYLINE: By Sabra Chartrand

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE last thing a patient wants to hear after having a potentially cancerous growth removed is that a piece of the tumor has been lost inside the body. Yet that is exactly what happens a surprising number of times when polyps are removed from the colon.
Now two doctors at Beth Israel Medical Center in New York City who tired of searching for wayward polyps have won a patent for a simple snare that traps the growth before it is cut away. 
 Colon cancer is second to lung cancer as the nation's most common form of the disease, afflicting about 150,000 people a year. It usually begins with mushroom-shaped polyps on the colon, or large intestine. To remove them, a doctor uses a fiber-optic scope to lasso the growth, then severs it with electric current. If cancer is found in the polyp stem, then it may have invaded the colon as well, so surgery is required to remove part of the colon.
But first a biopsy is necessary, and that can be difficult if some or all of the polyp is missing.
 
Time-Consuming Process
 "Once it's cut, the polyp chase starts," said Dr. Naomi L. Nakao, a gastroenterologist who invented the snare with Dr. Peter Wilk. "The polyp rolls back into the colon and gets lost in the feces. Many times it's a painful, time-consuming thing to retrieve the polyp.
"You have to try suction, or forceps, and the polyp falls off or gets macerated," she added. If those methods fail, the patient gets one or more enemas in the hope of flushing out the polyp. Dr. Nakao says that in up to a third of cases, the polyp is never found.
"Often the time spent trying to retrieve the polyp is as long as the cauterization procedure itself," she said.
Dr. Nakao said she was motivated to design the snare after being consulted on a case in which the polyp was so torn that it was unclear whether cancer cells had come from its stem or cap.
"The patient had to have a colon resection, since it was impossible to determine where the cancer was," Dr. Nakao said. "Afterwards, a biopsy was done, and no cancer cells were found in the colon itself. So the surgery was unnecessary."
The snare, which looks like a tiny butterfly net, is slipped over the polyp when the growth is lassoed; when the polyp is severed, it simply falls into the net. Dr. Nakao and Dr. Wilk said they were negotiating with several medical equipment manufacturers interested in licensing the snare. It received patent 5,190,542.
 
Wire Composite For Superconductors

After a five-and-a-half-year examination of its application, American Superconductor Corporation has won a patent for composites used in making superconducting wire.
The patent advances the complex struggle to develop economical superconductor technologies that will carry electricity inexpensively and efficiently. Cooled to very low temperatures -- the equivalent of about 225 degrees below zero Fahrenheit -- superconductive ceramics lose all resistance to electricity. That means superconductive power lines have a tremendous advantage over traditional copper or aluminum wires because more electricity can be transmitted over the same size wire without any energy dissipation.
Researchers are still trying to develop superconductor materials that will work at temperatures closer to normal.
The ceramics are also very brittle and one challenge has been to shape them into wires or coils. American Superconductor's newly patented composite combines high-temperature superconductive ceramics with metals like silver to make flexible cables.
 
Fine Ceramic Filament
 "Imagine a fine filament of ceramics running along the length of a metal wire, inside it," said Dr. Gregory J. Yurek, president of American Superconductor, which is based in Watertown, Mass., and is devoted to developing ceramic superconducting wires, wire products and systems. Its composite also works with gold and platinum.
"This creates a wire that can both carry superconductor current with no electrical resistance and also gets around Mother Nature, around the brittleness," Dr. Yurek added. "Because of cost, the reasonable metal of choice is silver."
American Superconductor has been "manufacturing a pilot line of these composite wires since last June," Dr. Yurek added. Its goal is to produce extremely long wires that can withstand being rolled, unrolled and handled during manufacture and installation.
There are vast potential benefits to mass-produced superconductor wire. Cities would be able to replace worn-out copper cables and increase power capacity without having to install additional or bigger power lines. Integrated circuits, electric motors and generators could all be made smaller, though they would require an adjacent refrigeration unit to cool the superconductors. American Superconductor's patent is 5,189,009.
 
Condom Logo Is Accepted
 The Old Glory Condom Corporation last week won an appeal to register its name and American-flag-inspired logo as a trademark after being turned down last summer because the Patent and Trademark Office said the images were scandalous.
The company sells red, white and blue condoms. It applied to register its logo of a condom waving flag-like from a pole and decorated with the stars and stripes design of the American flag. But the Government decided that using the flag to sell condoms would "scandalize or shock the conscience of a substantial composite of the general public."
In its appeal, the company said that many trademarks incorporated the flag and that many other condom companies had registered names or logos that could be perceived as scandalous.
The Patent and Trademark Office appeal board granted the trademark after finding no evidence to support the original refusal.
Patents are available by number for $3 from the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Balancing Czech

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: PRAGUE

 BODY:
The drama is classic: A courageous, charismatic dissident rallies the people behind him to reject the old regime; he brings in an ally to help him handle the reins of power; the trusted ally then either betrays or redeems the revolution.
In Russia, that drama is being played out toward betrayal, as the leader of the rump Parliament seeks to strip President Yeltsin of the power he legitimately derived from the people in an election. Ruslan Khasbulatov, though disavowed by his separatist home constituency, is reaching for Kremlin control. 
 In the Czech Republic, the other scenario is also in Act Two. Vaclav Havel, the jailed playwright who became President, brought in an American-trained economist who became Prime Minister. While Havel remains a prickly moral force and Western favorite, this legislative leader, Vaclav Klaus (Vaclav is a popular namefor Czech politicians) is in effective control, trying to turn a revolutionary dream into practical government.
"Everything in the post-Communist world is learned by doing," says Klaus. "Our main enemies were not the Communist apparatchiks. Our main enemies were the Western consultants, the investment bankers, the swarm of advisers who told us what we could not do." He likes to deride their "soft advice for hard currency."
Vaclav Klaus, an opinionated former academic -- "I have been a politician for only three years and three months" -- makes no effort to conceal his cockiness. "We have the only balanced budget in the world. And what we are doing here with our voucher system will be the subject of doctoral dissertations for decades to come."
For the price of about a week's salary, Czechs had a chance to buy a book of vouchers, which were a sort of warrant to receive stock in companies that were being privatized. Most Czechs were slow to act until some hotshot mutual fund salesmen took up the Government's idea and promised buyers big profits; the salesmen have since been restrained, but the whiff of greed did the trick.
"Everybody decided to participate in this special game," boasts Klaus, who when met with a skeptical look is inclined toward hyperbole. "There is no comparison in the history of mankind. There was not enough capital in the hands of people. We wanted to augment our capital without selling our country to the rest of the world."
For example, the state tobacco monopoly sold a large chunk of its equity to Philip Morris. Other shares in the same company will be offered in return for vouchers held by the Czech public; ordinary Czechs may soon be able to enrich themselves by ruining each other's lungs as Americans have successfully done for years.
Is the plunge into capitalism working? Too soon to tell: the shares are being distributed in waves over coming months, and nobody knows how much of the capital generated will be re-used to finance new ventures.
Major privatization here has lagged behind Poland and Hungary, but that may be because most Polish farmers always owned their land and Hungarians long mixed Communist borscht with free-style goulash. Klaus mutters darkly about "the Polish and Hungarian lobbies at The New York Times and Washington Post," but he admires Poland's Hanna Suchocka -- like himself, a Prime Minister who holds down deficits while a revolutionary leader gets Western adulation.
Klaus's test will come this year. Unemployment is 2 percent, "which Milton Friedman would say is below its natural level." As Government dinosaurs go private, unemployment is expected to rise rapidly. Then the Czech reformer will feel a little of the heat Boris Yeltsin's reformers are feeling.
Here's the difference: "You need political backing. To get this," says Klaus, " a democratic leader has to have, first, a positive vision -- it's not enough to be against Communism. Second, you need a pragmatic reform strategy. Third, you must create a consensus behind change -- that's why I created a political party, to create social cohesion in a time of turmoil."
The Czech Republic, divorced from a Slovakia still afflicted by socialist inertia, will surely work its way into the European market. The bigger question is whether Yeltsin can create a political party in Russia to provide enough social cohesion to resist his revolution's betrayers. What he needs to find is a Russian Vaclav Klaus.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Changing a Change of Mind, An Executive Quits at G.M.

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 15

 BODY:
From the moment Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua arrived at the General Motors Corporation's headquarters from Europe nine months ago, the straitlaced American automobile industry has never seen anyone so driven and so personally eccentric challenging the Motor City's protocol.
Little did anyone guess, until this afternoon, just how eccentric. 
 In a period of about 48 hours, Mr. Lopez, who has been wooed for months by Volkswagen A.G., formally changed his decision twice about whether to leave G.M., finally announcing his resignation at 1 P.M. today by dispatching a friend to G.M. headquarters with a handwritten note to John F. (Jack) Smith Jr., G.M.'s president and chief executive.
The note arrived just two hours before Mr. Smith had scheduled a news conference to announce that he would name Mr. Lopez president of G.M.'s vast North American operations, one of the most powerful jobs in American business.
 
Given Wide Authority
 Mr. Lopez's flip-flop, which began with his formal resignation from G.M. on Thursday, is a public embarrassment for Mr. Smith, his friend and mentor. In one of his first acts as G.M.'s president, Mr. Smith brought Mr. Lopez, a Spanish industrial engineer, to Detroit, and endowed him with broad powers to shake up the No. 1 auto maker's parts-making and purchasing operations. The hope was that he could repeat the cost-cutting successes that had helped Mr. Smith turn around G.M.'s sputtering European operations in the 1980's.
Mr. Lopez became a symbol of revolution by calling for a broad re-examination of operations at G.M., an auto maker that still makes about 70 percent of its parts.
In dealing with outside suppliers, like makers of steel and tires, he pressed for substantial price cuts that many manufacturers said were unreasonable. Despite his warm overtures to labor, the United Automobile Workers union eyed him warily, fearful that his notions would inevitably mean fewer jobs.
Today, instead of accepting the new G.M. job, Mr. Lopez presumably was on his way to Volkswagen's headquarters in Wolfsburg, Germany, where VW is expected to announce sweeping management changes on Tuesday. Those changes are likely to include naming Mr. Lopez as the No. 2 executive at VW. But a VW spokeswoman said tonight that the company had nothing new to announce.
The VW job, which would put Mr. Lopez in charge of worldwide production, would come with a financial package worth $20 million over five years, a sum unheard of except among the auto industry's top jobs.
No one at G.M. today knew Mr. Lopez's exact plans, however. He did not say in his note why he had decided a second time to leave G.M., Mr. Smith said.
Mr. Smith, his eyes rimmed red with emotion and exhaustion. described the contents of the note as "personal"; he acknowledged that Mr. Lopez's wife and three daughters wanted to return to Europe.
Mr. Smith stood before a room full of stunned reporters at the auto maker's headquarters; they had been invited to hear details of the 52-year-old executive's promotion. "It is not clear to me what his intentions are or where he is at this time," Mr. Smith said.
Harry Pearce, G.M.'s executive vice president and chief counsel, said he had telephoned Mr. Lopez at 10 A.M. "He sounded very upbeat," Mr. Pearce said of the man who was called "Inaki" by G.M. associates..
Antonette Simonetti, a G.M. public relations manager, said that she had talked to Mr. Lopez at about 11 A.M. today, discussing what he was going to say about his new job.
"He was fine," she said. "I am totally baffled and confused. He was going to say that this is a company that has passion and love, and if G.M. can channel those things to its customers, it will win."
The high-stakes bidding war for Mr. Lopez's services in some ways reflects how desperate both G.M. and VW have become to secure that rare executive who has a track record of performing high-level feats of financial and manufacturing derring-do.
Mr. Lopez succeeded during the last year where others had failed: saving G.M. hundreds of millions of dollars in costs and tearing up contracts with longtime suppliers who were believed to be inefficient.
Two months ago, VW came knocking. Mr. Smith tried personal diplomacy, calling Ferdinand Piech, the German auto maker's newly installed chief executive, to ask him to back off. Then, in early February, G.M. promoted Mr. Lopez to group executive in charge of worldwide purchasing, making him one of the auto maker's top dozen officers.
Executive power was not the only item on Mr. Lopez's wish list. "A major consideration for Inaki" was to build cars with fewer than 10 hours of labor per car, said Mr. Smith, compared with the 20 or so hours at even the most efficient plants. Mr. Lopez tried to persuade G.M. to build a new assembly plant, incorporating his theories, in his Basque homeland.
"We told him it was something we would do if we needed to build another car in Europe," Mr. Smith said. VW, which owns the Spanish automaker SEAT, apparently had made a similar promise, Mr. Smith said, although no auto maker is likely to build a new factory soon in Europe, where demand for vehicles is weakening in the midst of a recession..
Still, a VW commitment for a new plant may be announced on Tuesday.
The strange chain of events leading to Mr. Lopez's exit began on Wednesday, when he returned to Detroit from a European business trip. On his return, Mr. Smith said, he resigned.
On Thursday morning, Mr. Smith tried to persuade Mr. Lopez to stay, he said, offering him the top job in North American operations. It would have been an extraordinary promotion, vaulting him from purchasing chief to the No. 2 executive at G.M., in charge of everything from marketing and product planning to finance and research.
Opinion was divided among automotive analysts as to whether Mr. Smith went overboard to keep Mr. Lopez. One, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Mr. Lopez had proved his worth by virtue of G.M.'s improved financial results recently.
But another analyst, also speaking on condition of anonymity, said Mr. Lopez was manipulating the auto maker and he lacked expertise in areas like product development, marketing and dealer relations.
Outwardly, at any rate, it seemed to many that Mr. Lopez was auctioning his services to G.M. and VW.
At first, after he had resigned, "Inaki said no, there weren't going to be any negotiations," for a new G.M. job, Ms. Simonetti said. So. G.M. announced on Thursday that Mr. Lopez had resigned.
But that evening, about a dozen of Mr. Lopez's colleagues from G.M.'s purchasing department -- whom he often referred to as "my warriors" -- gathered at his home in Bloomfield Township, Mich., to commiserate, and to ask him to stay. "There were some sparks of hope; he agreed to talk to Jack Smith," Ms. Simonetti said.
Late Thursday and early Friday, Mr. Lopez's subordinates began calling Mr. Smith to see if he would welcome Mr. Lopez back. Mr. Smith, at the news conference today, confirmed that he had received about 10 telephone calls from employees.
On Friday morning, Mr. Lopez invited Mr. Smith, Mr. Pearce and G. Richard Wagoner Jr., the chief financial officer, to his home. He said he would stay at G.M. on two conditions: his family had to agree, and Mr. Piech had to agree to release him from his commitment to join VW. By Saturday, Ms. Simonetti said, both conditions were fulfilled.
If Mr. Piech actually released Mr. Lopez from his commitment, he did so reluctantly and with some obvious anger. On Saturday, Mr. Piech issued a statement saying that Mr. Lopez had agreed to "delay" joining VW for up to a year. He also accused G.M.'s board of trying to lure Mr. Lopez back.
But individuals close to G.M. directors, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the board played no role except to support Mr. Smith's actions.

PUB-DATE: March 16, 1993

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1689 words

HEADLINE: Revenge of the Righteous: Reform Comes to Capitol

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15

 BODY:
Nothing is sacred on Capitol Hill anymore. First perks were under attack, then pork became suspect. And now propaganda is getting a bad name.
Representative Porter J. Goss, Republican of Florida, has introduced a bill proposing that his colleagues be forced to pay cash for making extraneous comments in the Congressional Record, the official transcript of what is said in the House and Senate each day. 
 Denouncing what he calls runaway "propaganda" in the "Extensions of Remarks" section in the back of the Record, where lawmakers are allowed to tack on windy paeans to constituents and interest groups that were never delivered on the House floor, Mr. Goss suggests that members be charged $600 each time they add anything that does not pertain to legislative business.
 
Truffles of Privilege
 In the 103d Congress, righteousness is as fashionable as a dull red tie. An earnest freshman class, plus some zealous brethren from earlier classes, are submitting one bill after another intended to root out any remaining truffles of Congressional privilege and show that lawmakers know how to sacrifice, too.
Clinging to the notion that members of Congress deserve a bit of cushiness, some of the old-timers are grumbling that this year is shaping up to be the political version of "The Revenge of the Nerds." The marble halls that were once filled with the bonhomie of logrolling and backscratching are now bristling with goody-goody chic.
"If someone told them to cut their throats because it would be good for the economy, they're prepared to do it," said Representative Charles B. Rangel, the veteran Manhattan Democrat, complaining about the group of lawmakers christened "reformer wonks" by Norman Ornstein, an analyst with the American Enterprise Institute in Washington who focuses on Congress.
 
Victim of Streamlining
 "They have no idea," Mr. Rangel continued. "They're not checking with the leadership. They're just looking for clips for their newsletters. They're feeding on each others' enthusiasms. They have no plan, no strategy, no willingness to sit down and see what is really meaningful."
Mr. Rangel became disillusioned with the idea that "reform" was a magic word when, egged on by the Republicans and some Democrats in the freshman class, the House voted in January to start streamlining its operations by killing the select committees, including the one on Narcotics Abuse and Control that he headed.
In the Democratic cloakroom the other day, another senior Congressman reflected the paranoia in some quarters when he approached Representative Eric D. Fingerhut, a freshman from Cleveland who won office on a platform of cleaning up Congress. Mr. Fingerhut is now co-chairman of the Democratic New Members' Task Force on Reform.
"I hear you guys are going to take away our telephones," the older member groused to the 33-year-old newcomer, who offered reassurance that, while members of Congress might have to pay for their own parking some day, their long-distance calls were safe.
On the other hand, Representative Jim Nussle of Iowa, who has just been named chairman of the Republican House Reform Task Force, is jubilant at the reinforcements. Last year, as a 31-year-old freshman, Mr. Nussle wore a bag on his head on the House floor to dramatize his embarrassment about the House bank scandal. Though the bill died in committee last year, in the hands of lawmakers who had a hard time taking a man in a paper bag seriously, he says he plans to reintroduce it.
"Reform wasn't very popular last year," Mr. Nussle said. "Now, all of a sudden, everyone's a reformer. It's almost like, 'Can you top this?' "
Since Calvinist winds have swept through the Capitol before without much effect, except to increase the number of ethics committees exponentially, it is hard to say whether anything will really change. Ever since the news release was invented, politicians have used it to portray themselves as crusaders, even if they did not care about the particular virtue they were advocating.
Even those who support the idea of revamping Congress say there is a fair amount of showboating going on.
"The problem is that there are so few perks left there isn't really much for them to go after, but they promised their constituents that they would," said James Glassman, the editor of Roll Call, a weekly Capitol Hill newspaper. "So now we are beginning to see evidence that they are descending into triviality."
Consider the case of Representative Robert D. Inglis, a 33-year-old freshman Republican from South Carolina whose starched white shirt and close-cropped hair make him look more like an agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation than the paunchy, backslapping Southern Congressman of lore.
After the House banking scandal sent a shiver of rage through the country about special treatment for members of Congress, the leadership scurried to set a fee of $400 for the gymnasium. But increasing the fee into the vicinity of market value was not good enough for Mr. Inglis. He has sent the House Gym Association a check for $520 and a letter explaining that he had calculated the amount he would have to pay for a "nicer" health club in his Greenville, S. C., district, and hence would pay no less for the House gym.
 
Setting His Own Term Limit
 Perhaps the association is still puzzling over this uncommon bout of saintliness, because Mr. Inglis received no reply. Washington has not always been a place associated with virtue. Indeed, the city's career politicians have been more likely to evoke Aristotle's maxim that "there are some jobs in which it is impossible for a man to be virtuous."
"Some of the older members hope that this reform business is a phenomenon that will pass," said Mr. Inglis, who has set his own term limit of six years in the House. "But they are sadly mistaken. This train won't be stopped."
Unlike some of his more freewheeling colleagues, Mr. Fingerhut said he would use his frequent-flier miles to lower his travel expenses by buying more tickets to fly home to his district.
"You might laugh, but I feel very strongly about the ethics of frequent-flier miles," he said. "We bought these things with taxpayer dollars, and it's outrageous when people use them to go to Hawaii."
Representative Roscoe G. Bartlett, a freshman Republican from Maryland who lives within commuting distance of the Capitol, boasts that he has not yet submitted his first expense account, and hopes not to submit any. "I want to make a statement that it is not money that brought me here," he said. "I just want to serve the people."
Mr. Bartlett, a 66-year-old former college teacher who has a comfortable investment income, says he has given up half his $130,000 salary to set up scholarships for high school students in his western Maryland district, and has introduced a bill that would link Congressional pay to performance.
In a "Dear Colleague" letter, Mr. Bartlett urged "members to put their money where there [sic] mouth has been when it comes to cutting the deficit."
The bill would index the salaries of members to reductions in the Federal deficit. For every $100 billion in the deficit, Congressional salaries would be cut by 2 percent, and each year the percentage per $100 billion would double. But Mr. Bartlett did add a sweetener: "In the year the budget is balanced, all salaries will be doubled for that single year."
And then there is the attempt of Mr. Goss, the Florida Congressman, to tax colleagues who insert comments in the Congressional Record that are not relevant to the day's business.
With members of Congress, relevant is clearly a relative concept.
Take this entry in the March 4 Congressional Record from Representative Frank Pallone Jr., Democrat of New Jersey: "Mr. Speaker, on Sunday, March 7, 1993, in Red Bank, N. J., the Monmouth-Ocean County Council of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States of America will hold its annual Wyatt Earp Law Enforcement Day breakfast to honor their local law enforcement men of the year. . . . The annual event also honors the memory of two legendary Jewish law men, Marshall Wyatt Earp and former New York City Police Chief Jacob Hays."
Mr. Goss conceded that some of this season's "funny little bills" are intended not so much to save money, but to improve the credibility of Congress.
Credibility does not come cheap. Mr. Goss's two-page bill, for instance, costs about $500 a page to print.
Asked whether anyone might put in a bill to limit the time and money spent producing frivolous bills, Mr. Goss replied, "That's not a bad idea."
Perhaps the task will fall to Representative Spencer Bachus, a freshman Republican from Alabama who sent out photocopies of a news release proposing a 25 percent cut in all Government printing and reproduction.
Mr. Inglis, the South Carolina Congressman, has joined with a Democratic freshman, Representative Bart Stupak of Michigan, to introduce a bill to stop departing members from buying the furniture in their district offices at reduced prices.
As a news release from his office pointed out, with great umbrage, Mr. Inglis "was left with only a vinyl lime-green swivel chair in his Greenville, S. C., office." (Pictures of the chair are available upon request.)
Even with a spate of bills intended to rub some of the tarnish off Congress, Mr. Stupak said, he believed it will take a long time to improve the institution's abysmal image. "We'll start at some of the little things that have been nickel-and-diming us to death," the Congressman said. "Those are more repulsive to a lot of the public than expenditures like the huge military buildup."
Harking back to the image of Congress in its palmier, more prodigal days, Mr. Stupak said it is hard for him to identify with that era.
"You sure won't find the freshman class out drinking and philandering every night," he said, adding that he wants to make his mark in Washington "not by grabbing headlines or having an extra brewski with a colleague and slapping them on the back, but by hard work."
"We take the job seriously," he said. "Maybe too seriously."
